titleStmt.title: Syntax of the Moods and Tenses of the Greek Verb
titleStmt.author: William Watson Goodwin

div2.head: General View of the Moods.
div2.p: The Mood of a verb shows the manner in which the assertion of the verb is made.

The Greek verb has four moods, properly so called,—the indicative, the subjunctive, the optative, and the imperative. The infinitive, which is a verbal noun, and the participle and the verbal in -te/os, which are verbal adjectives, are so closely connected with the moods in many constructions, that they are discussed with them in Syntax.

The four proper moods, as opposed to the infinitive, are sometimes called the finite moods. The subjunctive, optative, imperative, and infinitive, as opposed to the indicative, are sometimes called the dependent moods.

div2.head: I. Indicative.
div2.p: The indicative, in its most primitive use, makes a simple, absolute assertion, or asks a question which includes or concerns such an assertion. e.g. *gra/fei, he is writing; e)/grafen, he was writing; e)/grayen, he wrote; gra/yei, he will write. *gra/fei;, is he writing? e)gra/yate;, did you write? gra/yete;, will you write? ti/ e)/grayen;, what did he write?

The indicative may also express (a)
A dependent statement (or quotation) of such an absolute assertion or question. e.g., *le/gei o(/ti gra/fei, he says that he is writing (he says gra/fw); le/gei o(/ti gra/yei, he says that he will write (he says gra/yw); e)rwta=| ti/ e)gra/yamen, he asks what we wrote; e)rwta=| ei) e)/graya, he asks whether I wrote. (b)
A distinct statement of an object aimed at or feared. e.g., *)epimelei=tai o(/pws tou=to genh/setai, he takes care that this shall be done (339); fobou/meqa mh\ a)mfote/rwn h(marth/kamen, we fear that we have missed both (369, 2). (c)
A distinct supposition of an absolute statement, that is, a supposition that such a statement is, was, or will be true. E.g., *ei) gra/fei, if he is writing; ei) e)/grayen, if he wrote; ei) ge/grafe, if he has written; ei) gra/yei, if he shall write or if he is to write. What is supposed in each case could be expressed by gra/fei, e)/grayen, ge/grafe, or gra/yei.
The past tenses of the indicative may, further, express a supposition that some statement either had been or were now true, while it is implied that really it was not or is not true. E.g.

*ei) e)/graya, if I had written; ei) e)/grafon, if I were now writing or if I had been writing; the context indicating that really I did not write or am not writing (410). These expressions originally always referred to the past, as they do in Homer.

Out of the form of unreal supposition (4) were developed after Homer the use of the past tenses of the indicative with ei)/qe or ei) ga/r in wishes (732); and also the Attic construction of the past tenses of the indicative to express an unaccomplished purpose (333), where there is an assimilation of the final clause to a preceding indicative. E.g. *ei) ga\r tou=to e)poi/hsa, O if I had only done this! *ei)/qe tou=to ei)=xes, O if you only had this!
*ei)/qe to/t' a)pe/qanon, i(/na mh\ tou=to e)/paqon, would that I had then perished, that I might not have suffered this.
For the indicative with a)/n or ke/, the potential indicative, see 243.

div2.head: II. Subjunctive.

list.label: (a)
(b)
list.item: Though this primitive use disappears in the later language, the subjunctive still remains closely related in sense to the future indicative, and in most of its constructions can be interchanged with it.

div2.p: The subjunctive in questions of appeal as to the future (287) has, even in Homer, developed the idea of propriety or expediency. E.g. *au)=qi me/nw h)=e qe/w; shall I remain here or run? Il. x. 62. So ph=| i)/w; whither shall I go? Od. xv. 509. But the future indicative can be used in the same sense; as ti/ dh=ta drw=men; mhte/r' h)= foneu/somen; what are we to do? shall we slay our mother? EUR. El. 967.(See 68.)

list.label: (a)
list.item: In exhortations and in prohibitions with mh/ (250, 259) the subjunctive has an imperative force, and is always future; as in i)/wmen, let us go; mh\ qauma/shte, do not wonder.

item.p: The future indicative occasionally occurs in prohibitions with mh/ (70).

list.label: (b)
list.item: The subjunctive with mh/, especially in Homer, may express a future object of fear with a desire to avert it; as in mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, may they not seize the ships (as I fear they will). (See 261.) From such expressions combined with verbs of fearing arose the dependent use of mh/ with the subjunctive expressing a future object of fear; as fobou=mai mh\ a)po/lhtai, I fear that he may perish.

div2.p: In the constructions with ou) mh/ (294) the subjunctive and the future indicative are used, without apparent distinction, in a future sense; as ou) mh\ ge/nhtai and ou) mh\ genh/setai, it will not happen.

The subjunctive may express a future purpose or a future object of care or exertion. E.g. *)/erxetai o(/pws tou=to i)/dh|, he comes that he may see this (317); e)pimelei=tai o(/pws tou=to ge/nhtai (or genh/setai), he takes care that this shall be done (339). In clauses of purpose the future indicative is sometimes used (324), and in the construction of 339 it became the regular Attic form.

In conditional clauses the subjunctive expresses either a future supposition (444), or a general supposition which is indefinite (never strictly present) in its time (462). (a)
In the former it supposes such a future case as the Homeric subjunctive (6) states; as e)a/n tis ei)/ph|, if one shall say (the thing supposed being ei)/ph| tis, one will say); here the future indicative may be used in essentially the same sense (447). In the general condition it supposes an event to occur at any time, as we say if any one ever goes or whoever goes, with an apodosis expressing repetition or a general truth; as e)a/n tis kle/yh| (or o(\s a)\n kle/yh|), kola/zetai, if any one steals (or whoever steals), he is always punished. (b)
The subjunctive in general suppositions is the only subjunctive which does not refer to future time, and here the future indicative can never be used. In most other languages (as in English and generally in Latin), and sometimes in Greek, such a condition is expressed by the present indicative, like an ordinary present supposition; but the Greek, in its desire to avoid a form denoting present time, generally fell into one which it uses elsewhere only for future time. The construction, however, appears in Homer imperfectly established, except in relative clauses (468): this indicates that it does not belong to the primitive uses of the subjunctive. (See 17.)
For the Homeric subjunctive with ke/ or a)/n in independent sentences, which does not differ perceptibly in meaning from the future with ke/ or a)/n, see 201, 1.

div2.head: III. Optative.
div2.p: The optative is commonly a less distinct and direct form of expression than the subjunctive, imperative, or indicative, in constructions of the same general character as those in which these moods are used.
This is seen especially in independent sentences, where the optative either expresses a wish or exhortation, or is used (regularly with a)/n or ke/) in a potential sense.

Thus i)/oimen, may we go, corresponds as a weaker form to i)/wmen, let us go. Corresponding to e)celqw/n tis i)de/tw, let some one go out and see, we have e)celqw/n tis i)/doi, may some one go out and see, Od. xxiv. 491 . *(/eloito a)/n, he would take or he might take, corresponds to the Homeric e(/lhtai or e(/lhtai/ ke, he will take or he may take (201, 1).

We find in Homer a few optatives expressing concession or permission, which have a neutral sense and can hardly be classed as either potential or wishing. See Il. iv. 17, ei) d' au)= pws to/de pa=si fi/lon kai\ h(du\ pe/loito, h)= toi me\n oi)ke/oito po/lis *pria/moio a)/naktos, au)=tis d' *)argei/hn *(ele/nhn *mene/laos a)/goito , where we may translate the apodosis either let the city still be a habitation and let M. carry away Helen, or the city may still be a habitation and M. may carry away Helen. In iii. 72 we have gunai=ka/ te oi)/kad' a)ge/sqw, and in iii. 255 tw=| de/ ke nikh/santi gunh\ kai\ kth/maq' e(/poito, where a)ge/sqw and e(/poito/ ke refer to essentially the same thing with a)/goito in iv. 19. Following Il. iii. 255(above) we have oi( d' a)/lloi nai/oimen *troi/hn, toi\ de\ ne/ontai, i. e. the rest of us may remain dwellers in Troy, while they will return to Greece. From such neutral future expressions were probably developed the two distinct uses of the optative. In its hortatory sense as a form of wishing, the optative was distinguished by the use of mh/ as a negative; while in its potential sense it had ou) as its negative (as in ou) mh\n ga/r ti kakw/teron a)/llo pa/qoimi, for really I can suffer nothing worse, Il. xix. 321), and it was soon further marked by the addition of ke/ or a)/n. (See Appendix I.)

In dependent clauses expressing purpose or the object of exertion or of fear, the optative is never an original form; but it always represents a dependent subjunctive or future indicative (8, b; 10) in the changed relation in which either of them is placed when its leading verb is changed from present or future to past time.

We represent this change in English by a change from may to might, or from shall or will to should or would; as e)/rxetai i(/na i)/dh|, he comes that he may see, h)=lqen i(/na i)/doi, he came that he might see; e)pimelei=tai o(/pws tou=to genh/setai, he takes care that this shall be done, e)pemelei=to o(/pws tou=to genh/soito, he took care that this should be done; fobei=tai mh\ tou=to pa/qh|, he fears that he may suffer this; e)fobh/qh mh\ tou=to pa/qoi, he feared that he might suffer this. Here the original subjunctive or future indicative (especially the latter) is very often used in place of the optative.

In all forms of indirect discourse the same principle (14) holds, that the optative after past tenses represents (in a changed relation) an indicative or a subjunctive of the direct form, which original mood is always used after present and future tenses, and may be retained after past tenses (667, 1).
In future conditions the optative expresses the supposition in a weakened future form, as compared with the stronger future of the subjunctive and the future indicative.

Compare e)a\n e)/lqw, if I (shall) go (444), with ei) e)/lqoimi, if I should go (455). Often the form of the leading sentence (the apodosis) decides whether a given supposition shall be expressed by a subjunctive or by an optative; thus in DEM. iv. 11 we have a)\n ou(=to/s ti pa/qh|, if anything happens (shall happen) to him (Philip), depending on poih/sete; and in the next sentence, referring to precisely the same contingency, we have ei)/ ti pa/qoi, depending on two optatives with a)/n.

The only remaining form of dependent optative is that found in past general suppositions, as ei)/ tis kle/yeien (or o(\s kle/yeien), e)kola/zeto, if ever any one stole (or whoever stole), he was (always) punished (462; 531).

Here the optative after a past tense represents an original subjunctive after a present tense (11), differing in this from the optative in future conditions (16), which is in an original construction. The late development of this optative appears from its almost total absence in protasis with ei) in Homer (468), where the corresponding subjunctive in protasis is also infrequent. It may therefore be disregarded in considering the primitive uses of the optative. (See 11 b.)
For a more full discussion of the relations of the optative to the other moods, see Appendix I.

div2.head: IV. Imperative.
div2.p: The imperative expresses a command, exhortation, entreaty, or prohibition (250 and 259). E.g. *feu=ge, begone! *)elqe/tw, let him come. *do/s moi tou=to, give me this. *mh\ poi/ei a)/dika, do not do what is unjust.

div2.head: The Tenses.
div2.p: There are seven Tenses,—the present, imperfect, perfect, pluperfect, aorist, future, and future perfect. The imperfect and pluperfect occur only in the indicative; the futures are wanting in the subjunctive and imperative.

These tenses may express two relations. They may designate the time of an action as present, past, or future; and also its character as going on, finished, or simply taking place. The latter relation is expressed by the tenses in all the moods and in the infinitive and the participle; the former is always expressed in the indicative, and to a certain extent (to be explained below) in the dependent moods and the participle.

The tenses are divided into primary tenses, which denote present or future time, and secondary or historical tenses, which denote past time. This distinction applies properly only to the tenses of the indicative; but it may be extended to any forms of the dependent moods which have the same distinction of time as the tenses of the indicative.

The primary tenses of the indicative are the present (in its ordinary uses), perfect, future, and future perfect. The secondary tenses are the imperfect, pluperfect, and aorist (in its ordinary uses).

This distinction will be more fully explained at the end of this chapter (165-191). It must be noted that the historic present (33) is a secondary tense, and the gnomic aorist (154) is a primary tense.

In speaking of the time denoted by any verb, we must distinguish between time which is present, past, or future with reference to the time of speaking or writing (that is, time absolutely present, etc.), and time which is present, past, or future with reference to the time of some verb with which the verbal form in question is connected (that is, time relatively present, etc.) Thus, when we say tou=to a)lhqe/s e)stin, this is true, e)sti/n is present with reference to the time of speaking; but when we say e)/fh tou=to a)lhqe\s ei)=nai or ei)=pen o(/ti tou=to a)lhqe/s e)stin (or ei)/h), he said that this was true, (i.e. he said “this is true”), the present tense which we use denotes time present to the time of the leading verb, i.e. time absolutely past and only relatively present. The same distinction is seen between the future in tou=to genh/setai, this will happen, and that in e)/fh tou=to genh/sesqai or ei)=pen o(/ti genh/setai (genh/soito), he said that this would happen; where the future in the first case is absolutely future, but in the other cases is only relatively future and may be even absolutely past. Again, in tou=to e)ge/neto, this happened, the aorist is absolutely past; but in e)/fh tou=to gene/sqai, or ei)=pen o(/ti tou=to e)ge/neto (or ge/noito), he said that this had happened, it denotes time past to the time of the past leading verb, and so is doubly past. But in connection with a future expression an aorist, though relatively past, may be absolutely future; as in PLAT. Rep. 478 D, to\ fane/n as subject of e)/sesqai means that which will hereafter have appeared. So diapraca/menos in 496 E. (See 143.)

It is a special distinction between the Greek and the English idioms, that the Greek uses its verbal forms much more freely to denote merely relative time. Thus, we translate the Greek presents ei)=nai and e)sti/ after e)/fh or ei)=pen (above) by our was; the futures genh/sesqai and genh/setai by would happen; and the aorists gene/sqai and e)ge/neto by had happened. This distinction appears especially in the indicative, optative, and infinitive of indirect discourse; in future forms after past tenses in final and object clauses with i(/na, o(/pws, etc.; and usually in the participle; but not in protasis.

div2.head: I. Tenses of the Indicative: Present.
div2.p: An important exception occurs when the present indicative in indirect discourse denotes time which is present relatively to the leading verb. See above, 22; 669, 2; 674, 1.

As the limits of such an action on either side of the present moment are not defined, the present may express a customary or repeated action or a general truth. E.g.
*(h pru/mna tou= ploi/ou o(\ ei)s *dh=lon *)aqhnai=oi pe/mpousin, the stern of the ship which the Athenians send to Delos (every year). PLAT. Phaed. 58A.
*ti/ktei toi ko/ros u(/brin, o(/tan kakw=| o)/lbos e(/phtai, satiety begets insolence, whenever prosperity follows the wicked. THEOG. 153.
*)en xro/nw| a)pofqi/nei to\ ta/rbos a)nqrw/poisin, in time timidity dies out in men. AESCH. Ag. 857.

The present denotes merely the continuance or progress of an action, without reference to its completion. It may, however, be implied by the context that the action is not to be completed, so that the present denotes an attempted or intended action. Especially di/dwmi, in the sense of offer, and pei/qw, try to persuade, are thus used. E.g.
*nu=n d' a(/ma t' au)ti/ka polla\ didoi=, he offers many things. Il. ix. 519.
*pei/qousi u(ma=s e)nanti/a kai\ toi=s no/mois kai\ tw=| dikai/w| yhfi/sasqai, they are trying to persuade you to vote contrary both to the laws and to justice. ISAE. i. 26.
This conative signification is much more common in the imperfect. See 36 and the examples.

The present is often used with expressions denoting past time, especially pa/lai, in the sense of a perfect and a present combined. E.g.
*kei=non i)xneu/w pa/lai, I have been tracking him a long time (and still continue it). SOPH. Aj. 20.
*ou) pa/lai soi le/gw o(/ti tau)to/n fhmi ei)=nai; i.e., have I not long ago told you (and do I not still repeat) that I call it the same thing? PLAT. Gorg. 489 C .
*qeou\s ai)tw= froura=s e)tei/as mh=kos AESCH. Ag. 1.
So polu\n xro/non tou=to poiw=. So in Latin, iam dudum loquor.

The presents h(/kw, I am come, and oi)/xomai, I am gone, are used in the sense of the perfect. An approach to the perfect sense is sometimes found in such presents as feu/gw, in the sense I am banished, a(li/skomai, I am captured, nikw= and kratw=, I am victorious, h(ttw=mai, I am conquered, a)dikw=, I have been unjust (I am a)/dikos). So the Epic i(/kw and i(ka/nw, with o)/llumai and sometimes ti/ktw in tragedy. E.g.
*oi)/xetai ei)s a(/la di=an, he is gone to the divine sea. Il. xv. 223.
*qemistoklh=s h(/kw para\ se/, I, Themistocles, am come to you. THUC. i. 137.
*tou\s a)di/kws feu/gontas dikai/ws kath/gagon, they justly restored those who were unjustly banished. PLAT. Menex. 242B.
*)ili/ou a(liskome/nou, after the capture of Ilium. THUC. vi. 2.
So a(liskome/nou tou= tei/xeos HDT. i. 85.
*(/opisqe th=s a)noigome/nhs qu/rhs, behind the open door. HDT. i. 9.
*ei) pa/nta tau=ta e)lumai/neto toi=s o(/lois, e(/ws a)ne/treye, ti/ *dhmosqe/nhs a)dikei=; how is Demosthenes to blame? DEM. xviii. 303.
*pu/rgwn o)llume/nwn e)n nausi\n e)/ban, I embarked after the towers had been destroyed. EUR. I.T. 1108.
*(/hde ti/ktei se, this woman is thy mother. Id. Ion. 1560.
Present participles are given in some examples here where they illustrate the meaning of the tense.

The Greek, like other languages, often uses such presents as I hear, I learn, I say, even when their action is finished before the time to which they strictly refer. E.g. *ei) stasia/zousin, w(/sper punqano/meqa, if they (the Sicilians) are in discord, as we learn. THUC. vi. 16.
*)epi\ po/leis, w(s e)gw\ a)koh=| ai)sqa/nomai, me/llomen i)e/nai mega/las, Id. vi. 20.

*ei)=mi as Future. The present ei)=mi, I am going, and its compounds, have a future sense. *ei)=mi thus became a future of e)/rxomai, the future e)leu/somai not being in good use in Attic prose. E.g.
*seu= u(/steros ei)=m' u(po\ gai=an, I shall go. Il. xviii. 333.
*ei)=mi pa/lin e)p' e)kei=na, I shall recur to that. PLAT. Phaed. 100B .
*)=w fi/l), e)gw\ me\n a)/peimi, su/as kai\ kei=na fula/cwn. Hom. Od. xvii. 593.
*)all' ei)/seimi, sou= d' ou) frontiw=, but I'll go in and not mind you. AR. Nub. 125.
*ei) d' ou(=toi a)pi/asin, h(mei=s mo/noi menou=men, but if they (shall) depart, we alone shall remain. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 24

In Homer ei)=mi is used also as a present; as oi(=os d' a)sth\r ei)=si met' a)stra/si, Il. xxii. 317. So ii. 87, Il. xi. 415; Od. iv. 401; and often in similes. This is doubtful in Attic; as in pro/seimi dw=ma kai\ bre/tas to\ so/n, AESCH. Eum. 242 , where pro/seimi may be pro/s + ei)mi/. See Krüger and Classen on e)pi/asin, THUC. iv. 61.

The future sense of ei)=mi and its compounds extends to the optative, infinitive, and participle in indirect discourse, and often to the participle in other uses (especially when it expresses purpose with w(s). E.g. *proei=pon o(/ti, ei) mh\ pareso/meqa sustrateuso/menoi, e)kei=noi e)f' h(ma=s i)/oien, i.e.that they would come against us. XEN. Hell. v. 2, 13 . See also v. 1, 34, where ei) mh\ a)pi/oien corresponds to ei) mh\ e)kpe/myoien. As i)/oimi in this use is equivalent to a future optative, it is naturally rare (128). *)apie/nai e)no/mizen o(/tan bou/lhtai, he believed he could depart (a)/peimi) whenever he pleased. THUC. v. 7. So
ou)k e)/fasan ( e)/fh ) i)e/nai, XEN. An. i. 3, 1 and 8; i. 4, 12: cf. ii. 1, 3, XEN. An. ii. 6 10.
*kai\ to\ pu=r ge au)= prosio/ntos tou= yuxrou= au)tw=| h)\ u(pecie/nai h)\ a)polei=sqai. PLAT. Phaed. 103D. (*prosio/ntos is an ordinary present participle: see 31.)
*ou) ga\r h)/|dein e)ciw/n, for he did not know that he was to go. AR. Pac. 1182.
*(o d' ei)s *pe/rsas i)w\n parh=n suneskeuasme/nos. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 26 .
*tau=t' ei)pw\n a)nista/mhn w(s a)piw/n. PLAT. Prot. 335 C (this might come under 31).
So a)nesth/kh w(s e)ciw/n, ib. 335 D.
*pareskeua/zeto w(s a)piou=sa. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 13
So THUC. vi. 63.

In the optative and infinitive not in indirect discourse, and often in the participle, the same forms of ei)=mi are used as ordinary presents. E.g.
*ou)de\n a)\n dia/foron poioi=, a)ll' e)pi\) tau)to\n i)/oien. PLAT. Rep. 360 C .
*ei) pole/mios i)/oi Ib. 415 E.
See i)/oi in Rep. 490B, in a peculiar indirect quotation. *(/ote i)/oi Id. Tim. 78C .
In XEN. An. i. 3,1, after i)e/nai as future (30), we have e)bia/zeto i)e/nai and h)/rcato proie/nai.
*)eco\n au)tw=| ei)sio/nti ei)s ta\s oi)ki/as suggi/gnesqai o(/tw| bou/loito. PLAT. Rep. 360 C .
*)apotrepo/menos o( a)h\r kai\ dia\ tou= sw/matos e)/cw i)w/n Id. Tim. 79C .
So ANT. v. 78, ANT. vi. 45.
In the subjunctive and imperative there can of course be no special future sense in these verbs.

In animated language the present often refers to the future, to express likelihood, intention, or danger. E.g.
*ei) au(/th h( po/lis lhfqh/setai, e)/xetai h( pa=sa *sikeli/a, if this city shall be captured, all Sicily is (at once) in their possession. THUC. vi. 91.
*me/nomen e(/ws a)\n e(/kastoi kata\ po/leis lhfqw=men; shall we wait until we are each captured, city by city? Id. vi. 77.
*ei) de/ fhsin ou(=tos, deica/tw kai\ parasxe/sqw, ka)gw\ katabai/nw, and I will take my seat. DEM. xix. 32.
So a)po/llumai, I am to perish, LYS. xii. 14. For a similar use of the perfect, see 51. (See also 61.)

(Historic Present.) The present is often used in narration for the aorist, sometimes for the imperfect, to give a more animated statement of past events. This is called the historic present. E.g.
*boulh\n e)pitexna=tai o(/pws mh\ a(lisqei=en *)aqhnai=oi, he contrives a plan to prevent the Athenians from assembling. HDT. i. 63.
*keleu/ei pe/myai a)/ndras: a)poste/llousin ou)=n, kai\ peri\ au)tw=n o( *qemistoklh=s kru/fa pe/mpei. THUC. i. 91.
*darei/ou kai\ *parusa/tidos gi/gnontai pai=des du/o XEN. AN. i. 1 .
*toiau=ta tou= paro/ntos h(ni/k' h(li/w| dei/knusi tou)/nar e)/kluon e)chgoume/nou SOPH. El. 424.
The historic present is not found in Homer.

div2.head: Imperfect.
div2.p: The imperfect represents an action as going on in past time; as e)/grafon, I was writing.

The imperfect is thus a present transferred to the past, retaining all the peculiarities of the present which are consistent with the change. Thus it may denote a customary or repeated action, or a series of actions; or, if it refers to a single action (as it very frequently does), it represents it in its progress rather than as a simple past occurrence (like the aorist). In narration it dwells on the course of an event instead of merely stating its occurrence. E.g.
*)epi\ *ke/kropos h( *)attikh\ kata\ po/leis w)|kei=to, kai\ ou) cunh/|esan bouleuso/menoi, a)ll' au)toi\ e(/kastoi e)politeu/onto kai\ e)bouleu/onto. *)epeidh\ de\ *qhseu\s e)basi/leusen, e)s th\n nu=n po/lin ou)=san cunw/|kise pa/ntas. THUC. ii. 15. (Here the imperfects refer to the state of the country or to customs; the aorists state events, e)basi/leuse, became king, cunw/|kise, collected into one state.)
*kai\ parasta\s o( me\n e)/nqen o( d' e)/nqen, e)bo/wn, e)ce/krouo/n me, teleutw=ntes e)xleu/azon: u(mei=s d' e)gela=te, kai\ ou)/t' a)kou/ein h)qe/lete ou)/te pisteu/ein e)bou/lesqe, they kept on shouting, etc.,and you laughed, etc. DEM. xix. 23.
*)epeirw/mhn ti le/gein tou/twn w(=n ei)s th\n bou/lhn a)ph/ggeila. Ibid.
*po/teron tau=ta pa/nta poiw=n h)di/kei kai\ parespo/ndei kai\ e)/lue th\n ei)rh/nhn h)\ ou)/; in doing all these things was he acting unjustly and breaking the peace, etc.? Id. xviii. 71 ; see also ib. 69. (Compare th\n ei)rh/nhn e)/luse ta\ ploi=a labw/n, of the event, ib. 73.)
*parelqw\n e)pi\ *qra/|khs *buzanti/ous h)ci/ou sumpolemei=n. Ib. 87.
*(umei=s ga\r tau=t' e)pra/ttete, kai\ tau=ta pa=sin u(mi=n h)/resken. (of a course of action) Id. xix. 189.
*)epeidh\ ga\r ei(=len *)/olunqon *fi/lippos, *)olu/mpia e)poi/ei, ei)s de\ th\n qusi/an pa/ntas tou\s texni/tas sunh/gagen. Ib. 192.
*ei)=ta to/t' ou)k e)/leges paraxrh=ma tau=ta ou)d' e)di/daskes h(ma=s; did you then not tell this at once on the spot, or instruct us? Ib. 25.
The same action (as in the last two examples) could easily have been mentioned, without reference to its continuance, as a mere event. For the relations of the imperfect to the aorist, see 56.

The imperfect, like the present (25), sometimes denotes attempted action, being here strictly an imperfect tense. So especially e)di/doun and e)/peiqon. E.g.
( *fi/lippos ) *(alo/nnhson e)di/dou, Philip offered Halonnesus (literally, tried to give it). AESCHIN. iii. 83.
*(/ekastos e)/peiqen au)to\n u(posth=nai th\n a)rxh/n, each one tried to persuade him to undertake the command. XEN. An. vi. 1, 19 .
*ku=ma i(/stat' a)eiro/menon, kata\ d' h(/|ree *phlei/wna, and was about to overpower the son of Peleus. Il. xxi. 327.
*)emisqou=to par' ou)k e)kdido/ntos th\n au)lh/n, he tried to hire the yard of one who refused to let it. HDT. i. 68.
*pe/myantes e)s *sa/rdis xruso\n w)ne/onto, they sent to Sardis and wanted to buy gold. HDT. i. 69.
*)epequ/mhse th=s xlani/dos, kai\ au)th\n proselqw\n w)ne/eto, he took a fancy (aor.) to the cloak, and tried to buy it. HDT. iii. 139.
*(\a e)pra/sseto ou)k e)ge/neto, what was attempted did not happen. THUC. vi. 74.
So proseti/qei, she wanted to add, AR. Nub. 63.

When the present has the force of the perfect (27), the imperfect has regularly the force of a pluperfect. E.g.
*(o o)/xlos kata\ qe/an h(=ken, the crowd had come to look on. THUC. vi. 31.
*)epei\ w)/|xeo nhi\ *pu/londe, after thou wast gone by ship to Pylos. Hom. Od. xvi. 24.

The imperfect sometimes denotes likelihood, intention, or danger in past time (see 32). E.g.
*)epeidh\ tw=| yeu/desqai a)pw/lluto, when he was on the point of ruin through his deceit. ANT. v. 37.
*kai\ ta)/m' e)/qnh|ske te/kn), a)pwllu/mhn d' e)gw/, and my children were about to die, and I was about to perish. EUR. H.F. 538.
*)ekaino/mhn ci/fei, I was to be slain, Id. I.T. 27.

The imperfect h)=n (generally with a)/ra) may express a fact which is just recognised as such by the speaker or writer, having previously been denied, overlooked, or not understood. E.g.
*)=w po/poi, ou)k a)/ra pa/nta noh/mones ou)de\ di/kaioi h)=san *faih/kwn h(gh/tores h)de\ me/dontes, i.e.they are not, as I once imagined. Od. xiii. 209.
*ou)k a)/ra mou=non e)/hn e)ri/dwn ge/nos, a)ll' e)pi\ gai=an ei)si\ du/w, there is not after all merely one race of discords, but there are two on earth. HES. Op. 11.
*(/od' h)=n a)/ra o( cullabw/n me, this is then the one who seized me. SOPH. Ph. 978.
*ou) su\ mo/nos a)/r' h)=sq' e)/poy; are you not then the only epops (as I thought)? AR. Av. 280.
*)=ar' ou) to/de h)=n to\ de/ndron, e)f' o(/per h)=ges h(ma=s; is not this then the tree to which you were bringing us? PLAT. Phaedrus 230 A
Other imperfects are rare; as h)pi/stw, XEN. Hell. iii. 4, 9 .

In like manner the imperfect may express something which is the result of a previous discussion, with reference to which the past form is used. This is sometimes called the philosophic imperfect. E.g.
*)=hn h( mousikh\ a)nti/strofos th=s gumnastikh=s, ei) me/mnhsai, music then (as we proved) corresponds, if you remember, to gymnastics. PLAT. Rep. 522A.
*kai\ di/kaion dh\ fh/somen a)/ndra ei)=nai tw=| au)tw=| tro/pw|, w(=|per kai\ po/lis h)=n dikai/a, and now we shall say that a man is just in the same way in which also a state was (shown to be) just. Ib. 441D.
*diafqerou=men e)kei=no, o(\ tw=| me\n dikai/w| be/ltion e)gi/gneto, tw=| de\ a)di/kw| a)pw/lluto, we shall destroy that which (as we proved) becomes better by justice and is ruined by injustice. PLAT. Crit. 47D.

The Greek sometimes uses an idiom like the English he was the one who did it for he is the one who did it; as h)=n o( th\n gnw/mhn tau/thn ei)pw\n *pei/sandros, THUC. viii. 68 ; ti/s h)=n o( bohqh/sas toi=s *buzanti/ois kai\ sw/sas au)tou/s; DEM. xviii. 88.

div2.head: Perfect and Pluperfect.
div2.p: The perfect represents an action as already finished at the present time; as ge/grafa, I have written (that is, my writing is now finished).
The pluperfect represents an action as already finished at a given past time; as e)gegra/fein, I had written (that is, my writing was finished at some specified past time).

The perfect, although it implies the performance of the action in past time, yet states only that it stands completed at the present time. This explains why the perfect is classed with the present as a primary tense, that is, as a tense of present time.

The perfect and the pluperfect may be expressed by the perfect participle with the present and imperfect of ei)mi/. Here, however, each part of the compound generally retains its own signification, so that this form expresses more fully the continuance of the result of the action of the perfect to the present time, and of that of the pluperfect to the past time referred to. E.g.
*pepoihkw/s e)stin (or h)=n), he is (or was) in the condition of having done,—he has done (or had done).
*)emou= oi( no/moi ou) mo/non a)pegnwko/tes ei)si\ mh\ a)dikei=n, a)lla\ kai\ kekeleuko/tes tau/thn th\n di/khn lamba/nein, it is the laws which not only have acquitted me of injustice, but have commanded me to inflict this punishment. LYS. i. 34.
*)eto/lma le/gein w(s e)gw\ to\ pra=gm' ei)mi\ tou=to dedrakw/s, he dared to say that I was the one who had done this deed. DEM. xxi. 104.
In DEM. xviii. 23, ou)/te ga\r h)=n presbei/a pro\s ou)de/na a)pestalme/nh to/te tw=n *(ellh/nwn means for there was no embassy then out on a mission to any of the Greeks; whereas a)pe/stalto would have given the meaning no embassy had ever been sent out (see 831).
This of course does not apply to cases where the compound form is the only one in use, as in the third person plural of the perfect and pluperfect passive and middle of mute and liquid verbs.

On the other hand, although the simple form very often implies the continuance of the result of the action down to the present time or to a specified past time, it does so less distinctly than the compound form, and not necessarily (see the last two examples below). E.g.
*)epimelw=s oi( qeoi\ w(=n oi( a)/nqrwpoi de/ontai kateskeua/kasin, the Gods have carefully provided what men need. XEN. Mem. iv. 3, 3 .
*tw=n poihtw=n tines u(poqh/kas w(s xrh\ zh=n kataleloi/pasin, some of the poets have left us suggestions how to live. ISOC. ii. 3.
*)akh/koa me\n tou)/noma, mnhmoneu/w d' ou)/, I have heard the name, but I do not remember it. PLAT. Theaet. 144 B.
*(/a soi tu/xh ke/xrhke, tau=t' a)fei/leto, Fortune has taken back what she has lent you. Men. Fr. 598.

*)/exw with the aorist and sometimes the perfect participle may form a periphrastic perfect (831). In tragedy and in Herodotus this is often fully equivalent to our perfect with "have"; elsewhere, especially in Attic prose, the participle and e)/xw are more or less distinct in their force. Still, this is the beginning of the modern perfect. E.g.
*poi/w| su\n e)/rgw| tou=t' a)peilh/sas e)/xeis; have you made this threat? SOPH. O. C. 817.
*to\n me\n proti/sas, to\n d' a)tima/sas e)/xei; Id. Ant. 22 ; see ib. 32.
*(hma=s pra=gos a)/skopon e)/xei pera/nas. Id. Aj. 21.
*hu)da=to ga\r tau=t', ou)de/ pw lh/cant' e)/xei, i.e. the story has not yet ceased to be told. Id. O. T. 731 ; see Id. Tr. 37, tarbh/sas' e)/xw.
*(/os sfe nu=n a)tima/sas e)/xei. EUR. Med. 33 ; see ib. 90.
*)/arews te moi=ran metalabw\n e)/xei tina/. Bacch. 302.
*sou= qauma/sas e)/xw to/de. SOPH. Ph. 1362 ; so PLAT. Phaedr. 257C (in poetic language).
*oi(=a/ moi bebouleukw\s e)/xei. SOPH. O. T. 701 (after sth/sas e)/xeis in 699).
*(/ostis g' e)/xei mou )carpa/sas to\ paidi/on, whoever has snatched away (though here e)/xei may mean keeps). AR. Th. 706.
*)egklh/|sas' e)/xei ta\ siti/a. Id. Eccl. 355.
*(upe\r tw=n *(ellh/nwn tou\s su\ doulw/sas e)/xeis, i.e. whom you hold in slavery or whom you have enslaved. HDT. i. 27.
*)amfote/rwn me tou/twn a)poklhi/sas e)/xeis. Id. i. 37 ; so i. 41.
*)alazo/ni e)pitre/yantes h(me/as au)tou\s e)/xomen, we have entrusted ourselves, etc. Id. vi. 12.
*polla\ xrh/mata e)/xomen a)nhrpako/tes. XEN. An. i. 3, 14 (here e)/xomen expresses possession). See THUC. i. 68; DEM. ix. 12, DEM. xxvii. 17.

The beginning of this usage appears in HES. Op. 42: --
*kru/yantes ga\r e)/xousi qeoi\ bi/on a)nqrw/poisi
.

*ei)=xon or e)/sxon with the participle may form a periphrastic pluperfect in the same way (47). E.g. *(/on g' ei)=xon h)/dh xro/nion e)kbeblhko/tes. SOPH. Ph. 600. See HDT. i. 28, 73, and 75; XEN. An. iv. 7, 1.
(b) The pluperfect of such verbs has the signification of the imperfect; as oi)=da, I know, h)/|dein, I knew.

In epistles, the perfect and aorist are sometimes used where we might expect the present, the writer transferring himself to the time of the reader. E.g.
*)ape/stalka/ soi to/nde to\n lo/gon, I send you this speech. ISOC. i. 2.
*met' *)artaba/zou, o(/n soi e)/pemya, pra=sse. THUC. i. 129. (Here o(\n e)/pemya refers to the man who was to carry the letter.) So scripsi and misi in Latin.

The perfect sometimes refers to the future, to denote certainty or likelihood that an action will immediately take place, in a sense similar to that of the present (32), but with more emphasis, as the change in time is greater. E.g.
*(/wst' ei)/ me to/cwn e)gkrath\s ai)sqh/setai, o)/lwla, I shall perish at once. SOPH. Ph. 75.
*ka)\n tou=to nikw=men, pa/nq' h(mi=n pepoi/htai. XEN. An. i. 8. 12 . So perii in Latin.

In a somewhat similar sense (51), the pluperfect may express the immediate or sudden occurrence of a past action. This occurs especially in Homer and Herodotus. E.g.
*ou)d' a)pi/qhsen mu/qw| *)aqhnai/hs: h( d' *ou)lumpo/nde bebh/kein, and she was gone to Olympus. Il. i. 221.
*(h me\n qambh/sasa pa/lin oi)ko/nde bebh/kein. Od. i. 360.
*to\n d' e)/lipe yuxh\, kata\ d' o)fqalmw=n ke/xut' a)xlu/s. Il. v. 696.
*)/alloi de\ h(gemo/nas e)/xontes w(rme/ato e)pi\ to\ i(ro/n, they were on their way (at once). HDT. viii. 35 ; see ix. 61.
For the gnomic perfect, see 154 and 155.

div2.head: Aorist.
div2.p: The aorist indicative expresses the simple occurrence of an action in past time; as e)/graya, I wrote.

This fundamental idea of simple occurrence remains the essential characteristic of the aorist through all the dependent moods, however indefinite they may be in regard to time. The aorist takes its name (a)o/ristos, unlimited, unqualified) from its thus denoting merely the occurrence of an action, without any of the limitations (o(/roi) as to completion, continuance, repetition, etc., which belong to other tenses. It corresponds to the ordinary preterite (e.g. did, went, said) in English, whereas the Greek imperfect corresponds generally to the forms I was doing, etc. Thus, e)poi/ei tou=to is he was doing this or he did this habitually; pepoi/hke tou=to is he has already done this; e)pepoih/kei tou=to is he had already (at some past time) done this; but e)poi/hse tou=to is simply he did this, without qualification of any kind.

The aorist of verbs which denote a state or condition generally expresses the entrance into that state or condition. E.g. *basileu/w, I am king, e)basi/leusa, I became king; a)/rxw, I hold office, h)=rca, I took office; ploutw=, e)plou/thsa, I became rich.
*th=| a)lhqei/a| sunw/|kei kai\ ou)de/pw kai\ th/meron a)pole/loipen: a)lla\ para\ zw=ntos *timokra/tous e)kei/nw| sunw/|khse, she was his wife in good faith, and has not yet even to this day been divorced; but she went to live with him from Timocrates while T. was still living. DEM. XXX. 33.

The aorist is distinguished from the imperfect by expressing only the occurrence of an action or the entrance into a state or condition, while the imperfect properly represents an action or state as going on or as repeated. See the examples of the imperfect and aorist in 35, and compare sunw/|kei and sunw/|khse in DEM. xxx. 33 (in 55). The aorist is therefore more common in rapid narration, the imperfect in detailed description. It must be remembered that the same event may be looked upon from different points of view by the same person; thus in DEM. xviii. 71 and 73 (quoted in 35) e)/lue th
 ei)rh/nhn and th
 ei)rh/nhn e)/luse refer to the same thing, once as an act in progress, and once as a fact accomplished. No amount of duration in an act, therefore, can make the aorist an improper form to express it, provided it is stated as a single past event viewed as a whole. Thus e)basi/leuse de/ka e)/th (see HDT. ii. 157) means he had a reign of ten years, (which is viewed as a single past event), while e)basi/leue de/ka e)/th might refer to the same reign in the sense he was reigning during ten years. The aorist may refer even to a series of repetitions; but it takes them collectively as a whole, while the imperfect would take them separately as individuals. See DEM. xviii. 80, meta\ tau=ta de\ tou\s a)posto/lous a(/pantas a)pe/steila , and afterwards I sent out all the naval armaments; and xviii. 60, a(\ me
 pro\ tou= politeu/esqai kai\ dhmhgorei=n e)me\ prou)/labe kai\ kate/sxe *fi/lippos , the (succession of) advantages which Philip secured during the period before I entered public life, emphatically opposed (as a whole) to Philip's many failures after that time, which are mentioned in a(\ de\ kai\ diekwlu/qh. If the orator had wished to dwell on the number of the advantages or failures, or on their duration, he could have used the imperfect. See the last example under 35.

Since the same event may thus be stated by the aorist or the imperfect according to the writer's point of view, it is natural that it should occasionally be a matter of indifference which form is used, especially when the action is of such a nature that it is not important to distinguish its duration from its occurrence. For example, this distinction can seldom be important in such expressions as he said, he commanded; and we find e)/legon and e)ke/leuon in the historians where no idea of duration can have been in mind. See oi( d' e)ke/leuo/n te e)pie/nai, kai\ parelqo/ntes oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)/legon toia/de, THUC. i. 72 , followed, at the end of the speech in 79, by toiau=ta de\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi ei)=pon and *)arxi/damos e)/lece toia/de. In such cases as the following (cited with others by Krüger) it was not important to the narrative whether the idea of duration was included in the expression or not: ba/lleto and ba/leto, Il. ii. 43 and 45; qh=ken and ti/qei, Il. xxiii. 653 and 656; dw=ke and di/dou, Il. vii. 303 and 305; e)/lipen and lei=pe, Il. ii. 106 and 107; compare also mi/stullon with e)/peiran, w)/pthsan, and e)ru/santo, Il. i. 465 and 466. In all these cases the fundamental distinction of the tenses, which was inherent in the form, remained; only it happened that either of the two distinct forms expressed the meaning which was here needed equally well. It must not be thought, from these occasional examples, that the Greeks of any period were not fully alive to the distinction of the two tenses and could not use it with skill and nicety. But the Greeks, like other workmen, did not care to use their finest tools on every occasion; and it is often necessary to remember this if we would avoid hair-splitting.

The aorist, expressing simply a past occurrence, is sometimes used where we should expect a perfect or pluperfect, the action being merely referred to the past without the more exact specification which these tenses would give. E.g.
*tw=n oi)ketw=n ou)de/na kate/lipen, a)ll' a(/panta pe/praken, he (has) left none of the servants, but has sold everything. AESCHIN. i. 99.
*)etra/ponto e)s to\n *pa/normon, o(/qenper a)nhga/gonto, they turned towards Panormus, whence they (had) set sail. THUC. ii. 92.
*ku=ron de\ metape/mpetai a)po\ th=s a)rxh=s h(=s au)to\n satra/phn e)poi/hsen, from the dominion of which he (had once) made him satrap. XEN. An. i. 1,2 .

The aorist is generally used with e)pei/ or e)peidh/, after that, the aorist with the particle being equivalent to our pluperfect. So after e(/ws and pri/n, until. E.g.
*)epeidh\ e)teleu/thse *darei=os kai\ kate/sth *)artace/rchs, after Darius (had) died and Artaxerxes had become established. XEN. An. i. 1, 3.
*ou) pro/sqen e)cenegkei=n e)to/lmhsan pro\s h(ma=s po/lemon pri\n tou\s strathgou\s h(mw=n sune/labon, they did not dare to bring war upon us until they (had) seized our generals.
Ib. iii. 2, 29.
But the pluperfect may still be used after e)pei/ or e)peidh/, to give additional emphasis to the doubly past action; as in DEM. xviii. 42, e)peidh\ e)chpa/thsqe me\n u(mei=s, e)chpa/thnto de\ oi( *fwkei=s kai\ a)nh/|rhnto ai( po/leis, ti/ e)ge/neto;
So in Latin we have generally postquam venit, but occasionally postquam venerat.

The aorist is sometimes used colloquially by the poets (especially the dramatists), when a sudden action, which is just taking place, is spoken of as if it had already happened. E.g.
*)eph/|nes' e)/rgon kai\ pro/noian h(\n e)/qou, I must approve your act, etc. SOPH. Aj. 536.
*(/hsqhn a)peilai=s, e)ge/lasa yolokompi/ais, I am amused by your threats, I cannot help laughing, etc. AR. Eq. 696.

The aorist sometimes refers vividly to the future, like the present (32) or perfect (51); as a)pwlo/mhn ei)/ me lei/yeis, I perish if you leave me. EUR. Alc. 386 : so EUR. Med. 78. See also w)/leto, Il. ix. 413 and 415.

In questions with ti/ ou), expressing surprise that something is not already done, and implying an exhortation to do it, the aorist is sometimes used strangely like a future. E.g.
*ti/ ou)=n ou) dihgh/sw h(mi=n th\n cunousi/an; why then don't you tell us about the meeting? PLAT. Prot. 310A.
*ti/ ou)=n ou) kai\ *pro/dikon kai\ *(ippi/an e)kale/samen; why then don't we call Prodicus and Hippias too? Ib. 317D.
So ti/ ou)=n ou) . . . e)ske/yw;
Soph. 251 E.
See also SOPH. O. T. 1003.
For the gnomic aorist see 154.

div2.head: Future.
div2.p: The future denotes that an action is to take place in time to come; as gra/yw, I shall write or I shall be writing, sometimes I will write; pei/setai, he will suffer, sometimes he shall suffer.
In indirect discourse and in all final constructions the future expresses time future relatively to the leading verb. See 22.

The future may represent an action in its duration, its mere occurrence, or its inception; as e(/cw, I shall have, or I shall obtain; tou=to dw/sw, I shall give this; a)/rcw, I shall rule, or I shall obtain power (cf. 55). E.g.
*pragmateu/ontai o(/pws a)/rcousin, they take trouble to gain power. XEN. Rep. Lac. xiv. 5.
*)=ar' ou) (diairete/on) oi(/tines a)/rcousi/n te kai\ a)/rcontai; must we not distinguish between those who are to rule and those who are to be ruled? PLAT. Rep. 412B.
*ph=| stasia/sousin oi( e)pi/kouroi kai\ oi( a)/rxontes; how will they fall into faction? Ib. 545D (see below, o(/pws dh\ prw=ton sta/sis e)/mpese).

The future may be used in a gnomic sense, denoting that something will always happen when an occasion offers. E.g. *)anh\r o( feu/gwn kai\ pa/lin maxh/setai. MEN. Mon. 45.
“He that fights and runs away may turn and fight another day.”

The future is sometimes used to express what will hereafter be proved or be recognised as a truth. Compare the use of the imperfect in 40. E.g. *filo/sofos h(mi=n e)/stai o( me/llwn kalo\s ka)gaqo\s e)/sesqai fu/lac, he will prove to be a philosopher. PLAT. Rep. 376 C .

The future is sometimes used in questions of doubt, where the subjunctive is more common (287). E.g.
*ti/ dh=ta drw=men; mhte/r' h)= foneu/somen; what shall we do? shall we kill our mother? EUR. El. 967 : so EUR. Ion. 758.
*poi= tre/yomai; whither shall I turn? Id. Hipp. 1066.
*ei)=t e)gw/ sou fei/somai; AR. Ach. 312.
*ti/ ou)=n poih/somen; po/teron ei)s th\n po/lin pa/ntas tou/tous paradeco/meqa; what then shall we do? Are we to receive all these into the state? PLAT. Rep. 397D

The second person of the future may express a concession or permission; and it often expresses a command, like the imperative. E.g.
*pro\s tau=ta pra/ceis oi(=on a)\n qe/lh|s, you may act as you please. SOPH. O. C. 956.
*pa/ntws de\ tou=to dra/seis, but by all means do this. AR. Nub. 1352. So in the common imprecations, a)polei=sqe, oi)mw/cesqe, may you perish, etc.
*xeiri\ d' ou) yau/seis pote/. EUR. Med. 1320.
Compare the Latin facies ut sciam, let me know; abibis, depart.

In a few instances the future indicative with mh/ expresses a prohibition, like the imperative or subjunctive with mh/ (259). E.g.
*tau/thn, a)/n moi xrh=sqe sumbou/lw|, fula/cete th
 pi/stin pro\s tou=ton to
 *qra=|ka, kai\ mh\ boulh/sesqe ei)de/nai, k.t.l., if you follow my advice, hold fast to this security (69) , and do not wish to know, etc. DEM. xxiii. 117.
*)ea
 de\ eu)= fronh=te, kai\ nuni\ tou=to fanero
 poih/sete, kai\ mhdemi/an au)toi=s a)/deian dw/sete. LYS. xxix. 13.
*ce/non a)dikh/seis mhde/pote kairo
 labw/n. MEN. Mon. 397.
So probably ou) si=ga; mhde
 tw=nd' e)rei=s kata\ pto/lin, silence! say nothing of all this in the city. AESCH. Sept. 250. (See 279.)

The future sometimes denotes a present intention, expectation, or necessity that something shall be done, in which sense the periphrastic form with me/llw (73) is more common. E.g.
*ti/ diafe/rousi tw=n e)c a)na/gkhs kakopaqou/ntwn, ei)/ ge peinh/sousi kai\ diyh/sousi kai\ r(igh/sousi kai\ a)grupnh/sousi; if they are to endure hunger and thirst, etc. XEN. Mem. ii. 1, 17 . (Here ei) me/llousi peinh=n kai\ diyh=n, etc., would be more common, as in the last example under 73.)
*ai)=re plh=ktron, ei) maxei=, raise your spur, if you are going to fight. AR. Av. 759.
The distinction between this and the ordinary future (63) is important in conditional sentences (see 407).

A still more emphatic reference to a present intention is found in the question ti/ le/ceis; what do you mean to say? often found in tragedy; as w)/moi, ti/ le/ceis; h)= ga\r e)ggu/s e)sti/ pou; EUR. Hec. 1124. So EUR. Hec. 511, EUR. Hec. 712; EUR. Hipp. 353; EUR. Ion. 1113; SOPH. Ph. 1233.
For the future in protasis, see 447 and 407; in relative clauses expressing a purpose, 565; with a)/n, 196; with ou) mh/, 294-301.

(*me/llw, with the Infinitive.) A periphrastic future is formed by me/llw and the present or future (seldom the aorist) infinitive. This form sometimes denotes mere futurity, and sometimes intention, expectation, or necessity. E.g. *me/llei tou=to pra/ttein (or pra/cein), he is about to do this, or he intends to do this. So in Latin, facturus est for faciet.
*me/llw u(ma=s dida/cein o(/qen moi h( diabolh\ ge/gone. PLAT. Ap. 21B.
*ou)kou=n deh/sei tou= toiou/tou tino\s a)ei\ e)pista/tou, ei) me/llei h( politei/a sw/|zesqai; if the constitution is to be preserved. PLAT. Rep. 412A . (See 71.)

Although the present and the future infinitive were preferred with me/llw (73), the aorist was still used by some writers, as by Euripides. See
AESCH. Prom. 625 me/llw paqei=n ;
EUR. Ion. 80 me/llw tuxei=n ,
EUR. Ion. 760 qanei=n me/llw ,
EUR. El. 17 me/llonta qanei=n ,
Phoen. 300 me/lleis qigei=n ;& mdash; where the metre allows no change.
The future infinitive with me/llw forms the only regular exception to the general principle which restricts the use of the future infinitive to indirect discourse (see 86; 112).

The imperfect (seldom the aorist) of me/llw with the infinitive expresses past intention, expectation, or necessity. E.g.
*ku/klwy, ou)k a)/r' e)/melles a)na/lkidos a)ndro\s e(tai/rous e)/dmenai e)n sph=i glafurw=|, so you were not after all to eat, etc. (cf. 39). Od. ix. 475. See Il. ii. 36.
*)/emello/n s' a)=ra kinh/sein e)gw/, I thought I should start you off. AR. Nub. 1301.
*)epista/thn labei=n, o(\s e)/mellen au)tw\ kalw/ te ka)gaqw\ poih/sein PLAT. Ap. 20A.
*)eme/llhsan e)mba/llein THUC. i. 134.

div2.head: Future Perfect.
div2.p:
The future perfect denotes that an action will be already finished at some future time. It is thus a perfect transferred to the future. E.g.
*kai/ me e)a\n e)cele/gch|s, ou)k a)xqesqh/somai/ soi, a)lla\ me/gistos eu)erge/ths par' e)moi\ a)nagegra/yei, you will have been enrolled as my greatest benefactor. PLAT. Gorg. 506 C
*)\hn de\ mh\ ge/nhtai, ma/thn e)moi\ keklau/setai, su\ d' e)gxanw\n teqnh/ceis, I shall then have had my whippings for nothing, and you will have died grinning. AR. Nub. 1435.

The future perfect often denotes the continuance of an action, or the permanence of its results, in future time. E.g. *du/namin, h(=s e)s a)i/dion toi=s e)pigignome/nois mnh/mh katalelei/yetai, power, the memory of which will be left to our posterity for ever. THUC. ii. 64. (Compare 105.)

The future perfect sometimes denotes certainty or likelihood that an action will immediately take place, which idea is still more vividly expressed by the perfect (51). E.g.
*ei) de\ parelqw\n ei(=s o(stisou=n du/naito dida/cai, pa=s o( parw\n fo/bos lelu/setai, all the present fear will be at once dispelled. DEM. xiv. 2. (Here the inferior Mss. have le/lutai, which would be like o)/lwla, quoted in 51.)
*fra/ze, kai\ pepra/cetai, speak, and it shall be no sooner said than done. AR. Plut. 1027.
*eu)qu\s *)ariai=os a)festh/cei, w(/ste fi/los h(mi=n ou)dei\s lelei/yetai XEN. An. ii. 4, 5 .

The future perfect can be expressed by the perfect participle and e)/somai. In the active voice this is the only form in use, except in a few cases (chiefly e(sth/cw and teqnh/cw). E.g. *)\an tau=t' ei)dw=men, kai\ ta\ de/onta e)so/meqa e)gnwko/tes kai\ lo/gwn matai/wn a)phllagme/noi, we shall have already resolved to do our duty and shall have been freed from vain reports. DEM. iv. 50. (See 45 and 831.)

A similar circumlocution with the aorist participle and e)/somai is sometimes found, especially in the poets. E.g.
*ou) siwph/sas e)/sei; SOPH. O.T. 1146.
*luphqei\s e)/sei. SOPH. OC 816.
(See 47 and 831.)
When the perfect is used in the sense of a present (49), the future perfect is its regular future; as keklh/somai, memnh/somai, a)festh/cw, I shall be named, I shall remember, I shall withdraw, etc.

In many other verbs, the future perfect differs very slightly, if at all, from an ordinary future. Thus pepra/somai is the regular future passive of pipra/skw. Still, where there is another future, the future perfect is generally more emphatic.

It must be remembered that, in most cases in which the Latin or the English would use a future perfect in a dependent clause, the Greek uses an aorist or even a perfect subjunctive. (See 90 and 103, with the examples.)

div2.head: II. Tenses of the Dependent Moods.
div2.p: The distinctions of time which mark the various tenses in the indicative are retained when the optative and infinitive represent the indicative in indirect discourse, and usually in the participle. But in other constructions these distinctions of time disappear in the dependent moods, and the tenses here differ only in their other character of denoting the continuance, the completion, or simply the occurrence of an action (20). The infinitive with a)/n is not included in this statement (see Chap. III.)
The tenses in these two uses must, therefore, be discussed separately.

div2.head: Not in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: In the subjunctive and imperative, and also in the optative and infinitive not in indirect discourse (666; 684), the tenses chiefly used are the present and the aorist. The perfect is used here only when the completion of the action is to be emphasized (see 102-110). For the occasional future, see 111-113; 130-132.

div2.head: Present and Aorist.
div2.p: This is a distinction entirely unknown to the Latin, which has (for example) only one form, si faciat, corresponding to ei) poioi/h and ei) poih/seien, and only facere to correspond to both poiei=n and poih=sai (as used above).

It is sometimes difficult here, as in the corresponding case of the imperfect and the aorist indicative (56; 57), to see any decisive reason for preferring one tense to the other; and it can hardly be doubted that the Greeks occasionally failed to make use of this, as well as of other fine distinctions, when either form would express the required sense equally well, although they always had the distinction ready for use when it was needed. Compare the present and the aorist subjunctive and optative in the following examples:—
*)ea
 ga/r ti/ se fanw= kako
 pepoihkw\s, o(mologw= a)dikei=n: e)a
 me/ntoi mhde
 fai/nwmai kako
 pepoihkw\s mhde\ boulhqei\s, ou) kai\ su\ o(mologh/seis mhde
 u(p' e)mou= a)dikei=sqai; if I shall appear (aorist) to have done you any wrong, and if I shall appear (present) to have done you no wrong. XEN. Cyr. v. 5, 13.
*ei) me
 ga prosde/caito *fwke/as summa/xous . . . ei) de\ mh\ prosde/xoito, k.t.l. DEM. xix. 318.
*ei)/ tines pollw=n qana/twn h)=san ai)/tioi, ( i(/na ) pa/ntwn tou/twn dekaplasi/as a)lghdo/nas u(pe e(ka/stou komi/sainto, kai\ au)= ei)/ tines eu)ergesi/as eu)ergethko/tes ei)=en, ( i(/na ) kata\ tau)ta\ th
 a)ci/an komi/zointo, if any had caused many deaths, that they might receive (aorist) suffering for all these, tenfold for each; and again, if they had done kind services to any, that they might in like manner receive (present) their due reward. PLAT. Rep. 615B.
In the last example, it is obvious that the change from komi/sainto to komi/zointo is connected with the change from ei) h)=san to ei) eu)ergethko/tes ei)=en; but it is questionable whether the latter change is the cause or the effect, and it is also quite as hard to see the reason for this change in the protasis, when both conditions are equally general, as for that in the final clause. Probably no two scholars would agree in the reasons which they might assign for the use of the tenses in these examples. It is certain, however, that either present or aorist would express the meaning equally well in all these cases.

div2.head: Subjunctive and Imperative.
div2.p:
The present and aorist subjunctive and imperative are always future, except that in general conditions (462; 532) the subjunctive is general in its time. In all final constructions the subjunctive is future relatively to the leading verb. The following examples will show the distinction of the two tenses:—
*peiqw/meqa pa/ntes: feu/gwmen su\n nhusi\ fi/lhn e)s patri/da gai=an, let us all be persuaded; let us fly, etc. Il. ii. 139.
*ti/ fw=; ti/ drw=; what shall I say? what shall I do?
*pw=s ou)=n peri\ tou/twn poiw=men; how then shall we act about this? PLAT. Phil. 63a
*)analogisw/meqa ta\ w(mologhme/na h(mi=n, let us enumerate the points which have been conceded by us. PLAT. Prot. 332D.
*mhde\n fobhqh=|s, fear not. But mhde\n fobou=, be not timid.
*ti/ poih/sw; what shall I do (in this case)? But ti/ poiw=; what shall I do (generally)?
*ou) mh\ tou=to ei)/ph|s, you shall not say this.
*ou) mh\ ge/nhtai, it will not happen.
So in the Homeric ou)de\ i)/dwmai, nor shall I ever see (6).
*)\an de/ tis a)nqisth=tai, peiraso/meqa xeirou=sqai, but if any one shall stand opposed to us, we will try to subdue him. XEN. An. vii. 3, 11 .
*ka)\n po/lemos h)=|, e(/ws a)\n e)p' a)/llon e)/xwmen strateu/esqai, sou= te kai\ tw=n sw=n a)feco/meqa, and if there shall be war, so long as we shall be able, etc. XEN. Hell. iv. 1, 38
*)all' h(=| a)\n gignw/skw be/ltista e)rw=, but I will speak as I shall think best. THUC. vi. 9.
*ou(\s a)\n bou/lh| poih/sasqai fi/lous, a)gaqo/n ti le/ge peri\ au)tw=n pro\s tou\s a)pagge/llontas, whomsoever you shall wish, etc. ISOC. i. 33.
*(/apas lo/gos, a)\n a)ph=| ta\ pra/gmata, ma/taio/n ti fai/netai kai\ keno/n, all speech, if (wherever) deeds are wanting, appears vain and empty. DEM. ii. 12.
*summaxei=n tou/tois e)qe/lousin a(/pantes, ou(\s a)\n o(rw=si pareskeuasme/nous, all are willing to be allied to those whom they see prepared. DEM. iv. 6.
*(ws a)\n ei)/pw peiqw/meqa, let us obey as I shall direct. Il. ix. 704.
*)\hn e)ggu\s e)/lqh| qa/natos, ou)dei\s bou/letai qnh/|skein, if death comes near (the moment that death comes near), no one wants to die. EUR. Alc. 671.
*)\hn th\n ei)rh/nhn poihsw/meqa, meta\ pollh=s a)sfalei/as th\n po/lin oi)kh/somen, if we (shall) make the peace, etc. ISOC. viii. 20.
*(\on me\n a)\n i)/dh| a)gnw=ta (sc. o( ku/wn), xalepai/nei: o(\n d' a)\n gnw/rimon (sc. i)/dh|); a)spa/zetai, i.e. whomsoever the dog sees (at any time), etc. PLAT. Rep. 376A.
*dokei= moi katakau=sai ta\s a(ma/cas, i(/na mh\ ta\ zeu/gh h(mw=n strathgh=|, a)lla\ poreuw/meqa o(/ph| a)\n th=| stratia=| sumfe/rh|, it seems good to me to burn the wagons, that our beasts of burden may not be our generals, and that we may go on whithersoever it may be best for the army. XEN. An. iii. 2, 27.
*kai\ ga\r basileu\s ai(rei=tai, ou)x i(/na e(autou= kalw=s e)pimelh=tai, a)ll' i(/na kai\ oi( e(lo/menoi di) au)to\n eu)= pra/ttwsi XEN. Mem. iii. 2, 3.
*de/doika mh\ e)pilaqw/meqa th=s oi)/kade o(dou=, I fear lest we may forget the road home. XEN. An. iii. 2, 25.
*dianoei=tai au)th\n lu=sai, w(s mh\ diabh=te a)ll' a)polhfqh=te, he intends to destroy the bridge, that you may not pass over but be caught.
Ib. ii. 4, 17 .
*feu=ge, begone;
xairo/ntwn, let them rejoice;
mh\ nomi/zete, do not believe.
*ei)pe/ moi, tell me;
do/te moi tou=to, give me this.
*sfendo/nhn ti/s moi do/tw, let some one give me a sling. AR. AV. 1187.

When the aorist subjunctive depends on e)peida/n (or e)pa/n, e)ph/n), after that, it is referred by this meaning of the particle to time preceding the action of the leading verb, so that e)peida\n tou=to i)/dw, h(/cw means after I (shall) have seen this, I will come; and e)peida\n tou=to i)dw, a)pe/rxomai, after I have seen this, I (always) depart. In such cases it may be translated by our future perfect when the leading verb is future, and by our perfect when the leading verb denotes a general truth and is translated by the present. As the subjunctive here can never depend upon a verb of simply present time, it can never refer to time absolutely past; and we use the perfect indicative in translating such an aorist after a verb expressing a general truth, merely because we use the present in translating the leading verb, although this is properly not present but general in its time.

In like manner, after e(/ws, pri/n, and other particles signifying until, before that, and even after the relative pronoun or e)a/n, the aorist subjunctive may be translated by our future perfect or perfect, when the context shows that it refers to time preceding that of the leading verb. E.g.
*xrh\ de\, o(/tan me
 tiqh=sqe tou\s no/mous, o(poi=oi/ tine/s ei)si skopei=n, e)peida
 de\ qh=sqe, fula/ttein kai\ xrh=sqai, while you are enacting laws, you must look to see of what kind they are; but after you have enacted them, you must guard and use them. DEM. xxi. 34. (Here the present tiqh=sqe with o(/tan, while, refers to an action continuing through the time of the leading verb; but qh=sqe with e)peida/n, after that, refers to time past relatively to the leading verb.)
*tau=ta, e)peida
 peri\ tou= ge/nous ei)/pw, to/te, a)
 bou/lhsqe a)kou/ein, e)rw=, when I shall have spoken about my birth, then, if you desire to hear, I will speak of these things. DEM. lvii. 16 . (Here the aorist ei)/pw, though absolutely future, denotes time past with reference to e)rw=.)
*)epeida
 diapra/cwmai a(\ de/omai, h(/cw, when I shall have accomplished what I desire, I will come. XEN. An. ii. 3, 29.
*)epeida
 de\ kru/ywsi gh=|, a)nh h(|rhme/nos u(po\ th=s po/lews le/gei e)p' au)toi=s e)/painon to
 pre/ponta, when they have covered them with earth, etc. THUC. ii. 34.
*(/ews a)
 sw/|zhtai to\ ska/fos, to/te xrh\ proqu/mous ei)=nai: e)peida
 de\ h( qa/latta u(pe/rsxh|, ma/taios h( spoudh/, as long as the vessel remains in safety (present); but the moment that the sea has overwhelmed it (aorist). DEM. ix. 69.
*(/ews a)
 e)kma/qh|s, e)/x' e)lpi/da, until you have learnt fully, have hope. SOPH. OT 834.
*mi/a de\ kli/nh kenh\ fe/retai tw=n a)fanw=n, oi(\ a)
 mh\ eu(reqw=sin e)s a)nai/resin, and one bier is always carried empty, in honour of the missing, whose bodies are not (have not been) found. THUC. ii. 34.
*dianoei=tai, a(\ a)
 a)/lloi th=| a)reth=| katapra/cwsi, tou/twn i)somoirei=n; i.e. he thinks of having an equal share in those things which others by their valour have acquired? XEN. Cyr. ii. 3, 5
*pa/nq' o(/s' a)
 e)k pole/mou gignome/nhs ei)rh/nhs proeqh=|, tau=ta toi=s a)melh/sasin a)po/llutai, all things which are (or have been)abandoned when peace is made are always lost to those who abandoned them. DEM. xix. 151.
*)\hn d' a)/ra kai/ tou pei/ra| sfalw=sin, a)ntelpi/santes a)/lla e)plh/rwsan th
 xrei/an, if they have been disappointed in anything, they always supply the deficiency, etc. (154 and 171). THUC. i. 70.
*ou)xi\ pau/somai, pri
 a)/n se tw=n sw=n ku/rion sth/sw te/knwn, I will not cease before I have (shall have) made you master of your children. SOPH. OC 1040.
*mh\ ste/naze pri
 ma/qh|s, do not groan until you have heard. SOPH. Ph. 917.

This use of the aorist subjunctive (90) sometimes seems to approach very near to that of the perfect subjunctive (103); and we often translate both by the same tense. But in the perfect, the idea of an action completed at the time referred to is expressed by the tense of the verb, without aid from any particle or from the context; in the aorist, the idea of relative past time can come only from the particle or the context. (See 103 with examples, and 104.) The Greek often uses the less precise aorist subjunctive and optative (see 95) where the perfect would be preferred but for its cumbrous forms; and we sometimes give the aorist more precision than really belongs to it in itself by translating it as a perfect or future perfect. (See the last six examples under 90.) The following example illustrates the distinction between the perfect and aorist subjunctive:—

*(\on me
 a)
 i)/dh| a)gnw=ta ( o( ku/wn ), xalepai/nei: o(
 d' a)
 gnw/rimon ( i)/dh| ), a)spa/zetai, ka)
 mhde
 pw/pote u(p au)tou= a)gaqo
 pepo/nqh|, whomsoever he sees whom he knows, he fawns upon, even if he has hitherto received no kindness from him. PLAT. Rep. 376A. Compare this with e)a
 a)gaqo/n ti pa/qh| u(po/ tinos, a)spa/zetai, if he ever happens to receive any kindness from any one, he always fawns upon him; and e)peida
 a)gaqo/n ti pa/qh|, a)spa/zetai, after he has received any kindness, he always fawns upon him.

The present subjunctive with mh/ or o(/pws mh/ after verbs of fearing, though it generally refers to a future object of fear, may also denote what may hereafter prove to be an object of fear. E.g.
*de/doika mh\ a)lhqe\s h)=|, I fear it may prove true. DEM. ix. 1.
*deinw=s a)qumw=, mh\ ble/pwn o( ma/ntis h)=|, lest the prophet may prove to have his sight (cf. the following dei/ceis de\ ma=llon). SOPH. OT 747 ; so Ant. 1114.
*(/ora mh\ peri\ toi=s filta/tois kubeu/h|s, beware lest it may prove that you are staking what is dearest. PLAT. Prot. 314A.
*(/ora o(/pws mh\ para\ do/can o(mologh=|s Id. Crit. 49C . In all these cases the present indicative would be required if the object of fear were really present (369, 1).
Compare the examples of the perfect subjunctive in 103.

In a few passages of Homer the aorist subjunctive with mh/ seems to express a similar fear that something may prove to have already happened; as dei/doika mh/ se parei/ph|, I fear it may prove that she persuaded you, Il. i. 555. So Il. x. 98, mh\ koimh/swntai a)/tar la/qwntai , and x. 538, dei/doika mh/ ti pa/qwsi , I fear lest it may prove that they have met some harm. The reference to the past here cannot come from any past force of the aorist subjunctive itself, but is probably an inference drawn from the context. As the later language would use a perfect subjunctive in such cases, these aorists seem to be instances of an earlier laxity of usage, like the use of a)po/loito/ ke for both would have perished and would perish (440).

In Il. x. 537 there is a similar case of the aorist optative in a wish: ai)\ ga\r dh\ w(=d' a)/far e)k *trw/wn e)lasai/ato mw/nuxas i(/ppous, i.e. may it prove that they have driven the horses away from the Trojans (95).

div2.head: Optative.
div2.p:
The present and aorist optative in independent sentences (in wishes and with a)/n), and in all conditional sentences except past general conditions (462; 532), express future time, the relation of which to the future expressed by other moods is explained in 12, 13, and 16. (Some Homeric present or past unreal conditions and present wishes are exceptions: see 438-441.) In all final constructions the optative (which is used only after past tenses) represents the subjunctive after primary tenses, and is future relatively to the leading verb. E.g. *ei)/qe tou=to ei)/h (utinam sit), O that this may be. *ei)/qe mh\ tau=ta pa/sxoien, may they not suffer these things (with a view to the progress of their suffering). But ei)/qe mh\ tau=ta pa/qoien, may they not suffer these things (viewed collectively). *ei)/qe su\ toiou=tos w)\n fi/los h(mi=n ge/noio, may you become a friend to us. XEN. Hell. iv. 1, 38
*mh\ ge/noito, may it not happen. See examples of the optative with a)/n below.
*ou) ga\r a)\n e)painoi/h me, ei) e)celau/noimi tou\s eu)erge/tas, for he would not praise me, if I should banish my benefactors. XEN. An. vii. 7, 11.
*ei)/hs forhto\s ou)k a)\n, ei) pra/ssois kalw=s, you would not be endurable, if you should be in prosperity (at any time) AESCH. Prom. 979.
*pw=s ga\r a)/n tis, a(/ ge mh\ e)pi/staito, tau=ta sofo\s ei)/h; for how could any one be wise in that which he did not understand (i.e. ei)/ tina mh\ e)pi/staito)? XEN. Mem. iv. 6, 7.
*)all' ei)/ ti mh\ fe/roimen, w)/trunen fe/rein, but if we neglected to bring anything, he always exhorted us to bring it. EUR. Alc. 755.
*ou)k a)pelei/peto e)/ti au)tou=, ei) mh/ ti a)nagkai=on ei)/h, he never left him, unless there was some necessity for it. XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 40 .
*ei) e)/lqoi, pa/nt' a)\n i)/doi, if he should go, he would see all.
*ei) e)/lqoi, pa/nq' e(w/ra, if ever (whenever) he went, he (always) saw all.
*ou)d' ei) pa/ntes e)/lqoien *pe/rsai, plh/qei ge ou)x u(perbaloi/meq' a)\n tou\s polemi/ous, not even if all the Persians should come, should we surpass the enemy in numbers. XEN. Cyr. ii. 1, 8.
*(/ote e)/cw tou= deinou= ge/nointo kai\ e)cei/h pro\s a)/llous a)/rxontas a)pie/nai, polloi\ au)to\n a)pe/leipon, but when they were come out of danger and it was in their power (present) to go to other commanders, (in all such cases) many left him. Id. An. ii. 6, 12.
*)/aneu ga\r a)rxo/ntwn ou)de\n a)\n ou)/te kalo\n ou)/te a)gaqo\n ge/noito, nothing could be done, etc.
Ib. iii. 1, 38.
*ou)k oi)=da o(/ ti a)/n tis xrh/saito au)toi=s, I do not know what use any one could make of them.
Ib. iii. 1, 40.
*tou/tou e)pequ/mei, i(/na eu)= pra/ttoi, he desired this in order that he might be in prosperity.
*)efobei=to mh\ tou=to poioi=en, he feared lest they should do this (habitually).
*dh=los h)=n e)piqumw=n a)/rxein, o(/pws plei/w lamba/noi, e)piqumw=n de\ tima=sqai, i(/na plei/w kerdai/noi: fi/los te e)bou/leto ei)=nai toi=s me/gista duname/nois, i(/na a)dikw=n mh\ didoi/h di/khn XEN. An. ii. 6, 21. (Here the aorist optative would have referred to single acts of receiving, getting gain, and suffering punishment, while the present refers to a succession of cases, and to a whole course of conduct.)
*)=hn o( *fi/lippos e)n fo/bw| mh\ e)kfu/goi ta\ pra/gmat' au)to/n, Philip was in fear lest the control of affairs might escape him. DEM. xviii. 33.

The aorist optative with e)peidh/ or e)pei/, after that, is referred by the meaning of the particle to time preceding that of the leading verb, like the aorist subjunctive in 90; so that e)peidh\ i)/doi a)ph/|ei means after he had seen he (always) went away. This gives the aorist in translation the force of a pluperfect. So after words meaning until, and in the other cases mentioned in 90. E.g.
*ou(\s me\n i)/doi ei) ta/ktws i)o/ntas, ti/nes te ei)=en h)rw/ta, kai\ e)pei\ pu/qoito e)ph/|nei, he asked any whom he saw marching in good order, who they were; and after he had ascertained, he praised them. XEN. Cyr. v. 3, 55.
*perieme/nomen e(ka/stote e(/ws a)noixqei/h to\ desmwth/rion: e)peidh\ de\ a)noixqei/h, ei)sh/|eimen para\ to\n *swkra/th, we waited each morning until the prison was opened (or had been opened); and after it was opened, we went in to Socrates. PLAT. Phaed. 59D.
In PLAT. Rep. 331 C, ei)/ tis la/boi para\ fi/lou a)ndro\s swfronou=ntos o(/pla, ei) manei\s a)paitoi= , is thus given by Cicero (Offic. iii. 95): Si gladium quis apud te sanae mentis deposuerit, repetat insaniens ; and there can be no doubt that ei)lhfw\s ei)/h (the equivalent of deposuerit) would have been more exact than la/boi in Greek (see 91). For a peculiar aorist optative in Il. x. 537, see above (93, end).

div2.head: Infinitive.
div2.p:
A present or aorist infinitive (without a)/n) not in indirect discourse is still a verbal noun so far that it expresses no time except such as is implied in the context. Thus, when it depends on a verb of wishing or commanding or any other verb whose natural object is a future action, or when it expresses purpose, it is future without regard to its tense; as, in bou/lomai nika=n (or nikh=sai), I wish to be victorious (or to gain victory), the infinitive expresses time only so far as the noun ni/khn would in bou/lomai ni/khn. Likewise, when the present or aorist infinitive (without a)/n) has the article, except in the rare cases in which it stands in indirect discourse (794), it has no reference to time in itself; as in to\ gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn labei=n e)stin, to learn is to obtain knowledge, where gnw=nai expresses time only as the noun gnw=sis would in its place. E.g.
*)/ecesti me/nein, it is possible to remain.
*)ece/stai tou=to poiei=n, it will be possible to do this.
*de/omai u(mw=n me/nein, I beg you to remain.
*ti/ to\ kwlu=on e)/t' au)to\n e)/stai badi/zein o(/poi bou/letai, what will there be to prevent him from going whither he pleases? DEM. i. 12.
*)eke/leusa au)to\n tou=to poiei=n, I commanded him to do this.
*)ebou/leto sofo\s ei)=nai, he wished to be wise.
*deino/s e)sti le/gein, he is skilled in speaking.
*(/wra badi/zein, it is time to be going.
*pa=n poiou=sin w(/ste di/khn mh\ dido/nai, they do everything so as to avoid being punished. PLAT. Gorg. 479 C .
*to\ me\n ou)=n e)pitima=n i)/sws fh/sai tis a)\n r(a/|dion ei)=nai, to\ d' o(/ ti dei= pra/ttein a)pofai/nesqai, tou=t' ei)=nai sumbou/lou, some one may say that finding fault is easy, but that showing what ought to be done is the duty of an adviser. DEM. i. 16. (*)epitima=n, a)pofai/nesqai, and pra/ttein belong here; but ei)=nai in both cases is in indirect discourse, 117.)
*ou) pleoneci/as e(/neken tau=t' e)/pracen, a)lla\ tw=| dikaio/tera tou\s *qhbai/ous h)\ u(ma=s a)ciou=n, he did this not from love of gain, but because of the Thebans making juster demands than you. Id. vi. 13.
*)eteixi/sqh de\ *)atala/nth nh=sos, tou= mh\ lh|sta\s kakourgei=n th\n *eu)/boian, in order to prevent pirates from ravaging Euboea. THUC. ii. 32.
*po/lew/s e)sti qa/natos a)na/staton gene/sqai, it is death for a city to be laid waste. LYCURG. 61.
*(/wsper tw=n a)ndrw=n toi=s kaloi=s ka)gaqoi=s ai(retw/tero/n e)sti kalw=s a)poqanei=n h)\ zh=n ai)sxrw=s, ou(/tw kai\ tw=n po/lewn tai=s u(perexou/sais lusitelei=n ( h(gou=nto )e)c a)nqrw/pwn a)fanisqh=nai ma=llon h)\ dou/lais o)fqh=nai genome/nais, as it is preferable for honourable men to die (aorist) nobly rather than to continue living (present) in disgrace, so also they thought that it was better (present) for the pre-eminent among states to be (at once) made to disappear (aorist) from among men, than to be (once) seen (aorist) to fall into slavery. ISOC. iv. 95.
*pe/mpousin e)s th\n *ke/rkuran pre/sbeis, deo/menoi mh\ sfa=s periora=n fqeirome/nous, a)lla\ tou/s te feu/gontas cunalla/cai sfi/si kai\ to\n tw=n barba/rwn po/lemon katalu=sai, asking them not to allow them to be destroyed, but to bring their exiles to terms with them, and to put an end to the barbarians' war. THUC. i. 24.
*to\ ga\r gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn pou labei=n e)stin, to learn is to obtain knowledge. PLAT. Theaet. 209 E
*pa/ntes to\ katalipei=n au)ta\ pa/ntwn ma/lista feu/gomen, we all try most of all to avoid leaving them behind. XEN. Mem. ii. 2, 3.
*ou) ga\r to\ mh\ labei=n ta)gaqa\ ou(/tw ge xalepo\n w(/sper to\ labo/nta sterhqh=nai luphro/n Id. Cyr. vii. 5, 82.
*tou= piei=n e)piqumi/a, the desire of obtaining drink. THUC. vii. 84.
*keleu/ei au)to\n e)lqei=n, he commands him to go.
*)eke/leusen au)to\n e)lqei=n, he commanded him to go.
*keleu/sei au)to\n e)lqei=n, he will command him to go.
*pro\s tw=| mhde\n e)k th=s presbei/as labei=n, tou\s ai)xmalw/tous e)lu/sato, besides receiving nothing from the embassy, he ransomed the captives. DEM. xix. 229.
*ei pro\ tou= tou\s *fwke/as a)pole/sqai yhfi/saisqe bohqei=n, if before the destruction of the Phocians you should vote to go to their assistance. Id. xviii. 33.
*ta\s ai)ti/as prou)/graya, tou= mh/ tina zhth=sai/ pote e)c o(/tou tosou=tos po/lemos kate/sth, that no one may ever ask the reason why, etc. THUC. i. 23.
*to\n u(pe\r tou= mh\ gene/sqai tau=t' a)gw=na, the contest to prevent these from being done. DEM. xviii. 201.
No account is here taken of the infinitive with a)/n (204).

The distinction between the present and aorist infinitive is well illustrated by Aristotle, when he says of pleasure, Nic. Eth. x. 3. 4 h(sqh=nai me
 ga e)/sti taxe/ws w(/sper o)rgisqh=nai, h(/desqai d' ou)\, ou)de\ pro\s e(/teron: badi/zein, de\ kai\ au)/cesqai kai\ pa/nta ta\ toiau=ta. metaba/llein me
 ou)=n ei)s th
 h(donh
 taxe/ws kai\ brade/ws e)/stin, e)nergei=n de\ kat' au)th
 ou)k e)/sti taxe/ws, le/gw d' h(/desqai . We may BECOME pleased (h(sqh=nai) quickly, as we may get angry quickly; but we cannot BE pleased (h(/desqai) quickly, even as compared with another person, although we can thus walk and grow and do such things. We may then change into a state of pleasure quickly or slowly, but we cannot actually enjoy the pleasure, I mean BE PLEASED (h(/desqai), quickly.

So in PLAT. Theaet. 155 C, Socrates says, a)/neu tou= gi/gnesqai gene/sqai a)du/naton (sc. e)me\ e)la/ttw), i.e. without going through the process of becoming (gi/gnesqai) smaller, it is impossible for me to get (gene/sqai) smaller.

*xra/w, a)naire/w, qespi/zw, and other verbs signifying to give an oracular response, generally take the present or the aorist infinitive, expressing the command or warning of the oracle, where we might expect the future in indirect discourse (135). These verbs here take the ordinary construction of verbs of commanding, advising, and warning. E.g.
*le/getai de\ *)alkmai/wni to\n *)apo/llw tau/thn th\n gh=n xrh=sai oi)kei=n it is said that Apollo gave a response to Alcmaeon that he should inhabit this land (warned him to inhabit it). THUC. ii. 102.
*xrwme/nw| de\ tw=| *ku/lwni a)nei=len o( qeo\s e)n th=| tou= *dio\s th=| megi/sth| e(orth=| katalabei=n th\n *)aqhnai/wn a)kro/polin, that he should seize. Id. i. 126.
*)eke/xrhto ga\r toi=si *spartih/th|si, h)\ *lakedai/mona a)na/staton gene/sqai h)\ to\n basile/a sfe/wn a)pole/sqai HDT. vii. 220.
*eqe/spise komi/sai kai\ ei)sidei=n EUR. I.T. 1014.
*(ws xrhsmou= o)/ntos th\n po/lin diafqarh=nai, as if there were an oracle dooming the city to perish. PLAT. Rep. 415 C .
*polla/ki ga/r oi( e)/eipe nou/sw| u(p' a)rgale/h| fqi/sqai h)\ u(po\ *trw/essi damh=nai the diviner told him that he must either die by painful disease, or perish at the hands of the Trojans. Il. xiii. 667.
But we find a)nei=len e)/sesqai, THUC. i. 118; xrh/santos krath/sein, LYCURG. 99; e)ke/xrhsto basileu/sein, HDT. ii. 147; as indirect discourse.

Even verbs of saying and thinking, as le/gw when it signifies to command, and dokei=, it seems good, may take the present or aorist infinitive not in indirect discourse, like other verbs of the same meaning. *ei)=pon seldom takes the infinitive, except when it signifies to command (753). The context will always distinguish these cases from indirect quotations. E.g.
*tou/tois e)/legon plei=n, I told them to sail. DEM. xix. 150. (*tou/tous e)/legon plei=n would mean I said that they were sailing.)
*ei)pw\n mhde/na parie/nai ei)s th\n a)kro/polin, having given orders that no one should pass into the citadel. XEN. Hell. v. 2, 29.
*)=w fi/loi, h)/dh me/n ken e)gw\n ei)/poimi kai\ a)/mmin mnhsth/rwn e)s o(/milon a)konti/sai now I would command you to join me in hurling, etc. Hom. Od. xxii. 262.
*paradou=nai le/gei he tells us to give her up (he says, give her up). AR. Av. 1679.
*dokei= h(mi=n tou=to poiei=n (or poih=sai) it pleases us to do this. (But dokei= moi u(ma=s tou=to poiei=n (or poih=sai) generally means it seems to me that you are doing this, or did this.)
*)/edoce in the sense it was resolved, introducing a decree, is followed by the present or aorist (not future) infinitive.

Verbs of hoping, expecting, promising, and swearing form an intermediate class between those that take the infinitive in indirect discourse and other verbs (136). When they refer to a future object, they naturally take the future infinitive, but may also have the present or aorist infinitive (not in indirect discourse) like verbs of wishing, etc. Thus he promised to give may be u(pe/sxeto dido/nai (or dou=nai) as well as u(pe/sxeto dw/sein.
To facilitate comparison, the examples of the present and aorist infinitive thus used are given with those of the future in 136.

The present ai)/tio/s ei)mi, I am the cause, is often used with reference to the past, where logically a past tense would be needed; as ai)/tio/s e)sti tou/tw| qanei=n, he is the cause of his death, instead of ai)/tios h)=n tou/tw| qanei=n, he was the cause of his death. This may make an ordinary aorist infinitive appear like a verb of past time. E.g.
*ai)/tioi ou)=n ei)si kai\ u(mi=n pollw=n h)/dh yeusqh=nai kai\ dh\ a)di/kws ge/ tinas a)pole/sqai they are the cause why you were deceived and some even perished (i.e. they caused you to be deceived and some even to perish). LYS. xix. 51.
*teqna=sin: oi( de\ zw=ntes ai)/tioi qanei=n they are dead; and the living are the causes of their death. SOPH. Ant. 1173.
*(/h moi mhtri\ me\n qanei=n mo/nh metai/tios Id. Tr. 1233.

div2.head: Perfect.
div2.p: As the perfect indicative represents an act as finished at the present time, so the perfect of any of the dependent moods properly represents an act as finished at the time (present, past, or future) at which the present of that mood would represent it as going on.
