It will be understood that no assimilation to the optative can take place when the protasis is present or past, as a change to the optative here would involve a change of time. See 561.

II. (a) In final and object clauses with i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, o)/fra, and mh/, the subjunctive (or future indicative) is generally used after a potential optative with a)/n or after an optative in protasis referring to the future. E.g. *)=h r(a/ ke nu=n a(/m' h(mi=n oi)/kad' e(/poio, o)/fra i)/dh|, k.t.l. Od. xv. 431. So Od. vi. 57, Od. xvi. 87; Il. xxiv. 264. *di) w)to\s a)
 pau=ra sumfe/roi, w(s o)rou/sh|. SOPH. El. 1439.
*ti/s au)to
 a)
 kale/seien, w(s i)/dh| me; Bacch. 1258.
*)oknoi/hn a)
 ei)s ta\ ploi=a e)mbai/nein, mh\ katadu/sh|: foboi/mhn d' a)
 tw=| h(gemo/ni e(/pesqai, mh\ h(ma=s a)ga/gh| o(/qen ou)x oi(=o/n te e)/stai e)celqei=n. XEN. An. i. 3, 17. *ti/s ou)k a)
 feu/goi, i(/na mh/d' a)/kwn au)th=| peripe/sh|; DEM. xxv. 33. *oi)/omai a)
 u(ma=s me/ga o)nh=sai to\ stra/teuma, ei) e)pimelhqei/hte o(/pws a)nti\ tw=n a)polwlo/twn w(s ta/xista strathgoi\ kai\ loxagoi\ a)ntikatastaqw=sin. XEN. An. iii. 1, 38. *ei) de\ kai\ o(/pws ei)rh/nh e)/stai faneroi\ ei)/hte e)pimelou/menoi. Id. Vect. v. 10 (see 180, b).

(b) The only examples of the optative here are one in Aristophanes, one in Plato, and six in XenophonSee Weber, Absichtssä tze, pp. 220, 221; 245-247. I have assumed that Weber's collection of examples is complete.:—

*dia\ tou=t' ei)ko/tws bou/loint' a)
 h(ma=s e)colwle/nai, i(/na ta\s teleta\s la/boien. Pac. 411. *ou)k a)/n pw pa/nu ge me/ga ti ei)/h, ei) bouko/lous . . . prosqei=men, i(/na oi( gewrgoi\ e)pi\ to\ a)rou=n e)/xoien bou=s. PLAT. Rep. 370D. *peirw/|mhn (a)
) mh\ pro/sw u(mw=n ei)=nai, i(/na, ei)/ pou kairo\s ei)/h, e)pifanei/hn. XEN. Cyr. ii. 4, 17. So Cyr. i. 6, Cyr. 22; An. ii. 4, An. 3, An. iii. 1, 18 (with various readings in last two). *(h fulakh\ geloi/a tis a)

 au)to/nomon ge/noito faneroi\ ei)/hte e)pimelou/menoi. XEN. Vect. v. 9; but in the next sentence, o(/pws ei)rh/nh e)/stai (see 180, a).
(c) After an optative in a wish twelve examples of these clauses with the optative and ten with the subjunctive are cited from Homer and the lyric and tragic poets. These are

*ta/xista/ moi e)/ndon e(tai=roi ei)=en, i(/n' e)n klisi/h| laro\n tetukoi/meqa do/rpon Od. xiv. 407. So xviii. 368, Od. xx. 79. (Subjunctive in Il. xvi. 99, Il. xxiv. 74; Od. iv. 735, Od. xviii. 202.) So THEOG. 885, THEOG. 1119; PIND. Py. v. 120 (?). (Subj. Nem. viii. 35.) *)/elqoi o(/pws ge/noito tw=nd' e)moi\ luth/rios. AESCH. Eum. 297.
*genoi/man i(/n' u(la=en e)/pesti po/ntou pro/blhm' a(li/kluston, ta\s i(era\s o(/pws prosei/poimen *)aqh/nas SOPH. Aj. 1217 ; so Ph. 324 and Tr. 953. (Subj. SOPH. Tr. 1109.) *ei)/ moi ge/noito fqo/ggos e)n braxi/osi, w(s pa/nq' o(marth=| tw=n e)/xointo gouna/twn. EUR. Hec. 836; so EUR. Hipp. 732. (Subjunctives in EUR. Hel. 174, Suppl. 621, I.T. 439, EUR. Ion. 671.)

No case of either subjunctive or optative after an optative in a wish in prose is cited by Weber. Perhaps one may be found in DEM. xviii. 89, where Cod. *s reads, w(=n diama/rtoien, kai\ meta/sxoien w(=n u(mei=s oi( ta\ be/ltista boulo/menoi tou\s qeou\s ai)tei=te, mh\ metadoi=en u(mi=n w(=n au)toi\ proh/|rhntai, which can best be translated, in which (hopes) may they be disappointed; and may they (rather) share the blessings for which you, who wish for the best, pray the Gods, lest they involve you in the evils which they have chosen for themselves. *mh/ with the subjunctive in this sense occurs twice in Demosthenes, DEM. xix. 225, DEM. xxxviii. 26.The alternative, if we keep this reading, is to make mh\ metadoi=en an independent wish, as if it were mhde\ metadoi=en, the usual reading.

In relative sentences expressing a purpose the future indicative is regularly retained after optatives and even after past tenses of the indicative (566). For exceptional cases of the optative in this construction see 573 and 574, with 134.

III. In indirect quotations and questions depending upon an optative which refers to the future, the indicative is the only form regularly used to represent an indicative of the direct discourse. E.g. *ou) ga\r a)\n tou=to/ g' ei)/pois, w(s e)/laqen. AESCHIN. ii. 151. *)ekei=no le/gein a)\n e)pixeirh/seie *lepti/nhs, w(s ai( leitourgi/ai ei)s pe/nhtas a)nqrw/pous e)/rxontai (187). DEM. xx. 18; so xvi. 4. *ei) a)podeixqei/h ti/na xrh\ h(gei=sqai tou= laisi/ou. XEN. An. iii. 2, 36.

But in DEM. xvi. 5 we find the optative in an indirect quotation: ou) ga e)kei=no/ g' a)
 ei)/poimen, w(s a)ntalla/casqai bouloi/meq' a)ntipa/lous *lakedaimoni/ous a)nti\ *qhbai/wn. There are no other readings, and we must call it an exceptional case of assimilation (we could not say this, that we wished, etc.) unless we emend it either by reading boulo/meqa (as proposed by Madvig, Bemerk. p. 21) or by inserting a)/n. In PLAT. Rep. 515 D, we find in the best MSS. ti/ a)
 oi)/ei au)to
 ei)pei=n, ei)/ tis au)tw=| le/goi o(/ti to/te me
 e(w/ra fluari/as, nu=n de\ o)rqo/tera ble/poi; what do you think he would say, if any one should tell him that all that time he had been seeing foolish phantoms, but that now he saw more correctly? (Some MSS. read ble/pei.)

In Il. v. 85, *tudei/dhn ou)k a)\n gnoi/hs pote/roisi metei/h, the optative represents me/testin in the direct question; but ou)k a)\n gnoi/hs here refers to the past, meaning you would not have known (442).

IV. In indirect questions depending on an optative, the optative may represent an interrogative subjunctive (287) of the direct question. E.g. *ou)k a)
 e)/xois e)celqw
 o(/ ti xrw=|o sautw=|, if you should withdraw, you would not know what to do with yourself. PLAT. Crit. 45B. *ou)k a)
 e)/xois o(/ ti xrh/saio sautw=|, a)ll' i)liggiw/|hs a)
 kai\ xasmw=|o ou)k e)/xwn o(/ ti ei)/pois. Gorg. 486B. The direct questions here were ti/ xrw=mai;—ti/ xrh/swmai;—ti/ ei)/pw; The subjunctive can always be retained in this construction, even after past tenses (677).

div2.head: Infinitive and Participle.
div2.p: The present, perfect, and future of the infinitive and participle, and the aorist infinitive when it is not in indirect discourse, regularly denote time which is relative to that of the leading verb. They therefore merely transmit the force of that verb, as primary or secondary, to the dependent clauses. E.g. *bou/letai le/gein ti/ tou=to/ e)stin, he wishes to tell what this is. *)ebou/leto le/gein ti/ tou=to ei)/h, he wished to tell what this was. *fhsi\n a)khkoe/nai ti/ e)stin, he says he has heard what it is. *)/efh a)khkoe/nai ti/ ei)/h, he said he had heard what it was. *fhsi\ poih/sein o(/ ti a)\n bou/lhsqe, he says he will do whatever you may wish. *)/efh poih/sein o(/ ti bou/loisqe, he said he would do whatever you might wish.

*me/nousin boulo/menoi ei)de/nai ti/ e)sti. *)/emenon boulo/menoi ei)de/nai ti/ ei)/h. *me/nousin a)khkoo/tes ti/ e)stin. *)/emenon a)khkoo/tes ti/ ei)/h, they waited, having heard what it was (ti/ e)sti/n; ). *me/nousin a)kouso/menoi ti/ e)stin. *)/emenon a)kouso/menoi ti/ ei)/h.
*bou/letai gnw=nai ti/ tou=to/ e)stin, he wishes to learn what this is. *)ebou/leto gnw=nai ti/ tou=to ei)/h, he wished to learn what this was.

*ou)deni\ pw/pote tou/twn dedw/kate th
 dwrea
 tau/thn ou)d' a)/n doi/hte, e)cei=nai tou\s i)di/ous e)xqrou\s u(bri/zein au)tw=n e(ka/stw|, o(po/t' a)
 bou/lhtai kai\ o(
 a)

DEM. xxi. 170. *ou)/q' u(mi=n ou)/te *qhbai/ois ou)/te *lakedaimoni/ois ou)depw/pote sunexw/rhqh tou=q' u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn, poiei=n o(/ ti bou/loisqe, never was this granted you, etc., to do whatever you pleased. Id. ix. 23.Here poiei=n denotes a habit, and is followed by the optative (532); if the leading verb were sugxwrei=tai, we should have poiei=n o(/ ti a)
 bou/lhsqe. Compare the two subjunctives in the preceding example.

The present infinitive and participle representing the imperfect (without a)/n), and the perfect representing the pluperfect, are secondary tenses in themselves, without regard to the leading verb. E.g. *pw=s ga\r oi)/esqe dusxerw=s a)kou/ein, ei)/ ti/s ti le/goi; how unwillingly do you think they heard it, when any one said anything? DEM. vi. 20.So PLAT. Rep. 430A. See these and other examples under 119.
For the perfect see XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 27 , and THUC. v. 49, under 123.

The aorist infinitive in indirect discourse is a past tense in itself, and is therefore secondary. E.g. *fhsi\ gnw=nai ti/ tou=to ei)/h, he says that he learned what this was. *)/efh gnw=nai ti/ tou=to ei)/h, he said that he had learned what this was.

*fhsi\ ga\r o(mologh=sai/ me tou= klh/rou tw=| paidi\ to\ h(miklh/rion metadw/sein ei) nikh/saimi tou\s e)/xontas au)to/n (he says I promised, metadw/sw e)a\n nikh/sw). ISAE. xi. 24.
*qalh=n *qra=|tta/ tis qerapaini\s a)poskw=yai le/getai, w(s ta\ me\n e)n ou)ranw=| proqumoi=to ei)de/nai, ta\ d' e)/mprosqen au)tou= lanqa/noi au)to/n. PLAT. Theaet. 174 A
*)=ara/ soi dokw= ou) mantikw=s a(\ nu=n dh\ e)/legon ei)pei=n, o(/ti *)aga/qwn qaumastw=s e)roi= e)gw\ d' a)porh/soimi; Symp. 198A. In all these cases the optative depends on the aorist infinitive as a past tense.

The aorist participle properly refers to time past relatively to the leading verb. It is therefore secondary when the leading verb is past or present, so that the participle refers to time absolutely past; but it may be primary when the leading verb is future, if the participle refers to time absolutely future. E.g. *)/iste h(ma=s e)lqo/ntas i(/na tou=to i)/doimen, you know that we came that we might see this.

*yh/fwn de\ dei/sas mh\ dehqei/h pote\ i(/n' e)/xoi dika/zein, ai)gialo
 e)/ndon tre/fei, and once he took fright lest he might sometime lack pebbles (for votes) to enable him to be a judge, and so he keeps a beach on the premises. AR. Vesp. 109.
*pro\s o)rgh
 e)kfe/rei, meqei=sa/ moi le/gein a(\ xrh/|zoimi, you rush into a passion, after you gave me leave to say what I wished (i.e. a(\ a)
 xrh/|zh|s). SOPH. El. 628.

*(upeipw\n ta)/lla o(/ti au)to\s ta)kei= pra/coi, w)/|xeto. THUC. i. 90. *th=| ma/stigi tupte/sqw plhga\s u(po\ kh/rukos e)n th=| a)gora=|, khru/cantos w(=n e(/neka me/llei tu/ptesqai, i.e. let the crier flog him, after proclaiming (having proclaimed) for what he is to be flogged. Leg. 917

The tenses of the infinitive and participle with a)/n are followed, in dependent clauses, by those constructions that would follow the finite moods which they represent, if these stood in the same position. See Chapter III.

div2.head: The Particle a)/n.
div2.p: The adverb a)/n (with the epic ke/, Doric ka/) has two uses, which must be distinguished.

1. In one use, it denotes that the action of the verb to which it is joined is dependent upon some condition, expressed or implied. This is its force with the secondary tenses of the indicative, and with the optative, infinitive, and participle: with these it belongs strictly to the verb, to which it gives a potential force, like our would.

2. In its other use, it is joined regularly to ei), if, to relative and temporal words, and sometimes to the final particles w(s, o(/pws, and o)/fra, when any of these are followed by the subjunctive. Here, although as an adverb it qualifies the verb, it is so closely connected with the relative or particle, that it often coalesces with it, forming e)a/n, h)/n, a_)/n o(/tan, o(po/tan, e)peida/n, e)pa/n or e)ph/n (Ionic e)pea/n).

These statements include only the constructions which are in good use in Attic Greek. For the epic use of ke/ or a)/n with the subjunctive in a potential sense (as with the optative) see 201, 1; for ke/ or a)/n with the future indicative see 196.

There is no word or expression in English which can be used separately to translate a)/n. In its first use (192, 1) we express it by the form of the verb which we use; as e)/lqoi a)/n, he would go; h)=lqen a)/n, he would have gone. In its second use, with the subjunctive, it generally has no force that can be made perceptible in translation.

The peculiar use of a)/n can be understood only by a study of the various constructions in which it occurs. These are enumerated below, with references (when it is necessary) to the more full explanation of each in Chapter IV.

No theory of the origin of either a)/n or ke/ has yet helped to explain their meaning, however valuable the discussion of the question may have been to comparative philology. It seems to be clear that ke/ is the older particle; it occurs 621 times in Homer while a)/n occurs 155 times; in Pindar the two are nearly balanced; a)/n has a preference for negative sentences, being very often attached to the negative; a)/n is more emphatic, as appears indeed from its fixed accent, while ke/ is enclitic; ke/ is much more frequent than a)/n in relative clauses in Homer.See Monro, Homeric Grammar, pp. 265-267. For Pindar, see Gildersleeve in Jour. Phil. iii. pp. 446-455, where may be found a complete enumeration of the passages in Pindar containing either a)/n (30 cases) or ke/ (33 cases). But, practically, it is still safe to assume that the two particles are used in substantially the same sense in all epic and lyric poetry. In Herodotus and Attic Greek only a)/n is used.

div2.head: Indicative with a)/n.
div2.p: The present and perfect indicative are never used with a)/n.

This seems to occur chiefly when Plato and Aristotle use ka)
 ei) (= kai\ a)
, ei)) like kai\ ei), without regard to the mood of the verb which is to follow, to which ka)/n really belongs. See PLAT. Men. 72 C, ka)
 ei) pollai/ ei)sin, e(/n ge/ ti ei)=dos tau)to
 pa=sai e)/xousi , i.e. even if they are many, still (it would seem to follow that) they all have one and the same form. So PLAT. Rep. 579 D, Soph. 247E. So ARISTOT. Pol. iii. 6, 1, ka)
 ei) plei/ous , with skepte/on e)sti/n.

Examples of a different class (without ka)\n ei)) are obviously corrupt, and have now almost disappeared from our texts. One of the last relics, Leg. 712E, e)gw\ de\ ou(/tw nu=n e)cai/fnhs a)\n e)rwthqei\s o)/ntws o(/per ei)=pon, ou)k e)/xw ei)pei=n , is now simply emended by reading a)nerwthqei/s.

The future indicative is often used with ke/ or a)/n by the early poets, especially Homer. The addition of a)/n seems to make the future more contingent than that tense naturally is, sometimes giving it a force approaching that of the optative with a)/n. E.g. *)all' i)/q), e)gw\ de/ ke/ toi *xari/twn mi/an o(plotera/wn dw/sw, o)puie/menai kai\ sh
 keklh=qai a)/koitin, I will give you one of the younger Graces, etc. Il. xiv. 267. *kai/ ke/ tis w(=d' e)re/ei *trw/wn u(perhnoreo/ntwn, and some one will (or may) thus speak. Il. iv. 176. *(o de/ ken kexolw/setai o(/n ken i(/kwmai, and he may be angry to whom I come. Il. i. 139.
*ei) d' a)/ge, tou\s a)
 e)gw
 e)pio/yomai: oi( de\ piqe/sqwn Il. ix. 167.
*par' e)/moi ge kai\ a)/lloi, oi(/ ke/ me timh/sousi, others, who will honour me. Il. i. 174.
*ei) d' *)oduseu\s e)/lqoi kai\ i(/koit' e)s patri/da gai=an, ai)=ya/ ke su
 w(=| paidi\ bi/as a)poti/setai a)ndrw=n Od. xvii. 539. Here a)poti/setai/ ke, which may be aorist subjunctive (201, 1), is used nearly in the sense of the optative, corresponding to the optatives in the protasis.
*ke/ is much more common with the future than a)/n.

The use of a)/n with the future indicative in Attic Greek is absolutely denied by many critics, and the more careful revision of the texts has greatly diminished the number of examples cited in support of it. Still, in several passages, even of the best prose, we must either emend the text against the Mss., or admit the construction as a rare exception. E.g. *ai)gupti/ous de\ ou)x o(rw= poi/a| duna/mei summa/xw| xrhsa/menoi ma=llon a)
 kola/sesqe th=s nu=n su
 e)moi\ ou)/shs. XEN. An. ii. 5. 13 *)/efh ou)=n to
 e)rwtw/menon ei)pei=n, ou)x h(/kei, fa/nai, ou)d' a)
 h(/cei deu=ro, he said that the one who was asked replied, He hasn't come, and he won't come this way. PLAT. Rep. 615D. (The only other reading is h(/coi. The colloquial style here makes a)/n less objectionable; see SOPH. Ant. 390, quoted in 208.) *)/efh le/gwn pro\s u(ma=s w(s, ei) diafeucoi/mhn, h)/dh a)
 u(mw=n oi( ui(ei=s pa/ntes panta/pasi diafqarh/sontai. Id. Ap. 29C. *ka)
 e)/t' e)/ti fo/nion o)/yomai ai(=ma (so the Mss.). EUR. El. 484.
See 208 and 216, on the future infinitive and participle with a)/n.
The most common use of a)/n with the indicative is with the secondary tenses, generally the imperfect and aorist, in the apodosis of an unfulfilled condition (410) or in a potential sense (243).
The imperfect and aorist indicative are sometimes used with a)/n in an iterative sense (162), which construction must not be confounded with that just mentioned (198).

div2.head: Subjunctive and Optative with a)/n.
div2.p: In Attic Greek a)/n is regularly used with the subjunctive in protasis and in conditional relative sentences, and sometimes in final clauses with w(s and o(/pws, being always closely joined with the particle or the relative; but never in independent sentences. See 325, 381, and 522.

1. In epic poetry, when the independent subjunctive has nearly the sense of the future indicative (284), it sometimes takes ke/ or a)/n. This forms a future potential expression, nearly equivalent to the future indicative with ke/ or a)/n, and sometimes approaching the optative with ke/ or a)/n. E.g. *ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/h|sin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, and if he does not give her up, I will take her myself. Il. i. 324 ; see also i. 137.
See 285 and 452. For the variety of nearly equivalent future potential forms which the Homeric language presents, reduced to one in Attic Greek, see 235.

2. The epic language has ke/ or a)/n with the subjunctive in the constructions of 192, 2; but its use of ke/ or a)/n in conditions is less strict, and that with final particles is more free, than the Attic use of a)/n.

The optative with a)/n forms the apodosis of the less vivid future condition (like the English form with would or should), or has a potential sense. E.g. *ei) tou=to poih/seien, a)/qlios a)\n ei)/h, if he should do this, he would be wretched. *(hde/ws a)\n e)roi/mhn au)to/n, I should like to ask him. (See 233 and 455.)
For construction of a)/n or ke/ with ei) or the final particles and the optative, see 460; and 329, 330, 349, 350, 351.
As the future optative came into common use after the future indicative with a)/n (196) was nearly extinct, it was never used with a)/n.

div2.head: Infinitive with a)/n.
div2.p: The infinitive can be used with a)/n in all cases in which a finite verb would have a)/n if it stood in its place.

This is found chiefly in indirect discourse, in which each tense of the infinitive with a)/n represents the corresponding tenses of the indicative or optative with a)/n in the direct form. The context must decide whether the indicative or optative is represented in each case.

(Present.) The present infinitive, which represents also the imperfect (119), when used with a)/n, may be equivalent either to the imperfect indicative with a)/n or to the present optative with a)/n. It can represent no other form, as no other form of these tenses has a)/n joined with the verb in a finite mood. E.g. *fhsi
 au)tou\s e)leuqe/rous a)
 ei)=nai, ei) tou=to e)/pracan, he says that they would (now) be freeif they had done this (ei)=nai a)/n representing h)=san a)/n). *fhsi
 au)tou\s e)leuqe/rous a)
 ei)=nai, ei) tou=to pra/ceian, he says that they would (hereafter) be freeif they should do this (ei)=nai a)/n representing ei)/hsan a)/n). *oi)/esqe ga to
 pate/ra ou)k a)
 fula/ttein kai\ th
 timh
 lamba/nein tw=n cu/lwn; do you think he would not have taken care and have received the pay for the timber? DEM. xlix. 35. (Here the direct discourse would be e)fu/latten a)
 kai\ e)la/mbanen.) *marturi/w| e)xrw=nto, mh\ a)
 tou/s ge i)soyh/fous a)/kontas, ei) mh/ ti h)di/koun oi(=s e)ph/|esan, custrateu/ein, they used us as an argument, that people who had an equal vote with themselves (like us) would not be serving with them against their will, unless those whom they attacked were guilty of some wrong. THUC. iii. 11. *oi)=mai ga a)
 ou)k a)xari/stws moi e)/xein, for I think it would not be a thankless labour (ou)k a)
 e)/xoi). XEN. An. ii. 3, 18.

(Perfect.) The perfect infinitive, which represents also the pluperfect (123), when used with a)/n, may be equivalent either to the pluperfect indicative with a)/n or to the perfect optative with a)/n. E.g. *ei) mh\ ta\s a)reta\s u(pe au)tw=n e)kei/nas oi( *maraqw=ni kai\ *salami=ni pare/sxonto, . . . pa/nta tau=q' u(po\ tw=n barba/rwn a)
 e(alwke/nai (sc. fh/seien a)/n tis), if those at Marathon and Salamis had not exhibited those deeds of valour in their behalf, any one would say that all these would have been captured by the barbarians. DEM. xix. 312. (Here e(alwke/nai a)/n represents e(alw/kesan a)/n.) *)all' ou)k a)
 h(gou=mai au)tou\s di/khn a)ci/an dedwke/nai, ei) a)kroasa/menoi au)tw=n katayhfi/saisqe, but I do not believe they would (then) have suffered sufficient punishment, if you after hearing them should condemn them. LYS. xxvii. 9. (Here the protasis in the optative shows that dedwke/nai a)/n represents dedwko/tes a)
 ei)=en (103); but if the protasis were ei) kateyhfi/sasqe, if you had condemned them, dedwke/nai a)/n would represent e)dedw/kesan a)/n, they would have suffered.) See also, in xxvii. 8, ou)k a)
 a)polwle/nai, a)lla\ di/khn dedwke/nai, representing perfect optatives with a)/n. *)andrapodw/deis a)
 dikai/ws keklh=sqai (h(gei=to). XEN. Mem. i. 1, 16. (Here keklh=sqai a)/n represents keklhme/noi a)
 ei)=en.)
These constructions are of course rare, as are the forms of the finite moods here represented.

(Aorist.) The aorist infinitive with a)/n may be equivalent either to the aorist indicative with a)/n or to the aorist optative with a)/n. E.g. *ou)k a)
 h(gei=sq' au)to
 ka)
 e)pidramei=n; do you not believe that (if this had been so) he would even have run thither? i.e. ou)k a)
 e)pe/dramen; DEM. xxvii. 56. *)/aneu de\ seismou= ou)k a)/n moi dokei= to\ toiou=to cumbh=nai gene/sqai (ou)k a)
 cumbh=nai representing ou)k a)
 cune/bh), but unless there had been an earthquake, it does not seem to me that such a thing could by any chance have happened. THUC. iii. 89. *tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h)/lpizen i)/sws a)
 e)pecelqei=n kai\ th
 gh=n ou)k a)
 periidei=n tmhqh=nai (i.e. i)/sws a)
 e)pece/lqoien kai\ ou)k a)
 perii/doien). Id. ii. 20. *ou)d' a)
 krath=sai au)tou\s th=s gh=s h(gou=mai (i.e. krath/seian a)/n). Id. vi. 37.

(Future.) The future infinitive with a)/n can be equivalent only to the Homeric construction of the future indicative with a)/n. But as a)/n is not found in Homer with the future infinitive, this construction rests chiefly on the authority of passages in Attic writers, and is subject to the same doubts and suspicions as the future indicative with a)/n in those writers. (See 197.) Unless we exterminate the latter, there can be no objection to this as its representative. In the following passages it is still retained on the best MS. authority.

*nomi/zontes, ei) tau/thn prw/thn la/boien, r(a|di/ws a)
 sfi/si ta)/lla prosxwrh/sein. THUC. ii. 80. (Here the direct discourse would regularly have had either the future indicative without a)/n, or the aorist optative with a)/n.) The same may be said of THUC. v. 82, nomi/zwn me/giston a)
 sfa=s w)felh/sein (where one MS. reads by correction w)felh=sai). See also THUC. vi. 66; viii. 25 and 71; and PLAT. Crit. 53D ; PLAT. Crat. 391A.
*sxolh=| poq' h(/cein deu=r' a)
 e)chu/xoun e)gw/, I declared that I should be very slow to come hither again. SOPH. Ant. 390. (Here the colloquial style may account for h(/cein a)/n, as for h(/cei a)/n in PLAT. Rep. 615 D, unless we take a)/n with e)chu/xoun. See 197.) In PIND. Ol. i. 108, we have ei) de\ mh\ taxu\ li/poi, e)/ti glukute/ran ken e)/lpomai su
 a(/rmati qow=| klei+/cein.
As the future optative is never used with a)/n (203), this can never be represented by the future infinitive with a)/n.

The infinitive with a)/n is rare in the early poets, occurring but once in Homer, Il. ix. 684 (quoted under 683), and three times in Pindar, Pyth. viii. 20 (present), Pyth. iii. 110 (aorist), and Ol. i. 108 (future, quoted in 208).

The infinitive with a)/n sometimes represents an iterative imperfect or aorist indicative with a)/n (162). This must be carefully distinguished from the potential use. E.g. *)akou/w *lakedaimoni/ous to/te e)mbalo/ntas a)
 kai\ kakw/santas th
 xw/ran a)naxwrei=n e)p' oi)/kou pa/lin, I hear that the Lacedaemonians at that time, after invading and ravaging the country, used to return home again. DEM. ix. 48. (Here a)naxwrei=n a)/n represents a)nexw/roun a)/n in its iterative sense, they used to return.) *fasi\ me
 ga au)to
 e)repto/menon ta\ tw=n e)xo/ntwn a)ne/rwn ou)k a)
 e)celqei=n a)po\ th=s sipu/hs: tou\s d' a)ntibolei=n a)
 o(moi/ws, they say that, when he was feeding on men of wealth, he never would get away from the meal-tub; and they all alike used to implore him (ou)k a)
 e)ch=lqen, oi( de\ h)ntibo/loun a)/n). AR. Eq. 1295.

The infinitive with a)/n, in the cases already mentioned, stands in indirect discourse after a verb of saying or thinking. Sometimes, however, it is found in other constructions, where the present or aorist infinitive (without a)/n) would be expected. In such cases there is an approach to the usage of indirect discourse, so far at least that the infinitive with a)/n has the force of the corresponding tense of the indicative or optative. E.g. *ta\ de\ e)nto\s ou(/tws e)kai/eto, w(/ste h(/dista a)
 e)s u(/dwr yuxro
 sfa=s au)tou\s r(i/ptein, so that they would most gladly have thrown themselves into cold water (r(i/ptein a)/n here being equivalent to e)/rripton a)/n). THUC. ii. 49. *mia=s tre/fei pro\s nukto\s, w(/ste mh/t' e)me\ mh/t' a)/llon, o(/stis fw=s o(ra=|, bla/yai pot' a)/n, so that you could harm (bla/yeias a)/n) neither me nor any other who beholds the light. OSOPH. .T. 374. So SOPH. Tr. 669. *)/efqasan parelqo/ntes th
 tw=n *)aqhnai/wn oi)kodomi/an, w(/ste mhke/ti mh/te au)toi\ kwlu/esqai u(p' au)tw=n, e)kei/nous te kai\ panta/pasin a)pesterhke/nai, ei) kai\ kratoi=en, mh\ a)
 e)/ti sfa=s a)poteixi/sai, so as to be no longer themselves obstructed by them, and so as to have deprived them absolutely of the power of ever again walling them in, even if they should be victorious. THUC. vii. 6.
*(/usomen th
 nu/kta pa=san: w(/st' i)/sws boulh/setai ka)
 e)n *ai)gu/ptw| tuxei=n w)
 ma=llon h)\ kri=nai kakw=s, we will rain all night long, so that perhaps he will wish to have the luck to be (that he might by chance find himself) in Egypt rather than to judge unfairly. AR. Nub. 1130. (Here tuxei=n a)/n follows bou/lomai like the future infinitive in THUC. vi. 57: see 113.) We have e)lpi/zw followed by the infinitive and a)/n in THUC. vii. 61, to\ th=s tu/xhs ka)
 meq' h(mw=n e)lpi/santes sth=nai, hoping that fortune may take sides with us (stai/h a)/n). See also SOPH. El. 1482, a)lla/ moi pa/res ka)
 smikro
 ei)pei=n, but permit me at least to say a little (that I might say even a little, ei)/poimi a)/n).
See the corresponding use of the future infinitive in similar expressions, where there is the same approach to indirect discourse (113).

Even the infinitive with the article occasionally takes a)/n, as in ANT. v. 8, tou=to u(ma=s dida/cw, ou) tw=| feu/gein a)\n to\ plh=qos to\ u(me/teron, this I will teach you, not because I would avoid your people. In SOPH. Ant. 236, th=s e)lpi/dos to\ mh\ paqei=n a)\n a)/llo , the hope that I could not suffer anything else, the construction is practically that of indirect discourse (794).

div2.head: Participle with a)/n.
div2.p: When the participle is used with a)/n, each tense represents the corresponding tenses of the indicative or optative with a)/n.

The participle with a)/n is not, like the infinitive with a)/n, found chiefly in indirect discourse; but a)/n is more frequently added to an attributive or a circumstantial participle (822) to give it a potential force equivalent to that of the indicative or optative with a)/n. The participle with a)/n is not found in Homer or Pindar.

(Present.) The present participle (like the present infinitive) with a)/n represents the imperfect indicative or the present optative with a)/n. E.g. *oi)=da au)tou\s e)leuqe/rous a)
 o)/ntas, ei) tou=to e)/pracan, I know they would (now) be free, if they had done this. *oi)=da au)tou\s e)leuqe/rous a)
 o)/ntas, ei) tou=to pra/ceian, I know they would (hereafter) be free, if they should do this. (In the former o)/ntas a)/n represents h)=san a)/n, in the latter ei)/hsan a)/n.) *tw=n lambano/ntwn di/khn o)/ntes a)
 dikai/ws (i.e. h)=men a)/n), whereas we should justly be among those who inflict punishment. DEM. lvii. 3. *(/oper e)/sxe mh\ kata\ po/leis au)to
 e)piple/onta th
 *pelopo/nnhson porqei=n, a)duna/twn a)
 o)/ntwn (u(mw=n) e)pibohqei=n, when you would have been unable to bring aid (a)du/natoi a)
 h)=te). THUC. i. 73. *po/ll' a)
 e)/xwn e(/ter' ei)pei=n peri\ au)th=s paralei/pw, although I might be able to say many other things about it, I omit them. DEM. xviii. 258. *)apo\ panto\s a)
 fe/rwn lo/gou dikai/ou mhxa/nhma poiki/lon (i.e. o(\s a)
 fe/rois), thou who wouldst derive, etc. SOPH. O.C. 761.

(Aorist.) The aorist participle with a)/n represents the aorist indicative or the aorist optative with a)/n. E.g. *ou)/te o)/nta ou)/te a)
 geno/mena logopoiou=sin, they relate things which are not real, and which never could happen (i.e. ou)k a)
 ge/noito). THUC. vi. 38. *)ef' h(mw=n ou) gegono\s ou)d' oi)=da ei) geno/menon a)/n, (a thing) which has not occurred in our day, and I doubt whether it ever could occur (ge/noito a)/n). PLAT. Rep. 414 C. *)alla\ r(a|di/ws a)
 a)feqei\s, ei) kai\ metri/ws ti tou/twn e)poi/hse, proei/leto a)poqanei=n, whereas he might easily have been acquitted, etc. XEN. Mem. iv. 4, 4. *kai\ ei) a)ph/xqhsqe w(/sper h(mei=s, eu)= i)/smen mh\ a)
 h(=sson u(ma=s luphrou\s genome/nous toi=s cumma/xois, kai\ a)nagkasqe/ntas a)
 h)\ a)/rxein, k.t.l. (i.e. ou)k a)
 e)ge/nesqe, kai\ h)nagka/sqhte a)/n), if you had become odious as we have, we are sure that you would have been no less oppressive to your allies, and that you would have been forced, etc. THUC. i. 76. *(orw=n to\ paratei/xisma a(plou=n o)
 kai\, ei) e)pikrath/seie/ tis th=s a)naba/sews, r(a|di/ws a)
 au)to\ lhfqe/n (i.e. r(a|di/ws a)
 lhfqei/h), seeing that it would easily be taken, etc. Id. vii. 42.So w(s ta/x' a)
 sumba/ntwn, DEM. xxiii. 58 (see 918).

(Future.) A few cases of the future participle with a)/n, representing the future indicative with a)/n, are found in Attic writers. These rest on the same authority as those of the future indicative and the future infinitive with a)/n (197 and 208). E.g. *)afi/ete h)\ mh\ a)fi/ete, w(s e)mou= ou)k a)
 poih/sontos a)/lla, ou)d' ei) me/llw polla/kis teqna/nai (i.e. ou)k a)
 poih/sw a)/lla): so all MSS. PLAT. Ap. 30B. *tou\s o(tiou=n a)
 e)kei/nw| poih/sontas a)nh|rhko/tes e)k th=s po/lews e)/sesqe. DEM. xix. 342. (Here most MSS., including *s, have poih/sontas, but A has poih/santas.) *pa/lai tis h(de/ws a)
 i)/sws e)rwth/swn ka/qhtai, many a one has long been sitting here who perhaps would be very glad to ask (so all MSS.). DEM. ix. 70.

The participle with a)/n can never represent a protasis, because there is no form of protasis which could be represented by a participle, where a)/n is separable from the conditional particle. (See 224.)

div2.head: Position of a)/n.
div2.p: 1. When a)/n is used with the subjunctive, if it does not coalesce with the relative or particle into one word (as in e)a/n, o(/tan, etc.), it is generally separated from it only by such monosyllables as me/n, de/, te/, ga/r, kai/, nu/, pe/r, etc., rarely ti\s.
See examples under 444 and 529.

2. In Homer and Hesiod two such words may precede ke/; as ei)/ per ga/r ken, ei) ga/r nu/ ke, ei) ga/r ti/s ke, o(\s me
 ga/r ke. This is rare with a)/n in prose; see DEM. iv. 45, o(/poi me
 ga a)/n. Exceptional are o(/poi tis a)
, oi)=mai, prosqh=|, DEM. ii. 14; o(/ ti a)/llo a)
 dokh=| u(mi=n, XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 52. The strange kaq' w(=n mhnu/h| a)/n tis, ANT. v. 38, is now corrected to a)
 mhnu/h|, but still stranger is o(/poson h( fa/rugc a)
 h(mw=n xanda/nh| (?), AR. Ran. 259.

When a)/n is used with the optative or indicative, it may either stand near the verb, or be attached to some other emphatic word. Particularly, it is very often placed directly after interrogatives, negatives, adverbs of time, place, etc., and other words which especially affect the sense of the sentence. E.g. *)alla\ ti/s dh\ qew=n qerapei/a ei)/h a)
 h( o(sio/ths; PLAT. Euthyph. 13D. *)all' o(mw=s to\ kefa/laion au)tw=n r(a|di/ws a)
 ei)/pois. Id. 14 A. *ou)k a)
 dh\ to/nd' a)/ndra ma/xhs e)ru/saio metelqw
, *tudei/dhn, o(\s nu=n ge a)
 kai\ *dii\ patri\ ma/xoito; Il. v. 456.
*pw=s a)
 to
 ai(mulw/taton, e)xqro
 a)/lhma, tou/s te dissa/rxas o)le/ssas basilh=s, te/los qa/noimi kau)to/s SOPH. Aj. 389.
*polla\ ka)
 a)/kwn e)/drwn Id. O.T. 591.
*ta/xist' a)/n te po/lin oi( toiou=toi e(te/rous pei/santes a)pole/seian. THUC. ii. 63.

1. By a peculiar usage, a)/n is often separated from its verb by such verbs as oi)/omai, dokw=, fhmi/, oi)=da, etc. In such cases care must be taken to connect the a)/n with the verb to which it really belongs. E.g. *kai\ nu=n h(de/ws a)/n moi dokw= koinwnh=sai, and now I think I should gladly take part (a)/n belonging to koinwnh=sai). XEN. Cyr. viii. 7, 25. So AESCHIN. iii. 2 (end). *ou)d' a)
 u(mei=s oi)=d' o(/ti e)pau/sasqe polemou=ntes, nor would you (I am sure) have ceased fighting. DEM. vi. 29. *po/tera ga a)
 oi)/esqe r(a=|on ei)=nai; DEM. xlix. 45. *)ekle/canta a(\ mh/te proh/|dei mhdei\s mh/t' a)
 w)|h/qh th/meron r(hqh=nai, selecting what nobody knew beforehand and nobody thought would be mentioned to-day. DEM. xviii. 225. (Here r(hqh=nai a)/n = r(hqei/h a)/n. If a)/n were taken with w)|h/qh, the meaning would be, what nobody would have thought had been mentioned.) *ti/ ou)=n a)
, e)/fhn, ei)/h o( *)/erws; Symp. 202D.

2. Especially irregular are such expressions as ou)k oi)=da a)
 ei), or ou)k a)
 oi)=da ei), followed by an optative or indicative to which the a)/n belongs. E.g. *ou)k oi)=d' a)
 ei) pei/saimi, I do not know whether I could persuade him. EUR. Med. 941. (The more regular form would be ou)k oi)=da ei) pei/saimi a)/n.) So Alc. 48. *ou)k a)
 oi)=d' ei) dunai/mhn. PLAT. Tim. 26B. *ou)k oi)=d' a)
 ei) e)kthsa/mhn pai=da toiou=ton. XEN. Cyr. v. 4, 12. So ou)k a)
 oi)=d' o(/ ti a)/llo ei)=xon yhfi/sasqai, I do not know what other vote I could have given (ti/ a)/llo ei)=xon a)
 yhfi/sasqai; ), DEM. xlv. 7.

(*ta/x' a)/n.) Among the words to which a)/n is very frequently joined is ta/xa, perhaps (i.e. quickly, soon), the two forming ta/x' a)/n, which expression is sometimes supposed to mean perhaps. But ta/x' a)/n cannot be used unless the a)/n belongs in its ordinary sense to the verb of the sentence.

Thus ta/x' a)
 ge/noito means it might perhaps happen, and ta/x' a)
 e)ge/neto means it might perhaps have happened; but the latter can never mean perhaps it happened, like i)/sws e)ge/neto. *ta/xa alone often means perhaps, as in XEN. An. v. 2, 17. Aristotle writes ta/xa and a)/n separately in the same sense as ta/x' a)/n; as ta/xa de\ kai\ ma=llon a)
 tau/thn u(pola/boi, Nic. i. 5, Nic. 6.

*)/an never begins a sentence, or a clause before which a comma could stand. But it may directly follow a parenthetic clause, provided some part of its own clause precedes. E.g. *)all' w)= me/l' a)/n moi siti/wn diplw=n e)/dei, Pac. 137.So to\ me/llon, e)pei\ ge/noit), a)\n klu/ois (or without the commas), the future you can hear when it comes, AESCH. Ag. 250.

div2.head: Repetition of a)/n.
div2.p:
*)/an is sometimes used twice, or even three times, with the same verb. This may be done in a long sentence, to make the conditional force felt through the whole, especially when the connexion is broken by intermediate clauses. It may also be done in order to emphasise particular words with which a)/n is joined, and to make them prominent as being affected by the contingency. E.g. *(/wst' a)
, ei) sqe/nos la/boimi, dhlw/saim' a)
 oi(=) au)toi=s fronw=. SOPH. El. 333. *ou)/ ta)
 e(lo/ntes au)=qis a)nqaloi=en a)/n. AESCH. Ag. 340. *)/allous g' a)
 ou)=n oi)o/meqa ta\ h(me/tera labo/ntas dei=cai a)
 ma/lista ei)/ ti metria/zomen. THUC. i. 76. (See 220.) *ou)/t' a)
 keleu/saim', ou)/t' a)
, ei) qe/lois e)/ti pra/ssein, e)mou= g' a)
 h(de/ws drw/|hs me/ta SOPH. Ant. 69.
*le/gw kaq' e(/kaston dokei=n a)/n moi to
 au)to
 a)/ndra par' h(mw=n e)pi\ plei=st' a)
 ei)/dh kai\ meta\ xari/twn ma/list' a)
 eu)trape/lws to\ sw=ma au)/tarkes pare/xesqai. THUC. ii. 41. (Here a)/n is used three times, belonging to pare/xesqai.) *(umw=n de\ e)/rhmos w)
 ou)k a)
 i(kano\s oi)=mai ei)=nai ou)/t' a)
 fi/lon w)felh=sai ou)/t' a)
 e)xqro
 a)le/casqai. XEN. An. i. 3, 6. (Here a)/n is used three times, belonging to ei)=nai.) *ou)k a)
 h(gei=sq' au)to
 ka)

A participle representing a protasis (472) is especially apt to have an emphatic a)/n near it. This, by showing that the verb is to form an apodosis, tends to point out the participle as conditional in an early part of the sentence. E.g. *nomi/sate to/ te fau=lon kai\ to\ me/son kai\ to\ pa/nu a)kribe\s a)
 cugkraqe
 ma/list' a)
 i)sxu/ein, believe that these, if they should be united, would be especially strong. THUC. vi. 18. (Here cugkraqe/n, not with a)/n, is equivalent to ei) cugkraqei/h.) *)agw=nas a)/n ti/s moi dokei=, e)/fh, w)= pa/ter, proeipw
 e(ka/stois kai\ a)=qla protiqei\s ma/list' a)
 poiei=n eu)= a)skei=sqai, it seems to me, said he, father, that if any one should proclaim contests, etc., he would cause, etc. XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 18. (Here the protasis implied in the participles is merely emphasised by a)/n, which belongs to poiei=n.) (Here a)/n stands near le/gontos only to point this out as the protasis to which its own verb pisteu=sai is the apodosis, with which a)/n is not repeated.)
(a) Repetition of ke/ is rare; yet it sometimes occurs. E.g.
*tw=| ke ma/l' h)/ ken e)/meine kai\ e)ssu/meno/s per o(doi=o, h)/ ke/ me teqnhui=an e)/ni mega/roisin e)/leipen. Od iv. 733.

div2.head: Elliptical uses of a)/n.
div2.p:
*)/an is sometimes used elliptically without a verb, when one can be supplied from the context. E.g. *oi( oi)ke/tai r(e/gkousin: a)ll' ou)k a)
 pro\ tou= (sc. e)/rregkon), the slaves are snoring; but they wouldn't have been doing so at this hour in old times. AR. Nub. 5.
*(ws ou)/t' a)

 e)cei/poimi/ tw|, ou)/t' a)
 te/knoisi toi=s e)moi=s (sc. e)cei/poimi), ste/rgwn o(/mws SOPH. O.C. 1528.
*ti/ a)
 dokei= soi *pri/amos (sc. pra=cai), ei) ta/d' h)/nusen; but what think you Priam would have done if he had accomplished what you have? AESCH. Ag. 935. *sw/frwn me

So pw=s ga a)/n (sc. ei)/h); how could it? pw=s ou)k a)/n; and similar phrases; especially w(/sper a)

*ka)/n in both its meanings (as kai/ with the adverb a)/n, and as kai/ with a_)/n = e)a/n) may stand without a verb. E.g. *)all' a)/ndra xrh\ dokei=n pesei=n a)

div2.head: Use of the Moods.
div2.p: This chapter treats of all constructions which require any other form of the finite verb than the simple indicative in absolute assertions and direct questions (2). The infinitive and participle are included here so far as either of them is used in indirect discourse, in protasis or apodosis, and in other constructions (as with pri/n and w(/ste) in which the finite moods also are used.
These constructions are discussed under the following heads:—
I. The potential optative and indicative.

II. The imperative and subjunctive in commands, exhortations, and prohibitions.—Subjunctive and indicative with mh/ and mh\ ou) in cautious assertions.— *(/opws and o(/pws mh/ with the independent future indicative or subjunctive.
III. The subjunctive (like the future indicative) in independent sentences.—The interrogative subjunctive.
IV. *ou) mh/ with the subjunctive or future indicative.
V. Final and object clauses after i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, o)/fra, and mh/.
VI. Conditional sentences.
VII. Relative and temporal sentences, including consecutive sentences with w(/ste, etc.
VIII. Indirect discourse.
IX. Causal sentences.
X. Expressions of a wish.

div2.head: Section I: The Potential Optative and Indicative.
div2.p: We find fully established in the Homeric language a use of the optative and the past tenses of the indicative with a)/n or ke/, which expresses the action of the verb as dependent on circumstances or conditions; as e)/lqoi a)/n, he might (could or would) go; h)=lqen a)/n, he might (could or would) have gone. Such an optative or indicative is called potential.

div2.head: I. Potential Optative.
div2.p: It has already been seen (13) that Homer sometimes uses the optative in a weak future sense, without ke/ or a)/n, to express a concession or permission. Such neutral forms seem to form a connecting link between the simple optative in wishes and the optative with a)/n, partaking to a certain extent of the nature of both. (For a full discussion of these forms and their relations, see Appendix I.) Such expressions seem to show that the early language used forms like e)/lqoimi and i)/doimi in two senses, I may go and I may see, or may I go and may I see, corresponding to e)/lqw and i)/dw in their two Homeric senses I shall go and I shall see (284), or let me go and let me see (257).

The neutral optatives like Il. iv. 18 are rare even in Homer, the language having already distinguished the two meanings in sense, and marked them in most cases by external signs. The optative expressing what may happen in the future took the particle ke/ or a)/n, and was negatived by ou), denoting the relations which we express by our potential mood with may, can, might, could, would, and should. Thus e(/loimi/ ke h)/ ken a(loi/hn, I may slay or I may be slain, Il. xxii. 253; a)nh\r de/ ken ou)/ ti *dio\s no/on ei)ru/ssaito, a man cannot contend against the will of Zeus, Il. viii. 143.When the idea of ability, possibility, or necessity is the chief element in the expression, and is not (as above) merely auxiliary, it is expressed by a special verb like du/namai, dei=, or xrh/. Especially, the idea of obligation is generally expressed by dei= or xrh/ with the infinitive; as tou=de xrh\ klu/ein, him we must obey, SOPH. Ant. 666. On the other hand, the simple optative (without ke/ or a)/n) was more and more restricted to the expression of a wish or exhortation, and was negatived by mh/; as mh\ ge/noito, may it not happen, pi/qoio/ moi, listen to me (Hom. Od. iv. 193) , as opposed to ou)k a)\n ge/noito, it could not happen. The potential forms e)/lqoimi a)/n and i)/doimi a)/n differ from the more absolute future indicative and the old subjunctive forms e)/lqw and i)/dw, I shall go and I shall see, by expressing a future act as dependent on some future circumstances or conditions, which may be more or less distinctly implied. The freedom of the earlier language extended the use of the potential optative to present and sometimes even to past time. See 438 and 440.

In most cases the limiting condition involved in the potential optative is not present to the mind in any definite form, and can be expressed in English only by such words as perchance, possibly, or probably, or by the auxiliaries could, would, should, might, etc. with the vague conditions which these imply (like if he should try, if he pleased, if he could, if what is natural should happen, etc.) Sometimes a more general condition is implied, like in any possible case; as ou)k a)
 dexoi/mhn tou=to, I would not accept this (on any terms); here the expression becomes nearly absolute, and may often be translated by our future, as ou)k a)
 meqei/mhn tou= qro/nou, I will not give up the throne (AR. Ran. 830), or (in positive sentences) by must, as pa/ntes qauma/zoien a)
 tou=to, all must admire this.

The optative thus used with no conscious feeling of any definite condition, but still implying that the statement is conditioned and not absolute, is the simplest and most primitive potential optative. It is equivalent to the Latin potential subjunctive, as credas, dicas, cernas, putes, etc., you may believe, say, perceive, think, etc. The Homeric language has six forms, all expressing futurity with different degrees of absoluteness and distinctness; as o)/yomai, o)/yomai/ ke, i)/dwmai, i)/dwmai/ ke, i)doi/mhn, i)doi/mhn ke (or a)/n), containing every step from I shall see to I should see. Of these only the first and the last (with a tradition of the second) survived the Homeric period, and the others (especially the fifth) were already disappearing during that period (240), being found unnecessary as the language became settled, and as the optative with ke/ or a)/n became more fixed as a future potential form.
In the following examples of the potential optative no definite form of condition is present to the mind:—

*)emoi\ de\ to/t' a)
 polu\ ke/rdion ei)/h, but it would at that time (be likely to) profit me far more. Il. xxii. 108.
*feu/gwmen: e)/ti ga/r ken a)lu/caimen kako
 h)=mar, let us flee; for perchance we may still escape the evil day. Od. x. 269.
*plhsi/on a)llh/lwn: kai/ ken dioi+steu/seias, the rocks are close together: you might perhaps shoot an arrow across the space. Od. xii. 102. So Od. xxiii. 125.
*ou)kou=n po/rois a)
 th/nde dwrea
 e)moi/; would you then grant me this favour? AESCH. Prom. 616. So pa=n ga a)
 .pu/qoio/ mou, for you can learn anything (you please) from me. Ib. 617.
*ti/ to/nd' a)
 ei)/pois a)/llo; what else could you say of this man? SOPH. Ant. 646. So Ant. 552 and 652. *polla\s a)
 eu(/rois mhxana/s, you can find many devices. And. 85. *(/eyomai/ toi kai\ ou)k a)
 leifqei/hn, I will follow you and in no case will I be left behind. HDT. iv. 97. *oi( me
 (sc. le/gontes) w(s ou)deni\ a)

 me
 swfrosu/nhn katama/qoi a)/n tis. XEN. An. i. 9, 3. So Mem. i. 3, Mem. 5, Mem. iii. 5, Mem. 1 and 7. *di\s e)s to
 au)to

 e)mbai/hs, you cannot step twice into the same river (saying of Heraclitus). PLAT. Crat. 402A. *ou) mh
 e)/sti kalli/wn o(do\s ou)d' a)
 ge/noito, there is none and there could be none. Ib. Phil. 16B; so 64 B. *)akou/ois a)/n, you can hear. Rep. 487E. *deica/tw w(s oi( *qettaloi\ nu=n ou)k a)

 e)/gwg' e)roi/mhn *lepti/nhn, but I would gladly ask Leptines. Id. xx. 129. *ei) h)gno/hse tau=ta, ge/noito ga a)
 kai\ tou=to, if he did not know this,—and it might easily so happen. Ib. 143. *ou)/t' a)

 meqei/mhn tou= qro/nou, I will not give up the throne. AR. Ran. 830.So ou)k a)
 dexoi/mhn, AESCH. Eum. 228. *ti/s ou)k a)

*bouloi/mhn a)/n, I should like, is used like velim. For e)boulo/mhn a)/n, vellem, see 246.

The potential optative in the second person may have the force of a mild command or exhortation. E.g.
*su\ me
 komi/zois a)
 seauto
 h(=| qe/leis, you may take yourself off whither you please (a milder expression than ko/mize seauto/n). SOPH. Ant. 444. So Ant. 1339.
*klu/ois a)
 h)/dh, *foi=be prostath/rie, hear me now. El. 637.
*xwroi=s a)
 ei)/sw Id. Ph. 674.
So probably Il. ii. 250: tw=| ou)k a)\n basilh=as a)na\ sto/m' e)/xwn a)goreu/ois, therefore you must not take kings upon your tongue and talk (or do not take, etc.)

Occasionally the potential optative expresses what may hereafter prove to be true or to have been true. E.g. *pou= dh=t' a)
 ei)=en oi( ce/noi; where may the strangers be? (i.e. where is it likely to turn out that they are?) SOPH. El. 1450. *(h ga e)mh\ (sc. sofi/a) fau/lh tis a)
 ei)/h, for it may turn out that my wisdom is of a mean kind. Symp. 175E. *(ellh/nwn tina/s fasi a(rpa/sai *eu)rw/phn: ei)/hsan d' a)
 ou(=toi *krh=tes, and these would prove to be Cretans (or to have been Cretans). HDT. i. 2. *au(=tai de\ ou)k a)
 pollai\ ei)/hsan, and these (the islands) would not prove to be many. THUC. i. 9.
This has nothing to do with the Homeric use of the optative with ke/ or a)/n in a present or a past sense (438; 440). See the similar use of the subjunctive with mh/ after verbs of fearing (92).

The potential optative may express every grade of potentiality from the almost pure future ou)k a)
 meqei/mhn, I will not give up (under any circumstances), to ou)k a)
 dikai/ws e)s kako
 pe/soimi/ ti, I could not justly fall into any trouble, SOPH. Ant. 240 , where dikai/ws points to the substance of a limiting condition, if justice should be done. From this the step is but slight to such cases as ou)/te e)sqi/ousi plei/w h)\ du/nantai fe/rein: diarragei=en ga a)/n, they do not eat more than they can carry; for (if they should) they would burst, XEN. Cyr. viii. 2, 21 , where ei) . . . e)sqi/oien is necessary to complete the sense and is clearly understood from the preceding words. A final step in the same direction is taken when the condition is actually stated as part of the sentence. As e)/lqoi a)/n means he would go (under some future circumstances), if these limiting circumstances are to be definitely expressed it is natural to use the corresponding form of condition, ei) with the optative, as ei) keleu/seias e)/lqoi a)/n, if you should command he would go. The protasis is thus assimilated to the apodosis in form, as it conforms to it in sense and general character. So when a conclusion is to follow such a condition as ei) keleu/seias, the corresponding optative with a)/n, i.e. the potential optative, is naturally chosen, although nothing but regard to harmony and symmetry makes either if you should command he will go or if you command he would go, or the equivalent Greek forms, objectionable. In fact, these very forms are far more common in the more fluid Homeric language than in the fixed and regular style of Attic prose. There is, therefore, no necessary or logical bond of union between two forms like ei) keleu/seias and e)/lqoi a)/n. This connexion is, indeed, far more the effect of assimilation in form, as appears especially when the apodosis contains an optative in a wish; as in w(s a)po/loito kai\ a)/llos o(/tis toiau=ta/ ge r(e/zoi, may another perish also who shall do the like (Hom. Od. i. 47) , where if a)pole/sqw had been used we should naturally have had r(e/zh|.
For examples of the optative with a)/n or ke/ with a definite protasis expressed or implied in the context, see 455 and 472.

The use of a)/n or ke/ with the potential optative had already become fixed in the Homeric language. A few cases of neutral optatives in Homer, which seem to show an early potential use without ke/ or a)/n, have been given above (13). Besides these, a few more distinctly potential optatives without a)/n or ke/ occur in Homer, but they are exceptions to the general usage even there. Such are the following:—

*ou)/ ti kakw/teron a)/llo pa/qoimi Il. xix. 321.
*tou/tou ge spome/noio kai\ e)k puro\s ai)qome/noio a)/mfw nosth/saimen Il. x. 246.
*(rei=a qeo/s g' e)qe/lwn a)mei/nonas dwrh/saito Il. x. 556 : see Od. iii. 231.
*xerma/dion la/be, o(\ ou) du/o g' a)/ndre fe/roien Il. v. 302 : so xx. 285. *ou)/ tis pei/seie gunai=ka Od. xiv. 122. So also Il. vii. 48, Il. xiv. 190, Il. xv. 45, Il. 197.
See, further, Theog. 723 and 725; PIND. Ol. x. 21, Py. iv. 118.

Some cases of the optative without a)/n occur with the indefinite e)/stin o(/s in Homer, and with e)/stin o(/stis, e)/stin o(/pws, e)/stin o(/poi, in the Attic poets. These form a class by themselves. E.g. *ou)k e)/sq' o(\s sh=s ge ku/nas kefalh=s a)pala/lkoi. Il. xxii. 348. *ou) ga\r e)/hn o(/s ti/s sfin e)pi\ sti/xas h(gh/saito. Il. ii. 687. *ou)k e)/sq' o(/pws le/caimi ta\ yeudh= kala/. AESCH. Ag. 620.
*ou)k e)/sq' o(/tw| mei/zona moi=ran nei/maim' h)\ soi Id. Prom. 292.
*ou)k e)/stin o(/stis plh\n e)mou= kei/raito/ nin. Id. Cho. 172. *)/est' ou)=n o(/pws *)/alkhstis e)s gh=ras mo/loi; EUR. Alc. 52. *)/esq' o(/poi tis stei/las paralu/sai yuxa/n; Ibid. 113.

On the other hand, a few other cases in the Attic poets are mere anomalies, even if we admit that the text is sound. E.g.
*tea\n, *zeu=, du/nasin ti/s a)ndrw=n u(perbasi/a kata/sxoi; what transgression of man can check thy power? SOPH. Ant. 605.
*)all' u(pe/rtolmon a)ndro\s fro/nhma ti/s le/goi; AESCH. Cho. 594.
*pw=s ou)=n ta/d), w(s ei)/poi tis, e)chma/rtanes; i.e. "as one might say." (?) EUR. Andr. 929.
*qa=sson h)\ le/goi tis pw/lous e)sth/samen Id. Hipp. 1186.
*(/wsper ei)/poi tis to/pos, as one would say to/pos (?) AR. Av. 180.
The cases cited from Attic prose are now generally admitted to be corrupt. See Krüger, ii. 54, 3, Anm. 8.

div2.head: II. Potential Indicative.
div2.p: As the potential optative represents a future act as dependent on future circumstances (234), so the potential indicative originally represents a past act as dependent on past circumstances. Therefore, while h)=lqen means he went, h)=lqen a)/n means he would have gone (under some past circumstances). It is probable that no definite limiting circumstances were present to the mind when this form first came into use, so that h)=lqen a)/n naturally signified merely that it was likely, possible, or probable that he went or (as we express it) that he might have gone or would have been likely to go, sometimes that he must have gone.

In this sense it appears as a past form of the potential optative, e.g. of e)/lqoi a)/n in the sense he might perchance go or he would be likely to go (in the future). The same relation appears in Latin, where credas, putes, cernas, dicas, you would be likely to believe, think, etc., are transferred to past time as crederes, putares, cerneres, diceres, you would have believed, thought, etc.We are probably justified in assuming that the past meaning which here appears in crederes, etc. is the original meaning of the Latin imperfect subjunctive in this use, as it certainly is that of the Greek imperfect indicative with a)/n. See 435. Here putet and putaret are precisely equivalent to oi)/oito a)/n, he would be likely to think, and w)/|eto a)/n, he would have been likely to think.

We find the potential indicative in its simplest use (last mentioned)—with no reference to any definite condition, but merely expressing past possibility, probability, or necessity— in all classes of Greek writers. E.g. *ou)d' a)\n e)/ti fra/dmwn per a)nh\r *sarphdo/na di=on e)/gnw, no longer would even a shrewd man have known Sarpedon. Il. xvi. 638. *(upo/ ken talasi/frona/ per de/os ei(=len, fear might have seized even a man of stout heart. Il. iv. 421.See other Homeric examples below.

*)all' h)=lqe me
 dh\ tou=to tou)/neidos ta/x' a)
 o)rgh=| biasqe
 ma=llon h)\ gnw/mh| frenw=n, but this reproach may perhaps have come from violence of wrath, etc. SOPH. O. T. 523. (Here ta/x' a)
 h)=lqe expresses past possibility, with no reference to any definite condition, unfulfilled or otherwise.) *qeoi=s ga h)=n ou(/tw fi/lon ta/x' a)/n ti mhni/ousin ei)s ge/nos pa/lai, for perchance it may have been thus pleasing to Gods who of old bore some wrath against our race. Id. O.C. 964. (According to the common punctuation ta/x' a)/n would be taken with mhni/ousin, = oi(\ ta/x' a)n ti e)mh/nion, who may perchance have borne some wrath, see PLAT. Phaedr. 265B , below; but the analogy of O. T. 523 favours the other interpretation.) *pro\s poi=on a)
 to/nd' au)to\s ou(dusseu\s e)/plei; i.e. who might this man have been to whom Ulysses was sailing? Ph. 572. *(\o qeasa/menos pa=s a)/n tis a)nh h)ra/sqh da/ios ei)=nai, every man who saw this drama (the Seven against Thebes) would have been eager to be a warrior. AR. Ran. 1022. (This is the past form of pa=s a)/n tis e)rasqei/h da/ios ei)=nai, every one would be eager, having no more reference to an unfulfilled condition than the latter has.) *die/bhsan, w(s me

THUC. vi. 2. *)eperrw/sqh d' a)/n tis e)kei=no i)dw/n, and any one would have been encouraged who saw that. XEN. Hell. iii. 4, 18. *qa=tton h)\ w(/s tis a)

*ti/ ga kai\ boulo/menoi metepe/mpesq' a)

Two Homeric examples are peculiar in their reference to time:—

*)alla\ ta/xista pei/ra o(/pws ken dh\ sh\n patri/da gai=an i(/khai: h)\ ga/r min zwo/n ge kixh/seai, h)/ ken *)ore/sths ktei=nen u(pofqa/menos, su\ de/ ken ta/fou a)ntibolh/sais, but strive with all speed to come to your fatherland; for either you will find him (Aegisthus)alive (and so can kill him yourself), or else Orestes may have already killed him before you come, and then you can go to his funeral. Od. iv. 544. (Here h)/ ken ktei=nen, by a change in the point of view, expresses what will be a past possibility at the time of the arrival of Menelaus, to which time the following optative is future.) *kai\ ga\r *trw=a/s fasi maxhta\s e)/mmenai a)/ndras, oi(/ ke ta/xista e)/krinan me/ga nei=kos, for they say that the Trojans are men of war, who would most speedily have decided a mighty strife (implying that they would therefore speedily decide any impending strife). Od. xviii. 261. (This was said by Ulysses before he went to Troy. See 249.)

In most cases of the past tenses of the indicative with a)/n there is at least an implied reference to some supposed circumstances different from the real ones, so that h)=lqen a)/n commonly means he would have gone (if something had not been as it was). When we speak of a past event as subject to conditions, we are apt to imply that the conditions were not fulfilled, as otherwise they would not be alluded to. This reference to an unfulfilled condition, however, does not make it necessary that the action of the potential indicative itself should be unreal, although this is generally the case. (See 412.) The unfulfilled past condition to which the potential indicative refers may be as vague and indistinct as the future condition to which the potential optative refers (235); as if he had wished, if he had tried, if it had been possible, in any case, and others which are implied in our auxiliaries might, could, would, should, etc., but are seldom expressed by us in words. Compare ou)de

 poih/seian, they could do no harm (i.e. if they should try), with ou)de
 a)

 e)poi/hsan, they could have done no harm (i.e. if they had tried). E.g. *ou) ga/r ken duna/mesqa qura/wn u(yhla/wn a)pw/sasqai li/qon, for we could not have moved the stone from the high doorway. Od. ix. 304.
*me/noim' a)/n: h)/qelon d' a)

*tou/tou ti/s a)/n soi ta)ndro\s a)mei/nwn eu(re/qh; who could have been found, etc.? Ib. 119.
*)/ekluon a(
 e)gw\ ou)d' a)
 h)/lpis' au)da/n, I heard a voice which I could never even have hoped to hear. Id. El. 1281. *du/) e)ce/lecas, oi(=n e)gw\ h(/kist' a)
 h)qe/lhs' o)lwlo/toin klu/ein. Id. Ph. 426. *klu/ein a)

 e)chlegxo/mhn, by which I might have been exposed. AR. Ran. 959. *to/te o)ye\ h)=n, kai\ ta\s xei=ras ou)k a)
 kaqew/rwn, it was then dark, and they would not have seen the show of hands (in voting). XEN. Hell. i. 7, 7. *poi/wn d' a)
 e)/rgwn h)\ po/nwn h)\ kindu/nwn a)pe/sthsan; from what acts, etc., would they have shrunk back (i.e. if they had been required of them)? Isoc. iv. 83. *pro\ pollw=n me

Id. xix. 91. (Here u(ph=rxen a)/n and h)=n a)/n refer to an actual fact, the possession of certain places; the apodosis prosh=n a)/n refers to something which was prevented from becoming a fact. This passage shows the natural steps from the potential form to the apodosis. See 247.)

When no definite condition is understood with the potential indicative, the imperfect with a)/n regularly refers to past time, according to the older usage (435), like the aorist; as in the examples above.

The imperfect referring to present time, which is common in apodosis after Homer (410), appears in these potential expressions chiefly in a few simple phrases, especially in e)boulo/mhn a)/n, vellem, I should wish, I should like (also I should have liked). Even in Homer the construction with w)/felon and the infinitive (424), which includes a form of potential indicative (415; 416), sometimes refers to present time. E.g.
*)egw\ d' e)boulo/mhn a)
 au)tou\s a)lhqh= le/gein: meth=n ga a)
 kai\ e)moi\ tou/tou ta)gaqou= ou)k e)la/xiston me/ros. nu=n de\ ou)/te pro\s th
 po/lin au)toi=s toiau=ta u(pa/rxei ou)/te pro\s e)me/, and I should like it if they spoke the truth; for (were that so) no small part of this advantage would be mine: but this is not true of them, etc. LYS. xii. 22.
*meidi/an, o(
 e)boulo/mhn a)
 pollw=n e(/neken zh=n, Midias, whom for many reasons I should like to have alive. AESCHIN. iii. 115.
See LYCURG. 3. (For e)boulo/mhn a)/n as past, see SOPH. Ph. 1239, quoted in 245.) See also AR. Nub. 680, e)kei=no d' h)=n a)
 kardo/ph, *klewnu/mh , and this would be kardo/ph, etc. For bouloi/mhn a)/n, velim, see 236.
For w)/felon and the infinitive as present in Homer, see 424.

It is but a slight step from the potential forms quoted in 245 and 246 to those which form the conclusion to an unfulfilled condition definitely implied in the context. After Homer the imperfect with a)/n may here refer to present time. E.g. *)alla/ ke kei=na ma/lista i)dw
 o)lofu/rao qumw=|, but you would have lamented most in your heart if you had seen this (i)dw/n = ei) ei)=des). Od. xi. 418.
*ou)de/ ken au)to\s u(pe/kfuge kh=ra me/lainan, a)ll' *(hfaistos e)/ruto, nor would he by himself have escaped, but Hephaestus rescued him. Il. v. 22. *)all' ei)ka/sai me
, h(du/s: ou) ga a)
 ka/ra polustefh\s w(=d' ei(=rpe, but, as it seems, he has good news; for (otherwise) he would not be coming with head thus thickly crowned. SOPH. OT 83 ; so O. C. 125, 146. *pollou= ga a)
 ta\ o)/rgana h)=n a)/cia, for instruments would be worth much (if they had this power). PLAT. Rep. 374D. *)/hgete th
 ei)rh/nhn o(/mws: ou) ga h)=n o(/ ti a)
 e)poiei=te, for there was nothing that you could have done (if you had not kept the peace). DEM. xviii. 43. *shmei=on de/: ou) ga a)
 deu=r' h(=kon w(s u(ma=s, for (otherwise) they would not have come hither to you. Id. xix. 58. *to/te *fili/ppw| prodedwke/nai pa/ntas a)
 e)/sxen ai)ti/an, in that case she (Athens) would have had the blame of having betrayed all to Philip Id. xviii. 200.See other examples in 472.

The final step is taken when an unreal condition is expressed as part of the sentence, forming the protasis to which the potential indicative is the apodosis; as h)=lqen a)\n ei) e)ke/leusa, he would have gone if I had commanded him. The dependent protasis, by a natural assimilation, has a past tense of the indicative corresponding to the form of the apodosis. On the other hand, when an unreal condition has been expressed, as ei) e)ke/leusa, the potential indicative is the natural form to state what would have been the result if the condition had been fulfilled. (See 390, 2; and 410.) The potential indicative does not change its essential nature by being thus made part of an unreal conditional expression, and it is not necessarily implied that its action did not take place (see 412). Although the latter is generally implied or inferred, while the reverse seldom occurs, still it is important to a true understanding of the nature of the indicative with a)/n to remember that it is not essential or necessary for it either to refer to an unreal condition or to denote in itself what is contrary to fact.
For a periphrastic form of potential indicative with e)/dei, xrh=n, etc., with the infinitive, see 415.
For the Homeric use of the present optative with ke/ or a)/n as a present potential form (like the later imperfect with a)/n), see 438.
For the rare Homeric optative with ke/ in the sense of the past tenses of the indicative with ke/ or a)/n, see 440.

From the primitive use of the past tenses of the indicative to express what was likely to occur under past circumstances, we may explain the iterative use of these tenses with a)/n (162), which is generally thought to have no connection with the potential indicative with a)/n. Thus h)=lqen a)/n, meaning originally he would have gone (under some past circumstances), might easily come to have a frequentative sense, he would have gone (under all circumstances or whenever occasion offered), and hence to mean he used to go. See SOPH. Ph. 443, o(\s ou)k a)\n ei(/let' ei)sa/pac ei)pei=n, o(/pou mhdei\s e)w/|h, (Thersites) who used never to be content to speak but once when all forbade him (lit. when nobody permitted him). Originally ou)k a)\n ei(/leto would mean he would not have been content (under any circumstances), hence he was never content. The optative e)w/|h (532) shows the nature of the expression here. See the examples under 162, and the last example under 244.

This construction is not Homeric; but it is found in Herodotus and is common in Attic Greek. There is no difficulty in understanding it as an offshoot of the potential indicative, when it is seen that the latter did not involve originally any denial of its own action.

div2.head: Section II.
div2.p: The Imperative and Subjunctive in Commands, Exhortations, and Prohibitions.—Subjunctive and Indicative with mh/ and mh\ ou) in Cautious Assertions.—*(/opws and o(/pws mh/ with the Independent Future Indicative, etc.

div2.head: Imperative in Commands, etc.
div2.p: The imperative is used to express a command, an exhortation, or an entreaty. E.g. *le/ge, speak thou. *feu=ge, begone! *)elqe/tw, let him come. *xairo/ntwn, let them rejoice. *)/erxesqon klisi/hn *phlhia/dew *)axilh=os. Il. i. 322. *zeu=, qewro\s tw=nde pragma/twn genou=. AESCH. Cho. 246.
For prohibitions, i.e. negative commands, see 259 and 260.

The imperative is often emphasised by a)/ge or a)/gete, fe/re, i)/qi, deu=ro or deu=te, come, look here; or by ei) d' a)/ge (474). *)/age, fe/re, and i)/qi may be singular when the imperative is plural, and in the second person when the imperative is in the third. E.g. *ei)/p' a)/ge moi kai\ to/nde, fi/lon te/kos, o(/s tis o(/d' e)sti/n. Il. iii. 192. , *)all' a)/ge mi/mnete pa/ntes, e)uknh/mides *)axaioi/ Il. ii. 331.
*ba/sk' i)/qi, ou)=le o)/neire, qoa\s e)pi\ nh=as *)axaiw=n. Il. ii. 8.
*)/age dh\ a)kou/sate. XEN. Ap. 14.
*)/agete deipnh/sate XEN. Hell. v. 1, 18.
*fe/r' ei)pe\ dh/ moi SOPH. Ant. 534.
*fe/re dh/ moi to/de ei)pe/ PLAT. Crat. 385B.
*)/iqi dh\ le/con h(mi=n prw=ton tou=to XEN. Mem. iii. 3, 3.
*)/iqi nun pari/stasqon AR. Ran. 1378.
*)/iqi nun libanwto\n deu=ro/ tis kai\ pu=r do/tw Ib. 871.
*kai/ moi deu=ro, w)= *me/lhte, ei)pe/ PLAT. Ap. 24 C . *deu=te, lei/pete ste/gas EUR. Med. 894.

The poets sometimes use the second person of the imperative with pa=s in hasty commands. E.g. *)/akoue pa=s, hear, every one! AR. Thes. 372. *xw/rei deu=ro pa=s u(phre/ths: to/ceue, pai=e: sfendo/nhn ti/s moi do/tw. Id. Av. 1186. *)/age dh\ siw/pa pa=s a)nh/r. Id. Ran. 1125.

The imperative is sometimes used by the dramatists after oi)=sq' o(/ and similar interrogative expressions, the imperative being really the verb of the relative clause.See Postgate in Transactions of the Cambridge Philological Society, III. 1, pp. 50-55. The difficulty of translating such expressions is similar to that of translating relatives and interrogatives with participles. E.g. *)all' oi)=sq' o(\ dra=son; tw=| ske/lei qe/ne th\n pe/tran, but do you know what you must do?—strike the rock with your leg! AR. Av. 54. *oi)=sq' o(/ moi su/mpracon; do you know what you must do for me? EUR. Her. 451. *oi)=sqa/ nun a(/ moi gene/sqw; desma\ toi=s ce/noisi pro/sqes, do you know what must be done for me?—put bonds on the strangers. Id. IT 1203. *oi)=sq' w(s poi/hson; do you know how you must act? SOPH. O.T. 543. (Compare EUR. Cyc. 131, oi)=sq' ou)=n o(\ dra/seis;
do you know what you are to do?)
The English may use a relative with the imperative, as in which do at your peril. See HDT. i. 89, ka/tison fula/kous, oi(\ lego/ntwn w(s a)nagkai/ws e)/xei. So SOPH. O.C. 473.
A peculiar interrogative imperative is found in mh\ e)ce/stw; is it not to be allowed? PLAT. Polit. 295E ; and e)panerwtw)= ei) kei/sqw, I ask whether it is to stand, Leg. 800E. (See 291.)

The imperative sometimes expresses a mere assumption, where something is supposed to be true for argument's sake. E.g. *plou/tei te ga\r kat' oi)=kon, ei) bou/lei, me/ga, kai\ zh= tu/ra|nnon sxh=m' e)/xwn, i.e. grant that you are rich and live in tyrant's state (lit. be rich, etc.) SOPH. Ant. 1168.
*proseipa/tw tina\ filikw=s o(/ te a)/rxwn kai\ o( i)diw/ths, suppose that both the ruler and the private man address one in a friendly way. XEN. Hier. viii. 3.

div2.head: First Person of Subjunctive as Imperative.
div2.p: The want of a first person in the imperative is supplied by the first person of the subjunctive, which expresses both positive and negative exhortations and appeals (the negative with mh/). *)/age, a)/gete, ei) d' a)/ge, fe/re, i)/qi, deu=ro, and deu=te (251) may precede this subjunctive; so sometimes e)/a, permit, let.

The first person plural is most common, and generally expresses an exhortation of the speaker to others to join him in doing or in not doing some act. E.g. *)/iwmen, let us go; mh\ i)/wmen, let us not go.
*oi)/kade/ per su\n nhusi\ new/meqa, to/nde d' e)w=men, let us sail homeward with our ships, and leave him. Il. ii. 236.
*)all' a)/ge mhke/ti tau=ta legw/meqa, but come, let us no longer talk thus. Il. xiii. 292 ; so ii. 435. *)all' a)/ge dh\ kai\ nw=i medw/meqa qou/ridos a)lkh=s, Il. iv. 418.
*ei) d' a)/get' a)mfi\ po/lin su\n teu/xesi peirhqw=men, Il. xxii. 381 ; so 392. *deu=te, fi/loi, to\n cei=non e)rw/meqa, Od. viii. 133.
*mh\ dh/ pw lu/wmeqa i(/ppous, a)ll' i)o/ntes *pa/troklon klai/wmen, Il. xxiii. 7.
*)all' ei) dokei=, ple/wmen, o(rma/sqw taxu/s, SOPH. Ph. 526.
*)epi/sxeton, ma/qwmen, Ib. 539 , *fe/re dh\ diapera/nwmen lo/gous EUR. And. 333.
*deu=ro/ sou ste/yw ka/ra, Bacch. 341.
*)epi/sxes, e)mba/lwmen ei)s a)/llon lo/gon, El. 962.
*parw=me/n te ou)=n w(/sper *ku=ros keleu/ei, a)skw=me/n te di) w(=n ma/lista dunhso/meqa kate/xein a(\ dei=, pare/xwme/n te h(ma=s au)tou/s, k.t.l. XEN. Cyr. viii. 1, 5.
*mh/ pote fw=men e(/neka tou/twn mhde\n ma=llo/n pote yuxh\n a)po/llusqai PLAT. Rep. 610B.
*)/ea dh\ nu=n e)n soi\ skeyw/meqa Id. Soph. 239B.

The less common first person singular is, in affirmative exhortations, generally preceded by a word like a)/ge, etc. (251), or by some other command, and the speaker appeals to himself to do something or to others for permission to do it. In negative appeals with mh/ the first person singular is rare and poetic; the speaker may call on others to avert some evil from himself, or he may utter a threat or a warning. E.g. *)all' a)/ge dh\ ta\ xrh/mat' a)riqmh/sw kai\ i)/dwmai, come, let me count the things and see. Od. xiii. 215.
*)all' a)/geq' u(mi=n teu/xe) e)nei/kw qwrhxqh=nai Od. xxii. 139.
*qa/pte me o(/tti ta/xista, pu/las *)ai/dao perh/sw, bury me as quickly as possible; let me pass the gates of Hades. Il. xxiii. 71. *)all' a)/ge nu=n e)pi/meinon, a)rh/ia teu/xea du/w. Il. vi. 340. *fe/re a)kou/sw, come, let me hear. HDT. i. 11.
*si=ga, pnoa\s ma/qw: fe/re pro\s ou)=s ba/lw EUR. H.F. 1059.
*)epi/sxet), au)dh\n tw=n e)/swqen e)kma/qw. Id. Hipp. 567. *le/ge dh\, i)/dw. PLAT. Rep. 457 C.

*mh/ se, ge/ron, koi/lh|sin e)gw\ para\ nhusi\ kixei/w, let me not find you at the ships! Il. i. 26. *mh/ seu a)kou/sw eu)xome/nou. Il. xxi. 475. *)alla/ m' e)/k ge th=sde gh=s po/rqmeuson w(s ta/xista, mh/d' au)tou= qa/nw. SOPH. Tr. 801.
*)=w cei=noi, mh\ dh=t' a)dikhqw=. Id. O.C. 174.

In the first person (255-257) both present and aorist subjunctive are used with mh/, the distinction of 259 applying only to the second and third persons. In affirmative exhortations the second and third persons of the subjunctive are not regularly used, the imperative being the only recognised form. But in SOPH. Ph. 300, fe/r), w)= te/knon, nu=n kai\ to\ th=s nh/sou ma/qh|s (if the text is sound), the positive ma/qh|s seems strangely to follow the analogy of the negative mh\ ma/qh|s. Nauck reads ma/qe here. See also to\ ya/fisma a)nateqa=| in an inscription quoted in Appendix I. p. 385.

div2.head: Imperative and Subjunctive in Prohibitions.
div2.p:
In prohibitions, in the second and third persons, the present imperative or the aorist subjunctive is used with mh/ and its compounds. The distinction of tense here is solely the ordinary distinction between the present and aorist (87), and has no reference to the moods. E.g. *mh\ poi/ei tou=to, do not do this (habitually), or do not go on doing this (or stop doing this); mh\ poih/sh|s tou=to, (simply) do not do this.
*)ecau/da, mh\ keu=qe no/w|, i(/na ei)/domen a)/mfw Il. i. 363.
*)atrei/dh, mh\ yeu/de' e)pista/menos sa/fa ei)pei=n Il. iv. 404.
*)argei=oi, mh/ pw/ ti meqi/ete qou/ridos a)lkh=s Il. iv. 234.
*ei)pe/ moi ei)rome/nw| nhmerte/a, mhd' e)pikeu/sh|s Od. xv. 263.
*)/hdh nu=n sw=| paidi\ e)/pos fa/o, mhd' e)pi/keuqe (compare the last example). Od. xvi. 168.
*tw=| nu=n mh/ moi ma=llon e)n a)/lgesi qumo\n o)ri/nh|s Il. xxiv. 568. See Il. xxiv. 778.
*mh\ dh/ me e(/lwr *danaoi=sin e)a/sh|s kei=sqai Il. v. 684.
*klu=qi mhde\ megh/rh|s Od. iii. 55.
*mh/ pws a)ndra/si dusmene/essin e(/lwr kai\ ku/rma ge/nhsqe, do not become prey and spoil to hostile men. Il. v. 487.
*mh/ pote a)po\ pa=san o)le/ssh|s a)glai+/hn Od. xix. 81.
*(umei=s de\ th=| gh=| th=|de mh\ baru\n ko/ton skh/yhsqe, mh\ qumou=sqe, mhd' a)karpi/an teu/chte AESCH. Eum. 800.
*(\on mh/t' o)knei=te, mh/t' a)fh=t' e)/pos kako/n SOPH. O.C. 731.
*mh\ qh=sqe no/mon mhde/na, a)lla\ tou\s bla/ptontas u(ma=s lu/sate. DEM. iii. 10. (Here qe/sqe would not be allowed; but lu/sate, an affirmative command, is regular.) *mh\ kata\ tou\s no/mous dika/shte: mh\ bohqh/shte tw=| peponqo/ti deina/: mh\ eu)orkei=te. Id. xxi. 211.
*mh\ pri/h|, pai=, da=|da AR. Nub. 614.
*kai\ mhdei\s u(pola/bh| me bou/lesqai laqei=n. Isoc. v. 93. *kai\ mhdei\s oi)e/sqw m' a)gnoei=n. Id. iv. 73.

The third person of the aorist imperative is sometimes used with mh/ in prohibitions; but the second person with mh/ is very rare and only poetic. E.g. *mhd' h( bi/a se mhdamw=s nikhsa/tw SOPH. Aj. 1334.
*mhde/ soi melhsa/tw AESCH. Prom. 332 ; so 1002. *kai\ mhdei\s u(mw=n prosdokhsa/tw a)/llws. PLAT. Ap. 17 C.

*tw=| mh/ moi pate/ras poq' o(moi/h| e)/nqeo timh=| Il. iv. 410 ; see Od. xxiv. 248.
*mh/ pw katadu/seo mw=lon *)/arhos Il. xviii. 134.
*mh\ yeu=son, w)= *zeu=, mh/ m' e(/lh|s a)/neu doro/s in SOPH. Peleus, Frag. 450, is parodied in AR. Thes. 870, mh\ yeu=son, w)= *zeu=, th=s e)piou/shs e)lpi/dos .

div2.head: Independent Subjunctive with mh/ Implying Fear (Homeric).
div2.p: In the following Homeric examples the independent subjunctive with mh/ expresses apprehension, coupled with a desire to avert the object of fear, both ideas being inherent in the construction. The third person is the most common here.

*mh\ dh\ nh=as e(/lwsi kai\ ou)ke/ti feukta\ pe/lwntai, may they not (as I fear they may) seize the ships and make it no longer possible to escape. Il. xvi. 128.
*mh\ dh/ moi tele/swsi qeoi\ kaka\ kh/dea qumw=|, may the Gods not bring to pass (as I fear they may) bitter woes for my soul. Il. xviii. 8.
*mh/ ti xolwsa/menos r(e/ch| kako\n ui(=as *)axaiw=n, may he not (as I fear he may) in his wrath do anything to harm the sons of the Achaeans. Il. ii. 195.
*)/w moi e)gw\, mh/ ti/s moi u(fai/nh|sin do/lon au)=te a)qana/twn Od. v. 356.
*mh/ pw/s m' e)kbai/nonta ba/lh| li/qaki proti\ pe/trh| ku=ma me/g' a(rpa/can, mele/h de/ moi e)/ssetai o(rmh/, I fear that some great wave may dash me against a solid rock, and my effort will (then) be in vain (the expression of fear being merged in an assertion). Od. v. 415. See also Il. xxi. 563; Od. v. 467, Od. xvii. 24, Od. xxii. 213.
*tw=n ei)/ ken pa/ntwn a)nth/somen, mh\ polu/pikra kai\ ai)na\ bi/as a)poti/seai e)lqw/n, I fear you may punish their violence only to our bitter grief (and may you not do this). Od. xvi. 255.
*mh/ ti kako\n r(e/cwsi kai\ h(me/as e)cela/swsin, a)/llwn d' a)fikw/meqa gai=an, may they not (as I fear) do us some harm and drive us out, and may we not come to some land of others. Od. xvi. 381.
*mh/ min e)gw\ me\n i(/kwmai i)w\n, o( de/ m' ou)k e)leh/sei, I fear I may approach him as I come, while he will not pity me. Il. xxii. 122 (see Od. v. 415, above). *mh/ toi kata\ pa/nta fa/gwsin kth/mata dassa/menoi, su\ de\ thu+si/hn o(do\n e)/lqh|s Od. xv. 12.
The present subjunctive occurs in Od. xv. 19, mh/ ti fe/rhtai , and in xvi. 87, mh/ min kertome/wsin . See also pe/lwntai in Il. xvi. 128, above. (See 258.)
In these examples sometimes the fear itself, and sometimes the desire to avert its object, is more prominent.

(a) By prefixing dei/dw or fobou=mai to any of the subjunctives with mh/ in 261, we get the full construction with verbs of fearing; as dei/dw mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, I fear they may seize the ships, in which mh\ e(/lwsi represents an original construction which at first followed dei/dw paratactically—I fear: may they not seize the ships— and afterwards became welded with it as a dependent clause. So if dei/dw were removed from a sentence like dei/dw mh/ ti pa/qh|sin, Il. xi. 470, we should have an independent clause like those quoted above. See mh\ dama/ssh| and dei/dw mh\ ge/nwmai, Od. v. 467 and 473.

(b) In like manner, by prefixing other verbs than those of fearing to such clauses, the original negative final clause with mh/ is developed; as maxou/meqa mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, we will fight that they may not seize the ships. Again, if the leading clause were removed from a sentence like au)tou= mi/mn' e)pi\ pu/rgw|, mh\ pai=d' o)rfaniko\n qh/h|s xh/rhn te gunai=ka, remain here on the tower, lest you make your child an orphan and your wife a widow, Il. vi. 431, there would remain mh/ . . . qh/h|s, do not make, or may you not make, in the originally independent form, like the clauses with mh/ in 261. (See 307.)

(*mh\ ou), with the Subjunctive.) The clause with mh/ expressing desire to avert an object of fear, in its original simple form as well as in the developed final construction, may refer to a negative object, and express fear that something may not happen. Here mh\ ou) is used with the subjunctive, like ne non in Latin.

Thus mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi being may they not seize the ships, mh\ ou) nh=as e(/lwsi would be may they not fail to seize the ships, implying fear that they may not seize them. Homer has one case of mh\ ou) after a verb of fearing: dei/dw mh\ ou)/ ti/s toi u(po/sxhtai to/de e)/rgon, Il. x. 39.He has several cases of mh\ ou) in final clauses and one in an object clause (354). Il. i. 28, mh/ nu/ toi ou) xrai/smh| skh=ptron kai\ ste/mma qeoi=o, is often cited as a case of independent mh\ ou), meaning beware lest the staff and fillet of the God shall prove of no avail to you. So Delbrück (I. p. 119), who nevertheless quotes Il. i. 565, a)ll' a)ke/ousa ka/qhso e)mw=| d' e)pipei/qeo mu/qw|, mh/ nu/ toi ou) xrai/smwsin o(/soi qeoi/ ei)s' e)n *)olu/mpw|, as containing a dependent final clause. In the two other cases of mh\ ou) with the subjunctive in Homer, Il. xv. 164 (an object clause, see 354), and xxiv. 569 (final), the dependence of the clause with mh\ ou) is even more obvious; and in Il. xxiv. 584 we have in mh\ ou)k e)ru/saito the decisive proof that this clause is felt to be dependent in the change from the subjunctive to the optative after a past tense. It is therefore more than doubtful whether mh\ ou) xrai/smh| in Il. i. 28 is not dependent on mh/ se kixei/w in vs. 26. Plato in paraphrasing this passage ( Rep. 393E) takes the clause as final and dependent (see 132). But, whether we have a case of independent mh\ ou) with the subjunctive in Homer or not, there can be no doubt that this is the original form from which came the dependent final clause with mh\ ou).

After Homer we have the independent clause with mh/ in Aeschylus, Ag. 134 and 341; in Euripides we have independent mh/ in Alc. 315 (mh\ sou\s diafqei/rh| ga/mous), Orest. 776 (mh\ la/bwsi/ s' a)/smenoi), H. F. 1399 (ai(=ma mh\ soi=s e)como/rcwmai pe/plois), and mh\ ou) in Tro. 982 (mh\ ou) pei/sh|s sofou/s), besides Rhes. 115 (mh\ ou) mo/lh|s). Aristophanes, Eccl. 795, has a doubtful mh\ ou) la/bh|s (Heindorf and Meineke, for MSS. la/bois).
