Besides these few cases, we have in Plato three of mh/ with the subjunctive implying apprehension in the Homeric sense (261): Euthyd. 272C (mh\ ou)=n tis o)neidi/sh|), Symp. 193B (mh/ moi u(pola/bh|), Leg. 861E (mh/ tis oi)/htai).
Euripides and Herodotus are the first after Homer to use mh\ ou) in dependent clauses of fear (306).

div2.head: Subjunctive with mh/ and mh\ ou) in Cautious Assertions.
div2.p: In Herodotus v. 79 we have a)lla\ ma=llon mh\ ou) tou=to h)=| to\ manth/ion, but I suspect rather that this may prove not to be the meaning of the oracle. This is the first example of a construction, very common in Plato, used also by Aristotle, and found once in Demosthenes, in which mh/ with the subjunctive expresses a suspicion that something may be (or may prove to be) true, and mh\ ou) with the subjunctive a suspicion that something may not be true; the former amounting to a cautious assertion, the latter to a cautious negation. Examples from Plato are:—

*mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=| to\ a)lhqe\s ei)pei=n, I am afraid the truth may be too rude a thing to tell. Gorg. 462 E. *mh\ w(s a)lhqw=s tau=ta ske/mmata h)=| tw=n r(a|di/ws a)poktinnu/ntwn, I suspect these may prove to be considerations for those, etc. Crit. 48 C. *mh\ fau=lon h)=| kai\ ou) kaq' o(do/n, I think it will be bad and not in the right way (i.e. mh\ ou) h)=|). Crat. 425B. *)alla\ mh\ ou)x ou(/tws e)/xh|, a)ll' a)nagkai=on h)=| ei)do/ta ti/qesqai (i.e. mh\ h)=|). Crat. 436B. *)alla\ mh\ ou) tou=t' h)=| xalepo
, qa/naton e)kfugei=n, but I suspect this may not be the hard thing, to escape death. Ap. 39A. *(hmi=n mh\ ou)de
 a)/llo skepte/on h)=|, I am inclined to think we have nothing else to consider. Crit. 48 C. *mh\ ou) de/h| u(pologi/zesqai, I think there will be no need of taking into account, etc. Crit. 48D. *mh\ ou)k h)=| didakto
 a)reth/, it will probably turn out that virtue is not a thing to be taught. Men. 94E *)alla\ mh\ ou)x ou(=toi h(mei=s w)=men, but I think we shall not prove to be of this kind. Symp. 194COther examples in Plato are Phaed. 67B, Phaed. 69A; Theaet. 188D; Crat. 429C, Crat. 432A, Crat. 432B, Crat. 435C, Crat. 438C, Crat. 440C; Men. 89C, Men. 94B; Lys. 209A, Lys. 219D, Lys. 220A; Symp. 214C; Parm. 130D, Parm. 132B, Parm. 134E, Parm. 136D; Leg. 635; Theag. 122B; Amat. 137 See Weber B. (pp. 191, 192), who gives these examples in Plato, with HDT. v. 79 and DEM. i. 26, as the only cases of independent mh/ or mh\ ou) in this peculiar sense before Aristotle.
See also Aristotle, Eth. x. 2. 4, mh\ ou)de\n le/gwsin (v. l. le/gousin), there can hardly be anything in what they say. (See 269.)
In DEM. i. 26 we have mh\ li/an pikro\n ei)pei=n h)=|, I am afraid it may be too harsh a thing to say.
The present subjunctive here, as in dependent clauses of fear (92), may refer to what may prove true.

In these cautious assertions and negations, although no desire of the speaker to avert an object of fear is implied, there is always a tacit allusion to such a desire on the part of some person who is addressed or referred to, or else an ironical pretence of such a desire of the speaker himself.

The subjunctive with mh/ in this sense is sometimes found in dependent clauses. E.g. *(/ora mh\ a)/llo ti to\ gennai=on kai\ to\ a)gaqo\n h)=| tou= sw/|zein kai\ sw/|zesqai, see to it lest (it prove true that) these may be different things, etc. PLAT. Gorg. 512D. The common translation, see whether they may not be different, gives the general sense, but not the construction, which is simply that of mh\ a)/llo ti h)=| (265) transferred to a dependent clause.

In a few cases Plato has mh/ with the subjunctive in a cautious question with a negative answer implied. As mh\ a)/llo ti h)=| tou=to means this may possibly be something else, so the question mh\ a)/llo ti h)=| tou=to; means can this possibly be something else? The four examples given by Weber are:—

*mh/ ti a)/llo h)=| para\ tau=ta; can there be any other besides these? Rep. 603C. *)=ara mh\ a)/llo ti h)=| qa/natos h)\ tou=to; is it possible that death can prove to be anything but this? Phaed. 64C. So mh/ ti a)/llo h)=| h)/, k.t.l.; Parm. 163D. *)alla\ mh\ e)mh\ periergi/a h)=| kai\ to\ e)rwth=sai/ se peri\ tou/tou; but can it be that even asking you about this is inquisitiveness on my part? Sisyph. 387 C (this can be understood positively, it may be that it is, etc.).

In XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 12 , the same interrogative construction occurs with mh\ ou): mh\ ou)=n ou) du/nwmai e)gw\ ta\ th=s dikaiosu/nhs e)/rga e)chgh/sasqai; do you suspect that I shall be unable to explain the works of Justice?

In PLAT. Phil. 12D we have pw=s ga\r h(donh/ ge h(donh=| mh\ ou)x o(moio/taton a)\n ei)/h; for how could one pleasure help being most like another? Here ei)/h a)/n takes the place of h)=|, and pw=s shows that the original force of mh/ is forgotten.

div2.head: Indicative with mh/ and mh\ ou) in Cautious Assertions.
div2.p: The present or past tenses of the indicative with mh/ or mh\ ou) may express a similar cautious assertion or suspicion about a present or past act. As fobou=mai mh\ pa/sxei (or e)/paqen) means I fear that he is suffering (or suffered), so mh\ pa/sxei or mh\ e)/paqen may mean I suspect he is suffering or I suspect he suffered, and mh\ ou) pa/sxei or mh\ ou)k e)/paqen may mean I suspect he does not (or did not) suffer. (Cf. 265.) E.g. *mh\ ga\r tou=to me\n, to\ zh=n o(posondh\ xro/non, to/n ge w(s a)lhqw=s a)/ndra e)ate/on e)sti\ kai\ ou) filoyuxhte/on (i.e. kai\ mh\ ou) fil.), for I am of the opinion that this, merely living for a certain time, is what one who is truly a man should disregard, and that he should not be fond of life. PLAT. Gorg. 512D. (This passage is often strangely emended and explained.) *)all' a)/ra mh\ ou) toiau/thn u(polamba/neis sou th\n ma/qhsin e)/sesqai, I suspect that you do not think your learning will be like this. Prot. 312A. *)alla\ mh\ tou=to ou) kalw=s w(mologh/samen, but perhaps we did not do well in assenting to this. Men. 89C. (This may be interrogative (268): can it be that we did not do well, etc.?)
So Aristotle, Eth. x. 1, Eth. 3, mh/ pote de\ ou) kalw=s le/getai, but it may be that this is not well said: compare x. 2, Eth. 4, quoted in 265.
Apart from independent sentences with mh\ ou) (263-269), this double negative occurs chiefly in ordinary clauses after verbs of fearing where the object of fear is negative (305; 365).

div2.head: o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ with the Independent Future Indicative, etc.
div2.p: The Athenians developed a colloquial use of o(/pws or o(/pws mh/ with the future indicative to express either a positive exhortation or command or a prohibition. Thus o(/pws tou=to e)rei=s, see that you say this, is a familiar way of saying ei)pe\ tou=to. So o(/pws mh\ tou=to e)rei=s is equivalent to mh\ tou=to ei)/ph|s. This expression was probably suggested and certainly encouraged by the common Attic construction of o(/pws and the future after verbs of striving, taking care, etc. (339); so that it is common to explain this form by an ellipsis of sko/pei in sko/pei o(/pws tou=to e)rei=s, see to it that you say this. But we may doubt whether any definite leading verb was ever in mind when these familiar exhortations were used (see 273).

The earliest example is AESCH. Prom. 68, o(/pws mh\ sauto
 oi)ktiei=s pote , beware lest at some time you may have yourself to pity, which conveys a warning, like mh/ se kixei/w, Il. i. 26.In AESCH. Ag. 600, we have the first person singular with o(/pws (used like the subjunctive in 257): o(/pws d' a)/rista to
 e)mo
 ai)doi=on po/sin speu/sw de/casqai (not mentioned by Weber). In Sophocles there is only one case, O. T. 1518, gh=s m' o(/pws pe/myeis a)/poikon , send me forth an exile from the land (like pe/myon me). Five examples in Euripides are simple exhortations, as a)ll' o(/pws a)nh e)/sei, but see that you are a man, Cycl. 595 ; so also Cycl. 630, H. F. 504, I. T. 321, Or. 1060 (with doubtful construction): one conveys a warning, Bacch. 367, *penqeu\s d' o(/pws mh\ pe/nqos ei)soi/sei do/mois toi=s soi=si , beware lest Pentheus bring sorrow (pe/nqos) into your house.

We find the greater part of the examples of 271 in the colloquial language of Aristophanes,See Weber, pp. 85, 95, 113, 124, for the history of this usage. Weber cites 41 examples from Aristophanes, besides Ach. 343; 13 from Plato, whose extraordinary use of the independent sentence with mh/ has been noticed; 7 from Xenophon, 9 from Demosthenes, 2 from Lysias, and one from Isaeus. who often uses the imperative and o(/pws with the future as equivalent constructions in the same sentence. E.g. *kata/qou su\ ta\ skeu/h taxe/ws, xw)/pws e)rei=s e)ntau=qa mhde\n yeu=dos, put down the packs quickly, and tell no lies here. Ran. 627. *)all' e)/mba xw)/pws a)rei=s th\n *sw/teiran. Ib. 377.See also Eq. 453, Eq. 495, Eccl. 952, Ach. 955.
*nu=n ou)=n o(/pws sw/seis me, so now save me. Nub. 1177.
*(/opws pare/sei moi kai\ su\ kai\ ta\ paidi/a, be on hand, you and your children (an invitation). Av. 131.
*)/age nun o(/pws eu)qe/ws u(farpa/sei Nub. 489.

(Examples from Prose.) *(/opws ou)=n e)/sesqe a)/ndres a)/cioi th=s e)leuqeri/as, prove yourselves men worthy of freedom. XEN. An. i. 7, 3. *(/opws moi, w)= a)/nqrwpe, mh\ e)rei=s o(/ti e)/sti ta\ dw/deka di\s e(/c, see that you do not tell me that twice six are twelve. PLAT. Rep. 337 B: so 336 D. *fe/re dh\ o(/pws memnhso/meqa tau=ta. Gorg. 495D. *(/opws ge, a)/n ti tou/twn gi/gnhtai, tou/tous e)paine/sesqe kai\ timh/sete kai\ stefanw/sete, e)me\ de\ mh/: kai\ me/ntoi ka)/n ti tw=n e)nanti/wn, o(/pws tou/tois o)rgiei=sqe. DEM. xix. 45. *(/opws toi/nun peri\ tou= pole/mou mhde\n e)rei=s, see therefore that you say nothing about the war. Ib. 94.
One case occurs in Herodotus in iii. 142. (See also 280, below.)

Although the second person is naturally most common in these expressions, the first and third persons also occur. E.g. *(/opws de\ to\ su/mbolon labo/ntes e)/peita plhsi/on kaqedou/meqa. AR. Eccl. 297. *oi)/moi ta/las, o( *zeu\s o(/pws mh/ m' o)/yetai, don't let Zeus see me! Id. Av. 1494. *kai\ o(/pws, w(/sper e)rwtw=si proqu/mws, ou(/tw kai\ poiei=n e)qelh/sousin. DEM. viii. 38. (See also 278.)
*)/age and fe/re (251) sometimes introduce this construction. See examples above (273 and 274).

In a few cases the prohibition with o(/pws mh/ takes the form of a warning. Besides AESCH. Prom. 68 and Bacch. 367, quoted above, see XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 18 , o(/pws ou)=n mh\ a)polei= mastigou/menos, look out that you are not flogged to death. So PLAT. Prot. 313 C, quoted in 283.

*(/opws mh/ with the future indicative or the subjunctive sometimes occurs in independent sentences implying a desire to avert something that is not desired, like mh/ with the subjunctive in Homer and sometimes in Attic Greek (261; 264). E.g. *(/opws mh\ ai)sxroi\ me\n fanou/meqa a)sqenei=s de\ e)so/meqa, let us not appear base and be weak (as I fear we may). XEN. Cyr. iv. 2, 39. *(/opws mh\ a)nagka/swmen (so most MSS.) au)tou\s, ka)\n mh\ bou/lwntai, a)gaqou\s gene/sqai, there is danger of our compelling them to become brave, even against their will. Ib. iv. 1, Ib. 16. *kai\ o(/pws ge mhde\ to\ xwri/on h(de/ws o(rw=sin e)/nqa kate/kanon h(mw=n tou\s summa/xous, and let us not allow them even to enjoy the sight of the place where they slew our allies. Ib. v. 4, Ib. 21. *(/opws mh\ fh/sh| tis h(ma=s h(dupaqei=n, take care lest any one say of us, etc. Id. Symp. iv. 8. *)all' o(/pws mh\ ou)x oi(=o/s t' e)/somai, proqumou/menos de\ ge/lwta o)flh/sw, but I am afraid that I shall not have the power, but that in my zeal I shall make myself ridiculous. PLAT. Rep. 506D. So Men. 77A.

These cases (278) are analogous to those of o(/pws mh/ with the future indicative or the subjunctive after verbs of fearing, in place of the simple mh/ (370). They are also a connecting link between the subjunctive with mh/ in prohibitions and the rare future indicative with mh/ in the same sense; as tau/thn fula/cete th\n pi/stin, kai\ mh\ boulh/sesqe ei)de/nai, hold fast to this security, and do not wish to know, etc., DEM. xxiii. 117 (see other examples in 70).

In a few cases o(/pws mh/ with the subjunctive expresses a cautious assertion, where the simple mh/ is generally used (265). E.g. *kai\ o(/pws mh\ e)n me
 toi=s zwgrafh/masin h)=| tou=to, and it may be that this will prove true in the case of pictures. PLAT. Crat. 430D. Weber (p. 264) quotes HDT. vi. 85 for this sense: o(/kws e)c u(ste/rhs mh/ ti u(mi=n, h)
 tau=ta poih/shte, panw/leqron kako
 e)s th
 xw/rhn e)mba/lwsi, it is not unlikely that they will turn about and bring some fatal harm on your country; but this can be understood like the examples in 278.

*(ws a)
 skopoi\ nu=n h)=|te tw=n ei)rhme/nwn, mind now and guard what I have said (i.e. be watchful to do it), SOPH. Ant. 215 , must be brought under this head (271). In the early stage of the Attic construction of o(/pws with the future, of which only two cases occur in Aeschylus and one in Sophocles (272), w(s a)
 h)=|te was here used like o(/pws e)/sesqe. Compare e)pimelei=sqai w(s a)
 praxqh=|, Hipp. ix. 2 (see 351).

In AR. Ach. 343 is the single case of o(/pws mh/ with a present tense, expressing a suspicion and apprehension concerning a present ground of fear: a)ll' o(/pws mh/ n' toi=s tri/bwsin e)gka/qhntai/ pou li/qoi, but I am afraid they now have stones hidden somewhere in their cloaks. This bears the same relation to the common o(/pws mh/ with the future (272) that fobou=mai mh\ pa/sxousin, I fear that they are suffering (369, AR. Ach. 1), bears to fobou=mai mh\ pa/sxwsin, I fear that they may suffer (365); and the same that mh\ tou=to e)ate/on e)sti/ (269) bears to mh\ skepte/on h)=| (265).

Positive independent sentences with o(/pws all have the future indicative, the regular form in dependent object clauses of this nature (339). Among the 33 independent clauses with o(/pws mh/ which are cited (excluding AR. Ach. 343) ten have the subjunctive, and four others have more or less MS. support for the subjunctive. Of the ten, the two quoted in 280, and the three from Xenophon quoted in 278, are either in cautious assertions or in sentences implying fear or the averting of danger, where the subjunctive is the regular form. The other five express warning, and are quoted here:—

*opws de\ tou=to mh\ dida/ch|s mhde/na, but be sure that you teach this to nobody. AR. Nub. 824.
*kai\ o(/pws ge mh\ o( sofisth\s e)capath/sh| h(ma=s, and do not let the sophist cheat us. PLAT. Prot. 313 C. *)all' o(/pws mh/ ti h(ma=s sfh/lh| to\ a)ei\ tou=to. Id. Euthyd. 296A. *(/opws mhdei/s se pei/sh|, do not let anybody persuade you, etc. Charm. 157B. *kai\ o(/pws mh\ poih/shte o(\ polla/kis u(ma=s e)/blayen, and see that you do not do what has often harmed you. DEM. iv. 20.

Four of these subjunctives are of the s- class, easily confounded with the future indicative, and the judgment of scholars on these has depended to a great extent upon their opinion about the admissibility of the subjunctive with o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ in dependent object clauses (339). This question will be discussed in 364. But it may fairly be claimed, independently of the main question, that these cases of o(/pws mh/ with the subjunctive in prohibitions are supported by the analogy of mh/ with the subjunctive in the same sense. Thus mh\ dida/ch|s, do not teach, makes o(/pws mh\ dida/ch|s in the same sense much more natural than the positive o(/pws dida/ch|s would be, for which there is no such analogy and little or no MS. authority. On this ground the examples are given above as they stand in the MSS.

div2.head: Section III: Subjunctive, like the Future Indicative, in Independent Sentences.—Interrogative Subjunctive.
Homeric Subjunctive.
div2.p:
In the Homeric language the subjunctive (generally the aorist) may be used in independent sentences, with the force of a future indicative. The negative is ou). E.g. *ou) ga/r pw toi/ous i)/don a)ne/ras ou)de\ i)/dwmai, for I never yet saw nor shall I ever see such men. Il. i. 262.
*(umi=n e)n pa/ntessi perikluta\ dw=r' o)nomh/nw, I will enumerate the gifts before you all. Il. ix. 121.
*du/somai e)s *)ai/dao kai\ e)n neku/essi faei/nw, I will descend to Hades and shine among the dead (said by the Sun). Od. xii. 383. (Here the future du/somai and the subjunctive faei/nw do not differ in force.) *mnh/somai ou)de\ la/qwmai *)apo/llwnos e(ka/toio, I will remember and will not forget the far-shooting Apollo. Hymn. Ap. 1.
*au)tou= oi( qa/naton mhti/somai, ou)de/ nu to/n ge gnwtoi/ te gnwtai/ te puro\s lela/xwsi qano/nta, i.e., they shall not give his dead body the honour of a funeral pyre. Il. xv. 349.
*ei) de/ ke teqnhw=tos a)kou/sw, sh=ma/ te/ oi( xeu/w kai\ e)pi\ kte/rea kterei+/cw, I will raise a mound for him, and pay him funeral honours. Od. ii. 222.
*ou) ga/r ti/s me bi/h| ge e(kw\n a)e/konta di/htai Il. vii. 197.
*kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin, and some one will say. Il. vi. 459. (In vs. 462, referring to the same thing, we have w(/s pote/ tis e)re/ei.) *ou)k e)/sq' ou(=tos a)nh\r ou)d' e)/ssetai ou)de\ ge/nhtai, o(/s ken *thlema/xw| sw=| ui(e/i xei=ras e)poi/sei Od. xvi. 437.
*ou)de/ min a)nsth/seis: pri\n kai\ kako\n a)/llo pa/qh|sqa, nor will you bring him back to life; sooner will you suffer some new evil besides. Il. xxiv. 551 (the only example of the second person).

This Homeric subjunctive, like the future indicative, is sometimes joined with ke/ or a)/n in a potential sense. This enabled the earlier language to express an apodosis with a sense between that of the optative with a)/n and that of the simple future indicative, which the Attic was unable to do. (See 201 and 452.) E.g. *ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/h|sin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, but if he does not give her up, I will take her myself. Il. i. 324. (Here e(/lwmai/ ken has a shade of meaning between e(loi/mhn ken, I would take, and ai(rh/somai, I will take, which neither Attic Greek nor English can express. See 235, end.) *th
 me
 pe/myw, e)gw\ de/ k' a)/gw *brishi/da, her I will send; but I shall take Briseis. Il. i. 184. *nu=n d' a)
 polla\ pa/qh|si fi/lou a)po\ patro\s a(martw/n, but now he must suffer much, etc. Il. xxii. 505. *(=his u(peropli/h|si ta/x' a)/n pote qumo
 o)le/ssh|, by his own insolence he may perchance lose his life. Il. i. 205.
In the following cases the subjunctive and the optative with ke/ or a)/n are contrasted:—

*)/allon k' e)xqai/rh|si brotw=n, a)/llon ke filoi/h, one mortal he (a king) will hate, and another he may love. Od. iv. 692.
*ei)/ ti/s se i)/doito, au)ti/k' a)
 e)cei/poi *)agame/mnoni, kai/ ken a)na/blhsis lu/sios nekroi=o ge/nhtai, if any one should see you, he would straightway tell Agamemnon, and there might (may) be a postponement, etc. Il. xxiv. 653.
*ei) me
 dh\ a)nti/bion su
 teu/xesi peirhqei/hs, ou)k a)/n toi xrai/smh|si bio\s kai\ tarfe/es i)oi/, Il. xi. 386. Compare h(/n x' u(mi=n sa/fa ei)/pw o(/te pro/tero/s ge puqoi/mhn, (a message) which I will (would) tell you plainly so soon as I shall (should) hear it, Od. ii. 43 , with h(/n x' h(mi=n sa/fa ei)/poi o(/te pro/tero/s ge pu/qoito, Od. ii. 31 , — both referring to the same thing.

div2.head: Interrogative Subjunctive.
div2.p:
*ph=| t' a)/r' e)gw\, fi/le te/knon, i)/w; teu= dw/maq' i(/kwmai; h)= i)qu\s sh=s mhtro\s i)/w kai\ soi=o do/moio; whither shall I go? to whose house shall I come? etc. Od. xv. 509.
*)=h au)to\s keu/qw; fa/sqai de/ me qumo\s a)nw/gei Od. xxi. 194.
*)=w *zeu=, ti/ le/cw; poi= frenw=n e)/lqw, pa/ter; SOPH. O.C. 310.
*)/wmoi e)gw\, pa= bw=; pa= stw=; pa= ke/lsw; EUR. Hec. 1056. *poi= tra/pwmai; poi= poreuqw=; Ib. 1099. *ei)/pw ti tw=n ei)wqo/twn, w)= de/spota; shall I make one of the regular jokes? AR. Ran. 1. *ti/na ga\r ma/rtura mei/zw para/sxwmai; i.e. how shall I bring forward a greater witness? DEM. xix. 240. *mhd), e)a/n ti w)nw=mai, e)/rwmai o(po/sou pwlei=; may I not ask, etc.? *mhd' a)pokri/nwmai ou)=n, a)/n ti/s me e)rwta=| ne/os, e)a\n ei)dw=; and may I not answer, etc.? XEN. Mem. i. 2, 36. *mh\ a)pokri/nwmai, a)ll' e(/teron ei)/pw; PLAT. Rep. 337B. So mh\ fw=men; Ib. 554B *misqwsw/meqa ou)=n kh/ruka, h)\ au)to\s a)nei/pw; Ib. 580B. *mequ/onta a)/ndra pa/nu sfo/dra de/cesqe sumpo/thn, h)\ a)pi/wmen; will you receive him, or shall we go away? Symp. 212E. *)=ara mh\ ai)s xunqw=men to\n *persw=n basile/a mimh/sasqai; shall we then be ashamed to imitate the king of the Persians? —we shall not be ashamed; shall we? XEN. Oec. iv. 4.

*pou= dh\ bou/lei kaqizo/menoi a)nagnw=men; where wilt thou that we sit down and read? PLAT. Phaedr. 228E. (So ib. 263 E.) *bou/lei ou)=n e)piskopw=men o(/pou h)/dh to\ dunato/n e)sti; XEN. Mem. iii. 5, 1. *bou/lei la/bwmai dh=ta kai\ qi/gw ti/ sou; SOPH. Phil. 761. *bou/lesq' e)peispe/swmen; EUR. Hec. 1042. *qe/leis mei/nwmen au)tou= ka)nakou/swmen go/wn; SOPH. El. 81. *ti/ soi qe/leis dh=t' ei)ka/qw; Id. O.T. 650.
*qe/lete qhrasw/meqa *penqe/ws *)agau/hn mhte/r' e)k bakxeuma/twn, xa/rin t' a)/nakti qw=men; EUR. Bacch. 719.
*bou/lesqe to\ o(/lon pra=gma a)fw=men kai\ mh\ zhtw=men; AESCHIN. i. 73.

In PLAT. Rep. 372 E, we find ei) d' au)= bou/lesqe kai\ flegmai/nousan po/lin qewrh/swmen, ou)de\n a)pokwlu/ei, but if, again, you will have us examine an inflamed state, there is nothing to prevent. This shows that bou/lesqe is not parenthetical, but is felt to be the leading verb on which the subjunctive depends (see 288). In Phaed. 95E, i(/na mh/ ti diafu/gh| h(ma=s, ei)/ te/ ti bou/lei prosqh=|s h)\ a)fe/lh|s, the subjunctives may depend on i(/na.

*ei) bou/lesqe qewrh/swmen, if you wish us to examine, quoted in 287, shows that we have in bou/lesqe with the subjunctive a parataxis not yet developed into a leading and a dependent clause. It is probable that nothing like this was felt in the simple subjunctive as it is found in Homer. The original interrogative subjunctive is probably the interrogative form corresponding to the subjunctive in exhortations (256); e)/lqwmen, let us go, becoming e)/lqwmen; shall we go? (See Kühner, § 394, 5.) When bou/lei and bou/lesqe were first introduced in appeals to others, the two questions were doubtless felt to be distinct; as bou/lesqe; ei)/pw; do you wish? shall I speak?— which were gradually welded into one, do you wish that I speak? Compare in Latin cave facias, — visne hoc videamus? etc. No conjunction could be introduced to connect bou/lei or qe/leis to the subjunctive in classic Greek, as these verbs could have only the infinitive; but in later Greek, where i(/na could be used after qe/lw, the construction was developed into qe/lete i(/na ei)/pw; do you wish me to speak? See pa/nta o(/sa a)
 qe/lhte i(/na poiw=sin u(mi=n oi( a)/nqrwpoi, whatsoever ye would that men should do unto you, N. T. MATTH. vii. 12. So qe/lw i(/na dw=|s moi th
 kefalh
 *)iwa/nnou tou= baptistou=. MARC. vi. 25.These forms appear in the New Testament side by side with the old construction without i(/na; as ti/ soi qe/leis poih/sw; what wilt thou that I should do unto thee? with the answer, i(/na a)nable/yw, that I may receive my sight, LUC. xviii. 41.So bou/lesqe u(mi=n a)polu/sw to
 basile/a tw=n *)ioudai/wn; IOH. xviii. 39.
From qe/lete i(/na ei)/pw; comes the modern Greek qe/lete na\ ei)/pw; will you that I speak? and probably also the common future qa\ ei)/pw, I shall speak (if qa/ represents qe/lw na/).

The third person of the subjunctive is sometimes used in these questions of appeal, but less frequently than the first, and chiefly when a speaker refers to himself by ti\s. E.g. *po/tero/n se/ tis, *ai)sxi/nh, th=s po/lews e)xqro\n h)\ e)mo\n ei)=nai fh=|; i.e. shall we call you the city's enemy, or mine? DEM. xviii. 124. *ei)=ta tau=q' ou(=toi peisqw=sin u(pe\r au)tw=n se poiei=n, kai\ ta\ th=s sh=s ponhri/as e)/rga e)f' e(autou\s a)nade/cwntai; i.e. are these men to believe, etc.; and are they to assume, etc.? Id. xxii. 64. *ti/ tis ei)=nai tou=to fh=|; Id. xix. 88. *pw=s ti/s toi pei/qhtai; how can any one obey you? Il. i. 150.
*qu/gater, poi= tis fronti/dos e)/lqh|; SOPH. O.C. 170.
*poi= tis ou)=n fu/gh|; Id. Aj. 403.
*po/qen ou)=n tis tau/ths a)/rchtai ma/xhs; Phil. 15
*pw=s ou)=n e)/t' ei)/ph|s o(/ti sune/stalmai kakoi=s; EUR. H. F. 1417 , the only case of the second person, is probably corrupt. Dindorf reads a)\n ei)/pois.

The subjunctive is often used in the question ti/ pa/qw; what will become of me? or what harm will it do me? literally, what shall I undergo? E.g.
*)/w moi e)gw\, ti/ pa/qw; ti/ nu/ moi mh/kista ge/nhtai; Od. v. 465. So Il. xi. 404.
*ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ drw=; ti/ de\ mh/swmai; AESCH. Sept. 1057.
*ti/ pa/qw tlh/mwn;
Pers. 912 ; Ar. Pl. 603.
*ti/ pa/qw; ti/ de\ mh/somai; oi)/moi SOPH. Tr. 973.
*to\ me/llon, ei) xrh\, pei/somai: ti/ ga\r pa/qw; I shall suffer what is to come, if it must be; for what harm can it do me? EUR. Ph. 895. (The difference between ti/ pa/qw; and pa/sxw in its ordinary use is here seen.)
*(wmolo/ghka: ti/ ga\r pa/qw; PLAT. Euthyd. 302D.
So in the plural, ti/ ga\r pa/qwmen mh\ boulome/nwn u(me/wn timwre/ein; HDT. iv. 118.

(Negative mh/.) The negative mh/ of the interrogative subjunctive is explained by the origin of the construction (288). If e)/lqwmen; shall we go? is the interrogative of e)/lqwmen, let us go, then mh\ e)/lqwmen; shall we not go? is the interrogative of mh\ e)/lqwmen, let us not go, and implies (addressed to others) do you wish not to have us go? This is still more evident when bou/lesqe is prefixed to the subjunctive (288). Similar to this interrogative form of the subjunctive of exhortation is the rare interrogative imperative (also negatived by mh/); as a)\n o( meta\ te/xnhs gra/yas a)fi/khtai, mh\ e)ce/stw dh\ e(/tera prosta/ttein; i.e. is he not to be allowed to give other orders? PLAT. Polit. 295E , where mh\ e)ce/stw; is the interrogative of mh\ e)ce/stw, let him not be allowed, as mh\ e)/lqwmen; (above) is that of mh\ e)/lqwmen, let us not go. See also the indirect question in Leg. 800E, e)panerwtw= pa/lin, tw=n e)kmagei/wn tai=s w)dai=s ei) prw=ton e(\n tou=q' h(mi=n a)re/skon kei/sqw, I ask again, whether first this is to stand approved by us as one of our models for songs. We cannot express such an imperative precisely in English; and there is the same difficulty with oi)=sq' o(\ dra=son; etc., in 253. See also w(/ste with imperative forms (602).

1. When the future indicative is used in the sense of the interrogative subjunctive (68), it may be negatived by mh/; as pw=s ou)=n mh/te yeu/somai fanerw=s; how then shall I escape telling an open lie? (where there is some MS. authority for yeu/swmai), DEM. xix. 320 (see Shilleto's note).

2. A similar use of mh/ is found with the potential optative (with a)/n) in questions, if the idea of prevention is involved in it; as ti/ ou)=n ou) skopou=men pw=s a)
 au)tw=n mh\ diamarta/noimen; why then do we not consider how we can avoid mistaking them? (the direct question here would differ little from pw=s mh\ diamarta/nwmen; ). XEN. Mem. iii. 1, 10. So pw=s a)/n tis mh\ qumw=| le/goi peri\ qew=n; how can one help being excited when he speaks of Gods? Leg. 887C. Sometimes such an optative with mh/ is in a second clause, preceded by a positive question, so that the harshness of mh\ a)/n with the optative is avoided; as ti/ a)
 le/gontes ei)ko\s h)\ au)toi\ a)poknoi=men h)\ pro\s tou\s e)kei= cum: ma/xous skhpto/menoi mh\ bohqoi=men; i.e. what good ground can we give for holding back ourselves, or what decent excuse can we make to our allies there for withholding our aid from them? THUC. vi. 18.So ti/na a)
 tro/pon e)gw\ me/ga dunai/mhn kai\ mhdei/s me a)dikoi=; in what way can I have great power and prevent any one from doing me wrong? PLAT. Gorg. 510D. See also ISOC. v. 8, ISOC. xv. 6.In DEM. xxi. 35, po/tera mh\ dw=| dia\ tou=to di/khn h)\ mei/zw doi/h dikai/ws; shall he escape punishment for this, or would he rather deserve a still greater penalty?—doi/h is used as if ou)k a)
 doi/h had preceded (Schaefer inserts ka)/n).

In PLAT. Phaed. 106 D is the singular expression, sxolh=| ga a)/n ti a)/llo fqora
 mh\ de/xoito, ei)/ ge to\ a)qa/naton a)i/dion o)
 fqora
 de/cetai, for hardly can anything else escape from admitting destruction if the immortal, which is eternal, is to admit it. This differs from the preceding interrogative examples merely in the substitution of sxolh=|, hardly, for pw=s or ti/na tro/pon.

As ou) cannot be used with the interrogative subjunctive, mh/ here sometimes introduces a question which expects an affirmative answer. See XEN. Mem. i. 2, 36 , and PLAT. Rep. 337 B, PLAT. Rep. 554 B, quoted in 287; and compare XEN. Oec. iv. 4 (ibid.), where a negative answer is expected. In PLAT. Rep. 552 E, we must read mh\ oi)w/meqa (not oi)o/meqa, Herm. ), shall we not think? as the answer must be affirmative (see Stallbaum's note).

div2.head: Section IV: ou) mh/ with the Subjunctive and the Future Indicative.
div2.p: The subjunctive and the future indicative are used with the double negative ou) mh/ in independent sentences, sometimes expressing a denial, like the future indicative with ou), and sometimes a prohibition, like the imperative or subjunctive with mh/. The compounds of both ou) and mh/ can be used here as well as the simple forms.
For a discussion of the origin of this construction, and of the relation of the sentences of denial to those of prohibition, see Appendix II.

(Denial.) The subjunctive (usually the aorist), and sometimes the future indicative, with ou) mh/ may have the force of an emphatic future with ou). Thus ou) mh\ tou=to ge/nhtai, sometimes ou) mh\ tou=to genh/setai, means this surely will not happen. E.g.

(Aor. Subj.) *kai\ tw=nd' a)kou/sas ou)/ ti mh\ lhfqw= do/lw|, I shall not be caught by any trick. AESCH. Sept. 38. So Sept. 199, Supp. 228. *ou) mh\ pi/qhtai, he will not obey. SOPH. Ph. 103. *ou) ga/r se mh\ gnw=si. Id. El. 42.
*kai\ ou)/ ti mh\ la/xwsi tou=de summa/xou Id. O.C. 450.
*ou)/toi s' *)axaiw=n, oi)=da, mh/ tis u(bri/sh| Id. Aj. 560.
*(o d' ou) pa/restin, ou)de\ mh\ mo/lh| pote/, but he is not here, and he never will come. EUR. H.F. 718.
*kou) mh/ poq' a(lw=. AR. Ach. 662. *tw=n h)\n krath/swmen, ou) mh/ tis h(mi=n a)/llos strato\s a)ntisth=| kote a)nqrw/pwn. HDT. vii. 53.So i. 199. *ou) mh/ pote e)sba/lwsin. THUC. iv. 95; cf. v. 69. *ou) mh/ se kru/yw pro\s o(/ntina bou/lomai a)fike/sqai. XEN. Cyr. vii. 3, 13. *(ws oi( *)arme/nioi ou) mh\ de/cwntai tou\s polemi/ous. Ib. iii. 2, Ib. 8 (see 296, b). *)\an kaqw/meqa oi)/koi, ou)de/pot' ou)de\n h(mi=n ou) mh\ ge/nhtai tw=n deo/ntwn. DEM. iv. 44; so ix. 75. *ou)/te ga\r gi/gnetai ou)/te ge/gonen ou)de\ ou)=n mh\ ge/nhtai a)lloi=on h)=qos pro\s a)reth/n, for there is not, nor has there been, nor will there ever be, etc. PLAT. Rep. 492E. (Here ou)de\ mh\ ge/nhtai seems merely more emphatic than the ordinary ou)de\ genh/setai.)

(Aor. Subj. 2d Pers. ) *ou) ga/r ti ma=llon mh\ fu/gh|s to\ mo/rsimon, for you shall none the more escape your fate. Sept. 281. *)all' ou)/ pot' e)c e)mou= ge mh\ pa/qh|s to/de. SOPH. El. 1029. *ou) mh/ pot' e)s th\n *sku=ron e)kpleush|s e)/xwn. Id. Ph. 381. *)all' ou)/ ti mh\ fu/ghte laiyhrw=| podi/. EUR. Hec. 1039.
*kou)xi\ mh\ pau/shsqe, you will never cease. AR. Lys. 704.

(Pres. Subj.) *)\hn ga\r a(/pac du/o h)\ triw=n h(merw=n o(do\n a)po/sxwmen, ou)ke/ti mh\ du/nhtai basileu\s h(ma=s katalabei=n. XEN. An. ii. 2, 12. So ou) mh\ du/nwntai, Id. Hier. xi. 15. *pro\s tau=ta kakou/rgei kai\ sukofa/ntei, ei)/ ti du/nasai: a)ll' ou) mh\ oi(=o/s t' h)=|s, but you will not be able. PLAT. Rep. 341B. *ou) ga\r mh\ dunato\s w)=. Phil. 48D. In the much-discussed passage, SOPH. OC 1023 , a)/lloi ga\r oi( speu/dontes, ou(\s ou) mh/ pote xw/ras fugo/ntes th=sd' e)peu/xwntai qeoi=s, for there are others in eager pursuit; and they (the captors) will never (be in a condition to) be thankful to the Gods for escaping these and getting out of this land, the chief force is in fugo/ntes, as if it were ou) mh\ fu/gwsi w(/ste e)peu/xesqai qeoi=s, the present subjunctive expressing a state of thankfulness.

(Fut. Ind.) *ou)/ soi mh\ meqe/yomai/ pote. SOPH. El. 1052.
*ou)/ toi mh/pote/ s' e)k tw=n e(dra/nwn, w)= ge/ron, a)/konta/ tis a)/cei Id. O.C 176 ; so ou)k ou)=n mh\ o(doiporh/seis O. C. 848.
*ma\ to\n *)apo/llw ou) mh/ s' e)gw\ perio/yoma)pelqo/nt) (i.e. perio/yomai a)pelqo/nta). AR. Ran. 508. *tou\s ponhrou\s ou) mh/ pote belti/ous poih/sete. AESCHIN. iii. 177.
*ou) mh/ with the subjunctive or the future indicative can stand in various dependent sentences:—

(a) Especially in indirect discourse; as eu)= ga\r oi)=d' safw=s o(/ti tau=q' . . . ou) mh\ )pila/qh|. Pac. 1302.So XEN. Cyr. viii. 1, 5 , XEN. Hell. iv. 2, 3 ; PLAT. Rep. 499B. See also THUC. v. 69.We have ou) mh/ with the future optative after w(s, representing the future indicative of the direct form, in SOPH. Ph. 611: ta/ t' a)/lla pa/nt' e)qe/spisen, kai\ ta)pi\ *troi/as pe/rgam' w(s ou) mh/ pote pe/rsoien ei) mh\ to/nde a)/gointo. (The direct discourse was ou) mh/ pote pe/rsete e)a\n mh\ to/nde a)/ghsqe.) In a similar construction in XEN. Hell. i. 6, 32 , the future indicative is retained after a past tense: ei)=pen o(/ti h( *spa/rth ou)de\n mh\ ka/kion oi)kiei=tai au)tou= a)poqano/ntos. In EUR. Phoen. 1590, we have the future infinitive of indirect discourse with ou) mh/: ei)=pe *teiresi/as ou) mh/ pote, sou= th/nde gh=n oi)kou=ntos, eu)= pra/cein po/lin, representing ou) mh\ eu)= pra/cei po/lis.

(b) In causal sentences with w(s; as AR. Av. 461: le/ge qarrh/sas, w(s ta\s sponda\s ou) mh\ pro/teron parabw=men, for we will not break the truce before you have spoken. So XEN. Cyr. iii. 2, 8 (see 295).
(c) In consecutive sentences with w(/ste; as PLAT. Phaedr. 227D : ou(/tws e)pitequ/mhka a)kou=sai, w(/st), e)a\n poih=| to\n peri/paton *me/gara/de, ou) mh/ sou a)poleifqw=.

In AESCH. Ag. 1640, to\n de/ mh\ peiqa/nora zeu/cw barei/ais ou)/ti mh\ seirafo/ron kriqw=nta pw=lon, and I will yoke him who is not obedient under a heavy yoke, (and I will let him run) by no means as a wanton colt in traces, ou)/ti mh/ belongs grammatically to zeu/cw, though its position makes it affect the following words in sense: cf. kai\ mh\n to/d' ei)pe\ mh\ para\ gnw/mhn e)moi/, AESCH. Ag. 931, where the force of mh/ falls on the words that follow it. See Paley's note on AESCH. Ag. 1640 (1618).

(Prohibition.) In the dramatic poets, the second person singular of the future indicative (occasionally of the subjunctive) with ou) mh/ may express a strong prohibition. Thus ou) mh\ lalh/seis means you shall not prate, or do not prate, being nearly equivalent to mh\ la/lei or mh\ lalh/sh|s. E.g. *)=w pai=, ti/ qroei=s; ou) mh\ par' o)/xlw| ta/de ghru/sei, do not (I beg you) speak out in this way before the people. EUR. Hipp. 213. *)=w qu/gater, ou) mh\ mu=qon e)pi\ pollou\s e)rei=s. Id. Supp. 1066. *ou) mh\ gunaikw=n deilo
 ei)soi/seis lo/gon, do not adopt the cowardly language of women. And. 757. *ou) mh\ e)cegerei=s to
 u(/pnw| ka/toxon ka)k- kinh/seis ka)nasth/seis foita/da deinh
 no/son, w)= te/knon, do not wake him and arouse, etc. SOPH. Tr. 978. (Here ou) mh/ belongs to three verbs.) *ti/ poiei=s; ou) mh\ katabh/sei, don't come down. AR. Vesp. 397.
*poi=os *zeu/s; ou) mh\ lhrh/sh|s: ou)d' e)/sti *zeu/s, Zeus indeed! Don't talk nonsense; there isn't any Zeus. Id. Nub. 367. (Here all MSS. have lhrh/sh|s. See Id. Nub. 296, quoted in 298; and section 301 below.)

A prohibition thus begun by ou) mh/ with the future or subjunctive may be continued by mhde/ with another future form. An affirmative command may be added to the prohibition by a future or an imperative with a)lla/ or de/. E.g. *ou) mh\ kalei=s m), w)=nqrwf), i(keteu/w, mhde\ katerei=s tou)/noma, do not call to me, I implore you, nor speak my name. AR. Ran. 298. *ou) mh\ prosoi/seis xei=ra mhd' a(/yei pe/plwn, do not bring your hand near me nor touch my garments. EUR. Hipp. 606.
*ou) mh\ prosoi/seis xei=ra, bakxeu/seis d' i)w
, mhd' e)como/rcei mwri/an th
 sh
 e)moi/, do not bring your hand near me; but go and rage, and do not wipe off your folly on me. Bacch. 343. (Here mhde/ continues the original prohibition as if there had been no interruption.)

*ou) mh\ lalh/seis, a)ll' a)kolouqh/seis e)moi/, do not prate, but follow me. AR. Nub. 505.
*ou) mh\ diatri/yeis, a)lla\ geu/sei th=s qu/ras, do not delay, but taste of the door. Id. Ran. 462. *ou) mh\ fluarh/seis e)/xwn, w)= *canqi/a, a)ll' a)ra/menos oi)/seis pa/lin ta\ strw/mata. Ib. 524. *ou) mh\ dusmenh\s e)/sei fi/lois, pau/sei de\ qumou= kai\ pa/lin stre/yeis ka/ra, . . . de/cei de\ dw=ra kai\ paraith/sei patro/s, be not inimical to friends, but cease your rage, etc. EUR. Med. 1151.
*ou) mh\ skw/yh|s mhde\ poih/sh|s (so all the MSS.) a(/per oi( trugodai/mones ou(=toi, a)ll' eu)fh/mei, do not scoff, nor do what these wretches do; but keep silence! AR. Nub. 296. (Here the imperative is used precisely like the future with a)lla/ or de/ in the preceding examples.)

The clause with mhde/ is here a continuation of that with ou) mh/, ou) belonging to both. The future in the clause with a)lla/ or de/ is like that in pa/ntws tou=to dra/seis, by all means do this AR. Nub. 1352 (see 69). A single ou) mh/ may introduce a prohibition consisting of several futures connected by kai/, as in SOPH. Tr. 978 (quoted in 297).

Sometimes ou) with the future indicative in a question implying an affirmative answer (thus equivalent to an exhortation) is followed by mh/ or mhde/ with the future in a question implying a negative answer (and thus equivalent to a prohibition). Here there is no case of ou) mh/. E.g.
*ou) si=g' a)ne/cei, mhde\ deili/an a)rei=s; will you not keep silence, and not become a coward? SOPH. Aj. 75. (Here mh\ deili/an a)rei=s; is an independent question, will you be a coward? = do not be a coward.)
*ou) qa=sson oi)/seis, mhd' a)pisth/seis e)moi/; will you not extend your hand. and not distrust me? Id. Tr. 1183.
*ou)k ei)= su/ t' oi)/kous, su/ te *kre/wn kata\ ste/gas, kai\ mh\ to\ mhde\n a)/lgos ei)s me/g' oi)/sete; Id. O.T. 637.

All the examples under 297 and 298 are usually printed as interrogative, in accordance with Elmsley's doctrine, stated in his note to EUR. Med. 1120 (1151) and in the Quarterly Review for June 1812. He explains ou) mh\ lalh/seis; as meaning will you not stop prating? (lit. will you not not prate?); and when a second clause in the future with mhde/ or a)lla/ follows, he extends the interrogative force of ou) also to this. But this explanation requires an entirely different theory to account for ou) mh/ in clauses of denial (295), where no question is possible. Moreover, the five examples of the second person of the subjunctive quoted under 295, taken in connection with those in 297 and 298, are sufficient to show the impossibility of separating the two constructions in explanation. One of the examples in 298 (AR. Nub. 296), where the imperative eu)fh/mei follows in the clause with a)lla/, seems decisive against the interrogative theory. The examples under 299 are really interrogative; but they consist practically of an exhortation followed by a prohibition (both being interrogative), and contain no construction with ou) mh/ at all.

In most modern editions of the classics the subjunctive is not found in the construction of 297; and in many cases the first aorist subjunctive in -sh|s has been emended to the future, against the authority of the MSS., in conformity to Dawes's rule. (See 364.) Thus, in AR. Nub. 296 and 367 the MSS. have the subjunctive; and in 296, ou) mh\ skw/yh|s could not be changed to ou) mh\ skw/yeis, as the future of skw/ptw is skw/yomai. Elmsley's emendation skw/yei, which is adopted by most editors, requires a greater change than should be made merely to sustain an arbitrary rule, which rests on no apparent principle. If both constructions (295 and 297) are explained on the same principle, there is no longer any reason for objecting to the subjunctive with ou) mh/ in prohibitions; and it seems most probable that both future indicative and subjunctive were allowed in both constructions, but that the subjunctive was more common in clauses of denial, and the future in clauses of prohibition.

div2.head: Section V.: Final and Object Clauses after i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, o)/fra, and mh/.
Classification.—Negatives.
div2.p: The final particles are i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, and (in epic and lyric poetry) o)/fra, that, in order that. To these must be added mh/, lest, which became in use a negative final particle.
The clauses which are introduced by these particles, all of which are sometimes called final clauses, may be divided into three classes:—

Pure A. final clauses, in which the end or purpose of the action of any verb may be expressed; as e)/rxetai i(/na tou=to i)/dh|, he is coming that he may see this; a)pe/rxetai i(/na mh\ tou=to i)/dh|, he is departing that he may not see this; h)=lqen i(/na tou=to i)/doi, he came that he might see this. Here all the final particles are used, but with different frequency in various classes of writers (see 311-314).

Object B. clauses with o(/pws or o(/pws mh/ after verbs of striving, etc.; as sko/pei o(/pws genh/setai, see that it happens; sko/pei o(/pws mh\ genh/setai, see that it does not happen. These clauses express the direct object of the verb of striving, etc., so that they may stand in apposition to an object accusative like tou=to; as sko/pei tou=to, o(/pws mh/ se o)/yetai, see to this, viz., that he does not see you. They also imply the end or purpose of the action of the leading verb, and to this extent they partake of the nature of final clauses.

C. Clauses with mh/ after verbs of fearing, etc.; as fobou=mai mh\ tou=to ge/nhtai, I fear that this may happen; e)fobh/qh mh\ tou=to ge/noito, he feared that this might happen. These clauses have in use become object clauses, though in their origin they are of a very different nature (262; 307).

Although the object clauses of class B partake slightly of the nature of final clauses, so that they sometimes allow the same construction (the subjunctive for the future indicative), still the distinction between classes A and B is very strongly marked. An object clause, as we have seen, can stand in apposition to a preceding tou=to; whereas a final clause would stand in apposition to tou/tou e(/neka, as e)/rxetai tou/tou e(/neka, i(/na h(mi=n bohqh/sh|, he comes for this purpose, viz., that he may assist us. The two can be combined in one sentence; as spouda/zei o(/pws plouth/sei, i(/na tou\s fi/lous eu)= poih=|, he is eager to be rich, that he may benefit his friends.

Care must be taken not to mistake the nature of an object clause with o(/pws when its subject is attracted by the leading verb; as sko/pei th\n po/lin o(/pws swqh/setai for sko/pei o(/pws h( po/lis swqh/setai, see that the city is saved. So also when an object clause of the active construction becomes a subject clause in the equivalent passive form; as e)pra/tteto o(/pws summaxi/an ei)=nai yhfiei=sqe, it was brought about that you should vote to have an alliance made ( AESCHIN. iii. 64), which represents the active construction e)/pratton o(/pws yhfiei=sqe.

The regular negative after i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, and o)/fra is mh/; but after mh/, lest, ou) is used. E.g. *)ape/rxetai, i(/na mh\ tou=to i)/dh|, he is departing that he may not see this. *fobei=tai mh\ ou) tou=to ge/nhtai, he is afraid that this may not happen.

This use of mh\ ou) (305) occurs in Homer in a few final clauses (263) and once after dei/dw ( Il. x. 39). After this it is confined to clauses after verbs of fearing, with the exception of XEN. Mem. ii. 2, 14 , Cyneg. vii. 10, and the peculiar mh\ ou)k e)parke/soi in PLAT. Rep. 393 E (132). This use of ou) after mh/ is naturally explained by the origin of the dependent clause with mh/ (262); but after mh/ had come to be felt as a conjunction and its origin was forgotten, the chief objection to mh\ . . . mh/ was probably in the sound, and we find a few cases of it where the two particles are so far apart that the repetition is not offensive. Such a case is XEN. Mem. i. 2, 7 : e)qau/maze d' ei)/ tis foboi=to mh\ o( geno/menos kalo\s ka)gaqo\s tw=| ta\ me/gista eu)ergeth/santi mh\ th\n megi/sthn xa/rin e(/coi, where we should expect mh\ ou)x e(/coi. So THUC. ii. 13: u(potoph/sas mh\ . . . parali/ph| kai\ mh\ dhw/sh|. So in a final clause, mh\ . . . mh\ prosde/xoito, PLAT. Euthyd. 295D.

div2.head: Development of Clauses with i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, o)/fra, and mh/.
div2.p: The development of final clauses and of clauses with mh/ after verbs of fearing from an original parataxis, or co-ordination of two independent sentences, is especially plain in dependent negative clauses with the simple mh/. Thus a)po/stixe, mh/ ti noh/sh| *(/hrh, withdraw, lest Hera notice anything ( Il. i. 522), presents the form of an original paratactic expression, which would mean withdraw:—may not (or let not) Hera notice anything, the latter clause being like mh\ dh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, may they not take the ships ( Il. xvi. 128), and mh\ dh/ moi tele/swsi qeoi\ kaka\ kh/dea ( Il. xviii. 8). (See 261.) Such sentences as these last imply fear or anxiety lest the event may happen which mh/ with the subjunctive expresses a desire to avert; and in a primitive stage of the language they might naturally be preceded by a verb of fearing, to which the (still independent) subjunctive with mh/ would stand in the relation of an explanatory clause defining the substance of the fear. Thus dei/dw:—mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi would originally be two independent sentences, I fear:—may they not take the ships; but would in time come to be felt as a single sentence, equivalent to our I fear that (lest) they may take the ships. After fobou=mai mh\ tou=to pa/qwsin (for example) was domesticated in the sense I fear lest they may suffer this, the second clause followed the ordinary course, and began to be felt as a thoroughly dependent clause; and when the leading verb became past, the subjunctive became optative, as e)fobh/qhn mh\ tou=to pa/qoien, I feared lest they might suffer this. When this stage is reached, all feeling of the original independence may be said to have vanished and a dependent clause is fully established. As this decisive evidence of complete dependence is constantly found in the Homeric language, we cannot suppose that such an expression as dei/doika mh/ ti pa/qwsin ( Il. x. 538) was still felt to be composed of two independent sentences, although the original paratactic form is precisely preserved. Indeed, we have no evidence that the step from parataxis to hypotaxis was taken after the Greek language had an independent existence.See Brugmann, Griechische Grammatik, p. 122.

It was a simple and natural step to extend the construction thus established to present and past objects of fear, although we cannot assume for the primitive language such independent indicatives with mh/ as we find later (see 269). In Homer we find dei/dw mh\ qea\ nhmerte/a ei)=pen, I fear that the Goddess spoke the truth (Od. v. 300) . This use was greatly extended in Attic Greek (see 369).

This simple construction of a dependent verb introduced by mh/ with no connecting conjunction remained the established form after verbs of fearing in all periods of the language; and occasional exceptions, like mh\ fobou= w(s a)porh/seis, do not fear that you will be at a loss (371), ou) fobei= o(/pws mh\ a)no/sion pra=gma tugxa/nh|s pra/ttwn; (370), and ou) fobou/meqa e)lassw/sesqai, we are not afraid that we shall have the worst of it (372), in place of the regular mh\ a)porh/sh|s, mh\ tugxa/nh|s, mh\ e)lasswqw=men, only prove the rule. The original independent sentence with mh/, expressing an object of fear which it is desired to avert, like mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, is well established in Homer and appears occasionally in the Attic poets (261; 264). But in Plato it suddenly appears as a common construction, expressing, however, not an object of fear but an object of suspicion or surmise (265), so that mh/ with the subjunctive is a cautious expression of a direct assertion; as mh\ a)groiko/teron h)=| to\ a)lhqe\s ei)pei=n, I rather think the truth may be too rude to tell (Gorg. 462E).

In like manner, the simple negative form of the pure final clause, as a)po/stixe, mh/ ti noh/sh| *(/hrh (quoted above), was already established in Homer, the negative mh/ serving as a connective, so that the want of a final conjunction was not felt. Here also the feeling of dependence is shown by the subjunctive becoming optative when the leading verb is past; as in feu/comai mh/ ti/s me i)/dh| and e)/fugon mh/ ti/s me i)/doi. But it is obvious that only negative purpose could be expressed by this simple form, in which mh/ could serve as a connective. We find, it is true, a few positive sentences in which a purpose is implied by the mere sequence of two clauses; as a)ll' a)/ge nu=n i)qu\s ki/e *ne/storos i(ppoda/moio: ei)/domen (subjunctive)h(/n tina mh=tin e)ni\ sth/qessi ke/keuqen, i.e.go straightway to Nestor : let us know what counsel he buries in his breast (Hom. Od. iii. 17) , and qa/pte me o(/tti ta/xista: pu/las *)ai/dao perh/sw, burg me as quickly as possible: let me pass the gates of Hades ( Hom. Il. xxiii. 71). But these disconnected expressions, with no particle to unite them, could never satisfy the need of a positive sentence of purpose. To supply this want, several final particles were developed, and were already in familiar use in Homer. These are i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, and o)/fra, which will be discussed separately.

(*(/ina.) *(/ina is the only purely final particle, having nothing of the relative character of w(s and o(/pws, or of the temporal character of o)/fra. Its derivation is uncertain. It appears in Homer as a fully developed final conjunction, and occasionally also in the sense of where ( Od. ix. 136) and whither ( Od. xix. 20). It is overshadowed in epic and lyric poetry by o)/fra, and in tragedy by w(s; but Aristophanes uses it in threefourths of his final sentences, and in Plato and the orators it has almost exterminated the other final particles. As i(/na is purely final, both in use and in feeling, it never takes a)/n or ke/, which are frequently found with the other final particles, especially with the relative w(s.

(*ws.) 1. *(ws is originally an adverb of manner, derived from the stem o(- of the relative o(/s, like ou(/tws from the stem of ou(=tos. As a relative it means originally in which way, as; as an indirect interrogative it means how, whence comes its use in indirect discourse (663, 2). Since purpose can be expressed by a relative pronoun, which in Homer regularly takes the subjunctive (568), as h(gemo/n' e)sqlo\n o)/passon, o(/s ke/ me kei=s' a)ga/gh|, send me a good guide, ,to lead me thither (Od. xv. 310) , so can it be by the relative adverb of manner, as kri=n' a)/ndras kata\ fu=la, kata\ frh/tras, w(s frh/trh frh/trhfin a)rh/gh|, fu=la de\ fu/lois, divide the men in that way by which clan may help clan, etc., i.e. (so) divide them that clan may help clan, etc. ( Il. ii. 362). Here the original force of w(s can be seen; but in
Od. xvii. 75, o)/trunon e)mo\n poti\ dw=ma gunai=kas, w(/s toi dw=r' a)pope/myw , in order that I may send you the gifts, the final force is as strong as if we had i(/na a)pope/myw.

2. *(ws, however, always retained so much of its original relative nature that it could take ke/ or a)/n in a final sentence with the subjunctive, like other final relatives, which in Homer hardly ever omit ke/ before a subjunctive (568). Compare o(/s ke/ me kei=s) a)ga/gh| (above) with the equivalent w(/s ke/ me kei=s' a)ga/gh|. The final clause thus receives a conditional form, with which it must have received originally more or less conditional force.See Gildersleeve in Jour. Phil. iv. p. 422. Thus an expression like pei/qeo w(s a)\n ku=dos a)/rhai probably meant originally obey in whatever way you may gain glory, or obey in some way in which you may gain glory, w(s a)\n a)/rhai being chiefly a conditional relative clause (529); but before the Homeric usage was established, the final element had so far obliterated the relative, that the conditional force of w(s a)/n must have been greatly weakened. The expression in Homer ( Il. xvi. 84) may have meant obey that (if so be) you may gain me glory. (See examples under 326.) The same is true of the less common use of ke/ or a)/n with o)/fra and o(/pws in Homer (327; 328). How far the original conditional force survived in the Attic w(s a)/n and o(/pws a)/n with the subjunctive, especially in o(/pws a)/n of Attic prose, is a question which at this distant day we have hardly the power to answer, and each scholar will be guided by his own feeling as he reads the expressions. (See 326; 328; 348.) It certainly can be seen in some of Xenophon's uses of w(s a)/n with the subjunctive; see Cyr. ii. 4 and Eques. i. 16, quoted in Appendix IV.

3. *(ws and w(/s ke with the subjunctive are used in Homer also in object clauses after verbs of planning, considering, etc. (341), where o(/pws with the future indicative is the regular Attic form. *(ws (with w(s a)/n) is by far the most common final particle in tragedy; it seldom occurs in Aristophanes and Herodotus; while in Attic prose it almost entirely disappears,Weber (p. 174) quotes two passages of Demosthenes as examples of final w(s with the future indicative, a construction otherwise unknown in Attic prose: w(s de\ safw=s gnw/sesqe o(/ti a)lhqh= le/gw, e)gw\ u(mi=n e)rw=, xxiv. 146; and w(s de\ katafane\s e)/stai o(/ti pro/teron a)naisxuntou=ntes periege/nonto, a)nagi/gnwske ta\s marturi/as, xliii. 42. But compare the common formula of the orators w(s (or o(/ti) a)lhqh= le/gw, labe\ th\n marturi/an (or ka/lei tou\s ma/rturas), e.g. in DEM. xxvii. 28, with the occasional full form, i(/na ei)dh=te tau=ta o(/ti a)lhqh= le/gw, labe\ th\n marturi/an, DEM. xlv. 19; so xviii. 305. See also w(s ei)ko/ta poiou=men, kai\ ta/d' e)nnoh/sate (sc. i(/na ei)dh=te), XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 33. This common ellipsis shows that in DEM. xliii. 42 we can easily supply a final clause like i(/na ei)dh=te before w(s katafane\s e)/stai, that you may know how it is to be established, etc. In xxiv. 146 there is no need even of an ellipsis, as we can translate how you are to know that I speak the truth, I will explain to you. except in Xenophon, with whom it is again common, though less so than o(/pws or i(/na. (See Weber's tables in Appendix III.)

(*(/opws.) 1. *(/opws is related to w(s as o(po/te to o(/te, being the adverb of the relative stem o(- and the indefinite stem po- combined.See Delbrück, Conj.u. Opt.p. 61. Like w(s, it is originally a relative adverb, meaning as; and it can always be used in this sense, as in ou(/tws o(/pws du/nantai, thus as they can, THUC. vii. 67.Then it is used in indirect questions, in the sense of o(/tw| tro/pw|, how, in what way, and is followed by the future indicative; as skopei=n o(/pws h( po/lis swqh/setai, to see how the city can be saved. So toi=s gegenhme/nois ponhroi=s, o(/pws mh\ dw/sousi di/khn, o(do\n dei/knusi, he shows those who have been rascals how they can avoid suffering punishment (= o(/tw| tro/pw| mh\ dw/sousi), DEM. xxiv. 106.Then, by a slight modification in sense, it may denote also the object to which the striving, etc., is directed; so that skopei=n (or skopei=n tou=to) o(/pws h( po/lis swqh/setai may mean to see (to this, viz.) that the city shall be saved. Here, however, the subjunctive is sometimes allowed, as the interrogative force of o(/pws is lost sight of and its force as a final particle, in order that, begins to appear. From this it becomes established as a final particle, and denotes the purpose in ordinary final clauses. From the original force of o(/pws as a relative, used in indirect questions in the sense of how, we must explain its occasional use in indirect questions in the sense of w(s (706).

The interrogative force of o(/pws can be seen from passages in which other interrogative words take its place in the same sense; as DEM. xvi. 19, skopei=n e)c o(/tou tro/pou mh\ genh/sontai (fi/loi), to see in what way they can be prevented from becoming friends; and THUC. i. 65, e)/prassen o(/ph| w)feli/a tis genh/setai, he negotiated to have some help come (how some help should come). So THUC. iv. 128, e)/prassen o(/tw| tro/pw| ta/xista toi=s me\n cumbh/setai tw=n de\ a)palla/cetai.See Madvig's Syntax, § 123.

2. Although o(/pws is fully established in the Homeric language, both in its half-interrogative use after verbs of planning, etc. (341), and also in its final sense, it seldom occurs in Homer in either construction. It first becomes frequent in the Attic poets. In Thucydides and Xenophon it is the most common final particle; and in these writers, as in tragedy, its final use greatly exceeds its use in object clauses. The latter, however, far exceeds the final use in Herodotus, Plato, and the orators; but here i(/na has gained almost undisputed possession of the field as a final particle.

3. *(/opws never takes ke/ or an in pure final clauses in Homer. *(/opws a)/n with the subjunctive appears for the first time in final clauses in Aeschylus (328), and afterwards maintains itself vigorously by the side of the simple o(/pws. In object clauses o(/pws ke with the subjunctive is found in a few places in Homer, and o(/pws a)/n in a few in the Attic poets, while o(/pws a)/n in these clauses in prose is found chiefly in Plato and Xenophon (348).

(*)/ofra.) The most common final particle in Homer is o)/fra, which is originally a temporal particle, meaning while (so long as) and then until. From the last meaning the final force was naturally developed, as the idea of until, when it looks forward to the future, may involve that of aiming at an object to be attained, as in English we shall fight until we are free. Another temporal particle meaning both while and until, e(/ws, is used in a final sense in a few passages of the Odyssey (614, 2). Both of the temporal uses of o)/fra appear in full vigour in Homer; but its final character must have been more distinctly marked at an earlier period than that of either w(s or o(/pws, so that it seldom took either ke/ or a)/n before the subjunctive.
*)/ofra is found only in epic and lyric poetry.

(Negative Final Clauses.) The need of these final particles was first felt, as has been shown (310), in positive clauses of purpose, as a negative purpose could always be expressed by the simple mh/, which thus became in use a conjunction. Still the final particles were as well suited to negative as to positive final clauses, and they could always be prefixed to mh/, which thus was restored to its natural place as a negative adverb. Thus feu/comai i(/na mh/ ti/s me i)/dh| has the same meaning as the older feu/comai mh/ ti/s me i)/dh|, I shall flee, that no one may see me.

The history of the Greek language shows a gradual decrease of final mh/ and an increase of the final particles with mh/ in negative final clauses.In Homer, Hesiod, and the lyric poets we find 131 cases of simple mh/ and 50 of the final particles with mh/; in tragedy the proportion is 76 : 59; in Aristophanes it is 8 : 55; in Herodotus, 8 : 53. In Attic prose (except in Plato and Xenophon) the simple mh/ in final clauses almost vanishes. Thucydides has only 4 or 5 cases; the ten orators only 4 (Demosthenes 2, Isocrates 1, Isaeus 1); Plato 24; and Xenophon 12. The tendency in this direction was so strong that o(/pws mh/ sometimes took the place of mh/ even after verbs of fearing, to express the object of the fear (370), while it became the regular form after verbs of striving, etc., to express the object aimed at (339).

The different origin of the negative final clause (with i(/na mh/, etc.) and of the clause with mh/ explains the fact that, while clauses introduced by the final particles are negatived by mh/, those introduced by mh/, lest, are negatived by ou). (See 306.)

Finally, the Attic Greek took the last step in developing the final clause, by using the past tenses of the indicative with i(/na, w(s, and o(/pws to express a purpose which failed of attainment because of the failure of the action of the leading sentence; as ti/ m' ou)k e)/kteinas, w(s mh/pote tou=t' e)/deica; why did you not kill me, that I might never have shown this? (See 333.)

div2.head: Pure Final Clauses.
div2.p:
Pure final clauses regularly take the subjunctive if the leading verb is primary, and the optative if the leading verb is secondary. E.g.
*nu=n d' e)/rxesq' e)pi\ dei=pnon, i(/na cuna/gwmen *)/arha Il. ii. 381.
*soi\ d' w(=de mnhsth=res u(pokri/nontai, i)n' ei)dh=|s au)to\s sw=| qumw=| ei)dw=si de\ pa/ntes *)axaioi/. Od. ii. 111.
*ei)/pw ti dh=ta ka)/ll' i)n' o)rgi/zh| ple/on; SOPH. O.T. 364.
*kai\ ga\r basileu\s ai(rei=tai, ou)x i(/na e(autou= kalw=s e)pimelh=tai, a)ll' i(/na kai\ oi( e(lo/menoi di) au)to\n eu)= pra/ttwsi. XEN. Mem. iii. 2, 3.

For the relative frequency of the final particles, see Appendix III.

As final clauses after past tenses express some person's previous purpose or motive, they allow the double construction of indirect discourse (667, 1); so that, instead of the optative, they can have the mood and tense which the person himself would have used in conceiving the purpose. Thus we can say either h)=lqen i(/na i)/doi, he came that he might see, or h)=lqen i(/na i)/dh|, because the person himself would have said e)/rxomai i(/na i)/dw, I come that I may see.

Hence the subjunctive in final clauses after past tenses is very common, in some writers even more common than the regular optative. E.g.
*)epeklw/santo d' o)/leqron a)nqrw/pois, i(/na h)=|si kai\ e)ssome/noisin a)oidh/ Od. viii. 579.
*)axlu\n d' au)= toi a)p' o)fqalmw=n e(/lon, h(\ pri\n e)ph=en, o)/fr' e)u\ gignw/skh|s h)me\n qeo\n h)de\ kai\ a)/ndra Il. v. 127.
*)aristeu\s cunebou/leuen e)kpleu=sai, o(/pws e)pi\ ple/on o( si=tos a)nti/sxh| THUC. i. 65.
*)=hlqon presbeuso/menoi, o(/pws mh\ sfi/si to\ *)attiko\n ( nautiko\n ) prosgeno/menon e)mpo/dion ge/nhtai Id. i. 31.
*)exw/roun e)k tw=n oi)kiw=n, o(/pws mh\ kata\ fw=s qarsalewte/rois ou)=si prosfe/rwntai kai\ sfi/sin e)k tou= i)/sou gi/gnwntai, a)ll' h(/ssous w)=si Id. ii. 3.
*kai\ e)pi/thde/s se ou)k h)/geiron, i(/na w(s h(/dista dia/gh|s PLAT. Crit. 43B.
*ploi=a kate/kausen i(/na mh\ *ku=ros diabh=| XEN. An. i. 4, 18.
*tau/tas i(/na kwlu/hq' oi( no/moi sunh/gagon u(ma=s, ou)x i(/na kuri/as toi=s a)dikou=si poih=te DEM. xix. 1.
*kai\ peri\ tou/twn e)mnh/sqhn, i(/na mh\ tau)ta\ pa/qhte Id. iii. 6. (Here the purpose was conceived in the form i(/na mh\ tau)ta\ pa/qwsin.)
This principle applies also to clauses with o(/pws after verbs of striving (339) and with mh/ after verbs of fearing, etc. (365).

This is a favourite construction with certain authors, especially Thucydides, who also, on the same principle, prefers the indicative and subjunctive to the optative in ordinary indirect discourse after past tenses (670). The early poets, on the other hand, especially Homer, use it very sparingly.Weber, p. 243, gives a comparison of the usage of various writers, showing that the proportion of subjunctives to optatives after past tenses in pure final clauses and after verbs of fearing is as follows:—in Homer 35 : 156, Pindar 2 : 10, Aeschylus 2 : 9, Sophocles 2 : 23, Euripides 31 : 65, Aristophanes 13 : 37, Herodotus 86 : 47, Thucydides 168 : 60, Lysias 22 : 19, Isocrates 21 : 17, Isaeus 8: 17, Demosthenes 40 : 40, Aeschines 13 : 7, Plato 22 : 79, Xenophon 45 : 265. In all writers before Aristotle 528 : 894. In the Attic writers and Herodotus, excluding Xenophon, the two are just equal, Isaeus 441.

The subjunctive thus used for the optative makes the language more vivid, by introducing more nearly the original form of thought of the person whose purpose is stated. As the two forms are equally correct, we sometimes find both in the same sentence, just as we find the indicative and optative interchanged in indirect discourse (670; see 677 and 690). E.g. *(ecakosi/ous loga/das e)ce/krinan, o(/pws tw=n te *)epipolw=n ei)/hsan fu/lakes kai\, h)\n e)s a)/llo ti de/h|, taxu\ cunestw=tes paragi/gnwntai, i.e. they selected them, that they might be guards of Epipolae, and that they might be on hand if they should be needed for anything else. THUC. vi. 96. *parani=sxon de\ fruktou\s, o(/pws a)safh= ta\ shmei=a toi=s polemi/ois h)=| kai\ mh\ bohqoi=en, they raised fire-signals at the same time, in order that the enemy's signals might be unintelligible to them, and that they (the enemy) might not bring aid. Id. iii. 22.

A common interpretation of the latter and of similar passages, that the subjunctive mood indicates the immediate, and the optative the remote consequence of the action contained in the principal verbs, the second being a consequence of the first (Arnold), manifestly could not apply to the first example.

The use of the optative for the subjunctive in final clauses after primary tenses is, on the other hand, very rare, and is to be viewed as a mere irregularity of construction. See a)/cw th=l' *)iqa/khs, i(/na moi bi/oton polu\n a)/lfoi Od. xvii. 250 ; o(/ppws maxe/ointo, Il. i. 344; and vii. 340, Il. xviii. 88.So SOPH. El. 56, O. C. 11; HDT. ii. 93 (i(/na mh\ a(ma/rtoien). Most of these are emended by various editors; and no good reason for the anomaly appears in any of them.

Sometimes the optative is properly used after a leading verb which implies a reference to the past as well as the present. E.g. *tou=ton e)/xei to\n tro/pon o( no/mos, i(/na mhde\ peisqh=nai mhd' e)capathqh=nai ge/noit' e)pi\ tw=| dh/mw|. DEM. xxii. 11. (Here e)/xei implies also the past existence of the law; the idea being, the law was made as it is, so that it might not be possible, etc.) So DEM. xxiv. 145, DEM. 147.In DEM. iii. 34 i(/na tou=q' u(pa/rxoi depends on a past verb of saying to be mentally supplied. In AR. Ran. 23, tou=ton d' o)xw=, i(/na mh\ talaipwroi=to mhd) a)/xqos fe/roi, I am letting him ride, that he might not be distressed, etc., the meaning of o)xw= goes back to the time when Dionysus first let the slave mount the ass.

(Future Indicative.) The future indicative occasionally takes the place of the subjunctive in pure final clauses. It occurs chiefly with o(/pws, very seldom with o)/fra, w(s, and mh/, and never with i(/na.Weber cites the following cases, in addition to those given above. For o(/pws: AESCH. Cho. 265, Suppl. 449; SOPH. Aj. 698 (?); EUR. El. 835; AR. Vesp. 528, Pac. 309, Pac. 431, Lys. 1093, Thesm. 431, Lys. 653, Lys. 285 (?), Eccl. 783, Eccl. 997; ANDOC. i. 89; Hipp. i. 18, Mem. ii. 1, Mem. 1 (paideu/ein o(/pws e)/stai?). In XEN. Cyr. ii. 1, 4 and 21 the MSS. vary: in Cyr. iii. 3, Cyr. 42 o(/pws is probably independent. For o)/fra: Il. viii. 110; Od. iv. 163, Od. xvii. 6. For w(s: Bacch. 784. For mh/: Od. xxiv. 544; THEOG. 1307; AR. Eccl. 488.Only four undoubted examples occur in prose. It has essentially the same force as the subjunctive. E.g. *ai)ei\ de\ malakoi=si kai\ ai(muli/oisi lo/goisi qe/lgei, o(/pws *)iqa/khs e)pilh/setai Od. i. 56.
*mh\ pro/sleusse, h(mw=n o(/pws mh\ th\n tu/xhn diafqerei=s. SOPH. Ph. 1068.
*)apomukte/on de/ soi/ g', o(/pws lh/yei piei=n EUR. Cycl. 561.
*)ardw= s' o(/pws a)mblastanei=s. AR. Lys. 384.
*)ep' au)tou\s tou\s prolo/gous sou tre/yomai, o(/pws to\ prw=ton th=s tragw|di/as me/ros prw/tiston basaniw=. AR. Ran. 1120. *proie/nai (dei=) tw=n to/pwn e)nqumou/menon, o(/pws mh\ diamarth/setai. Cyneg. XEN. ix. 4. *xrh\ a)nabiba/zein e)pi\ to\n troxo\n tou\s a)nagrafe/ntas, o(/pws mh\ pro/teron nu\c e)/stai pri\n puqe/sqai tou\s a)/ndras a(/pantas. AND. i. 43.

*qa/rsunon de/ oi( h)=tor e)ni\ fresi\n, o)/fra kai\ *(/ektwr ei)/setai. Il. xvi. 242.
*(ws ti/ r(e/comen; that we may do what? SOPH. O.C. 1724.
*(/wst' ei)ko\s h(ma=s mh\ bradu/nein e)sti\, mh\ kai/ tis o)/yetai xh)mw=n i)/sws katei/ph| AR. Eccl. 495. So mh\ kexolw/setai, Il. xx. 301.

div2.head: a)/n, or ke/, in Final Clauses with Subjunctive.
div2.p: The final particles which have a relative origin, w(s, o(/pws, and o)/fra, sometimes have a)/n or ke/ in final clauses with the subjunctive. They did this originally in their capacity as conditional relatives; and it is probable that at first ke/ or a)/n with the relative gave the clause a combined final and conditional force, in which the conditional element gradually grew weaker as the relative particles came to be felt chiefly or only as final particles (312, 2). *(/ina and mh/ never take a)/n or ke/ in this way.In the single case of ke/ with i(/na, Od. xii. 156, a)ll' e)re/w me\n e)gw\n, i(/na ei)do/tes h)/ ke qa/nwmen, h)/ ken a)leua/menoi qa/naton kai\ kh=ra fu/gwmen , i(/na ke is not used like w(/s ke, etc., above, but i(/na is followed by a potential subjunctive with ke/ (285). The repetition of ke/ removes the case from the class under consideration. *(/ina in its sense of where may have a)/n (see SOPH. OC 405 ). *mh/, lest, may have a)/n with the optative after verbs of fearing (368).

(*(ws.) 1. *(/ws ke and w(s a)/n are together much more common in Homer with the subjunctive than simple w(s. *(ws a)/n with the subjunctive is not uncommon in the Attic poets, and it occurs in Herodotus; but (like w(s itself) it almost disappears in Attic prose. E.g. *pei/qeo, w(s a)/n moi timh
 mega/lhn kai\ ku=dos a)/rhai, obey, that thou mayest gain for me great honour and glory. Il. xvi. 84.
*au)ta/r oi( profrw
 u(poqh/somai, w(/s ke ma/l' a)skhqh\s h(
 patri/da gai=an i(/khtai Od. v. 143.
*pai/sate, w(/s x', o( cei=nos e)ni/sph| oi(=si fi/loisin Od. viii. 251.
*)all' i)/qi, mh/ m' e)re/qize, saw/teros w(/s ke ne/hai, that thou mayest go the more safely. Il. i. 32. *prosdeo/meqa . . . sumpe/myai h(mi=n, w(s a)/n min e)ce/lwmen e)k th=s xw/rhs. HDT. i. 36.
*tou\s e)mou\s lo/gous qumw=| ba/l', w(s a)

*touti\ labw/n mou to\ skia/deion u(pe/rexe a)/nwqen, w(s a)

2. In Attic prose w(s a)/n with the subjunctive is found only in Xenophon and in one passage of Thucydides.

The last is THUC. vi. 91: (pe/myete) a)/ndra *spartia/thn a)/rxonta, w(s a)\n tou/s te paro/ntas cunta/ch| kai\ tou\s mh\ qe/lontas prosanagka/sh|. See XEN. An. ii. 5, 16 , w(s d' a)\n ma/qh|s, a)nta/kouson. So XEN. An. vi. 3, 18. See other examples of Xenophon's peculiar use of w(s a)/n with the subjunctive in Appendix IV.

(*)/ofra.) *)/ofra ke and o)/fr' a)/n have the subjunctive in a few final clauses in Homer. E.g. *ou(=tos nu=n soi a(/m' e(/yetai, o)/fra ken eu(/dh| soi=sin e)ni\ mega/roisin Od. iii. 359.
*)/iomen, o)/fra ke qa=sson e)gei/romen o)cu
 *)/arha Il. ii. 440.
*to
 cei=non a)/g' e)s po/lin, o)/fr' a)

For o)/fra ke and o)/fr' a)/n with the optative, see 329, 1.

(*(/opws.) *(/opws does not occur in Homer in pure final clauses with either ke/ or a)/n. *(/opws a)/n final with the subjunctive appears first in Aeschylus, and remains in good use in Attic poetry and prose, being almost the only final expression found in the formal language of the Attic inscriptions. One case of o(/kws a)/n occurs in Herodotus. E.g. *fu/lasse ta)n oi)/kw| kalw=s, o(/pws a)
 a)rti/kolla sumbai/nh| ta/de, watch what goes on in the house, that these things may work harmoniously. AESCH. Cho. 579: so AESCH. Prom. 824, AESCH. Eum. 573, AESCH. Eum. 1030, Suppl. 233. *)/isqi pa=n to\ drw/menon, o(/pws a)

div2.head: a)/n, or ke/, in Final Clauses with Optative.
div2.p: 1. (*(ws, and o)/fra, in Homer and w(s, and o(/kws, in Herodotus.) In Homer w(/s ke and w(s a)/n sometimes have the optative in final clauses after both primary and secondary tenses. *)/ofra ke and o)/fr' a)/n occur each once in Homer with the optative after past tenses. Herodotus has w(s a)/n and o(/kws a)/n with the optative after past tenses, and o(/kws a)/n once after a present tense. This optative with ke/ or a)/n after primary tenses is certainly potential as well as final; and this analogy makes it difficult or impossible to take it in any other sense after secondary tenses, though here the potential force is less obvious.

(a) After primary tenses six cases occur in the Odyssey and one in Herodotus:—
*)aperri/gasi ne/esqai w(/s k' au)to\s e)ednw/saito qu/gatra they dread to go to him that he may settle (if he will) the bridal gifts of his daughter, lit. that he would settle, etc. Od. ii. 53 .
*knuzw/sw de/ toi o)/sse, w(s a)\n a)eike/lios fanei/hs I will dim your eyes, to the end that you might appear unseemly. Od. xiii. 401.
*du/o dou=re kallipe/ein, w(s a)\n e)piqu/santes e(loi/meqa Od. xvi. 297.
*tw=| ke ta/xa gnoi/hs filo/thta/ te polla/ te dw=ra e)c e)meu=, w(s a)/n ti/s se sunanto/menos makari/zoi, so that one would call you blessed. Od. xvii. 164 (= xv. 537, Od. xix. 310).
*(hgei/sqw o)rxhqmoi=o, w(/s ke/n tis fai/h ga/mon e)/mmenai e)kto\s a)kou/wn let him lead off the dance, so that any one who should hear without would say there was a marriage. Od. xxiii. 134.
*)/isxesqe ptole/mou, w(/s ken a)nai/mwti/ ge diakrinqei=te ta/xista Od. xxiv. 531.
*keleu/ei se to\ paidi/on qei=nai, o(/kws a)\n ta/xista diafqarei/h, he bids you so expose the child that he would be likely to perish most speedily. HDT. i. 110.

(b) After past tenses the following cases occurIt must be confessed that there are some difficult questions concerning these optatives with ke/ or a)/n in final clauses after past tenses. It may perhaps be thought that the subjunctive after w(/s ke, o(/kws a)/n, etc., has been changed to the optative after a past tense retaining ke/ or a)/n without effect on the verb. Compare e(/ws a)/n with the optative (613, 4; 702). Would o(/kws a)/n in HDT. i. 22 (quoted in 328) have changed its nature if a)ggei/lh| had been changed to a)ggei/leie? On the other hand, can we separate the optatives in HDT. i. 75 and 99 (in b) from the optative in i. 110 (in a)? The potential view seems, on the whole, much the more natural; but the potential force can be expressed in English only with great difficulty, owing to the ambiguity of our auxiliaries might, would, should, etc.:—

*(=ue d' a)/ra *zeu\s sunexe\s, o)/fra ke qa=sson a(li/ploa tei/xea qei/h. Il. xii. 25. *)ew/lpein se *fqi/hnde ne/esqai, w(s a)/n moi to\n pai=da *skuro/qen e)caga/gois, i.e. I hoped for your coming, that you might perchance bring my son away from Scyros. Il. xix. 330.
*kai/ min makro/teron kai\ pa/ssona qh=ken i)de/sqai, w(/s ken *faih/kessi fi/los pa/ntessi ge/noito Od. viii. 20.
*tu/mbon xeu/amen, w(/s kei thlefanh\s e)k ponto/fin a)ndra/sin ei)/h Od. xxiv. 83.
*su\ de/ me proi+/eis, o)/fr' a)\n e(loi/mhn dw=ra (Bekker a)neloi/mhn). Ib. 333.

*le/getai diw/ruxa o)ru/ssein, o(/kws a)
 to\ strato/pedon i(drume/non kata\ nw/tou la/boi, i.e. he is said to have dug (119) a channel, in order that the river might flow behind the army. HDT. i. 75. *tau=ta de\ peri\ e(wuto
 e)se/mnue tw=nde ei(/neken, o(/kws a)
 mh\ o(re/ontes oi( o(mh/likes lupeoi/ato kai\ e)pibouleu/oien, a)ll' e(teroi=o/s sfi doke/oi ei)=nai mh\ o(rw=si, in order that his companions might not be offended by seeing him and plot against him, but that he might appear to them to be of another nature when they did not see him. Id. i. 99. *porfu/reon ei(=ma peribalo/menos, w(s a)
 punqano/menoi plei=stoi sune/lqoien. Id. i. 152. *to\ u(/dwr to/te e)ph=kan, w(s a)
 xaradrwqei/h o( xw=ros, they let in the water, in order that the country might be gullied. Id. vii. 176. *perie/pempon e)/cwqen *skia/qou, w(s a)
 mh\ o)fqei/hsan periple/ousai *eu)/boian. Id. viii. 7. *)/hlaunon tou\s i(/ppous, w(s a)
 to
