 mh\ i)doi/ato oi( *pe/rsai e)cormeome/nous. Ib. 51.

2. *(ws a)/n with the optative in Attic prose is found chiefly in Xenophon. It is never strictly final; but w(s is relative or interrogative, and the optative with a)/n is potential. E.g. *)/edocen au)tw=| tou=to poih=sai, w(s o(/ti h(/kista a)
 e)pifqo/nws spanio/s te kai\ semno\s fanei/h, he decided to do this in such a way that he might appear, etc. (i.e. in the way by which.) XEN. Cyr. vii. 5, 37. (Here the separation of a)/n from w(s makes the potential character plainer.) *(ws d' a)
 kai\ oi( po/des ei)=en tw=| i(/ppw| kra/tistoi, ei) me/n tis e)/xei r(a/|w a)/skhsin, k.t.l., as to means by which the horse's feet could be kept strongest. Hipp. i. 16.See other examples in Appendix IV. This is the same relative use of w(s with the potential optative which we find in DEM. vi. 3, w(s me
 a)
 ei)/poite dikai/ous lo/gous a)/meinon *fili/ppou pareskeu/asqe: w(s de\ kwlu/sait' a)
 e)kei=non pra/ttein tau=ta, pantelw=s a)rgw=s e)/xete, as to means by which you could make just speeches, you are better equipped than Philip; but as to steps by which you could prevent him from doing what he does, you are wholly inactive. See also DEM. vi. 37, w(s d' a)
 e)cetasqei/h ma/list' a)kribw=s, mh\ ge/noito, as to any means by which the truth could be tested most thoroughly,—may this never come!
*(/opws a)/n with a final potential optative occurs once in Thucydides, four times in Xenophon, and once in Aeschylus.

*ta\s prw/|ras katebu/rswsan, o(/pws a)
 a)polisqa/noi h( xei e)piballome/nh, they covered the prows with hides, that the (iron) hand when thrown on might be likely to slip off. THUC. vii. 65. *)edwke xrh/mata *)antalki/da|, o(/pws a)
, plhrwqe/ntos nautikou= u(po\ *lakedaimoni/wn, oi( *)aqhnai=oi ma=llon th=s ei)rh/nhs prosde/ointo. XEN. Hell. iv. 8, 16. (Here plhrwqe/ntos nautikou=, if a navy should be manned, stands as protasis to prosde/ointo a)/n.) *(/opws d' a)
 w(s e)rrwmene/staton to\ stra/teuma poih/saito, e)c a)/llwn po/lewn h)rgurolo/gei. Ib. iv. 8, Ib. 30. *pa=sin e)di/dou bou=s te, o(/pws a)
 qu/santes e(stiw=|nto, kai\ e)kpw/mata. Id. Cyr. viii. 3, Id. Cyr. 33 (one MS. omits a)/n). *th
 lei/an a)pe/pemye diati/qesqai *(hraklei/dhn, o(/pws a)
 misqo\s ge/noito toi=s stratiw/tais. Id. An. vii. 4, Id. An. 2 (most MSS. have o(/pws ge/nhtai). SO AESCH. Ag. 364.
In these cases the final force is equally strong with the potential.

div2.head: Elliptical Constructions.
div2.p: In colloquial Greek we often find i(/na ti/; that what?— where ti/ takes the place of a final clause, which generally appears in the answer to the question. E.g. *b*l. i(/na ti/; *p*r. dh=lon toutogi/: i(/na . . . e)/xwsin. AR. Eccl. 719. So AR. Nub. 1192, Pac. 409. So DEM. xix. 257: i(/na ti/; i(/n' w(s meta\ plei/sths suggnw/mhs par' u(mw=n kathgorw=. Just before this we have dia\ ti/; i(/na mh/te e)le/ou mh/te suggnw/mhs tu/xh|. So PLAT. Ap. 26 C.

A final clause may stand without a leading verb expressed, when the omission can easily be supplied; as o(/ti h)=rca, mh\ a)podhmh/sw; i(/na ge mh\ prolabw\n xrh/mata th=s po/lews h)\ pra/ceis drasmw=| xrh/sh|, because I held an office, may I not leave the country? No: that you may not take to flight, etc. AESCHIN. iii. 21.

div2.head: Secondary Tenses of Indicative in Final Clauses.
div2.p: In Attic Greek the secondary tenses of the indicative are used in final clauses with i(/na, sometimes with o(/pws or w(s, to denote that the purpose is dependent upon some unaccomplished action or unfulfilled condition, and therefore is not or was not attained.

The tenses of the indicative differ here as in conditional sentences, the imperfect (the most frequent tense) referring to present time or to continued or repeated action in past time, the aorist and pluperfect to past time (410). Thus i(/na tou=to e)/pratten means in order that he might be doing this (but he is not doing it), or that he might have been doing this (but he was not); i(/na tou=to e)/pracen means that he might have done this (but he did not); i(/na tou=to e)pepra/xei means that he might have done this (but he has not). E.g. *ou)k a)
 e)sxo/mhn, i(/n' h)= tuflo/s te kai\ klu/wn mhde/n, in that case I should not have forborne (to destroy my hearing), so that I might (now) be both blind and devoid of hearing (implying that really he is not so). SOPH. O.T. 1387. *feu=, feu=, to\ mh\ ta\ pra/gmat' a)nqrw/pois e)/xein fwnh
, i(/n) h)=san mhde
 oi( deinoi\ lo/goi, Alas! alas! that the facts have no voice for men, so that words of eloquence might be as nothing. EUR. Fr.(EUR. Hipp.) 442. *)eboulo/mhn me
 e(/teron a)
 tw=n h)qa/dwn le/gein ta\ be/ltisq', i(/n' e)kaqh/mhn h(/suxos. AR. Eccl. 151. *)exrh=n ei)skale/santas ma/rturas pollou\s parashmh/nasqai keleu=sai ta\s diaqh/kas, AR. Eccl. i (/n), ei)/ ti e)gi/gneto a)mfisbhth/simon, h)=n ei)s ta\ gra/mmata tau=t) e)panelqei=n. DEM. xxviii. 5. (This implies that they did not have the will thus sealed, so that it is not now possible to refer to it in case of dispute.) *)ech/|thsen a)/n me to
 pai=da, i(/n) ei) mh\ paredi/doun mhde
 di/kaion le/gein e)do/koun. DEM. xxix. 17. *)exrh=n au)tou\s th
 pro- te/ran zh/thsin zhtei=n, i(/na a)phlla/gmeqa tou/tou tou= dhmagwgou=, they ought to have made the previous investigation, in order that we might have been already freed from this demagogue (but we have not been freed from him). DIN. i. 10. See LYS. i. 40 and 42; ISOC. ix. 5, ISOC. xviii. 51. *)alla\ se\ e)xrh=n h(mi=n sugxwrei=n, i(/na sunousi/a e)gi/gneto, but you ought to give way to us, that our conversation might not be interrupted (as it is). PLAT. Prot. 335 C.

*ti/ dh=t' ou)k e)/rriy' e)mauth\n th=sd' a)po\ pe/tras, o(/pws tw=n pa/ntwn po/nwn a)phlla/ghn; why did I not throw myself from this rock, that I might have been freed from all my toils? AESCH. Prom. 747 : so AESCH. Cho. 195.See SOPH. El. 1134. *ou)kou=n e)xrh=n se *phga/sou ceu=cai ptero\n, o(/pws e)fai/nou toi=s qeoi=s tragikw/teros; Pac. 135.

*ti/ m' ou) labw\n e)/kteinas eu)qu\s, w(s e)/deica mh/pote e)mauto\n a)nqrw/poisin e)/nqen h)= gegw/s; that I might never have shown, as I have done. SOPH. O.T. 1391.
*ei) ga/r m' u(po\ gh=n h(=ken, w(s mh/te qeo\s mh/te tis a)/llos toi=sd' e)pegh/qei, would that he had sent me under the earth, so that neither any God nor any one else should be rejoicing at these things (as they are). AESCH. Prom. 152.
*)/edei ta\ e)ne/xura to/te labei=n, w(s mhd' ei) e)bou/leto e)du/nato e)capata=n. XEN. An. vii. 6, 23 (the only case in Xenophon).

This construction is the result of an assimilation, which makes more distinct the connection in thought between the two clauses. It is especially common after secondary tenses implying unfulfilled conditions and unaccomplished wishes.

*)/an cannot properly be added to the indicative in this construction. In the two examples in which it is found, it would seem that the construction has slipped into an apodosis, or that copyists have been misled by the resemblance to an apodosis and inserted a)\n.

*zw=nti e)/dei bohqei=n, o(/pws o(/ti dikaio/tatos w)
 kai\ o(siw/tatos e)/zh te zw=n kai\ teleuth/sas a)timw/rhtos a)
 kakw=n a(marthma/twn e)gi/gneto, in order that he might thus live while he lives, and (so that) after death he would be (as a consequence of such a life) free from punishment (?). Leg. 959 B. *to/n ge pra/ttonta/ ti di/kaion ou) prosh=ken a)porei=n a)ll' eu)qu\s le/gein, i(/na ma=llon a)
 e)pisteu/eto u(f) u(mw=n, (possibly) that the result might be that he would be (in that case) the more trusted by you. ISAE. xi. 6.

The indicative can never be used in this construction, unless the final clause refers to present or past time, and unless also it is distinctly implied that the purpose is not (or was not) attained. If the purpose is future (at the time of speaking), or if it is left uncertain whether the object is or was attained, it must be expressed in the ordinary way by the subjunctive or optative, even though it depends on one of the class of verbs mentioned above. Both constructions may occur in the same sentence. E.g. *ou(\s (tw=n ne/wn tou\s a)gaqou\s) h(mei=s a)
 e)fula/ttomen e)n a)kropo/lei, i(/na mhdei\s au)tou\s die/fqeiren, a)ll' e)peidh\ a)fi/kointo ei)s th
 h(li- ki/an, xrh/simoi gi/gnointo tai=s po/lesin, we should guard (in that case) in the Acropolis, that no one might corrupt them (as some now corrupt them), and that when (in the future) they should become of age they might become useful to their states. PLAT. Men. 89B. (Here it is not implied that they never become useful, this depending partly on the future.) *tau=t' a)
 h)/dh le/gein pro\s u(ma=s e)pexei/roun, i(/n' ei)dh=te pollou= dei=n a)/cion o)/nta tuxei=n tou= yhfi/smatos au)to
 toutoui/, I should (if that were so) be now undertaking to explain this to you, that you might (after hearing me) know that he is far from deserving the honour of the proposed decree. DEM. xxiii. 7. *kai/toi xrh=n se h)\ tou=ton mh\ gra/fein h)\ e)kei=non lu/ein, ou)x, i(/na o(\ bou/lei su\ ge/nhtai, pa/nta suntara/cai, i.e. you ought not to have confused everything in order that what you want might be done. DEM. xxiv. 44.
Clauses with mh/ after verbs of fearing are never thus assimilated to a preceding indicative, as there is no reference here to the attainment of a purpose.

A purpose can be expressed in various forms besides that of the final clause; as by the relative with the future indicative, or in Homer with the subjunctive (565; 568); by the infinitive (770) or the infinitive with w(/ste or w(s (587, 3); by the future participle (840); by u(pe/r with the genitive of the articular infinitive (802).

div2.head: Object Clauses with o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ after Verbs of Striving, etc.
div2.p: In Attic Greek and in Herodotus, object clauses with o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ after verbs signifying to strive, to plan, to care for, to effect, regularly have the future indicative after primary tenses to express the object aimed at. The subjunctive also is used, but less frequently than the future indicative.

After secondary tenses the future optative may be used, corresponding to the future indicative after primary tenses; but generally the future indicative is retained, as the original form of the thought (319). The other tenses of the optative are sometimes used, to correspond to the same tenses of the subjunctive, or the subjunctive itself may be retained (318). E.g. *)epimelei=tai o(/pws (or o(/pws mh\) genh/setai or ge/nhtai, he takes care that it may (or may not) happen. *)epemelei=to o(/pws genh/setai, genh/soito, or ge/noito, he took care that it should happen.

(Fut.) *to\ me
 kalw=s e)/xon o(/pws xroni/zon eu)= menei= bouleute/on, we must take counsel that what is well shall continue to be well. AESCH. Ag. 846. *didou\s de\ to/nde fra/z) o(/pws mhdei\s brotw=n kei/nou pa/roiqen a)mfidu/setai xroi+/. SOPH. Tr. 604. *soi\ dh\ me/lein xrh\ ta)/ll' o(/pws e(/cei kalw=s. I. T. EUR. 1051. *ei)rh/nh d' o(/pws e)/stai protimw=s' ou)de/n, but that there shall be peace they care not. AR. Ach. 26. *soi\ mele/tw o(/kws mh/ se o)/yetai. HDT. i. 9. *(/ora o(/kws mh\ a)posth/sontai. Id. iii. 36. *xrh\ o(ra=n tou\s *)argei/ous o(/pws swqh/setai h( *pelopo/nnhsos. THUC. v. 27. *(/wsper to
 poime/na dei= e)pimelei=sqai o(/pws sw=|ai/ te e)/sontai ai( oi)=es kai\ ta\ e)pith/deia e(/cousin, ou(/tw kai\ to
 strathgo
 e)pimelei=sqai dei= o(/pws sw=|oi/ te oi( stratiw=tai e)/sontai kai\ ta\ e)pith/deia e(/cousi, kai\ ou(= e(/neka strateu/ontai tou=to e)/stai. XEN. Mem. iii. 2, 1. *kalw=s de\ dhmagwgh/seis, h)
 skoph=|s o(/pws oi( be/ltistoi me
 ta\s tima\s e(/cousin, oi( d' a)/lloi mhde
 a)dikh/sontai. ISOC. ii. 16. *fro/ntiz) o(/pws mhde
 a)na/cion th=s timh=s tau/ths pra/ceis. Ib. 37. *ti/ ma/list' e)n a(/pasi diespou/dastai toi=s no/mois; o(/pws mh\ genh/sontai oi( peri\ a)llh/lous fo/noi. DEM. xx. 157. *mi/kran pro/noian e)/xein u(mi=n o( qei\s to
 no/mon dokei= o(/pws ku/rios e)/stai kai\ mh/te sugxuqh/setai mh/t' au)= metapoihqh/setai; Id. xxiii. 62. *kalo
 to\ paraskeua/zein o(/pws w(s be/ltistai e)/sontai tw=n politw=n ai( yuxai/. PLAT. Gorg. 503A. *dei= eu)labei=sqai, ma/lista me
 o(/pws mh\ e)ggenh/sesqon, a)
 de\ e)gge/nhsqon, o(/pws o(/ti ta/xista e)ktetmh/sesqon. Rep. 564C.

(Subj.) *xrh\ fula/ssein kai\ prokatalamba/nein o(/pws mhd' e)s e)pi/noian tou/tou i)/wsi. THUC. iii. 46. (*paraskeua/zesqai) o(/pws su\n qew=| a)gwnizw/meqa. XEN. Cyr. i. 5, 14. *ou) ga\r o(/pws plei/onos a)/cios ge/nhtai e)pimelei=tai, a)ll' o(/pws au)to\s o(/ti plei=sta w(rai=a karpw/setai (subj. and fut. combined). Symp. viii. 25. *ou) fula/cesq' o(/pws mh\ despo/thn eu(/rhte. DEM. vi. 25. *)/allou tou e)pimelh/sei h)\ o(/pws o(/ti be/ltistoi oi( poli=tai w)=men; PLAT. Gorg. 515B *(/ora o(/pws mh\ para\ do/can o(mologh=|s. Id. Crit. 49C.

(Fut. Opt.) *)/ezh u(po\ pollh=s e)pimelei/as o(/pws w(s e)la/xista me\n o)/yoito, e)la/xista d' a)kou/soito, e)la/xista d' e)/roito. XEN. Oec. vii. 5. (After a primary tense this would be o(/pws o)/yetai, a)kou/setai, e)/rhtai. But Cobet reads e)roi/h.) *)epemelei=to o(/pws mh\ a)/sitoi/ pote e)/sointo. Id. Cyr. viii. 1, Id. Cyr. 43.See the examples under 130.

(Fut. Indic. after past tenses.) *)/eprasson o(/pws tis boh/qeia h(/cei. THUC. iii. 4. *proqumhqe/ntos e(no\s e(ka/stou o(/pws h( nau=s proe/cei. Id. vi. 31. *eu)labei=sqai parekeleu/esqe a)llh/lois, o(/pws mh\ lh/sete diafqare/ntes. PLAT. Gorg. 487D. *ou)d' o(/pws o)rqh\ pleu/setai proei/deto, a)lla\ to\ kaq' au(to\n o(/pws e)pi\ toi=s e)xqroi=s e)/stai pareskeu/asen. DEM. xix. 250; so xix. 316.

(Pres. or Aor. Opt.) *)epeme/leto au)tw=n, o(/pws a)ei\ a)ndra/poda diateloi=en. XEN. Cyr. viii. 1, 44. *)apekri/nato, o(/ti au)tw=| me/loi o(/pws kalw=s e)/xoi. Id. An. i. 8, Id. An. 13. *)ememelh/kei de\ au)toi=s o(/pws o( i(ppagre/ths ei)dei/h ou(\s de/oi pe/mpein. Id. Hell. iii. 3, Id. Hell. 9.

(Subj. after past tenses.) *frourh/sous) (h)=|ca) o(/pws *ai)/gisqos h(ma=s mh\ la/qh|. SOPH. El. 1402.SO HDT. ii. 121. *)/eprassen o(/pws po/lemos ge/nhtai. THUC. i. 57. *)/eprasson o(/pws a)posth/swsin *)aqhnai/wn th\n po/lin. Id. iii. 70. *)wnei=tai par' au)tw=n o(/pws mh\ a)pi/wmen (v.l. a)/pimen) e)k *makedoni/as, he bribed them to effect that we should not leave Macedonia (after historic present). DEM. xviii. 32.

It will thus be seen that the future indicative is the most common form in these sentences, after both primary and secondary tenses; the future optative, which is theoretically the regular form after secondary tenses, being rarely used. (See 128.)

div2.head: Homeric and other Early Usages.
div2.p: In Homer, verbs signifying to plan, to consider, and to try, chiefly fra/zomai, bouleu/w, mermhri/zw, and peirw=, have o(/pws or w(s with the subjunctive after primary tenses, and the optative (never future) and sometimes the subjunctive (318) after secondary tenses. *ke/ is almost always used here with w(s and the subjunctive, less frequently with o(/pws (313, 3).

The original relative and interrogative force of o(/pws and w(s is more apparent here than in the Attic construction of o(/pws with the future indicative, especially after verbs of considering; though after peirw= the dependent clause comes nearer the later meaning. E.g. *au)toi\ de\ frazw/meq' o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ge/nhtai, let us ourselves consider how the very best things may be done. Od. xiii. 365.
*frazo/meq' (imperfect) *)argei/oisin o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ge/noito Od. iii. 129.
*fra/zesqai o(/ppws ke mnhsth=ras ktei/nh|s Od. i. 295.
*perifrazw/meqa pa/ntes no/ston, o(/pws e)/lqh|sin i.e. how he may come. Od. i. 76.
*fra/zwmesq' w(/s ke/n min pepi/qwmen Il. ix. 112.
*fra/ssetai w(/s ke ne/htai, e)pei\ polumh/xano/s e)stin Od. i. 205.
*(/ama pro/ssw kai\ o)pi/ssw leu/ssei o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ge/nhtai, i.e. he looks to see how, etc. Il. iii. 110.
*)eno/hse qea\ w(s *)oduseu\s e)/groito Od. vi. 112.
*ou) ga\r dh\ tou=ton me\n e)bou/leusas no/on au)th\, w(s h)= toi kei/nous *)oduseu\s a)poti/setai e)lqw/n; Od. v. 23.
*bou/leuon o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ge/noito Od. ix. 420.
*)=hlqon, ei)/ tina boulh\n ei)/poi o(/pws *)iqa/khn e)s paipalo/essan i(koi/mhn Od. xi. 479.
*mermh/rizen o(/pws a)poloi/ato pa=sai nh=es Od. ix. 554.
*mermh/rize kata\ fre/na w(s *)axilh=a timh/sh| (or timh/sei)), i.e. how he might honour Achilles. Il. ii. 3.
*)all' a)/ge mh=tin u(/fhnon o(/pws a)poti/somai au)tou/s Od. xiii. 386.
*(/wrmhnen a)na\ qumo\n o(/pws pau/seie po/noio di=on *)axillh=a Il. xxi. 137.
*mnhso/meq' w(/s x' o( cei=nos h(\n patri/da gai=an i(/khtai, mhde/ ti messhgu/s ge kako\n kai\ ph=ma pa/qh|sin Od. vii. 192. In Hymn. Pyth. Ap. 148 we have texnh/somai w(/s ke ge/nhtai.
*pei/ra o(/pws ken dh\ sh\n patri/da gai=an i(/khai, i.e. try to find means by which you may go, etc. Od. iv. 545.
*peira=| w(/s ke *trw=es u(perfi/aloi a)po/lwntai Il. xxi. 459.
*toi=si de\ po/ll' e)pe/telle peira=n w(s pepi/qoien a)mu/mona *phlei+/wna Il. ix. 179. In Il. xv. 164 we have fraz/esqw mh/ m' ou)de\ tala/ssh| mei=nai (354).
For a full citation of the Homeric examples with o(/pws and w(s, see Appendix III. 3.
The frequent addition of ke/ to w(s or o(/pws in Homer shows the relative origin of the construction (312, 2).
For o(/kws a)/n in Herodotus, see 350; for o(/pws a)/n in this construction in Attic writers, see 348, 349.

In Homer o(/pws takes the future indicative chiefly when it is merely an indirect interrogative, with no reference to purpose, as in Il. ii. 252, ou)de/ ti/ pw sa/fa i)/dmen o(/pws e)/stai ta/de e)/rga , we do not yet even know certainly how these things are to be; or in Od. xiii. 376, fra/zeu o(/pws mnhsth=rsin a)naide/si xei=ras e)fh/seis , consider how you will lay hands on the shameless suitors. See Il. ix. 251; Od. xx. 38. In Od. xx. 28 the future indicative is retained after a past tense, there being as yet no future optative (128); e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa e)li/sseto mermhri/zwn o(/ppws dh\ mnhsth=rsin a)naide/si xei=ras e)fh/sei. *(/opws may take the future (like other tenses) as a simple relative; as in Il. i. 136, o(/pws a)nta/cion e)/stai, as shall be an equivalent.

*)/ofra has the subjunctive in an object clause in Il. vi. 361, h)/dh ga/r moi qumo\s e)pe/ssutai, o)/fr' e)pamu/nw *trw/essi , and the optative in Od. iv. 463, ti/s sumfra/ssato boula\s o)/fra m' e(/lois; In Il. i. 523, e)moi\ de/ ke tau=ta melh/setai o)/fra tele/ssw , o)/fra may mean until.

The single object clause of this class in Pindar is Pyth. i. 72, neu=son a(/meron o)/fra kat' oi)=kon o( *foi=nic o( *tursanw=n t' a)la/latos e)/xh| , grant that the Phoenician, with the Etruscan war-cry, may keep quiet at home. (See 359.)

As relics of the Homeric usage we find w(s with the subjunctive in sentences of this class in EUR. Med. 461, I. T. 467, PLAT. Rep. 349 C; and with the optative in AESCH. Prom. 203 (see 353, below). Herodotus has w(s with the future indicative in iii. 84, 159, vii. 161 (in the last w(s strathgh/seis gli/xeai). Herodotus has w(s a)/n with the subjunctive in iii. 85, mhxanw= w(s a)\n sxw=men tou=to to\ ge/ras, which is cited as the solitary case of w(s a)/n in these object clauses after Homer, except in Xenophon (351). See also Sept. 627, Eum. 771; SOLON xiii. 38; SOPH. Ant. 215 (in 281, above).

div2.head: o(/pws a)/n, in Attic Greek and Herodotus.: w(s, and w(s a)/n, in Xenophon.
div2.p:
The Attic writers sometimes use o(/pws a)/n with the subjunctive in these object clauses. This occurs chiefly in Aristophanes, Xenophon, and Plato. E.g. *sko/pei o(/pws a)
 a)poqa/nwmen a)ndrikw/tata, see that we die most manfully. AR. Eq. 80. *diamhxanh/somai o(/pws a)
 i(sti/on sapro
 la/bh|s, I will contrive that (somehow?) you get a rotten mast. Ib. 917. So AR. Nub. 739, AR. Eccl. 623, AR. Ach. 1060, AR. Eq. 926. *ma=llon h)\ pro/sqen ei)sh/|ei au)tou\s o(/pws a)
 kai\ e)/xonte/s ti oi)/kade a)fi/kwntai. XEN. An. vi. 1, 17. (Here some word like e)pime/leia is understood as the subject of ei)sh/|ei.) *tw=n a)/llwn e)pimelei=tai o(/pws a)
 qhrw=sin. Id. Cyr. i. 2, Id. Cyr. 10. *)eke/leuse to
 *ferau/lan e)pimelhqh=nai o(/pws a)
 ou(/tw ge/nhtai au)/rion h( e)ce/lasis. Ib. viii. 3, Ib. 6: so v. 5, Ib. 48.See also XEN. Cyneg. vi. 23; Eques. iv. 3. *)=h a)/llou e)fie/menoi dika/sousin h)\ tou/tou, o(/pws a)
 e(/kastoi mh/t' e)/xwsi ta)llo/tria mh/te tw=n au(tw=n ste/rwntai; PLAT. Rep. 433E. *pa/nta poiou=ntas o(/pws a)
 sfi/si to\ phda/lion e)pitre/yh|. Ib. 488C. *)ea
 d' e)/lqh|, mhxanhte/on o(/pws a)
 diafu/gh| kai\ mh\ dw=| di/khn o( e)xqro/s. Gorg. 481A.

Besides the examples cited above, Weber gives fifteen of Plato, and the following: SOPH. Tr. 618; EUR. I. A. 539; ISAE. vii. 30; DEM. xvi. 17, DEM. xix. 299. He adds HDT. i. 20, where o(/kws a)/n is certainly final.

The only case of o(/pws a)/n with the optative in an object clause in Attic Greek, except in Xenophon (351), is PLAT. Lys. 207E, proqumou=ntai o(/pws a)\n eu)daimonoi/hs, which is potential and on the Xenophontic model (see 351, 2). In DEM. xxxv. 29, e)keleu/omen tou/tous e)pimelei=sqai o(/pws a)\n w(s ta/xist' a)pola/boimen ta\ xrh/mata, Cod. A reads a)pola/bwmen.

Herodotus has o(/kws a)/n with the potential optative four times after past tenses. E.g. *proqumeome/nou de\ *loci/ew o(/kws a)\n ge/noito, being zealous that it might (in some way) be done. i. 91. So ii. 126, iii. 44, v. 98.

(Xenophon.) Although Xenophon generally follows the Attic usage in these object clauses (339), he yet violates this signally by having w(s and w(s a)/n with both subjunctive and optative, and o(/pws a)/n with the optative; and further by having the optative with w(s a)/n and o(/pws a)/n after both primary and secondary tenses. He also has w(s twice with the future indicative (like o(/pws) and once with the future optative.

1. *(ws or w(s a)/n with the subjunctive, w(s with the future indicative, and w(s with the optative, are used by Xenophon like o(/pws in the construction of 339. E.g. *)epimelou=ntai w(s e)/xh| ou(/tws. Oec. xx. 8. (Here the regular Attic usage requires o(/pws e(/cei.) *)epimelei=sqai w(s a)\n praxqh=|, to take care that they shall be done. Hipp. ix. 2. *)epeme/lonto w(s mh\ kwlu/ointo. Cyr. vi. 3, Cyr. 2. *(ws de\ kalw=s e(/cei ta\ u(me/tera, e)moi\ melh/sei. Ib. iii. 2, Ib. 13. *proei=pen w(s mhdei\s kinh/soito mhde\ a)na/coito. Hell. ii. 1, Hell. 22 (see 355).
For Xenophon's regular use of o(/pws in all these constructions, see examples under 339. For his regular use of o(/pws a)/n with the subjunctive, see 348.

2. When the optative follows w(s a)/n or o(/pws a)/n, it is always potential, and the original relative and interrogative force of w(s and o(/pws plainly appears. E.g. *)epime/lontai w(s a)
 be/ltistoi ei)=en oi( poli=tai, they take care that the citizens may be best (to see how they might be best). Cyr. i. 2, Cyr. 5. *(ws a)
 a)sfale/stata/ g' ei)dei/hn e)poi/oun, I took steps that (by which) I might know most accurately. Ib. vi. 3, Ib. 18. *skopw= o(/pws a)
 w(s r(a=|sta dia/goien, I am considering how they might live the easiest lives. Symp. vii. 2. (Cf. PLAT. Lys. 207E, quoted in 349.)
For a full enumeration of all the irregular passages of this class in Xenophon, see Appendix IV.

div2.head: Negative Object Clauses.
div2.p:
None of the object clauses with o(/pws or w(s in Homer (341) are negative, except that Od. vii. 192 combines w(/s ke i(/khtai with mhde/ ti pa/qh|sin. Negative object clauses are expressed in Homer, like most negative final clauses (315), by the simple mh/ with the subjunctive or optative, as in
Il. v. 411, fraz/esqw mh/ ti/s oi( a)mei/nwn sei=o ma/xhtai , and Il. xv. 164, Il. xxii. 358, Od. xvii. 595, all with fra/zomai mh/ and the subjunctive. So me/mbleto tei=xos mh\ *danaoi\ pe/rseian, Il. xxi. 517. These examples show a common origin with clauses after verbs of fearing, but the optative in the last example indicates that the original parataxis is no longer felt.

The earliest example of a negative object clause with a final particle and mh/ is AESCH. Prom. 203, speu/dontes (past) w(s *zeu\s mh/pot' a)/rceien qew=n . In all the Attic writers and in Herodotus the development of the negative object clause with o(/pws mh/ and the future keeps pace with that of the negative final clause with i(/na mh/, etc.

(*mh/, for o(/pws mh/, in Object Clauses.) Verbs of this class (339) which imply caution, especially o(rw= and skopw=, may have the simple mh/ with the subjunctive (rarely with the future indicative), even in Attic prose, like ordinary verbs of fear and caution (365), as well as o(/pws mh/ with the future. Such verbs belong equally to the two classes B and C (303). E.g. *sko/pei mh/ soi pro/noi) h)=| tou= qeou= fulakte/a SOPH. O.C. 1180.
*(/ora su\ mh\ nu=n me/n tis eu)xerh\s parh=|s. Id. Ph. 519.
*(/ora mh\ para\ gnw/mhn pe/sh|s EUR. H.F. 594.
*sko/pei ta/de, mh\ nu=n fugo/ntes ei)=q' a(lw=men u(/steron. And. 755.
*throu= mh\ la/bh|s u(pw/pia AR. Vesp. 1386.
*(/ora mh\ ma/thn ko/mpos o( lo/gos ou(=tos ei)rhme/nos h)=|, i.e. lest this may prove to have been spoken, etc. HDT. vii. 103. *(/ora mh\ pollw=n e(ka/stw| h(mw=n xeirw=n deh/sei. XEN. Cyr. iv. 1, 18. *skopei= dh\ mh\ tou/tois au(to\n e)caith/shtai kai\ katagela/sh|. DEM. xxi. 151. *(/ora ou)=n mh/ ti kai\ nu=n e)rga/shtai. PLAT. Symp. 213D So Il. xv. 164 (see 342).
See the corresponding use of o(/pws mh/ for mh/ after verbs of fearing (370).

div2.head: o(/pws, after Verbs of Asking, Commanding, etc.
div2.p:
Verbs of asking, entreating, exhorting, commanding, and forbidding, which regularly take an object infinitive, sometimes have an object clause with o(/pws or o(/pws mh/ in nearly or quite the same sense. E.g.
*didou\s de\ to/nde fra/z o(/pws mhdei\s brotw=n kei/nou pa/roiqen a)mfidu/setai xroi+/, i.e. tell him that no one shall put on the robe before himself. SOPH. Tr. 604: so SOPH. Aj. 567.
*lakedaimoni/wn e)de/onto to\ yh/fism' o(/pws metastrafei/h AR. Ach. 536.
*kai/ s' ai)tw= braxu\, o(/pws e)/somai/ soi *fano/s. Id. Eq. 1256.
*(/okws e(wutw=n ge/nhtai to\ e)/rgon parakeleusa/menoi, e)/rgou ei)/xonto proqumo/teron. HDT. ix. 102.
*to\ *pa/nakton e)de/onto *boiwtou\s (?) o(/pws paradw/sousi *lakedaimoni/ois. THUC. v. 36.
*(/opws me\n mh\ a)poqa/nh| h)ntibo/lei kai\ i(ke/teuen, LYS. i. 29.
*paraitei=sqai o(/pws au)tw=n mh\ katayhfi/shsqe. ANT. i. 12.
*deh/setai d' u(mw=n o(/pws di/khn mh\ dw=|. Ib. 23: so ai)tou=mai o(/pws dw=|, Ibid.
*diakeleu/ontai o(/pws timwrh/setai pa/ntas tou\s toiou/tous. PLAT. Rep. 549E.
*paragge/llei o(/pws mh\ e)/sontai. Ib. 415B
*)/emoige a)phgo/reues o(/pws mh\ tou=to a)pokrinoi/mhn (fut. opt.) Ib. 339A.
*)apeirhme/non au)tw=| o(/pws mhde\n e)rei= w(=n h(gei=tai, when he is forbidden to say a word of what he believes. Ib. 337 E.

This is rare in Homer; but twice in the Odyssey li/ssomai has an object clause with o(/pws:—
*li/ssesqai de/ min au)to\s o(/pws nhmerte/a ei)/ph|, and implore him yourself to speak the truth. Od. iii. 19. (Compare the regular construction, ou)de/ se li/ssomai me/nein Il. i. 174. )
*li/sseto d' ai)ei\ *(/hfaiston klutoergo\n o(/pws lu/seien *)/arha, he implored him to liberate Ares. Od. viii. 344.

*li/ssomai with i(/na and the subjunctive is found in Od. iii. 327: li/ssesqai de/ min au)to\s i(/na nhmerte\s e)ni/sph| , and implore him yourself that he may speak the truth. With this we may compare DEM. xvi. 28, dh=loi e)/sontai ou)x i(/na *qespiai\ katoikisqw=si mo/non poiou/menoi th
 spoudh/n, it will be evident that they take an interest not merely in having Thespiae established; in both cases the object clause falls into the construction of a pure final clause. This is very rare in classic Greek; but it reappears in the later language, as in the New Testament: thus e)ntolh
 kainh
 di/dwmi u(mi=n, i(/na a)gapa=te a)llh/lous, a new commandment I give unto you, that ye love one another, IOH. Evang. xiii. 34. So e)deh/qhn i(/na e)kba/llwsin, LUC. ix. 40. Compare the Latin, rogat ut liceat.
In Od. xvii. 362 we find w)/trun' w(s a)\n pu/rna kata\ mnhsth=ras a)gei/roi, she exhorted him that he should collect bread among the suitors. (See 329, 1).

The singular case of w(s with the subjunctive in Il. i. 558, th=| s' o)i/w kataneu=sai e)th/tumon, w(s *)axilh=a timh/sh|s, o) le/sh|s de\ pole/as e)pi\ nhusi\n *)axaiw=n, i.e. I believe that you promised by your nod to honour Achilles, etc. has the appearance of indirect discourse; but probably kataneu/w w(s is used with the same feeling as li/ssomai o(/pws in 356, promising to act here taking the same construction as entreating to act. See PIND. Py. i. 72 (in 346). *(ws, as an adverb of manner, is here clearly on its way to its use in indirect discourse. Some read timh/seis and o)le/seis.

A singular use of o(/pws and the future indicative with dei= se in place of the regular infinitive occurs in SOPH. Aj. 556, dei= se o(/pws dei/ceis , for dei= se dei=cai, and Ph. 54, th
 *filokth/tou se dei= yuxh
 o(/pws lo/goisin e)kkle/yeis le/gwn. So Cratinus, Ph. Fr. 108, dei= s' o(/pws eu)sxh/monos a)lektruo/nos mhde
 dioi/seis. This would be like de/omai o(/pws (355) except for the object se/, which is like se/ in dei= se tou/tou, the o(/pws clause representing the genitive.

div2.head: Object Infinitive and Indirect Questions.
div2.p: Some verbs which regularly take an object clause with o(/pws sometimes take an object infinitive, which may have the article tou= or to/. (See 373 and 374.) E.g. *)aei/ tina e)peme/lonto sfw=n au)tw=n e)n tai=s a)rxai=s ei)=nai, they always took care that one of their own number should be in the offices (where we should expect o(/pws tis e)/stai or e)/soito). THUC. vi. 54. *ou)d' e)pemelh/qhn tou= didaskalo/n moi/ tina gene/sqai tw=n e)pistame/nwn. XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 4. *to\ me\n ou)=n lektikou\s gi/gnesqai tou\s suno/ntas ou)k e)/speuden. Ib. iv. 3, Ib. 1. (See 793.)

Verbs signifying to see or look out (like skopw=) may be followed by an indirect question with ei), whether; as ei) cumponh/seis kai\ cunerga/sei sko/pei, see whether you will assist me, etc. SOPH. Ant. 41.
For independent clauses with o(/pws and o(/pws mh/ with the future, often explained by an ellipsis of sko/pei or skopei=te, see 271-283.

div2.head: Aorist Subjunctive in -sw and -swmai -- Dawes's Canon.
div2.p: When an aorist subjunctive active or middle was to be used with o(/pws or o(/pws mh/ in any construction, the second aorist was preferred to a first aorist in -sw or -swmai, if both forms were in use. This preference arose from the great similarity in form between these sigmatic aorists and the future indicative (as between bouleu/sh| and bouleu/sei, bouleu/shtai and bouleu/setai). This made it natural also for a writer to avoid those forms of the subjunctive which were nearly identical with the future indicative where the latter could be used as well. This of course does not apply to the first aorist subjunctive passive, which has no resemblance to the future; and there is no reason for applying it to liquid aorists like mei/nw and sfh/lw.

The general rule laid down by Dawes more than a century ago (Misc. Crit. pp. 222 and 228), the so-called Canon Davesianus, which declared the first aorist subjunctive active and middle a solecism after o(/pws mh/ and ou) mh/, was extended by others so as to include o(/pws (without mh/), and the Greek authors were thoroughly emended to conform to it. As this rule has no other foundation than the accidental circumstance just mentioned (363), it naturally fails in many cases, in some of which even emendation is impossible. In the first place, there is no reason for applying the rule to pure final clauses, in which the future indicative is exceptional (324); and here it is now generally abandoned in theory, though not always in practice. There is, therefore, no objection whatever to such sentences as these: w(=n e(/neka e)pitaqh=nai, o(/pws a)polau/swmen kai\ o(/pws genw/meqa, XEN. Cyr. vii. 5, 82 ; e)kklhsi/an cunh/gagon, o(/pws u(pomnh/sw kai\ me/mywmai, THUC. ii. 60; and th
 a)gora
 e)pi\ th
 qa/lassan komi/sai, o(/pws para\ ta\s nau=s a)ristopoih/swntai, kai\ di) o)li/gou toi=s *)aqhnai/ois e)pixeirw=sin, THUC. vii. 39, in which the best Mss. have the subjunctive. Indeed, where the reading is doubtful, the subjunctive should be preferred in these cases. Secondly, in independent prohibitions with o(/pws mh/, although the future is the regular form, there is less objection to the subjunctive (even the first aorist) than in positive commands with simple o(/pws, since the analogy of the common mh\ poih/sh|s tou=to, do not do this, supports o(/pws mh\ poih/sh|s tou=to in the same sense (283). There is no such analogy, however, to justify such a positive command as o(/pws poih/sh|s tou=to, do this, and this form has much less manuscript authority to rest on. Thirdly, in the case of ou) mh/, if both constructions (denials and prohibitions) are explained on the same principle, no reason exists for excluding the subjunctive from either; and it cannot be denied that both the first and the second aorist subjunctive are amply supported by the manuscripts. (See 301.) Fourthly, in object clauses with o(/pws there is so great a preponderance of futures over subjunctives, that the presumption in all doubtful cases is here in favour of the future, as it is in favour of the subjunctive in pure final clauses. A much stronger case, therefore, is made out by those who (like Weber and most modern editors) change all sigmatic aorist subjunctives in this construction to futures. Some cases, however, resist emendation; as XEN. An. v. 6, 21 , keleu/ousi prostateu=sai o(/pws e)kpleu/sh| h( stratia/, where we cannot read e)kpleu/sei, as the future is e)kpleu/somai or e)kpleusou=mai. In DEM. i. 2, all Mss. except one read paraskeua/sasqai th
 taxi/sthn o(/pws e)nqe/nde bohqh/shte kai\ mh\ pa/qhte tau)to/n, and it seems very arbitrary to change bohqh/shte to bohqh/sete and leave pa/qhte. But a few cases like these weigh little against the established usage of the language, and we must perhaps leave the venerable Canon Davesianus undisturbed in the single department of object clauses with o(/pws, although we may admit an occasional exception even there.
See Transactions of the American Philological Association for 186970, pp. 46-55, where this question is discussed more fully.

div2.head: Clauses with mh/ after Verbs of Fearing, etc.
div2.p: Verbs and phrases which express or imply fear, caution, or danger take mh/, lest or that, with the subjunctive if the leading verb is primary, and with the optative if the leading verb is secondary. The subjunctive can also follow secondary tenses to retain the mood in which the object of the fear originally occurred to the mind.
*mh/ (like Latin ne) denotes fear that something may happen which is not desired; mh\ ou) (ut = ne non) denotes fear that something may not happen which is desired. E.g.

*fobou=mai mh\ ge/nhtai (vereor ne accidat), I fear that it may happen: fobou=mai mh\ ou) ge/nhtai (vereor ut accidat), I fear that it may not happen.
*dei/dw mh\ qh/ressin e(/lwr kai\ ku/rma ge/nwmai. Od. v. 473.
*dei/dw mh\ ou)/ ti/s toi u(po/sxhtai to/de e)/rgon. Il. x. 39. (This is the only case of mh\ ou) in these sentences in Homer. The next that are found are EUR. And. 626, El. 568, Phoen. 263. See 264, above.)
*ou) fobh=| mh/ s' *)/argos a)poktei=nai qe/lh|. EUR. Or. 770.
*poi=on e)/qnos ou) dokei= u(perhth/sein fobou/menon mh/ ti pa/qh|; XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 10
*fronti/zw mh\ kra/tiston h)=| moi siga=n. Id. Mem. iv. 2, 39
*fulatto/menos mh\ do/ch| manqa/nein ti. Ib. iv. 2, 3
*de/doika mh\ ou)d' o(/sion h)=| a)pagoreu/ein. PLAT. Rep. 368B.
*ta\ peri\ th=s yuxh=s pollh\n a)pisti/an pare/xei toi=s a)nqrw/pois, mh\ e)peida\n a)pallagh=| tou= sw/matos ou)damou= e)/ti h)=|, a)lla\ diafqei/rhtai/ te kai\ a)pollu/htai. Plat. Phaed. 70A.
*ou)kou=n nu=n kai\ tou=to ki/ndunos, mh\ la/bwsi prosta/tas au(tw=n tinas tou/twn, there is danger of this, that they may take, etc. XEN. An. vii. 7, 31
*ki/nduno/s e)sti, mh\ metaba/lwntai kai\ ge/nwntai meta\ tw=n polemi/wn. Isoc. xiv. 38.
*)oknw= mh/ moi o( *lusi/as tapeino\s fanh=| PLAT. Phaedr. 257C
*eu)labou= de\ mh\ fanh=|s kako\s gegw/s. SOPH. Tr. 1129.
*ou)de\n deinoi\ e)/sontai mh\ bohqe/wsi tau/th|. HDT. vii. 235.
*(upopteu/omen kai\ u(ma=s mh\ ou) koinoi\ a)pobh=te. THUC. iii. 53.
*ai)sxuno/menos mh\ fortikw=s skopw=men. PLAT. Theaet. 183E.
*oi( mu=qoi stre/fousin au(tou= th\n yuxh\n, mh\ a)lhqei=s w)=si, torment his soul with fear lest they may prove true (92). Id. Rep. 330 D.

*dei/sas mh/ pw/s oi( e)rusai/ato nekro
 *)axaioi/. Il. v. 298. *(/azeto ga mh\ *nukti\ qoh=| a)poqu/mia e)/rdoi. Il. xiv. 261. *)egw\ ga h(/mhn e)kpeplhgmenh fo/bw|, mh/ moi to\ ka/llos a)/lgos e)ceu/roi pote/. SOPH. Tr. 24. *)/edeisan oi( *(/ellhnes mh\ prosa/goien pro\s to\ ke/ras kai\ au)tou\s katako/yeian. XEN. An. i. 10, 9. *ou)ke/ti e)peti/qento, dedoiko/tes mh\ a)potmhqei/hsan. Ib. iii. 4, Ib. 29. *)/edeisan mh\ lu/tta tis w(/sper kusi
 h(mi=n e)mpeptw/koi. Ib. v. 7, Ib. 26. *(upopteu/sas mh\ th
 qugate/ra le/goi, h)/reto, having suspected that he might mention his daughter. Id. Cyr. v. 2, Id. Cyr. 9. *)hqu/mhsa/n tines, e)nnoou/menoi mh\ ta\ e)pith/deia ou)k e)/xoien o(po/qen lamba/noien. Id. An. iii. 5, Id. An. 3. *ou)dei\s ga ki/ndunos e)do/kei ei)=nai mh/ tis a)/nw poreuome/nwn e)k tou= o)/pisqen e)pi/spoito. Ib. iv. 1, Ib. 6.

*oi( *fwkaie/es ta\s nh/sous ou)k e)bou/lonto pwle/ein, deimai/nontes mh\ e)mpo/rion ge/nwntai. HDT. i. 165. *tw=| ga\r dedie/nai mh\ lo/gois h(/ssous w)=si, tolmhrw=s pro\s ta\ e)/rga e)xw/roun. THUC. iii. 83. *perideh\s geno/menos mh\ e)pipleu/swsin ai( nh=es. Id. iii. 80. *)/edeisa mh\ *troi/an a)qroi/sh| kai\ cunoiki/sh| pa/lin. EUR. Hec. 1138. *oi( qew/menoi e)fobou=nto mh/ ti pa/qh|. Symp. ii. 11. *dh=los h)=n pa=sin (*ku=ros) o(/ti u(perefobei=to mh/ oi( o( pa/ppos a)poqa/nh|. Cyr. i. 4, Cyr. 2.
For the present subjunctive in these sentences denoting what may hereafter prove to be an object of fear, see 92.

The manner in which this complex sentence expressing fear was developed from an independent sentence like mh\ nh=as e(/lwsi, may they not seize the ships, and a preceding verb of fearing like dei/dw, the two gradually becoming one sentence, has already been explained (307). As the fear and the desire to avert the cause of fear are both implied in mh/ with the subjunctive, it is not strange that this expression can follow verbs like o(rw= and oi)=da which do not imply fear in themselves; as e)celqw/n tis i)/doi, mh\ dh\ sxedo\n w)=si kio/ntes, let some one go out and see that they do not approach near (cf. videat ne accedant); originally, let some one go out and look to it: may they not approach, Od. xxiv. 491. So ou)de/ ti i)/dmen, mh/ pws kai\ dia\ nu/kta menoinh/swsi ma/xesqai, nor do we know any way to prevent their being impelled to fight even during the night; originally, nor have we any knowledge: may they not be impelled to fight, Il. x. 100.See also PLAT. Phaed. 91 D, to/de a)/dhlon panti\, mh\ polla\ sw/mata katatri/yasa h( yuxh\ to\ teleutai=on au)th\ a)pollu/htai, i. e. no one knows any security against the soul itself finally perishing, etc. The indirect question sometimes used in translating such a clause with mh/, as whether they may not approach or whether they may not be impelled, is merely an attempt to express the hesitation which the apprehension involves, as there can be, of course, no real indirect question. See especially the cases of mh/ with the present indicative (369, 1), which are often called interrogative. See the corresponding construction in 492.
(Future Indicative.) Sometimes, though seldom, mh/ has the future indicative after verbs of fearing. The examples are:—

*frh
 a)mu/ssetai fo/bw|, mh\ po/lis pu/qhtai . . . kai\ to\ *kissi/wn po/lism' a)nti/doupon a)/|setai, bussi/nois d' e)n pe/plois pe/sh| laki/s. AESCH. Pers. 115. *tau=t' ou)=n fobou=mai, mh\ po/sis me
 *(hraklh=s e)mo\s kalei=tai (fut.), th=s newte/ras d' a)nh/r. SOPH. Tr. 550. *de/doika mh\ a)/llou tino\s meqe/cw. XEN. Cyr. ii. 3, 6. *fobou=mai de\ mh/ tinas h(dona\s h(donai=s eu(rh/somen e)nanti/as. Phil. 13 A. *)alla\ (fobero
 kai\ sfalero
) mh\ sfalei\s kei/somai. Rep. 451A. (The last two examples are not given by Weber.)
For three cases of mh/ with the future optative after past tenses of verbs of fearing, representing the future indicative, see 131.

The particles a)/n and ke/ are never used with mh/ and the subjunctive. But a potential optative with a)/n can follow mh/ after a verb expressing fear or anxiety, after both primary and secondary tenses (168). E.g. *de/doika ga mh\ prw\| le/gois a)
 to
 po/qon to
 e)c e)mou=, I fear that you might perhaps tell. SOPH. Tr. 631. *ou)/te prosdoki/a ou)demi/a (h)=n) mh\ a)/n pote oi( pole/mioi e)pipleu/seian. THUC. ii. 93. *)ekei=no e)nnow= mh\ li/an a)
 taxu\ swfronisqei/hn, lest (in that case) I should be very soon brought to my senses. XEN. An. vi. 1, 28.
*dedio/tes mh\ kataluqei/h a)
 o( dh=mos LYS. xiii. 51.

(Present and Past Tenses of Indicative with mh/.) Verbs of fearing may refer to present or past objects. (See 308.) *mh/ can therefore be used with the present and past tenses of the indicative after these verbs.
1. *mh/ with the present indicative expresses a fear that something is now going on. E.g.

*de/doika mh\ plhgw=n de/ei, I am afraid that you need blows. AR. Nub. 493.
*(orw=men mh\ *niki/as oi)/etai/ ti le/gein, let us be cautious lest Nicias is thinking that he says something. PLAT. Lach. 196 C. (Here oi)/htai would have meant lest Nicias may think, in the future.) *(/ora mh\ e)kei=non kwlu/ei. Id. Charm. 163A. *fobei=sqe mh\ duskolw/tero/n ti nu=n dia/keimai h)\ e)n tw=| pro/sqen bi/w|, you are afraid that I am now in a more peevish state of mind than I used to be in (where the subjunctive would have been future, lest I may hereafter be). Plat. Phaed. 84E. *)epi/sxes, w(s a)/n prou)cereunh/sw sti/bon, mh/ tis politw=n e)n tri/bw| fanta/zetai, ka)moi\ me\n e)/lqh| fau=los w(s dou/lw| yo/gos. EUR. Phoen. 92. (Here mh\ fanta/zetai means lest any one is now to be seen; and mh\ e)/lqh|, lest any report may come hereafter.) *)all' ei)so/mesqa mh/ ti kai\ kata/sxeton krufh=| kalu/ptei kardi/a| qumoume/nh, do/mous parastei/xontes. SOPH. Ant. 1253. (The idea is, we shall learn the result of our anxiety lest she is concealing, etc.In this passage and the following, if anywhere, it would seem necessary to admit the interrogative force often ascribed to mh/. But here, as elsewhere, it is plain that the dependent clause with mh/ expresses the object of an apprehension. To establish mh/ as an interrogative, meaning whether, mh/ should not only follow a verb like oi)=da, but also be followed by a clause expressing no object of apprehension, like ei)so/mesqa mh\ oi( fi/loi zw=sin, we shall learn whether our friends are now living; but no such example can be found in classic Greek. The use of ei), whether, after verbs of fearing (376) shows how the Greeks expressed an indirect question in such cases.) *ka)mauth=s pe/ri qe/lw puqe/sqai, mh\ )pi\ toi=s pa/lai kakoi=s proskei/meno/n ti ph=ma sh\n da/knei fre/na, and I wish to inquire about myself, (in fear) lest, etc. EUR. Her. 481. *)/anac, e)moi/ toi, mh/ ti kai\ qeh/laton tou)/rgon to/d), h( cu/nnoia bouleu/ei pa/lai. SOPH. Ant. 278. (The idea is, my mind has long been deliberating in anxiety lest this is the work of the Gods, e)sti/n being understood after mh/.That this is the correct explanation, and that we need not emend the passage so as to read tou)/rgon to/d' h)=|, cu/nnoia bouleu/ei pa/lai, is suggested by the scholion: h( su/nnoia moi bouleu/etai kai\ oi)/etai mh\ kai\ qeh/lato/n e)sti to\ pra=gma. So perhaps we should read fobei=sqai mh/ ti daimo/nion ta\ pra/gmata e)lau/nei (vulg. e)lau/nh|) in DEM. ix. 54 (with Cod. A). But the subjunctive in both passages might be explained on the principle of 92.) *(/ora, fula/ssou, mh/ tis e)n sti/bw| brotw=n (sc. e)stin). I. T. EUR. 67.

2. *mh/ with the perfect indicative expresses a fear that something has already happened. The difference between this and the perfect subjunctive is often very slight, the latter expressing rather a fear that something may hereafter prove to have happened (103). E.g. *nu=n de\ fobou/meqa mh\ a)mfote/rwn a(/ma h(marth/kamen, but now we fear that we have missed both at once. THUC. iii. 53. (The perfect subjunctive here would mean lest it may hereafter prove that we have missed.) *de/doika mh\ lelh/qamen (th\n ei)rh/nhn) e)pi\ pollw=| a)/gontes, I fear that we have been unconsciously enjoying peace borrowed at high interest. DEM. xix. 99. *fobou=mai mh\ lo/gois tisi\ yeude/sin e)ntetuxh/kamen. PLAT. Lys. 218 D

3. *mh/ can be used with the imperfect or the aorist indicative, to express fear that something happened in past time.
*dei/dw mh\ dh\ pa/nta qea\ nhmerte/a ei)=pen, I fear that all that the Goddess said was true. Od. v. 300.
*)all' o(/ra mh\ pai/zwn e)/legen, but be careful lest he was speaking in jest. PLAT. Theaet. 145B.

(*(/opws mh/, for mh/, with Verbs of Fearing.) Verbs denoting fear and caution are sometimes followed by an object clause with o(/pws mh/ and the future indicative, the subjunctive, or the optative, like verbs of striving, etc. (339). It will be noticed that o(/pws mh/ here is exactly equivalent to mh/ in the ordinary construction, so that fobou=mai o(/pws mh\ genh/setai (or ge/nhtai) means I fear that it will happen (not I fear that it will not happen). E.g. *de/doik' o(/pws mh\ )k th=s siwph=s th=sd' a)narrh/cei (Laur. a)narrh/ch) kaka/, I fear that a storm of evil will burst forth from this silence. SOPH. OT 1074 (the earliest example). *tou= dai/monos de/doix' o(/pws mh\ teu/comai kakodai/monos, I fear that the luck that I shall get will be bad luck. AR. Eq. 112. *eu)labou/menoi o(/pws mh\ oi)xh/somai. PLAT. Phaed. 91 C. *de/doika o(/pws mh\ a)na/gkh genh/setai, I fear that there may be a necessity. DEM. ix. 75. *ou) fobei= o(/pws mh\ a)no/sion pra=gma tugxa/nh|s pra/ttwn; PLAT. Euthyph. 4E. *fula/ttou o(/pws mh\ ei)s tou)nanti/on e)/lqh|s. XEN. Mem. iii. 6, 16. *(hde/ws a)\n (qre/yaimi to\n a)/ndra), ei) mh\ foboi/mhn o(/pws mh\ e)p' au)to/n me tra/poito. Ib. ii. 9, 3. *toi=s presbute/rois a)ntiparakeleu/omai mh\ kataisxunqh=nai o(/pws mh\ do/cei malako\s ei)=nai, i.e. not to be shamed into fear lest he may seem to be weak. THUC. vi. 13.
Compare the corresponding use of mh/ for o(/pws mh/ in ordinary object clauses, especially with o(rw= and skopw=, which belong equally to both classes, B and C. (See 354.)

(Indirect Discourse with w(s, or o(/pws.) In curious contrast with the preceding construction with o(/pws mh/ for mh/ (370) is that by which verbs of fearing sometimes take the construction of ordinary indirect discourse. Here w(s and even o(/pws, that, may introduce the object of the fear, thus taking the place of mh/ in the common construction. This apparently occurs only when the leading verb is negatived. E.g. *mh\ dei/sh|s poq' w(s ge/lwti tou)mo
 faidro
 o)/yetai ka/ra, do not fear that she will ever see my face joyful (=mh\ i)/dh|). SOPH. El. 1309: so 1426. *)andro\s mh\ fobou= w(s a)porh/seis a)ci/ou, do not fear that you will be at a loss. XEN. Cyr. v. 2, 12. (Here the direct discourse would be a)porh/sw, I shall be at a loss.) *mh\ dei/shte w(s ou)x h(de/ws kaqeudh/sete, do not fear that you will not sleep sweetly. Id. Cyr. vi. 2, Id. Cyr. 30. (Here mh\ ou)x would be the ordinary expression.) *ou) tou=to de/doika, w(s e)a
 a)kroa=sqe au)tw=n a)poyhfiei=sqe, I have no fear of this, that you will acquit them if you hear them. LYS. xxvii. 9. *mh\ tre/sh|s o(/pws se/ tis a)pospa/sei bi/a|, that any one shall tear you away by force. EUR. Her. 248. *mh\ fobeu= mh/te e)me\, w(/s seo peirw/menos le/gw lo/gon to/nde, mh/te gunai=ka th
 e)mh
, mh/ ti/ toi e)c au)th=s ge/nhtai bla/bos, do not fear either that I am saying this to try you (w(s le/gw), or lest any harm shall come (mh\ ge/nhtai). HDT. i. 9. (Here the two constructions after fobeu= make the principle especially clear.)

In all these cases mh/ or o(/pws mh/ would be regular, and exactly equivalent to w(s and o(/pws here. In the same way, we say in English he fears lest this may happen and he fears that this may happen in the same sense. In Greek we might have mh\ tre/sh|s o(/pws mh/ se/ tis a)pospa/sei (370) in the same sense as mh\ tre/sh|s o(/pws se/ tis a)pospa/sei (above).

(Infinitive.) The future infinitive may stand in indirect discourse after verbs of fearing, to represent a future indicative of the direct course. E.g. *ou) fobou/meqa e)lassw/sesqai, we are not afraid that we shall have the worst of it. THUC. v. 105. (Here mh/ with the subjunctive would be the regular form.)

The present or aorist infinitive (without mh/), not in indirect discourse, may follow verbs of fearing, to denote the direct object of the fear; as in English, I fear to go. This infinitive may have the article. E.g. *fobou=mai ou)=n diele/gxein se, mh\ u(pola/bh|s, k.t.l., I am afraid to refute you, lest you may suspect, etc. PLAT. Gorg. 457E. *fobh/setai a)dikei=n, he will be afraid to do wrong. XEN. Cyr. viii. 7,15. (But fobh/setai mh\ a)dikh=|, he will fear that he may do wrong.) *dedie/nai fasko/ntwn *kerkurai/wn e)/xein au)to/n. THUC. i. 136. *ou) kate/deisan e)selqei=n. Id. iv. 110. *pe/frika *)erinu\n tele/sai ta\s kata/ras, I shudder at the idea of the Fury fulfilling the curses. Sept. 720. (But in vs. 790, tre/w mh\ tele/sh| means I tremble lest she may fulfil them.) See also XEN. An. i. 3, 17. *to\ a)poqnh/|skein ou)dei\s fobei=tai, to\ de\ a)dikei=n fobei=tai. PLAT. Gorg. 522E.

Verbs of caution may be followed by an infinitive (with or without mh/), which sometimes has the article; the infinitive or the infinitive with mh/ having the same meaning as a clause with mh/ and the subjunctive or optative. E.g. *pw=s ou)k a)/cion au)to/n ge fula/casqai toiou=ton gene/sqai; why ought he not to guard against becoming such a man himself? XEN. Mem. i. 5, 3. (Here gene/sqai is equivalent to mh\ ge/nhtai.) *fulatto/menos to\ luph=sai/ tina, taking care to offend no one. DEM. xviii. 258. *fula/ssein mhde/na peraiou=sqai, to guard against any one's crossing over. THUC. vii. 17. *fulatto/menon kai\ proorw/menon mh\ kataisxu=nai tau/thn. DEM. xxv. 11. (For mh/ in this construction see 815, DEM. 1.) In THUC. vii. 77, we find the infinitive with w(/ste after fula/ssw.

*ki/nduno/s e)sti, the principal expression denoting danger, which takes mh/ and a finite verb, is quite as regularly followed by the infinitive. E.g. *ou) smikro\s ki/nduno/s e)stin e)capathqh=nai, there is no little danger of their being deceived. PLAT. Crat. 436B.
*kinduneu/w is regularly followed by the infinitive (747).

(Indirect Questions.) Verbs of fearing may be followed by an indirect question introduced by ei), whether, or by some other interrogative. *(/opws as an interrogative here must not be confounded with o(/pws as a conjunction. E.g. *ou) de/doika ei) *fi/lippos zh=|, a)ll' ei) th=s po/lews te/qnhke to\ tou\s a)dikou=ntas misei=n kai\ timwrei=sqai, I have no fear (on the question) whether Philip is alive; but I have fear (about this), whether our city's habit of hating and punishing evil-doers is dead. DEM. xix. 289. *fo/bos ei)/ moi zw=sin ou(\s e)gw\ qe/lw. EUR. Her. 791. *fe/rousa/ soi ne/ous h(/kw lo/gous, fo/bw| me
 ei)/ tis despotw=n ai)sqh/setai, through fear whether any one will perceive it (where mh\ ai)/sqhtai would have meant lest any one shall perceive it). EUR. Andr. 60.See XEN. Cyr. vi. 1, 17. *fobou=ntai o(/poi pote\ probh/setai h( tou= a)ndro\s du/namis. XEN. Hell. vi. 1, 14. (The direct question would be poi= probh/setai; ) *th
 qeo
 d' o(/pws la/qw de/doika, I am in fear (about the question) how I shall escape the Goddess. I. T. EUR. 995. (The direct question was pw=s la/qw; 287.) So SOPH. Ph. 337. *)aporou=ntes pw=s xrh\ a)peiqei=n, fobou/menoi de\ pw=s xrh\ a)peilou=nti u(pakou=sai. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 19.

(Causal o(/ti.) Verbs of fearing may be followed by o(/ti, because, and an ordinary causal sentence with the indicative (713). E.g. *ou)k a)/cion dia\ tou=to fobei=sqai tou\s polemi/ous, o(/ti polloi\ tugxa/nousin o)/ntes, to fear them, because they happen to be many. ISOC. vi. 60. *foboume/nhs th=s mhtro\s, o(/ti to\ xwri/on e)punqa/neto nosw=des ei)=nai. Id. xix. 22. *(/oti de\ pollw=n a)/rxousi, mh\ fobhqh=te, a)lla\ polu\ ma=llon dia\ tou=to qarrei=te, do not be afraid because they rule many, etc. XEN. Hell. iii. 5, 10. *)efobei=to, o(/ti o)fqh/sesqai e)/melle ta\ basi/leia oi)kodomei=n a)rxo/menos, he was afraid, because he was about to be seen beginning to build the palace. Id. Cyr. iii. 1, Id. Cyr. 1. *fobou/menos to\ ka/esqai kai\ to\ te/mnesqai, o(/ti a)lgeino/n, fearing them because they are painful. PLAT. Gorg. 479A. So THUC. vii. 67.

div2.head: Section VI: Conditional Sentences.
div2.p: A conditional sentence consists of two clauses, a dependent clause containing the condition, which usually precedes and is called the protasis, and the leading clause containing the conclusion, which is called the apodosis. The protasis is regularly introduced by the particle ei), if, negatively ei) mh/.

*ai) is a Doric and Aeolic form for ei), and is sometimes used in epic poetry in the forms ai)/qe and ai)\ ga/r, and less frequently in ai)/ ke.*ai) for ei) is usually left in Homer by editors as the Mss. give it. But Bekker (Homerische Blätter, pp. 61, 62) quotes Heyne with approval, who says that no human being can tell why we have ai) in one place and ei) in another. Bekker cites, to illustrate this, ai)/q' ou(/tws xo/lon tele/sei) *)agame/mnwn, Il. iv. 178, and ei)/q' w(/s toi gou/naq' e(/poito, Il. iv. 313; also ai)/ ke qeo\s i(/khtai, Il. v. 129, followed immediately by a)ta\r ei)/ ke *)afrodi/th e)/lqh|s' e)s po/lemon. Bekker in his last edition of Homer (1858) gives only ei), ei)/qe, and ei) ga/r, without regard to the Mss.; and he is followed by Delbrück.

The name protasis is often restricted to clauses introduced by a particle meaning if. But it applies equally to all conditional relative and temporal clauses (520), and it properly includes all clauses which naturally precede their leading clauses in the order of thought, as e)pei\ h)/|sqeto tou=to, a)ph=lqen, after he perceived this, he departed. Such a clause may still be called a protasis, even when it follows its leading clause, provided the order of thought is not changed.

The adverb a)/n (epic ke/ or ke/n, Doric ka/) is regularly joined with ei) in the protasis when the verb is in the subjunctive, ei) with a)/n (a^) forming the compound e)a/n, h)/n, or a)/n (a_). (See 200.) The simple ei) is used in the protasis with the indicative and the optative.
The same adverb a)/n is regularly used in the apodosis with the optative, and also with the past tenses of the indicative when non-fulfilment of the condition is implied.

The only Ionic contraction of ei) a)/n is h)/n, which is used in Homer and Herodotus. The Attic Greek has e)a/n, h)/n, and a)/n (a_); but a_)/n, if, was probably never used by the tragedians or by Thucydides, although the Mss. have it in a few cases.
The negative particle of the protasis is regularly mh/, that of the apodosis is ou).

When ou) is found in a protasis, it is generally closely connected with a particular word (especially the verb), with which it forms a single negative expression; so that its negative force does not (like that of mh/) affect the protasis as a whole. E.g.

*pa/ntws dh/pou (ou(/tws e)/xei), e)a/n te su\ kai\ *)/anutos ou) fh=te e)a/n te fh=te, if you deny it, as well as if you admit it. PLAT. Apol. 25B.
*ei) tou\s qano/ntas ou)k e)a=|s ( = kwlu/eis) qa/ptein, if you forbid burying the dead. SOPH. Aj. 1131.
*ei) me
 ou) polloi\ (=o)li/goi) h)=san, kaq' e(/kaston a)
 peri\ tou/twn h)kou/ete, if there were only a few, etc. LYS. xiii. 62: cf. 76. *tw=nde me
 ou)de
 i)/son e)sti
, ei)/ge a)f' h(mw=n ge tw=n e)n me/sw| ou)dei\s ou)de/pote a)/rcetai, there is no fairness in this, if (it is the plan, that) no one is ever to begin with us. XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 3.

In all these cases mh/ could be used, even where ou) seems especially proper; as in a)/n t' e)gw\ fw= a)/n te mh\ fw=, whether I admit or deny it, DEM. xxi. 205.See EUR. Hipp. 995, ou)d' h)\n su\ mh\ fh=|s. The use of mh/ or ou) was determined by the feeling of the speaker at the moment as to the scope of his negation. The following example makes the difference between ou) and mh/ particularly clear, ou) affecting merely the verb, and mh/ affecting the whole clause (including the ou)): ei) mh\ *pro/cenon ou)x u(pede/canto, e)sw/qhsan a)/n, if it had not been that they did not receive Proxenus, they would have been saved, DEM. xix. 74.

*ei) ou) with the indicative is sometimes found in Homer where the Attic Greek would have ei) mh/; as in ei) de/ moi ou)k e)pe/ess' e)pipei/setai a)ll' a)logh/sei, Il. xv. 162. See also Il. xx. 129; Od. ii. 274, Od. xii. 382.

After verbs expressing wonder, delight, and similar emotions (494), where a protasis seems to take the place of a causal sentence, ei) ou) can be used, on the principle of 384, though here mh/ is more common. See examples of ei) mh/ under 494; and for ei) ou) see ISOC. i. 44, mh\ qauma/sh|s ei) polla\ tw=n ei)rhme/nwn ou) pre/pei soi. See also 387.

When two clauses introduced by me/n and de/ depend upon a single ei) which precedes them both, ou) is used even more frequently than mh/; as such clauses have their own construction independently of the ei), which merely introduces each of them as a whole, not affecting the construction of particular words. E.g. *deino
 a)
 ei)/h, ei) oi( me
 e)kei/nwn cu/mmaxoi e)pi\ doulei/a| th=| au(tw=n fe/rontes ou)k a)perou=sin, h(mei=s d' e)pi\ tw=| au)toi\ sw/|zesqai ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen, it would be a hard thing, if (it is a fact that) their allies will not refuse, etc. while we will not contribute. THUC. i. 121. *ei)=t' ou)k ai)sxro
, ei) to\ me
 *)argei/wn plh=qos ou)k e)fobh/qh th
 *lakedaimoni/wn a)rxh
 u(mei=s de\ ba/rbaron fobh/sesqe; is it not then disgraceful, if (it is true that), while the Argive people did not fear, you are going to be afraid, etc. DEM. xv. 23.See also PLAT. Phaed. 97 A; LYS. xxx. 32; ISAE. vi. 2; DEM. xxxviii. 18; AESCHIN. iii. 242.

div2.head: Classification of Conditional Sentences.
div2.p: The most obvious natural distinction is that of (a) present and past conditions and (b) future conditions. Present and past conditions (a) are divided into two classes by distinguishing (1) those which imply nothing as to the fulfilment of the condition from (2) those which imply that the condition is not or was not fulfilled. Future conditions (b) have two classes (1, 2), distinguished by the manner in which the supposition is stated. Class 1 of present and past conditions is further distinguished on the ground of the particular or general character of the supposition, as explained below in II. (394).
Excluding from the class (a) 1 the present and past general suppositions which have a peculiar construction (395, a and b), we have—

div2.head: I. Four Forms of Ordinary Conditions: (a) Present and Past Conditions.
div2.p: In present or past conditions, the question of fulfilment has already been decided, but we may or may not wish to imply by our form of statement how this has been decided. In Greek (as in English or Latin) we may, therefore, state such a condition in either of two ways:—

1. We may simply state a present or past condition, implying nothing as to its fulfilment; as if he is (now) doing this, ei) tou=to pra/ssei,—if he was doing it, ei) e)/prasse,—if he did it, ei) e)/prace, —if he has (already) done it, ei) pe/praxe,—if he had (already) done it (at some past time), ei) e)pepra/xei. The apodosis here expresses simply what is (was or will be) the result of the fulfilment of the condition. Thus we may say:—

*ei) pra/ssei tou=to, kalw=s e)/xei, if he is doing this, it is well; ei) pra/ssei tou=to, h(ma/rthken, if he is doing this, he has erred; ei) pra/ssei tou=to, kalw=s e(/cei, if he is doing this, it will be well. *ei) e)/prace (or e)/prasse) tou=to, kalw=s e)/xei (ei)=xen, e)/sxen, or e(/cei), if he did this, it is (was or will be) well. *ei) pe/praxe tou=to, kalw=s e(/cei, if he has done this, it will be well. So with the other tenses of the indicative in the apodosis. (See 402.)
So in Latin: Si hoc facit, bene est; Si hoc fecit, bene erit; etc.

2. On the other hand, we may state a present or past condition so as to imply that it is not or was not fulfilled; as if he were (now) doing this, ei) tou=to e)/prasse;—if he had done this, ei) tou=to e)/prace (both implying the opposite). The apodosis here expresses what would be (or would have been) the result if the condition were (or had been) fulfilled. The adverb a)/n in the apodosis distinguishes these forms from otherwise similar forms under (a) 1. Thus we may say:—
*ei) e)/prasse tou=to, kalw=s a)\n ei)=xen, if he were (now) doing this, it would be well; or if he had been doing this, it would have been well.

*ei) e)/prace tou=to, kalw=s a)\n e)/sxen (or a)\n ei)=xen), if he had done this, it would have been well (or it would now be well). On the other hand, ei) e)/prace tou=to, kalw=s e)/sxen (without a)/n) would mean if he did this, it was well. (See 410.)
In Latin: Si hoc faceret, bene esset (present); Si hoc fecisset, bene fuisset (past).
The Greek has no form implying that a condition is or was fulfilled, and it is hardly conceivable that any language should find such a form necessary or useful.

div2.head: (b) Future Conditions.
div2.p: The question as to the fulfilment of a future condition is still undecided. We may state such a condition in Greek (as in English and Latin) in either of two ways:—

1. We may say if he shall do this, e)a\n pra/ssh| (or pra/ch|) tou=to (or, still more vividly, ei) pra/cei tou=to), making a distinct supposition of a future case. The apodosis expresses what will be the result if the condition shall be fulfilled. Thus we may say:—

*)ea\n pra/ssh| (or pra/ch|) tou=to, kalw=s e(/cei, if he shall do this (or if he does this), it will be well (sometimes also ei) pra/cei tou=to). (See 444 and 447.) In Latin: Si hoc faciet (or si hoc fecerit), bene erit.

2. We may also say if he should do this, ei) pra/ssoi (or pra/ceie) tou=to, still supposing a case in the future, but less distinctly and vividly than before. The apodosis corresponds to this in form (with the addition of a)/n), and expresses what would be the result if the condition should be fulfilled. Thus we may say:—
*ei) pra/ssoi (or pra/ceie) tou=to, kalw=s a)\n e)/xoi, if he should do this, it would be well. (See 455.) In Latin: Si hoc faciat, bene sit.

The Latin commonly employs the future indicative, si hoc faciet (corresponding strictly to ei) tou=to pra/cei, if he shall do this), or the future perfect, si hoc fecerit, to express the form of protasis which the Greek expresses by e)a/n and the subjunctive (e)a\n tou=to pra/ssh| or pra/ch|); and it uses the form si hoc faciat to represent the Greek ei) tou=to pra/ssoi, if he should do this.

div2.head: II. Present and Past General Suppositions.
div2.p: The supposition contained in a protasis may be either particular or general.

A particular supposition refers to a definite act or to several definite acts, supposed to occur at some definite time (or times); as if he (now) has this, he will give it; if he had it, he gave it; if he had had the power, he would have helped me; if he shall receive it (or if he receives it), he will give it; if he should receive it, he would give it. So if he always acts justly (or if he never commits injustice), I honour him; if he acted justly on all these occasions, he will be rewarded.

A general supposition refers indefinitely to any act or acts of a given class which may be supposed to occur or to have occurred at any time; as if ever he receives anything, he (always) gives it; if ever he received anything, he (always) gave it; if he had (on any occasion) had the power, he would (always) have helped me; if ever any one shall (or should) wish to go, he will (or would) always be permitted. So if he ever acts justly, I (always) honour him; if he ever acted justly, he was (always) rewarded.

Although this distinction is seen in all classes of conditions, present, past, and future (as the examples show), it is only in present and past conditions which do not imply nonfulfilment (i.e. in those of 390, 1) that the Greek distinguishes general from particular suppositions in construction. Here, however, we have two classes of conditions which contain only general suppositions.

(a) When the apodosis has a verb of present time expressing a customary or repeated action, the protasis may refer (in a general way) to any act or acts of a given class which may be supposed to occur at any time within the period represented in English as present. Thus we may say:—

*)ea/n tis kle/pth|, kola/zetai, if (ever) any one steals, he is (in all such cases) punished; e)a/n tis pra/ssh| (or pra/ch|) toiou=to/n ti, xalepai/nomen au)tw=|, if (ever) any one does such a thing, we are (always) angry with him; e)a/n tis tou/tou pi/h|, a)poqnh/|skei, if any one (ever) drinks of this, he dies. (See 462.)

(b) When the apodosis has a verb of past time expressing a customary or repeated action, the protasis may refer (in a general way) to any act or acts of a given class which may be supposed to have occurred at any time in the past. Thus we may say:—

Although the Latin sometimes agrees with the Greek in distinguishing general conditions from ordinary present and past conditions, using si faciat and si faceret in a general sense, like e)a\n pra/ssh| and ei) pra/ssoi above, it yet commonly agrees with the English in not recognising the distinction, and uses the indicative alike in both classes. Even the Greek sometimes (especially in poetry) neglects the distinction, and uses the indicative in these general conditions (467).

In external form the general present condition coincides with the more vivid future condition, 392, 1, as both are expressed by e)a/n and the subjunctive, the form of the apodosis alone distinguishing them. But in sense there is a much closer connexion between the general present condition and the ordinary present condition expressed by ei) and the present indicative, 390, 1, with which in most languages (and sometimes even in Greek) it coincides also in form (see 396). On the other hand, e)a/n with the subjunctive in a future condition agrees substantially in sense with ei) and the future indicative (447), and is never interchangeable with ei) and the present indicative.

div2.head: Origin of the Greek Conditional Sentence.—Early Combinations of ei) with ke/ or a)/n.
div2.p: It is impossible to discuss intelligently the origin of the conditional sentence until the etymology and original meaning of the particles ei), ai), a)/n, and ke/ are determined. On these questions we have as yet little or no real knowledge. The theory of ei) or ai) which identifies it with the pronominal stem sva (sve), Oscan svai, and Latin si, is perhaps the most common. By this the original meaning of ei), or rather of one of its remote ancestors in some primitive language, would be at a certain time (or place), in a certain way.See Delbrück, Conj. und Opt., pp. 70, 71, who terms this a wahrscheinliche positive Vermuthung. But, even on this theory, we can hardly imagine any form of ei) as existing in the Greek language until the word had passed at least into the relative stage, with the force of at which time (or place), in which way, under which circumstances. It cannot be denied that the strong analogy between conditional and relative sentences and the identity of most of their forms give great support to any theory by which the conditional sentence is explained as an outgrowth of the relative, so that the conditional relative sentence is made the original conditional construction. Thus ei) h)=lqen might at some time have meant in the case in which he went, and ei) e)/lqh|, in the case in which he shall go (or in case he shall go), etc. But here we are on purely theoretical ground; and we must content ourselves practically with the fact, that in the earliest Greek known to us ei) was fully established in its conditional sense, like our if and Latin si.

The regular types of the conditional sentence, which are given above (390-395) as they appear in Attic prose, have been mainly sifted from a rich variety of forms which are found in earlier Greek. In Homer we have all tenses of the indicative used as in Attic Greek, except that the imperfect has not yet come to express an unreal present condition, but is still confined to the past. The future indicative sometimes has ke/ in protasis, and the future with ke/ or a)/n can stand in apodosis. The subjunctive in protasis can have ei)/ ke (even ei) a)/n), h)/n, or ei) alone; and it can stand in a future apodosis either alone or with a)/n or ke/ (like the optative). The optative sometimes has ei)/ ke in protasis, and occasionally stands in apodosis without a)/n or ke/. Once we find ei)/ ke with the aorist indicative ( Il. xxiii. 526).

Thus, while we have in Attic prose two stereotyped forms of future conditional sentences, e)a
 (h)
, a_)
) dw=|, e(lou=mai and ei) doi/h, e(loi/mhn a)/n, we have in Homer h)
 dw=|, ei)/ ke dw=|, ei) dw=|, and ei) doi/h, ei)/ ke doi/h, in protasis; and e(lou=mai, e(lou=mai/ ke, e(/lwmai, e(/lwmai/ ke, and e(loi/mhn ke (or a)/n), rarely e(loi/mhn alone, in apodosis; with every variety of combination of these. (For the details and examples, see 450-454 and 460.)

There is a tendency in Homer to restrict the subjunctive with simple ei) (without ke/ or a)/n) to general conditions (468), and a similar but less decided tendency to restrict the subjunctive with conditional relatives without ke/ or a)/n to the generic relative construction (538). But the general condition with ei) appears in Homer in a primitive stage, compared with the corresponding relative construction, which is fully developed. Both subjunctive and optative are freely used in general relative conditions in Homer, as in Attic Greek; while in general conditions with ei) the subjunctive occurs only nineteen times and the optative only once (468). On the supposition that the clause with ei) is derived from the relative clause, this would appear as the ordinary process of development.

It is perhaps the most natural view of the various conditional expressions, ei), ei)/ ke, ei) a)/n, etc. to suppose that at some early stage the Greek had two perfectly analogous forms in future conditions, one with two subjunctives, and one with two optatives, e.g. ei) dw=| tou=to, e(/lwmai and ei) doi/h tou=to, e(loi/mhn. The particle ke/ would then begin to be allowed in both of these conditions and conclusions, giving to each more distinctly its force as a protasis or an apodosis.As I do not profess to have any distinct theory of the origin or the original meaning of either ke/ or a)/n, I have not attempted to define their force, except so far as they emphasise what we see by usage may be implied by the sentence without their aid. It would thus be allowed to say ei)/ ke dw=| tou=to, e(/lwmai/ ke and ei)/ ke doi/h tou=to, e(loi/mhn ke, both of which forms actually occur in Homer. Gradually the tendencies of the language restricted the use of ke/ more and more to the subjunctive in protasis and the optative in apodosis, although for a time the usage was not strict. This state of transition appears in Homer, who preserves even a case of an otherwise extinct use of ei)/ ke with the aorist indicative. Shortly before this stage, however, a new tendency was making itself felt, to distinguish the present general condition from the particular in form, the way being already marked out by the conditional relative sentence. As this new expression was to be distinguished from both the really present condition ei) bou/letai and the future ei)/ ke bou/lhtai, the half-way form ei) bou/lhtai (which had nearly given place to ei)/ ke bou/lhtai in future conditions) came into use in the sense if he ever wishes.Monro ( Gr. Hom. p. 263) thinks the primary use of a)/n or ke/n is to show that the speaker is thinking of particular instances or occasions. If this is so, we should expect these particles to be first used in future conditions, while the later general conditions would first take the simple ei), as is here supposed. This would soon develop a corresponding form for use after past tenses, ei) bou/loito, if he ever wished, of which we see only the first step in Homer, Hom. Il. xxiv. 768. (See 468.) It would hardly be possible to keep the two uses of ei) with the subjunctive distinct in form, and in time the form with ke/ (or a)/n) was established in both (381). But we see this process too in transition in Homer, where ei)/ ke or some form of ei) a)/n is used in all future conditions except nine, and has intruded itself into five of the nineteen general conditions. We must suppose a corresponding process in regard to ke/ or a)/n in conditional relative clauses to have gone on before the Homeric period, with more complete results.See Jour. Phil. iii. pp. 441, 442, where Gildersleeve refers to the use of ei), o(/te, etc. with the optative in oratio obliqua, representing e)a/n, o(/tan, etc. with the subjunctive in the direct form, as evidence of an old use of ei), o(/te, etc. with the subjunctive. In Attic Greek, except in a few poetic passages, the usage is firmly established by which the subjunctive in protasis requires a)/n in both particular and general conditions.

div2.head: I. Four Forms of Ordinary Conditional Sentences: (a) Present and Past Conditions.
1. Simple Suppositions (chiefly Particular).
div2.p:
When the protasis simply states a present or past particular supposition, implying nothing as to the fulfilment of the condition, it takes a present or past tense of the indicative with ei). Any form of the verb may stand in the apodosis to express the result if the condition is or was fulfilled. E.g. *ei) e)bro/nthse, kai\ h)/strayen, if it thundered, it also lightened. This form of condition may be used even when the supposition is notoriously contrary to fact, if the speaker does not wish to imply this by the construction; as in DEM. xviii. 12, tw=n me/ntoi kathgoriw=n, . . . ei)/per h)=san a)lhqei=s, ou)k e)/ni th=| po/lei di/khn a)ci/an labei=n, but if the charges were true (=erant, not essent), the state cannot obtain adequate satisfaction. So in English, we can say if three times six are twenty as well as if three times six were twenty, or if all men are liars as well as if all men were liars,—from different points of view.

A present or past general supposition is sometimes expressed by the indicative: see examples in 467. Here the Greek neglects the distinction which it regularly makes between general and particular suppositions of this class.

Pindar uses these simple conditions with ei) and the indicative more than all other forms.See Jour. Phil. iii. p. 438. But among his forty-eight cases are many general conditions (467), which most writers would have expressed by the subjunctive.

(Future Indicative in Present Suppositions.) Even the future indicative with ei) may be used in a present condition, if it expresses merely a present intention or necessity that something shall be done hereafter; as when ei) tou=to poih/sei means if he is (now) about to do this, and not (as it does in an ordinary future condition) if he shall do this (hereafter). E.g. *ai)=re plh=ktron, ei) maxei=, raise your spur, if you are going to fight. AR. Av. 759. (*ei) maxei= in protasis commonly means if you shall fight, like e)a
 ma/xh|.) *)=h nu=n e)gw\ me

Ant. 484. *ti/ diafe/rousi tw=n e)c a)na/gkhs kakopaqou/ntwn, ei)/ ge peinh/sousi kai\ diyh/sousi kai\ r(igw/sousi kai\ a)grupnh/sousi kai\ ta)/lla pa/nta moxqh/sousin e(ko/ntes; how do they differ, etc., if they are to suffer hunger, thirst, etc.? XEN. Mem. ii. 1, 17. So ei) po/lemo/s te dama=| kai\ loimo\s *)axaiou/s, if both war and pestilence are to lay the Achaeans low, Il. i. 61; and ei) diablhqh/somai, if I am to be slandered, EUR. Hec. 863.In Il. v. 715, h)= r() a(/lion to

It is important to notice that a future indicative of this kind could not be changed to a subjunctive with e)a/n without an entire change of sense and time. It must therefore be distinguished from the future in future conditions, where it is generally interchangeable with the subjunctive (447). Here it is nearly equivalent to the periphrastic future expressed by me/llw and the infinitive (73), in which the tense of me/llw (as in ei) me/llousi tou=to poiei=n = ei) tou=to poih/sousin) shows that the condition is really present and not future. So with the Latin periphrastic future, si hoc facturus est.

A present condition may be expressed by a potential optative in the protasis, and a present or past condition by a potential indicative; as ei)/per a)/llw| tw| a)nqrw/pwn peiqoi/mhn a)
, kai\ soi\ pei/qomai, if (it is true that) I would trust any one of mankind, I trust you, PLAT. Prot. 329 B; ei) tou=to i)sxuro

div2.head: 2. With Supposition contrary to Fact.
div2.p: When the protasis states a present or past supposition, implying that the condition is not or was not fulfilled, and the apodosis expresses what would be (or would have been) the result if that condition were (or had been) fulfilled, the past tenses of the indicative are used in both protasis and apodosis, and the apodosis contains the adverb a)/n.

The imperfect here, in either protasis or apodosis, refers to present time or to an act as going on or repeated in past time, the aorist to a simple occurrence in past time, and the (rare) pluperfect to an act completed in past or present time. E.g. *ei) tou=to e)/prasse, kalw=s a)
 ei)=xen, if he were (now) doing this, it would be well (implying that he is not doing it). This may also mean if he had been doing this, it would have been well (implying that he was not doing it). The context must decide, in each case, to which time the imperfect refers. *ei) tou=to e)/prace, kalw=s a)
 e)/sxen, if he had done this, it would have been well (implying that he did not do it). *ei) tou=to e)pepra/xei, kalw=s a)
 ei)=xen, if he had finished doing this (now or at any past time), it would be well (implying either he has not or he had not finished it).
