These examples show the fully developed construction, as it appears in the Attic writers and in Herodotus. For the more primitive Homeric usage, see 435 and 438.

This construction is equivalent to that of the Latin imperfect and pluperfect subjunctive in protasis and apodosis. With regard to the tenses, the Latin imperfect subjunctive represents the Greek imperfect indicative referring to present time, and rarely that referring to past time; while the Latin pluperfect subjunctive represents the Greek aorist and pluperfect indicative, and also most cases of the Greek imperfect referring to past time.

1. It will be seen that, when this construction is used, it is usually implied not merely that the condition of the protasis is not (or was not) fulfilled but also that the action of the apodosis does not (or did not) take place; thus ei) tou=to ei)=pon, e)pei/sqh a)/n, if I had said this, he would have been persuaded, generally implies not merely that I did not say this but also that he was not persuaded. But this denial of the apodosis is not an essential character of the construction, as we can see if we change the apodosis to ou)k a)\n e)pei/sqh, he would not have been persuaded, when it is not implied that he really was persuaded. We have seen that there is nothing in the nature of the potential indicative which makes a denial of its action necessary (244); and when this form is made the apodosis of an unreal condition, it simply states that something would happen (or would have happened) in a case which did not arise. Denial of the apodosis can follow as a logical inference from denial of the protasis only in the rare cases in which the unreal condition is the only one under which the action of the apodosis could have taken place, as when we say if the moon had entered the earth's shadow, she would have been eclipsed, where the denial of either clause carries with it by necessity the denial of the other. But if we say if it had rained, the ground would be wet, the denial of the protasis cuts off only one of many conditions under which the ground might be wet. Such sentences as this are, however, very common, though they are not used to prove the opposite of the apodosis (that the ground is not wet); but they are arguments in which the apodosis is assumed to be false (on the ground of observation or experience), and from this it is argued that the assumption of the protasis is false; that is, since the ground is not wet (as we can see), it cannot have rained, which is a good argument. This is the case in THUC. i. 9, and PLAT. Gorg. 516 E (quoted in 410, above); where it is argued that Agamemnon had a navy because this was a necessary condition of his ruling islands, and that certain persons were not good men because they suffered what they did, the facts of ruling islands and of suffering being assumed in the argument as established on independent evidence. In other cases, where it is stated that the apodosis would follow as a consequence from the fulfilment of the condition, as in SOPH. Aj. 45, ka)\n e)cepra/cat' ei) kathme/lhs' e)gw/ , he would even have accomplished it, if I had been careless, whatever negation of the apodosis is implied (here ou)k e)cepra/cato) comes from a feeling that when the only condition under which it is stated that an action would have taken place fails, there is no reason for believing it to have taken place at all. We may doubt whether any negation of the apodosis is implied in the form of expression in such cases. Certainly, in many cases in which the apodosis states a consequence which would follow from the action of an unreal protasis, this negation is assumed as already known apart from the construction; thus in SOPH. El. 556 (quoted in 410) the apodosis means you would not then be offensive to listen to, and the only ground on which we mentally add as you now are is our knowledge of Clytaemnestra's feeling towards Electra. If the sentence were if all men began their speeches politely, they would not be offensive, we should not think of supplying as they now are without some knowledge of the facts.

2. When the sentence merely affirms or denies that one act, if it had occurred, would be accompanied by another act, and there is no necessary relation between the two acts as cause and effect, and there is no argument drawn from the admitted unreality of the conclusion to prove the opposite of the condition, no denial of the apodosis is implied in the expression, although we may know from the context or in some other way that the action of the apodosis does not (or did not) occur. Thus in PLAT. Ap. 17 D, ei) tw=| o)/nti ce/nos e)tu/gxanon w)
, cunegignw/skete dh/pou a)/n moi ei) e)n e)kei/nh| th=| fwnh=| e)/legon, etc., if I were really a foreigner, you would surely pardon me if I spoke in my own dialect, etc., it is not implied that now you do not pardon me. We should rather say that nothing at all is implied beyond the statement you would pardon me in that case. If the apodosis were you would not be angry with me, the impossibility of understanding but now you are angry would make this plainer. Again, in XEN. An. vi. 1, 32 , ou)d' a)
 e)/gwge e)stasi/azon ei) a)/llon ei(/lesqe, neither should I (any more than Xenophon) be quarrelsome if you had chosen another man, nothing like stasia/zw is implied; on the other hand, any such implication as ou) stasia/zw must come from the circumstances of the case, not from the form of expression. In SOPH. OT 220 , ou) ga a)
 makra
 i)/xneuon au)to/s, if the protasis is ei) i)/xneuon au)to/s, if I were undertaking the search by myself (alone), the apodosis I should not be very far on the track does not imply makra
 i)xneu/w, or anything more than the sentence states. (See 511.) Again, in SOPH. Tr. 896, ei) parou=sa plhsi/a e)/leusses oi(=) e)/drase, ka/rt' a)
 w)/|ktisas, the statement does not imply ou)k w)/|ktisas, although this may be true.

3. Further, in concessive sentences introduced by kai\ ei) or ei), even if or although, or ou)d' ei), not even if, where it is stated that something would be true even in a supposed case (which does not arise), we have what amounts to a statement that the thing in question would be true in any case. Here, therefore, the action of the apodosis is distinctly affirmed; as in ISOC. xxi. 11, *niki/as me
, ei) kai\ to
 a)/llon xro/non ei)/qisto sukofantei=n, to/t' a)
 e)pau/sato: *eu)qu/nous de\, kai\ ei) mhde\ pw/pote dienoh/qh a)dikei=n, to/t' a)
 e)ph/rqh, i.e. N. would then have stopped, while E. would have been urged on, in any case. So DEM. xxx. 14, and xl. 23. See PLAT. Rep. 620 D, ta\ au)ta\ a)
 e)/prace kai\ prw/th laxou=sa (=kai\ ei) prw/th e)/laxen), it would have done the same even if it had drawn the first choice.

In the unreal conditional sentence, therefore, the unreality of the supposition is always implied, and that of the apodosis is generally either assumed or implied. The implied opposite of an imperfect is always a present or imperfect, that of an aorist is an aorist, and that of a pluperfect is usually a perfect or pluperfect. Thus ei) e)/prasse, when it means if he were doing, implies a)ll' ou) pra/ssei, but really he is not doing; when it means if he had been doing, it implies a)ll' ou)k e)/prasse, but really he was not doing: ei) mh\ e)/pracen, if he had not done, implies a)ll' e)/pracen, but really he did do: ei) e)pepoih/kei tou=to, if he had already done this, implies either a)ll' ou) pepoi/hken, but really he has not done it, or a)ll' ou)k e)pepoih/kei, but really he had not done it, according to the context. The aorist, however, is very often used here, as elsewhere, where the pluperfect would express the time intended more exactly; as in the sentence quoted in 410 from DEM. iv. 5, ou)de\n a)\n w(=n nuni\ pepoi/hken e)/pracen, where the perfect pepoi/hken shows that the pluperfect might have been used for e)/pracen (see 58).

Sometimes an aorist not referring to past time is found in the apodosis, after a protasis in the imperfect referring to the present. This occurs chiefly in Plato, and generally with ei)=pon a)/n, a)pekrina/mhn a)/n, or a similar verb, meaning I should at once reply. The aorist excludes the idea of duration which the imperfect would express, and for the same reason it cannot be strictly present; in effect it does not differ much from an aorist optative with a)/n, the apodosis really being the result (in the case supposed) would be (h)=n a)/n) that I should reply (ei)/poimi a)/n), etc. E.g. *ei) me
 ou)=n su/ me h)rw/tas ti tw=n nu=n dh\, ei)=pon a)
, k.t.l., if then you were asking me any one of the questions before us, I should (at once) say, etc. PLAT. Euthyph. 12D *(/wsper a)
 ei) e)tu/gxanen w)
 u(podhma/twn dhmiourgo\s, a)pekri/nato a)
 dh/ pou/ soi o(/ti skutoto/mos, as, if he chanced to be a maker of shoes, he would answer that he was a cobbler. Gorg. 447D. See also Symp. 199D, Men. 72B, Theag. 123B; ANT. Tetr. A. b. 13. In PLAT. Prot. 311 B, C, we have ei)/ ti/s se h)/reto, ti/ a)
 a)pekri/nw; with the answer ei)=pon a)
 w(s, k.t.l., twice, referring to present time; but in D, ei) ou)=n tis h(ma=s e)/roito (future), followed by ti/ a)
 au)tw=| a)pokrinai/meqa;

An example of this is found in SOPH. Ant. 755: ei) mh\ path\r h)=sq), ei)=pon a)/n s' ou)k eu)= fronei=n, if you were not my father, I should say you were not right in mind. See EUR. Alc. 125, h)=lqen a)/n, i.e. (the result would be that) she would return. So Alc. 360.

div2.head: Apodosis without a)/n.—*)/edei, xrh=n, etc. with the Infinitive.
div2.p: A peculiar form of potential indicative without a)/n consists of an infinitive depending on the imperfect of a verb of obligation, propriety, or possibility, like e)/dei, xrh=n or e)xrh=n, ei)ko\s h)=n, or prosh=ken. This expression refers to past or present time, and generally implies a denial of the action of the infinitive. Thus e)/dei tou=ton a)poqanei=n in this idiomatic use means he ought to have perished (but did not); e)/dei h(ma=s tou=to poiei=n means we ought to be doing this (but we are not) or we ought to have done this (but we did not do it). This combination contains in other words what might have been expressed substantially by a past indicative with a)/n of the verb of the infinitive, qualified by an adverb or other expression denoting obligation, propriety, or possibility: thus e)/dei tou=ton a)poqanei=n is (as a construction) equivalent to ou(=tos dikai/ws (or a)ci/ws) a)\n a)pe/qanen, he would justly have perished, and ei)ko\s h)=n se tou=to paqei=n is equivalent to tou=to ei)ko/tws a)\n e)/paqes, you would properly have suffered this (implying ou)k e)/paqes). Strictly, the expression involves also an unreal protasis, as (in the last case) ei) to\ ei)ko\s e)/paqes, which with the apodosis tou=to e)/paqes a)/n appears substantially in ei)ko\s h)=n se tou=to paqei=n. (See 511.)
When the present infinitive is used, the expression is present or past; with the aorist infinitive it is always past.

The following imperfects may take the infinitive in this sense: e)/dei, xrh=n or e)xrh=n, ei)ko\s h)=n, prosh=ken, e)nh=n, e)ch=n, h)=n (or u(ph=rxenSee ISOC. v. 34.), it was possible, one might, the impersonal h)=n with adjectives or nouns expressing obligation, propriety, possibility, and similar ideas, as di/kaion h)=n, a)/cion h)=n, kalo\n (ka/llion, ISAE. ii. 15; ARISTOT. Eth. x. 9, Eth. 18 (p. 1181 a, Eth. 4). krei=tton, DEM. xx. 23.
kra/tiston ISOC. xx. 14. ) h)=n, ai)sxro\n h)=n, prosh=kon h)=n, ou) qaumasto\n h)=n, DEM. xviii. 248.
a)sfale/steron h)=n, LYS. vii. 24.
i)/son h)=n, ANT. v. 13.
eu)/logon h)=n,ARISTOT. Eth. x. 9, Eth. 19 (p. 1181 a, Eth. 6). suggnwsto\n h)=n, oi(=o/s t' h)=n, e)/rgon h)=n, h)=n with the verbal in -te/os,—also e)/prepen, sune/feren, LYS. xiii. 28.
e)lusite/lei, DEM. lix. 112. The imperfects not included in these references will be found among the examples in 419-422. The above list could doubtless be greatly extended. with other verbs of the same nature. To these must be added the expressions specially mentioned below in 424-431.

These are all originally expressions of past necessity, obligation, etc., involving no reference to any condition (unfulfilled or otherwise); and in this sense they may always be used, as in DEM. xix. 124, e)/dei me/nein, he was obliged to stay (and did stay), and HDT. i. 8, xrh=n ga\r *kandau/lh| gene/sqai kakw=s, for C. was doomed to fall into trouble. It is only by idiomatic usage that the denial of the action of the infinitive comes to be implied in them, and that a past tense comes to express present time, both of which characteristics are found in Greek, Latin, and English; as e)/dei se au)to\n filei=n, debebas eum colere, you ought to love him (but you do not), ought being the past of owe. The infinitive is felt to be negatived, even when the negative belongs to the leading verb.

Like the potential indicative, this form of expression can either (1) be used alone, with no external protasis expressed or distinctly implied, as in xrh=n se e)lqei=n, you ought to have gone; or (2) stand as apodosis to an unreal protasis, as in ei) e)ke/leuse, xrh=n se e)lqei=n, if he had commanded it, you ought to have gone.

I. When these expressions are used alone, the denial of the action of the infinitive is always implied. E.g. *tou/sde ga\r mh\ zh=n e)/dei, for these ought not to be living (as they are). SOPH. Ph. 418. *)/edei me\n tou\s le/gontas a(/pantas mh/te pro\s e)/xqran poiei=sqai lo/gon mhde/na mh/te pro\s xa/rin, i.e. the speakers ought not to say a word out of regard either to enmity or to favour (and yet they do so). DEM. viii. 1. *sigh/sas h(ni/k' e)/dei le/gein, keeping silence when he ought to speak. Id. xviii. 189: cf. xviii. 191.

*xrh=n ga/r se mh/t' au)to/n pot' ei)s *troi/an molei=n, h(ma=s t' a)pei/rgein, for you ought yourself never to have gone to Troy, and you ought (now) to keep me away from it. SOPH. Ph. 1363.See AESCH. Ag. 879, AESCH. Cho. 930; SOPH. El. 1505. *qanei=n, qanei=n se, pre/sbu, xrh=n pa/ros te/knwn. And. 1208. *ti/ e)xrh=n me poiei=n; mh\ prosa/gein gra/yai (tou\s pre/sbeis); what ought I to have done (which I did not do)? Ought I not to have proposed (as I did) to invite the ambassadors? DEM. xviii. 28. *)exrh=n me\n ou)=n kai\ di/kaion h)=n tou\s to\n ste/fanon oi)ome/nous dei=n labei=n au(tou\s a)ci/ous e)pideiknu/nai tou/tou, mh\ e)me\ kakw=s le/gein: e)peidh\ de\ tou=to pare/ntes e)kei=no poiou=sin, k.t.l., i.e. those who think they ought to receive the crown ought to show that they deserve it themselves, and not be abusing me; but since now they have neglected the former and do the latter, etc. lId. i. 3.

*sfw=|n d', w)= te/kn', ou(\s me
 ei)ko\s h)=n ponei=n ta/de, those of you who ought to be bearing these labours. SOPH. O.C. 342.
*pro\s tou/tous to
 a)gw=na katasth=nai, ou(\s ei)ko\s h)=n tw=| me
 teqnew=ti timwrou\s gene/sqai tw=| d' e)pecio/nti bohqou/s, who properly should have come forward to avenge the dead and to help the prosecutor. ANT. i. 2. *ei) u(po\ tw=n polemi/wn me
 e)sw/qhmen, ou(\s ei)ko\s h)=n diakwlu/ein mh\ sw/|zesqai, i.e. who would naturally have tried to prevent us from being saved. LYS. xx. 36. See DEM. xl. 30. *kai\ ma/lista ei)ko\s h)=n u(ma=s proora=sqai au)ta\ kai\ mh\ malakw=s, w(/sper nu=n, cummaxei=n. THUC. vi. 78. (The orator adds, a)ll ou)/q' u(mei=s nu=n ge/ pw ou)/q' oi( a)/lloi e)pi\ tau=ta w(/rmhsqe.) *me/nein ga e)ch=n tw=| kathgorou=nti tw=n a)/llwn, he might have stood his ground (but really he ran away). DEM. iii. 17: cf. xviii. 14, DEM. xxvii. 58; LYS. xii. 31.

*th
 diaqh/khn h)fa/nikate, e)c h(=s h)=n ei)=de/nai peri\ pa/ntwn th
 a)lh/qeian, you have concealed the will, from which we (now) might know the truth about the whole matter. DEM. xxviii. 10. *th=s h(mete/ras e)/xqras h(ma=s e)f' h(mw=n au)tw=n di/kaion h)=n to
 e)cetasmo
 poiei=sqai, i.e. we should justly settle up our quarrel by ourselves. Id. xviii. 16: cf. 13, where di/kaion h)=n is understood with xrh=sqai, he would justly have used them. *pra/ttwn polu\ be/ltion h)\ se\ prosh=kon h)=n (sc. pra/ttein), being much better off than you deserve to be. xlId. v. 69. *kai\ mh
 a)/cio/n g' h)=n a)kou=sai, indeed, it was worth your while to hear them (a)ci/ws a)
 h)kou/sate). PLAT. Euthyd. 304D. The person addressed had just said ou)k oi(=o/s t' h)= katakou/ein.

*)/allw| e)/prepen le/gein a(\ le/geis, another would have becomingly said what you say (a)/llos a)\n e)/lege prepo/ntws). PLAT. Rep. 474D. *to\ dusxere/staton tw=n o)noma/twn, o(\ tw=n fqonou/ntwn e)/rgon h)=n le/gein, a)ll' ou) tw=n proestw/twn th=s toiau/ths paideu/sews, the most disagreeable of names (Sophist), which the envious ought to use rather than those who stand at the head of the business in question. ISOC. xiii. 19.

II. When this form is made the apodosis of an unreal condition (expressed or distinctly implied), it states that what the infinitive denotes would necessarily, properly, or possibly be done (or have been done) if the case supposed were a real one. The chief force of the apodosis here always lies in the infinitive, while the leading verb acts as an auxiliary (which we can generally express by ought, might, or could, or by an adverb), modifying the idea of the infinitive more or less in different cases. But when the chief stress is laid on the necessity, propriety, or possibility of the act, and not on the act itself, so that the real apodosis is in the leading verb, this takes a)/n, like any other imperfect in such an apodosis (423). In some cases, however, even when no a)/n is added, the force of the infinitive is so modified by the idea of the leading verb that the opposite of the apodosis (which is generally inferred) cannot be expressed without including both ideas (see examples in 422, 1).
In the following examples the infinitive represents the real apodosis, and its action is denied as when no protasis is added (419):—

*ei) e)p' h(me/as mou/nous e)strathla/tee o( *pe/rshs, xrh=n au)to
 pa/ntwn tw=n a)/llwn a)pexo/menon i)e/nai ou(/tw e)pi\ th
 h(mete/rhn: kai\ a)
 e)dh/lou pa=si w(s e)pi\ *sku/qas e)lau/nei, if the Persian were making his expedition against us alone, he should leave all others and be marching directly into our country; then he would show everybody that he was marching against Scythians. HDT. iv. 118. *dei=n (=e)/dei) de\, ei)/per h)=n dunato
, a)/neu tw=n a)/llwn au)to\ le/gesqai: nu=n de\ a)du/naton. PLAT. Theaet. 202A. *xrh=n s), ei)/per h)=sqa mh\ kako\s, pei/santa/ me gamei=n ga/mon to/nd), a)lla\ mh\ sigh=| fi/lwn, i.e. if you were not base, you should make this marriage with my consent, and not (as you do) in secret from your friends. EUR. Med. 586. *ei)/ tina (proi=ka) e)di/dou, ei)ko\s h)=n kai\ th
 doqei=san u(po\ tw=n paragene/sqai fasko/ntwn marturei=sqai, i.e. if he had given any dowry, it would naturally have been attested by witnesses. ISAE. iii. 28.See Id. iv. 18. *)eme\ ei) me
 e)n a)/llais tisi
 h(me/rais h)di/khse/ ti tou/twn i)diw/thn o)/nta, Id. i)di/a| kai\ di/khn prosh=ken au)tw=| dido/nai, i.e. in that case he would properly have given satisfaction by a private suit (as if he had said proshko/ntws i)di/a| di/khn a)
 e)di/dou). DEM. xxi. 33; see xxxiii. 25 and 38. *ou) ga e)nh=n mh\ parakrousqe/ntwn u(mw=n (=ei) mh\ parekrou/sqhte) mei=nai *fili/ppw|, for Philip could not have remained (as he did) unless you had been deceived. Id. xix. 123. *ei) h)=san a)/ndres, w(/sper fasi
, a)gaqoi\, o(/sw| a)lhpto/teroi h)=san toi=s pe/las, tosw=|de fanerwte/ran e)ch=n au)toi=s th
 a)reth
 deiknu/nai, i.e. in that case they might all the more plainly manifest their virtue (which they do not do). THUC. i. 37. *ei) e)bou/leto di/kaios ei)=nai, e)ch=n au)tw=| misqw=sai to
 oi)=kon, h)\ gh=n pria/menos e)k tw=n prosio/ntwn tou\s pai=das tre/fein, i.e. he might have let the house, or have bought land and supported the children from the income. LYS. xxxii. 23. *)en au)th=| th=| di/kh| e)ch=n soi fugh=s timh/sasqai, ei) e)bou/lou. PLAT. Crit. 52C . (See ISOC. xvii. 29.) *polloi=s do/cw, w(s oi(=o/s t' w)/n se sw/|zein ei) h)/qelon a)nali/skein xrh/mata, a)melh=sai, many will think that, whereas I might have saved you if I had been willing to spend money,I neglected it. Ib. 44

1. In the following examples the idea of the infinitive is so modified by that of the leading verb, that the real apodosis (the opposite of which is implied) includes both ideas; but the chief force still remains in the infinitive, so that no a)/n is added.

*ei) ga u(po\ o)do/ntos toi ei)=pe teleuth/sein me, xrh=n dh/ se poie/ein ta\ poie/eis: nu=n de\ u(po\ ai)xmh=s, for if the dream had said that I was to be killed by a tooth, then you would properly do what you now do; but it really said I was to be killed by a spear. HDT. i. 39. (Here the real apodosis is not in poie/ein alone, which is affirmed in ta\ poie/eis, but in the combined idea you would do with propriety; and it is the opposite of this which is implied. *xrh=n a)/n, which might have been used, would throw the main force on the xrh=n, with the meaning it would be your duty to do.) *ei) me
 ou)=n a(/pantes w(mologou=men *fi/lippon th=| po/lei polemei=n, ou)de
 a)/llo e)/dei to
 pario/nta le/gein kai\ sumbouleu/ein h)\ o(/pws a)sfale/stata au)to
 a)munou/meqa, i.e. if then we were all agreed that Philip is at war with us, the speaker ought to say nothing else and to give no other advice than this, etc. (but it is added that, as there is a difference of opinion, it is necessary, a)na/gkh e)sti/n, to speak on another subject also). DEM. ix. 6. (This implies not he does speak, etc., but he is bound to speak, etc. *)/edei a)/n would merely have thrown the balance of force upon the necessity, whereas now it falls on the speaking and advising.) *ei) ga par' e)moi\ e)te/qh to\ grammatei=on, e)nh=n ai)tia/sasqai *)apatouri/w| w(s e)gw\ h)fa/nika ta\s sunqh/kas, for if the account-book had been given me to keep, A. might possibly have charged me with putting the contract out of the way (implying that, as it was, he could not charge me with this). Id. xxxiii. 37. *ei) me
 e(w/ra metame/lon th=| po/lei tw=n pepragme/nwn, ou)k a)/cion h)=n qauma/zein au)tou=, if he had seen that the state repented of her acts, we should have no good reason for being surprised at him (implying we now have good reason for surprise, a)ci/ws qauma/zomen). ISOC. xviii. 21.

The preceding examples confirm the reading of the best MSS. in EUR. Med. 490, ei) ga h)=sq' a)/pais e)/ti, suggnwsto
 h)=n soi tou=d' e)rasqh=nai le/xous, which may be translated, for if you had remained still childless, you might pardonably have become enamoured of this new marriage, the apodosis being equivalent to h)ra/sqhs a)/n with an adverb meaning pardonably (if you had done what would have been pardonable). This implies not you were not enamoured, but you were not pardonably enamoured. If no protasis had been added, suggnwsto
 h)=n e)rasqh=nai (in its potential sense) must have meant you might pardonably have become enamoured (but you did not), and then a)/n would have been required to give the sense it would have been pardonable (but is not so). The other reading, suggnw/st' a)
 h)=n, would make the same change in the balance of force that xrh=n a)/n, e)/dei a)/n, e)nh=n a)/n, and a)/cion a)
 h)=n would make in the preceding examples.

2. In concessive sentences introduced by kai\ ei), even if, ou)d' ei), not even if, or ei), although, containing unreal conditions, where the action of the apodosis is not denied but affirmed (see 412, 3), the real apodosis may be represented by an infinitive and a leading verb like e)/dei, e)ch=n, etc. combined. E.g. *ou)k e)ch=n au)tw=| dika/zesqai peri\ tw=n to/te gegenhme/nwn, ou)d' ei) pa/nta tau=t' h)=n pepoihkw\s a(/ fhsin ou(=tos, he could not maintain a suit about what was then done, even if I had really done what he says I did (implying ou)k e)/cestin au)tw| dika/zesqai, but with the chief force on dika/zesqai). ISOC. xviii. 19. *ou)d' ei) gnh/sioi h)=san ei)spoihtoi\ de\, w(s ou(=toi e)/fasan, ou)d' ou(/tw prosh=ken au)tou\s *eu)kth/monos ei)=nai, not even if they were genuine sons and were afterwards adopted into another family, would they now properly belong to E. 's house (implying they do not properly belong there). ISAE. vi. 44.See also HDT. vii. 56; DEM. xviii. 199, DEM. xxiii. 107.

*ou)d' ei) ga h)=n to\ pra=gma mh\ qeh/laton, a)ka/qarton u(ma=s ei)ko\s h)=n ou(/tws e)a=n, for even if the duty were not urged upon you by a God, you ought not to leave the guilt unpurged as you do. SOPH. O.T. 255. (Here the apodosis as a whole is affirmed, although the infinitive itself, not to leave, is denied. So in the two following examples.) *kalo
 d' h)=n, ei) kai\ h(marta/nomen, toi=sde ei)=cai th=| h(mete/ra| o)rgh=|, h(mi=n d' ai)sxro
 (sc. h)=n) bia/sasqai th
 metrio/thta, if we had even been in the wrong, they might fairly have yielded to our wrath, while we could not have done violence to their moderation without disgrace. THUC. i. 38. *)/acion h)=n, ei) kai\ mhde
 au)tai=s pro/teron u(ph=rxen a)gaqo
, (tau/tas) th=s megi/sths dwrea=s para\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn tuxei=n, i.e. these cities, even if they had had no other merit to rely on, deserved to receive (ought to have received) the greatest reward from the Greeks (which, it is said, they did not receive). ISOC. xii. 71.

(*)/edei a)/n, etc.) The examples in 421, 1 and 2, show that the common rule for distinguishing e)/dei etc. with the infinitive (without a)/n) from e)/dei a)/n etc. with the infinitive,—that the former is used when the action of the infinitive is denied, the latter when the obligation, propriety, or possibility is denied, —often cannot be applied, though as a working rule it can be used in the great majority of cases. While there are many sentences in which either form would express the required sense, the essential distinction is, that the form without a)/n is used when the chief force of the apodosis falls on the infinitive, the leading verb being an auxiliary (see 420); but the leading verb takes a)/n when the chief force falls on the necessity, propriety, or possibility of the act, rather than on the act itself.
The following examples will illustrate the form with a)/n:—

*ei) me
 ga e)gw\ e)/ti e)n duna/mei h)=n tou= r(a|di/ws poreu/esqai pro\s to\ a)/stu, ou)de
 a)/n se e)/dei deu=ro i)e/nai: a)ll' h(mei=s a)
 para\ se\ h)=|men: nu=n de/ se xrh\ pukno/teron deu=ro i)e/nai, i.e. in that case there would be no need (as there now is) of your coming hither. PLAT. Rep. 328 C. *tw=| me
 patri\ au)th=s, ei) pai=des a)/rrenes mh\ e)ge/nonto, ou)k a)
 e)ch=n a)/neu tau/ths diaqe/sqai, her father, if he had had no male children, would not have been allowed to leave her out of his will (implying a)ll' e)ch=n). ISAE. x. 13. *ei) ou)=n parekalou=men a)llh/lous e)pi\ ta\ oi)kodomika\, po/teron e)/dei a)
 h(ma=s ske/yasqai h(ma=s au)tou\s kai\ e)ceta/sai ei) e)pista/meqa th
 te/xnhn; e)/dei a)
 h)\ ou)/; i.e. in that case would it be needful or not to examine ourselves and inquire whether we understand the art? PLAT. Gorg. 514A. See also DEM. iv. 1, quoted in 410.
A comparison of these examples with those in 422, 1, will show the distinction between the two forms and also the narrowness of the line which sometimes separates them.
For a discussion of xrh=n and xrh=n a)/n in DEM. xviii. 195, and of xrh=n and e)xrh=n a)/n in LYS. xii. 32 and 48, and for other remarks on these constructions, see Appendix V.

1. The imperfect w)/fellon or o)/fellon of o)/fe/llw (Epic of o)fei/lw), owe, debeo, and the aorist w)/felon or o)/felon are sometimes used with the infinitive in Homer like xrh=n, e)/dei, etc. in the later construction (415). E.g. *timh/n pe/r moi o)/fellen *)olu/mpios e)gguali/cai *zeu\s u(yibreme/ths: nu=n d' ou)de/ me tutqo\n e)/tisen, i.e. Zeus ought to have secured me honour; but now he has not honoured me even a little. Il. i. 353. *nu=n o)/felen kata\ pa/ntas a)risth=as pone/esqai lisso/menos, now ought he to be labouring among all the nobles, beseeching them. Il. x. 117. *)all' w)/felen a)qana/toisin eu)/xesqai, but he ought to have prayed to the Gods. Il. xxiii. 546.For the reference to present time in Il. x. 117, see 246 and 734.

2. From this comes the common use of this form in expressions of a wish, in Homer and in Attic Greek; as w)/fele *ku=ros zh=n, would that Cyrus were living (lit. Cyrus ought to be living), XEN. An. ii. 1, 4. (See 734.)

Similar to this is the occasional use of e)boulo/mhn (with out a)/n) and the infinitive, to express what some one wishes were now true (but which is not true). E.g. *)eboulo/mhn me
 ou)=n kai\ th
 boulh
 kai\ ta\s e)kklhsi/as o)rqw=s dioikei=sqai kai\ tou\s no/mous i)sxu/ein, I would that both the Senate and the assemblies were rightly managed, and that the laws were in force (implying the opposite of o)rqw=s dioikei=sqai and i)sxu/ein). This is analogous to w)/felen ei)=nai, would that it were, and e)/dei ei)=nai, it ought to be (but is not). AESCHIN. iii. 2. *)eboulo/mhn me
 ou)k e)ri/zein e)nqa/de, I would that I were not contending here (as I am), or I would not be contending here. AR. Ran. 866. *)eboulo/mhn th
 du/namin tou= le/gein e)c i)/sou moi kaqesta/nai th=| sumfora=|, I would that power of speech equal to my misfortune were granted me. ANT. v. i. *)eboulo/mhn ka)gw\ ta)lhqh= pro\s u(ma=s ei)pei=n dunhqh=nai, I would that I had found the power to tell you the truth. ISAE. x. 1. *)eboulo/mhn mhd' u(f' e(no\s a)dikei=sqai tw=n politw=n, I would I had not been wronged by a single one of the citizens. Frag. Id. 4 (Scheibe): see Frag. 22.
*)eboulo/mhn a)/n, vellem, I should wish or I should have liked, can always be used as a potential indicative, like e)/dei a)/n etc. (423): see AR. Eccl. 151; AESCHIN. iii. 115. (See 246.)

(a) The aorist of kinduneu/w is used with the infinitive, as a periphrasis for the verb of the infinitive with a)/n. E.g. *(h po/lis e)kindu/neuse pa=sa diafqarh=nai ei) a)/nemos e)pege/neto, the city ran the risk of being utterly destroyed if a wind had arisen. THUC. iii. 74. *ei) mh\ e)cefu/gomen ei)s *delfou\s e)kinduneu/samen a)pole/sqai, we ran the risk of perishing had we not fled to Delphi, i.e. we should very probably have perished if we had not fled. AESCHIN. iii. 123.For e)kindu/neusa a)/n see (b) below.

So with ki/ndunos h)=n: as in AND. ii. 12, ei) to/te ta\ e)pith/deia mh\ ei)sh/xqh, ou) peri\ tou= sw=sai ta\s *)aqh/nas o( ki/ndunos h)=n au)toi=s ma=llon h)/, k.t.l., i.e. they ran a risk, in case the supplies had not then been brought in, not so much about saving Athens, as, etc.

(b) When the chief force of the apodosis lies in e)kindu/neusa, even though the meaning is not much affected by the distinction in form, a)/n is used (as with e)/dei etc. in 423). So in XEN. An. iv. 1, 11 , ei) plei/ous sunele/ghsan, e)kindu/neusen a)\n polu\ diafqarh=nai tou= strateu/matos, if more had been collected, there would have been danger of much of the army being destroyed.

(a) The imperfect of me/llw with the infinitive may express a past intention or expectation which was not realised, and so take the place of the verb of the infinitive with a)/n. E.g. *)=h ma/la dh\ *)agame/mnonos fqi/sesqai kako\n oi)=ton e)/mellon, ei) mh\ . . . e)/eipes, i.e. I should have perished like A. (lit. I was to have perished), if thou hadst not spoken. Hom. Od. xiii. 383. *me/llen me/n pote oi)=kos o(/d' a)fneio\s kai\ a)mu/mwn e)/mmenai: nu=n d' e(te/rws e)bo/lonto qeoi/, this house was to have been rich and glorious; but now the Gods have willed it otherwise. Hom. Od. i. 232. *ou) sustrateu/sein e)/mellon, they were not going to join him, or they would not have joined him (in that case). DEM. xix. 159; see xviii. 172. *(=htton to\ a)di/khma pollw=n ou)sw=n e)/melle dh=lon e)/sesqai, the offence would have been less plain when there were many (olive trees). LYS. vii. 24. See THUC. v. 38, me/llontes pro/teron, ei) tau=ta e)/peisan, peira/sesqai. Compare the Latin: Hoc facturi erant, nisi venisset, they were to have done this (would have done this), had he not come.This use of e)/mellon with the infinitive corresponds precisely to the Sanskrit use of the past future tense in the sense of the Greek aorist indicative with a)/n. Thus if he had said (avaksyat) this, he would have slain (ahaniSyat) Indra (zat. Brahm. i. 6, THUC. 3^{10}), where the two verbs are augmented past futures, meaning literally he was going to say and he was going to slay. See Whitney's Sanskrit Grammar, § 950.

(b) A single case of a)/n with e)/mellen occurs in AND. i. 21: ei) kai\ path e)bou/leto u(pome/nein, tou\s fi/lous a)
 oi)/esqe . . . e)pitre/pein au)tw=|, a)ll' ou)k a)
 paraitei=sqai kai\ dei=sqai a)pie/nai o(/pou a)
 e)/mellen swqh/sesqai; i.e. to depart to a place where he would have been likely to be safe. Most critics repudiate this a)/n; but it seems perfectly analogous to a)/n with e)/dei, xrh=n, etc. (423).

Similar is the use of e)/fhn in Od. iv. 171: kai/ min e)/fhn e)lqo/nta filh/semen e)/coxon a)/llwn, ei) nw=in no/ston e)/dwken (*zeu/s), i.e. I intended to love him (and should have done so) had Zeus granted us a return.

An analogous case is LYS. xii. 60: a)pole/sai pareskeua/zonto th\n po/lin ei) mh\ di) a)/ndras a)gaqou/s, they were preparing to destroy the city (and would have destroyed it) had it not been for good men.

A few expressions which have no dependent infinitive are practically equivalent to a potential indicative with a)/n, and so can stand as the apodosis of an unreal condition. E.g. *tou/tw| d' ei) mh\ w(molo/goun a(\ ou(=tos e)bou/leto, ou)demi/a| zhmi/a| e)/noxos h)=n, but if they had not acknowledged to him what he wanted, he was liable to no charge (i.e. he could not have been accused). LYS. vii. 37. *(ws, ei) me
 to\ e)p' au)tofw/rw| mh\ prosege/grapto, e)/noxos w)
 (=h)=n) th=| a)pagwgh=|, assuming that, if the words e)p' au)tofw/rw|, had not been added, he might properly have been tried by a)pagwgh/. Id. xiii. 85. *pisteu/ontos ga e)mou= e)moi\ ei)de/nai a(\ le/gw, kalw=s ei)=xen h( paramuqi/a, i.e. for if I trusted (=ei) e)pi/steuon) to any knowledge of my own about what I am saying, the consolation which you offer would encourage me (lit. your consolation was good on that supposition). PLAT. Rep. 450D. (We might have had kalo
 h)=n se paramuqei=sqai in the same sense.) *ei) to\ kwlu=sai th
 tw=n *(ellh/nwn koinwni/an e)pepra/kein e)gw\ *fili/ppw|, soi\ to\ mh\ sigh=sai loipo
 h)=n, in that case it remained for you not to keep silent (i.e. you should not have kept silent). DEM. xviii. 23. (The article with sigh=sai only slightly distinguishes this from the examples under 421.)

The same explanation applies to other cases in which a rhetorical omission of a)/n in apodosis is commonly assumed; as in EUR. Hec. 1113, ei) de\ mh\ *frugw=n pu/rgous peso/ntas h)=|smen *(ellh/nwn dori\, fo/bon pare/sxen ou) me/sws o(/de ktu/pos, but if we had not known that the Phrygian towers had fallen, this noise gave us cause for terror in earnest (i.e. would easily have terrified us).

Occasionally a protasis takes the place of the infinitive in the construction of 419. E.g. *)epei\ to/de ke/rdion h)=en, ei) no/sths' *)oduseu\s kai\ u(po/tropos i(/keto dw=ma, for it had been a greater gain if Ulysses had returned (for ke/rdion h)=en *)oduse/a nosth=sai). Od. xx. 331.Compare MATTH. Ev. xxvi. 24, kalo
 h)=n au)tw=|, ei) ou)k e)gennh/qh o( a)nqrwpos e)kei=nos, it had been good for that man if he had not been born (for kalo
 h)=n au)tw=| mh\ gennhqh=nai). *ei) de\ a)pofeu/cetai, krei/ttwn h)=n o( a)gw
 mh\ gegenhme/nos (=ei) mh\ e)gege/nhto), but if he is acquitted, it were better that the trial had never taken place (for krei=tton h)=n to
 a)gw=na mh\ gegenh=sqai). AESCHIN. i. 192.

This occasional substitution of a protasis does not indicate that the infinitive in krei=tton h)=n au)tw=| e)lqei=n, he had better have gone, was felt as a protasis. We could substitute for this English it were better if he had gone, but only by a change of construction.

div2.head: Homeric Peculiarities.
div2.p: In Homer the construction of the unreal conditional sentence is not completely developed. It is not improbable that in the primitive language the optative could express in a rough way both present and past unreal conditions, and in Homer the present unreal condition is still expressed only by the present optative (438).

The aorist indicative in Homer, both in protasis and in apodosis with a)/n or ke/, is used as in Attic Greek; but the imperfect is always past, never present.Mr. Monro ( Gr. Hom. p. 236) doubts this statement, and refers to Hom. Od. iv. 178, kai/ ke qa/m' e)nqa/d' e)o/ntes e)misgo/meq), ou)de/ ken h(me/as a)llo\ die/krinen, as a case in which the imperfect e)misgo/meqa takes in the present time, we should (from that time till now) have been meeting. It seems to me that, according to the Homeric usage, we can find no more in qa/ma e)misgo/meqa/ ke than we should have had frequent meetings, and the rest comes from the context. In any case, this use is far removed from the Attic e)poreuo/meqa a)
 e)pi\ basile/a, we should (now) be on our way to the King (410). A nearer approach to the later use perhaps appears in Hom. Il. xxiv. 220, ei) me
 ga/r tis m' a)/llos e)keleuen, if any other (had?) commanded me. But see Hom. Il. ii. 80. E.g. *kai/ nu/ ke dh\ cife/ess' au)tosxedo
 ou)ta/zonto, ei) mh\ kh/rukes h)=lqon, they would have wounded each other, had not heralds come. Il. vii. 273. *)/enqa ke loigo\s e)/hn kai\ a)mh/xana e)/rga ge/nonto, ei) mh\ a)/r' o)cu\ no/hse path a)ndrw=n te qew=n te, then there would have been, etc. Il. viii. 130.So viii. 366. *kai/ nu/ ke dh\ prote/rw e)/t' e)/ris ge/net' a)mfo/teroisin, ei) mh\ *)axilleu\s au)to\s a)ni/stato kai\ kate/ruken. Il. xxiii. 490.See Il. xi. 504; Od. xvi. 221, Od. xxiv. 51.

*kai/ nu/ k' e)/ti ple/onas *luki/wn kta/ne di=os *)odusseu\s, ei) mh\ a)/r' o)cu\ no/hse me/gas koruqai/olos *(/ektwr, i.e. Ulysses would have killed still more, had not Hector perceived him. Il. v. 679. *kai/ nu/ ken h)/ia pa/nta kate/fqito kai\ me/ne) a)ndrw=n, ei) mh/ ti/s me qew=n o)lofu/rato kai/ m' e)sa/wsen. Od. iv. 363.
But w)/felon with the present infinitive may be present, even in Homer, both as a potential expression (424) and in wishes (734).
We find the imperfect referring to present time in Theognis: see vs. 905, ei) me\n ga\r katidei=n bio/tou te/los h)=n, ei)ko\s a)\n h)=n. See Nem. iv. 13.
In Il. xxiii. 526, ei)/ ke is found with the aorist indicative in protasis, ke/ apparently adding nothing to the sense:—
*ei) de/ k' e)/ti prote/rw ge/neto dro/mos a)mfote/roisin, *tw=| ke/n min pare/lass' ou)d' a)mfh/riston e)/qhken.

(Optative in present unreal Conditions.) In Homer a present unfulfilled condition is regularly expressed by the present optative with ei), and its apodosis (if present) by the present optative with ke/ or a)/n.

The only instance of this form in both protasis and apodosis is Il. xxiii. 274, ei) me
 nu=n e)pi\ a)/llw| a)eqleu/oimen *)axaioi\, h)= t' a)
 e)gw\ ta\ prw=ta labw
 klisi/hnde feroi/mhn, if we were now contending in honour of any other (than Patroclus), I should take the first prize and bear it to my tent. Twice we have the optative with a)/n in apodosis with the regular imperfect or aorist indicative (past) in the protasis: Il. ii. 80, ei) me/n tis to
 o)/neiron a)/llos e)/nispen, yeu=do/s ken fai=men kai\ nosfizoi/meqa ma=llon, if any other had told the dream, we should call it a lie and rather turn away from it; and the same apodosis after ei)/ ti/s m' a)/llos e)ke/leuen, in Il. xxiv. 222.In Od. ii. 184, ou)k a)
 to/ssa qeoprope/wn a)go/reues, ou)de/ ke *thle/maxon kexolwme/non w(=d' a)niei/hs, we have first the imperfect with a)/n as a past apodosis, (in that case) you would not have made this speech with all its divination; and then the present optative with ke/ as present, nor would you be urging Telemachus on, as you now are; both referring to an unfulfilled past condition, if you had perished, suggested by katafqi/sqai w)/feles in vs. 183.

See the corresponding use of the present optative in Homer to express an unaccomplished present wish (739). In both wishes and conditional sentences, it must be remembered, the use of the optative in its ordinary future sense is completely established in Homer. See examples in 455 and 722.

(Optative in past unreal Apodosis.) Homer has four cases of the optative with ke/ (three aorist and one present) in the apodosis referring to the past, with the regular indicative in the protasis expressing a past unfulfilled condition. These are—

*kai/ nu/ ken e)nq' a)po/loito a)/nac a)ndrw=n *ai)nei/as, ei) mh\ a)/r' o)cu\ no/hse *dio\s quga/thr *)afrodi/th, Aeneas would have perished, had not Aphrodite quickly perceived him. Il. v. 311. *kai/ nu/ ken e)nq' a)po/loito *)/arhs a)=tos pole/moio, ei) mh\ *)heriboi/a *(erme/h| e)ch/ggeilen. Il. v. 388. *ou)/ ke qano/nti per w(=d' a)kaxoi/mhn, ei) meta\ oi(=s e(ta/roisi da/mh *trw/wn e)ni\ dh/mw|, I should not have felt so grieved if he had perished, qano/nti (=ei) e)/qanen) being further explained by ei) . . . da/mh. Od. i. 236. *)/enqa ke r(ei=a fe/roi kluta\ teu/xea, ei) mh/ oi( a)ga/ssato *foi=bos *)apo/llwn, he would easily have borne away the famous armour had not Phoebus Apollo grudged him. Il. xvii. 70.Here a)pw/|leto, a)kaxo/mhn, and e)/fere would be the regular forms even in Homer, corresponding to the regular protases.

In the transitional state of the Homeric language we see that the past tenses of the indicative had fully established themselves in the protasis of past unreal conditions, but not so thoroughly in the apodosis, where the optative occasionally occurs. In present unreal conditions, the optative alone is used in both protasis and apodosis.

Besides the full conditional sentences above quoted, we find in Homer many potential optatives with ke/ or a)/n which seem to belong to the borderland between past and future conclusions, and are not definitely fixed in the past (like the apodoses in 440) by a past tense in the protasis.

Such are especially fai/hs ke, as in Il. iii. 220, Il. xv. 697, and ou)de/ ke fai/hs, as in Il. iv. 429, Il. xvii. 366, Od. iii. 124, Il. iii. 392.In the first four cases it seems most natural to translate them as past, you would have said, nor would you have said; but in the last two cases it is more natural to translate nor would you say (future), and so with fai/hn ken, Il. vi. 285.But in the fluid state of the language which allowed both a)pw/leto/ ke and a)po/loito/ ke to mean he would have perished, and fe/roi ke to mean both he would carry (fut.) and he would have carried, according to the protasis which was used with them, it is easy to understand how fai/hs ke (without a protasis) might have a vague potential force, you might perchance say, which could be felt as either past or future as the context demanded. We must, therefore, hold that the optative with ke/ in such cases expresses merely what could happen, without any limitations of time except such as are imposed by the context; and according to the limitations thus imposed we translate such optatives (with more exactness than they really possess) either as past or as future. In one case the feeling of past time is seen in the dependent verb: Il. v. 85, *tudei+/dhn d' ou)k a)\n gnoi/hs pote/roisi metei/h, you would not have known to what side he belonged. (This occurs in the same book of the Iliad with both the examples of a)po/loito/ ke for a)pw/leto/ ke.)
Other examples are the following:—

*ou)k a)
 e)/peit' *)odush=i/ g' e)ri/sseien broto\s a)/llos, no other mortal could then vie with Ulysses (after a past verb). Il. iii. 223. *)/enq' ou)k a)/n bri/zonta i)/dois *)agame/mnona di=on. Il. iv. 223. *)/enq' ou)/ ken r(e/a i(/ppos e)sbai/h, pezoi\ de\ menoi/neon ei) tele/ousin (the connection with menoi/neon gives e)sbai/h a past direction). Il. xii. 58. *)/enqa k' e)/peita kai\ a)qa/nato/s per e)pelqw
 qhh/saito i)dw
 kai\ tarfqei/h fresi
 h(=|sin. Od. v. 73. *(ws ou)k a)
 e)/lpoio new/teron a)ntia/santa, i.e. as you would not expect (?) a younger person to do. Od. vii. 293. *ou)de/ ken i)/rhc ki/rkos o(marth/seien. Od. xiii. 86.Further, compare Od. ix. 241 with Il. i. 271 and v. 303.

div2.head: Homeric Usages in Herodotus and in Attic Greek.
div2.p:
(a) Herodotus has a few cases of the potential optative with the same vague reference to time which has been noticed in Homer (442), and we may sometimes translate these, like those in Homer, by past expressions. E.g. *ta/xa de\ a)
 kai\ oi( a)podo/menoi le/goien a)piko/menoi e)s *spa/rthn w(s a)paireqei/hsan u(po\ *sami/wn, and perhaps those who sold it (the cup) might come to Sparta and tell that they had been robbed of it. HDT. i. 70 (see Stein's note). All that the optative itself seems to express is that this would be a natural story for them to tell. In vii. 214, ei)dei/h me
 ga a)
 kai\ e)w
 mh\ *mhlieu\s tau/thn th
 a)/trapo
 *)onh/ths, ei) th=| xw/rh| polla\ o(milhkw\s ei)/h, for Onetes, even if he was not a Malian, might know this path, supposing him to have had much acquaintance with the country, the optative in protasis (expressing no condition contrary to fact) shows that ei)dei/h a)/n is not felt to be past. See also vii. 180, ta/xa d' a)/n ti e)pau/roito; viii. 136, ta/x' a)
 prole/goi, might perhaps warn him; ix. 71, tau=ta a)
 ei)/poien, they might say this.
For ei)/hsan d' a)\n ou(=toi *krh=tes, HDT. i. 2, and similar expressions, see 238.

(b) In EUR. Med. 568, ou)d' a)\n su\ fai/hs ei)/ se mh\ kni/zoi le/xos , the condition seems to be present and contrary to fact, like ei) mh\ e)/knizen. See also PLAT. Menex. 240 D, e)n tou/tw| dh\ a)/n tis geno/menos gnoi/h oi(=oi a)/ra e)tu/gxanon o)/ntes, k.t.l. Such examples are extremely rare in Attic Greek.

div2.head: (b) Future Conditions: 1. Subjunctive or Future Indicative in Protasis with a future Apodosis.
div2.p:
When a supposed future case is stated distinctly and vividly (as if I shall go or if I go in English) the protasis generally takes the subjunctive with e)a/n, h)/n, or a)/n (a_) (Epic ei)/ ke or ai)/ ke). The apodosis takes the future indicative or some other form expressing future time, to denote what will be the result if the condition of the protasis is fulfilled. E.g. *)ea/n ti la/bw, dw/sw soi, if I (shall) receive anything, I will give it to you. *)ea/n ti la/bh|s, do/s moi, if you receive anything, give it to me. *ei) de/ ken w(\s e)/rch|s kai/ toi pei/qwntai *)axaioi\, gnw/sh| e)/peiq' o(/s q' h(gemo/nwn kako\s o(/s te/ nu law=n, but if you shall do thus and the Achaeans obey you, you will then learn both which of the leaders and which of the soldiers is bad. Il. ii. 364. *ai)/ k' au)to

It will be seen that the apodosis here (444) may consist of any future expression,—the future indicative, the imperative, the subjunctive in exhortations and prohibitions, the infinitive in any future sense, the potential optative with a)/n, or the optative in a wish. It may also contain a present indicative including a reference to the future, like xrh/ or dei= or the verbal in te/os, or the present used emphatically for the future, like o(mologw= above quoted (444) from XEN. Cyr. v. 5, 13 , or pau=la/ e)sti in PLAT. Rep. 473D.

The English, especially the colloquial language, seldom expresses the distinction between this form of the future condition and the present condition (402). Thus modern custom allows us to use the inexact expression if he wishes, not merely for ei) bou/letai, if he now wishes, but also for e)a\n bou/lhtai, if he shall wish. The sense, however, generally makes the distinction in time clear.

It is worth noting that the Authorised Version of the English New Testament never uses forms like if he does, if he is, in either future or present conditions, even when the Greek has the present indicative with ei); but it has either the subjunctive or the future indicative in future conditions, and the subjunctive in present conditions. The Revised Version, on the other hand, admits the present indicative (as if he is) in present conditions, but not consistently. See LUC. xxiii. 35, ei) ou(=to/s e)stin o( *xristo/s, V. A. if he be Christ, R. V. if this is the Christ; but in MATTH. vi. 23, ei) ou)=n to\ fw=s to\ e)n soi\ sko/tos e)sti/n, both versions have if therefore the light that is in thee be darkness. See also Cor. ii. v. 17.

(Future Indicative in Protasis.) The future indicative with ei) is often used in the protasis to express a future condition. This is a still stronger form of expression than the subjunctive, though it sometimes alternates with it in the same sentence. Both, however, correspond to the English if I shall do this, if I do this, etc. The future, as an emphatic form, is especially common when the condition contains a strong appeal to the feelings or a threat or warning.In minatory and monitory conditions: see Gildersleeve in Trans. of Assoc. Phil. for 1876, p. 13. This article contains an enumeration of all the cases of e)a/n with the subjunctive in future conditions and of ei) with the future indicative in the three tragedians. It appears that in Aeschylus there are 22 cases of the future and only 8 of the subjunctive; in Sophocles 67 futures and 55 subjunctives; in Euripides 131 futures and 177 subjunctives. If we omit the futures which are equivalent to me/llw with an infinitive, for which the subjunctive could not be substituted (see 407), we have in Aeschylus 15 futures in future conditions and 8 subjunctives; in Sophocles 46 and 55; in Euripides 98 and 177. In Attic prose Thucydides and Lysias have the largest proportion of futures; but in prose, as in Aristophanes, the subjunctives always preponderate. It is thus a favourite construction with the tragedians. E.g. *ei) ga *)axilleu\s oi)=os e)pi\ *trw/essi maxei=tai, ou)de\ mi/nunq' e(/cousi podw/kea *phlei+/wna, if Achilles shall fight alone against the Trojans, not even a little while will they keep back the swift son of Peleus. The future in protasis is also appropriately used when a future apodosis is implied in a past tense; as in SOPH. OT 843 , ei) le/cei to

, ou)k e)gw\ k)ta/non, if he shall tell the same number (it will follow that) I did not kill him. So EUR. Med. 1249.
This use of the future must be distinguished from its use in present conditions (407), where it is equivalent to me/llw and the infinitive and cannot be interchanged with the subjunctive.

div2.head: Homeric Peculiarities.
div2.p: In the Homeric language the following peculiarities appear in this construction:—

By far the most common Homeric form with the sub junctive in future conditions is ei)/ ke, often ei) me/n ke, ei) de/ ke, etc. (218). *)/hn also is frequent, being the only Homeric contraction of ei) a)/n. *ei) d' a)/n occurs in Il. iii. 288, and ei)/ per a)/n in Il. v. 224 and 232. *)/hn per ga/r k' e)qe/lwsin is found in Od. xviii. 318.

*ei)/ ke or ai)/ ke is sometimes found even with the future indicative in Homer. E.g. *ai)/ ken a)/neu e)me/qen *)ili/ou pefidh/setai ou)d' e)qelh/sei e)kpe/rsai, i)/stw tou=to. Il. xv. 213. (See 196.)

The subjunctive with ke/ is sometimes used in the apodosis instead of the future indicative, thus making the apodosis correspond in form to the protasis. E.g. *ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/h|sin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, and if he do not give her up, I will take her myself. Il. i. 324 (compare i. 137). This gives a form with two subjunctives analogous to that which has the optative in both protasis and apodosis (460). See 399. (For de/ in apodosis see 512.)
For the Epic use of the future indicative with ke/ or a)/n in apodosis, see 196.

The simple ei) (without ke/ or a)/n) is sometimes used with the subjunctive in future conditions in Homer, apparently in the same sense as ei)/ ke or h)/n. E.g. *ei)/ per ga/r se katakta/nh|, ou)/ s' e)/t' e)gw/ ge klau/somai. Il. xxii. 86. *ei) d' au)= tis r(ai/h|si qew=n e)ni\ oi)/nopi po/ntw|, tlh/somai e)n sth/qessin e)/xwn talapenqe/a qumo/n. Od. v. 221.So Il. i. 341, Il. v. 258, Il. xii. 223, Il. 245; Od. i. 204, Od. i. 188, Od. xii. 348.Only these nine cases occur, and the more common use of the simple ei) with the subjunctive in Homer is in general suppositions (see 468).

1. This Homeric use of the simple ei) with the subjunctive in future conditions was allowed by poetic license in a few passages of the Attic drama, chiefly in tragedy, even in the dialogue. E.g. *ei) ga\r qa/nh|s kai\ teleuth/sas a)fh=|s. SOPH. Aj. 496.
*dusta/laina ta)/r' e)gw\ ei)/ sou sterhqw=. Id. O.C. 1443. So Ant. 887.
*ei) mh/ s' e)kfa/gw e)k th=sde th=s gh=s, ou)de/pote biw/somai. AR. Eq. 698. So AESCH. Pers. 791; EUR. Or. 1534, I. A. 1240, ei) peisqh=|s (MSS.); all in dialogue. In Sappho 118. 1A, we have ai)/ tis e)/rhtai.

2. In Attic prose, this construction is extremely rare and always doubtful. The MSS., however, have it in a few passages, as THUC. vi. 21: *ou) nautikh=s stratia=s mo/non dei=, a)lla\ kai\ pezo\n polu\n zumplei=n, a)/llws te kai\ ei) custw=sin ai( po/leis fobhqei=sai. (Here a few inferior MSS. read h)/n.)

div2.head: 2. Optative in Protasis and Apodosis.
div2.p:
When a supposed future case is stated less distinctly and vividly than the subjunctive would state it (as if I should go in English), the protasis takes the optative with ei). The apodosis takes the optative with a)/n to denote what would be the result if the condition of the protasis should be fulfilled. E.g. *ei) e)/lqoi, pa/nt' a)
 i)/doi, if he should go, he would see all. *ei)/ s' ou(/tws e)qe/loi file/ein kh/doito/ te qumw=|, tw=| ke/n tis kei/nwn ge kai\ e)klela/qoito ga/moio, if she should be willing thus to love you, etc., then some of them would cease even to think of marriage. Od. iii. 223. *)=h ken ghqh/sai *pri/amos *pria/moio/ te pai=des, a)/lloi te *trw=es me/ga ken kexaroi/ato qumw=|, ei) sfw=in ta/de pa/nta puqoi/ato marname/noiin. Il. i. 255. *)all' ei)/ moi/ ti pi/qoio, to/ ken polu\ ke/rdion ei)/h. Il. vii. 28.
*ei)/hs forhto\s ou)k a)
, ei) pra/ssois kalw=s, you would not be bearable if you should ever be in prosperity. AESCH. Prom. 979 . *oi)=kos d' au)to\s, ei) fqoggh

 a)qliw/tatos ei)/h; Id. xi. 47. *pw=s ou)=n ou)k a)\:n oi)ktro/tata pa/ntwn e)gw\ peponqw\s ei)/hn, ei) e)me\ yhfi/sainto ei)=nai ce/non; how then should I not have suffered (lit. be hereafter in the condition of having suffered) the most pitiable of all things, if they should vote me a foreigner? DEM. lvii. 44. (See 103 for other examples of the perfect optative.)

This form of the conditional sentence in its fully developed use, as it appears in Attic Greek, must be carefully distinguished from that of 410; the more so, as we often translate both ei)/h a)/n and h)=n a)/n by the same English expression, it would be; although the latter implies that the supposition of the protasis is a false one, while the former implies no opinion of the speaker as to the truth of the supposition. We have seen (438-440) that the more primitive Homeric language had not yet fully separated these two constructions, and still used the optative in the apodosis of present, and sometimes of past, unreal conditions.

On the other hand, the distinction between this form and that of 444 is less marked, and it is sometimes of slight importance which of the two is used. As it is often nearly indifferent in English whether we say if we shall go (or if we go) it will be well, or if we should go it would be well, so may it be in Greek whether we say e)a\n e)/lqwmen kalw=s e(/cei or ei) e)/lqoimen kalw=s a)\n e)/xoi. In writing Greek, this distinction can generally be made by first observing the form of the apodosis in English; if that is expressed by should or would, it is to be translated by the Greek optative with a)/n; if it is expressed by shall or will, by the future indicative. Other forms of the apodosis, as the imperative, will present no difficulty. The form to be used in the protasis will then appear from the principles of the dependence of moods (170-178); the optative will require another optative with ei) in the dependent protasis, while the future indicative or any other primary form will require a subjunctive with e)a/n or a future indicative with ei).
In indirect discourse after past tenses we often find an optative in protasis, which merely represents the same tense of the subjunctive or indicative in the direct discourse. See 667, 1; 689; 694.
For the occasional omission of a)/n in an apodosis of this kind, see 240-242.

The potential optative with a)/n may stand in the protasis with ei); as in ei) e)/lqoimi a)/n, supposing that I would go, easily distinguished from ei) e)/lqoimi, supposing that I should go. Such an expression does not belong here, but is really a present condition. (See 409; 506.)
The future optative cannot be used in protasis or apodosis, except in indirect discourse to represent a future indicative of the direct discourse. (See 128 and 203.)

div2.head: Homeric Peculiarities.
div2.p:
*ei)/ ke with the optative is sometimes found in Homer, and ei)/ per a)/n occurs once.See the examples in Lange, Partikel EI, pp. 185, 186. There are twenty-six cases of ei)/ ke with the optative in Homer, and one of ei)/ per a)/n ( Il. ii. 597); besides Il. v. 273 (= viii. 196) and Od. xvii. 223, mentioned in the text (461). This is a mark of the unsettled usage of the earlier language, in which ke/ or a)/n was not yet required with the subjunctive in protasis, and was still allowed with the optative or indicative (401). It is difficult to see any essential difference between these protases with ei)/ ke and those with the simple ei) and the optative. E.g. *ei) de/ ken *)/argos i(koi/meq' *)axaiiko/n, ou)=qar a)rou/rhs, gambro/s ke/n moi e)/oi, and if we should ever come to Achaean Argos, then he would (shall) be my son-in-law. Il. ix. 141 ; cf. ix. 283, and Od. xii. 345, Od. xix. 589. *pw=s a)
 e)gw/ se de/oimi met' a)qana/toisi qeoi=sin, ei)/ ken *)/arhs oi)/xoito xre/os kai\ desmo
 a)lu/cas. Od. viii. 352. *tw=n ke/n toi xari/saito path a)perei/si) a)/poina, ei)/ ken e)me\ zwo
 pepu/qoit' e)pi\ nhusi
 *)axaiw=n. Il. vi. 49.The distinction between these cases and those of 458 is obvious.

In Il. i. 60, ei)/ ken with the optative forms a subordinate protasis, with a remoter and less emphatic supposition than the main protasis ei) dama=| (future); nu=n a)/mme pa/lin plagxqe/ntas o)i/w a)\y a)ponosth/sein, ei)/ ken qa/nato/n ge fu/goimen, ei) dh\ o(mou= po/lemo/s te dama=| kai\ loimo\s *)axaiou/s, now I think we shall be driven back and shall return home again—that is, supposing us to escape death—if both war and pestilence are at the same time to destroy the Achaeans. In Il. ii. 597 we have ei)/ per a)\n au)tai\ *mou=sai a)ei/doien.
These constructions are never negative.

In the strange protasis, ei) tou/tw ke la/boimen, Il. v. 273 and viii. 196, the separation of ei) from ke/ might compel us to recognise a potential force, if we could (possibly) secure these; but the difference between this and the Attic examples of ei) with the potential optative and a)/n (458; 506), and the difficulty of seeing any difference between this and ei) tou/tw la/boimen, if we should secure these, induced Bekker to read ei) tou/tw ge la/boimen here, and also to/n g' ei)/ moi doi/hs (for to/n k' ei)) in Od. xvii. 223.
The Homeric use of the optative in present and past unreal conditional sentences has been discussed (438).

div2.head: II. Present and Past General Suppositions.
div2.p:
In present or past general suppositions, the apodosis expresses a customary or repeated action or a general truth in present or past time, and the protasis refers in a general way to any act or acts of a given class. Here the protasis has the subjunctive with e)a/n after present tenses, and the optative with ei) after past tenses. The apodosis has the present or imperfect indicative, or some other form which implies repetition. E.g. *)\hn e)ggu\s e)/lqh| qa/natos, ou)dei\s bou/letai qnh/|skein, if (or when) death comes near, no one is (ever) willing to die. EUR. Alc. 671. *)\hn me
 a(/dh| kai\ nh/fousi, xre/wntai au)tw=|: h)
 de\ mh\ a(/dh|, metiei=si. HDT. i. 133. *diatelei= misw=n, ou)k h)/n ti/s ti au)to

*)all' ei)/ ti mh\ fe/roimen, w)/trunen fe/rein, but if we ever stopped bringing him food, he always urged us to bring it. EUR. Alc. 755. *ei)/ tis a)ntei/poi, eu)qu\s teqnh/kei, if any one objected, he was a dead man at once (52). THUC. viii. 66. *ei)/ tina punqa/noito u(bri/zonta, tou=ton e)dikai/eu. HDT. i. 100. *ei) de/ tinas qoruboume/nous ai)/sqoi- to, to\ ai)/tion tou/tou skopw=n katasbennu/nai th

 e)peira=to, whenever he saw any making a disturbance, he always tried, etc. XEN. Cyr. v. 3, 55. *ou)k a)pelei/peto e)/ti au)tou=, ei) mh/ ti a)nagkai=on ei)/h, he never left him, unless there was some necessity for it. Id. Mem. iv. 2, Id. Mem. 40. *)=hn toi=s me
 o)fqalmoi=s e)pikou/rhma th=s xio/nos, ei)/ tis me/lan ti e)/xwn pro\ tw=n o)fqalmw=n poreu/oito, tw=n de\ podw=n ei)/ tis kinoi=to. Id. An. iv. 5, Id. An. 13. *)epeidh\ de\ ei)=don au)to
 ta/xista, sullabo/ntes a)/gousin a)/ntikrus w(s a)poktenou=ntes, ou(=per kai\ tou\s a)/llous a)pe/sfatton ei)/ tina lh|sth
 h)\ kakou=rgon sulla/boien, i.e. where they had been in the habit of killing any others whom they took. LYS. xiii. 78.

This optative referring to past time must be especially distinguished from the optative in ordinary protasis referring to the future (455). *ei) and e)a/n in this construction are often almost equivalent to o(/te or o(/tan (which are the more common expressions), and the protasis has precisely the same construction as the relative sentences of 532.
The present and aorist subjunctive and optative here do not differ except as explained in 87. The future optative of course is never used here (128).
The examples in 462 exhibit the ordinary Attic usage. In Homer we find this construction in a partially developed state: see 468.

The gnomic aorist (154) and other gnomic and iterative expressions (162; 163) may be used in the apodosis of these general conditions. The gnomic aorist, as a primary tense, is followed by the subjunctive. E.g. *)\hn sfalw=sin, a)ntelpi/santes a)/lla e)plh/rwsan th\n xrei/an, if they fail, they always supply the deficiency, etc. THUC. i. 70. *)\hn de/ tis tou/twn ti parabai/nh|, zhmi/an au)toi=s e)pe/qesan, they (always) impose a penalty upon every one who transgresses. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 2. *ei)/ tines i)/doie/n ph| tou\s sfete/rous e)pikratou=ntas, a)neqa/rshsan a)/n, whenever any saw their friends in any way victorious, they would be encouraged (i.e. they were encouraged in all such cases). THUC. vii. 71.See XEN. Mem. iv. 6, 13 , quoted in 162.

(Indicative.) The indicative is sometimes found in the place of the subjunctive or optative in these general conditions, that is, these follow the construction of ordinary present and past suppositions, as in Latin and English. Here the speaker refers to one of the cases in which the event may occur, as if it were the only one,—that is, he states the general supposition as if it were particular. E.g.

*moi=rai d' a)fi/stant), ei)/ tis e)/xqra pe/lei o(mogo/nois, ai)dw= kalu/yai, the Fates stand aloof to hide their shame, if there is enmity among kindred. PIND. Py. iv. 145; cf. Ol. i. 64. (See 406.) *ei)/ tis du/o h)\ kai\ ple/ous tis h(me/ras logi/zetai, ma/taio/s e)stin, if any one ever counts upon two or even more days, he is a fool. SOPH. Tr. 944. *)eleuqe/rws politeu/omen, ou) di) o)rgh=s to\n pe/las, ei) kaq' h(donh/n ti dra=|, e)/xontes, i.e. not (having a habit of) being angry with our neighbour if he ever acts as he pleases. THUC. ii. 37. (Here the indicative dra=| is used as if some particular act of one neighbour, and not any act of any neighbour, were in mind.) *ei) ga/r tis e)n dhmokrati/a| tetimhme/nos tolma=| bohqei=n toi=s para/noma gra/fousin, katalu/ei th\n politei/an u(f' h(=s teti/mhtai. AESCHIN. iii. 196. *ei)/ ti/s ti e)phrw/ta, a)pekri/nonto, if any one asked anything, they replied (to all such). THUC. vii. 10. *)emi/sei ou)k ei)/ tis kakw=s pa/sxwn h)muneto, a)ll' ei)/ tis eu)ergetou/menos a)xa/ristos fai/noito. Xen. Ag. xi. 3.Here, without any apparent reason, the writer changes from the indicative to the optative. (See 534.)

div2.head: Homeric and Other Poetic Peculiarities.
div2.p: In Homer the subjunctive appears in protasis in general suppositions (462) only nineteen times, and the optative only once. Here the subjunctive generally (in fourteen cases) has the simple ei) (without ke/ or a)/n). E.g. *ei)/ per ga/r te xo/lon ge kai\ au)th=mar katape/yh|, a)lla/ ge kai\ meto/pisqen e)/xei ko/ton, o)/fra tele/ssh|, for even if he swallows his wrath for the day, still he keeps his anger hereafter, until he accomplishes its object. Il. i. 81. *tw=n ou)/ ti metatre/pom' ou)d' a)legi/zw, ei)/ t' e)pi\ deci/) i)/wsi, ei)/ t' e)p' a)ristera/, I do not heed them nor care for them, whether they go to the right or to the left. Il. xii. 238.So Il. iv. 262, Il. x. 225, Il. xi. 116, Il. xvi. 263, Il. xxi. 576, Il. xxii. 191 (the last four in similes); Od. i. 167, Od. vii. 204, Od. xii. 96, Od. xiv. 373, Od. xvi. 98 (= 116).

*)/hn pote dasmo\s i(/khtai, soi\ to\ ge/ras polu\ mei=zon, if ever a division comes, your prize is always much greater. Il. i. 166.So Od. xi. 159, h)\n mh/ tis e)/xh|. Besides these two cases of h)/n, Homer has two of ei)/ ke, Il. xi. 391, Il. xii. 302; and one of ei)/ per a)/n, Il. iii. 25 (five in all).

The single case of ei) with the optative in a past general condition in Homer is Il. xxiv. 768: a)ll' ei)/ ti/s me kai\ a)/llos e)ni/ptoi, a)lla\ su\ to/n ge kate/rukes, but if any other upbraided me, you (always) restrained him.

Pindar has only eight cases of the subjunctive in protasis. These all have general suppositions and all have the simple ei);Jour. Phil. iii. p. 443. The examples are Ol. vi. 11; Pyth. iv. 266, 273 (perhaps also 263); Nem. vii. 11, Nem. ix. 46; Isth. iii. 58, Nem. iv. 12; Frag. 171 (Böckh), 5. The references to the other poets in 470 and 471 do not profess to be complete. as polloi\ de\ me/mnantai, kalo\n ei)/ ti ponaqh=|, but many remember it if a noble work is done, Ol. vi. 11.

The other lyric and elegiac poets show no preference for the simple ei). The following cases may be cited: CALL. i. 13 ei) h)=| (but h)/n in 17); TYRT. xii. 35 ei) fu/gh| (but h)/n xi. 16); SOL. iv. 30 ei) h)=|? (but h)/n xii. 1, SOL. xiii. 29); THEOG. 121, THEOG. 122 ei) lelh/qh| . . . e)/xh|, and 321 ei) o)pa/ssh| (but h)/n 93, THEOG. 186, THEOG. 379, THEOG. 697, THEOG. 929, THEOG. 932, THEOG. 1355, THEOG. 1356, THEOG. 1385); all (both ei) and h)/n) in general conditions. See SIM. AMORG. vii. 15, THEOG. 69, THEOG. 97 (h)/n).

In the Attic poets we find a few cases of the simple ei) in general conditions. E.g. *)all' a)/ndra, kei)/ tis h)=| sofo\s, to\ manqa/nein po/ll' ai)sxro\n ou)de\n kai\ to\ mh\ tei/nein a)/gan. SOPH. Ant. 710. So SOPH. Aj. 521; O. T. 198, SOPH. Aj. 874; O. C. 509; AESCH. Supp. 91, AESCH. Eum. 234.
For the simple ei) in future conditions, see 453; 454. For the probable relation of ei) to ei)/ ke, h)/n, e)a/n, etc., see 401.

div2.head: Peculiar Forms of Conditional Sentences: Substitution and Ellipsis in Protasis.—Protasis without a Verb.
div2.p:
Often the protasis is not expressed in its regular form with ei) or e)a/n, but is contained in a participle, or implied in an adverb like ou(/tws or dikai/ws, in a preposition with its case, or in some other form of expression. When a participle represents the protasis (841), its tense is always that in which the verb itself would have stood in the indicative, subjunctive, or optative. The present (as usual) includes the imperfect, and the perfect includes the pluperfect. E.g. *tou=to poiou=ntes eu)= pra/cousin (i.e. e)a
 poiw=sin), if they (shall) do this, they will prosper. *tou=to poih/santes eu)= pra/cousin (i.e. e)a
 poih/swsin). *tou=to poiou=ntes eu)= a)
 pra/ttoien (i.e. ei) poioi=en), if they should do this, they would prosper. *tou=to poih/santes eu)= a)
 pra/ttoien (i.e. ei) poih/saien). *tou=to poiou=ntes eu)= a)
 e)/pratton (i.e. ei) e)poi/oun), if they were doing this (or if they had been doing this), they would be in prosperity. *tou=to poih/santes eu)= a)
 e)/pratton (i.e. ei) e)poi/hsan), if they had done this, they would be in prosperity.

*pw=s dh=ta di/khs ou)/shs o( *zeu\s ou)k a)po/lwlen to
 pate/r' au(tou= dh/sas; i.e. how is it that Zeus has not been destroyed, if Justice exists? AR. Nub. 904. (Here di/khs ou)/shs represents ei) di/kh e)sti/n.) *)all' ei)so/mesqa do/mous parastei/xontes (e)a
 parastei/xwmen), but we shall know, if we enter the house. SOPH. Ant. 1255. *su\ de\ klu/wn ei)/sei ta/xa (e)a
 klu/h|s), but you will soon know, if you listen. AR. Av. 1390. So mh\ maqw/n, unless I learn, for e)a
 mh\ ma/qw, AR. Nub. 792. *kai/ ken tou=t' e)qe/loimi *dio/s ge dido/ntos a)re/sqai (*dio\s di/dontos = ei) *zeu\s didoi/h), and this I should like to obtain, if Zeus would only give it. Hom. Od. i. 390. *toiau=ta/ ta)
 gunaici\ sunnai/wn e)/xois (ei) sunnai/ois), such things would you suffer, if you should live with women. Sept. 195. *ou)d' a)
 siwph/saimi th
 a)/thn o(rw=n stei/xousan a)stoi=s (i.e. ei) o(rw/|hn). SOPH. Ant. 185. *)aqhnai/wn de\ to\ au)to\ tou=to paqo/ntwn, diplasi/an a)
 th
 du/namin ei)ka/zesqai (oi)=mai), but if the Athenians should ever suffer this (paqo/ntwn = ei) pa/qoien), I think it would be inferred that their power was twice as great. THUC. i. 10. (Here only the context shows that paqo/ntwn does not represent ei) e)/paqon, if they had ever suffered.) *pri
 gene/sqai h)pi/sthsen a)/n tis a)kou/sas (i.e. ei) h)/kousen), before it happened, any one would have disbelieved such a thing if he had heard it. THUC. vii. 28. *ou) ga a)
 metapei/qein u(ma=s e)zh/tei mh\ toiau/ths ou)/shs th=s u(parxou/shs u(polh/yews, for he would not be seeking to change your minds, if such were not the prevailing opinion (i.e. ei) mh\ toiau/th h)=n). DEM. xviii. 228. *)/estin ou)=n o(/pws tau=t' a)
, e)kei=na proeirhkw\s, o( au)to\s a)nh mh\ diafqarei\s e)to/lmhsen ei)pei=n; is it possible then that the same man, after saying that, would have dared to say this unless he had been corrupted (ei) mh\ diefqa/rh)? Id. xix. 308. *mh\ kathgorh/santos *ai)sxi/nou mhde
 e)/cw th=s grafh=s ou)d' a)
 e)gw\ lo/gon ou)de/na e)poiou/mhn e(/teron (ei) mh\ kathgo/rhsen). Id. xviii. 34. *ta\ au)ta\ a)
 e)/prace kai\ prw/th laxou=sa (i.e. ei) prw/th e)/laxen), it (the soul) would have done the same, even if it had had the first choice by the lot. PLAT. Rep. 620D.
*mamma=n d' a)
 ai)th/santos h(=ko/n soi fe/rwn a)
 a)/rton, and if you ever asked for something to eat, I used to come bringing you bread. AR. Nub. 1383. (Here ai)th/santos represents ei) ai)th/seias in a general supposition, AR. Nub. 462. For h(=kon a)/n see 162.)

*ou)/te e)sqi/ousi plei/w h)\ du/nantai fe/rein, diarragei=en ga\r a)/n: ou)/t' a)mfie/nnuntai plei/w h)\ du/nantai fe/rein, a)popnigei=en ga\r a)/n, they do not eat more than they can bear, for (if they should) they would burst, etc. XEN. Cyr. viii. 2, 21. *au)toi\ a)\n e)poreu/qhsan h(=| oi( a)/lloi: ta\ d' u(pozu/gia ou)k h)=n a)/llh| h)\ tau/th| e)kbh=nai, they would have gone themselves where the others went; but the animals could not go otherwise than as they did. Id. An. iv. 2, Id. An. 10.So h)= ga\r a)\n lwbh/saio, Il. i. 232.

*(hmi=n d' e)c pollh=s a)
 periousi/as new=n mo/lis tou=to u(ph=rxe kai\ mh\ a)nagkazome/nois, w(/sper nu=n, pa/sais fula/ssein, but we should hardly have this advantage if we had a great superiority in number of ships (= ei) pollh
 periousi/an ei)/xomen) and if we were not compelled (ei) mh\ h)nagkazo/meqa), as we are, to use our whole fleet in guarding. THUC. vii. 13. *to\ me
 e)p' e)kei/nw| polla/kis a)
 dielu/qhsan, if it had depended on him, they often would have been disbanded. ISOC. iv. 142. *dia/ ge u(ma=s au)tou\s pa/lai a)
 a)polw/leite, if it had depended on yourselves, you would long ago have been ruined. DEM. xviii. 49. (So sometimes kaq' u(ma=s.) *pa/lai ga a)
 e(/neka/ ge yhfisma/twn e)dedw/kei di/khn, for, if decrees were of any avail, he would long ago have suffered punishment. Id. iii. 14. (Here the protasis is implied in e(/neka yhfisma/twn.) *ou(/tw ga ou)ke/ti tou= loipou= pa/sxoimen a)
 kakw=s, for in that case we should no longer suffer. Id. iv. 15.So w(s ou(/tw perigeno/menos a)/n, XEN. An. i. 1, 10. *ou)d' a)
 dikai/ws e)s kako
 pe/soimi/ ti. SOPH. Ant. 240.

In such cases the form of the apodosis generally shows what form of protasis is implied. When the apodosis is itself expressed by an infinitive or participle (479), as in THUC. i. 10 (above), the form of the protasis is shown only by the general sense of the passage.

The future participle is not used to represent the future indicative in future conditions (447); it may, however, represent the future in present conditions (407), where it is equivalent to me/llw and the infinitive; as in DEM. xxiv. 189, mh\ peri\ tou/twn u(mw=n oi)so/ntwn th\n yh=fon, ti/ dei= tau=ta le/gonta e)noxlei=n me nuni/; if you are not to give your vote about this, mh\ oi)so/ntwn representing ei) mh\ oi)/sete = ei) mh\ me/llete fe/rein. The present and aorist participles, when they represent the present and aorist subjunctive, express future conditions, thus making the future participle unnecessary. The aorist participle in protasis can always represent an aorist subjunctive in the sense explained in 90.

The verb of the protasis is suppressed in the Homeric ei) d' a)/ge, come now! This is commonly explained by an ellipsis of bou/lei, if you will, come now! But it is probable that no definite verb was in the speaker's mind in such expressions, even when we find it necessary to supply one. E.g. *ei) d' a)/ge, toi kefalh=| kataneu/somai, come now! I will nod my assent to thee. Il. i. 524. *ei) d' a)/ge mh
, pei/rhsai, i(/na gnw/wsi kai\ oi(/de, well! come now, try it. Il. i. 302. *ei) me
 dh\ qeo/s e)ssi qeoi=o/ te e)/klues au)dh=s, ei) d' a)/ge moi kai\ kei=non o)izuro
 kata/lecon (the apodosis being introduced by ei) d' a)/ge, come now, tell me). Od. iv. 831.

(*(ws ei).) There is a probably unconscious suppression of the verb of the protasis when w(s ei) or w(s ei)/ te is used in comparisons (especially in Homer) with a noun or adjective or with a participle. E.g. *tw=n ne/es w)kei=ai w(s ei) ptero\n h)e\ no/hma, their ships are swift as (if) a wing or thought. Od. vii. 36. *(ws m' a)su/fhlon e)/recen *)atrei+/dhs w(s ei)/ tin' a)ti/mhton metana/sthn, for the son of Atreus insulted me like (i.e as if he were insulting) some despised wanderer. Il. ix. 648. *)eple/omen *bore/h| a)ne/mw| r(hidi/ws w(s ei)/ te kata\ r(o/on, we sailed on with the northeast wind easily, as if (we were sailing) down stream. Od. xiv. 253. In all these cases no definite verb was in mind after ei), but the addition of ei) to w(s shows that a conditional force was felt (at least originally) in addition to the comparison; and this is the only difference between these examples and those with the simple w(s or w(/s te, as e(sth/kein w(/s ti/s te le/wn, he stood like a lion.See Lange, Partikel EI, p. 234. Lange is at great pains to show that there is no ellipsis here, or indeed in any cases of ei) without a verb like ei)/ per a)na/gkh, if necessary. By ellipsis we often mean merely what one language finds it necessary to supply to translate an idiom of another. There are few ellipses of which a speaker is really conscious when he uses them. In this sense, it seems to me that, whenever we use if without a verb, there is at least a suppression (if not an ellipsis) of a verb. In Attic poetry we find ma/thr w(sei/ tis pista/, like some faithful mother, SOPH. El. 234; and ptu/sas w(sei/ te dusmenh=, spurning her as an enemy, Ant. 653.With Hom. Od. vii. 36 compare Hymn. Py. Ap. 8, pro\s *)/olumpon w(/ste no/hma ei)=si , and 270, e)pi\ nh=a no/hm' w(\s a)=lto pe/tesqai .

*)olofuro/menoi w(s ei) qanato/nde kio/nta, bewailing him as if going to his death (in full as if they were bewailing him going), for which we say (changing the construction) as if he were going. Il. xxiv. 328.See also Il. xvi. 192, Il. v. 374. *)amfi\ de\ kapno\s gi/gnetai e)c au)th=s w(s ei) puro\s ai)qome/noio, i.e. the smoke rises from it (the fountain) as if (it rose) from a blazing fire. Il. xxii. 150.So Od. xix. 39.What seems like a more natural construction with w(s ei) or w(s ei)/ te is that of the optative with the apodosis suppressed (485).
In all these cases there is also a suppression of the verb of the apodosis (see 485).
For the participle in such expressions see 867-869.
(*ei) mh/.) *ei) mh/ is used without a verb in various expressions to introduce an exception.

1. With nouns and adjectives. E.g. *ti/s ga/r toi *)axaiw=n a)/llos o(moi=os, ei) mh\ *pa/troklos; who is like to you, except (unless it be) Patroclus? Il. xvii. 475.See Il. xviii. 192, Il. xxiii. 792; Od. xii. 325, Od. xvii. 383.Such expressions are like the simple ei) to/ g' a)/meinon, if this is better, Il. i. 116; ei) e)teo/n per, Il. xiv. 125; ei)/ per a)na/gkh, Il. xxiv. 667.

2. With participles. E.g. *ei) mh\ krema/sas to\ no/hma, i.e. I could never have done it, except by suspending thought. AR. Nub. 229. So ou)de/n pot' ei) mh\ cunqanoume/nhn, AESCH. Ag. 1139; ei) mh\ katadu/santes, THUC. vii. 38; e)a\n mh\ th=s a)dei/as doqei/shs, DEM. xxiv. 46.

3. In the expression ei) mh\ dia\ tou=to (or tou=ton). E.g. *kai\ ei) mh\ dia\ to\n pru/tanin, e)ne/pesen a)/n, and, had it not been for the Prytanis, he would have been thrown in. PLAT. Gorg. 516E. (Compare dia/ ge u(ma=s, DEM. xviii. 49, quoted in 472.) *ou) ga\r w(s ei) mh\ dia\ *lakedaimoni/ous, ou)d' w(s ei) mh\ *pro/cenon ou)x u(pede/canto, ou)d' w(s ei) mh\ di) *(hgh/sippon, ou)d' w(s ei) mh\ dia\ to\ kai\ to\, e)sw/qhsan a)\n oi( *fwkei=s, ou)x ou(/tw to/te a)ph/ggeilen, for he did not then report that if it had not been for the Lacedaemonians, or if they had not refused to receive Proxenus, or if it had not been for Hegesippus, or if it had not been for this and that, the Phocians would have been saved. DEM. xix. 74.
4. In the rare expression ei) mh\ ei), except if, except in case that. E.g.

*(o xrhmatistiko\s th
 tou= tima=sqai h(donh
 h)\ th
 tou= manqa/nein ou)deno\s a)ci/an fh/sei ei)=nai, ei) mh\ ei)/ ti au)tw=n a)rgu/rion poiei=, the money-maker will say that the pleasure of receiving honour or that of learning is not worth anything, unless (it is worth something) in case either of them produces money. PLAT. Rep. 581D. In Prot. 351C, e)gw\ ga le/gw, kaq' o(\ h(de/a e)sti
, a)=ra kata\ tou=to ou)k a)gaqa\, mh\ ei)/ ti a)p' au)tw=n a)pobh/setai a)/llo;
—for I ask this: so far as they are pleasant, are they not just so far good, without taking into account any other result (i.e. other than their pleasantness) which may come from them?—mh/ is not a mistake for ei) mh/, but it seems to imply a conditional participle like u(pologizo/menos (though no precise word can be supplied), very much as mh\ o(/ti and mh\ o(/pws imply a verb of saying (707). The meaning clearly is, Are not things good just so far as they are pleasant, if we take no account of any other (i.e. unpleasant) element in them? This sense would hardly be found in the emended reading ei) mh/ ti. In THUC. i. 17 the Cod. Vat.reads ei) mh/ ti, although ei) mh\ ei)/ ti can be understood as in PLAT. Rep. 581 D (above).

Equivalent to ei) mh\ ei) (476, 4) is plh\n ei), except if or unless, in which plh/n represents the apodosis. E.g. *ou)de\ ta\ o)no/mata oi(=o/n te au)tw=n ei)de/nai, plh\n ei)/ tis kwmw|diopoio\s tugxa/nei w)/n, it is not possible to know even their names, except in case one happens to be a comedian. PLAT. Ap. 18 C.
