In alternatives, ei) de\ mh/, otherwise, regularly introduces the latter clause, even when the former clause is negative. *ei) de\ mh/ is much more common here than e)a\n de\ mh/, even when e)a\n me/n with the subjunctive precedes. The formula ei) de\ mh/ was fixed in the sense of otherwise, in the other case, and no definite form of the verb was in mind.

*pro\s tau=ta mh\ tu/pt': ei) de\ mh\, sauto/n pot' ai)tia/sei, therefore do not beat me; but if you do, you will have yourself to blame for it. AR. Nub. 1433.
*ei) mh\ qanou=mai/ g': ei) de\ mh\, ou) lei/yw pote/, if I do not die (I will leave the place); otherwise (if I die) I shall never leave it. And. 254.See SOPH. Tr. 587. *po/lemon ou)k ei)/wn poiei=n: ei) de\ mh\, kai\ au)toi\ a)nagkasqh/sesqai e)/fasan fi/lous poiei=sqai ou(\s ou) bou/lontai, they said that otherwise (ei) de\ mh/) they should be obliged, etc. THUC. i. 28. *ei)=pon (*pausani/a|) tou= kh/rukos mh\ lei/pesqai: ei) de\ mh\, po/lemon au)tw=| *spartia/tas proagoreu/ein, they ordered him not to be left behind by the herald: and if he should be (ei) de\ mh/), (they told him) that the Spartans declared war against him. Id. i. 131. *mh\ poih/sh|s tau=ta: ei) de\ mh\, ai)ti/an e(/ceis. XEN. An. vii. 1, 8. *)ea
 me/n ti u(mi=n dokw= a)lhqe\s le/gein, cunomologh/sate: ei) de\ mh\, panti\ lo/gw| a)ntitei/nete. PLAT. Phaed. 91 C. So e)a
 me
 pei/shte, . . . ei) de\ mh\, k.t.l., DEM. ix. 71.
*ei) de/ alone is sometimes used for ei) de\ mh/; as in Symp. 212C, ei) me\n bou/lei, . . . ei) de/. So ei) d' ou)=n (sc. mh/), SOPH. Ant. 722, EUR. Hipp. 508.
The potential optative and indicative with a)/n, so far as they are apodoses, might be classed here; but these have higher claims to be treated as independent sentences. See Chapter IV., Section I.

div2.head: Substitution and Ellipsis in Apodosis.
div2.p: The apodosis, in any of its forms, may be expressed by an infinitive or participle, if the structure of the sentence requires it.

1. It may be expressed by the infinitive or participle in indirect discourse, each tense representing its own tenses of the indicative or optative, the present including the imperfect, and the perfect the pluperfect. If the finite verb in the apodosis would have taken a)/n, this particle is used with the infinitive or participle. E.g. *(hgou=mai, ei) tou=to poiei=te, pa/nta kalw=s e)/xein, I believe that, if you are doing this, all is well. *(hgou=mai, e)a
 tou=to poih=te, pa/nta kalw=s e(/cein, I believe that, if you (shall) do this, all will be well. *(hgou=mai, ei) tou=to poioi=te, pa/nta kalw=s a)
 e)/xein, I believe that, if you should do this, all would be well. *(hgou=mai, ei) tou=to e)poih/sate, pa/nta kalw=s a)
 e)/xein, I believe that, if you had done this, all would now be (or would have been) well. *oi)=da u(ma=s, e)a
 tou=to poih=te, eu)= pra/contas, I know that, if you do this, you will prosper.

*pw=s ga\r oi)/esqe dusxerw=s a)kou/ein *)olunqi/ous, ei)/ ti/s ti le/goi kata\ *fili/ppou kat' e)kei/nous tou\s xro/nous; how unwillingly do you think the O. heard it, if any one said anything against Philip in those times? DEM. vi. 20. (Here a)kou/ein represents the imperfect h)/kouon, and ei) le/goi is a general supposition, 462.)
For examples of each tense of the infinitive and participle, see 689. For the use of each tense of the infinitive or participle with a)/n and examples, see 204-208; 213-216.

2. It may be expressed by the infinitive in any of its various constructions out of indirect discourse, especially by one depending on a verb of wishing, commanding, advising, preparing, etc., from which the infinitive receives a future meaning. Such an infinitive is a common form of future apodosis with a protasis in the subjunctive or indicative. E.g. *bou/letai e)lqei=n e)a\n tou=to ge/nhtai, he wishes to go if this shall be done. *paraskeuazo/meqa a)pelqei=n h)\n dunw/meqa, we are preparing to depart if we shall be able. *keleu/ei se a)pelqei=n ei) bou/lei, he bids you depart if you please. (See 403 and 445.)

3. The apodosis may be expressed in an attributive or circumstantial participle. E.g. *(ra|di/ws a)\n a)feqei\s ei) kai\ metri/ws ti tou/twn e)poi/hse, proei/leto a)poqanei=n, whereas he might easily have been acquitted (a)fei/qh a)/n), if he had done any of these things even in a moderate degree, he chose to die. XEN. Mem. iv. 4, 4 *ske/mmata tw=n r(a|di/ws a)poktinnu/ntwn kai\ a)nabiwskome/nwn g' a)\n, ei) oi(=oi/ te h)=san, considerations for those who readily put men to death, and who would bring them to life again too if they could. PLAT. Crit. 48C. (*)anabiwskome/nwn a)/n = a)nebiw/skonto a)/n.) *(ws oi(=o/s t' w)/n se sw/|zein ei) h)/qelon a)nali/skein xrh/mata, whereas I might have saved you if I had been willing to spend money. Ib. 44B.

A verbal noun may take the place of an apodosis. E.g. *(ws o)/nt' a)nasthth=ra *kadmei/wn xqono\s ei) mh\ qew=n tis e)mpodw\n e)/sth dori/, as one who would have laid waste (= a)ne/sthsen a)/n) the Cadmeans' land, if some one of the Gods had not stood in the way of his spear. Sept. 1015.
Other forms in which an apodosis may appear, as a final clause, need no discussion. (See 445.)
In indirect discourse, after past tenses, an optative in the apodosis often represents an original indicative or subjunctive. (See 15 and 457.)

The apodosis is sometimes omitted, when some such expression as it is well or it will be done can be supplied, or when some other apodosis is at once suggested by the context. E.g. *)all' ei) me
 dw/sousi ge/ras mega/qumoi *)axaioi\, a)/rsantes kata\ qumo
, o(/pws a)nta/cion e)/stai,— ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/wsin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, if they give me a prize,—well; but if they do not, I shall take one for myself. Il. i. 135. (Here we must understand something like eu)= e(/cei, it will be well, after e)/stai.) *ei)/ per ga/r k' e)qe/lh|sin *)olu/mpios a)sterophth\s e)c e(de/wn stufeli/cai:— o( ga polu\ fe/rtato/s e)stin. Il. i. 580. (Here we must understand he can do it after the protasis. The following ga/r refers to this suppressed apodosis.) *ei) me
 e)gw\ u(ma=s i(kanw=s dida/skw oi(/ous dei= pro\s a)llh/lous ei)=nai:—ei) de\ mh\, kai\ para\ tw=n progegenhme/nwn manqa/nete. XEN. Cyr. viii. 7, 24.

*cei=noi patrw/ioi eu)xo/meq' ei)=nai, ei)/ pe/r te ge/ront' ei)/rhai e)pelqw\n *lae/rthn, we boast that we are friends by inheritance, (as you may know) if you go and ask Laertes. Od. i. 187.
*proshgoreu/qhs h( *dio\s kleinh\ da/mar me/llous' e)/sesq', ei)/ tw=nde prossai/nei se/ ti AESCH. Prom. 834 .

Sometimes the adverb a)/n, without a verb expressed, represents an apodosis in the indicative or optative, when the verb can easily be supplied. E.g. *oi( oi)ke/tai r(e/gkousin: a)ll' ou)k a)\n pro\ tou= (sc. ou(/tws e)/rregkon), but they would not have been snoring at this late hour in old times. AR. Nub. 5. (See 227.) So pw=s ga\r a)/n; (sc. ei)/h), how could it be?

In w(/sper a)\n ei) with a noun, as w(/sper a)\n ei) pai=s, like a child, there is originally a suppression of the verbs of both protasis and apodosis (227; 485); but in use the expression hardly differs from w(/sper. (See 868-870.)

(*(ws ei), and w(/sper ei).) There is an unconscious suppression of the verb of the apodosis when w(s ei), w(s ei)/ te, and w(/sper ei) are used in similes and comparisons. E.g. *laoi\ e(/ponq), w(s ei)/ te meta\ kti/lon e(/speto mh=la, the hosts followed as if sheep followed a ram. Il. xiii. 492. (No definite verb is understood here, either with w(s in Greek or with as in English, but the origin of the expression is the same in both.) *fia/lan w(s ei)/ tis dwrh/setai. PIND. Ol. vii. 1. *kai/ me fi/lhs' w(s ei)/ te path\r o(\n pai=da filh/sh|. Il. ix. 481. *oi( d' a)/r' i)/san w(s ei)/ te puri\ xqw\n pa=sa ne/moito, i.e. their march was as if the whole land should flame with fire (originally as it would be if, etc.) Il. ii. 780. *bh= d' i)/men, pa/ntose xei=r' o)re/gwn w(s ei) ptwxo\s pa/lai ei)/h, holding out his hand as if he had long been a beggar (438). Od. xvii. 366.For other optatives with w(s ei), see Il. xi. 467, Il. xxii. 410; Od. ix. 314, Od. x. 416, Od. 420.

p.quote: as if you had dwelt near by.
p.foreign: *(/omoia w(/sper ei)/ tis polla\ e)sqi/wn mhde/pote e)mpi/plaito,
p.quote: just as if one should eat much and never be filled.

div2.p: There is the same suppression of the apodosis in the examples in 475, where the protasis also is wanting with w(s ei) and similar expressions.

div2.head: Apodosis contained in the Protasis.
div2.p: A protasis may depend on a verb which is not its apodosis, the real apodosis being so distinctly implied in the form of expression that it need not be stated separately.

1. This is found especially in Homer, where ei)/ ke (ai)/ ke) or h)/n (without an expressed apodosis) often seems to have the force of in the hope that; as in patro\s e)mou= kle/os mete/rxomai, h)/n pou a)kou/sw, I am going to seek tidings of my father, if I shall chance to hear of him, i.e. that I may hear of him if perchance I shall, or in the hope that I shall hear of him ( Od. iii. 83). Here the protasis carries with it its own apodosis, which consists of an implied idea of purpose.The English translation of certain conditional clauses in the New Testament which have this peculiar construction preserves the sense of purpose or desire with the original form of protasis. Thus, that they should seek the Lord, if haply they might feel after him and find him, Acts xvii. 27; and he came (to the fig tree), if haply he might find anything thereon, MARK xi. 13. The whole sentence (both protasis and apodosis) is thus condensed into the protasis; but the apodosis is always felt in the implied idea of purpose or desire which is inherent in the idiom. As we have seen (312, Od. 2) that final clauses with a)/n or ke/ and the subjunctive originally included both a conditional relative clause and a final sentence, so here we have both a conditional and a final force included under a single conditional form; and this double force is felt also in the English translation, if haply, in the hope that, in case that, etc. E.g. *au)ta soi\ pukinw=s u(poqh/someq), ai)/ ke pi/qhai, but we will make you a wise suggestion, for you to obey it if you will. Il. xxi. 293. (Here the protasis ai)/ ke pi/qhai with its implied apodosis seems like pei/qoi) a)
 ei) pei/qoi), you can obey if you please, AESCH. Ag. 1049, and xai/roit' a)
 ei) xai/roit), Ib. 1394.) So Il. i. 207, Il. 420, Il. xi. 791, Il. xxiii. 82; Od. i. 279. *pe/myw d' e)s *spa/rthn . . . no/ston peuso/menon patro\s fi/lou, h)/n pou a)kou/sh|, h)d' i(/na min kle/os e)/xh|sin, I will send him to Sparta, to ask about his father's return, in hope that he may hear of it, and in order that glory may possess him. Od. i. 93. (Here the added final clause shows the distinction between this and the protasis h)/n pou a)kou/sh|.) So Od. i. 281, Od. ii. 216, Od. 360, Od. iii. 83. *ei)pe/ moi, ai)/ ke/ poqi gnw/w toiou=ton e)o/nta, if haply I may recognise him. Od. xiv. 118. *ba/ll' ou(/tws, ai)/ ke/n ti fo/ws *danaoi=si ge/nhai, if haply you may become (i.e. in hope that you may become), etc. Il. viii. 282.So Il. xi. 797, Il. 799, Il. xiii. 236, Il. xiv. 78, Il. xvi. 39, Il. 41 (cf. 84), Il. xvii. 121, 692, Il. xviii. 199. *kai/ oi( u(posxe/sqai duokai/deka bou=s i(ereuse/men, ai)/ k' e)leh/sh| a)/stu, . . . ai)/ ken *tude/os ui(o
 a)po/sxh| *)ili/ou i(rh=s, let her promise to sacrifice twelve oxen (to Athena), in hope that she may pity the city, . . . if haply she may keep the son of Tydeus from sacred Ilios, etc. Il. vi. 93. (For ai)/ ken a)po/sxh| Aristarchus read w(/s ken.) *eu)fhmh=sai/ te ke/lesqe, o)/fra *dii\ *kroni/dh| a)rh/someq), ai)/ k' e)leh/sh|, in order that we may pray to Zeus to pity us if he will (if haply he shall pity us). Il. ix. 171.So Il. vi. 281, Il. 309, Il. xvii. 245, Il. xxii. 419, Il. xxiv. 116, Il. 301, Il. 357; Od. xiii. 182.See also ei)/ ke/n pws bou/letai loigo
 a)mu=nai, Il. i. 66. *patro/klw| e)/fepe kraterw/nuxas i(/ppous, ai)/ ke/n pw/s min e(/lh|s, dw/h| de/ toi eu)=xos *)apo/llwn. Il. xvi. 724.So Il. xv. 297; Od. xxii. 76. *deu=r' i(ko/meq), ai)/ ke/ poqi *zeu\s e)copi/sw per pau/sh| o)izu/os. Od. iv. 34.So Od. i. 379, Od. ii. 144, Od. xii. 215, Od. xvii. 51, Od. 60, Od. xxii. 252. *ektoros o)/rswmen kratero
 me/nos, h)/n tina/ pou *danaw=n prokale/ssetai. Il. vii. 39. *(uyo/se d' au)gh\ gi/gnetai a)i/ssousa periktio/nessi i)de/sqai, ai)/ ke/n pws su
 nhusi
 a)rh=s a)lkth=res i(/kwntai. Il. xviii. 211. *ei) de/ k' e)/ti prote/rw paranh/comai, h)/n pou e)feu/rw h)io/nas, dei/dw, k.t.l., but if I shall swim on still farther, to find a shore if haply I may, I fear, etc. Od. v. 417. (Here h)/n pou e)feu/rw depends on an ordinary protasis, which, however, is not its apodosis.) *)all' a)/get), ai)/ ke/n pws qwrh/comen ui(=as *)axaiw=n, i.e. let us arm them if we can. Il. ii. 72 (so 83). *ske/pteo nu=n, ai)/ ke i)/dhai zwo
 e)/t' *)anti/loxon, if haply you may see. Il. xvii. 652. *sw=| oi)/kw| dw=ron potide/gmenos, ai)/ ke po/rh|sin, expecting a gift, if haply he shall give one (i.e. in hope that he will give one). Od. ii. 186.So Od. xv. 312. *)all' ou) ga/r s' e)qe/lw bale/ein toiou=ton e)o/nta la/qrh| o)pipeu/sas, a)ll' a)mfado
, ei)/ ke tu/xwmi, if haply I may hit you. Il. vii. 242. *nu=n au)=t' e)gxei/h| peirh/somai, ai)/ ke tu/xwmi, I will try with my spear, if haply I may hit you. Il. v. 279. *(ws o(/te tis troxo
 kerameu\s peirh/setai, ai)/ ke qe/h|sin, i.e. tries a wheel, in case it will run (i.e. to let it run if it will). Il. xviii. 600. (The analogy of the two preceding examples shows that there is no indirect question.)

*pare/zeo kai\ labe\ gou/nwn, ai)/ ke/n pws e)qe/lh|sin e)pi\ *trw/essin a)rh=cai, i.e. clasp his knees in the hope that he will aid the Trojans (that he may aid them in case he will). Il. i. 407.So Il. vii. 394, Il. x. 55, Il. xiii. 743, Il. xviii. 457; Od. iii. 92, Od. iv. 322.For these last examples, see 490, Od. 2.
For ai)/ ke in the common text of Homer, here as elsewhere, Bekker and Delbrück write ei)/ ke (see footnote to 379).

2. In alternatives with two opposite suppositions, this construction implies that the subject is ready for either result, though the former is hoped for or expected. E.g. *)iqu\s fe/retai me/nei, h)/n tina pe/fnh| a)ndrw=n h)\ au)to\s fqi/etai prw/tw| e)n o(mi/lw|, i.e. he (a lion) rushes on, ready to slay or to perish. Il. xx. 172.In Od. xxiv. 216, the common text has patro\s peirh/somai, ai)/ ke (or ei)/ ke) m' e)pignw/h| . . . h)=e/ ken a)gnoih=|si, I will try my father (ready for either result), in case he shall recognise me or shall not know me (where ke/n alone in the second clause is very strange). But La Roche reads h)/ ke/ m' e)pignw/h|, as an indirect question, one MS. having h)/ ke: see also Od. xviii. 265. *)epignw/h| is Hermann's conjecture for e)pignoi/h or gnoi/h.

The optative with ei) (rarely ei)/ ke) is sometimes used in Homer like the subjunctive after primary tenses in sentences of this class. It is also very common after past tenses, representing a subjunctive of the original form, though occasionally the subjunctive is retained in indirect discourse (696). E.g. *)all' e)/ti to\n du/sthnon o)i/omai, ei)/ poqen e)lqw\n a)ndrw=n mnhsth/rwn ske/dasin kata\ dw/mata qei/h, but I am still expecting the poor man, if haply he should come and scatter the suitors. Od. xx. 224.So Od. ii. 351. *)alla/ tis ei)/h *)agame/mnoni, ei) plei/onas para\ nau=fin e)potru/neie ne/esqai, let some one go to A. , in hope that he may exhort, etc. Hom. Od. xiv. 496.See also 491, below.

*bou/leuon o(/pws o)/x' a)/rista ge/noito, ei)/ tin' e(tai/roisin qana/tou lu/sin eu(roi/mhn, i.e. if haply I might find some escape. Od. ix. 420. *)all' e)gw\ ou) piqo/mhn, o)/fr' au)to/n te i)/doimi kai\ ei)/ moi cei/nia doi/h, but I disobeyed them, in order that I might see him (the Cyclops) and in hope that he would show me hospitality. Od. ix. 228. (The final clause and the protasis are here again clearly distinguished: see Od. i. 93 under 487, Od. 1.) *polla\ de/ t' a)/gke) e)ph=lqe met' a)ne/ros i)/xni) e)reunw=n, ei)/ poqen e)ceu/roi. Il. xviii. 321. *peirh/qh de\ eu(= au)tou= e)n e)/ntesi, ei) oi( e)farmo/sseie kai\ e)ntre/xoi a)/glaa gui=a, i.e. he tried himself in his armour, eager for it to fit him and for his limbs to play freely in it (if haply it should fit him, etc.). Il. xix. 384. (See the cases of the subjunctive after peirw=mai in 487, Il. 1.Here there is no indirect question, for Achilles can have no real doubt about the fit.) *)en de\ pi/qoi oi)/noio e(/stasan, ei)/ pot' *)odusseu\s oi)/kade nosth/seie, i.e. the casks of wine were waiting for the return of Ulysses. Od. ii. 340. *(=hsto ka/tw o(ro/wn, potide/gmenos ei)/ ti/ min ei)/poi, i.e. he sat looking down, waiting for Penelope to speak. Od. xxiii. 91. *to/d' h)nw/gei ei)pei=n e)/pos, ei)/ k' e)qe/lhte pau/sasqai pole/mou, he bade me say this word, if haply you might be willing to stop the war. Il. vii. 394. (This appears in vs. 387 as ei)/ ke ge/noito, and the direct form of the command in vs. 375 is ei)/ k' e)qe/lwsin.) In Il. xiv. 163-165 we have ei)/ pws i(mei/raito . . . tw=| de\ xeu/h| after a past tense. *nh=xe pare\c, ei)/ pou e)feu/roi h)io/nas. Od. v. 439. (Compare vs. 417, ei) de/ ke paranh/comai, h)/n pou e)feu/rw, under 487, Od. 1.)

See also Il. ii. 97, Il. iii. 450, Il. iv. 88, Il. x. 19, Il. xii. 122, Il. 333, Il. xiii. 807, Il. xx. 464, Il. xxiii. 40; Od. i. 115, Od. iv. 317, Od. ix. 267, Od. 317, Od. 418, Od. x. 147, Od. xi. 479, Od. 628, Od. xii. 334, Od. xiv. 460, Od. xxii. 91, Od. 381.

This construction (487; 488) with both subjunctive and optative is found also in Attic Greek and in Herodotus, but with less variety of expression, and at the same time with some extension of the usage. Especially to be noticed are the protases depending on verbs like bou/lomai and qe/lw in Herodotus. E.g. *qh/bas h(ma=s pe/myon, e)a/n pws diakwlu/swmen i)o/nta fo/non toi=sin o(mai/mois, send us to Thebes, to prevent, if haply we may, etc. SOPH. O.C. 1769.
*th=s e)mh=s gnw/mhs a)/kouson, h)/n ti/ soi dokw= le/gein, hear my judgment, in the hope that you may think there is something in what I say. EUR. H.F. 278.
*)ede/onto tou= *)aristago/rew, ei)/ kws au)toi=si para/sxoi du/nami/n tina kai\ kate/lqoien e)s th
 e(wutw=n, they besought A. , if in any way he might supply them with an armed force and they might be restored to their own land (to do this). HDT. v. 30. *fronh/santes ei)/ kws e(
 ge/noito to\ *(ellhniko/n, having it at heart that, if it were in any way possible, the Hellenic race should be made one. Id. vii. 145. *boulome/nhn ei)/ kws a)mfo/teroi genoi/ato basile/es, i.e. wishing that both might be made kings, if in any way this could be done. Id. vi. 52. *)ebouleu/eto qe/lwn ei)/ kws tou/tous prw/tous e(/loi. Id. ix. 14. *pro/qumoi h)=san e)pixeire/ein (sc. th=|si nhusi\), ei)/ kws e(/loien au)ta/s. Id. viii. 6. *pe/myantes par' *)aqhnai/ous pre/sbeis, ei)/ pws pei/seian mh\ sfw=n pe/ri newteri/zein mhde/n, to persuade them if they might, etc. THUC. i. 58. *poreuo/menoi e)s th
 *)asi/an w(s basile/a, ei)/ pws pei/seian au)to/n, followed by boulo/menoi pei=sai au)to
, ei) du/nainto, strateu=sai, in nearly the same sense. Id. ii. 67. *punqano/menoi tou\s *)aqhnai/ous e)s th
 *kama/rinan presbeu/esqai, ei)/ pws prosaga/gointo au)tou/s, that they went on an embassy to C., to bring the town over if they could. Id. vi. 75. (Compare e)s *)akra/ganta *sikano
 a)pe/steilan, o(/pws u(paga/goito th
 po/lin ei) du/naito, Id. vii. 46.This might have been ei)/ pws u(paga/goito th
 po/lin, and in vi. 75 we might have had o(/pws prosaga/gointo au)tou\s ei) du/nainto, with nearly the same force, but with different constructions.) See v. 4, ei)/ pws . . . diasw/seian. *(ike/tai pro\s se\ deu=r' a)fi/gmeqa, ei)/ tina po/lin fra/seias h(mi=n eu)/eron, we have come hither to you as suppliants, in the hope that you might tell us of some city soft as a fleece (to have you tell us, if perchance you might do so). AR. Av. 120. *)/akouson kai\ e)mou=, e)a/n soi tau)ta\ dokh=|, listen to me too, in the hope that you may think the same (in case the same shall seem true to you). PLAT. Rep. 358 B: so 434 A. *(/ora ou)=n kai\ proqumou= katidei=n, e)a/n pws pro/teros e)mou= i)/dh|s kai\ e)moi\ fra/sh|s, i.e. for the chance that you may see it first and tell me. Ib. 432C: so 618 C, Theaet. 192C, Soph. 226 C.. See also XEN. An. ii. 1, 8 , a)/n ti du/nwntai, and AR. Nub. 535. On this principle we must explain AR. Ran. 339, ou)/koun a)tre/m' e(/ceis, h)/n ti kai\ xordh=s la/bh|s , will you not keep quiet then, in the hope of getting some sausage too? (i.e. to have some sausage if you chance to get any)

1. The apodosis may, further, be suggested by the context, even by the protasis itself, without implying that the protasis expresses a purpose or desire of the leading subject. This gives rise to a variety of constructions. E.g. *ktanei=n e)moi/ nin e)/dosan, ei)/te mh\ ktanw
 qe/loim' a)/gesqai pa/lin e)s *)argei/an xqo/na, they gave her (Helen) to me to slay, or, in case I should prefer not to slay her but to carry her back to the land of Argos (for me to do this). EUR. Tro. 874. *(/hn (th
 cummaxi/an) ge ou)k e)pi\ toi=s fi/lois e)poih/sasqe, tw=n de\ e)xqrw=n h)/n tis e)f' u(ma=s i)/h|, i.e. you made it (to use) in case any of your enemies should come against you. THUC. vi. 79. *pro\s th
 po/lin, ei) e)pibohqoi=en, e)xw/roun, they marched towards the city, (to be ready) in case the citizens should rush out. Id. vi. 100. *ta)/lla, h)
 e)/ti naumaxei=n oi( *)aqhnai=oi tolmh/swsi, pareskeua/zonto, they made other preparations, (to be ready) in case the Athenians should venture on further sea-fights. Id. vii. 59. *kh/rugma poiou=ntai . . . tw=n nhsiwtw=n ei)/ tis bou/letai e)p' e)leuqeri/a| w(s sfa=s a)pie/nai, they make proclamation, in case any of the islanders wishes to come over to them with promise of freedom (for him to do so). Id. vii. 82. *ou)demi/a bla/bh tw=n pro\s ta\s po/leis diapompw=n e)/s te kataskoph
 kai\ h)/n ti a)/llo fai/nhtai e)pith/deion, there is no harm in the envoys whom we have sent to the various cities, partly for inquiry, and also in case any other advantage may appear (to secure this), i.e. to secure any other advantage that may appear. Id. vi. 41.So kai\ ei)/ tina pro\s a)/llon de/oi, Id. v. 37. *)ara\s poiou=ntai, ei)/ tis e)pikhrukeu/etai *pe/rsais, they invoke curses, if any one (i.e. to fall on any one who) sends heralds to the Persians. ISOC. iv. 157. *filotimei=sqai mhd' e(ni\ e)f' a)/llw| h)\ e)pi\ xrhma/twn kth/sei kai\ e)a/n ti a)/llo ei)s tou=to fe/rh|, i.e. for anything else that may lead to this. PLAT. Rep. 553D See ARISTOT. Eth. x. 9, 2: e)/xein (th
 a)reth
) kai\ xrh=sqai peirate/on, h)\ ei)/ pws a)/llws a)gaqoi\ gino/meqa , we must try to possess and employ virtue, or if there is any other means of becoming virtuous (to use this).

2. In the Homeric examples in which the protasis consists of an infinitive depending on e)qe/lw (487, 1, end), the apodosis is suggested by the infinitive rather than by e)qe/lw. This shows that ai)/ k e)qe/lh|si, in itself has no final force. See also Od. xxii. 381, pa/pthnen d' *)oduseu\s kat' e(o\n do/mon, ei)/ tis e)/t' a)ndrw=n zwo\s u(poklope/oito a)lu/skwn kh=ra me/lainan, he peered through his house, in case any man might still be alive and hiding himself (i.e. to find any such man), where no desire or hope is implied, and the construction is like that of THUC. vi. 100 (above).

In PLAT. Rep. 327 C, ou)kou=n e)/ti e)llei/petai to\ h)\n pei/swmen u(ma=s w(s xrh\ h(ma=s a)fei=nai; the subject of e)llei/petai is a protasis introduced by to/, into which the apodosis has been wholly absorbed. The construction is, is there not still left the supposition of our persuading you that you must let us go? But the meaning is, is it not left for us to persuade you that you must let us go, if we can (i.e. pei=sai h)\n pei/swmen)? This is an important example for explaining this whole class of sentences (486-490). The cases in 490 make it plain that the final force often ascribed to ei) or h)/n comes from the suppression of an apodosis containing the idea of purpose or desire, since the same form of protasis which is sometimes called final has no final force when a slightly different apodosis is implied (as in THUC. vi. 79, THUC. 100, THUC. vii. 59).

Sometimes a clause with ei)/ ke or h)/n (rarely ei)) and the subjunctive, or with ei)/ ke or ei) and the optative, in Homer is the object of oi)=da, ei)=don, or a verb of saying, expressing in a conditional form a result which is hoped for or desired. These clauses have the appearance of indirect questions; but the analogy of the preceding examples (487-490) shows that all are based on the same idiom,—a protasis which involves its own apodosis so that it would be useless to express the latter separately. The examples are these:—

*ti/s oi)=d' ei)/ ke kai\ au)to\s i)w
 koi/lhs e)pi\ nho\s th=le fi/lwn a)po/lhtai, who knows the chances that he too may perish, etc.? or who knows the chances of his perishing, etc., if haply he may? Od. ii. 332. (We may translate colloquially: who knows? supposing he too shall perish?) *ti/s oi)=d' ei)/ k' *)axileu\s fqh/h| e)mw=| u(po\ douri\ tupei\s a)po\ qumo
 o)le/ssai; who knows the chances that Achilles may first be struck (the chances of his being first struck, if haply he shall be)? Il. xvi. 860. (We should naturally express this by a different construction, whether he may not be first struck.) *ti/s oi)=d' ei)/ ke/n oi( su
 dai/moni qumo
 o)ri/nw pareipw/n; who knows the chances of my rousing his spirit by persuasion, if haply I shall do so? Il. xv. 403.In Il. xi. 792 we have Nestor 's advice to Patroclus, ti/s oi)=d' ei)/ ke/n oi( su
 dai/moni qumo
 o)ri/nais pareipw/n; who knows the chances that you could rouse his spirit by persuasion? (o)ri/nais ke being potential). *ou) mh
 oi)=d' ei) au)=te kakorrafi/hs a)legeinh=s prw/th e)pau/rhai kai/ se plhgh=|sin i(ma/ssw, I am not sure of the chances of your being the first to enjoy your own device, etc., i.e. I am not so sure that you may not be the first to enjoy it, if it shall so chance. Il. xv. 16. *zeu\s ga/r pou to/ ge oi)=de kai\ a)qa/natoi qeoi\ a)/lloi, ei)/ ke/ min a)ggei/laimi i)dw/n: e)pi\ polla\ d' a)lh/qhn, Zeus and the other immortals (alone) know this, the chance of my bringing news of him, if haply I have seen him and so might do this. Od. xiv. 119. *ei) d' a)/ge dh/ moi tou=to, qea\, nhmerte\s e)ni/spes, ei)/ pws th
 o)loh
 me
 u(pekprofu/goimi *xa/rubdin, th
 de/ k' a)munai/mhn o(/te moi si/noito g' e(tai/rous, i.e. tell me this without fault, the chance of my escaping Charybdis if haply I should do this, and of my then keeping Scylla off if I could (lit. tell me this, supposing I should escape Charybdis and could then keep Scylla off). Od. xii. 112 (this translation supposes k' to be potential, affecting only a)munai/mhn).

*)=h me/nete *trw=as sxedo\n e)lqe/men, o)/fra i)/dht' ai)/ k' u)/mmin u(pe/rsxh| xei=ra *kroni/wn; are you waiting for the Trojans to come near, that you may see the chances of the son of Cronos holding his hand over you?—or that you may see him hold his hand over you, if haply he may do this? Il. iv. 247. (We might say, is it that you may see it,—supposing the son of Cronos to hold his hand over you?) *tw=n s' au)=tis mnh/sw, i(/n) a)pollh/ch|s a)pata/wn, o)/fr) i)/dh|s h)/n toi xrai/smh| filo/ths te kai\ eu)nh/, i.e. that you may see the chances of your device availing you, or that you may see it if perchance your device shall avail you. Il. xv. 31.

See also Il. xx. 435, a)ll' h)= toi me
 tau=ta qew=n e)n gou/nasi kei=tai, ai)/ ke/ se xeiro/tero/s per e)w
 a)po\ qumo
 e(/lwmai, i.e. this rests with the Gods, for me to take your life away, weaker though I am, if perchance I may. The conditional construction is more obvious here than in Il. iv. 247 and xv. 31; but in all three we naturally fall into an indirect question when we attempt to express the thought in English.

A comparison of these peculiar conditional constructions (491) expressing hope or desire with clauses with mh/ expressing anxiety and desire to prevent a result, both depending on oi)=da or ei)=don, is suggestive. With Od. ii. 332 and Il. xvi. 860 (in 491) compare Il. x. 100, ou)de/ ti i)/dmen, mh/ pws kai\ dia\ nu/kta menoinh/swsi ma/xesqai, nor do we know any way to prevent their being impelled, etc., and PLAT. Phaed. 91 D (quoted in 366); and with Il. iv. 247 and xv. 31 (491) compare Od. xxiv. 491, i)/doi mh\ dh\ sxedo\n w)=si kio/ntes (366). This comparison shows that ei)de/nai (or i)dei=n) ei)/ ke tou=to ge/nhtai means to know (or see) the chances of gaining this (object of desire); while ei)de/nai (or i)dei=n) mh\ tou=to ge/nhtai means to know (or see) some way to prevent this (object of fear). The idea of desire or anxiety belongs to the dependent clause, and not at all to the leading verb.

These Homeric expressions (491), in which nearly all the force is in the protasis, so that the apodosis is not only suppressed but hardly felt at all, helps to show how the particle ei) came to be an indirect interrogative, in the sense of whether. But in Attic Greek, where the interrogative use is fully established, only the simple ei) (never h)/n or e)a/n) can mean whether, even when the verb is subjunctive (680).

div2.head: ei) after Expressions of Wonder, Indignation, etc.
div2.p: After many expressions of wonder, delight, contentment, indignation, disappointment, pity, and similar emotions, a protasis with ei) may be used to express the object of the emotion. When the supposition of the protasis is present or past, a causal sentence would generally seem more natural. Such expressions are especially qauma/zw, ai)sxu/nomai, a)gapw=, a)ganaktw=, and deino/n e)stin. E.g. *qauma/zw d' e)/gwge ei) mhdei\s u(mw=n mh/t' e)nqumei=tai mh/t' o)rgi/zetai, o(rw=n, k.t.l., I wonder that no one of you is either concerned or angry, when he sees, etc. (lit. if no one is either concerned or angry, I wonder). DEM. iv. 43. *)all' e)kei=no qauma/zw, ei) *lakedaimoni/ois me/n pote a)nth/rate, nuni\ d' o)knei=te e)cie/nai kai\ me/llete ei)sfe/rein, but I wonder at this, that you once opposed the Lacedaemonians, but now are unwilling, etc. Id. ii. 24. (The literal meaning is, if (it is true that) you once opposed, etc., then I wonder.) *ou)k a)gapa=| ei) mh\ di/khn de/dwken, a)ll' ei) mh\ kai\ xrusw=| stefa/nw| stefanwqh/setai a)ganaktei=, he is not content if he has not been punished; but if he is not also to be crowned with a golden crown, he is indignant. AESCHIN. iii. 147. *kai\ w(s a)lhqw=s a)ganaktw=, ei) ou(twsi\ a(\ now= mh\ oi(=o/s t' ei)mi\ ei)pei=n, I am indignant that (or if) I am not able, etc. PLAT. Lach. 194A. *ou) dh\ qaumasto/n e)stin, ei) strateuo/menos kai\ ponw=n e)kei=nos au)to\s u(mw=n mello/ntwn kai\ yhfizome/nwn kai\ punqanome/nwn perigi/gnetai, it is no wonder that he gets the advantage of you, etc. DEM. ii. 23. *mhde\ me/ntoi tou=to mei=on do/chte e)/xein, ei) oi( *kurei=oi pro/sqen su\n h(mi=n tatto/menoi nu=n a)festh/kasin, i.e. do not be discontented, if (or that) the Cyraeans have now withdrawn. XEN. An. iii. 2, 17. *ai)nw= se, ei) ktenei=s da/marta sh/n. EUR. Tro. 890.

*deino
 a)
 ei)/h prh=gma, ei) *sa/kas me
 dou/lous e)/xomen, *(/ellhnas de\ ou) timwrhso/meqa. HDT. vii. 9. *ai)sxro/n e)stin, ei) e)gw\ me
 ta\ e)/rga u(pe/meina, u(mei=s de\ mhde\ tou\s lo/gous a)ne/cesqe. DEM. xviii. 160. *deino
 a)
 ei)/h, ei) oi( me
 e)kei/nwn cu/mmaxoi ou)k a)perou=sin, h(mei=s de\ ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen. THUC. i. 121. *te/ras le/geis, ei) . . . ou)k a)
 du/nainto laqei=n. PLAT. Men. 91 D (see 506). *deino
 ei) oi( au)toi\ ma/rtures tou/tois me
 a)
 marturou=ntes pistoi\ h)=san, e)moi\ de\ marturou=ntes a)/pistoi e)/sontai, it is hard that the same witnesses testifying for them would have been trustworthy, and testifying for me are to be untrustworthy. ANT. vi. 29.See AESCHIN. i. 85.
In all the preceding examples the protasis belongs under 402, the futures expressing present suppositions (407). For ei) ou) see 386 and 387, with examples.

The same construction is sometimes used when the leading verb is past. E.g. *kateme/mfeto au(to\n kai\ tou\s su\n au(tw=|, ei) oi( a)/lloi a)kma/zein ma=llon e(autw=n e)do/koun. XEN. Cyr. iv. 3, 3. But generally such sentences are affected by the principle of indirect discourse, and have either the optative or the form of the direct discourse: see XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 3 , h)xqe/sqhn ei)/ ti mei=on dokoi=en e)/xein (where dokou=si might have been used). See EUR. Med. 931, ei)sh=lqe/ m' oi)=ktos, ei) genh/setai, and XEN. An. i. 4, 7 , w)/|kteiron ei) a(lw/sointo. For such sentences see 697.

These expressions may also be followed by o(/ti and a causal sentence, as in PLAt. Theaet. 142A, e)qau/mazon o(/ti ou)x oi(=o/s t' h)= eu(rei=n. The construction with ei) gives a milder or more polite form of expression, putting the object of the wonder etc. into the form of a supposition, instead of stating it as a fact as we should do in English. They may also be followed by protases expressing ordinary conditions, which have nothing peculiar: see ISOC. xv. 17, a)gaphto\n (sc. e)sti/n) h)\n e)klabei=n dunhqw=si to\ di/kaion, they must be content if they are able (cf. xix. 20); and PLAT. Prot. 315 E, DEM. ii. 23 (ei) perih=men).
This construction must not be mistaken for that in which ei) is used in the sense of whether, to introduce an indirect question; as h)rw/twn ei) h)=lqen, I asked whether he had come.

div2.head: Mixed Constructions.
div2.p: The forms of protasis and apodosis which are contained in the classification above (388-397) include by far the greater number of the examples found in the classic authors. Many cases remain, however, in which the protasis and apodosis do not belong to the same form. Especially, the great wealth of conditional expressions which the Homeric language exhibits in both protasis and apodosis (399) allowed great variety of combination; and the early poets used much greater freedom in these sentences than suited the more exact style of Attic prose.

div2.head: I. Optative in Protasis, with Future or Present Indicative or an equivalent form in Apodosis.
div2.p: (a) In the earlier language a protasis with the optative is not infrequently followed by an apodosis with the future indicative or imperative or (in Homer) with the subjunctive. The subjunctive or future indicative in Homer may also take ke/ or a)/n (452). E.g. *ei)/ ti/s moi a)nh\r a(/m' e(/poito kai\ a)/llos, ma=llon qalpwrh\ kai\ qarsalew/teron e)/stai, if any other man should follow with me, there will be more comfort and greater courage. Il. x. 222. (The want of symmetry in the Greek is here precisely what it is in the English; and ei)/h a)/n is no more required in the apodosis than would be is, though both are the conventional forms.) See Il. ix. 388, and xxiii. 893, po/rwmen, ei) e)qe/lois. *to/n g' ei)/ pws su\ du/naio loxhsa/menos lelabe/sqai, o(/s ke/n toi ei)/ph|si o(do/n, he will tell you, etc. Od. iv. 388.See Il. xi. 386, ei) peirhqei/hs, ou)k a)/n toi xrai/smh|si bio/s; and Il. ii. 488, Il. xx. 100, Od. xvii. 539. *ei) de\ dai/mwn gene/qlios e(/rpoi, *di\ tou=t' *)enuali/w| t' e)kdw/somen pra/ssein. PIND. Ol. xiii. 105.For the cases in Pindar here and in 500 and 501, see Jour. Phil. iii. p. 444. So in an old curse, ei)/ tis ta/de parabai/noi, e)nagh\s e)/stw, AESCHIN. iii. 110.See SOPH. OT 851 , ei)/ ti ka)ktre/poito, ou)/toi to/n ge *lai+/ou fo/non fanei= dikai/ws o)rqo/n.

(b) A present indicative in the apodosis with an optative in the protasis is sometimes merely an emphatic future expression. E.g. *pa/nt' e)/xeis, ei)/ se tou/twn moi=r' e)fi/koito kalw=n, you have the whole, should a share of these glories fall to your lot. PIND. Isth. iv.(v.) 14. So kairo
 ei) fqe/gcaio, mei/wn e(/petai mw=mos a)nqrw/pwn, i.e. should you speak seasonably, you are sure to be followed by less censure of men, Py. i. 81. In THUC. ii. 39 we have kai/toi ei) r(aqumi/a| ma=llon h)\ po/nwn mele/th| e)qe/loimen kinduneu/ein, perigi/gnetai h(mi=n, k.t.l., and now supposing that we should choose to meet dangers with a light heart rather than with laborious training, we secure the advantage, etc. This sentence is loosely jointed, like the others which have this combination; the condition is stated as a remotely supposed case, in the vague future form, but the apodosis, we at once gain this advantage, etc., is adapted to a present supposition. The optative is generally emended to e)qe/lomen, although it is one of the best attested words in Thucydides, being in the best Mss. and also being quoted by Dion. Hal. as a faulty expression. The criticism of Dionysius (de thuc. Idiom. 12, 1) is instructive: e)ntau=qa ga to\ me
 e)qe/loimen r(h=ma tou= me/llonto/s e)sti xro/nou dhlwtiko
, to\ de\ perigi/gnetai tou= paro/ntos: a)ko/louqon d' a)
 h)=n ei) sune/zeuce tw=| e)qe/loimen to\ perie/stai, i.e. the future expression ei) e)qe/loimen should have a future form like perie/stai to correspond to it.
In DEM. xviii. 21, ei) ga\r ei)=nai/ ti dokoi/h ta\ ma/lista e)n tou/tois a)di/khma, ou)de/n e)sti dh/pou pro\s e)me/, the apodosis refers to the real protasis if there is any apparent fault.

(c) In most cases, however, the present indicative in the apodosis precedes, containing a general statement, and the optative adds a remote future condition where we should expect a general present supposition. E.g. *ou)/ moi qe/mis e)/st), ou)d' ei) kaki/wn se/qen e)/lqoi, cei=non a)timh=sai, it is not right for me—even supposing a more wretched man than you should come—to dishonour a stranger. Od. xiv. 56. *qarsale/os ga\r a)nh\r e)n pa=sin a)mei/nwn e)/rgoisin tele/qei, ei) kai/ poqen a)/lloqen e)/lqoi. Od. vii. 51.So v. 484, Od. viii. 138; Il. ix. 318. *ou)/t' ou)=n a)ggeli/h| e)/ti pei/qomai, ei)/ poqen e)/lqoi, ou)/te qeopropi/hs e)mpa/zomai, h(/n tina mh/thr e)cere/htai, neither do I any longer put trust in reports— should any one come—nor do I regard any divination which my mother may ask. Od. i. 414. (Here the remoteness of the supposition in ei) e)/lqoi is contrasted with the greater vividness of that expressed in e)cere/htai). *deino/n t), ei)/ k' e)f' a(/macan u(pe/rbion a)/xqos a)ei/ras a)/cona kauka/cais ta\ de\ fo/rti) a)maurwqei/h, it is hard, . . . supposing you should break your axle and your load should perish. HES. Op. 692. *ke/rdos de\ fi/ltaton, e(ko/ntos ei)/ tis e)k do/mwn fe/roi, it is the dearest gain, if one should bring it from the house of a willing giver. PIND. Py. viii. 13. See Isth. ii. 33. So SOPH. Ant. 1032.

In most of these examples a general supposition with the subjunctive (or present indicative) in the protasis would have agreed more closely with the thought. If the protasis had preceded, so as to determine the character of the sentence, the apodosis would naturally have had the optative with ke/ or a)/n, or some future form (as in the cases under a).

(d) The optative in protasis sometimes depends on the present of a verb of obligation, propriety, or possibility with an infinitive, the two forming an expression that is nearly equivalent in sense to an optative with a)/n. E.g. *ei) ga\r ei)/hsan du/o tine\s e)nanti/oi no/moi, ou)k a)mfote/rois e)/ni dh/pou yhfi/sasqai, for if there should be two laws opposed to each other, you could not surely vote for both. DEM. xxiv. 35.This is analogous to the apodosis formed by e)/dei, xrh=n, e)nh=n, etc., with the infinitive (415). There, for example, e)nh=n au)tw=| e)lqei=n, he could have gone, is nearly equivalent to h)=lqen a)/n, and here e)/nestin au)tw=| e)lqei=n, he could go, is nearly equivalent to e)/lqoi a)/n. This use of the optative is more common in the corresponding relative conditional sentences (555).

div2.head: II. Indicative or Subjunctive in Protasis, with Potential Optative or Indicative in Apodosis.
div2.p:
(a) A present or past tense of the indicative in the protasis with a potential optative or indicative (with a)/n) in the apodosis is a perfectly natural combination, each clause having its proper force. E.g. *ei) de/ tis a)qana/twn ge kat' ou)ranou= ei)lh/louqas, ou)k a)
 e)/gwge qeoi=sin e)pourani/oisi maxoi/mhn, but if thou art one of the immortals come from heaven, I would not fight against the Gods of heaven. Il. vi. 128. *pollh\ ga a)
 eu)daimoni/a ei)/h peri\ tou\s ne/ous, ei) ei(=s me
 mo/nos au)tou\s diafqei/rei, oi( d' a)/lloi w)felou=sin, for there would (naturally) be great happiness, etc. PLAT. Ap. 25B. *ei)/ ti qe/sfaton patri\ xrhsmoi=sin i(knei=q), w(/ste pro\s pai/dwn qanei=n, pw=s a)
 dikai/ws tou=t' o)neidi/zois e)moi/; if a divine decree came to my father through oracles that he was to die by his sons' hands, how can you justly reproach me with this? SOPH. OC 969 ; so 974-977. *(/wst' ei)/ moi kai\ me/sws h(gou/menoi ma=llon e(te/rwn prosei=nai au)ta\ polemei=n e)pei/sqhte, ou)k a)
 ei)ko/tws nu=n tou= ge a)dikei=n ai)ti/an feroi/mhn, if you were persuaded to make war by thinking, etc., I should not now justly be charged with injustice. THUC. ii. 60. *ei) ga ou(=toi o)rqw=s a)pe/sthsan, u(mei=s a)
 ou) xrew
 a)/rxoite, for if these had a right to secede, it would follow that your dominion is unjust. Id. iii. 40: see vi. 92, and DEM. xxi. 37. *kai/toi to/te to
 *(uperei/dhn, ei)/per a)lhqh= mou nu=n kathgorei=, ma=llon a)
 ei)ko/tws h)\ to/nd' e)di/wken, and yet, if he is now making true charges against me, he would then have prosecuted Hypereides with much more reason than (he now has for prosecuting) this man. DEM. xviii. 223.
*ei) ga gunai=kes ei)s to/d' h(/cousin qra/sous, . . . par' ou)de
 au)tai=s h)=n a)
 o)llu/nai po/seis, for if women are to come to this height of audacity (407) it would be as nothing for them to slay their husbands. EUR. Or. 566.
*tou=to, ei) kai\ ta)/lla pa/nta a)posterou=sin, a)podou=nai prosh=ken, even if they steal all the rest, they ought to have restored this (415). DEM. xxvii. 37.

(b) An unreal condition in the indicative followed by a potential optative seldom occurs and is not a strictly logical combination. E.g. *ei) tou=t' e)pexei/roun le/gein, ou)k e)/sq' o(/stis ou)k a)\n ei)ko/tws e)pitimh/seie/ moi, if I were undertaking to say this, (the result would be that) every one would censure me with reason. DEM. xviii. 206. (Here many Mss. and Dion. Hal.p. 1054 read e)peti/mhse, the ordinary form in such an apodosis.) See [LYS. ] xv. 8.

(c) When a subjunctive or a future indicative in protasis has a potential optative in the apodosis, there is sometimes a distinct potential force in the apodosis (as in 503), and sometimes the optative with a)/n is merely a softened expression for the future indicative (235). E.g. *ei) me/n ken patro\s bi/oton kai\ vo/ston a)kou/sw, h)= t' a)
 truxo/meno/s per e)/ti tlai/hn e)niauto/n, if I hear of my father's life and return, wasted as I am, I can still endure it for a year. Od. ii. 218. (See the next verses, Od. 220-223, ei) de/ ke teqnew=tos a)kou/sw, with future forms in the apodosis. See also the corresponding verses, Od. i. 287-292.) *)all' e)/ti me/n ke kai\ w(\s kaka/ per pa/sxontes i(/koisqe, ai)/ k' e)qe/lh|s so
 qumo
 e)rukake/ein, but still even so, though suffering evils, you may come home, if you will curb your passion. Od. xi. 104; so xi. 110 and xii. 137. See Il. xxi. 556. *ei) de/ ken o)/y' a)ro/sh|s, to/de ke/n toi fa/rmakon ei)/h, but if you plough late, this may be your remedy. HES. Op. 485; so 665. *)all' h)
 e)fh=|s moi, . . . le/caim' a)
 o)rqw=s, i.e. I would fain speak. SOPH. El. 554. So O. T. 216, Phil. 1259; EUR. Hel. 1085. *ou)de\ ga a)
 pollai\ ge/furai w)=sin, e)/xoimen a)
 o(/poi fugo/ntes h(mei=s swqw=men, for not even if there are (shall be) many bridges, could we (in the case supposed) find a place to fly to and be safe. XEN. An. ii. 4, 19.

*ei) ga/r ti le/ceis w(=| xolw/setai strato\s, ou)/t' a)\n tafei/h pai=s o(/d' ou)/t' oi)/ktou tu/xoi, for if you say anything by which the army shall be made angry, this child cannot be buried or find pity. EUR. Tro. 730; see Suppl. 603, EUR. Cycl. 474. *frou/rion ei) poih/sontai, th=s me\n gh=s bla/ptoien a)/n ti me/ros, ou) me/ntoi i(kano/n ge e)/stai kwlu/ein h(ma=s, k.t.l., if they (shall) build a fort, they might perhaps injure some part of our land; but it will not be sufficient to prevent us, etc. THUC. i. 142.
In the following examples the optative with a)/n seems to form a future apodosis to the future protasis; though in some of them it may be thought to be potential:—

*ei) de/ ken eu)ploi+/hn dw/h| kluto\s ei)nosi/gaios, h)/mati/ ken trita/tw| *fqi/hn e)ri/bwlon i(koi/mhn, i.e. on the third day I shall arrive. Il. ix. 362. (The reference to this in PLAT. Crit. 44B shows that i(koi/mhn a)/n is a mere future.) See Il. xiii. 377, Il. xvii. 38; Od. xxi. 114. *)adikoi/hmen a)
 ei) mh\ a)podw/sw, I should be guilty of wrong, should I (shall I) not restore her. EUR. Hel. 1010.See EUR. Ion. 374, Suppl. 520, I. A. 1189, Cycl. 198.
*)\hn ou)=n ma/qh|s moi to
 a)/dikon tou=ton lo/gon, ou)k a)
 a)podoi/hn ou)d' a)
 o)bolo
 ou)deni/, if you (shall) learn this cheating reason for me, I will not (or: I would not) pay even an obol to any one. AR. Nub. 116.
*kai\ ou(/tws a)
 deino/tata pa/ntwn pa/qoien, ei) ou(=toi o(mo/yhfoi kat' e)kei/nwn tw=n a)ndrw=n toi=s tria/konta genh/sontai. LYS. xiii. 94. (Here we should expect ei) ge/nointo.) *tw=n a)topw- ta/twn me/nt' a)
 ei)/h, ei), a(\ nu=n a)/noian o)fliska/nwn o(/mws e)klalei=, tau=ta dunhqei\s mh\ pra/cei. DEM. i. 26.

div2.head: III. Potential Optative or Indicative (with a)/n) in the Protasis.
div2.p:
A potential optative (with a)/n) in the protasis may express a present condition, and a potential indicative (with a)/n) a present or past condition. E.g. *ei) mhde\ dou=lon a)krath= decai/meq' a)
, pw=s ou)k a)/cion au)to/n ge fula/casqai toiou=ton gene/sqai; if we would not take even a slave who was intemperate, how can it be other than fitting to guard oneself against becoming so? XEN. Mem. i. 5, 3. *kai\ e)gw\, ei)/per a)/llw| tw| a)nqrw/pwn peiqoi/mhn a)
, kai\ soi\ pei/qomai, and I, if I would trust any man, trust you. PLAT. Prot. 329B. *ou)/toi pantelw=s, ou)d' ei) mh\ poih/sait' a)
 tou=to w(s e)/gwge/ fhmi dei=n, eu)katafro/nhto/n e)stin, this (preparation) is not wholly to be despised, even if you would not do this as I say you ought. DEM. iv. 18.Notice the difference between this supposition that you would not do this if you could (i.e. ou)k a)
 poih/saite tou=to) and the ordinary ei) mh\ poih/saite tou=to, supposing you not to do this.

*ei) toi/nun tou=to i)sxuro
 h)=n a)
 tou/tw| tekmh/rion, ka)moi\ gene/sqw tekmh/rion, k.t.l., if then this would have been a strong proof for him (sc. had he had it), so let it be also a proof for me, etc. DEM. xlix. 58. *ei) mh\ dia\ to\ tou/tous bou/lesqai sw=sai, e)cw/lhs a)poloi/mhn kai\ prow/lhs ei) proslabw/n g' a)
 a)rgu/rion pa/nu polu\ meta\ tou/twn e)pre/s beusa, had it not been for my wish to save these (captives), may I perish utterly and before my day if I would have gone on an embassy with these men even for very high pay. DEM. xix. 172. (Here the protasis to which the apodosis a)poloi/mhn refers is really the whole expression ei) . . . e)pre/sbeusa a)/n ei) mh\ . . . sw=sai, if I would have gone except to save these, e)pre/sbeusa a)/n in the protasis being itself the apodosis to ei) mh\ . . . sw=sai.) In DEM. xviii. 101, kai\ ti/s ou)k a)
 a)pe/kteine/ me dikai/ws, ei)/ ti tw=n u(parxo/ntwn th=| po/lei kalw=n lo/gw| mo/non kataisxu/nein e)pexei/rhs' a)/n; —if we retain the final a)/n (strongly supported by Mss.), we must translate if (it is true that) I would (under any circumstances) have undertaken, etc., and not simply if I had undertaken (ei) e)pexei/rhsa). (See 557.)

It is obvious that such forms (506) express simple present or past conditions, the real protasis always being if it IS (or WAS) the case that something would now be (or would have been), or if it IS the case that something would hereafter be under certain circumstances. (See 409.)

div2.head: IV. Irregular Combinations.—Present or Past with Future in one Protasis.
div2.p:
In a few irregular constructions, which are only cases of anacoluthon, the speaker adapts his apodosis to a form of protasis different from that which he has actually used. E.g. *)egw\ me
 a)
, ei) e)/xoimi, w(s ta/xista o(/pla e)poiou/mhn pa=si *pe/rsais. XEN. Cyr. ii. 1, 9. (Here e)poiou/mhn a)/n is used as if ei) ei)=xon, if I were able, had preceded. We should expect poioi/mhn a)/n, which is found in one Ms.) *ei) ou)=n ei)dei=en o(/ti qea=tai au)tou\s, XEN. Cyr. i (/ento a)
 e)pi\ tou\s po/nous . . . kai\ katerga/zointo a)
 au)th/n, if then they knew that she (virtue) sees them, they would rush into labours and would secure her. XEN. Cyn. xii. 22.
*ei) me
 ga ei)s gunai=ka swfroneste/ran ci/fos meqei=men, duskleh\s a)
 h)=n fo/nos EUR. Or. 1132. (Here we should expect ei)/h; or meqei=men may be indicative.)

The same protasis may have one verb in the indicative referring to present or past time, and another in the optative referring to the future. E.g. *)egw\ ou)=n deina\ a)
 ei)/hn ei)rgasme/nos, ei), o(/te me/n me oi( a)/rxontes e)/tatton, to/te me
 e)/menon, tou= de\ qeou= ta/ttontos li/poimi th
 ta/cin, I should therefore (prove to) have behaved outrageously, if when the state authorities stationed me I stood my ground, but (if) now when God stations me I should desert my post. PLAT. Ap. 28E. (Here the supposed combination of the two acts is the future condition to which the future apodosis refers.) *)epeu/xomai pa=si tou/tois, ei) a)lhqh= pro\s u(ma=s ei)/poimi kai\ ei)=pon kai\ to/t' eu)qu\s e)n tw=| dh/mw|, eu)tuxi/an moi dou=nai, i.e. if I should speak the truth and if I did speak it then, etc. DEM. xviii. 141. *ei) de\ mh/t' e)/sti mh/te h)=n mh/te a)
 ei)pei=n e)/xoi mhdei\s mhde/pw kai\ th/meron, ti/ to
 su/mboulon e)xrh=n poiei=n; but if there neither is nor was (any such thing), and if no man yet even at this day could possibly tell of any, what ought the statesman to have done? Ib. 190.

div2.head: V. Several Protases in one Sentence.
div2.p:
Two or more protases, not co-ordinate, may belong to the same sentence; but one always contains the leading condition, to which the rest of the sentence (including the other conditions) is the conclusion. Here several protases may belong to one apodosis; or the leading condition may be followed by two subordinate conditions, each with its own apodosis. E.g. *kai\ ga a)
 ou(=to/s ti pa/qh|, taxe/ws u(mei=s e(/teron *fi/lippon poih/sete, a)/nper ou(/tw prose/xhte toi=s pra/gmasi to
 nou=n, for if anything shall happen to this Philip, you will soon create another if this is your way of attending to the business. DEM. iv. 11.So xviii. 195, DEM. 217 (two cases in each). *ei) d' h)=men ne/oi di\s kai\ ge/rontes, ei)/ tis e)chma/rtane, diplou= bi/ou laxo/ntes e)cwrqou/meq' a)/n, if we were twice young and twice old, in case any one of us was in fault we should secure a double life and set ourselves right. EUR. Supp. 1084. See AR. Ran. 1449. *ei) ce/nos e)tu/gxanon w)
, cunegignw/skete dh/pou a)/n moi ei) e)n e)kei/nh| th=| fwnh=| te kai\ tw=| tro/pw| e)/legon e)n oi(=sper e)teqra/mmhn, i.e. if I were a foreigner, you would pardon me if I spoke in my own dialect, etc. PLAT. Ap. 17D. *ei)/ ti/s se a)ne/roito tou=to, ti/ e)sti sxh=ma; ei) au)tw=| ei)=pes o(/ti stroggulo/ths, ei)/ soi ei)=pen a(/per e)gw\, ei)=pes dh/pou a)
 o(/ti sxh=ma/ ti. Men. 74 B.

*ei) me
 peri\ kainou= tinos pra/gmatos prouti/qeto le/gein, e)pisxw
 a)
 e(/ws oi( plei=stoi tw=n ei)wqo/twn gnw/mhn a)pefh/nanto, ei) me
 h)/reske/ ti/ moi tw=n u(po\ tou/twn r(hqe/ntwn, h(suxi/an a)
 h)=gon, ei) de\ mh\, to/t' a)
 au)to\s e)peirw/mhn a(\ gignw/skw le/gein, i.e. if the subject of debate were new, I should have waited for others to speak; and then, if I liked anything that was said, I should keep quiet, and if not, I should try to say something myself. DEM. iv. 1; see also xxxiii. 25.

It will be noticed that when the leading condition is unreal (as in EUR. Supp. 1084, PLAT. Ap. 17 D, and DEM. iv. 1, above), this makes all subordinate past or present conditions also unreal, so far as the supposed case is concerned, without regard to their own nature. Thus, in DEM. iv. 1 and xxxiii. 25 we have two directly opposite suppositions both stated as contrary to fact, which could not be unless the leading supposition had made the whole state of things supposed in the sentence unreal like itself. It is obvious, therefore, that such a subordinate condition may refer to a case which is not in itself unreal, although it is part of a supposition which as a whole is unreal. This can be seen more easily in English. We can say, if he had been an Athenian, he would have been laughed at if he had talked as he did; but we are far from implying that the latter supposition (the subordinate one) is contrary to fact, although it would be expressed in Greek by ei) e)/legen. Still it is part of a supposed unreal state of things. This explains an apparent inconsistency in respect to sentences like ei)ko\s h)=n se tou=to paqei=n, you ought properly to have suffered this, when the opposite of the infinitive is implied (415), the expression being practically equivalent (as a conditional form) to tou=to e)/paqes a)
 ei) to\ ei)ko\s e)/paqes. As tou=to and to\ ei)ko/s are here identical, the apodosis is denied in the denial of the protasis. But if a new unreal protasis is added, the opposite of the infinitive is not necessarily implied (see 422, DEM. 1); and if we add a concessive protasis and say kai\ ei) mhde
 h)di/khsas, ei)ko\s h)=n se tou=to paqei=n, even if you had done nothing unjust, you ought (still) to have suffered this, tou=to generally represents what actually took place (see 422, DEM. 2). Here a new chief protasis has come in and changed the whole relation of the apodosis to the sentence. This offers a satisfactory explanation of the apparent anomaly in SOPH. OT 221 , ou) ga a)
 makra
 i)/xneuon au)to\s, mh\ ou)k e)/xwn ti su/mbolon, where mh\ ou)k e)/xwn is obviously equivalent to the condition ei) mh\ ei)=xon, while there is yet no such opposite implied as but I have a clue. The chief condition lies in the emphatic au)to/s, which is especially forcible after ce/nos me/n and ce/nos de/, and involves ei) mo/nos i)/xneuon. The meaning is, for I should not be very far on the track, if I were attempting to trace it alone without a clue. Thus without a clue becomes part of the unreal supposition without being itself contrary to fact, while mh/ in mh\ ou)k e)/xwn shows that e)/xwn is conditional, and not merely descriptive (as if it were ou)k e)/xwn). For mh\ ou) with the participle, see 818.

div2.head: de/, a)lla/, and au)ta/r in Apodosis.
div2.p: The apodosis is sometimes introduced by de/, a)lla/, or au)ta/r, but, as if the apodosis were co-ordinate with the protasis, and were not the leading sentence. This occurs when the apodosis is to be emphatically opposed to the protasis. It is especially common in Homer and Herodotus. E.g. *ei) de/ ke mh\ dw/wsin, e)gw\ de/ ken au)to\s e(/lwmai, but if they do not give it to me, (then) I will take one myself. Il. i. 137. *ei)/ per ga/r t' a)/lloi ge perikteinw/meqa pa/ntes nhusi\n e)p' *)argei/wn, soi\ d' ou) de/os e)/st' a)pole/sqai. Il. xii. 245. *ei)/ per . . . katape/yh|, a)lla/ te kai\ meto/pisqen e)/xei ko/ton. Il. i. 81. *ei) de\ qano/ntwn per katalh/qont' ei)n *)ai/dao, au)ta\r e)gw\ kai\ kei=qi fi/lou memnh/som' e(tai/rou. Il. xxii. 389. *ei) u(mi=n e)sti tou=to mh\ dunato\n poih=sai, u(mei=s de\ e)/ti kai\ nu=n e)k tou= me/sou h(mi=n e(/zesqe. HDT. viii. 22. *)all' ei) mhde\ tou=to bou/lei a)pokri/nasqai, su\ de\ tou)nteu=qen le/ge. XEN. Cyr. v. 5, 21.
This apodotic de/ cannot be expressed in English; as our adverbs then, yet, still, etc., necessarily fail to give the force of the Greek de/, which is always a conjunction.

The expression a)lla\ nu=n, now at least, is elliptical for ei) mh\ pro/teron a)lla\ nu=n (with apodotic a)lla/); as e)a\n to\ di/kaion a)lla\ nu=n e)qe/lhte dra=n, if even now (though not before) you will do what is right, AR. Av. 1598.See DEM. iii. 33.Sometimes a)lla/ alone seems to imply ei) mh/ ti a)/llo; as in AR. Nub. 1364, e)ke/leus' au)to\n a)lla\ murri/nhn labo/nta tw=n *ai)sxu/lou le/cai ti/ moi , I bade him at least (if nothing more) take a myrtle branch and give me a bit of Aeschylus. So 1369. In PLAT. Rep. 509 C, ei) mh/ ti a)lla\ . . . dieciw/n, if for nothing (else), that you may at least describe, etc., a)lla/ introduces an apodosis after ei) mh/ ti (sc. a)/llo).
For de/ used in the same way to introduce the sentence upon which a relative clause depends, see 564.

div2.head: Section VII: Relative and Temporal Sentences.
div2.p: Relative sentences may be introduced by relative pronouns and pronominal adjectives, or by relative adverbs of time, place, or manner. They include therefore all temporal sentences.
Clauses introduced by e(/ws, pri/n, and other particles meaning until have many peculiarities, and are treated separately (611-661).
Relative sentences may be divided into two classes:—

First, those in which the antecedent of the relative is definite; that is, in which the relative pronouns refer to definite persons or things, and the relative adverbs to definite points of time, place, etc. Secondly, those in which the antecedent is indefinite; that is, in which no such definite persons, things, times, or places are referred to.
Both the definite and the indefinite antecedent may be either expressed or understood. E.g.
(Definite.) *tau=ta a(\ e)/xw o(ra=|s, you see these things which I have; or a(\ e)/xw o(ra=|s. *(/ote e)bou/leto h)=lqen, (once) when he wished, he came.

(Indefinite.) *pa/nta a(\ a)
 bou/lwntai e(/cousin, they will have everything which they may want; or a(\ a)
 bou/lwntai e(/cousin, they will have whatever they may want. *(/otan e)/lqh|, to/te tou=to pra/cw, when he shall come (or when he comes), then I will do this. *(/ote bou/loito, tou=to e)/prassen, whenever he wished, he (always) did this. *(ws a)
 ei)/pw, ou(/tws poiw=men, as I shall direct, so let us act.
The relative may be used to express a purpose (565), or in a causal sense (580). The antecedent may then be either definite or indefinite.

When the antecedent is indefinite, the negative of the relative clause is mh/; when it is definite, ou) is used unless the general construction requires mh/ (as in prohibitions, wishes, final expressions, etc.).

div2.head: Relative with Definite Antecedent.
div2.p: A relative with a definite antecedent has no effect upon the mood of the following verb; and it therefore may take the indicative (with ou) for its negative) or any other construction that can occur in an independent sentence. E.g. *le/gw a(\ oi)=da, I say what I know. *le/gw a(\ h)/kousa. *le/cw a(\ a)kh/koa. *)/elecan a(\ h)/kousan. *pa/nta le/gei a(\ genh/setai. *pra/ssousin a(\ bou/lontai (or w(s bou/lontai), they are doing what (or as) they please. (On the other hand, pra/cousin a(\ a)\n bou/lwntai, or w(s a)\n bou/lwntai, they will do what they please, or as they please; the antecedent being indefinite.) *le/gw a(\ ou)k a)gnow=, I am saying that of which I am not ignorant.

*)all' o(/te dh/ r() e)k toi=o duwdeka/th ge/net' h)w\s, kai\ to/te dh\ pro\s *)/olumpon i)/san qeoi\ ai)e
 e)o/ntes, but when now the twelfth day from that came, etc. Il. i. 493.
*ti/s e)/sq' o( xw=ros dh=t', e)n w(=| bebh/kamen SOPH. O. C. 52.
*(/ews e)sti\ kairo\s, a)ntila/besqe tw=n pragma/twn, i.e. now, while there is an opportunity, etc. DEM. i. 20. (If the exhortation were future, he would say e(/ws a)
 h)=| kairo/s, so long as there shall be an opportunity.)
*(o de\ a)naba\s, e(/ws me
 ba/sima h)=n, e)pi\ tou= i(/ppou h)=gen: e)pei\ de\ a)/bata h)=n, katalipw
 to
 i(/ppon e)/speude pezh=| XEN. An. iii. 4, 49. So Il. i. 193, ei(=os w(/rmaine . *oi(/per de\ kai\ tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn to\ ple/on th=s ai)ti/as e(/comen, ou(=toi kai\ kaq' h(suxi/an ti au)tw=n proi+/dwmen, we who are to bear the greater part of the blame, etc. THUC. i. 83.
*(/oqen d' ou)=n r(a=|sta maqh/sesqe peri\ au)tw=n, e)nteu=qen u(ma=s kai\ e)gw\ prw=ton peira/somai dida/skein DEM. xxvii. 3. (Here e)nteu=qen refers to the point at which he intends to begin.) *)=h dh\ loi/gia e)/rg', o(/te m' e)xqodoph=sai e)fh/seis *(/hrh|, o(/t' a)
 m' e)re/qh|sin o)neidei/ois e)pe/essin, surely there will be sad work, when you shall impel me, etc. Il. i. 518. (Here o(/te refers to some time conceived as definite; whereas o(/t' a)
 e)re/qh|sin, when (if ever) she shall provoke me, is indefinite; see 530.) *nu\c d' e)/stai o(/te dh\ stugero\s ga/mos a)ntibolh/sei ou)lome/nhs e)me/qen, th=s te *zeu\s o)/lbon a)phu/ra Od. xviii. 272. (The time is conceived as definite.) *thnikau=ta, o(/te ou)d' o(/ ti xrh\ poiei=n e(/cete, then, when you will not even be able to do what you ought. DEM. xix. 262.

*)/arcomai d' e)nteu=qen o(/qen kai\ u(mei=s r(a=|st' a)
 ma/qoite ka)gw\ ta/xist' a)
 dida/caimi. DEM. xxix. 5. (With the potential optative compare the future indicative in DEM. xxvii. 3, above.) *nu=n de\ tou=to ou)k e)poi/hsen, e)n w(=| to
 dh=mon e)ti/mhsen a)/n, but he did not do this, in which he might have honoured the people. Id. xxi. 69. *ei)s kalo
 u(mi=n *)/anutos o(/de parekaqe/zeto, w(=| metadw=men th=s zhth/sews. PLAT. Men. 89 E (subjunctive in exhortation). *ou)/koun a)/cion toi=s tw=n kathgo/rwn lo/gois pisteu=sai ma=llon h)\ toi=s e)/rgois kai\ tw=| xro/nw|, o(
 u(mei=s safe/staton e)/legxon tou= a)lhqou=s nomi/sate. LYS. xix. 61. (Here the imperative nomi/sate is used in a sort of exclamation after o(/n, where ordinarily dei= nomi/sai would be used. See 253.) *)\an ga a)pofu/gh| me ou(=tos, o(\ mh\ ge/noito, th
 e)pwbeli/an o)flh/sw. DEM. xxvii. 67 (optative in wish).

So in me/mnhmai o(/te and similar expressions. E.g. *ou) me/mnh| o(/te t' e)kre/mw u(yoqen; do you not remember (the time) when you hung aloft? Il. xv. 18. *ei) me/mnhsai o(/t' e)gw/ soi a)pekrina/mhn. PLAT. Men. 79D. *oi)=sq' o(/te e)fa/nh. EUR. Hec. 112. (See 913.)

div2.head: Relative with Indefinite Antecedent. —Conditional Relative.
div2.p: A relative with an indefinite antecedent gives a conditional force to the clause in which it stands, and is called a conditional relative. The conditional relative clause stands in the relation of a protasis to the antecedent clause, which is its apodosis (380). The negative particle is mh/.

Thus, when we say a(\ nomi/zei tau=ta le/gei, he is saying what he (actually) thinks, or a(\ e)no/mize tau=ta e)/legen, he was saying what he thought, the actions of nomi/zei and e)no/mize are stated as actual facts, occurring at definite times; but when we say a(\ a)\n nomi/zh| (tau=ta) le/gei, he (always) says whatever he thinks, or a(\ nomi/zoi (tau=ta) e)/legen, he (always) said whatever he happened to be thinking, nomi/zh| and nomi/zoi do not state any such definite facts, but rather what some one may think (or may have thought) on any occasion on which he may speak or may have spoken. So, when we say a(\ nomi/zei tau=ta le/cei, he will say what he (now) thinks, nomi/zei denotes a fact; but when we say a(\ a)\n nomi/zh| le/cei, he will say whatever he happens to be (then) thinking, nomi/zh| denotes a supposed future case. Again,—to take the case in which the distinction is most liable to be overlooked,—when we say a(\ ou)k oi)=da ou)k oi)/omai ei)de/nai, what I do not know, I do not think that I know, ou)k oi)=da, as before, denotes a simple fact, and its object a(/ has a definite antecedent; but when Socrates says a(\ mh\ oi)=da ou)de\ oi)/omai ei)de/nai, the meaning is whatever I do not know (i.e. if there is anything which I do not know), I do not even think that I know it. In sentences like this, unless a negative is used (518), it is often difficult to decide whether the antecedent is definite or indefinite: thus a(\ oi)=da oi)/omai ei)de/nai may mean either what I (actually) know, I think that I know, or whatever I know (if there is anything which I know), I think that I know it.
The analogy of these indefinite relative clauses to conditional sentences will be seen at once. The following examples will make this clearer:—
*(/o ti bou/letai dw/sw, I will give him whatever he (now) wishes. *ei)/ ti bou/letai, dw/sw, if he wishes anything, I will give it. (402.)

*(/o ti e)bou/leto e)/dwka a)/n, I should have given him whatever he had wished. *(/o ti mh\ e)ge/neto ou)k a)\n ei)=pon, I should not have told what had not happened. *ei)/ ti e)bou/leto, e)/dwka a)/n, if he had wished anything, I should have given it. *ei)/ ti mh\ e)ge/neto, ou)k a)\n ei)=pon, I should not have told anything if it had not happened. (410.)
*(/o ti a)\n bou/lhtai, dw/sw, I will give him whatever he shall wish. *)ea/n ti bou/lhtai, dw/sw, if he shall wish anything, I will give it. (444.)
*(/o ti bou/loito doi/hn a)/n, I should give him whatever he might wish. *ei)/ ti bou/loito, doi/hn a)/n, if he should wish anything, I should give it. (455.)

*(/o ti a)\n bou/lhtai di/dwmi, I (always) give him whatever he wishes. *(/o ti bou/loito e)di/doun, I always gave him whatever he wished. *)ea/n ti bou/lhtai, di/dwmi, if he ever wishes anything, I (always) give it. *ei)/ ti bou/loito, e)di/doun, if he ever wished anything, I (always) gave it. (462.)
The particle a)/n (Epic ke/) is regularly joined with all relative words when they are followed by the subjunctive.

With o(/te, o(po/te, e)pei/, and e)peidh/, a)/n forms o(/tan, o(po/tan, e)pa/n or e)ph/n (Ionic e)pea/n), and e)peida/n. In Homer, where ke/ is generally used for a)/n, we have o(/te ke, e)pei/ ke, etc. (like ei)/ ke), also o(/t' a)/n, where in Attic we have o(/tan, o(po/tan, e)peida/n. *)eph/n, however, occurs often, and e)pei\ a)/n once, in Homer. Both e)ph/n and e)pa/n are rare in
The classification of common conditional sentences, with four classes of ordinary conditions and two of general conditions, given in 388-395, applies equally to conditional relative sentences.

div2.head: I. Four Forms of Ordinary Conditional Relative Sentences.
div2.p: The conditional relative sentence has four forms, two of present and past (525 and 528) and two of future conditions (529 and 531), which correspond to the four forms of ordinary protasis.

div2.head: (a) Present and Past Conditions.
div2.p:
When the relative clause simply states a present or past supposition, implying nothing as to the fulfilment of the condition, the verb is in one of the present or past tenses of the indicative. The antecedent clause can have any form of the verb, like an ordinary apodosis. (See 402.) E.g. *(\a mh\ oi)=da, ou)de\ oi)/omai ei)de/nai (like ei)/ tina mh\ oi)=da). PLAT. Ap. 21D. (See 520.) *xrh/sqwn o(/ ti bou/lontai let them deal with me as they please (i.e. ei)/ ti bou/lontai). AR. Nub. 439.
*)epi/stamai o(ra=n q' a(\ dei= me, kou)x o(ra=n a(\ mh\ pre/pei, I know how to see anything which I ought to see, and not to see anything which I ought not. InoEUR. , EUR. Fr. 417. (*(\a dei= is nearly equivalent to ei)/ tina dei=, and a(\ mh\ pre/pei to ei)/ tina mh\ pre/pei.) *tou\s plei/stous e)/nqaper e)/peson e(ka/stous e)/qayan: ou(\s de\ mh\ eu(/riskon, kenota/fion au)toi=s e)poi/hsan, i.e. they raised a cenotaph for any of them whom they did not find (like ei)/ tinas mh\ eu(/riskon). XEN. An. vi. 4, 9. *ti/ ga/r; o(/stis dapanhro\s w)
 mh\ au)ta/rkhs e)sti
, a)ll' a)ei\ tw=n plhsi/on dei=tai, kai\ lamba/nwn mh\ du/natai a)podido/nai, mh\ lamba/nwn de\ to
 mh\ dido/nta misei=, ou) dokei= soi kai\ ou(=tos xalepo\s fi/los ei)=nai; (i.e. supposing a case, ei)/ tis . . . mh\ au)ta/rkhs e)sti
, k.t.l.). Id. Mem. ii. 6, Id. Mem. 2.So h(/tis mhdamou= cummaxei=, THUC. i. 35. *(\a ga/r tis mh\ prosedo/khsen, ou)de\ fula/casqai e)gxwrei=, for there is no opportunity even to guard against what we did not expect (like ei)/ tina mh\ prosedo/khse/ tis). ANT. v. 19. *ei)s ta\ ploi=a tou/s te a)sqenou=ntas e)nebi/basan kai\ tw=n skeuw=n o(/sa mh\ a)na/gkh h)=n e)/xein (like ei)/ tina tw=n skeuw=n mh\ a)na/gkh h)=n e)/xein), i.e. any which they did not need. XEN. An. v. 3, 1. *)anqrw/pous die/fqeiren (h( qa/lassa) o(/soi mh\ e)du/nanto fqh=nai pro\s ta\ mete/wra a)nadramo/ntes, i.e. if any were unable to escape soon enough to the high land, so many the sea destroyed. THUC. iii. 89. *oi(=s me
 ai(/resis gege/nhtai ta)/lla eu)tuxou=si, pollh\ a)/noia polemh=sai: ei) d' a)nagkai=on h)=n, k.t.l., for any who have had the choice given them, while they are prosperous in other respects, it is great folly to go to war (i.e. ei)/ tisin ai(/resis gege/nhtai). Id. ii. 61. *pa/ntes i)/smen *xabri/an ou)/te tu/ptonta ou)/q' a(rpa/zonta to
 ste/fanon ou)/q' o(/lws prosio/nq' o(/poi mh\ prosh=ken au)tw=|, nor going anywhere at all where it was not lawful for him (i.e. ei)/ poi mh\ prosh=ken). DEM. xxi. 64. *pw=s ou)=n oi( a)gaqoi\ toi=s a)gaqoi=s fi/loi e)/sontai, oi(\ mh/te a)po/ntes poqeinoi\ a)llh/lois mh/te paro/ntes xrei/an au(tw=n e)/xousi; (i.e. ei) mh\ e)/xousi). Lys. 215 B. *nikw/|h d' o(/ ti pa=sin u(mi=n me/llei sunoi/sein (i.e. ei)/ ti me/llei), may any plan prevail which will benefit you all. DEM. iv. 51.

Care must be taken here (as in conditional sentences) not to include in this class general suppositions which require the subjunctive or optative (532). On the other hand, the examples falling under 534, in which the indicative is allowed, might properly be placed here, as they state a general supposition as if it were a particular one.

A conditional relative clause (like a clause with ei), 407) may take the future indicative to express a present intention or necessity. E.g. *)en tou/tw| kekwlu=sqai e)do/kei e(ka/stw| ta\ pra/gmata w(=| mh/ tis au)to\s pare/stai, each man felt that all progress was at an end in any affair in which he was not personally to take part. THUC. ii. 8.The direct form was e)n tou/tw| kekw/lutai (51; 122) w(=| mh\ pare/somai. *ou(= de\ a)lhqei/as tis a)tuxh/sei, pote\ tou/tou e)pisth/mwn e)/stai; but if one is to miss the truth of anything, will he ever understand it? PLAT. Theaet. 186 C. So probably XEN. Cyr. i. 5, 13 , o(/ ti ga\r mh\ toiou=ton a)pobh/setai par' u(mw=n, ei)s e)me\ to\ e)llei=pon e)/stai, i.e. if there is to be any failure on your part to come up to my expectations, the loss will fall on me.
This is the only form of conditional relative sentence that regularly takes the future indicative. (See 530.)
When a relative clause expresses a present or past condition, implying that it is not or was not fulfilled (like a protasis of the form 410), the verb is in a past tense of the indicative.

The antecedent clause generally has a past tense of the indicative with a)/n; but it may have a past tense of the indicative in an unreal condition, in an unaccomplished wish, or in a final clause. E.g. *(\a mh\ e)bou/leto dou=nai, ou)k a)
 e)/dwken, he would not have given what he had not wished to give (i.e. ei)/ tina mh\ e)bou/leto dou=nai, ou)k a)
 e)/dwken). *(opo/teron tou/twn e)poi/hsen, ou)deno\s a)
 h(=tton *)aqhnai/wn plou/sioi h)=san, whichever of these he had done (he did neither), they would be as rich as any of the Athenians. LYS. xxxii. 23. *ou)/te ga a)
 au)toi\ e)pexeirou=men pra/ttein a(\ mh\ h)pista/meqa, ou)/te toi=s a)/llois e)petre/pomen w(=n h)/rxomen a)/llo ti pra/ttein h)\ o(/ ti pra/ttontes o)rqw=s e)/mellon pra/cein: tou=to d' h)=n a)
 ou(= e)pisth/mhn ei)=xon, for (if that were so) we should not be undertaking (as we are) to do things which we did not understand, nor should we permit any others whom we were ruling to do anything else than what they were likely to do properly; and this would be whatever they had knowledge of. PLAT. Charm. 171E. (Here a(\ mh\ h)pista/meqa=ei)/ tina mh\ h)pista/meqa, if there were any things which we did not know,—w(=n h)/rxomen=ei)/ tinwn h)/rxomen,—o(/ ti e)/mellon=ei)/ ti e)/mellon,—and ou(= e)pisth/mhn ei)=xon=ei)/ tinos ei)=xon. E. Itis implied that none of the cases here supposed ever actually arose. *(/wsper toi/nun a)/llwn tinw=n tetta/rwn, ei) e(/n ti e)zhtou=men au)tw=n e)n o(tw|ou=n, o(po/te prw=ton e)kei=no e)/gnwmen, i(kanw=s a)
 ei)=xen h(mi=n, ei) de\ ta\ tri/a pro/teron e)gnwri/samen, au)tw=| a)
 tou/tw| e)gnw/risto to\ zhtou/menon. PLAT. Rep. 428A. (Here the antithesis of o(po/te prw=ton e)kei=no e)/gnwmen, in (whatever) case we had recognised this first, and ei) ta\ tri/a pro/teron e)gnwri/samen, if we had recognised the three sooner, makes the force of the relative especially clear.) *)ebasa/nizon a)
 me/xri ou(= au)toi=s e)do/kei, they would have questioned them (under torture) so long as they pleased. DEM. liii. 25. *ei) de\ oi)/koi ei)=xon e(/kastoi ta\s di/kas, tou/tous a)
 a)pw/llusan oi(/tines fi/loi ma/lista h)=san *)aqhnai/wn tw=| dh/mw|, if each had their trials at home, they would ruin any who were especially friendly, etc. Ath. i. 16. (Here oi(/tines h)=san,=ei)/ tines h)=san, forms a second protasis to the apodosis a)pw/llusan a)/n. See 511.) *kai\ o(phni/ka e)fai/neto tau=ta pepoihkw\s, w(mologei=t' a)
 h( kathgori/a toi=s e)/rgois au)tou=, and if he ever appeared to have done this, his form of accusation would agree with his acts. DEM. xviii. 14.

*ei) ce/nos e)tu/gxanon w)\n, cunegignw/skete dh/pou a)/n moi ei) e)n e)kei/nh| th=| fwnh=| te kai\ tw=| tro/pw| e)/legon e)n oi(=sper e)teqra/mmhn, if I happened to be a foreigner, you would surely pardon me, if I were (now) addressing you in both the language and the manner in which I had been brought up. PLAT. Ap. 17D. *(ws dh\ e)gw/ g' o)/felon ma/karo/s nu/ teu e)/mmenai ui(o\s a)ne/ros, o(\n ktea/tessin e(oi=s e)/pi gh=ras e)/tetmen, O that I were the son of some fortunate man, whom old age had found upon his own estate (i.e. if old age had found any such man, would that I had been his son). Hom. Od. i. 217.So Hom. Il. vi. 348 and 351.

So when the relative sentence depends on a past indicative in a final clause (333); as in DEM. xxiii. 48, tau=ta/ ge dh/pou prosh=ke gra/yai, i(/na o(/tw| pote\ tou)/rgon e)pra/xqh, tou/tw| ta\ e)k tw=n no/mwn u(ph=rxe di/kaia, he ought to have written it in this way, in order that any one by whom the deed had been done might have his rights according to the laws. (This implies that the law was not so written, so that the case supposed in o(/tw| e)pra/xqh never arose.) So DEM. liii. 24, i(/n' a)kou/santes e)k tou/twn e)yhfi/sasqe o(poi=o/n ti u(mi=n e)do/kei, that you might have voted whatever seemed good to you.
All examples of this form fall equally well under the general rule for assimilation (559).

div2.head: (b) Future Conditions.
div2.p:
(Subjunctive.) When the relative clause expresses a future condition of the more vivid form (like a protasis of the form 444), and the verb of the antecedent clause also refers to the future, the relative is joined with a)/n (or ke/) and takes the subjunctive. E.g. *ta/wn h(/n k' e)qe/lwmi fi/lhn poih/som' a)/koitin (like ei)/ ke/ tina e)qe/lwmi), whomsoever of these I may wish I shall make my wife. Il. ix. 397. *)ek ga *)ore/stao ti/sis e)/ssetai *)atrei+/dao, o(ppo/t' a)
 h(bh/sh| te kai\ h(=s i(mei/retai ai)/hs, i.e. vengeance will come from Orestes, when he shall grow up, etc. (like e)a/n pote h(bh/sh|). Od. i. 40. *to/te d' au)=te maxh/setai, o(ppo/te ke/n min qumo\s e)ni\ sth/qessin a)nw/gh| kai\ qeo\s o)/rsh|. Il. ix. 702. *)all' a)/geq), w(s a)
 e)gw
 ei)/pw, peiqw/meqa pa/ntes, let us obey as I may direct, i.e. if I give any direction (e)a/n pws ei)/pw), let us obey it. Il. ii. 139. *(hmei=s au)=t' a)lo/xous te fi/las kai\ nh/pia te/kna a)/comen e)n nh/essin, e)ph
 ptoli/eqron e(/lwmen, when we shall have taken the city. Il. iv. 238.So eu)=t' a)
 pi/ptwsin, Il. i. 242. *ou)kou=n, o(/tan dh\ mh\ sqe/nw, pepau/somai, therefore, when I shall have no more strength, I will cease. SOPH. Ant. 91. *tau=ta, e)peida
 peri\ tou= ge/nous ei)/pw, to/te e)rw=, I will speak of this, when I shall have spoken about my birth. DEM. lvii. 16. (See 90.) *)epeida
 diapra/cwmai a(\ de/omai, h(/cw. XEN. An. ii. 3, 29. *ti/na oi)/esqe au)th
 yuxh
 e)/cein, o(/tan e)me\ i)/dh| tw=n patrw/|wn a)pesterhme/non; what feelings do you think she will have, when (or if at any time) she shall see me, etc.? DEM. xxviii. 21. *tou/twn de\ *)aqhnai/ous fhmi\ dei=n ei)=nai pentakosi/ous, e)c h(=s a)/n tinos u(mi=n h(liki/as kalw=s e)/xein dokh=|, from whatever age it shall seem good to you to take them (i.e. if from any particular age, etc.) Id. iv. 21. *tw=n pragma/twn tou\s bouleuome/nous (h(gei=sqai dei=), i(/na a(\ a)
 e)kei/nois dokh=| tau=ta pra/tthtai, in order that whatever shall seem good to them shall be done. Ib. 39. *ou)/ moi fo/bou me/laqron e)lpi\s e)mpatei=n, e(/ws a)
 ai)/qh| tu=r e)f' e(sti/as e)mh=s *ai)/gisqos, so long as Aegisthus shall kindle fire upon my hearth. AESCH. Ag. 1434.

The future indicative is very rarely used in conditional relative clauses, as it is in common protasis (447), in the place of the subjunctive; as it would generally be ambiguous, appearing as if the ante cedent were definite. Some cases of o(/sos with the future, as o(/soi boulh/sontai, THUC. i. 22, are perhaps exceptions. (See 527.)

(Optative.) When the relative clause expresses a future condition of the less vivid form (like a protasis of the form 455), and the antecedent clause contains an optative referring to the future, the relative takes the optative (without a)/n).

The optative in the antecedent clause may be in an apodosis with a)/n, in a protasis, in an expression of a wish, or in a final clause. E.g. *ma/la ken qrasuka/rdios ei)/h, o(\s to/te ghqh/seien i)dw
 po/non ou)d' a)ka/xoito (i.e. ei)/ tis ghqh/seie, ma/la ken qrasuka/rdios ei)/h), any one who should then rejoice would be very stout-hearted. Il. xiii. 343. *bouloi/mhn k' e)pa/rouros e)w
 qhteue/men a)llw=| . . . w(=| mh\ bi/otos polu\s ei)/h, I should wish to be a serf attached to the soil, serving another man who had not much to live on. Od. xi. 489. *zhno\s ou)k a)
 a)=sson i(koi/mhn, o(/te mh\ au)to/s ge keleu/oi, unless he should himself bid me. Il. xiv. 247. So Il. vi. 329 and 521; and o(/stis kale/seie, AR. Nub. 1250.
*ou)k a)
 ou)=n qre/yais a)/ndra, o(/stis e)qe/loi te kai\ du/naito sou= a)peru/kein tou\s e)pixeirou=ntas a)dikei=n se; would you not support any man who should be both willing and able, etc.? XEN. Mem. ii. 9, 2. *peinw=n fa/goi a)
 o(po/te bou/loito, when he is hungry, he would eat whenever he might wish (like ei)/ pote bou/loito). Ib. ii. 1, Ib. 18.So i. 5, Ib. 4; i. 7, Ib. 3; iv. 2, Ib. 20. *pw=s ou)=n a)
 ei)dei/hs peri\ tou/tou tou= pra/gmatos ou(= panta/pasin a)/peiros ei)/hs; how then could you know about that thing of which you had no experience at all? PLAT. Men. 92 C. *)=ar' a)

 (xrh/mata), the older he should grow, the more he would always cling to it (i.e. ei)/ ti presbu/teros gi/gnoito, tosou/tw| ma=llon a)spa/zoito a)/n). Ib. 549 B. So 412D. *fh/somen mhde/pote mhde
