*ei) de\ bou/loio tw=n fi/lwn tina\ protre/yasqai o(po/te a)podhmoi/hs e)pimelei=sqai tw=n sw=n, ti/ a)\n poioi/hs; XEN. Mem. ii. 3, 12. *ei)ko/tws a)\n kai\ para\ qew=n praktikw/teros ei)/h, o(/stis mh\ o(po/te e)n a)po/rois ei)/h to/te kolakeu/oi, a)ll' o(/te ta\ a)/rista pra/ttoi to/te ma/lista tw=n qew=n memnw=|to. Id. Cyr. i. 6, Id. Cyr. 3. *(ws a)po/loito kai\ a)/llos, o(/ tis toiau=ta/ ge r(e/zoi, O that any other man might likewise perish who should do the like (i.e. ei)/ tis toiau=ta r(e/zoi). Hom. Od. i. 47. *ei) ga/r min qana/toio dushxe/os w(=de dunai/mhn no/sfin a)pokru/yai, o(/te min mo/ros ai)no\s i(ka/noi. Hom. Il. xviii. 464. *dw=ra qew=n e)/xoi, o(/tti didoi=en, may he have gifts of the Gods, whatever they may give. Hom. Od. xviii. 142. *)egi/gnwske dei=n tou\s u(phre/tas tou=to a)skei=n, w(s pa/nta nomi/zoien pre/pein au(toi=s pra/ttein o(/sa o( a)/rxwn prosta/ttoi. XEN. Cyr. ii. 1, 31.
For ke/ or a)/n in these relative sentences in Homer, see 542. All these examples fall also under the general rule for assimilation (558).

div2.head: II. General Conditional Relative Sentences.
div2.p:
A conditional relative sentence may express a general supposition, when the verb of the antecedent clause denotes a customary or repeated action or a general truth, while the relative clause refers in a general way to any act or acts of a given class. Here the subjunctive with o(\s a)/n, o(/tan, etc., follows primary tenses, and the optative (without a)/n) follows secondary tenses. (See 462.) E.g. *)exqro\s ga/r moi kei=nos o(mw=s *)ai+/dao pu/lh|sin, o(/s x' e(/teron me
 keu/qh| e)ni\ fresi
, a)/llo de\ ei)/ph|, for that man (i.e. any man) is hated by me like the very gates of Hades, who conceals one thing in his mind and speaks another. Il. ix. 312. *nemessw=mai/ ge me
 ou)de
 klai/ein o(/s ke qa/nh|si brotw=n kai\ po/tmon e)ni/sph|, I am never at all indignant at weeping for any mortal who may die, etc. Od. iv. 195. *oi)=nos, o(/s te kai\ a)/llous bla/ptei, o(\s a)/n min xa/ndon e(/lh| mhd' ai)/sima pi/nh|. Od. xxi. 293. *kai\ ga summaxei=n tou/tois e)qe/lousin a(/pantes, ou(\s a)

 po/lemon kaqi/stanto, and the Athenian navy continued to increase from the money which these contributed (pres.), and they, whenever they revolted (aor.), always found themselves unprepared and inexperienced for war. THUC. i. 99.

*)epi\ *moi/rios basile/os, o(/kws e)/lqoi o( potamo\s e)p' o)ktw\ ph/xeas, a)/rdeske *ai)/gupton th
 e)/nerqe *me/mfios, i.e. whenever the river rose. HDT. ii. 13. *to
 de\ xou=n to
 e)kforeo/menon, o(/kws ge/noito nu\c, e)s to
 *ti/grin e)cefo/reon, i.e. they carried it away every night. Id. ii. 150. *oi( de\ (*ka=res), o(/kws *mi/nws de/oito, e)plh/roun oi( ta\s ne/as. Id. i. 171. *)epeidh\ de\ a)noixqei/h, ei)sh/|eimen para\ to
 *swkra/th, i.e. each morning, when the prison was opened, etc. PLAT. Phaed. 59D. *(/ote e)/cw tou= deinou= ge/nointo, polloi\ au)to
 a)pe/leipon, many used to leave him when they were out of danger. XEN. An. ii. 6, 12. (If e)ge/nonto had been used, the whole sentence would refer to a particular case.)

The gnomic aorist and the other gnomic and iterative tenses (154-164) can be used in the antecedent clause of these general propositions. The gnomic aorist, as usual, is a primary tense, and is followed by the subjunctive (171). E.g.
*(/os ke qeoi=s e)pipei/qhtai, ma/la t' e)/kluon au)tou= whoever obeys the Gods, to him they are ready to listen (e)/kluon is aoristic). Il. i. 218.
*(/otan tis w(/sper ou(=tos i)sxu/sh|, h( prw/th pro/fasis a(/panta a)nexai/tise kai\ die/lusen DEM. ii. 9.
*(opo/te prosble/yeie/ tinas tw=n e)n tai=s ta/cesi, ei)=pen a)\n, w)= a)/ndres, k.t.l., i.e. he used to say, etc. XEN. Cyr. vii. 1, 10.
*ou)/t' a)/llote pw/pote pro\s xa/rin ei(lo/mhn le/gein, o(/ ti a)\n mh\ kai\ sunoi/sein pepeisme/nos w)=, I have never on other occasions preferred to say anything to please which I have not been convinced would also be for your advantage. DEM. iv. 51. (Here ei(lo/mhn has a sense approaching that of the gnomic aorist, and is followed by a subjunctive. See 156.)

Homeric examples of relatives with ke/ or a)/n and the subjunctive in general conditions are here included with the others, because this construction is fixed in the Homeric usage. In the greater number of general relative conditions which have the subjunctive, however, Homer uses the relative without ke/ or a)/n, as he prefers the simple ei) in the corresponding conditional sentences (468). See examples in 538.

(Indicative.) The indicative is sometimes used instead of the subjunctive and optative in relative sentences of this class. (See 467.) Here one of the cases in which the event may occur is referred to as if it were the only one. This use of the indicative occurs especially after the indefinite relative o(/stis; as the idea of indefiniteness, which is usually expressed by the subjunctive or optative, is here sufficiently expressed by the relative itself. E.g.
*)exqro\s ga/r moi kei=nos o(mw=s *)ai/dao pu/lh|sin *gi/gnetai, o(\s peni/h| ei)/kwn a)path/lia ba/zei. Od. xiv. 156.
Compare this with Il. ix. 312, the first example under 532.

*)emoi\ ga\r o(/stis pa=san eu)qu/nwn po/lin *mh\ tw=n a)ri/stwn a(/ptetai bouleuma/twn, *)all' e)k fo/bou tou glw=ssan e)gklei/sas e)/xei, *ka/kistos ei)=nai nu=n te kai\ pa/lai dokei=: *kai\ mei/zon' o(/stis a)nti\ th=s au(tou= pa/tras *fi/lon nomi/zei, tou=ton ou)damou= le/gw. SOPH. Ant. 178.
(Here we might have had o(\s a)\n . . . mh\ a(/pthtai, a)ll' . . . e)/xh|, and o(\s a)\n nomi/zh|, without any essential difference in meaning.)

*oi(/tines pro\s ta\s cumfora\s gnw/mh| me\n h(/kista lupou=ntai, e)/rgw| de\ ma/lista a)nte/xousin, ou(=toi kai\ po/lewn kai\ i)diwtw=n kra/tistoi/ ei)sin. THUC. ii. 64.So in the same chapter, o(/stis lamba/nei. *(/ostis d' a)fiknei=to tw=n para\ basile/ws pro\s au)to\n, pa/ntas ou(/tw diatiqei\s a)pepe/mpeto, whoever came to him, he always sent away, etc. XEN. An. i. 1, 5. *(/opou de\ xilo\s spa/nios pa/nu ei)/h, au)to\s d' e)du/nato paraskeua/sasqai, diape/mpwn e)ke/leue tou\s fi/lous i(/ppois e)mba/llein tou=ton. Ib. i. 9, Ib. 27. (In the last two examples there is some Ms. authority for the more regular a)fiknoi=to and du/naito.)
This use of the indicative (534) is rare in temporal sentences. See, however, the following:—

*peri\ tw=n a)/llwn tw=n a)dikou/ntwn, o(/te dika/zontai, dei= para\ tw=n kathgo/rwn puqe/sqai. LYS. xxii. 22. *ei)=xon maxai/rion, w(=| e)/sfatton w(=n kratei=n du/nainto, kai\ a)pote/mnontes a)\n ta\s kefala\s e)/xontes e)poreu/onto, o(po/te oi( pole/mioi au)tou\s o)/yesqai e)/me llon. XEN. An. iv. 7, 16. So o(po/te a)fi/stato, XEN. An. ii. 6, 27.
All these examples fall under the first class of conditional relative sentences (525).

The Greek generally uses the indicative in relative clauses depending on general negative sentences, where in Latin a subjunctive is more common. A general negation is really particular. E.g. *par' e)moi\ de\ ou)dei\s misqoforei=, o(/stis mh\ i(kano/s e)stin i)/sa ponei=n e)moi/, i.e. no one who is not able (no one unless he is able), nemo qui non possit. XEN. Hell. vi. 1, 5. *ou)dei\s ga\r ou)deni\ w)rgi/zeto o(/stis mh\ w)/|eto a)polei=sqai, for no one was angry with any one who did not think that he was about to perish (i.e. ei) mh\ w)/|eto). Ib. vii. 4, Ib. 37. *ou)damou= pw/poq), o(/poi presbeuth\s e)pe/mfqhn u(f' u(mw=n e)gw\, h(tthqei\s a)ph=lqon tw=n para\ *fili/ppou pre/sbewn, nowhere, whither I was sent as ambassador, did I ever come off worsted by Philip's ambassadors. DEM. xviii. 244.Here the leading sentence is particular, on no single occasion was I worsted, so that e)pe/mfqhn is regular; if the nearly equivalent universal affirmative on every occasion I proved superior had been intended, we should have had pemfqei/hn. See xviii. 45, prou)/legon kai\ diemarturo/mhn kai\ par' u(mi=n a)ei\ kai\ o(/poi pemfqei/hn; and the following in 244, e)n oi(=s krathqei=en oi( pre/sbeis au)tou= tw=| lo/gw|, tau=ta toi=s o(/plois e)piw\n katestre/feto. Notice the imperfects in the two affirmative examples, and the aorist in the preceding negative example.

1. The indicative is generally used in Greek (as in Latin) in parenthetical relative clauses, like o(/ ti pot' e)sti/n, whatever it is (quidquid est), o(/stis pot' e)sti/n (or e)/stai), etc. E.g. *zeu\s, o(/stis pot' e)sti\n, ei) to/d' au)tw=| fi/lon keklhme/nw|, tou=to/ nin prosenne/pw, Zeus, whoever he may be, etc. AESCH. Ag. 160.
*douleu/omen qeoi=s, o(/ ti pot' ei)si\n qeoi/ EUR. Or. 418.
*(hmi=n ge kre/sson . . . doulhi/hn u(pomei=nai h(/tis e)/stai, but it is better for us to submit to slavery, whatever it may be. HDT. vi. 12.So o(/ ti dh/ kote/ e)sti, HDT. vii. 16.

2. But o(/stis in such expressions can have the construction of an ordinary conditional relative, so that in future and general conditions it may take the subjunctive. E.g. *)all' o( prosaya/menos au)tw=n, o(/stis a)\n h)=|, lo/gon pare/xei, but each one who has to do with them, whoever he may be, gives his own account of them. AESCHIN. i. 127. *)all' u(f' u(mw=n e)/dei kexeirotonhme/non ei)=nai tou=ton, o(/stis a)\n h)=|, but this officer ought always to be elected by you, whoever he may be. DEM. iv. 27.See THEOG. 964.

div2.head: Homeric and other Poetic Peculiarities in Conditional Relative Sentences: Subjunctive without ke/ or a)/n.
div2.p: In general conditions which take the subjunctive, Homer commonly uses the relatives without ke/ or a)/n. This corresponds to his preference for the simple ei) in general conditions (468); but relative clauses of this class are much more frequent with him than the clauses with ei). E.g. *(/otti ma/l' ou) dhnaio\s o(\s a)qana/toisi ma/xhtai. Il. v. 407. *)anqrw/pous e)fora=|, kai\ ti/nutai o(/s tis a(ma/rth|. Od. xiii. 214. *zeu\s d' au)to\s ne/mei o)/lbon *)olu/mpios a)nqrw/poisin, e)sqloi=s h)de\ kakoi=sin, o(/pws e)qe/lh|sin, e(ka/stw|. Od. vi. 188. *ou) mh\n soi/ pote i)=son e)/xw ge/ras, o(ppo/t' *)axaioi\ *trw/wn e)kpe/rsws' eu)naio/menon ptoli/eqron. Il. i. 163.So also Il. i. 554, Il. iii. 109, Il. xiv. 81; Od. viii. 546, Od. xviii. 134.Here the meaning is essentially the same as when ke/ or a)/n is added, as in the examples under 532. The greater development of the general relative condition in Homer, especially in the use of the optative, compared with the less developed general condition with ei), has already been noticed (17; 400; 468).

The relative (like ei)) is sometimes found in Homer without ke/ or a)/n in future conditions. E.g. *gh/masq' o(/s tis a)/ristos a)nh kai\ plei=sta po/rh|sin, (tell her) to marry whoever may be the best man and may offer the most. Od. xx. 335.But in vs. 342, referring to the same thing, we have gh/masq' w(=| k' e)qe/lh|, to marry whom she may please. *pei/qeo d' w(s . . . e)n fresi\ qei/w. Il. xvi. 83; so Od. vi. 189. *ou) mh
 ga/r pote/ fhsi kako
 pei/sesqai o)pi/ssw, o)/fr' a)reth
 pare/xwsi qeoi\ kai\ gou/nat' o)rw/rh|, he says he shall never suffer evil hereafter, so long as the Gods shall supply valour, etc. Od. xviii. 132.So Il. xiii. 234.

*)/an is sometimes omitted in relative conditions with the subjunctive in lyric, elegiac, and dramatic poetry, as in Homer; chiefly in general conditions. A few examples occur in Herodotus; and even in Attic prose exceptional cases are occasionally found in the manuscripts. (See 469-471.) E.g. *me/ga toi kle/os ai)ei\, w(=|tini so
 ge/ras e(/spht' a)glao/n, great always is his glory, whom thy illustrious honour (Olympia) follows. PIND. Ol. viii. 10. So Ol. iii. 11, Nem. ix. 44. *pa/ntas e)pai/nhmi kai\ file/w e(kw
 o(/stis e)/rdh| mhde
 ai)sxro/n. SIMON. v. 20 (but o(\s a)
 mh\ kako\s h)=| in the same ode). See TYRT. xii. 34; SOL. xiii. 9 and 55, SOL. xxvii. 3; SIMON. lviii. 5, lxxxv. 7 (o)/fra . . . e)/xh|, but o(/tan h)=| in vs. 10).

*ge/ronta d' o)rqou=n flau=ron, o(\s ne/os pe/sh| SOPH. O.C. 395.
*tw=n de\ phmonw=n ma/lista lupou=s' ai(\ fanw=s' au)qai/retoi. Id. O.T. 1231. So Sept. 257, Eum. 211, Eum. 661, and probably 618 (o(\ mh\ keleu/sh|, for Mss. keleu/sei, after ei)=pon denoting a habit). *toi=si ga mh/te a)/stea mh/te tei/xea h)=| e)ktisme/na, . . . kw=s ou)k a)
 ei)/hsan ou(=toi a)/maxoi; HDT. iv. 46.So i. 216, HDT. ii. 85, HDT. iv. 66. *)epixw/rion o)
 h(mi=n ou(= me
 braxei=s a)rkw=si mh\ polloi=s xrh=sqai, it being our national habit not to use many words where few suffice. THUC. iv. 17. (Here ou(= me
 . . . polloi=s make five feet of an iambic trimeter, and the words are probably quoted from some poet. See Classen's note. The sentence continues, plei/osi de\ e)n w(=| a)
 kairo\s h)=|, k.t.l.) See also Leg. 737B, oi(=s h)=| and o(/sois meth=|. In SOPH. El. 225, o)/fra e)/xh| is particular.

div2.head: Relative with ke/ or a)/n and the Optative in Conditions.
div2.p:
In Homer the conditional relative (like ei)) sometimes takes ke/ or a)/n with the optative, the particle apparently not affecting the sense. E.g. *(h de/ k' e)/peita gh/maiq' o(/s ken plei=sta po/roi kai\ mo/rsimos e)/lqoi, and she then would marry whoever might give the most gifts, etc. Od. xxi. 161. *(/ws ke . . . doi/h w(=| k' e)qe/loi, that he might give her to whomsoever he pleased. Od. ii. 54.In these two cases o(\s po/roi and w(=| e)qe/loi would be the common expressions. In Od. iv. 600, however, dw=ron d' o(/tti ke/ moi doi/hs, keimh/lion e)/stw, whatever gift you might choose to give me, etc., may be potential. *nu=n ga/r x' *(/ektor' e(/lois, e)pei\ a)
 ma/la toi sxe/don e)/lqoi. Il. ix. 304. *(\os to\ katabro/ceien e)ph
 krhth=ri migei/h, ou)/ ken e)fhme/rio/s ge ba/loi kata\ da/kru pareiw=n, whoever should drink this when it was mingled in the bowl, would let no tear fall down his cheeks on that day. Od. iv. 222.So e)ph
 . . . ei(/hn, Il. xxiv. 227.
One case occurs of o(/te ke with the optative in a general relative sentence of past time: e)peuqo/meqa . . . o(/te ke/n tin' e)piza/felos xo/los i(/koi, Il. ix. 525.

div2.head: Homeric Similes with *(ws etc.
div2.p: In Homer similes and comparisons may be expressed by the subjunctive with w(s o(/te (rarely w(s o(po/te), as when, sometimes by w(s or w(/s te, as. Except in a few cases of w(s o(/t' a)/n, neither a)/n nor ke/ is found in these expressions.
With w(s o(/te or w(s o(po/te the subjunctive clearly expresses a general condition, and the meaning is as happens when, etc. E.g.
*(ws d' o(/te kinh/sh| *ze/furos baqu\ lh/ion e)lqw\n, la/bros e)paigi/zwn, e)pi/ t' h)mu/ei a)staxu/essin, w(\s tw=n pa=s' a)gorh\ kinh/qh,
and as (happens) when the west wind comes and moves a deep grain field, and it bows with its ears, so was their whole assembly moved. Il. ii. 147.
*(ws d' o(/t' o)pwrino\s *bore/hs fore/h|sin a)ka/nqas a)\m pedi/on, pukinai\ de\ pro\s a)llh/lh|sin e)/xontai, w(\s th\n a)\m pe/lagos a)/nemoi fe/ron e)/nqa kai\ e)/nqa. Od. v. 328.
See Il. v. 597, Il. vi. 506, Il. viii. 338; Od. ix. 391, Od. xix. 518; for w(s o(po/te, Od. iv. 335, Od. xvii. 126.
*(ws d' o(/t' a)\n a)stra/pth| po/sis *(/hrhs h)uko/moio, w(\s puki/n' e)n sth/qessin a)nestena/xiz) *)agame/mnwn. Il. x. 5.So Il. xi. 269, Il. xv. 170; Od. v. 394, Od. xxii. 468.

With w(s or w(/s te the conditional force of the subjunctive is not so obvious, especially as it depends directly on the verb of the antecedent clause, which is always particular and generally past. Here we should expect the present indicative, which sometimes occurs (548). We may suppose that the analogy of the far more frequent clauses with w(s o(/te (544)Delbrück, Conj.u. Opt.pp. 161, Opt. 162, cites 63 cases of this construction (49 in the Iliad, Opt. 14 in the Odyssey), of which 35 have w(s o(/te, Opt. 10 w(s o(/t) a)/n, Opt. 3 w(s o(po/te, Opt. 8 w(s, and 7 w(/s te. caused the same construction to be used also in these, in which the meaning is clearly the same. E.g.
*(ws de\ gunh\ klai/h|si fi/lon po/sin a)mfipesou=sa, o(/s te e(h=s pro/sqen po/lios law=n te pe/sh|sin, w(\s *)oduseu\s e)leeino\n u(p' o)fru/si da/kruon ei)=ben,
i.e. Ulysses wept as a wife weeps, etc. Od. viii. 523.

*(ws de\ le/wn e)n bousi\ qorw\n e)c au)xe/na a)/ch| po/rtios h)e\ boo\s, . . . w(\s tou\s a)mfote/rous e)c i(/ppwn *tude/os ui(o\s bh=se, and as a lion leaps among the cattle and breaks the neck of a heifer or an ox, so did the son of Tydeus dismount them both from their chariot. Il. v. 161.So Il. ix. 323, Il. x. 183, Il. 485; Od. v. 368.

In all the cases of w(/s te the pronominal article oi( or tou/s precedes, referring to the subject or object of the antecedent clause. E.g. *oi(\ d', w(/s t' a)mhth=res e)nanti/oi a)llh/loisin o)/gmon e)lau/nwsin, w(\s *trw=es kai\ *)axaioi\ e)p) a)llh/loisi qoro/ntes dh/|oun, and they,—as reapers against each other drive their swaths,— so did Trojans and Achaeans leap upon each other and destroy. Il. xi. 67.So Il. xii. 167, Il. xv. 323; Od. xxii. 302.

When a simile has been introduced by the subjunctive with w(s or w(s o(/te, it may be continued by verbs in the present indicative, which seem to be independent of the original construction. Even the aorist indicative may be used to add vividness to the description. E.g.

*(ws d' o(/te ti/s t' e)le/fanta gunh\ foi/niki mih/nh| *mh|oni\s h)e\ *ka/eira, parh/ion e)/mmenai i(/ppw|: kei=tai d' e)n qala/mw|, pole/es te/ min h)rh/santo i(pph=es fore/ein: basilh=i de\ kei=tai a)/galma: toi=oi/ toi, *mene/lae, mia/nqhn ai(/mati mhroi/. Il. iv. 141.

*(ws d' o(/t' a)f' u(yhlh=s korufh=s o)/reos mega/loio kinh/sh| pukinh
 nefe/lhn sterophgere/ta *zeu/s: e)k t' e)/fanen pa=sai skopiai\ kai\ prw/ones a)/kroi kai\ na/pai, ou)rano/qen d' u(perra/gh a)/spetos ai)qh/r: w(\s *danaoi\ nhw=n me
 a)pwsa/menoi dh/ion pu=r tutqo
 a)ne/pneusan pole/mou d' ou) gi/gnet' e)rwh/. Il. xvi. 296.

*(ws d' o(/te kapno\s i)w
 ei)s ou)rano
 eu(ru
 i(/khtai a)/steos ai)qome/noio, qew=n de/ e( mh=nis a)nh=ken, pa=si d' e)/qhke po/non, polloi=si de\ kh/de) e)fh=ken, w(\s *)axileu\s *trw/essi po/non kai\ kh/de) e)/qhken. Il. xxi. 522.

Sometimes the first clause of the simile has the present or aorist indicative. E.g. *(ws d' a)namaima/ei baqe/) a)/gkea qespidae\s pu=r, w(\s o(/ ge pa/nth qu=ne. Il. xx. 490. *(ws d' o(po/te plh/qwn potamo\s pedi/onde ka/teisin, polla\s de\ dru=s e)sfe/retai, w(\s e)/fepen. Il. xi. 492. *)/hripe d' w(s o(/te tis dru=s h)/ripen, and he fell as when an oak falls (once fell). Il. xiii. 389. *(ws d' o(/te ti/s te dra/konta i)dw\n pali/norsos a)pe/sth. Il. iii. 33: so w(/s te le/wn e)xa/rh, Il. iii. 23.
Another form of Homeric simile consists of w(s with a noun, followed by a relative with the subjunctive, which may be followed by an indicative as in 547. E.g.

*(o d' e)n koni/h|si xamai\ pe/sen, ai)/geiros w(\s, h(/ r(a/ t' e)n ei(amenh=| e(/leos mega/loio pefu/kh| lei/h, a)ta/r te/ oi( o)/zoi e)p' a)krota/th| pefu/asin: th\n me\n q' a(rmatophgo\s a)nh\r ai)/qwni sidh/rw| e)ce/tam), o)/fra i)/tun ka/myh| perikalle/i di/frw|: h( me/n t' a)zome/nh kei=tai potamoi=o par' o)/xqas: toi=on a)/r' *)anqemi/dhn *simoei/sion e)cena/ricen *ai)/as diogenh/s. Il. iv. 482.
For w(s ei) or w(s ei)/ te with the optative in Homeric similes, see 485.

div2.head: o(/ ti mh/ and o(/son mh/ without a Verb.
div2.p:
*(/o ti mh/ and o(/son mh/, like ei) mh/ (476), are used in the sense of except, unless, with no verb expressed. E.g. *(/o ti ga\r mh\ *)aqh=nai, h)=n ou)de\n a)/llo po/lisma lo/gimon, for except Athens (what was not Athens) there was no (Ionic) city of any account. HDT. i. 143.So i. 18, ou)damoi\ o(/ ti mh\ *xi=oi mou=noi. *ou) ga\r h)=n krh/nh, o(/ ti mh\ mi/a e)n au)th=| th=| a)kropo/lei, for there was no spring, except one on the very citadel. THUC. iv. 26: so iv. 94, THUC. vii. 42.
*ou)/t' e)pi\ qewri/an e)ch=lqes o(/ ti mh\ a(/pac ei)s *)isqmo\n, ou)/te a)/llose ou)damo/se ei) mh/ poi strateuso/menos. PLAT. Crit. 52B . So Plat. Phaed. 67A, Plat. Rep. 405C.

*)/isqi ga\r dokw=n e)moi\ kai\ cumfuteu=sai tou)/rgon ei)rga/sqai q), o(/son mh\ xersi\ kai/nwn, i.e. and to have done the deed too, except so far as you did not slay with your own hands. SOPH. O.T. 346.

Homer once has o(/ ti mh/ or o(/te mh/ in the same sense: ou)/ te/ tew| spe/ndeske qew=n o(/ ti mh\ *dii\ patri/, i.e. except to Zeus (o(/ ti mh/ = ei) mh/), Il. xvi. 227.Here Lange (p. 161) reads o(/te mh/.

div2.head: Special Forms of Antecedent Clause.
div2.p: A conditional relative clause (like a protasis with ei)) may depend on an infinitive or participle (with or without a)/n), on a final clause, on a protasis, or on a verbal noun representing the antecedent clause (or apodosis). E.g.

See DEM. xxi. 64 (quoted in 525); PLAT. Ap. 17 D, DEM. xxiii. 48 (quoted in 528); AESCH. Ag. 1434, DEM. iv. 21 and 39, DEM. xxviii. 21 (quoted in 529); PLAT. Euthyd. 302 A, Theaet. 155A, XEN. Mem. ii. 3, 12 , Cyr. i. 6, Cyr. 3, Cyr. ii. 1, Cyr. 31 (quoted in 531). *(orw= soi tou/twn deh=son o(/tan e)piqumh/sh|s fili/an pro/s tinas poiei=sqai. XEN. Mem. ii. 6, 29.

*kai\ e)me\ dei= a)phlla/xqai kata\ ta\s sunqh/kas, e)peidh\ to\ peri\ tou= *prwtago/rou lo/gou te/los sxoi/h, i.e. I ought to be released according to what we agreed to do when the discussion of the doctrine of Protagoras should come to an end. PLAT. Theaet. 183 C.

After past verbs of waiting or expecting in Homer o(po/te with the optative sometimes has the meaning of until, like e(/ws. E.g. *oi( d' e(/at' . . . potide/gmenoi o(ppo/t' a)/r' e)/lqoi *)idai=os, and they sat waiting until (for the time when) Idaeus should come. Il. vii. 414. So iv. 334, Il. ix. 191, Il. xviii. 524. (See 698.)

div2.head: Mixed Conditional Constructions.
div2.p: The relative with the optative sometimes depends on a present or future tense. This occurs chiefly in Homer, and arises from the slight distinction between the subjunctive and optative in such sentences. E.g. *ai)pu/ oi( e)ssei=tai nh=as e)niprh=sai, o(/te mh\ au)to/s ge *kroni/wn e)mba/loi ai)qo/menon dalo\n nh/essi, it will be a hard task for him to fire the ships, unless the son of Kronos should himself hurl a flaming brand upon the ships. Il. xiii. 317. (Regularly o(/te ke mh\ e)mba/lh|, unless he shall hurl.) So Od. xix. 510. *kai\ d' a)/llh| nemesw= h(/ tis toiau=ta ge r(e/zoi, and I am angry with any other woman who says (should say) the like. Od. vi. 286. (This resembles the loosely jointed examples in 500.)

*toiou/tw| de\ e)/oikas, e)pei\ lou/saito fa/goi te, eu(de/menai malakw=s, and you seem like such a man as would sleep comfortably (like one likely to sleep comfortably) after he had washed and eaten. Od. xxiv. 254. (This resembles the examples in 555.)
The optative regularly follows an optative in a wish (177).

In Attic Greek an optative in the relative clause sometimes depends on a verb of obligation, propriety, possibility, etc., with an infinitive, the two forming an expression nearly equivalent to an optative with a)/n, which would be expected in their place. (See 502.) E.g. *)all' o(
 po/lis sth/seie, tou=de xrh\ klu/ein, we should obey any one whom the state might appoint (if the state should appoint any one, we ought to obey him). SOPH. Ant. 666. (*xrh\ klu/ein is followed by the optative from its nearness to dikai/ws a)
 klu/oi tis.) *)alla\ tou= me
 au)to
 le/gein a(\ mh\ safw=s ei)dei/h fei/desqai dei=, i.e. we ought to abstain, etc.; like fei/doito a)/n tis. XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 19. *ou(\s de\ poih/sasqai/ tis bou/loito sunergou\s proqu/mous, tou/tous panta/pasin e)/moige dokei= a)gaqoi=s qhrate/on ei)=nai (qhrate/on ei)=nai = qhra=n dei=n). Ib. ii. 4, Ib. 10. *(uperora=n ou) dunato
 u(mw=n a)ndri\ o(\s ei)dei/h kuri/ous o)/ntas o(/ ti bou/lesqe au)tw=| xrh=sqai. Id. Hell. vii. 3, Id. Hell. 7.So Ib. iii. 4, Ib. 18. *swfro/nwn e)sti\ mhde\ ei) mikra\ ta\ diafe/ronta ei)/h po/lemon a)nairei=sqai. Ib. vi. 3, Ib. 5.So after polu\ r(a=|o/n (e)sti), Ib. vi. 5, Ib. 52. *swfro/nwn e)sti
, ei) mh\ a)dikoi=nto, h(suxa/zein, i.e. it is proper for prudent men, etc. THUC. i. 120. *)apodote/on ou)d' o(pwstiou=n to/te, o(po/te tis mh\ swfro/nws a)paitoi=. PLAT. Rep. 332A. So AESCH. Eum. 726.

An indicative or subjunctive in the relative clause may depend on a potential optative (with a)/n), sometimes when the potential force is felt in the apodosis, and sometimes when the optative with a)/n is treated as a primary tense from its nearness to the future indicative. E.g. *ou)kou=n kai\ to\ u(giai/nein kai\ to\ nosei=n, o(/tan a)gaqou= tinos ai)/tia gi/gnhtai, a)gaqa\ a)
 ei)/h, therefore, both health and disease, when they prove to be the causes of any good, would naturally be good things. XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 32 ; so ii. 2, XEN. Mem. 3. *(/otan de/ tis qew=n bla/pth|, du/nait' a)
 ou)d' a)
 i)sxu/wn fugei=n, when one of the Gods does mischief, not even a strong man could escape. SOPH. El. 696.
*(/wst' a)pofu/gois a)
 h(/ntin' a)
 bou/lh| di/khn so that you can (could) get off in any suit you please. AR. Nub. 1151.
*oi(/tines toi=s me
 i)/sois mh\ ei)/kousi, toi=s de\ krei/ssosi kalw=s prosfe/rontai, pro\s de\ tou\s h(/ssous me/trioi/ ei)si, plei=st' a)
 o)rqoi=nto. THUC. v. 111. *(\o de\ mhde
 kako
 poiei=, ou)d' a)/n tinos ei)/h kakou= ai)/tion; and what does no harm could not be the cause of any harm at all, could it? PLAT. Rep. 379B. *)egw\ de\ tau/thn me
 th
 ei)rh/nhn, e(/ws a)
 ei(=s *)aqhnai/wn lei/phtai, ou)de/pot' a)
 sumbouleu/saimi poih/sasqai th=| po/lei, I would never advise the city to make this peace, so long as a single Athenian shall be left. DEM. xix. 14. (Here e(/ws lei/poito, so long as one should be left, would be more regular.) *(/otan d' a)fani/sas tis ta)kribe\s lo/gw| e)capata=n peira=tai, pw=s a)
 dikai/ws pisteu/oito; Id. xxxiii. 36. (See 178.)

A conditional relative clause may contain a potential optative or indicative (with a)/n), which has its proper meaning. E.g. *)ec w(=n a)/n tis eu)= le/gwn diaba/lloi, e)k tou/twn au)tou\s pei/sesqai (e)/fh), he said that they would form their opinion upon any slanders which any good speaker might chance to utter. THUC. vii. 48. *(/ontin' a)
 u(mei=s ei)s tau/thn th
 ta/cin katesth/sate, ou(=tos tw=n i)/swn ai)/tios h)=n a)
 kakw=n o(/swnper kai\ ou(=tos, any one soever whom you might have appointed to this post would have been the cause of as great calamities as this man has been. DEM. xix. 29. (Without a)/n, o(/ntina katesth/sate would be equivalent to ei)/ tina a)/llon katesth/sate, if you had appointed any one else (which you did not do). With a)/n, it is a potential indicative.)
See 506, and for the optative with ke/ in conditional relative sentences in Homer (probably not potential), see 542.

div2.head: Assimilation in Conditional Relative Clauses.
div2.p:
When a conditional relative clause referring to the future depends on a subjunctive or optative referring to the future, it regularly takes by assimilation the same mood with its leading verb. The leading verb may be in a protasis or apodosis, in another conditional relative clause, in an expression of a wish, or in a final clause. E.g. *)ea/n tines oi(\ a)
 du/nwntai tou=to poiw=si, kalw=s e(/cei, if any who shall be able do this, it will be well. *ei)/ tines oi(\ du/nainto tou=to poioi=en, kalw=s a)
 e)/xoi, if any who should be able should do this, it would be well. *ei)/qe pa/ntes oi(\ du/nainto tou=to poioi=en, O that all who may be able would do this. (Here the principle of assimilation makes oi(\ du/nainto after an optative preferable to oi(\ a)
 du/nwntai, which would express the same idea.) *teqnai/hn o(/te moi mhke/ti tau=ta me/loi, may I die when these are no longer my delight. MIMN. i. 2.So in Latin: Si absurde canat is qui se haberi velit musicum, turpior sit. — Sic injurias fortunae quas ferre nequeas defugiendo relinquas.
For examples see 529 and 531.

When a conditional relative clause depends on a past tense of the indicative implying the non-fulfilment of a condition, it regularly takes a past tense of the indicative by assimilation. The leading verb may be in a protasis or apodosis, in another conditional relative clause, in an expression of a wish, or in a final clause. E.g. *ei)/ tines oi(\ e)du/nanto tou=to e)/pracan, kalw=s a)\n e)/sxen, if any who had been able had done this, it would have been well. *ei)/qe pa/ntes oi(\ e)du/nanto tou=to e)/pracan, O that all who had been able had done this. So in Latin: Nam si solos eos diceres miseros quibus moriendum esset, neminem tu quidem eorum qui viverent exciperes.
For examples see 528.

It will be seen that this principle of assimilation accounts for the unreal indicative and the optative in conditional relative sentences, which have been already explained by the analogy of the forms of protasis. (See 528 and 531.) In fact, wherever this assimilation occurs, the relative clause stands as a protasis to its antecedent clause. Occasionally this principle is disregarded, so that a subjunctive depends on an optative (178).
For the influence of assimilation in determining the mood of a dependent sentence, see 176.

The indicative in the construction of 525, referring simply to the present or past, cannot be affected by assimilation, as this would change its time. E.g. *(umei=s d' e(/loisqe o(/ ti kai\ th=| po/lei kai\ a(/pasi sunoi/sein u(mi=n me/llei, and may you choose what is likely to benefit the state and all of you. DEM. iii. 36.Compare this with DEM. ix. 76, o(/ ti d' u(mi=n do/ceie (so *s originally), tou=t), w)= pa/ntes qeoi\, sunene/gkoi, whatever you may decide, may this be for our good.
In SOPH. Ant. 373, o(\s ta/d' e)/rdei would belong here; but o(\s ta/d' e)/rdoi (Laur.), =ei)/ tis ta/d' e)/rdoi, falls under 558.

The principle of 558 and 559 applies only to conditional relative clauses. If the relative refers to a definite antecedent, there can be no assimilation, and the indicative or any other construction required by the sense is used. E.g. *ei) tw=n politw=n oi(=si nu=n pisteu/omen, tou/tois a)pisth/saimen, oi(=s d' ou) xrw/meqa, tou/toisi xrhsai/mesq), i)/sws swqei=men a)/n. AR. Ran. 1446. *ei)/q' h)=sqa dunato\s dra=n o(/son pro/qumos ei)=, O that thou couldst do as much as thou art eager to do. EUR. Her. 731. (With h)=sqa for ei)= the meaning would be as much as thou wert (or mightest be) eager to do.)

Conditional relative clauses depending on a subjunctive or optative in a general supposition (462; 532) are generally assimilated to the subjunctive or optative; but sometimes they take the indicative (534). E.g. *ou)d), e)peida\n w(=n a)\n pri/htai ku/rios ge/nhtai, tw=| prodo/th| sumbou/lw| peri\ tw=n loipw=n e)/ti xrh=tai. DEM. xviii. 47.See PLAT. Rep. 508 C and D (reading w(=n o( h(/lios katala/mpei); PLAT. Charm. 164B. *(o de\ to/te ma/lista e)/xairen, o(po/te ta/xista tuxo/ntas w(=n de/ointo a)pope/mpoi. XEN. Ag. ix. 2.

*ai)ti/a me
 ga/r e)stin, o(/tan tis yilw=| xrhsa/menos lo/gw| mh\ para/sxhtai pi/stin w(=n le/gei, e)/legxos de\, o(/tan w(=n a)
 ei)/ph| tis kai\ ta)lhqe\s o(mou= dei/ch|. DEM. xxii. 22. (Here w(=n le/gei and w(=n a)
 ei)/ph| are nearly equivalent.) *)eka/lei de\ kai\ e)ti/ma o(po/te tina\s i)/doi toiou=ton poih/santas o(\ pa/ntas e)bou/leto poiei=n. XEN. Cyr. ii. 1, 30. (Here bou/loito for e)bou/leto would correspond to de/ointo in Ag. ix. 2, above.)

div2.head: de/ in the Antecedent Clause.
div2.p: The conjunction de/ sometimes introduces the clause on which a relative depends. Its force here is the same as in apodosis (512). E.g. *oi(/h per fu/llwn geneh\, toi/h de\ kai\ a)ndrw=n. Il. vi. 146. *)epei/ te o( po/lemos kate/sth, o( de\ fai/netai kai\ e)n tou/tw| prognou\s th\n du/namin, and when the war broke out, (then) he appears, etc. THUC. ii. 65. *me/xri me\n ou)=n oi( toco/tai ei)=xon te ta\ be/lh au)toi=s kai\ oi(=oi/ te h)=san xrh=sqai, oi( de\ a)ntei=xon, so long as their archers both had their arrows and were able to use them, they held out. Id. iii. 98. *)epeidh\ de\ a)fiko/menoi ma/xh| e)kra/thsan . . . fai/nontai de\ ou)d' e)ntau=qa pa/sh| th=| duna/mei xrhsa/menoi. Id. i. 11. *(/wsper oi( o(pli=tai, ou(/tw de\ kai\ oi( peltastai/. XEN. Cyr. viii. 5, 12.

div2.head: Final Relative Clauses Expressing Purpose.
div2.p:
(Future Indicative.) In Attic Greek a relative with the future indicative often expresses a purpose, like a final clause. Its negative is mh/. E.g. *presbei/an de\ pe/mpein, h(/tis tau=t' e)rei= kai\ pare/stai toi=s pra/gmasin, and to send an embassy to say these things, and to be present at the transaction. DEM. i. 2. *fhmi\ dh\ dei=n h(ma=s pro\s *qettalou\s presbei/an pe/mpein, h(\ tou\s me
 dida/cei tau=ta, tou\s de\ parocunei=. Id. ii. 11. *)/edoce tw=| dh/mw| tria/konta a)/ndras e(le/sqai, oi(\ tou\s patri/ous no/mous cuggra/yousi, kaq' ou(\s politeu/sousi, the people voted to choose thirty men, to compile the ancestral laws by which they were to govern. XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 2. *ei)/sw de\ pe/myai (e)ke/leuse) tina\s, oi(/tines au)tw=| ta\ e)/ndon i)do/ntes a)paggelou=sin. XEN. Cyr. v. 2, 3. *nautiko
 pareskeu/azon o(/ ti pe/myousin e)s th
 *le/sbon, kai\ nau/arxon prose/tacan *)alki/dan, o(\s e)/mellen e)pipleu/sesqai. THUC. iii. 16.See DEM. xxi. 109. *ou) ga e)/sti moi xrh/mata, o(po/qen e)kti/sw, for I have no money to pay the fine with. PLAT. Ap. 37 C.

*(pi=yo/n me gh=s e)k th=sde, o(/pou qnhtw=n fanou=mai mhdeno\s prosh/goros. SOPH. OT 1437 ; so 1412. *me/llousi ga/r s' e)ntau=qa pe/myein, e)/nqa mh/ poq' h(li/ou fe/ggos proso/yei, zw=sa d' u(mnh/seis kaka/, they are to send you where you shall never behold the sun's light (to some place, that there you may never behold, etc.). Id. El. 379. So Id. Aj. 659; Id. Tr. 800.

The antecedent of the relative in this construction may be either definite or indefinite; but the negative is always mh/ because of the final force. The future indicative is regularly retained after past tenses, as in object clauses with o(/pws (340); but see 573 and 574.
A past purpose may be expressed by the imperfect of me/llw. See 76; and THUC. iii. 16, quoted in 565.

(Subjunctive and Optative in Homer.) In Homer these final relative clauses have the subjunctive (generally with ke/) after primary tenses, and the present or aorist optative (without ke/) after secondary tenses. E.g. *kai\ a(/m' h(gemo/n' e)sqlo
 o)/passon, o(/s ke/ me kei=s' a)ga/gh|, and also send a good guide, who shall lead me thither (to lead me thither). Od. xv. 310. *au)to\s nu=n o)/nom' eu(/reo, o(/ ti ke qh=ai paido\s paidi\ fi/lw|, find a name to give the child. Od. xix. 403. *teo
 ou)/noma ei)pe\, i(/na toi dw= cei/nion, w(=| ke su\ xai/rh|s. Od. ix. 355. *au)ti/ka ma/ntis e)leu/setai, o(/s ke/n toi ei)/ph|sin o(do/n. Od. x. 538. *(/elkos d' i)hth e)pima/ssetai, h)d' e)piqh/sei fa/rmax), a(/ ken pau/sh|si melaina/wn o)duna/wn. Il. iv. 191. *)all' a)/gete, klhtou\s o)tru/nomen, oi(/ ke ta/xista e)/lqws' e)s klisi/hn *phlhia/dew *)axilh=os. Il. ix. 165. *)/ekdote, kai\ timh
 a)potine/men h(/n tin' e)/oiken, h(/ te kai\ e)ssome/noisi met' a)nqrw/poisi pe/lhtai. Il. iii. 459.The last verse (found also iii. 287) and Od. xviii. 336 are the only cases in Homer of the subjunctive without ke/ in these sentences.

*)/aggelon h(=kan, o(\s a)ggei/leie gunaiki/, they sent a messenger to tell the woman. Od. xv. 458. *pa/pthnen d' a)na\ pu/rgon *)axaiw=n, ei)/ tin' i)/doito h(gemo/nwn, o(/s ti/s oi( a)rh\n e(ta/roisin a)mu/nai. Il. xii. 333.This optative is rare.
The earlier Greek here agrees with the Latin in using the subjunctive and optative, while the Attic adopts a new construction with the future indicative.

The future indicative occurs in Od. xiv. 333, w)/mose nh=a kateiru/sqai kai\ e)parte/as e)/mmen e(tai/rous, oi(\ dh/ min pe/myousi fi/lhn e)s patri/da gai=an. The potential optative with ke/ may take the place of a future form; as ou)de/ oi( a)/lloi ei)/s), oi(/ ken kata\ dh=mon a)la/lkoien kako/thta, Od. iv. 166.So tw=n k' e)pibai/hn, Il. v. 192 (cf. xxii. 348). In none of the Homeric examples of this construction is the relative clause negative.
A final force is seen in a few Homeric temporal clauses with o(/te (o(/t' a)/n, o(/te ke) or o(po/te with the subjunctive, which are chiefly expressions of emphatic prediction:—

*)/essetai h)=mar o(/t' a)/n pot' o)lw/lh| *)/ilios i(rh\, *zeu\s de/ sfin au)to\s e)pissei/h|sin e)remnh\n ai)gi/da pa=sin, a day shall come when sacred Ilios shall fall (i.e. a day for the fall of Ilios) and when Zeus shall shake his terrible aegis before them all. Il. iv. 164; so vi. 448. See Il. viii. 373, Il. xxi. 111.See Monro, Gr. Hom. p. 209.

1. In Attic Greek the subjunctive is not used in final relative sentences as it is in Homer (568). A few expressions like e)/xei o(/ ti ei)/ph|, he has something to say, follow the analogy of ou)k e)/xei o(/ ti ei)/ph|, he knows not what to say, which contains an indirect question (667). E.g. *toiou=ton e)/qos pare/dosan, w(/ste e(kate/rous e)/xein e)f' oi(=s filotimhqw=sin, that both may have things in which they may glory. Isoc. iv. 44. (Here there is really no indirect question, for the meaning is not that they may know in what they are to glory.) *ou)de\n e)/ti dioi/sei au)tw=|, e)a\n mo/non e)/xh| o(/tw| diale/ghtai, if only he shall have some one to talk with. Symp. 194D. *toi=s me/llousin e(/cein o(/ ti ei)sfe/rwsin. XEN. Oec. vii. 20.Compare a)porei=s o(/ ti le/gh|s and eu)porei=s o(/ ti le/gh|s in the same sentence, PLAT. Ion 536B.

2. The subjunctive and optative may be used with a deliberative force, even when the relative has an antecedent, provided the leading clause expresses doubt or perplexity. E.g. *ou) ga\r a)/llon oi)=d' o(/tw| le/gw. SOPH. Ph. 938. *ou)k e)/xw so/fism' o(/tw| phmonh=s a)pallagw=. AESCH. Pr. 470. *ou)de/na ei)=xon o(/stis e)pistola\s pe/myeie. I. T. EUR. 588.So i(kanou\s oi(=s dw=, XEN. An. i. 7, 7 (cf. 677). See SOPH. Ph. 281.

The present or aorist optative occurs rarely in Attic with a final sense, where there is no deliberative force. E.g. *kru/yas' e(auth\n e)/nqa mh/ tis ei)si/doi, bruxa=to. SOPH. Tr. 903.So o(/stis la/koi, AR. Ran. 97. See PLAT. Rep. 398 B and 578E.
For the construction of 572 and 573 see Appendix VI (p. 411).

The future optative also occasionally occurs, as the natural correlative of the regular future indicative, which is generally retained after past tenses (566). E.g. *)/efeugon e)/nqa mh/pot' o)yoi/mhn o)nei/dh telou/mena, I fled to (some place) where I might never see the disgrace accomplished. SOPH. O.T. 796. *)esko/pei o(/pws e)/soito au)tw=| o(/stis zw=nta ghrotrofh/soi kai\ teleuth/santa qa/yoi au)to\n kai\ ta\ nomizo/mena au)tw=| poih/soi. ISAE. ii. 10. *ai(reqe/ntes e)f' w(=|te cuggra/yai no/mous, kaq' ou(/stinas politeu/sointo, having been chosen with the condition that they should compile laws, by which they were to govern. XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 11. (See Ib. ii. 3, Ib. 2, quoted in 565, where kaq' ou(\s politeu/sousi is used in the same sense.)

div2.head: Consecutive Relative Clauses Expressing Result. -- Causal Relative.
div2.p:
(Indicative, with negative ou).) The relative with any tense of the indicative can be used to denote a result, in the sense of w(/ste with the indicative (582). The negative here is ou). This occurs chiefly after negative clauses, or interrogatives implying a negative. E.g. *ti/s ou(/tw mai/netai o(/stis ou) bou/letai/ soi fi/los ei)=nai; who is so mad that he does not wish to be your friend? XEN. An. ii. 5, 12. (Here w(/ste ou) bou/letai might be used.) *)akou/sas toiau=q' a(\ to
 tou=d' ou)/ pot' eu)franei= bi/on SOPH. O.C. 1352 . So HDT. vii. 46. *ti/s ou(/tws eu)h/qhs e)sti
 u(mw=n, o(/stis a)gnoei= to
 e)kei=qen po/lemon deu=ro h(/conta, a)
 a)melh/swmen; i.e. who of you is so simple that he does not know, etc. ? DEM. i. 15. (Here w(/ste a)gnoei= might be used.) *ti/s ou(/tw po/rrw tw=n politikw=n h)=n pragma/twn, o(/stis ou)k e)ggu\s h)nagka/sqh gene/sqai tw=n sumforw=n; ISOC. iv. 113. *ti/s ou(/tws r(a/|qumo/s e)stin, o(/stis ou) metasxei=n boulh/setai tau/ths th=s stratei/as; Id. iv. 185.

So also with the potential optative; as ou)dei\s a)\n ge/noito ou(/tws a)dama/ntinos, o(\s a)\n mei/neien e)n th=| dikaiosu/nh|, no one would ever become so adamantine that he would remain firm in justice. PLAT. Rep. 360 B.

(Future or Present Indicative, with negative mh/.) The relative with the future (sometimes the present) indicative may denote a result which is aimed at, in the same general sense as w(/ste with present or aorist infinitive (582), but with more exactness (577). The negative is mh/. E.g. *eu)/xeto mhdemi/an oi( suntuxi/hn toiau/thn gene/sqai, h(/ min pau/sei katastre/yasqai th
 *eu)rw/phn, i.e. no such occurrence as to prevent him from subjugating Europe. HDT. vii. 54. (We might have w(/ste min pau=sai. Compare ei)s tosau/thn h)=lqe metabolh
 w(/sq' a(pa/shs th=s *)asi/as gene/sqai despo/ths, ISOC. v. 66.) *)ano/hton e)pi\ toiou/tous i)e/nai w(=n krath/sas mh\ katasxh/sei tis, it is absurd to attack men of such a kind that if we overcome them we shall not hold them. THUC. vi. 11. (Here w(/ste mh\ katasxei=n, so as not to hold them, could express only the general sense of the construction.) *(o gra/fwn i)di/a| ti *xaridh/mw| toiou=ton o(\ mh\ pa=si kai\ u(mi=n e)/stai. DEM. xxiii. 86. *toiau=t' a)paggelou=si e)c w(=n mhd' a)
 o(tiou=n h)=| kinhqh/sontai. Id. xix. 324. *ti/s ou)k a)
 de/caito toiau/ths politei/as mete/xein, e)n h(=| mh\ dialh/sei xrhsto\s w)/n; ISOC. iii. 16. *ou)de\ toiau=ta le/gein (pre/pei) e)c w(=n o( bi/os mhde
 e)pidw/sei tw=n peisqe/ntwn. Id. iv. 189. *toiau=ta zhth/seis le/gein e)c w(=n mh/te au)to\s xei/rwn ei)=nai do/ceis mh/te tou\s mimoume/nous lumanei=. Id. xi. 49. *boulhqei\s toiou=ton mnhmei=on katalipei=n, o(\ mh\ th=s a)nqrwpi/nhs fu/sew/s e)stin (=w(/ste mh\ ei)=nai). Id. iv. 89.

The construction of w(/ste after toiou=tos (584), which best corresponds to this relative expression, is not common, as ou(/tws is the natural antecedent of w(/ste, while toiou=tos is naturally followed by oi(=os or o(/s. The relative clause with the future is a much more definite expression, with its power of designating time, number, and person, than the infinitive. (See THUC. vi. 11, under 576.) *toiou=tos may also be followed by oi(=os and the infinitive (759).

*(/opws as a relative is sometimes used in this construction in a way which illustrates its use as a final particle. (See 313.) E.g. *poi/ee de\ ou(/tw o(/kws tw=n sw=n e)ndeh/sei mhde/n, and act so that there shall be nothing wanting on your part; lit. act in that way by which, etc. HDT. vii. 18. *to\ ou(/tws e)pi/stasqai a)nqrw/pwn a)/llwn prostateu/ein o(/pws e(/cousi pa/nta ta\ e)pith/deia, . . . tou=to qaumasto\n e)fai/neto, i.e. in such a way that they should have, etc. XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 7. So Cyr. ii. 4, Cyr. 31.

(Optative.) The relative in this consecutive construction does not take the subjunctive. The optative occurs occasionally depending upon another optative. We find the future optative in PLAT. Rep. 416 C, fai/h a)/n tis dei=n kai\ ta\s oi)kh/seis kai\ th
 a)/llhn ou)si/an toiau/thn au)toi=s paraskeua/sasqai, h(/tis mh/te tou\s fu/lakas w(s a)ri/stous ei)=nai pau/soi au)tou\s, kakourgei=n te mh\ e)paroi= peri\ tou\s a)/llous poli/tas, with which compare 415 E, toiau/tas oi(/as xeimw=no/s te ste/gein kai\ qe/rous i(kana\s ei)=nai. The aorist occurs in DEM. vi. 8, th=| h(mete/ra| po/lei ou)de
 a)
 e)ndei/caito tosou=ton ou)de\ poih/seien, u(f' ou(= peisqe/ntes tina\s *(ellh/nwn e)kei/nw| proei=sqe, i.e. nothing so great as to persuade you to sacrifice any of the Greeks to him (=w(/ste u(ma=s peisqe/ntas proe/sqai). The practical difference between the pure optative here and the potential proei=sqe a)/n, like o(\s a)
 mei/neien in PLAT. Rep. 360 B (quoted in 575), is slight; but it would be seen if we had w(/ste proe/sqai here (so great as to make you sacrifice) and w(/ste mei/neien a)/n there (so firm that he would remain).

The relative may have a causal signification, being equivalent to o(/ti, because, and a personal pronoun or demonstrative word. The verb is generally in the indicative, as in ordinary causal sentences (713); but it may be in the potential optative or potential indicative. The negative is ou); but when the relative clause is conditional as well as causal, the negative is mh/. E.g. *qaumasto
 poiei=s, o(\s h(mi=n ou)de
 di/dws, you do a strange thing in giving us nothing (like o(/ti su\ ou)de
 di/dws). XEN. Mem. ii. 7, 13. *do/cas a)maqe/a ei)=nai, o(\s . . . e)ke/leue, believing him to be unlearned, because he commanded, etc. HDT. i. 33. *th
 mhte/ra (e)maka/rizon), oi(/wn te/knwn e)ku/rhse (like o(/ti toi/wn). Id. i. 31. *eu)dai/mwn e)fai/neto, w(s a)dew=s kai\ gennai/ws e)teleu/ta, i.e. because he died so fearlessly and nobly (w(s being equivalent to o(/ti ou(/tws). PLAT. Phaed. 58E.

*talai/pwros ei)=, w(=| mh/te qeoi\ patrw=|oi/ ei)si mh/q' i(era/, you are wretched, since you have no ancestral Gods (if you really have none), etc. Euthyd. 302B. *pw=s a)
 o)rqw=s e)mou= katagignw/skoite, w(=| to\ para/pan pro\s toutoni\ mhde
 sumbo/laio/n e)stin; i.e. since I have no contract at all with this man (or if I have no contract). DEM. xxxiii. 34. *(/opou toi/nun mhdei\s teto/lmhke tw=n oi)kei/wn tou/tw| marturh=sai, pw=s ou)k ei)ko/s e)stin u(ma=s h(gei=sqai/ me ta)lhqh= le/gein; whereas then (or if then) no one has dared, etc. xlId. ix. 38.So lv. 26. *(opo/te ai( me
 e)c a)rxh=s sunqh=kai h)fani/sqhsan e(/terai de\ mh\ e)gra/fhsan, pw=s o)rqw=s a)
 e)moi\ dika/zoito, kaq' ou(= mh\ e)/xei parasxe/sqai sunqh/kas; whereas the original agreement disappeared and the other was never written, how can he justly go to law with me, when (or if) he cannot bring forward any agreement against me? Id. xxxiii. 30.So SOPH. OT 817 , SOPH. O.T. 1335, O. C. 1680, Ant. 696, Ph. 178, Ph. 255; AR. Ran. 1459; HDT. i. 71 (toi=si/ ge mh/ e)sti mhde/n); THUC. iv. 126 (oi(/ ge mhde\ . . . h(/kete). The potential imperfect occurs in ANT. v. 66, mh\ toi/nun e)moi\ nei/mhte to\ a)/poron tou=to, e)n w(=| mhd' a)
 au)toi\ eu)porei=te, do not then bring upon me this perplexity, in which you yourselves would not know what to do (half causal, half conditional).

In the last examples with mh/, the causal and the conditional forces are united, but in English we can express only one of them. Thus w(=| mh/te qeoi\ patrw=|oi/ ei)si, besides its causal force, implies a condition; so that we might translate equally well if (as it appears) you have no ancestral Gods, you are wretched. The same combination of cause and condition is seen in the Latin siquidem.

div2.head: Consecutive Clauses with w(/ste or w(s and with e)f' w(=| or e)f' w(=|te.
div2.p: Consecutive Clauses with w(/ste or w(s and with e)f' w(=| or e)f' w(=|te.See Gildersleeve in Jour. Phil. vii. pp. 161-175; and Seume, De Sententiis Consecutivis Graecis, Göttingen, Phil. 1883.

A consecutive clause expresses a consequence, that is, the effect or result (actual or potential) of something that is stated in the leading clause. Such a clause is introduced by some relative word, generally by w(/ste, so as, so that. (See 575.) The consequence may be either one which the action of the leading verb aims at and tends to produce, or one which that action actually does produce. This is the fundamental distinction between w(/ste with the infinitive (with mh/ for its negative) and w(/ste with the indicative (with ou) for its negative). E.g. *pa=n poiou=sin w(/ste di/khn mh\ dido/nai, they do everything in such a way as (i.e. so as) not to suffer punishment, i.e. they aim, in all they do, at not being punished; it is not, however, implied that they actually escape. PLAT. Gorg. 479 C. On the other hand, pa=n poiou=sin w(/ste di/khn ou) dido/asin would mean they do everything in such a way that (i.e. so that) they are not punished.

Though this illustrates the fundamental distinction in thought on which the distinction in form is based, there are many examples in which w(/ste with the infinitive and w(/ste with the indicative seem to amount to essentially the same thing, although the processes by which the meaning is expressed in the two constructions are essentially different. Thus we can say ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s w(/ste di/khn mh\ dido/nai, he is so skilful as not to be punished, and also ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s w(/ste di/khn ou) di/dwsin, he is so skilful that he is not punished; and though we should receive the same impression from both statements, so that both might be made of the same man under the same circumstances, yet the two constructions (one stating a tendency and the other a fact) are very different, and they seemed far more so to a Greek than they do to us.

*(/wste is properly a relative particle of comparison, meaning as. Its correlative so may be expressed in a demonstrative like ou(/tws, or implied; as ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s w(/ste se pei=sai, he is so skilful as to persuade you, or h( po/lis tetei/xistai w(/ste i(kanh\ ei)=nai sw/|zein tou\s e)noikou=ntas, the city is walled so as to be able to keep its inhabitants safe. (See toiou/tous kai\ ou(/tw tre/fein ku/nas w(/ste e)pixeirh=sai, PLAT. Rep. 416 A; and compare toiou=tos oi(=os with the infinitive in 759.) These expressions in Greek state no more than he has the skill to persuade you and the city has walls enough to be able, etc.; the further ideas that he does persuade and the city is able are inferences, which are strongly suggested and generally felt when the expressions are used, but they do not lie in the words. When the Greek wishes to express these facts definitely and not to leave them to inference, it uses the indicative with w(/ste; as ou(/tws e)sti\ deino\s w(/ste se pei/qei, he is so skilful that he persuades you, or h( po/lis tetei/xistai w(/ste i(kanh/ e)stin. But here the use of a finite verb compels the writer to make his expression more definite than it was before; for, whereas w(/ste pei=sai and w(/ste i(kanh\ ei)=nai meant only (so) as to persuade and (so) as to be able, without limiting the expressions to past, present, or future time, he cannot use a tense of the indicative without fixing its time, that is, without making a definite statement. So long as the infinitive has no subject and can be translated by our simple infinitive (as above), we can generally express its force without putting into our translation more than we find in the Greek; the formal distinction between so skilful as to persuade and so skilful that he persuades being apparent even when we mean substantially the same by both. When the clause with w(/ste is negative, a marked distinction appears in Greek to show the different point of view taken in the two expressions, and we have w(/ste mh\ pei=sai and w(/ste ou) pei/qei. This is of course lost in English with our single negative. But when the infinitive has a subject, it must be translated by a finite verb in some definite tense, number, and person, that is, by a statement and not by a mere expression of tendency, although the force of the infinitive in Greek is the same as before. Thus we generally translate sxola/zeis, w(/ste qauma/zein e)me/ ( EUR. Hec. 730), you delay, so that I am astonished, as if it were w(/ste qauma/zw e)gw/, simply because we cannot use our infinitive with a subject expressed. If, however, we substitute an equivalent form which avoids this difficulty, like so as to astonish me, we see that there is really no such definite character in w(/ste qauma/zein e)me/ as we impose upon it, and that it no more expresses a statement than w(/ste se pei=sai (above) does. The same difficulty of translating the Greek infinitive with its subject has done much to obscure the force of the tenses of the articular infinitive and of the infinitive with a)/n. (See also 603.)

In many uses of the infinitive with w(/ste it is not even inferred that the result towards which the infinitive expresses a tendency is actually reached. Thus, in clauses with w(/ste expressing a purpose or a condition, and where the infinitive is generally used without w(/ste, we cannot substitute the indicative for the infinitive (see the examples under 587, 2 and 3, and 588).Shilleto (in the Appendix to his edition of Demosthenes de Falsa Legatione) thus illustrates the distinction between w(/ste ou)k e)bou/leto and w(/ste mh\ bou/lesqai. The difference seems simply to be this: ou(/tws a)/frwn h(=n w(/ste ou)k e)bou/leto, he was so foolish that he did not wish (expressive of the real result or consequence); ou(/tws a)/frwn h)=n w(/ste mh\ bou/lesqai, he was so foolish as not to wish (expressive of the natural consequence). . . . Now it is obvious that an energetic speaker, wishing to express that the result (was not only of a nature to follow, but) actually did follow, would employ the indicative: whereas in ordinary and unimpassioned language the infinitive would imply all that was necessary, the natural consequence supposing the real.

In Homer w(/ste (or rather w(/s te) is found, with two exceptions (589), only in the sense of as, like w(/sper. See its use in similes, as w(/s te le/wn e)xa/rh, Il. iii. 23.The te here is like that commonly added to relatives in Homer (as in o(/s te) and to e)pei/ in Herodotus. The Attic poets are the first to use w(/ste freely with the infinitive. In Sophocles we first find w(/ste with the finite moods; this seems to have arisen from a desire to express definitely the accomplishment of the result, which the infinitive expressed only by inference.
*(ws, originally of the same meaning with w(/s te, was seldom used in consecutive sentences except in certain authors. (See 608.)

div2.head: w(/ste with the Infinitive.
div2.p: *(/wste with the infinitive, with a demonstrative expressed or implied, means so as; but when the infinitive has a subject which must be expressed in English, we are generally obliged to translate the particle with its antecedent by so that. The expression properly means only that one action or state is of such a nature as to be followed by another as a consequence; but it is often implied also, apart from the words, that the second action or state actually does follow.

1. The consequence may be simply a result which a previous act tends to produce. E.g. *)amfi\ de\ kuklou=nto pa=san nh=son, w(/st' a)mhxanei=n o(/poi tra/pointo, and they encircled the whole island, so that they (the Persians) knew not whither to turn (i.e. so as to perplex the Persians, etc.) AESCH. Pers. 457.
*to/sonde misei=n w(/ste th
 di/khn patei=n, to hate so violently as to trample on justice. SOPH. Aj. 1335 ; so 1325. *su\ de\ sxola/zeis, w(/ste qauma/zein e)me/, but you delay, so that I am astonished (see 584). EUR. Hec. 730. *pa/ntas ou(/tw diatiqei\s a)pepe/mpeto w(/ste au)tw=| ma=llon fi/lous ei)=nai h)\ tw=| basilei=. XEN. An. i. 1, 5. *duskoli/a kai\ mani/a polla/kis ei)s th
 dia/noian e)mpi/ptousin ou(/tws w(/ste kai\ ta\s e)pisth/mas e)kba/llein. Id. Mem. iii. 12, Id. Mem. 6. *)=hn pepaideume/nos ou(/tws w(/ste pa/nu mikra\ kekthme/nos pa/nu r(a|di/ws e)/xein a)rkou=nta, he had been so educated as very easily to have enough, although he possessed very little. Ib. i. 2, Ib. 1. *fu=nai de\ o( *ku=ros le/getai filotimo/tatos, w(/ste pa/nta me
 po/non a)natlh=nai pa/nta de\ ki/ndunon u(pomei=nai. Id. Cyr. i. 2, Id. Cyr. 1. *)ape/xrh ga a)
 toi=s gnwsqei=sin e)mme/nein, w(/ste mhdemi/an h(mi=n ei)=nai pro\s tou=ton diafora/n, for we should be content to abide by the decision so as to have no difference with him. DEM. xxvii. 1. *polla\s e)lpi/das e)/xw a)rkou/ntws e)rei=n, w(/ste u(ma=s mh/t' a)poleifqh=nai tw=n pragma/twn mh/t' a)gnoh=sai, k.t.l. Id. xxvii. 2. *toiou=ton e)/qos h(mi=n pare/dosan, w(/ste speisame/nous sunelqei=n e)s tau)to/n. ISOC. iv. 43.So iv. 42. *ei) toiou=ton ei)/h h( sofi/a, w(/st' e)k tou= plhreste/rou ei)s to
 kenw/teron r(ei=n h(mw=n, of such a nature as to flow. PLAT. Symp. 175D
*pei/somai ga\r ou) tosou=ton ou)de\n w(/ste mh\ ou) kalw=s qanei=n, for I shall suffer nothing so terrible as to prevent me from dying gloriously. SOPH. Ant. 96. (For mh\ ou) see 815, SOPH. Ant. 2.)

2. The consequence may have the form of a stipulation, condition, or limitation. E.g. *poiou=ntai o(mologi/an pro\s *pa/xhta, w(/ste *)aqhnai/ois e)cei=nai bouleu=sai peri\ tw=n *mutilhnai/wn, they make a treaty with Paches, to the effect that the Athenians shall be permitted, etc. THUC. iii. 28. *)anasth/sas au)tou\s w(/ste mh\ a)dikh=sai, having removed them on condition of doing them no harm. Ibid. So i. 29, THUC. vii. 83.So Id. iii. 114, cummaxi/an e)poih/santo e)pi\ toi=sde, w(/ste mh\ strateu/ein. *)eco\n au)toi=s tw=n loipw=n a)/rxein *(ellh/nwn, w(/st' au)tou\s u(pakou/ein basilei=, it being in their power to rule the rest of the Greeks, on condition that they should themselves serve the King. DEM. vi. 11.

3. The consequence may be aimed at as a purpose, the consecutive clause becoming also final. E.g. *pa=n poiou=sin, w(/ste di/khn mh\ dido/nai, they do everything in such a way as not to suffer punishment, i.e. that they may not suffer. PLAT. Gorg. 479 C. (Here i(/na mh/ with the subjunctive might be used, but it would express only the final element.) *)eboulh/qhsan *)eleusi=na e)cidiw/sasqai, w(/ste ei)=nai sfi/si katafugh\n ei) deh/seie, they wished to appropriate Eleusis, so that they might have a refuge if they should need it. XEN. Hell. ii. 4, 8. *mhxanai\ pollai/ ei)sin, w(/ste diafeu/gein qa/naton, there are many devices for escaping death. PLAT. Ap. 39A. (Here we might have o(/pws diafeucei=tai/ tis.) *mhxana\s eu(rh/somen, w(/st' e)s to\ pa=n se tw=nd' a)palla/cai po/nwn, we will find devices to free you, etc. (= o(/pws se a)palla/comen). AESCH. Eum. 82.

The infinitive with w(/ste sometimes follows verbs of wishing, commanding, etc., which regularly take a simple infinitive of the object (746), less frequently verbs which take an infinitive of the subject (745); and sometimes adjectives and nouns which regularly take the simple infinitive (758). E.g. *ku/pris ga\r h)/qel' w(/ste gi/gnesqai ta/de, for the Cyprian Goddess wished this to be done, i.e. had (such) a wish (as) that this should be done. EUR. Hipp. 1327.
*dikaiw=n w(/st' e)mou= klu/ein lo/gous asking that he (Polynices) should hear my words (to the effect that he should hear). SOPH. O. C. 1350.
*tou\s strathgou\s tw=n po/lewn e)di/dasken w(/ste do/nta xrh/mata au)to\n pei=sai, he instructed him to give money and persuade the generals. THUC. viii. 45.
*to\ me\n du/nasqai, w)= *fai=dre, w(/ste a)gwnisth\n te/leon gene/sqai, the ability to become a finished disputer (i.e. having such power as to become). PLAT. Phaedr. 269 D.
*)elqo/ntes pro\s au)tou\s pei/qousin w(/ste meta\ sfw=n *)/argei e)pixeirh=sai. THUC. iii. 102. (In the same chapter, pei/qei *)akarna=nas bohqh=sai *naupa/ktw|.) *)/epeisan tou\s *)aqhnai/ous w(/ste e)cagagei=n e)k *pu/lou *messhni/ous. Id. v. 35. *yhfisa/menoi au)toi\ prw=toi w(/ste pa/sh| proqumi/a| a)mu/nein, having voted to defend them, etc. Id. vi. 88. *ei)s a)na/gkhn kaqe/stamen w(/ste kinduneu/ein. ISOC. vi. 51. (See 749.) So du/namin w(/ste e)ggene/sqai, power to grow up in it, PLAT. Rep. 433B.
*ei)/ ti qe/sfaton patri\ xrhsmoi=sin i(knei=q', w(/ste pro\s pai/dwn qanei=n, if my father was warned by oracles that he should perish by his children's hands. SOPH. O.C. 969.

*pa/nu moi e)me/lhsen w(/ste ei)de/nai, it concerned me very much to know. XEN. Cyr. vi. 3, 19. *)adu/naton u(mi=n w(/ste *prwtago/rou tou=de sofw/tero/n tina e(le/sqai, it is impossible for you to choose any one wiser than Protagoras here (you have not such power as to choose). PLAT. Prot. 338 C. So XEN. Mem. i. 3, 6. *cune/bh eu)qu\s meta\ th
 ma/xhn w(/ste pole/mou me
 mhde
 e)/ti a(/yasqai mhdete/rous, pro\s de\ th
 ei)rh/nhn ma=llon th
 gnw/mhn ei)=xon. THUC. v. 14. (Here the construction changes suddenly to the indicative in ei)=xon.) *)=ar' e)/stin w(/ste ka)ggu/qen qe/an labei=n; is it possible for me to have a sight of it near by? SOPH. Ph. 656.

*pw=s ga/r tis i(kano\s ge/noit' a)\n w(/ste a)ei\ prosta/ttein to\ prosh=kon; for how could one become capable of always giving the proper command (so capable as)? PLAT. Polit. 295A. *po/tera pai=de/s ei)si fronimw/teroi w(/ste maqei=n ta\ frazo/mena h)\ a)/ndres; i.e. are they wiser than men in learning, etc.? XEN. Cyr. iv. 3, 11. *ne/oi w(/ste tosou=to pra=gma diele/sqai, too young to decide. PLAT. Prot. 314B. So ge/rwn w(/ste s' w)felei=n, EUR. Andr. 80. *yuxro/n (e)sti to\ u(/dwr) w(/ste lou/sasqai, the water is too cold to bathe in. XEN. Mem. iii. 13, 3. (Cf. lou/sasqai yuxro/teron and qermo/teron piei=n, in the same section.)

In many of these cases it seems impossible to believe that w(/ste added anything to the sense, even as it was felt by the Greeks. The expressions were probably stereotyped in usage, and their origin was forgotten. Indeed, w(/ste and w(s (608) sometimes seem to have no more meaning than our to with the infinitive, which in some cases we can use or omit at pleasure, though with some change of sense, as in I dare say and I dare to say. Compare I command you to go and I bid you go. The examples show that there is hardly a construction in which the simple infinitive was used where w(/ste is not occasionally prefixed to it. It is important here to remember that w(/ste means only as (or, including the antecedent, so as); never so that, except in the construction with the finite moods, although this is often a necessary makeshift in our translation.
For w(/ste or w(s with the infinitive after the comparative and h)/, see 764 (b).

(*(/ws te, in Homer.) The only two Homeric examples of w(/ste (w(/s te) with the infinitive are Il. ix. 42, ei) de\ soi\ au)tw=| qumo\s e)pe/ssutai w(/s te ne/esqai, e)/rxeo, but if your own mind is eagerly set upon returning, go; and Od. xvii. 20, ou) ga\r e)pi\ staqmoi=si me/nein e)/ti thli/kos ei)mi\, w(/s t' e)piteilame/nw| shma/ntori pa/nta piqe/sqai, for I am no longer of a fit age to abide at the sheepfolds, (and there) to obey in everything a master's command (this comes under 587, Od. 2, above). These cases seem to show that the usage was already established; although Lehrs (de Aristarchi Stud. Hom. p. 157) proposes to expunge w(/s te in both. Op. 43 we have r(hidi/ws ga/r ken kai\ e)p' h)/mati e)rga/ssaio, w(/s te/ se kei)s (= kai\ ei)s) e)niauto\n e)/xein kai\ a)ergo\n e)o/nta, i.e. so as to have enough for a year, even without working.
(Tenses.) The tenses of the infinitive most frequently used with w(/ste are the present and aorist, with their usual distinction (87). See the examples above.

The perfect is sometimes used to express completion or decisiveness of the action (109; 110). E.g. *newsti\ a)po\ no/sou braxu/ ti lelwfh/kamen, w(/ste kai\ xrh/masi kai\ toi=s sw/masin hu)ch=sqai, i.e. we have recovered a little, so as to have increased. THUC. vi. 12. *lo/gwn kai\ bouleuma/twn koinwno\n a)/n se poioi=nto, w(/ste mhde\ e(/n se lelhqe/nai w(=n boulo/meqa ei)de/nai, so that not a single one of the things we wish to know should have escaped you. XEN. Cyr. vi. 1, 40. *toiau=ta politeu/mata e(le/sqai (e)moi\ u(ph=rcen) w(/ste polla/kis e)stefanw=sqai, kai\ mhde\ tou\s e)xqrou\s e)pixeirei=n le/gein, k.t.l., so as often to have been crowned (perfect), and so as not even to have my enemies undertake (present) to say, etc. DEM. xviii. 257. See Id. xxiii. 68; LYS. xxxii. 27; ISOC. iii. 32, ISOC. iv. 45; ISAE. x. 1; and the examples quoted in 109 and 110.

1. The future infinitive with w(/ste is common only when it depends on an infinitive in indirect discourse and represents a future indicative of the direct form; so ei)s tou=t' a)naidei/as au)to\n h(/cein a)kou/w, w(/ste *lakedaimoni/wn kathgorh/sein, DEM. xix. 72.So LYS. v. 2. See other examples under 594.

2. Elsewhere it is rare and perhaps doubtful. In DEM. xxix. 5 and xxx. 5, w(/sq' u(ma=s a(/pantas ei)/sesqai is found in all MSS., and it is no more objectionable than other exceptional uses of the future, as that after bou/lomai and de/omai (see 113), or than w(/ste with the infinitive with a)/n not in indirect discourse (211; 592). In DEM. xvi. 4 we have, e)/sti toi/nun e)/n tini toiou/tw| kairw=| ta\ pra/gmata nu=n, . . . w(/ste *qhbai/ois me\n a)sqenei=s gene/sqai, *lakedaimoni/ous d), ei) poih/sontai th\n *)arkadi/an u(f' e(autoi=s, pa/lin i)sxurou\s genh/sesqai, the change of time making the change of tense natural.

In THUC. iii. 34 we have, prokalesa/menos e)s lo/gous *(ippi/an, w(/ste, h)
 mhde
 a)re/skon le/gh|, pa/lin au)to
 katasth/sein e)s to\ tei=xos sw=n kai\ u(gia=, on the condition that, if his proposals should not be satisfactory, he would restore H. to the fort safe and sound. Here katasth/sein represents katasth/sw in the words of Paches; but the future is still exceptional in its use (see 113). In THUC. i. 29, THUC. iii. 28 (two passages) and 114, vii. 83, where there was the same ground for the future, we find the present or aorist infinitive with w(/ste.

The infinitive with a)/n (not in indirect discourse) can follow w(/ste to express a consequence in a potential form, corresponding to the potential optative or indicative. E.g. *)apoteteixisme/noi a)
 h)=san, w(/ste mhd' ei) mete/pemyan e)/ti o(moi/ws a)
 au)tou\s w)felei=n, they would have been already walled in, so that, even if they had sent for them, it would not any longer have been of as much use to them. THUC. vii. 42. *tw=n oi)kei/wn moi pragma/twn toiou/twn sumbebhko/twn w(/ste u(ma=s a)
 a)kou/santas e)leh=sai, such as would make you pity me if you should hear them. L. DEM. 59. *)apolhfqe/ntos, w(/ste mh\ a)
 du/nasqai e)panelqei=n oi)/kade, so that he would not be able to return. Id. viii. 35.See also the examples under 211, and the cases of indirect discourse with w(/ste a)/n under 594. (The translation of the infinitive here is necessarily inexact. See 584.)

Herodotus often writes ou(/tw w(/ste together, ou(/tw referring to the whole leading sentence, and not (as it generally does) to a single word or expression. E.g. *)ape/drh e)s *tege/hn, ta\s me\n nu/ktas poreuo/menos, ta\s de\ h(me/ras katadu/nwn e)s u(/lhn, ou(/tw w(/ste tri/th| eu)fro/nh| gene/sqai e)n *tege/h|, he escaped to Tegea, travelling by night and hiding in the woods by day, (in such wise) as on the third night to arrive at Tegea. HDT. ix. 37.So iii. 105, HDT. viii. 27, HDT. ix. 61, HDT. 73.
For the same usage before a finite verb, see 601 (end).

(*(/wste, with Infinitive in Indirect Discourse. *(/wste ou).) When a clause with w(/ste depends on an infinitive in indirect discourse, and is itself a part of the quotation, its verb representing a finite mood of the direct form, it regularly has the infinitive, in the tense of the direct discourse, even when on other grounds a finite verb would seem more natural. Here the future infinitive and the infinitive with a)/n may be used, as in other indirect discourse (135; 204). The negative ou) of the direct form is generally retained with such an infinitive. E.g. *)/efasan tou\s stratiw/tas ei)s tou=to trufh=s e)lqei=n w(/st' ou)k e)qe/lein pi/nein ei) mh\ a)nqosmi/as ei)/h (they said ei)s tou=to trufh=s h)=lqon w(/ste ou)k h)/qelon pi/nein), they said that the soldiers became so fastidious that they would not drink any wine unless it had a strong bouquet. XEN. Hell. vi. 2, 6. *(uma=s ei)de/nai h(gou=mai tou=ton ou(/tw skaio
 ei)=nai w(/ste ou) du/nasqai maqei=n ta\ lego/mena. LYS. x. 15. *ou(/tw de\ a)to/pous tina\s e)n th=| po/lei ei)=nai w(/ste ou)k ai)sxu/nesqai loidoroume/nous au)tw=| (i.e. ou(/tws a)/topoi w(/ste ou)k ai)sxu/nontai). DEM. xix. 308.So xviii. 283, DEM. xix. 152. *ei)=nai de\ pollou\s a)/llous (sc. e)/fh), ou(\s bou/lesqai koinwnei=n th=s sunta/cews, w(/ste ou)/te xrhma/twn ou)/te stratiwtw=n e)/sesqai a)pori/an (i.e. a)/lloi ei)si
, ou(\s bou/lomai (see 755) koinwnei=n, w(/ste ou)k e)/stai a)pori/a). AESCHIN. iii. 96: so i. 174. *tosou=ton fronh=sai fh\|s au)tou\s w(/ste ou)x h(gh/sasqai sfa=s au)tou\s a)ci/ous ei)=nai zh=n, k.t.l. (i.e. tosou=ton e)fro/nhsan w(/ste ou)x h(gh/santo). ISOC. xii. 255. *ei)=nai de\ (sc. le/getai) taxuth=ta ou)deni\ e(te/rw| o(/moion, ou(/tw w(/ste, ei) mh\ prolamba/nein tou\s *)indou\s th=s o(dou= e)n w(=| tou\s mu/rmhkas sulle/gesqai, ou)de/na a)/n sfewn a)posw/|zesqai (i.e. ei) mh\ prolamba/noien th=s o(dou= e)n w(=| sulle/gointo, ou)dei\s a)
 a)posw/|zoito). HDT. iii. 105 (see 755): so i. 189. *toiau=ta e)nomi/zeto ta\ u(pa/rxonta au)tw=| ei)=nai, w(/ste ou)k a)/n poq' e(te/ras e)piqumh=sai politei/as (i.e. ou)k a)
 e)piqumh/seie). LYS. xviii. 6: so xxi. 18. See also THUC. v. 40, THUC. viii. 76; ISAE. iii. 39, ISAE. xi. 27; PLAT. Ap. 26 D, PLAT. Euthyd. 305 C, Leg. 806A, Alcib. ii. 143D

*(/wste mh/, however, as the ordinary form with the infinitive, may be used in indirect discourse (594), even with the future infinitive or the infinitive with a)/n. E.g. *thlikau/thn h(gei=sqai po/lin oi)kei=n to\ me/geqos, w(/ste mhd' a)
 o(tiou=n h)=| deino
 pei/sesqai. DEM. ix. 67. *)/wimhn ou(/tws e)mfanh\s ei)=nai toi=s a)lazoneuome/nois polemw=n, w(/ste mhde/n' a)/n pote gene/sqai pisto
 tw=n lego/ntwn. ISOC. xii. 20: so xii. 144. In ISAE. iii. 51, w(/ste mhde\ e)kdou=nai would have been the same in the direct form.
Cases of w(/ste with a finite verb in indirect discourse are rare, but sometimes occur; as oi)omai/ s' a)napei/sein, w(/ste ge ou)de\n a)nterei=s, AR. Nub. 1342. So EUR. Tro. 973; Leg. 692

1. Occasionally w(/ste ou) with the infinitive represents a finite mood with ou) of direct discourse, even when there is no preceding infinitive to assimilate it (as there is in all the cases in 594). E.g. *)ennohsa/tw o(/ti ou(/tws h)/dh to/te po/rrw th=s h(liki/as h)=n w(/st), ei) kai\ mh\ to/te, ou)k a)
 pollw=| u(/steron teleuth=sai to
 bi/on, let him reflect that he (Socrates) was then already so far advanced in life that he would have ended his days not much later, etc. (i.e. ou)k a)
 pollw=| u(/steron e)teleu/thsen). XEN. Mem. iv. 8, 1. (Seume classes this with the cases in 597, XEN. Mem. 2 because of ou) pollw=|. But the infinitive depends directly on a clause with o(/ti in indirect discourse.) So in ARISTOT. Pol. ii. 9, 17: le/gousi w(s metedi/dosan th=s politei/as, w(/st' ou) gi/nesqai to/te th
 o)liganqrwpi/an.

2. Sometimes ou) is found with w(/ste and the infinitive when the negative belongs to a single word, as in ou) polloi/ for o)li/goi. See ISOC. viii. 107: ou(/tw kakw=s prou)/sthsan tw=n pragma/twn w(/sq' h(ma=s ou) polloi=s e)/tesin u(/steron pa/lin e)pipola/sai. So ISAE. ix. 17.
In a few cases, however, w(/ste ou) is found with the infinitive where none of the preceding explanations (594; 597) will apply. Such are the following:—

*(/wst' ou)/te nukto\s u(/pnon ou)/t' e)c h(me/ras e)me\ stega/zein h(du
, a)ll' o( prostatw=n xrono\s dih=ge/ m' ai)e
 w(s qanoume/nhn, so that neither by night nor by day did sweet sleep spread her wings over me. SOPH. El. 780. (Here there is an easy transition from the infinitive to the following indicative.) *ou) makra
 ga teixe/wn periptuxai\, w(/st' ou)x a(/panta/ s' ei)de/nai ta\ drw/mena, not so large that you do not know all (i.e. the city is so small, that you know all) that is done. EUR. Ph. 1357. *(/wst' ou)d) i)/xnos ge teixe/wn ei)=nai safe/s, yes; so that not even a trace of the walls is to be seen. Id. Hel. 107. *nu=n de\ perie/sthken ei)s tou=to, w(/ste to
 i)di/a| kinduneu/onta ou) filo/polin a)lla\ filopra/gmona dokei=n ei)=nai. LYCURG. 3. *ou)d' au)= ou(/tws a)/poros h)=n ou)d' a)/filos w(/st' ou)k a)
 e)ceurei=n to
 a)pogra/yonta, nor, moreover, was I so helpless or friendless that I could not find one to bring an a)pografh/ (ou)k a)
 e)ceu/roimi). DEM. liii. 1. *ou(/tw d' a)rxai/ws ei)=xon, ma=llon de\ politikw=s, w(/ste ou)de\ xrhma/twn w)nei=sqai par' ou)deno\s ou)de/n. Id. ix. 48. (This may be explained as oratio obliqua, on the ground of a)kou/w and the infinitive in the preceding clause. But I agree with Seume in thinking this connection too remote to account for w(/ste ou). Here there is neither an assimilating infinitive, as in the examples in 594, nor a leading clause with o(/ti or w(s, as in those in 597, Id. 1.In fact, w(/ste ou) gives the only ground for calling the clause with ei)=xon indirect discourse.)

The examples in 598 have one common character: in all of them the thought could be expressed equally well by w(/ste with the infinitive or w(/ste with a finite verb, for even in EUR. Ph. 1357 and DEM. liii. 1 a fact rather than a mere tendency is expressed. We can, therefore, easily suppose a mixture of two constructions by which, for example in EUR. Hel. 107, instead of w(/ste mh\ ei)=nai or w(/ste ou)k e)/stin, either of which would express the sense, we have w(/ste ou)k ei)=nai.The explanation of w(/ste ou) with the infinitive on the ground of oratio obliqua was first made, I believe, by Shilleto in the Appendix to his Demosthenes de Falsa Legatione (1844). It is also given by Madvig ( Synt.§ 205, Anm. 3), who confines w(/ste ou) to clauses depending on the infinitive of oratio obliqua after verbs like fhmi/, oi)=mai, etc. (i.e. like the examples in 594). Shilleto's faith in his own explanation was somewhat shaken by finding that four of the passages quoted in 598 could not be brought under his canon. Under the influence of Shilleto's essay, I originally suggested the mixture of two equivalent constructions given above, as applicable to all cases of w(/ste ou), not appreciating the wide influence of the principle of oratio obliqua upon the construction. This occasional confusion would be made easier by familiarity with w(/ste ou) and the infinitive in indirect discourse.

In a few cases w(/ste seems to be omitted, even when its antecedent is expressed; as in AESCH. Ag. 478, ti/s w(=de paidno\s h)\ frenw=n kekomme/nos, flogo\s paragge/lmasin ne/ois purwqe/nta kardi/an e)/peit' a)llaga=| lo/gou kamei=n; who is so childish, etc., (as) to be inflamed in heart, etc., and then to suffer from a change of report? See also HDT. iii. 12, ou(/tw i)sxurai\, mo/gis a)\n li/qw| pai/sas diarrh/ceias, so strong, you could hardly break them with a stone.

div2.head: w(/ste with the Finite Moods.
div2.p:
*(/wste with the indicative means properly so that, and expresses the actual result of the action of the leading verb. E.g. *ou(/tws a)gnwmo/nws e)/xete, w(/ste e)lpi/zete au)ta\ xrhsta\ genh/sesqai, k.t.l.; are you so senseless that you expect, etc.? DEM. ii. 26. (Here w(/ste e)lpi/zein, so senseless as to expect, would express the senselessness of expecting, without necessarily implying that you do expect.) *be/bhken, w(/ste pa=n e)n h(su/xw|, pa/ter, e)/cesti fwnei=n, he has gone, so that we can say everything in quiet. SOPH. O.C. 82 . So Ph. 75, El. 1204. *ou(/tws h(mi=n dokei= panto\s a)/cia ei)=nai, w(/ste pa/ntes to\ katalipei=n au)ta\ ma/lista feu/gomen, so that we all especially avoid, etc. XEN. Mem. ii. 2, 3. *ou)x h(=ken: w(/sq' oi( *(/ellhnes e)fro/ntizon. Id. An. ii. 3, Id. An. 25. *ei)s tou=t' a)plhsti/as h)=lqon, w(/st' ou)k e)ch/rkesen au)toi=s e)/xein th
 kata\ gh=n a)rxh
, a)lla\ kai\ th
 kata\ qa/lattan du/namin ou(/tws e)pequ/mhsan labei=n, w(/ste tou\s summa/xous tou\s h(mete/rous a)fi/stasan. ISOC. xii. 103. *tau=ta pepoi/hka a)ko/ntwn *)aqhnai/wn, w(/st), ei)/per eu)= fronei=te, tou/tous me
 e)xqrou\s u(polh/yesqe, e)moi\ de\ pisteu/sete. DEM. xviii. 40. *ou(/tws e)narge/s e)sti, w(/sq' eu(rh/sete. AESCHIN. i. 128. *(/wst' e)a
 te/ttaras mo/non po/leis pei/sh|s, kai\ ta\s a)/llas pollw=n kakw=n a)palla/ceis. ISOC. v. 31. (Examples like w(/st' . . . pisteu/sete in DEM. xviii. 40 might be punctuated in this way.)
So ou(/tw w(/ste in Herodotus (see 593); as e)s pa=n kakou= a)pi/kato, ou(/tw w(/ste a)na/statoi e)gi/nonto, vii. 118.

As w(/ste in this construction has no effect upon the mood of its verb, it may have any construction that would be allowed in an independent sentence. It may thus take a potential optative or indicative with a)/n, a prohibitory subjunctive, an imperative, or an interrogative. E.g. *(/wst' ou)k a)
 au)to
 gnwri/saim' a)
 ei)sidw/n. EUR. Or. 379.
*paqw
 me
 a)nte/drwn, w(/st', ei) fronw=n e)/prasson, ou)d' a)
 w(=d' e)gigno/mhn kako/s. SOPH. O.C. 271.
*(/wst', ei) makra\ h( peri/odos, mh\ qauma/sh|s. PLAT. Phaedr. 274A.
*qnhto\s d' *)ore/sths: w(/ste mh\ li/an ste/ne. SOPH. El. 1172.
*(/wste po/qen i)/sasin; so how do they know? DEM. xxix. 47. So ou) mh/ and the subjunctive (296);
ou(/tws e)pitequ/mhka a)kou=sai, w(/ste . . . ou) mh/ sou a)poleifqw=, PLAT. Phaedr. 227D (see 296, above).

Occasionally there is a change from the infinitive to a finite verb in a sentence after w(/ste, with a corresponding change in meaning; as in THUC. iii. 21, w(/ste pa/rodon mh\ ei)=nai para\ pu/rgon, a)lla\ di) au)tw=n me/swn dih/|esan, i.e. the towers were built SO AS to allow no passage by a tower outside, but SO THAT the men passed through the inside of them. (See 584.)

A few cases occur of a peculiar assimilation of a clause with w(/ste to a preceding optative in protasis, w(/ste having apparently the force of a conditional relative. E.g. *ei)/ tis th
 gunai=ka th
 sh
 ou(/tw qerapeu/seien w(/ste filei=n au)th
 ma=llon poih/seien e(auto
 h)\ se\, a)=r' a)/n se eu)fra/nai; if one should court your wife so as to make her more fond of himself than of you, etc. XEN. Cyr. v. 5, 30 (two MSS. have poih/sein). So v. 3, XEN. Cyr. 47 (ei)/soito). *ei)/ tis xrw=|to tw=| a)rguri/w| w(/ste pria/menos oi(=on e(tai/ran dia\ tau/thn ka/kion me
 to\ sw=ma e)/xoi, ka/kion de\ th
 yuxh
, pw=s a)
 w)fe/limon ei)/h; Id. Oec. i. 13. *katagelasto/teron ei) . . . h(mei=s ei)s tosou=ton mikroyuxi/as e)/lqoimen, w(/ste ta\ prosta/gmata tou/twn u(pomei/naimen (so Cod. Urb.; other MSS. u(pomei=nai). ISOC. vi. 84.

A few cases occur of w(/ste with the optative in indirect discourse. E.g. *)elogi/zonto de\ kai\ to\ i(ppiko\n, w(s to\ me\n a)nti/palon polu\, to\ de\ au)tw=n o)li/gon ei)/h, to\ de\ me/giston, o(/ti oi( nekroi\ u(po\ tw=| tei/xei e)/keinto, w(/ste ou)de\ krei/ttosin ou)=si r(a/|dion ei)/h a)nele/sqai. XEN. Hell. iii. 5, 23. See also ISOC. xvii. 11.

As the regular negative of the infinitive after w(/ste is mh/, so that of the indicative and potential optative is ou). In DEM. xix. 218 we have w(/ste mh/te . . . mh/te . . . mh/te . . . a)lla\ kai\ . . . ei)=ta th\n ei)rh/nhn e)poih/sasqe a)gaphtw=s, where the force of a preceding ei) seems really to govern the verb, that of w(/ste being wasted in the eight lines which separate the verb from it. In DEM. liv. 15, mhd' o(tiou=n e)/stai can be taken with ei). In SOPH. Tr. 575, e)/stai tou=to khlhth/rion, w(/ste mh/tin' ei)sidw\n ste/rcei gunai=ka kei=nos a)nti\ sou= ple/on, i.e. a charm to prevent him from loving more than you any other woman whom he may see, w(/ste mh/ seems to have a final sense with the future, like a final relative. Compare w(/ste mh/ with the infinitive in PLAT. Gorg. 479 C (quoted in 587, 3).

div2.head: w(/ste with the Participle.
div2.p:
(a) As a clause with w(/ste depending on an infinitive in indirect discourse is generally assimilated to that infinitive, so one depending on a participle in indirect discourse may be assimilated to the participle. E.g. *ou)d' ou(/tws a)gnw/mona ou)d' a)/topon ou)de/na (sc. o(rw= o)/nta) w(/ste, ei) mh\ poih/sousin a(/pantes o(/s' a)
 au)to\s, ou) fa/skonta poih/sein ou)de
 ou)d' au)to/n, nor do I see that any one is so unwise or absurd, that, if all will not do whatever he does, he too refuses to do anything (i.e. ou)dei\s ou(/tws a)gnw/mwn e)sti
 w(/ste ou) fa/skei). DEM. x. 40. *ta\ de\ pra/gmata (o(rw=) ei)s tou=to proh/konta, w(/ste o(/pws mh\ peiso/meqa au)toi\ pro/teron kakw=s ske/yasqai de/on, but I see things have come to this, that we must (w(/ste dei=) consider how we may not ourselves suffer harm first. Id. iii. 1. *)epidei/cw *)astu/filon ou(/tw sfo/dra misou=nta tou=ton, w(/ste polu\ a)
 qa=tton diaqe/menon mhde/na pote\ tw=n e(autou= oi)kei/wn dialexqh=nai *kle/wni, ma=llon h)\ to
 tou/tou ui(o
