 poihsa/menon, I will show that Astyphilus so hates him, that he would much sooner have ordered in his will that no one of his relatives should ever speak to Cleon, than have adopted his son as his own (polu\ a)
 qa=tton die/qeto). ISAE. ix. 16.Other examples are [DEM. ] Erot. 3; ISOC. iv. 64; PLAT. Rep. 519 A.
(b) In two cases there is a like assimilation to a participle not in indirect discourse:—

*tw=n qeatw=n sumfiloneikou/ntwn e)kei/nw| kai\ misou/ntwn tou=ton, w(/ste tw=n xorw=n to\n me\n e)painou/ntwn, tou= d' a)kroa/sasqai ou)k e)qelo/ntwn. AND. iv. 20. *suggnw/mhn e)/xein ei), proelhluqw\s ei)s tou=to w(/ste u(po\ tw=n e)mautou= dou/lwn u(brisqei\s, ou) du/namai katasxei=n, k.t.l. DEM. xlv. 83.

The last examples seem to show that clauses with w(/ste can be assimilated to a preceding participle as we have seen them assimilated to an optative (604). Compare with this construction ISOC. iv. 21, ou)dei\s ga\r a)\n e(te/ran po/lin e)pidei/ceie tosou=ton e)n tw=| pole/mw| tw=| kata\ gh=n u(pere/xousan, o(/son th\n h(mete/ran e)n toi=s kindu/nois toi=s kata\ qa/lattan diafe/rousan.

div2.head: w(s used like w(/ste.
div2.p: In their original use w(s and w(/s te are related precisely as o(/s and o(/s te in Homer. But in consecutive sentences w(/ste gradually gained almost exclusive control, so that w(s here became very rare. *(ws occurs chiefly in Aeschylus, Sophocles, Herodotus, and Xenophon, where it is used in the same constructions and in the same sense as w(/ste. E.g.

(With Infin.) *(/hkousin e)kfugo/ntes: w(s ste/nein po/lin *persw=n. AESCH. Pers. 510. *pepwkw/s g), w(s qrasu/nesqai ma=llon, bro/teion ai(=ma, kw=mos e)n do/mois me/nei, having drunk of mortals' blood so as to be more emboldened, a band of revellers abides in the house. Id. Ag. 1188.So Pers. 437, Ag. 546, Eum. 36, Eum. 427, Eum. 799, Eum. 895. *su/mmetros ga w(s klu/ein, for he is near enough for us to hear. SOPH. O.T. 84. *ou)d' u(po\ zugw=| lo/fon dikai/ws ei)=xon, w(s/ ste/rgein e)me/. Id. Ant. 292.So Id. Tr. 1125. *ou)k e)s tou=to a)frosu/nhs a)piko/menos w(s do/cai th
 e(wutou= du/namin perie/sesqai th=s basile/os. HDT. iii. 146. *(uyhlo
 de\ ou(/tw dh/ ti le/getai, w(s ta\s korufa\s au)tou= ou)x oi(=a/ te ei)=nai i)de/sqai, and it (the mountain) is said to be so high, that it is not possible to see its summits. Id. iv. 184. *(o potamo\s tosou=tos to\ ba/qos, w(s mhde\ ta\ do/rata u(pere/xein tou= ba/qous. XEN. An. iii. 5, 7. So ii. 3, XEN. An. 10. *fe/rontai kw/qwna, w(s a)po\ tou= potamou= a)ru/sasqai. Id. Cyr. i. 2, Id. Cyr. 8. *)en tw=| a)sfalei= h)/dh e)/somai, w(s mhde
 a)
 e)/ti kako
 paqei=n. Ib. viii. 7, Ib. 27.See iv. 2, Ib. 8. *ou(/tw ga dokou=men pareskeua/sqai w(s, h)
 me
 a)lhqeu/hte, Ib. i (kanoi\ ei)=nai u(ma=s eu)= poiei=n: h)
 de\ e)capata=te, ou(/tw nomi/zomen e)/xein w(s ou)x h(ma=s e)f) u(mi=n e)/sesqai, a)lla\ ma=llon u(ma=s e)f) h(mi=n genh/sesqai. Ib. iv. 2, Ib. 13. (In the last clauses we have w(s in indirect discourse, like w(/ste in 594, the direct form being ou)x h(mei=s e)so/meqa, a)lla\ ma=llon u(mei=s genh/sesqe. Most MSS., however, have gene/sqai.)

(With Indic.) *pro\s ta/d' w(s *sou/swn me
 a)/stu pa=n kenandri/an ste/nei. AESCH. Pers. 730. *ou(/tws e)/xei g' h( pi/stis, w(s to\ me
 dokei=n e)/nesti, pei/ra| d' ou) proswmi/lhsa/ pw, so stands my confidence, that belief is in it, while I have had nothing to do yet with testing it. SOPH. Tr. 590. *ou(/tw dh/ ti kleinh\ e)ge/neto w(s kai\ oi( pa/ntes *(/ellhnes *(rodw/pios to\ ou)/noma e)ce/maqon, i.e. so that all the Greeks came to know well the name of Rhodopis. HDT. ii. 135. *tou/tw| prosfile/es ou(/tw dh/ ti e)ge/nonto w(/s sfeas e)ke/leue th=s e(autou= xw/rhs oi)kh=sai. HDT. i. 163.So iii. 130. *ou(/tw moi proqu/mws e)boh/qhsas w(s nu=n to\ me
 e)p' e)moi\ oi)/xomai, to\ d' e)pi\ soi\ se/swsmai. XEN. Cyr. v. 4, 11. *tosou/tw| pleonekth/sei w(s peinh/sas tw=n h(di/stwn siti/wn teu/cetai. Ib. vii. 5, Ib. 81.So Hell. iv. 4, Hell. 16.

Besides the authors above mentioned, Euripides has one example of w(s with the infinitive like w(/ste, Cycl. 647; Thucydides one, vii. 34; and Plato one, Rep. 365D. We have w(s with the indicative in PLAT. Men. 71 A; and with the participle in XEN. Cyr. vii. 5, 46 , and PLAT. Tim. 56 C (w(s here having both the participle and the infinitive).
For w(s with the infinitive after the comparative and h)/, see 764.

div2.head: e)f' w(=| and e)f' w(=|te with the Infinitive and the Future Indicative.
div2.p: 1. *)ef' w(=| and e)f' w(=|te, on condition that, for the purpose of, take the infinitive, like w(/ste in some of its senses. E.g. *ei)=pen o(/ti spei/sasqai bou/loito, e)f' w(=| mh/te au)to\s tou\s *(/ellhnas a)dikei=n mh/te e)kei/nous kai/ein ta\s oi)ki/as, lamba/nein te ta)pith/deia o(/swn de/ointo. XEN. An. iv. 4, 6. *pw=s a)\n ou(=tos e)qe/loi ta\ a)llo/tria a)posterei=n e)f' w(=| kako/docos ei)=nai; Ag. iv. 1. *)afi/eme/n se, e)pi\ tou/tw| me/ntoi, e)f' w(=|te mhke/ti filosofei=n, on condition that you will no longer be a philosopher. PLAT. Ap. 29 C. *ai(reqe/ntes e)f' w(=|te cuggra/yai no/mous, kaq' ou(/stinas politeu/sointo, for the purpose of compiling laws. XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 11. (For politeu/sointo, see 574.) *diwmologh/qh au)tw=| a)postalh/sesqai *)aqh/naze tou= e)niautou= e(ka/stou mna=s ei)/kosi, e)f' w(=|te bohqh/sein toi=s *)amfisseu=sin. AESCHIN. iii. 114. (For the future infinitive, see 113.)

2. Herodotus and Thucydides sometimes have e)f' w(=| or e)f' w(=|te, on condition that, with the future indicative. E.g. *)epi\ tou/tw| de\ u(peci/stamai th=s a)rxh=s, e)f' w(=|te u(p' ou)deno\s u(me/wn a)/rcomai, I withdraw upon this condition, that I shall be ruled by none of you. HDT. iii. 83. *tou/toisi d' w)=n pi/sunos e)w\n kath/gage, e)f' w(=|te oi( a)po/gonoi au)tou= i(rofa/ntai tw=n qew=n e)/sontai. Id. vii. 153. *kai\ th\n *boiwti/an e)ce/lipon *)aqhnai=oi pa=san, sponda\s poihsa/menoi e)f' w(=| tou\s a)/ndras komiou=ntai. THUC. i. 113. *cune/bhsan e)f' w(=|te e)ci/asin e)k *peloponnh/sou u(po/spondoi kai\ mhde/pote e)pibh/sontai au)th=s, they made an agreement with the condition that they should depart from Peloponnesus under truce, and never again set foot in it. Id. i. 103.

div2.head: Temporal Particles signifying Until and Before.: e(/ws, o)/fra, ei)s o(/ or ei)so/ke, e)/ste, a)/xri, me/xri, until.
div2.p: Temporal Particles signifying Until and Before.: e(/ws,In Homer, where the form e(/ws would seldom suit the verse, ei)/ws or ei)=os is commonly written. o)/fra, ei)s o(/ or ei)so/ke, e)/ste, a)/xri, me/xri, until.

All of these words are used also in the sense of while, so long as, and have the constructions of ordinary relative clauses (514). In common with dum, donec, and quoad in Latin, and while or whiles in Elizabethan English,He shall conceal it whiles (= until) you are willing it shall come to note. Shakespeare. Twelfth Night, iv. 3. they mean not only during the time when, but also up to the time when. As relatives, in the former sense they can have an antecedent like te/ws, so long, e(/ws etc. meaning as; in the latter sense they can have one like me/xri tou/tou, down to that time, e(/ws etc. supplementing this by at which or when. The idea of a clause with until is that the action (or negation) of the leading clause continues to a time at which that of the dependent clause takes place. That the former action then ceases is an inference generally made, but not positively implied in the language, and not necessary. Our word until thus includes what the Greek may express by me/xri tou/tou e(/ws or (omitting the antecedent) by e(/ws alone.
*te/ws is occasionally used like e(/ws, as in DEM. xxi. 16.

A clause with until referring to an actual past occurrence (613) is simply a temporal clause of this peculiar character, with the construction of a relative clause with a definite antecedent (519). But when it refers to the future, it becomes a conditional relative clause, and maxou=mai e(/ws a)
 th
 po/lin e(/lw, I shall (continue to) fight to the time at which I shall take the city, has the conditional force which comes from the indefinite antecedent; for even if me/xri tou/tou were inserted here, it would denote no definite period, but only one limited or conditioned by the future capture of the city. The actual apodosis to the condition is not maxou=mai alone, but rather the whole implied idea, I shall go on fighting to the future time, the limit of which is set by e(/ws a)
 e(/lw. It has been seen (486; 490) that ordinary conditional clauses may condition not their expressed leading clause, but one which the context implies; as cummaxi/an poiou=men, h)/n tis e)f' h(ma=s i)/h|, we are making an alliance, (to be ready) in case any one shall attack us. Again, a conditional clause may refer to an object which is aimed at in the action of the leading verb; as *pa/troklon e)/fepe i(/ppous, ei)/ ke/n min e(/lh|s, turn your horses on P., if haply you may take him, i.e. that you may take him, if haply you may (487, 1). In like manner a conditional relative clause with until is very apt to refer to an object aimed at, and thus to become at once final, relative, and conditional: thus in Il. iii. 291 (see 613, Il. 3), it is distinctly implied that the end of the war (te/los pole/moio) is a condition which is to limit the time of fighting, and also an object at which the fighting aims. The same is true in general of the other forms of conditional relative sentence which the clause with until may take. It will be seen (614, Il. 2) that in the Odyssey e(/ws develops a peculiar force in this direction, which makes it almost a final particle.

(*(/ews.) 1. When e(/ws, until, refers to a definite past action, it takes the indicative, usually the aorist. E.g. *nh=xon pa/lin, ei(=os e)ph=lqon ei)s potamo/n, I swam on again until I came into a river. Od. vii. 280. *au)ta\r o( pezo\s qu=ne dia\ proma/xwn, ei(/ws fi/lon w)/lese qumo/n. Il. xi. 341.So Od. v. 123. *oi)mwgh\ katei=xe pelagi/an a(/la, e(/ws kelainh=s nukto\s o)/mm' a)fei/leto, until the eye of dark night interrupted. AESCH. Pers. 426. *pi/nei e(/ws e)qe/rmhn' au)to\n a)mfiba=sa flo\c oi)/nou. EUR. Alc. 758. *)/emeinan e(/ws a)fi/konto oi( strathgoi/. XEN. Hell. i. 1, 29. *kai\ tou=t' e)poi/oun e(/ws e)k th=s xw/ras a)ph=n. Id. Cyr. iii. 3, Id. Cyr. 4. *ou) pro/teron e)pau/santo, e(/ws th\n po/lin ei)s sta/seis kate/sthsan. LYS. xxv. 26. *me/xri tou/tou fi/los w)noma/zeto, e(/ws prou)/dwken *)/olunqon. DEM. xviii. 48.
In the last two examples pro/teron and me/xri tou/tou are antecedents of e(/ws, until, as te/ws often corresponds to e(/ws, while.

2. When a clause with e(/ws, until, refers to a result which was not attained in past time in consequence of the non-fulfilment of a condition, it takes a past tense of the indicative, like a conditional relative clause in a similar case (528). E.g. *(hde/ws a)
 tou/tw| e)/ti dielego/mhn, e(/ws au)tw=| th
 tou= *)amfi/onos a)pe/dwka r(h=sin a)nti\ th=s tou= *zh/qou, I should gladly have continued to talk with him, until I had paid him back Amphion's speech in return for Zethus's. PLAT. Gorg. 506B. *ou)k a)
 e)pauo/mhn, e(/ws a)pepeira/qhn th=s sofi/as tauthsi/. Crat. 396C. *)episxw
 a)
, e(/ws oi( plei=stoi tw=n ei)wqo/twn gnw/mhn a)pefh/nanto, . . . h(suxi/an a)
 h)=gon, i.e. I should have waited until most of the regular speakers had declared their opinion, etc. DEM. iv. 1. (For a)/n here, see 223.) So AR. Pac. 71. In LYS. xxii. 12 we have e(/ws e)pe/lipe after e)xrh=n fai/nesqai.
The leading verb must be an indicative with a)/n, or some other form implying the non-fulfilment of a condition. (See 559.)

3. When a clause with e(/ws refers to the future, and depends on a verb of future time (not an optative), e(/ws has a)/n or ke/ and the subjunctive, like a conditional relative clause (529). E.g. *maxh/somai au)=qi me/nwn, ei(/ws ke te/los pole/moio kixei/w, I shall remain here and fight, until I (shall) find an end of the war. Il. iii. 291.So xxiv. 183. *(/ews d' a)
 ou)=n pro\s tou= paro/ntos e)kma/qh|s, e)/x' e)lpi/da, until you learn the whole from him who was present, continue to hope. SOPH. O.T. 834. So AR. Nub. 1489. *me/xri ga tou/tou nomi/zw xrh=nai kathgorei=n, e(/ws a)
 qana/tou do/ch| tw=| feu/gonti a)/cia ei)rga/sqai , for so far do I think I ought to proceed in my accusation, until it shall appear that deeds deserving death have been done by the defendant. LYS. xii. 37. *dei= mh\ perime/nein e(/ws a)
 e)pistw=sin, we must not wait until they are upon us. ISOC. iv. 165. *ou)k a)name/nomen e(/ws a)
 h( h(mete/ra xw/ra kakw=tai, we are not waiting until our land shall be ravaged (i.e. until the ravaging shall be going on). XEN. Cyr. iii. 3, 18. The present subjunctive is rare; but when it is needed, it is unobjectionable: see THUC. i. 90 (quoted in 614, THUC. 1).

4. When a clause with e(/ws refers to the future and depends on an optative with a)/n, it generally has the optative (without a)/n) by assimilation, like a conditional relative clause (531). E.g. *ei) de\ pa/nu spouda/zoi fagei=n, ei)/poim' a)
 o(/ti para\ tai=s gunaici/n e)stin, e(/ws paratei/naimi tou=ton, but if he should be very eager to eat, I should tell him that his dinner is with the women, until I put him to torture. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 11. *kai\ to\ me
 a)
 e)calei/foien, to\ de\ pa/lin e)ggra/foien, e(/ws o(/ti ma/lista a)nqrw/peia h)/qh qeofilh= poih/seian, and they would blot out one thing and again put in another, until they made human characters as pleasing as possible to God. PLAT. Rep. 501B. *(wsau/tws a)
 didoi/hs (lo/gon), e(/ws e)pi/ ti i(kano
 e)lqois. Plat. Phaed. 101D. So after an infinitive depending on an optative; as de/oito/ g' a)
 au)tou= me/nein e(/ws a)pe/lqois, he would ask him to remain until you departed (should depart). XEN. Cyr. v. 3, 13. In Hom. Od. ii. 77 we have e(/ws ke with the optative (542): to/fra ga a)
 kata\ a)/stu potiptussoi/meqa mu/qw| xrh/mat' a)paiti/zontes, e(/ws k' a)po\ pa/nta do qei/h. In PLAT. Phaed. 101 D, e(/ws a)
 ske/yaio represents e(/ws a)
 ske/ywmai of direct discourse (see 702).
The optative with e(/ws is most common after past tenses, in the construction of 614.

5. When the clause introduced by e(/ws, until, depends upon a verb denoting a customary or repeated action or a general truth, and refers in a general way to any act or acts of a given class, it takes a)/n and the subjunctive after primary tenses, and the simple optative after secondary tenses. (See 532.) E.g. *(\a d' a)
 a)su/ntakta h)=|, a)na/gkh tau=ta a)ei\ pra/gmata pare/xein, e(/ws a)
 xw/ran la/bh|, they must always make trouble until they are put in order. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 37.
*poiou=men tau=q' e(ka/stoq', e(/ws a)
 au)to
 e)mba/lwmen e)s kako/n, we always treat him thus, until we cast him into trouble. AR. Nub. 1458.
*perieme/nomen ou)=n e(ka/stote, e(/ws a)noixqei/h to\ desmwth/rion, we waited every day until the prison was opened. PLAT. Phaed. 59D.

(Final use of e(/ws.) 1. It will be seen by the examples under 613 (see the first under 3 and the first three under 4) that the clause with e(/ws very often implies a purpose, the attainment of which is aimed at or expected. When such a clause, implying a purpose which would originally be expressed by a subjunctive, depends on a past tense, it generally takes the optative; but the subjunctive also may be used, to retain the mood in which the purpose would be originally conceived, as in final clauses (318). E.g. *ou)d' e)/tlh po/sios ei)/rusqai me/ga dw=ma diampere\s, ei(=os i(/koito, nor did she dare to guard her husband's great house constantly until he should come. Od. xxiii. 150. *(hsu/xaze tw=| stra/tw|, e(/ws toi=s *)amprakiw/tais de/oi bohqei=n, he kept quiet until it should be necessary to help the Ambraciots. THUC. iii. 102. (The present optative is rare.) So LYS. xiii. 25. *sponda\s e)poih/santo, e(/ws a)paggelqei/h ta\ lexqe/nta ei)s *lakedai/mona, they made a truce, (to continue) until what had been said should be announced at Sparta. XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 20. (Here e(/ws a)
 a)paggelqh=| might have been used, as in the following examples.) *(/ews d' a)
 tau=ta diapra/cwntai, fulakh
 kai\ misqo
 toi=s frouroi=s e(\c mhnw=n kate/lipe. Ib. v. 3, Ib. 25. *)all' e)pisxei=n (tou\s pre/sbeis e)ke/leuen) me/xri tosou/tou, e(/ws a)
 to\ tei=xos i(kano
 ai)/rwsin w(/ste a)poma/xesqai, but he bade them detain the ambassadors until they (the Athenians) should be getting their wall high enough to defend. THUC. i. 90. (Most editors emend ai)/rwsin to the aorist a)/rwsin, which with e(/ws would mean until they should get the wall high enough, the former being less definite and exact in its time, and therefore more appropriate here.)
For the intermediate form of e(/ws a)/n with the optative in such sentences, see SOPH. Tr. 687, AND. i. 81, ISOC. xvii. 15 (in 702).
2. In five passages in the Odyssey e(/ws with the optative after a past tense has an unusually strong final force, so that it appears almost like a final particle.

*pe/mpe de/ min pro\s dw/mat' *)odussh=os, ei(/ws *phnelo/peian o)durome/nhn goo/wsan pau/seie klauqmoi=o, she sent her to the house of Ulysses, (to the end) that she might cause Penelope to cease her lamenting. iv. 799. *)=wrse d' e)pi\ kraipno\n *bore/hn pro\ de\ ku/mat' e)/acen, e(/ws o(/ ge *faih/kessi filhre/tmoisi migei/h, and she roused swift Boreas and broke the waves before him, that Ulysses might come to the oar-loving Phaeacians. v. 385. *moxlo\n u(po\ spodou= h)/lasa pollh=s, ei(/ws qermai/noito, I pushed the club under the deep ashes, that it might be heated (to remain until it should be heated). ix. 375. So dw=ken e)/laion, ei(/ws xutlw/saito, vi. 79; and a)rw/menos ei(=os i(/koito, xix. 367.

In none of these cases will until express the final force of the clause with e(/ws. It appears as if e(/ws here began the same course by which o)/fra, w(s, and o(/pws became final particles (312-314), but did not complete the change.

(*)/ofra.) In epic poetry o)/fra, until, is used like e(/ws. E.g. *(\ws me\n *qrh/ikas a)/ndras e)pw/|xeto *tude/os ui(o\s, o)/fra duw/dek' e)/pefnen, until he had slain twelve. Il. x. 488. *)=hrx' i)/men, o)/fr' a)fi/konto kata\ strato\n, h(=| min a)nw/gei. Il. xiii. 329. *)/hien, o)/fra me/ga spe/os i(/keto. Od. v. 57. (See 613, Od. 1.)

*)alla\ me/n), o)/fra ke/ toi melihde/a oi)=non e)nei/kw, but wait, until I shall bring you honey-sweet wine. Il. vi. 258. *to/fra d' e)pi\ *trw/essi ti/qei kra/tos, o)/fr' a)
 *)axaioi\ ui(o
 e)mo
 ti/swsin, o)fe/llwsi/n te/ e( timh=|. Il. i. 509.So Il. xv. 232. (See 613, Il. 3.)

*nwleme/ws d' e)xo/mhn, o)/fr' e)ceme/seien o)pi/ssw i(sto\n kai\ tro/pin au)=tis, I clung steadfastly, until she (Charybdis) should vomit forth again the mast and keel. Od. xii. 437. (See 614, Od. 1.)

(*ei)s o(/ ke and e)s o(/.) Homer uses ei)s o(/ ke (or ei)so/ke), until, like e(/ws ke, with the subjunctive, and once with the optative. Herodotus uses e)s o(/ and e)s ou(=, until, like e(/ws, with the indicative, and e)s o(\ a)/n with the subjunctive. E.g. *mi/mnete ei)s o(/ ke a)/stu me/ga *pria/moio e(/lwmen, wait until we capture Priam's great city. Il. ii. 331. *(/uyi d' e)p' eu)na/wn o(rmi/ssomen, ei)s o(/ ken e)/lqh| nu\c a)mbro/th, and we will moor them far out by stones, until divine night shall come. Il. xiv. 77.In Il. xv. 70 we have ei)s o(/ k' *)axaioi\ *)/ilion e(/loien, depending on an optative with a)/n (613, Il. 4; 542).

*ou(=tos de\ a)nhkou/stee/ te kai\ lo/gon ei)=xe ou)de/na, e)s o(\ e)/labe th
 di/khn, but he disobeyed and paid no attention to me, until he got his punishment. HDT. i. 115. *(o *dhio/khs h)=n pollo\s ai)neo/menos, e)s o(\ tou=ton kataine/ousi basile/a sfi/si ei)=nai. Id. i. 98.So i. 158, Id. 202; v. 92; vi. 75. *)apei=xon th=s e)ceure/sios ou)de
 e)/lasson, e)s ou(= dh\ *li/xhs a)neu=re. Id. i. 67. (Many editors change e)s ou(= to e)s o(/.) In ii. 143, e(/ws ou(= a)pe/decan a(pa/sas au)ta/s, until they had shown them all, e(/ws ou(= of the MSS. is generally emended to e)s o(/. *)all' au)ta\ e)gw\ tw=| *(/ellhni cei/nw| fula/cw, e)s o(\ a)
 au)to\s e)lqw
 e)kei=nos a)pagage/sqai e)qe/lh|, I shall keep them until he comes himself and wishes to take them away. Id. ii. 115.
A singular case of e)s o(/ occurs in THUC. v. 66, e)s o(\ e)me/mnhnto, as far back as they remembered (Schol. meta\ th\n tw=n a)nqrw/pwn mnh/mhn).

(*)/este.) *)/este, until, is not found in Homer, but is used like e(/ws in tragedy, in Attic prose (especially in Xenophon), and in Herodotus. E.g. *xro/non ta/d' h)=n tosou=ton, e)/st' e)n ai)qe/ri me/sw| kate/sth lampro\s h(li/ou ku/klos kai\ kau=m' e)/qalpe. SOPH. Ant. 415: so SOPH. El. 753; AESCH. Prom. 457. *cunei=ron a)pio/ntes, e)/ste e)pi\ tai=s skhnai=s e)ge/nonto, they marched away without stopping, until they came to the tents. XEN. Cyr. vii. 5, 6 ; so XEN. An. iii. 4, 49.

*th
 parou=san a)ntlh/sw tu/xhn, e)/st' a)
 *dio\s fro/nhma lwfh/sh| xo/lou AESCH. Prom. 375 ; so 697. *)/afqoggon ei)=nai to
 palamnai=on no/mos, e)/st' a)
 sfagai\ kaqaima/cwsi, it is the law that the murderer shall be speechless until streams of blood have been poured upon him. Id. Eum. 448. *au)tou= th=|de mene/omen e)/st' a)
 kai\ teleuth/swmen. HDT. vii. 141. *perime/nete e)/st' a)
 e)gw\ e)/lqw. XEN. An. v. 1, 4.

*)epimei=nai keleu/santes e)/ste bouleu/sainto, e)qu/onto, bidding them wait until they had consulted, they made sacrifice. An. v. 5, An. 2. (*)/est' a)
 bouleu/swntai might have been retained from the direct form, as in the next example.) *)apekri/nato fula/ttein au)ta\, e)/st' a)
 au)to\s e)lqw
 la/bh| ta\ dw=ra, until he should come and take the gifts. Hell. iii. 1, Hell. 15.So An. vii. 1, An. 33; HDT. viii. 4.

p.foreign: *(opo/te w(/ra ei)/h a)ri/stou, a)ne/menen au)tou\s e)/ste e)mfa/goie/n ti, w(s mh\ boulimiw=|en,
p.quote: he always waited until they had eaten something.

div2.p: (*)/axri and me/xri.) *)/axri and me/xri, until, are used like e(/ws, but chiefly in prose and in later Greek. E.g. *kai\ tau=ta e)poi/oun me/xri sko/tos e)ge/neto, until darkness came on. XEN. An. iv. 2, 4 ; so iii. 4, XEN. An. 8. *ei(sth/kei me/xri e(/ws e)ge/neto. PLAT. Symp. 220D.

*me/xri d' a)\n e)gw\ h(/kw, ai( spondai\ meno/ntwn, but until I come, let the truce remain. XEN. An. ii. 3, 24 ; so i. 4, XEN. An. 13. *ei)=pe toi=s profu/laci keleu/ein tou\s kh/rukas perime/nein a)/xri a)\n sxola/sh|, to wait until he should find leisure. Ib. ii. 3, Ib. 2. *me/xri de\ tou=to i)/dwmen, mene/omen par' h(mi=n au)toi=si, but until we see this, we shall remain by ourselves. HDT. iv. 119 (for the omission of a)/n see 620). Herodotus prefers the form with ou(= (619).
*)/axri is much less common in this sense than me/xri. The forms a)/xris and me/xris are not used by the best writers.

*)/axri ou(= and me/xri ou(= are used like a)/xri and me/xri. E.g. *tw=n de\ tau=ta praca/ntwn, a)/xri ou(= o(/de o( lo/gos e)gra/feto, *tisi/fonos presbu/tatos w)
 tw=n a)delfw=n th
 a)rxh
 ei)=xe. XEN. Hell. vi. 4, 37. So Cyr. v. 4, Cyr. 16; THUC. v. 26; HDT. i. 187, HDT. vii. 60. *tou\s *(/ellhnas a)pelu/sato doulei/as, w(/st' e)leuqe/rous ei)=nai me/xri ou(= pa/lin au)toi\ au(tou\s katedoulw/santo. PLAT. Menex. 245A.

*paradi/dwmi e)nteila/menos qei=nai/ min e)s e)/rhmon o)/ros kai\ fula/ssein a)/xri ou(= teleuth/sh|, to watch him until he dies. HDT. i. 117 (see 614). *katati/qetai e)s *te/nedon me/xri ou(= toi=s *)aqhnai/ois ti do/ch|, until the Athenians shall pass some vote about them (see 620). THUC. iii. 28.

(Omission of a)/n.) *)/an is sometimes omitted after e(/ws and the other particles meaning until (including pri/n), when they take the subjunctive. This is most frequent in tragic poetry, but it occurs sometimes with e)s o(/ or e)s ou(= in Herodotus, and with me/xri and me/xri (or a)/xri) ou(= in Herodotus and Thucydides. E.g. *(/ews to\ xai/rein kai\ to\ lupei=sqai ma/qh|s. SOPH. Aj. 555.
*)arh/get' e)/st' e)gw\ melhqw=. Ib. 1183. So O. C. 77, Tr. 148, Ph. 764. *)es ou(= a)poqa/nwsi h)/ sfi pareureqh=| ti a)/dikon, me/xri tou/tou. HDT. iii. 31. *mhde/na e)kbh=nai me/xri plou=s ge/nhtai, that nobody should leave the ship before she sailed. THUC. i. 137. *au)tou\s e)s fulakh\n dieko/misan, me/xri ou(= *)aqh/naze pemfqw=sin. Id. iv. 46; see iv. 16 and 41, and iii. 28 (quoted in 619). See also me/xri de\ tou=to i)/dwmen, HDT. iv. 119, and a)/xri ou(= teleuth/sh|, Id. i. 117.
The only case in Homer of this omission of ke/ or a)/n is the doubtful one, e)/xei ko/ton o)/fra tele/ssh|, Il. i. 82, where o)/fra may perhaps be final. (See 468.)
For pri/n without a)/n with the subjunctive, even in Attic prose, see 648.

div2.head: pri/n, before, until: Meaning and General Use of pri/n.
div2.p: pri/n, before, untilGeschichtliche Entwickelung der Constructionen mit *pri/n, von Josef Sturm: Heft 3 of Schanz's Beiträge.: Meaning and General Use of pri/n.

*pri/n was originally a comparative adverb (= pro/teron and pa/ros), formed from pro/ and meaning before. It appears in the usual adverbial relations; as pri/n moi u(pe/sxeto, he once promised me; pri
 w)/n, having been of old; e)n tw=| pri
 xro/nw|, in the former time; and it once takes the genitive like a preposition in PIND. Py. iv. 43, pri
 w(/ras, before its time. With the infinitive it originally expressed a simple temporal relation, pri
 e)lqei=n being the equivalent of the later pro\ tou= e)lqei=n, before going. With the finite moods pri/n always expresses a limit of time and means until, like e(/ws, having become a conjunction, not losing, however, its original meaning of before. From this original comparative meaning, pri/n has a negative force, implying that something does or does not happen before (i.e. in the absence of) another event; so that ou)/pw or mh/pw with a temporal participle may generally be substituted for pri/n and the infinitive. Thus, in nai=e de\ *ph/daion pri
 e)lqei=n ui(=as *)axaiw=n, Il. xiii. 172, for pri
 e)lqei=n, before they came, we could substitute ou)/pw e)lqo/ntwn, etc. So pri
 a)/n with the subjunctive is often interchangeable with h)
 mh/, and always implies it; thus mh\ a)pe/lqh|s pri
 a)
 a)kou/sh|s, do not depart until you hear, implies h)
 mh\ a)kou/sh|s, without hearing. One result of this negative character of pri/n is its strong affinity for the aorist, the tense which denotes simple occurrence. (See Jour. Phil. ii. pp. 466 ff.)

In Homeric Greek pri/n generally takes the primitive construction with the infinitive without regard to the nature of the leading verb. In lyric poetry, Herodotus, and Attic Greek, pri/n takes the infinitive chiefly when the leading clause is affirmative; otherwise, it takes one of the finite moods, like e(/ws, having the sense of until. But, while the indicative may sometimes follow pri/n, meaning until, when the leading clause is affirmative, the subjunctive and optative are never used unless the leading clause is negative or involves a negative idea.

div2.head: Development of the Constructions with pri/n.
div2.p: The Attic uses of pri/n with the indicative, subjunctive, and optative, are seen in a primitive stage of development in Homer. The construction of pri/n itself with the indicative was yet unknown; but four cases of pri/n g' o(/te with the indicative show a tendency in this direction. Six cases of pri/n (without a)/n or ke/) with the subjunctive and one with the optative (in indirect discourse) mark the beginning of the later usage with these moods. On the other hand, 81 cases of pri/n with the infinitive show the prevailing Homeric construction. Here, as in all periods of the language, when pri/n takes the infinitive, we have simply a statement of fact, that one thing precedes another; in nai=e de\ *ph/daion pri\n e)lqei=n ui(=as *)axaiw=n, and he dwelt in Pedaeum before the coming of the sons of the Greeks, pri\n e)lqei=n implies no more than pro\ a)fi/cews or the later pro\ tou= e)lqei=n. Any further idea that may be implied comes from the context, and is not found in the words. This use of pri/n has little analogy in Greek syntax, its nearest parallel being the later use of w(/ste or w(s with the infinitive. The simplest theory, which best suits the Homeric usage, seems to be that pri/n has a quasi-prepositional relation to the infinitive, which is a verbal noun, a relation the same in effect as that of pro/ in pro\ tou= e)lqei=n in the later Attic construction. (See XEN. Mem. ii. 6, 6 , and DEM. xix. 73.) A similar use of a)nti/ with the infinitive in a few cases in Herodotus (see 803) shows a tendency to go further in the same direction.

The Homeric language was generally contented with the simple pri/n and the infinitive, even when it was implied that the clause with pri/n set a limit to the action (or negation) of the leading clause, i.e. when pri/n could be expressed by until. So in Il. xxi. 100, pri
 *pa/troklon e)pispei=n ai)/simon h)=mar, to/fra ti/ moi pefide/sqai fi/lteron h)=en *trw/wn, i.e. until the death of Patroclus I preferred to spare the Trojans (which he will no longer do); and xix. 312, ou)de/ ti qumw=| te/rpeto pri
 pole/mou sto/ma du/menai, i.e. he felt no pleasure until he entered the battle; in both cases the Attic Greek might have used pri/n with the indicative. So also when the clause with pri/n is future and conditional; as in Il. xix. 423, ou) lh/cw pri
 *trw=as a)/dhn e)la/sai pole/moio, I will not stop until I have given the Trojans enough of war. It was in cases like the last, where the mere temporal pri
 e)la/sai expresses the future condition very imperfectly, that the need of a more exact form was first felt. The need existed only after negative sentences, as here only could such a future condition be expressed by pri/n consistently with its original meaning before. I shall not cease fighting until (before) I see the end of the war contains a future condition (= h)
 mh/) which pri/n can properly express; but the equivalent affirmative, I shall go on fighting until I see the end of the war, could not be expressed by pri/n, as we cannot substitute before for until, but it would require e(/ws, which is until with no sense of before. The forms of parataxis suggested a simple and natural way of meeting this want, through the adverbial use of pri/n. In a sentence like ou)de/ min a)nsth/seis: pri
 kai\ kako
 a)/llo pa/qh|sqa, nor will you recall him to life:—sooner than this will you suffer some new affliction, Il. xxiv. 551, we have only to remove the colon and make pri/n a conjunction to obtain the regular construction of pri/n with the subjunctive, nor will you recall him to life before (until) you suffer some new affliction. This result could not have been attained with an affirmative leading clause; for while ou) tou=to poih/sw: pri/n me keleu/sh|s, I shall not do this:—you shall command me first, gives the meaning I shall not do this before you command me, the paratactic affirmative, tou=to poih/sw: pri/n me keleu/sh|s, would give only you will command me before I do this. I shall do this before you command me would be tou=to poih/sw pri/n se keleu=sai, which is not the result of any form of parataxis. The six cases of pri/n with the subjunctive in Homer are all without a)/n or ke/, and all follow negatives. The primitive character and the rarity of this construction seem to show that we are nearer the original parataxis here than in any other form; while the change of the subjunctive to the optative after a past tense in Il. xxi. 580 (see 639) shows that the dependence of the clause with pri/n is thoroughly established (cf. 307). An attempt to arrive at the same result in a more awkward way appears in two cases of pri/n g' o(/t' a)/n with the subjunctive in the Odyssey (641), where pri/n introduces the subjunctive with o(/t' a)/n very much as it introduces the infinitive.

No case of pri/n with the indicative occurs in Homer; but the want was supplied by pri/n g' o(/te dh/ with the indicative, which resembles pri/n g' o(/t' a)/n with the subjunctive just mentioned. As this construction is not the result of parataxis, and there is no such obstacle to combining the ideas of until and before in statements of past fact after affirmative clauses as was felt in future conditions (624), we find pri/n g' o(/te with the indicative after both affirmative and negative sentences (see the examples in 636). It thus appears that pri/n was not sufficiently established as a conjunction in Homer to take the indicative without the intervention of o(/te, although pri/n with the subjunctive had become a fixed construction.
The history of the uses of pri/n after Homer will be found below. (See 627; 632-634; 637; 642; 643; 645.)

div2.head: pri/n with the Infinitive.
div2.p:
(In Homer.) In Homer the infinitive regularly follows pri/n after both affirmative and negative sentences, often where the Attic Greek would have the finite moods. E.g. *nai=e de\ *ph/daion pri
 e)lqei=n ui(=as *)axaiw=n. Il. xiii. 172. *tou= d' e)/fqh o)reca/menos pri
 ou)ta/sai, ou)d' a)fa/marten. Il. xvi. 322. *sfw=in de\ pri/n per tro/mos e)/llabe fai/dima gui=a, pri
 po/lemo/n t' i)de/ein pole/moio/ te me/rmera e)/rga, before they saw the war, etc. Il. viii. 452. (See 657.) *feu/gei pri/n per o(/milon a)ollisqh/menai a)ndrw=n. Il. xv. 588. *)=h k' e)/ti polloi\ gai=an o)da\c ei(=lon pri
 *)/ilion ei)safike/sqai. Il. xxii. 17. *)alla/ oi( au)tw=| *zeu\s o)le/seie bi/hn pri
 h(mi=n ph=ma futeu=sai. Od. iv. 668. *ai)/q' w)/fell' a)/lloq' o)le/sqai pri
 e)lqei=n. Od. xviii. 402. *ou)d' a)polh/gei pri
 xroo\s a)ndrome/oio dielqei=n. Il. xx. 100. *ou) lh/cw pri
 *trw=as a)/dhn e)la/sai pole/moio. Il. xix. 423. *ou)/ m' a)potre/yeis pri
 xalkw=| maxe/sasqai. Il. xx. 257. *ou)d' o(/ ge loigo
 a)pw/sei pri/n g' a)po\ patri\ fi/lw| do/menai kou/rhn. Il. i. 97.

In the last three examples the subjunctive would be regular in Attic, and even Homer uses it in a few such cases (639). In Il. xx. 100 pri\n dih=lqen would have been the common Attic form. In the other examples, in which a mere temporal relation is expressed, the infinitive would be required in Attic Greek.
Hesiod has one example (Scut. 40) and the Homeric Hymns one ( Ven. 151) of pri/n with the infinitive, both after negative sentences.

(After Homer.) The lyric poets, Herodotus, and the Attic writers use the infinitive after pri/n chiefly when the leading sentence is affirmative. But the infinitive is always required when pri/n means simply before, not until. E.g.

*pri
 e)ktele/sai kate/bh do/mon *)/aidos. THEOG. 917. *(/istamai a)mpne/wn pri/n ti fa/men, I stand taking breath before I speak. Nem. viii. 19; so Py. ix. 113. *pri
 w)=n parei=nai e)kei=non e)s th
 *)attikh
, u(me/as kairo/s e)sti probohqh=sai e)s th
 *boiwti/an, before he comes into Attica, etc. HDT. viii. 144.
*pri
 nu=n ta\ plei/on' i(storei=n, e)k th=sd' e(/dras e)/celq', before seeking further, etc. SOPH. O.C. 36 . *)apope/mpousin ou)=n au)to
 pri
 a)kou=sai. THUC. ii. 12.So ii. 13, pri
 e)sbalei=n ei)s th
 *)attikh/n. *)afi/esan ta\ be/lh polu\ pri
 e)ciknei=sqai. XEN. Cyr. iii. 3, 60. *(hmei=s toi/nun *messh/nhn ei(/lomen pri
 *pe/rsas labei=n th
 basilei/an kai\ krath=sai th=s h)pei/rou, kai\ pri
 oi)kisqh=nai/ tinas tw=n po/lewn tw=n *(ellhni/dwn. ISOC. vi. 26. *kai\ pri
 e(\c mh=nas gegone/nai, a)pe/dwke. PLAT. Prot. 320A. *)apwlo/mesq' a)/r), ei) kako
 prosoi/somen ne/on palaiw=|, pri
 to/d' e)chntlhke/nai, we are ruined, then, if we shall add a new calamity to the former one, before we shall have exhausted this (109). EUR. Med. 78.

In the following cases the infinitive is necessary, even after negatives. *pri
 w(s *)/afobon e)lqei=n mi/an h(me/ran ou)k e)xh/reusen, she was not a widow a single day before she went to Aphobus (where until would be absurd). XXX. DEM. 33. *ou)de\ ga pri
 h(tthqh=nai th
 di/khn ei)=xen w(=n dikazo/meqa, i.e. he did not have it even before he lost the suit (much less afterwards). ISAE. v. 21.So AR. Av. 964; THUC. i. 39, THUC. 68.See also ISOC. v. 70, o(/tan dedi/wsi mh\ pro/tero/n ti pa/qh|s pri
 te/los e)piqei=nai toi=s prattome/nois, when they fear lest you may meet with some disaster before you finish what you are doing (not until you finish). Indeed, mh/ after a verb of fearing does not make a negative sentence so far as the sense is concerned, what affects the dependent clause being the positive idea in pa/qh|s: see SOPH. Tr. 632.

An infinitive with pri/n sometimes depends on a negative clause, where a finite mood might be allowed, because the temporal relation is still so prominent as to determine the construction. This may happen when the clause with pri/n precedes, so that the dependence which until expresses is obscured by the position. E.g. *(/opws mh\ pro/teron nu\c e)/stai pri
 puqe/sqai a(/pantas, i.e. lest night should come before they had heard them all. AND. i. 43. *pri
 th
 naumaxi/an nikh=sai h(ma=s, gh= ou)k h)=n a)ll' h)\ xwri/dion mikro/n, before we gained the naval victory, he had only a little piece of land (the argument tries to prove that he died poor). LYS. xix. 28. *kai/ moi mh\ qorubh/sh| mhdei\s pri
 a)kou=sai, and let no one interrupt me before he hears (where pri
 a)
 a)kou/sh|, until he hears, would suggest the wrong idea). DEM. v. 15. *pri
 de\ tau=ta pra=cai, mh\ skopei=te ti/s ei)pw
 ta\ be/ltista a)pole/sqai boulh/setai (where the irony of the question would make until absurd). Id. iii. 12: so 13. *pri
 me
 ga tou=to pra=cai *lewkra/thn a)/dhlon h)=n o(poi=oi/ tines o)/ntes e)tu/gxanon: nu=n de\ pa=si fanero/n (where the temporal relation in pri
 me/n and nu=n de/ is the only important one). LYCURG. 135. See also AESCH. Sept. 1048, Ag. 1067; SOPH. Aj. 1419; XEN. Cyr. iv. 3, 10.

The infinitive sometimes follows pri/n after negative sentences where we might have the optative, which for some reason was not common after pri/n. E.g. *ou)k a)
 meqei=to pri
 kaq' h(donh
 klu/ein, he would not give it up until he should hear (before hearing) what he desired. SOPH. Tr. 197. (We might have pri
 klu/oi: cf. SOPH. Tr. 2, ou)k a)
 ai)w=n' e)kma/qois brotw=n, pri
 a)
 qa/nh| tis, where pri
 qa/noi might have been used.) So AESCH. Supp. 772. *ou)d' a)
 diabouleu/sasqai e)/ti e)/fh, pri
 tri\s e)nne/a h(me/ras mei=nai, until he should wait, etc. THUC. vii. 50. *(ike/teuon mhdamw=s a)potre/pesqai, pri
 e)mbalei=n ei)s th
 xw/ran, until they should invade the country. XEN. Hell. vi. 5, 23. *ou)/te au)to/s pote pri
 i(drw=sai dei=pnon h(|rei=to. Id. Cyr. viii. 1, Id. Cyr. 38. (Here pri
 i(drw/seie in the generic sense would be the natural expression; but it is doubtful whether this construction was ever used with pri/n. For Id. An. iv. 5, Id. An. 30, see 646.)

There remain some cases of pri/n with the infinitive after negative clauses where the older usage seems to be retained in place of the more exact later use of the indicative or subjunctive. E.g. *ou)de\ pro\s dikasthri/w| ou)de\ bouleuthri/w| w)/fqhn ou)depw/pote, pri
 tau/thn th
 sumfora
 gene/sqai, i.e. never, until this calamity befell me. LYS. xix. 55. *)epeidh\ d' ou)k oi(=o/n t' e)sti
 ai)sqe/sqai (tou\s ponhrou\s) pri
 kakw=s tina paqei=n u(p' au)tw=n, but since it is not possible to recognise them until somebody is hurt by them (for pri
 a)
 pa/qh| tis). ISOC. xx. 14.In such cases the temporal relation seems to exclude the other in the writer's mind.

(*)\h pri/n.) We sometimes find h)\ pri/n, than before, with the infinitive, a past verb being understood after h)/. E.g. *oi( pole/mioi polu\ me
 e)la/ttone/s ei)sin nu=n h)\ pri
 h(tthqh=nai, polu\ d' e)la/ttones h)\ o(/te a)pe/drasan h(ma=s, they are much fewer now than (they were) before they were beaten, etc. XEN. Cyr. v. 2, 36. So vii. 5, XEN. Cyr. 77. *paralabw
 th
 po/lin xei=ron me
 fronou=san h)\ (sc. e)fro/nei) pri
 katasxei=n th
 a)rxh/n. ISOC. viii. 126.
This ellipsis occurs first in Xenophon.

div2.head: pri/n with the Indicative.
div2.p: (Early Poets.) *pri/n with the indicative does not occur in the Iliad or Odyssey, except in pri/n g' o(/te (see 636). The first case of simple pri/n with the indicative is Hymn. Py. Ap. 178, o(\s th=| g' a)ntia/seie, fe/reske/ ge/ min ai)/simon h)=mar, pri/n ge/ oi( i)o\n e)fh=ken *)apo/llwn , i.e. every one was slain, until Apollo sent an arrow at the monster. Three cases occur in Pindar: Ol. ix. 57, xiii. 65; Nem. iv. 28. The last is the first case of pri/n with the indicative after a negative sentence. These are the only cases before the Attic writers.

(Attic Poets.) Aeschylus has one example, after a negative: ou)k h)=n a)le/chm' ou)de\n, a)lla\ farma/kwn xrei/a| kateske/llonto, pri/n g' e)gw/ sfisin e)/deica kra/seis h)pi/wn a)kesma/twn, until I showed them, etc., Prom. 479. So likewise Aristophanes: pro/teron d' ou)k h)=n ge/nos a)qana/twn, pri\n e)/rws cune/micen a(/panta, Av. 700.Sophocles has one, after an affirmative: h)go/mhn d' a)nh\r a)stw=n me/gistos, pri/n moi tu/xh toia/d' e)pe/sth, until this fortune befell me, O. T. 775 . Euripides has seven examples, all (according to Sturm) after affirmatives, as follows:—

*)en eu)di/a| de/ pws e)/sth, pri
 dh/ tis e)fqe/gcato. And. 1145. *)/afrwn neo/s t' h)=n, pri
 e)sei=don oi(=on h)=n, I was a witless youth, until I saw, etc. I. A. 489 (where there is a negative force in a)/frwn). *)anw- lo/luce, pri/n g' o(ra=|, she shouted, until she saw, etc. Med. 1173. (Here the contrast of ei)=t' h(=ken me/gan kw/kuton in 1176 gives the idea that she did not begin the loud wailing until she saw the foam.) *spoudai\ h)=san i)/sai, pri
 *laertia/dhs pei/qei stratia/n. Hec. 132.The others are Alc. 128; Rhes. 294, Alc. 568.

These are all the cases of pri/n with the indicative which precede those in prose. It will be seen that the idea of until is always conspicuous, even when the leading verb is affirmative; and in the earlier stages of the construction little regard was paid to the character of the leading sentence. With prose a new and stricter usage begins (634).

(Prose.) In Attic prose and in Herodotus, pri/n, until, referring to a definite past action, regularly takes the indicative after negative sentences or those implying a negative, very rarely after affirmative sentences. E.g. *ou)/ti kw sumbolh
 e)poie/eto pri/n ge dh\ au)tou= prutanhi/h e)ge/neto, he did not yet make an attack until his own day of command came. HDT. vi. 110.So vi. 79, HDT. vii. 239, HDT. ix. 22; all with pri/n ge dh/. *tou/tou tou= e)/peos lo/gon ou)de/na e)poieu=nto pri
 dh\ e)petele/sqh. Id. i. 13.For pri
 h)/ in Herodotus see 651; and for pro/teron h)/ in Herodotus and Thucydides, see 653.

*ou) pro/teron e)pau/santo e)n o)rgh=| e)/xontes au)to
, pri
 e)zhmi/wsan xrh/masin, they did not cease to regard him with wrath until they fined him. THUC. ii. 65. *ou)d' h)ci/wsan new/tero/n ti poiei=n e)s au)to
, pri/n ge dh\ au)toi=s a)nh *)argi/lios mhnuth\s gi/gnetai, i.e. until he becomes, etc. Id. i. 132. *ou)/te to/te i)e/nai h)/qele, pri
 h( gunh\ au)to
 e)/peise. XEN. An. i. 2, 26. *ou) pro/teron h)qe/lhsen a)pelqei=n, pri
 au)to
 e)ch/lasan bi/a|. LYS. iii. 7. *messhni/ous poliorkou=ntes ou) pro/teron e)pau/santo, pri
 e)ce/balon e)k th=s xw/ras. ISOC. xii. 91. (Isocrates has the formula ou) pro/teron e)pau/santo pri/n with the indicative nine times.) *ou)k h)=n e)n *qh/bais a)sfale\s, pri
 th
 *boiwti/an a)pe/dwke kai\ tou\s *fwke/as a)nei=len. DEM. viii. 65.
*pa/lin tou=to te/mnwn ou)k e)panh=ke, pri
 e)feurw
 skaio/n tin' e)/rwta e)loido/rhse ma/l' e)n di/kh|. PLAT. Phaedr. 266A. (This is the only case in Plato; but he has three indicatives in unfulfilled conditions. See 637.)
The only examples in prose of pri/n with the indicative after strictly affirmative sentences are these three:—

*)epi\ polu\ dih=gon th=s h(me/ras peirw/menoi a)llh/lwn, pri
 dh\ *)ari/stwn pei/qei tou\s a)/rxontas. THUC. vii. 39. *paraplh/sia e)/pasxon, pri/n ge dh\ oi( *surako/sioi e)/treya/n te tou\s *)aqhnai/ous kai\ katedi/wkon e)s th
 gh=n. Id. vii. 71. *prosepole/mei *)aristofw=nti, pri
 au)tw=| th
 au)th
 tau/thn h)pei/lhsen e)paggeli/an e)n tw=| dh/mw| h(/nper e)gw\ *tima/rxw| e)ph/ggeila, he continued to attack Aristophon, until A. threatened him before the people with this same kind of summons (to dokimasi/a) which I served on Timarchus. AESCHIN. i. 64.In these cases the force of until in pri/n is made especially emphatic by the continuation of the state of things described by the leading imperfects. There seems to be a feeling implied like that in ou) pro/teron e)pau/santo pri/n (see Sturm, p. 333).

Sturm cites also THUC. i. 51 and 118, THUC. iii. 29 and 104, as examples. But the first two have actual negatives in the leading sentence; in iii. 29, tou\s *)aqhnai/ous lanqa/nousi, pri
 dh\ th=| *dh/lw| e)/sxon, the idea is that the Athenians did not see them until, etc.; in iii. 104, ta\ peri\ tou\s a)gw=nas katelu/qh u(po\ cumforw=n, pri
 dh\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi to/te to
 a)gw=na e)poi/hsan, the meaning is, the games were broken up (i.e. were no longer held) until the Athenians renewed them at this time. (See Jour. Phil. ii. p. 469.)
*pri/n g' o(/te, until, has the indicative in Homer, after affirmative as well as negative sentences. These cases occur:—

*)epi\ i)=sa ma/xh te/tato, pri/n g' o(/te dh\ *zeu\s ku=dos u(pe/rteron *(/ektori dw=ken, the battle hung equally balanced, until (when) Zeus gave higher glory to Hector. Il. xii. 436. *(/hmeq' a)tuzo/menai, pri/n g' o(/te dh/ me so\s ui(o\s a)po\ mega/roio ka/lessen, until your son called me. Od. xxiii. 42. *ou)d' w(\s tou= qumo\n e)/peiqon, pri/n g' o(/te dh\ qa/lamos pu/k' e)ba/lleto, i.e. until the battering began. Il. ix. 587.So in the suspected verses, pri/n g' o(/te . . . qa/rsunas, Od. xiii. 322.For Od. iv. 178, see 637.
Four cases of pri/n g' o(/te dh/ with the indicative are found in the Homeric Hymns: Del. 49; Cer. 96, Cer. 195, Cer. 202; after which this strange construction disappears.

(Indicative with pri/n, in unfulfilled conditions.) When the clause introduced by pri/n, until, refers to a result not attained in past time in consequence of the non-fulfilment of some condition, it takes a past tense of the indicative like the corresponding clause with e(/ws (613, 2). We find examples only of the aorist indicative after negative sentences:—

*)exrh=n tou\s a)/llous mh\ pro/teron peri\ tw=n o(mologoume/nwn sumbouleu/ein, pri
 peri\ tw=n a)mfisbhtoume/nwn h(ma=s e)di/dacan, they ought not to have given advice about undisputed matters, until they had instructed us about what is in dispute. ISOC. iv. 19. *xrh=n toi/nun *lepti/nhn mh\ pro/teron tiqe/nai to
 e(autou= no/mon, pri
 tou=ton e)/luse, before he had repealed this one. DEM. xx. 96. *ou)k a)
 e)peskeya/meqa pro/teron ei)/te didakto
 ei)/te ou) didakto
 h( a)reth\, pri
 o(/ ti e)/sti prw=ton e)zhth/samen au)to/, we should not have inquired whether virtue was teachable or not, until we had first asked what it is in itself. PLAT. Men. 86 D; so 84 C, and Theaet. 165D.

Besides these five cases in prose, we have the same construction with pri/n g' o(/te dh/ in Od. iv. 178: ou)de/ ken h(me/as a)/llo die/krinen, pri/n g' o(/te dh\ qana/toio me/lan ne/fos a)mfeka/luyen, nor would aught else have separated us until the black cloud of death had covered us.
For the same construction with pro/teron h)/ in HDT. viii. 93, see 653.

div2.head: pri/n with the Subjunctive and Optative: Subjunctive.
div2.p: When a clause with pri/n, until, refers to the future, and depends on a negative clause of future time (not containing an optative), pri/n takes the subjunctive, like e(/ws in a similar case (613, 3).
In Homer pri/n does not take ke/ or a)/n with the subjunctive, the form of the original parataxis being still retained (624). The examples of the subjunctive are these:—

*ou) ga/r pw katadu/someq' ei)s *)ai/dao do/mous, pri\n mo/rsimon h)=mar e)pe/lqh|, we shall not yet descend to the house of Hades, until the fated day shall come. Od. x. 174. (Here, if we insert a colon after do/mous and take pri/n as an adverb, sooner than this, we have the paratactic form.) So Il. xviii. 135; Od. xiii. 335, Od. xvii. 7.In Il. xviii. 190, ou)/ me pri/n g' ei)/a qwrh/ssesqai, pri/n g' au)th\n i)/dwmai, she did not permit me to arm myself until I should see her, the subjunctive of direct discourse (seen in xviii. 135) is retained after a past tense. So Il. xxiv. 781.In Il. xxi. 580 a similar subjunctive has been changed to the optative (644).
Hesiod has two cases of pri/n with the subjunctive, Th. 222, Op. 738, still without ke/ or a)/n as in Homer. *pri\n a)/n first occurs in THEOGN. 963 (see 642).

Two cases of pri/n g' o(/t' a)/n (used like pri/n) with the subjunctive occur in the Odyssey. The first is especially instructive, ii. 373: a)ll' o)/moson mh\ mhtri\ fi/lh| ta/de muqh/sasqai, pri/n g' o(/t' a)
 e(ndeka/th te duwdeka/th te ge/nhtai, h)\ au)th
 poqe/sai kai\ a)formhqe/ntos a)kou=sai, but swear not to tell this to my mother until the eleventh or twelfth day shall come, or (until) she shall miss me and hear of my departure. Here pri/n first introduces o(/t' a)
 ge/nhtai and then the two infinitives, having the same prepositional force with both. But in iv. 746, where the same scene is described, we have e)meu= d' e(/leto me/gan o(/rkon, mh\ pri
 soi\ e)re/ein pri
 dwdeka/thn ge gene/sqai h)\ s' au)th
 poqe/sai kai\ a)formhqe/ntos a)kou=sai, the simpler and more common pri
 gene/sqai taking the place of the unwieldy pri/n g' o(/t' a)
 ge/nhtai. The other case is iv. 475: ou) pri
 moi=ra fi/lous i)de/ein, pri/n g' o(/t' a)
 *ai)gu/ptoio u(/dwr e)/lqh|s.

After Homer and Hesiod pri/n a)/n is established as the regular form with the subjunctive. E.g. *mh/ pot' e)painh/sh|s pri
 a)
 ei)dh=|s a)/ndra safhne/ws. THEOG. 963 (the earliest case of pri
 a)/n). *ou)de\ lh/cei pri
 a)
 h)\ kore/sh| ke/ar h)\ e(/lh| tis a)rxa/n AESCH. Prom. 165 . *ou) ga/r pot' e)/cei pri
 a)
 kei/nas e)nargei=s deu=ro/ moi sth/sh|s a)/gwn, you shall not depart until you bring those girls and place them before my eyes. SOPH. O.C. 909 . *ou) mh\ nau=s a)formi/sh| xqono\s, pri
 a)
 ko/rhn sh
 *)ifige/neian *)/artemis la/bh| sfagei=san. EUR. I. T. 19.
*mh\ prokatagi/gnwsk', w)= pa/ter, pri
 a)/n g' a)kou/sh|s a)mfote/rwn AR. Vesp. 919.
*ou)/ kw/ se e)gw\ le/gw (eu)dai/mona), pri
 a)
 teleuth/santa kalw=s to
 ai)w=na pu/qwmai, until I shall hear that you have ended your life happily. HDT. i. 32. *ou) xrh/ m' e)nqe/nde a)pelqei=n, pri
 a)
 dw= di/khn. XEN. An. v. 7, 5. *ou)k oi(=o/n te u(ma=s pro/teron ei)de/nai, pri
 a)
 kai\ e)mou= a)kou/shte a)pologoume/nou. AND. i. 7. *tou\s d' ou) pro/teron pau/sontai pri
 a)
 ou(/tws w(/sper h(ma=s diaqw=sin. ISOC. xiv. 18.
*mh/pw ge, pri
 a)
 to\ kau=ma pare/lqh|, not yet, — until the heat of the day is past. PLAT. Phaedr. 242A.

div2.head: Optative.
div2.p: When a clause with pri/n, until, referring to the future, depends on a negative clause containing an optative in protasis or apodosis, in a wish, or in a final clause, it may have the optative (without a)/n) by assimilation, like a conditional relative clause (613, 4), or it may take the infinitive. These cases of the optative occur:—

*ou) ga a)
 ei)dei/hs a)ndro\s no/on ou)de\ gunaiko\s, pri
 peirhqei/hs, for you cannot know the mind of a man or a woman until you have tested it. THEOG. 125 (the earliest example). *ou)/pot' e)/gwg' a)
, pri
 i)/doim' o)rqo
 e)/pos, memfome/nwn a)
 katafai/hn, never would I assent when men blame him, until I should see the word proved true. SOPH. O.T. 505.
*mh\ stai/h polu/kwpon o)/xhma nao\s au)tw=|, pri
 ta/nde pro\s po/lin a)nu/seie, may his ship of many oars not stop until it makes its way to this city. Id. Tr. 655; so Phil. 961 (both after optative of wish). *parani=sxon fruktou\s, o(/pws mh\ bohqoi=en pri
 sfw=n oi( a)/ndres oi( e)cio/ntes diafu/goien, they raised signal torches, that the enemy might not come to the rescue until their own men who had gone forth had escaped. THUC. iii. 22. *nomi/santes ou)k a)
 e)/ti to
 *brasi/dan sfw=n prosaposth=sai ou)de
 pri
 paraskeua/sainto, thinking that B. would not cause any further secessions of their allies until they had made preparations. Id. iv. 117.So XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 48 (two examples). *ou)k a)
 pro/teron o(rmh/seie, pri/n th| bebai/wsaito th
 ske/yin th=s porei/as. Leg. 799 D. *ei) e(/lkoi tis au)to
, kai\ mh\ a)nei/h pri
 e)celku/seien ei)s to\ tou= h(li/ou fw=s, if one should drag him, and not let him go until he had dragged him out into the sunlight. Rep. 515E.
These are all the cases of this use of the optative with pri/n cited by Sturm. In many cases where the optative could have been used, the infinitive appears (see 629).

The optative with pri/n is more frequent in indirect discourse after a negative verb of past time, representing a subjunctive of the direct form, which is often retained. (See the corresponding use of e(/ws, 614.) E.g. *ou)k e)/qelen feu/gein pri
 peirh/sait' *)axilh=os, he would not fly until he should try Achilles. Il. xxi. 580. (The direct form was pri
 peirh/swmai, and peirh/shtai might have been used here. See Il. xviii. 190, in 639.) So Hymn. Cer. 334; HES. Scut. 18. *)/edoce/ moi mh\ si=ga, pri
 fra/saimi/ soi, to
 plou=n poiei=sqai. SOPH. Ph. 551. (In SOPH. Aj. 742 we have pri
 tu/xh| in a similar sentence.) *)ede/onto mh\ a)pelqei=n pri
 a)paga/goi to\ stra/teuma (v. l. pri
 a)
 a)paga/gh|). XEN. An. vii. 7, 57. (See ei)=pon mhde/na tw=n o)/pisqen kinei=sqai pri
 a)
 o( pro/sqen h(gh=tai, Cyr. ii. 2, Cyr. 8.) *)aphgo/reue mhde/na ba/llein, pri
 *ku=ros e)mplhsqei/h qhrw=n, until Cyrus should be satisfied. Cyr. i. 4, Cyr. 14. *(/hgou=nq' ou)de
 oi(=oi/ t' ei)=nai kinei=n, pri
 e)kpodw
 e)kei=nos au)toi=s ge/noito. ISOC. xvi. 5.So PLAT. Ap. 36 C, PLAT. Rep. 402 B, Leg. 678D.
For the infinitive, often preferred to the optative in such sentences, see 629.

div2.head: pri/n with Subjunctive in General Suppositions.
div2.p:
When the clause introduced by pri/n, until, is generic, and depends on a negative clause of present time expressing customary or repeated action or a general truth, we have pri
 a)/n with the subjunctive (613, 5). E.g. *(orw=si tou\s presbute/rous ou) pro/sqen a)pio/ntas gastro\s e(/neka, pri
 a)
 a)fw=sin oi( a)/rxontes. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 8. *ou) ga pro/teron kath/goros para\ toi=s a)kou/ousin i)sxu/ei, pri
 a)
 o( feu/gwn a)dunath/sh| ta\s proeirhme/nas ai)ti/as a)polu/sasqai. AESCHIN. ii. 2. *ou)dei\s pw/pote e)pe/qeto (gnomic) pro/teron th=| tou= dh/mou katalu/sei, pri
 a)
 mei=zon tw=n dikasthri/wn i)sxu/sh|. Id. iii. 235. *ou) pro/teron pau/ontai, pri
 a)
 pei/swsin ou(\s h)di/khsan. PLAT. Phaed. 114B. So Leg. 968C.

It is doubtful whether the optative was ever used with pri/n in the corresponding generic sense. In XEN. An. iv. 5, 30 , for pri\n paraqei=en the weight of MSS. authority seems to favour pri\n paraqei=nai. In Il. ix. 488 pri/n g' o(/te dh/ s' a)/saimi is of this class.

The principle by which pri/n takes the subjunctive and optative only after negative sentences, or sentences which were felt as negative, seems to have allowed of no exceptions. The two following cases have been cited:—

*ai)sxro
 d' h(gou=mai pro/teron pau/sasqai, pri
 a)
 u(mei=s o(/ ti a)
 bou/lhsqe yhfi/shsqe, which is practically equivalent to I refuse to stop until you have voted what you wish, ai)sxro/n having elsewhere a negative force (see 817). LYS. xxii. 4. *(/ostis ou)=n oi)/etai tou\s a)/llous koinh=| ti pra/cein a)gaqo
, pri
 a)
 tou\s proestw=tas au)tw=n dialla/ch|, li/an a(plw=s e)/xei kai\ po/rrw tw=n pragma/twn e)sti/n, which amounts to this: nobody but a simpleton thinks that the others will do anything in common until their leaders are united. ISOC. iv. 16. In Semonides i. 12, pri
 i(/khtai cannot be correct, as pri/n here does not mean until, but merely before.

*pri/n, like e(/ws, etc. (620), sometimes takes the subjunctive without a)/n, even in Attic Greek. E.g. *mh\ ste/naze pri
 ma/qh|s. SOPH. Ph. 917. So Ant. 619, Aj. 742, Aj. 965, Tr. 608, Tr. 946.
*ou)k e)/stin o(/stis au)to
 e)cairh/setai, pri
 gunai=k' e)moi\ meqh=| EUR. Alc. 848. So EUR. Or. 1218, EUR. Or. 1357.
*mh\, pri/n g' a)kou/sh|s xa)te/ran sta/sin melw=n AR. Ran. 1281. So AR. Eccl. 629. See HDT. i. 32, HDT. iv. 157, HDT. vi. 82. Even in Attic prose the MSS. omit a)/n in some places; as THUC. vi. 10, THUC. 29, THUC. 38, THUC. viii. 9; XEN. Oec. xii. 1, XEN. Cyn. iii. 6; AESCHIN. iii. 60; HYPER. Eux. xx. 10 (§ 4); PLAT. Theaet. 169 B, Tim. 57B; but many editors insert a)/n in all these places on their own responsibility.

A few cases of pri\n a)/n with the optative, if the text is sound, are to be explained (like those of e(/ws a)/n, 613, 4, end) as indirect discourse in which the direct form had pri/n a)/n with the subjunctive. See XEN. Hell. ii. 4, 18 (quoted in 702).

In sentences with pri/n we sometimes have a subjunctive depending on an optative with a)/n, as in conditional relative sentences (556). E.g. *ou)k a)
 ai)w=n' e)kma/qois brotw=n, pri
 a)
 qa/nh| tis, you cannot fully understand the life of mortals, until one dies. SOPH. Tr. 2. *ou)k a)
 a)pe/lqoimi pri
 panta/pasin h( a)gora\ luqh=|. XEN. Oec. xii. 1. *)\h le/goimen a)/n ti a)lhqe\s, ou) mh
 safe/s ge ou)de\ te/leon pri
 au)= (?) kai\ tau/tas au)th=s pa/sas perie/lwmen; PLAT. Polit. 281D. The leading verb here has merely the effect of a future form on the clause with pri/n.

div2.head: pri\n h)/, pro/teron h)/, and pa/ros, in the sense of pri/n.
div2.p:
*pri
 h)/, sooner than, which is a more developed form of pri/n, is found twice in the Iliad with the infinitive; and very frequently in Herodotus with the infinitive (only after past tenses), the indicative, and the subjunctive (without a)/n). E.g. *ou) mh
 sfw=i/ g' o)i/w pri/n g' a)popau/sasqai pri
 h)\ e(/tero/n ge peso/nta ai(/matos a)=sai *)/arha. Il. v. 287.The same words occur after pri
 h)/ in xxii. 266. *oi( de\ *ai)gu/ptioi, pri
 me
 h)\ *yammh/tixon sfe/wn basileu=sai, e)no/mizon e(wutou\s prw/tous gene/sqai pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn. HDT. ii. 2. *pri
 ga h)\ o)pi/sw sfe/as a)naplw=sai e)s ta\s *sa/rdis h(/lw o( *kroi=sos. Id. i. 78. *ou) ga dh\ pro/teron a)pane/sth, pri
 h)/ sfeas u(poxeiri/ous e)poih/sato. Id. vi. 45. *)adike/ei a)napeiqo/menos pri
 h)\ a)treke/ws e)kma/qh|. Id. vii. 10. *ou) pro/teron pau/somai pri
 h)\ e(/lw te kai\ purw/sw ta\s *)aqh/nas. Id. vii. 8.
A few cases of pri\n h)/ occur in the MSS. in Attic prose, as in THUC. v. 61, and XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 23 , Ag. ii. 4, An. iv. 5, 1; but many editors omit h)/.
*pro/teron h)/ is sometimes used like pri\n h)/, in the sense of pri/n.

This occurs chiefly with the infinitive in Herodotus and Thucydides, and with the subjunctive in Herodotus. *pro/teron h)/ with the indicative is sometimes used like pri/n, but it more frequently expresses a looser relation between two sentences which are independent in their construction (654). E.g.

(Infin., only after past tenses.) *tau=ta e)cagge/lqh pro/teron h)\ to\n *dauri/shn a)pike/sqai, this was announced before D. arrived. HDT. v. 118. *)=hsan ou(=toi to\ me\n pro/teron h)\ *pe/rsas a)/rcai *mh/dwn kath/kooi, to/te de\ *ku/rou. Id. i. 72. (*pro/tera as adj. for pro/teron): tau=ta kai\ pe/nte geneh=|si a)ndrw=n pro/tera/ e)sti h)\ *(hrakle/a e)n th=| *(ella/di gene/sqai. Id. ii. 44. *)epi\ tou\s pompe/as pro/teron h)\ ai)sqe/sqai au)tou\s eu)qu\s e)xw/rhsen, before they perceived them. THUC. vi. 58.So i. 69. Besides the cases in Herodotus and Thucydides, a few occur in the orators: see DEM. xxxi. 14, and lv. 14 (pro/teron h)/ and pri/n together).

(Subj., without a)/n.) *mh\ a)pani/stasqai a)po\ th=s po/lios pro/teron h)\ e)ce/lwsi. HDT. ix. 86; so ix. 87. In iv. 196 we have ou)/te pri\n a)\n a)piswqh=| ou)/te pro/teron h)\ la/bwsi. Besides five cases in Herodotus, we have only THUC. vii. 63, mh\ pro/teron a)ciou=n a)polu/esqai h)\ a)para/chte, and A. a. 2, ou) pro/teron e)pixeirou=sin h)\ poih/swntai.

(Indic.) *ou)de\ h)/|desan e)ou=san (th
 a)/trapon) pro/teron h)/ per e)pu/qonto *trhxini/wn, until they learned of it. HDT. vii. 175. *ou) pro/teron e)ne/dosan h)\ au)toi\ e)n sfi/si peripeso/ntes e)sfa/lhsan. THUC. ii. 65. *ou)d' au)th
 th
 a)po/stasin pro/teron e)to/lmhsan poih/sasqai h)\ meta\ pollw=n cumma/xwn e)/mellon cunkinduneu/sein. Id. viii. 24 (see the following example). *ou)k e)n no/w| e)/xontes tau/ths th=s h(me/rhs e)piqh/sesqai, ou)de\ pro/teron h)\ to\ su/nqhma/ sfi e)/melle fanh/sesqai, i.e. nor did they mean to make an attack until the signal was ready to appear to them. HDT. viii. 7. (With pri/n we should probably have had pri
 a)
 me/llh|.) *ei) e)/maqe, ou)k a)
 e)pau/sato pro/teron h)\ ei(=le/ min h)\ kai\ au)to\s h(/lw, if he had known it, he would not have stopped until he had either captured her or had been captured himself (indicative in unfulfilled condition). Id. viii. 93.

In other cases of pro/teron h)/ with the finite moods or the infinitive, there is no meaning of until, and h)/ merely connects two verbs as when it follows ma=llon. E.g. *)eke/leue to
 a)/ggelon a)pagge/llein o(/ti pro/teron h(/coi h)\ au)to\s boulh/setai, he bade the messenger announce that he should come sooner than he wanted him (the direct form being h(/cw pro/teron h)\ boulh/sei). HDT. i. 127. *polu\ plei=on plh=qos periesth/kei boulome/nwn prosie/nai, kai\ polu\ pro/teron h)\ oi( fi/loi parh=san, i.e. much sooner than his friends arrived. XEN. Cyr. vii. 5, 41. *pro/teron a)/n ti/s moi dokei= e)n th=| o(dw=| eu(rei=n h)\ daneizo/menos labei=n (i.e. pro/teron eu(/roi a)
 h)\ la/boi). Id. Mem. ii. 7, Id. Mem. 2: see i. 2, Id. Mem. 17.
*pro/teron e)pequ/mhsan h)\ to
 tro/pon e)/gnwsan. PLAT. Phaedr. 232E. Compare ma=llon h)\ zh=n, XEN. Mem. iv. 4, 4.

So with pro/sqen h)/, which is not used like pri/n; as pro/sqen h)\ su\ e)fai/nou, tou=t' e)khru/xqh SOPH. O.T. 736. See also XEN. An. ii. 1, 10 , a)pekri/neto o(/ti pro/sqen a)\n a)poqa/noien h)\ ta\ o(/pla paradoi/hsan, they answered, that they would die before they would give up their arms.

Thucydides once uses u(/steron h)/ with the infinitive, after the analogy of pro/teron h)/: pri\n de\ a)nasth=nai, e)/tesin u(/steron e(kato\n h)\ au)tou\s oi)kh=sai, *pa/mmilon pe/myantes *selinou=nta kti/zousin, before they were removed, and a hundred years after their own settlement, vi. 4.

*pa/ros, before, which is originally an adverb like pri/n, is used in Homer with the infinitive, but never with the other moods. E.g. *te/kna a)gro/tai e)cei/lonto pa/ros petehna\ gene/sqai. Od. xvi. 218. *)/enqa me ku=m' a)po/erse, pa/ros ta/de e)/rga gene/sqai. Il. vi. 348. *ou)de/ oi( u(/pnos pi=pten e)pi\ blefa/roisi pa/ros katale/cai a(/panta. Od. xxiii. 309.
*pa/ros with the infinitive occurs twelve times in Homer, always after affirmative sentences (except in Od. xxiii. 309).

div2.head: pri/n (as Adverb), pa/ros, pro/teron, pro/sqen, etc., before pri/n, in the Leading Sentence.
div2.p: Homer very frequently has the adverb pri/n, and occasionally other adverbs of the same meaning, in the clause on which pri/n with the infinitive or subjunctive depends. E.g. *mh\ pri\n e)p' h)e/lion du=nai, pri/n me kata\ prhne\s bale/ein *pria/moio me/laqron, may the sun not (sooner) go down before I have thrown to the ground Priam's palace (the first pri/n emphasising in advance the idea of the second). Il. ii. 413. So Il. i. 97, Il. ii. 348, Il. 354, Il. iv. 114; Od. iv. 747; Il. ix. 403 (to\ pri/n). *ou) ga/r min pro/sqen pau/sesqai o)i/w, pri/n g' au)to/n me i)/dhtai. Od. xvii. 7.So with ou) ga/r pw, Od. x. 174.See Sturm, pp. 239, Od. 261-263, who calls attention to the decrease of the double pri/n in the Odyssey. Of 43 cases of pri/n with the infinitive in the Iliad, Od. 20 have a preceding pri/n or other adverb; of 30 cases in the Odyssey, only 10 have such an adverb. Besides pri/n or to\ pri/n in the leading clause in Homer, pa/ros occurs three times, and pro/sqen and pro/teros each once. Before pri/n with the subjunctive in Homer such an adverb is always found, pri/n twice, ou)/pw or mh/pw three times, and pro/sqen once.

In Attic Greek pro/teron or pro/sqen frequently stands in the clause on which pri/n depends, like the adverb pri/n in Homer (657). E.g. *)apoqnh/|skousi pro/teron pri
 dh=loi gi/gnesqai oi(=oi h)=san. XEN. Cyr. v. 2, 9. *kai\ e)/ti pro/teron, pri
 e)s th
 *(ro/don au)tou\s a)nasth=- nai, ta/de e)pra/sseto. THUC. viii. 45. *pro/teron ou)k h)=n ge/nos a)qanatwn, pri
 e)/rws cune/micen a(/panta. AR. Av. 700. *ou) pro/teron pro\s h(ma=s to
 po/lemon e)ce/fhnan, pri
 e)no/misan, k.t.l. XEN. An. iii. 1, 16. *ou) toi/nun a)pokrinou=mai pro/teron, pri
 a)
 pu/qwmai. PLAT. Euthyd. 295 C. *kai\ ou) pro/sqen e)/sthsan, pri
 (h)\) pro\s toi=s pezoi=s tw=n *)assuri/wn e)ge/nonto. XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 23. *dei=tai au)tou= mh\ pro/sqen katalu=sai pri
 a)
 au)tw=| sumbouleu/shtai. XEN. An. i. 1, 10. The formula ou) pro/teron pau/sasqai pri/n with the indicative in the orators is familiar (see 634).

Other adverbs of time sometimes occur in the leading clause: thus pa/roiqen . . . pri/n, SOPH. El. 1131; ou)/pw . . . pri/n, THUC. vi. 71, THUC. viii. 9. *pri/n (used as in Homer) occurs twice in Euripides, and before pri
 h)/ in HDT. i. 165.Even pro/ in composition may refer to a following pri/n, as prou+fairw=n ta\s e)kklhsi/as pri
 e)pidhmh=sai tou\s pre/sbeis, AESCHIN. ii. 61.See DEM. iv. 41, ou)de\ pro\ tw=n pragma/twn proora=te ou)de
, pri
 a)
 pu/qhsqe.

*fqa/nw in the leading sentence may emphasise a following pri/n. E.g. *)/efqhn ai)nh/sas pri/n sou kata\ pa/nta dah=nai h)/qea. THEOG. 969 (see 887). So Il. xvi. 322, e)/fqh o)re/ca/menos pri
 ou)ta/sai. *)/efqhsan a)piko/menoi pri
 h)\ tou\s barba/rous h(/kein, they arrived before the barbarians came. HDT. vi. 116: so ix. 70. *fqh/sontai pleu/santes pri
 *xi/ous ai)sqe/sqai. THUC. viii. 12. *fqh=nai sumbalo/ntes pri
 e)lqei=n tou\s bohqh/sontas, to join battle before the auxiliaries should come up. ISOC. iv. 87.

In HDT. vi. 108 we find the infinitive depending on fqa/nw . . . h)/, the verb implying pro/teron or pri/n: fqai/hte a)\n polla/kis e)candrapodisqe/ntes h)/ tina puqe/sqai h(me/wn, you would often be reduced to slavery before any of us heard of it.

div2.head: Section VIII: Indirect Discourse or Oratio Obliqua, including Indirect Quotations and Questions.
div2.p: The words or thoughts of any person may be quoted either directly or indirectly. A direct quotation is one which gives the exact words of the original speaker or writer. An indirect quotation is one in which the original words conform to the construction of the sentence in which they are quoted. Thus the expression tau=ta bou/lomai may be quoted either directly (in oratio recta), as le/gei tis tau=ta bou/lomai; or indirectly (in oratio obliqua), as le/gei tis o(/ti tau=ta bou/letai or fhsi/ tis tau=ta bou/lesqai, some one says that he wishes for these.

Indirect quotations may be introduced by o(/ti or w(s and occasionally by other particles (negatively o(/ti ou), w(s ou), etc.) with a finite verb; sometimes by the infinitive without a particle; sometimes also by the participle.

1. *(/oti, that, was originally the neuter relative o(/ ti, used as a limiting accusative, in respect to which (or what), as to which, how far, etc. In Homer o(/, neuter of the relative o(/s, is used like o(/ti (709, 1). Thus oi)=da o(/ ti (or o(\) kaka\ mh/detai at first meant I know as to what he plans evil, or I know about his planning evil, and afterwards came to mean I know that he plans evil.

2. *(ws, the relative adverb of manner (312, 1), in this construction originally meant in what manner, how; and afterwards became established in the same sense as o(/ti, that. Compare the German use of wie (how) in narration. How for that is heard in vulgar English (as I told him how I saw this), and how that was once in good use in this sense for that. *(/opws is sometimes used like w(s in indirect discourse (706).

3. By a use similar to that of w(s (2), ou(/neka and o(qou/neka are sometimes weakened from their meaning for which purpose, wherefore, to the same sense as o(/ti and w(s, that (710, 1). These words are also used in a causal sense, because, like o(/ti, o(/, and w(s (712).
On the other hand, dio/ti, because, sometimes has the sense of o(/ti, that (710, 2).
4. *(/ote, when, in Homer sometimes loses its temporal force, and approaches o(/ti in meaning (709, 3).

1. Indirect quotations with o(/ti, w(s, etc., form the chief part of the class of substantive sentences, in which an assertion introduced by one of these particles is the subject or the object of a verb. But these sentences have no peculiar construction, except after verbs implying thought or the expression of thought (verba sentiendi et declarandi), as they elsewhere have the simple indicative or any other form which would be used in the corresponding independent assertions. See ou)x a(/lis w(s e)kei/rete kth/mat' e)ma/, is it not enough that you wasted my property? Od. ii. 312; polu\ ke/rdion e)/pleto o(/tti u(po/eicen, Il. xv. 227; tou=to a)/cion e)painei=n, o(/ti to\n fo/bon die/lusan tw=n *(ellh/nwn (668), PLAT. Menex. 241 B; tou=t' a)dikei=, o(/ti a)xrei=on th\n e)piei/keian kaqi/sthsin, DEM. xx. 155.

2. The infinitive of indirect discourse belongs to the large class of subject and object infinitives (745; 746; 751), being distinguished from the others of this class by preserving the time of its tense from the finite verb which it represents (85; 667, 3).See Schmitt, Ueber den Ursprung des Substantivsatzes mit Relativpartikeln im Griechischen, in Schanz's Beiträge, Heft 8.

1. Indirect questions may be introduced by ei), whether (rarely by a)=ra), and also by interrogative pronouns, pronominal adjectives, and adverbs, and by most relatives. Alternative indirect questions may be introduced by po/teron (po/tera) . . . h)/, ei)/te . . . ei)/te, ei) . . . h)/, ei) . . . ei)/te, whether . . . or.
*)ea/n or h)/n never means whether (see 493).

2. In Homer single indirect questions (when they are not introduced by interrogatives) generally have h)/ or ei), whether; and alternative questions have h)/ (h)e/) . . . h)= (h)=e), sometimes ei)/ te . . . ei)/ te, whether . . . or.
Bekker never allows ei) or ei)/ te in indirect questions in Homer, always writing h)/ or h)/ te, without regard to the MSS.
3. Indirect questions follow the same principles as indirect quotations with o(/ti or w(s, in regard to their moods and tenses. (For examples, see 669.)

The term indirect discourse or oratio obliqua includes all clauses which express indirectly the words or thoughts of any person (including those of the speaker himself), after verbs which imply thought or the expression of thought (verba sentiendi et declarandi), and after such expressions as fai/netai, it appears, dokei=, it seems, dh=lo/n e)stin, it is evident, safe/s e)stin, etc.

The term may be further applied to any single dependent clause, in any sentence, which indirectly expresses the thought of any other person than the speaker (or past thoughts of the speaker himself), even when the preceding or following clauses are not in indirect discourse. (See 694 and 684.)

div2.head: General Principles of Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: The following are the general principles of indirect discourse, the particular applications of which are shown in 669710.
1. In indirect quotations after o(/ti or w(s and in indirect questions,

(b) after secondary tenses, each primary tense of the indicative and each subjunctive of the direct discourse may be either changed to the same tense of the optative or retained in its original mood and tense. The imperfect and pluperfect, having no tenses in the optative, are generally retained in the indicative (but see 673). An aorist indicative belonging to a dependent clause of the direct discourse remains unchanged, but one belonging to the leading clause may be changed to the optative like a primary tense.

2. Secondary tenses of the indicative expressing an unreal condition, indicatives with a)/n, and all optatives (with or without a)/n), are retained, with no change in either mood or tense, after both primary and secondary tenses.

3. When the quotation depends on a verb which takes the infinitive or participle, the leading verb of the quotation is changed to the corresponding tense of the infinitive or participle, after both primary and secondary tenses, a)/n being retained if it is in the direct form; and the dependent verbs follow the preceding rules.

4. The adverb a)/n is never joined with a verb in indirect discourse unless it stood also in the direct form. On the other hand, a)/n is never omitted in indirect discourse if it was used in the direct form; except that, when it is joined to a relative word or a particle before a subjunctive in direct discourse, it is regularly dropped when the subjunctive is changed to the optative after a past tense in indirect discourse.

5. The indirect discourse regularly retains the same negative particle which would be used in the direct form. But the infinitive and participle sometimes take mh/ in indirect discourse where ou) would be used in the direct form. (See examples under 685 and 688.) In indirect questions introduced by ei), whether, and in the second part of alternative indirect questions (665), mh/ can be used as well as ou).

As an indirect quotation or question is generally the object or subject of its leading verb, it may stand in apposition with a pronoun like tou=to which represents such an object or subject; as tou=to le/gomen, o(/ti sofo/s e)stin, we say this, that he is wise; tou=to dh=lo/n e)stin, o(/ti sofo/s e)stin, this is plain, that he is wise; tou=to skeyo/meqa, ei) a)lhqh= le/geis, we shall inquire into this, whether you tell the truth.

div2.head: Simple Sentences in Indirect Discourse: Indicative and Optative after o(/ti and w(s, and in Indirect Questions.
div2.p: When the direct form is an indicative (without a)/n) in a simple sentence, we have (667, 1) the following rules for indirect quotations after o(/ti or w(s and for indirect questions:—

(See 663, Il. 1.) *gnwto\n de\ w(s h)/dh *trw/essin o)le/qrou pei/rat' e)fh=ptai. Il. vii. 401.

(For ou) and mh/ in the last four examples, representing ou) of the direct question, see 667, 5.) *qauma/zw po/tera w(s kratw=n ai)tei= ta\ o(/pla h)\ w(s dia\ fili/an dw=ra. XEN. It is to be noticed that indirect questions after primary tenses retain an indicative of the direct question in Greek, where the subjunctive is used in Latin. Thus, nescio quis sit, I know not who he is, in Greek is simply a)gnow= ti/s e)stin. This does not apply to indirect questions which would require the subjunctive in the direct form (677).

2. After secondary tenses the verb may be either changed to the optative or retained in the indicative, the tense of the direct discourse being retained in either case. The optative is the more common form. E.g. *)/elecen o(/ti gra/foi (or o(/ti gra/fei), he said that he was writing; i.e. he said gra/fw. *)/elecen o(/ti gegrafw\s ei)/h (or o(/ti ge/grafen), he said that he had written; i.e. he said ge/grafa. *)/elecen o(/ti gra/yoi (or o(/ti gra/yei), he said that he should write; i.e. he said gra/yw. *)/elecen o(/ti gra/yeien (or o(/ti e)/grayen), he said that he had written; i.e. he said e)/graya. (For the imperfect and pluperfect, see 672.)
