(Here le/goi might have been used.) *)ebouleu/onq' ou(=toi ti/n' au)tou= katalei/yousin, they were considering whom they should leave here. DEM. xix. 122. *)erwtw/ntwn tinw=n dia\ ti/ a)pe/qanen, paragge/llein e)ke/leuen, k.t.l. XEN. Hell. ii. 1, 4.

(a) After past tenses the indicative and optative are in equally good use; the optative being used when the writer incorporates the quotation entirely into his own sentence, and the indicative when he quotes it in the original words as far as his own construction allows. The indicative here, like the subjunctive in final clauses after past tenses (318), is merely a more vivid form of expression than the optative, with no difference in meaning. We even find both moods in the same sentence. E.g. *ou(=toi e)/legon o(/ti *ku=ros me\n te/qnhken, *)ariai=os de\ pefeugw\s e)n tw=| staqmw=| ei)/h kai\ le/goi, k.t.l. XEN. An. ii. 1, 3. (Here te/qnhken contains the most important part of the message.) *)ek de\ tou/tou e)punqa/neto h)/dh au)tw=n kai\ o(po/shn o(do\n dih/lasan, kai\ ei) oi)koi=to h( xw/ra. Id. Cyr. iv. 4, Id. Cyr. 4. *)eto/lma le/gein, w(s xre/a te pa/mpolla e)kte/tiken u(pe\r e)mou= kai\ w(s polla\ tw=n e)mw=n la/boien. DEM. xxvii. 49. *(/omoioi h)=san qauma/zein o(/poi pote\ tre/yontai oi( *(/ellhnes kai\ ti/ e)n nw=| e)/xoien. XEN. An. iii. 5, 13.

(b) The perfect and future were less familiar than the other tenses of the optative, so that these tenses were sometimes retained in the indicative even when the present or the aorist was changed to the optative. See the last two examples under (a). In indirect questions the aorist indicative was generally retained (see 125). Some writers (as Thucydides) preferred the more direct forms in all indirect discourse (320).

In Homer this construction (669) is fully developed in indirect questions: see examples of both indicative and optative in 669, 1 and 2. But in indirect quotations, while the indicative is freely used after both present and past tenses, the change of the indicative to the optative after past tenses had not yet been introduced. In the single case of ei)pei=n w(s with the optative, mermh/rice . . e(/kasta ei)pei=n, w(s e)/lqoi kai\ i(/koit' e)s patri/da gai=an, he hesitated about telling him each event, how he had returned, etc., Od. xxiv. 237, w(s appears only on its way from its meaning how (663, Od. 2) to its later use with the optative as that. We first find the optative in genuine oratio obliqua (with w(s) Hymn. Ven. 214, ei)=pen w(s e)/oi. Further, the later principle by which the indicative after past tenses (when it is not changed to the optative) retains the tense of the direct form is almost unknown in the Homeric language. Here a present or perfect indicative of the direct discourse after a past tense is changed to an imperfect or pluperfect; so that I knew that he was planning evil, which in Attic would be e)gi/gnwskon o(/ti kaka\ mh/doito (or mh/detai), in Homer is gi/gnwskon o(/ (= o(/ti) kaka\ mh/deto, Hom. Od. iii. 166. (For examples, see 674.) The aorist indicative, which has no corresponding tense to express its own time referred to the past, was always retained after past tenses; as in gnw= o(/ oi( ou)/ti h)=lqen, Hom. Il. xi. 439; so i. 537, Hom. Il. xxii. 445.Likewise the future indicative is once retained, in Hom. Od. xiii. 340, h)/|de) o(\ nosth/seis, I knew that you would return; but elsewhere the past future with e)/mellon is used, as in Hom. Il. xx. 466, ou)de\ to\ h)/|dh o(\ ou) pei/sesqai e)/mellen, and Hom. Od. xix. 94, Hom. Il. xi. 22.These examples show the need of the later future optative (129). In Hom. Il. xxii. 10, ou)de/ nu/ pw/ me e)/gnws w(s qeo/s ei)mi, and xx. 265 the present expresses a present truth rather than a past fact.

It thus appears that the peculiar constructions with o(/ti and w(s in oratio obliqua (667, 1, b), which gave such grace and variety to the later language, were not yet developed in Homer; but clauses with o(/ti, w(s, etc., were still connected with the leading verb by the same looser construction which we use in English (as I knew that he was planning evil), the dependent verb expressing its own absolute time (see 22), as it did in the relative clauses in which these clauses originated, or in the more primitive parataxis. Thus gi/gnwskon o(\ kaka\ mh/deto (above) meant originally I knew as to what he was planning evil; and without o(/, in a still earlier stage, I knew: he was planning evil (which we can say in English). Even after the more thorough incorporation of the dependent clause was established, by which either mh/detai or mh/doito became the regular form, the more primitive imperfect is occasionally found, even in Attic prose (see 674, 2).

The most common Homeric construction in indirect discourse is that of fhmi/ with the infinitive, of which 130 examples occur.See Schmitt, Ursprung des Substantivsatzes, p. 70. The following statistics are based on Schmitt's collection of Homeric examples. Homer has 40 cases of o(/ti, o(/tti, or o(/ with the indicative after verbs of knowing, hearing, perceiving, or remembering (23 of o(/, 17 of o(/ti or o(/tti); and 4 after verbs of saying (3 of o(/ti, 1 of o(/). 18 of w(s after verbs of knowing, etc.; 8 after verbs of saying. 5 of o(/ t) (for o(/ te=o(/) after gignw/skw, ei)/domai, and dh=lon. 2 of ou(/neka after verbs of knowing, etc.; 4 after verbs of saying (omitting Od. vii. 299 as causal). Only 3 of the 16 cases of these particles after verbs of saying are in the Iliad; while of the 65 cases after verbs of knowing, etc., 42 are in the Iliad (29 with o(/ti, etc., Od. 9 with w(s, Od. 3 with o(/ t), Od. 1 with ou(/neka).

An imperfect or pluperfect of the direct discourse is regularly retained in the indicative, after past tenses, for want of an imperfect or pluperfect optative. E.g. *)akou/sas de\ *cenofw=n e)/legen o(/ti o)rqw=s h)|tiw=nto kai\ au)to\ to\ e)/rgon au)toi=s marturoi/h, he said that they had accused him rightly, and that the fact itself bore witness to them; i.e. he said o)rqw=s h)|tia=sqe kai\ to\ e)/rgon u(mi=n marturei=. XEN. An. iii. 3, 12. *ei)=xe ga\r le/gein, kai\ o(/ti mo/noi tw=n *(ellh/nwn basilei= sunema/xonto e)n *plataiai=s, kai\ o(/ti u(/steron ou)de/pote strateu/sainto e)pi\ basile/a (he said mo/noi sunemaxo/meqa, kai\ ou)de/pote e)strateusa/meqa). Id. Hell. vii. 1, Id. Hell. 34. *tou/twn e(/kaston h)ro/mhn ei)/ tines ei)=en ma/rtures w(=n e)nanti/on th\n proi=k' a)pe/dosan, au)to\n d' *)/afobon, ei)/ tines parh=san o(/t' a)pela/mbanen, I asked each of these men whether there were any witnesses before whom they had paid the dowry; and Aphobus, whether there had been any present when he received it. DEM. xxx. 19. (The two questions were ei)si\ ma/rture/s tines; and parh=sa/n tines; )

(Imperfect Optative.) In a few cases, the present optative is used after past tenses to represent the imperfect indicative. The present optative thus supplies the want of an imperfect, like the present infinitive and participle (119 and 140). This can be done only when the context makes it perfectly clear that the optative represents an imperfect, and not a present. E.g. *to
 *timago/ran a)pe/kteinan, kathgorou=ntos tou= *le/ontos w(s ou)/te suskhnou=n e)qe/loi e(autw=| meta/ te *pelopi/dou pa/nta bouleu/oito. XEN. Hell. vii. 1, 38. (The words of Leon were ou)/te suskhnou=n h)/qele/ moi, meta/ te *pel. pa/nta e)bouleu/eto.) *ta\ pepragme/na dihgou=nto, o(/ti au)toi\ me
 e)pi\ tou\s polemi/ous ple/oien, th
 de\ a)nai/resin tw=n nauagw=n prosta/caien a)ndra/sin i(kanoi=s. Ib. i. 7, Ib. 5. (The direct discourse was au)toi\ me
 e)ple/omen, th
 de\ a)nai/resin proseta/camen.) *kai/ moi pa/ntes a)pekri/nanto, o(/ti ou)dei\s ma/rtus parei/h, komi/zoito de\ lamba/nwn kaq' o(posonou=n de/oito *)/afobos par' au)tw=n, they all replied, that no witness had been present, and that Aphobus had received the money from them, taking it in such sums as he happened to want. DEM. xxx. 20. (The direct discourse was ou)dei\s ma/rtus parh=n, e)komi/zeto de\ lamba/nwn kaq' o(posonou=n de/oito. *parei/h contains the answer to the question ei)/ tines parh=san in the preceding sentence, quoted in 672. The imperfect in that sentence prevents the optatives in the reply from being ambiguous.) *)akou/sas pisteu/w tou/tw|, w(s a)/ra *leo/ntios, ai)sqo/menos nekrou\s para\ tw=| dhmi/w| keime/nous, a(/ma me
 i)dei=n e)piqumoi=, a(/ma d' au)= dusxerai/noi kai\ a)potre/poi e(auto
, kai\ te/ws ma/xoito/ te kai\ parakalu/ptoito. PLAT. Rep. 439E. (All the optatives represent imperfects.) See also HDT. ix. 16 (end).

1. In Homer, where clauses with o(/ti, w(s, etc. are not yet constructed on the principles of indirect discourse (see 671), a present or perfect of the direct form appears as an imperfect or pluperfect in these clauses after past tenses. E.g. *ou)de/ ti h)/|dh o(/tti dhio/wnto laoi/. Il. xiii. 674 (here the present optative or indicative would be regular in Attic Greek). *)epo/rouse, gignw/skwn o(/ oi( au)to\s u(pei/rexe xei=ras *)apo/llwn (later u(pere/xoi or u(pere/xei). Il. v. 433. *ou) ga/r oi(/ tis h)/ggeil' o(/tti r(a/ oi( po/sis e)/ktoqi mi/mne pula/wn. Il. xxii. 438.See Od. xxiv. 182; and iii. 166, discussed in 671.

2. We sometimes find the imperfect and pluperfect with o(/ti or w(s representing the present or perfect of the direct form after past tenses, even in Attic Greek. In such cases the context always makes it clear that the tense represented is not an imperfect or pluperfect (672). E.g. *)en pollh=| a)pori/a| h)=san oi( *(/ellhnes, e)nnoou/menoi me
 o(/ti e)pi\ tai=s basile/ws qu/rais h)=san, ku/klw| de\ au)toi=s po/leis pole/miai h)=san, a)gora
 de\ ou)dei\s e)/ti pare/cein e)/mellen, a)pei=xon de\ th=s *(ella/dos ou) mei=on h)\ mu/ria sta/dia, prou)dedw/kesan de\ au)tou\s kai\ oi( ba/rbaroi, mo/noi de\ kataleleimme/noi h)=san ou)de\ i(ppe/a ou)de/na su/mmaxon e)/xontes, the Greeks thought: We are at the king's gates; hostile cities surround us; no one will supply us a market; we are not less than ten thousand stades from Greece; the barbarians have betrayed us, and we have been left alone. XEN. An. iii. 1, 2. (The direct forms would be the present and perfect indicative.) *dia\ to
 xqizino
 a)/nqrwpon, o(\s h(ma=s diedu/et', e)capatw=n kai\ le/gwn w(s filaqh/naios h)=n kai\ ta)n *sa/mw| prw=tos katei/poi, i.e. saying filaqh/naio/s ei)mi kai\ ta)n *sa/mw| prw=tos katei=pon. AR. Vesp. 283. (Here ei)mi/ is changed to h)=n, not to ei)/h or e)sti/: katei=pon could be changed only to katei/poi.)

3. In such cases the more thorough incorporation of the dependent clause which is required to make the oratio obliqua complete is wanting, and the clause stands in the loose relation in which, for example, causal sentences usually stand to their leading verb (see 715). For the same incomplete oratio obliqua in dependent clauses of a quotation, see 691 and 701.

1. An indirect quotation with o(/ti or w(s and the optative is sometimes followed by an independent optative, generally introduced by ga/r, which continues the quotation as if it were itself dependent on the o(/ti or w(s. E.g. *)/hkouon d' e)/gwge/ tinwn w(s ou)de\ tou\s lime/nas kai\ ta\s a)gora\s e)/ti dw/soien au)tw=| karpou=sqai: ta\ ga\r koina\ ta\ *qettalw=n a)po\ tou/twn de/oi dioikei=n, for (as they said) they must administer, etc. DEM. i. 22. *)apekri/nanto au)tw=| o(/ti a)du/nata sfi/sin ei)/h poiei=n a(\ prokalei=tai a)/neu *)aqhnai/wn: pai=des ga\r sfw=n kai\ gunai=kes par' e)kei/nois ei)/hsan. THUC. ii. 72. *)/elegon o(/ti panto\s a)/cia le/goi *seu/qhs: xeimw\n ga\r ei)/h, k.t.l. XEN. An. vii. 3, 13.

2. Such independent optatives are sometimes found even when no optative precedes; but the context always contains some allusion to another's thought or expression. E.g. *(upe/sxeto to
 a)/ndr' *)axaioi=s to/nde dhlw/sein a)/gwn: oi)/oito me
 ma/lisq' e(kou/sion labw
, ei) mh\ qe/loi d), a)/konta, i.e. he thought (as he said), etc. SOPH. Ph. 617. *)alla\ ga ou)de/n ti ma=llon h)=n a)qa/naton, a)lla\ kai\ au)to\ to\ ei)s a)nqrw/pou sw=ma e)lqei=n a)rxh\ h)=n au)th=| o)le/qrou, w(/sper no/sos: kai\ talaipwroume/nh te dh\ tou=ton to
 bi/on zw/|h, kai\ teleutw=sa/ ge e)n tw=| kaloume/nw| qana/tw| a)pollu/oito, and (according to the theory) it lives in misery, etc., and finally perishes in what is called death. PLAT. Phaed. 95D. (Plato is here stating the views of others.)

We may even have o(/ti or w(s with the optative when the leading verb is not past, if there is an implied reference to some former expression of the thought quoted. E.g. *)=ar' ou)=n dh\ ou) metri/ws a)pologhso/meqa, o(/ti pro\s to\ o)\n pefukw\s ei)/h a(milla=sqai, kai\ ou)k e)pime/noi, . . . a)ll' i)/oi kai\ ou)k a)mblu/noito ou)d' a)polh/goi tou= e)/rwtos, k.t.l., i.e. shall we not defend him very properly by stating (what we once said) that it is (was) his nature to press on towards pure Being, etc. (the optatives representing indicatives). PLAT. Rep. 490A.

div2.head: Subjunctive or Optative representing the Interrogative Subjunctive.
div2.p:
In indirect questions, after a primary tense, an interrogative subjunctive (287) retains its mood and tense; after a secondary tense, it may be either changed to the same tense of the optative or retained in the subjunctive. E.g. *frazw/meq' . . . h)/ r() au)=tis po/lemon o)/rsomen (subj.) h)= filo/thta met' a)mfote/roisi ba/lwmen, let us consider whether we shall again rouse war or cast friendship upon both armies. Il. iv. 14. *su\ de/ moi nhmerte\s e)ni/spes, h)/ min a)poktei/nw h)=e soi\ e)nqa/d' a)/gw, and do you tell me truly whether I shall slay him or bring him hither to you. Od. xxii. 166.See Od. xvi. 73, Od. xix. 524. *pro\s a)mfo/tera a)porw=, tau/thn q' o(/pws e)kdw= kai\ ta)/ll' o(po/qen dioikw=, I am at a loss on both questions, how I shall give her a dowry (pw=s tau/thn e)kdw=; ), and how (whence) I shall pay my other expenses (po/qen ta)/lla dioikw=; ). DEM. xxvii. 66. *bouleu/omai o(/pws se a)podrw=, I am trying to think how I shall escape you (pw=s se a)podrw=; ). XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 13. *ou)k e)/xw ti/ le/gw, I know not what I shall say. DEM. ix. 54.So in Latin, non habeo quid (or quod) dicam.
*ou)k e)/xw so/fism' o(/tw| a)pallagw=, I have no device (i.e. I know not) how I shall escape. AESCH. Prom. 470.
*ou) ga\r dh\ di) a)peiri/an ge ou) fh/seis e)/xein o(/ ti ei)/ph|s, for it is not surely through inexperience that you will declare that you know not what to say (i.e. ti/ ei)/pw; ). DEM. xix. 120.So o(/ ti dw= and oi(=s dw=, XEN. An. i. 7, 7. (See 572.) *ta\ de\ e)kpw/mata ou)k oi)=d' ei) *xrusa/nta| tou/tw| dw=, I do not know whether I shall give them, etc. Id. Cyr. viii. 4, Id. Cyr. 16. *)epanerome/nou *kthsifw=ntos ei) kale/sh| *dhmosqe/nhn, when Ctesiphon asks whether he shall call Demosthenes. AESCHIN. iii. 202. (For ei) see 680.)

*)en de/ oi( h)=tor mermh/ricen, h)\ o(/ ge tou\s me
 a)nasth/seien, o( d' *)atrei+/dhn e)nari/zoi, h)=e xo/lon pau/seien e)rhtu/seie/ te qumo/n. Il. i. 188. (The direct questions were tou\s me
 a)nasth/sw; *)atrei+/dhn d' e)nari/zw; pau/sw e)rhtu/sw te; ) *klh/rous pa/llon, o(ppo/teros dh\ pro/sqen a)fei/h xa/lkeon e)/gxos, i.e. they shook the lots (to decide) which should first throw his spear, the question being po/teros pro/sqen a)fh=|; Il. iii. 316. *)exrhsthria/zeto ei) e)kba/loi to
 *)/adrhston. HDT. v. 67. *)eph/ronto ei) paradoi=en *korinqi/ois th
 po/lin, they asked whether they should give up their city, the question being paradw=men th
 po/lin; THUC. i. 25. *)ebouleu/onto ei) ta\ skeuofo/ra e)ntau=qa a)/gointo h)\ a)pi/oien e)pi\ to\ strato/pedon. XEN. An. i. 10, 17 : so i. 10, XEN. An. 5. *)hpo/rei o(/ ti xrh/saito tw=| pra/gmati, he was at a loss how to act in the matter, i.e. ti/ xrh/swmai; Id. Hell. vii. 4, Id. Hell. 39. *ou) ga ei)/xomen o(/pws drw=ntes kalw=s pra/caimen, for we could not see how we should fare well if we did it. SOPH. Ant. 270.

*)apore/ontos de\ basile/os o(/ ti xrh/shtai tw=| pareo/nti prh/gmati, *)epia/lths h)=lqe/ oi( e)s lo/gous. HDT. vii. 213. *)hpo/rhse me\n o(pote/- rwse diakinduneu/sh| xwrh/sas. THUC. i. 63. *oi( *plataih=s e)bouleu/onto ei)/te katakau/swsin w(/sper e)/xousin, e)mprh/santes to oi)/khma, ei)/te ti a)/llo xrh/swntai, whether they should set the house on fire and burn them as they were, or should dispose of them in some other way. Id. ii. 4. *)aporh/santes o(/ph| kaqormi/swntai, e)s *prw/thn th\n nh=son e)/pleusan. Id. iv. 13.

The context must decide whether the optative in an indirect question represents a subjunctive (as here) or an indicative (669). The distinction is especially important with the aorist optative (see 125).

When the leading verb is an optative referring to the future, the optative can be used, by assimilation, to represent the subjunctive in these indirect questions. E.g. *xari/enta gou=n pa/qoim' a)\n, ei) mh\) xoim' o(/poi tau=ta kataqei/hn, if I should not have anywhere to put these down (know where to put them). AR. Eccl. 794. (See other examples under 186.)

*ei), whether, can introduce the subjunctive here, as well as the indicative or optative: see XEN. Cyr. viii. 4, 16 , and AESCHIN. iii. 202, quoted in 677. *)ea/n cannot mean whether, and wherever this introduces a subjunctive the expression is conditional. (See 493.)

div2.head: Indicative or Optative with a)/n.
div2.p:
An indicative or optative with a)/n retains its mood and tense (with a)/n) unchanged in indirect discourse with o(/ti or w(s and in indirect questions, after both primary and secondary tenses. E.g. *le/gei o(/ti tou=to a)
 e)ge/neto, he says that this would have happened: e)/legen o(/ti tou=to a)
 e)ge/neto, he said that this would have happened. *le/gei (or e)/legen) o(/ti ou(=tos dikai/ws a)
 qa/noi, he says (or said) that this man would justly be put to death.

(*qemistoklh=s) a)pekri/nato, o(/ti ou)/t' a)
 au)to\s *seri/fios w)
 o)nomasto\s e)ge/neto ou)/t' e)kei=nos *)aqhnai=os, he replied that he should not have become famous himself if he had been a Seriphian, nor would the other if he had been an Athenian. PLAT. Rep. 330A. *)ennoei=te, o(/ti h(=tton a)
 sta/sis ei)/h e(no\s a)/rxontos h)\ pollw=n. XEN. An. vi. i. 29. *apekri/nato, o(/ti pro/sqen a)
 a)poqa/noien h)\ ta\ o(/pla paradoi/hsan. Ib. ii. 1, Ib. 10. (The direct discourse was pro/sqen a)
 a)poqa/noimen.) *ou)k a)
 e)lpi/santas w(s a)
 e)pece/lqoi tis au)toi=s e)s ma/xhn, when they would never have expected that any one would come out to fight with them. THUC. v. 9. *parelqw/n tis deica/tw, w(s oi( *qettaloi\ nu=n ou)k a)
 e)leu/qeroi ge/nointo a)/smenoi. DEM. ii. 8. *ou)d' ei)de/nai fhsi\ ti/ a)
 poiw=n u(mi=n xari/saito, he says he does not even know what he could do to gratify you. Id. xix. 48.
*ou)k e)/xw ti/s a)
 genoi/man AESCH. Prom. 905 ; so 907. *)hrw/twn ei) doi=en a)
 tou/twn ta\ pista/ XEN. An. iv. 8, 7.
The same principle applies when a secondary tense of the indicative without a)/n in the construction of 415 is quoted. E.g.
(*)/elegen) o(/ti krei=tton h)=n au)tw=| to/te a)poqanei=n, he said that he had better have died at once. LYS. x. 25. (The direct discourse was krei=tton h)=n moi a)poqanei=n.)

div2.head: Infinitive in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: When the infinitive stands in indirect discourse, its tense represents the corresponding tense of the finite verb in the direct form, the present and perfect including the imperfect and pluperfect. If a)/n was used in the direct form, it must be retained in the quotation, each tense with a)/n representing the corresponding tenses of either indicative or optative with a)/n. E.g. *fhsi\ gra/fein, he says that he is writing; e)/fh gra/fein, he said that he was writing; fh/sei gra/fein, he will say that he is (then) writing. (He says gra/fw.) *fhsi\ (e)/fh) gra/fein a)\n, ei) e)du/nato, he says (or said) that he should now be writing, if he were able. (He says e)/grafon a)/n.) *fhsi\ (e)/fh) gra/fein a)\n, ei) du/naito, he says (or said) that he should write, if he should (ever) be able. (He says gra/foimi a)/n.)

*fhsi\ gra/yai, he says that he wrote; e)/fh gra/yai, he said that he had written; fh/sei gra/yai, he will say that he wrote. (He says e)/graya.) *fhsi\ (e)/fh) gra/yai a)\n, ei) e)dunh/qh, he says (or said) that he should have written, if he had been able. (He says e)/graya a)/n.) *fhsi\ (e)/fh) gra/yai a)\n, ei) dunhqei/h, he says (or said) that he should write, if he should (ever) be able. (He says gra/yaimi a)/n.)
*fhsi\ (fh/sei) gegrafe/nai, he says (or will say) that he has written; e)/fh gegrafe/nai, he said that he had written. (He says ge/grafa.) For the perfect with a)/n, see below and 206.

(Present.) *kai/ te/ me/ fhsi ma/xh| *trw/essin a)rh/gein. Il. i. 521. *pw=s dh\ fh\|s pole/moio meqie/men; Il. iv. 351.So Il. xvii. 338. *sku/zesqai/ oi( ei)pe\ qeou\s, e)me\ d' e)/coxa pa/ntwn a)qana/twn kexolw=sqai, tell him that the Gods are angry with him and that I am enraged with him beyond all the immortals. Il. xxiv. 113. *)arrwstei=n profasi/zetai, he pretends that he is sick: e)cw/mosen a)rrwstei=n toutoni/, he took his oath that this man was sick. DEM. xix. 124. *ou)k e)/fh au)to\s a)ll' e)kei=non strathgei=n, i.e. Cleon said that not he himself, but Nicias, was general; i.e. he said, ou)k e)gw\ au)to\s a)ll' e)kei=nos strathgei=. THUC. iv. 28. *ti/nas ou)=n eu)xa\s u(polamba/net' eu)/xesqai to
 *fi/lippon o(/t' e)/spenden; what prayers do you suppose Philip made, etc.? DEM. xix. 130. (*eu)/xesqai represents hu)/xeto: see 119.) *oi)=mai ga a)
 ou)k a)xari/stws moi e)/xein, for I think it would not be a thankless labour; i.e. ou)k a)
 e)/xoi. XEN. An. ii. 3, 18. *oi)/esqe ga to
 pate/ra ou)k a)
 fula/ttein kai\ th
 timh
 lamba/nein tw=n pwloume/nwn cu/lwn; do you think that my father would not have taken care and have received the pay for the timber sold? i.e. ou)k a)
 e)fu/latten kai\ e)la/mbanen; DEM. xlix. 35. (See 205.)

(Aorist.) *ou)de/ ke fai/hs a)ndri\ maxhsa/menon to/n g' e)lqe/men, nor would you say that he came after a battle with a man. Il. iii. 393. *katasxei=n fhsi tou/tous, he says that he detained them. *tou\s d' ai)xmalw/tous ou)d' e)nqumhqh=nai/ fhsi lu/sasqai, but he says that he did not even think of ransoming the prisoners. DEM. xix. 39. (He says kate/sxon and ou)d' e)nequmh/qhn.) *(o *ku=ros le/getai gene/sqai *kambu/sew, Cyrus is said to have been the son of Cambyses. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 1. *tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h)/lpizen i)/sws a)
 e)pecelqei=n kai\ th
 gh=n ou)k a)
 periidei=n tmhqh=nai, he hoped that the Athenians would perhaps march out and not allow their land to be laid waste; i.e. i)/sws a)
 e)pece/lqoien kai\ ou)k a)
 perii/doien. THUC. ii. 20. *)aph/|esan nomi/santes mh\ a)
 e)/ti i(kanoi\ gene/sqai kwlu=sai to
 teixismo/n. Id. vi. 102. (Here ou)k a)
 genoi/meqa would be the direct form: see 685.) So i. 139. *ou)k a)
 h(gei=sq' au)to
 ka)
 e)pidramei=n, do you not believe that (in that case) he would have run thither? i.e. e)pe/dramen a)
. DEM. xxvii. 56. (See 223.) A single infinitive with a)/n occurs in Homer: kai\ d' a)
 toi=s a)/lloisin e)/fh paramuqh/sasqai, Il. ix. 684. (The direct discourse is given in the words of Achilles in vs. 417, kai\ d' a)
 paramuqhsai/mhn.) (See 207.)

(Perfect.) *frone/w tetimh=sqai *dio\s ai)/sh|, I feel that I have been honoured. Il. ix. 608. *fhsi\n au)to\s ai)/tios gegenh=sqai, he says ai)/tios gege/nhmai. DEM. xix. 37. *ei)/kazon h)\ diw/konta oi)/xesqai h)\ katalhyo/meno/n ti proelhlake/nai. XEN. An. i. 10, 16. (Their thought was h)\ diw/kwn oi)/xetai, h)\ proelh/laken.) *)/efh xrh/maq' e(autw=| tou\s *qhbai/ous e)pikekhruxe/nai, he said that the Thebans had offered a reward for him. DEM. xix. 21. *)ante/legon mh\ dikai/ws sfw=n katadedika/sqai, le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw e)s *lakedai/mona ta\s sponda\s o(/t' e)se/pemyan tou\s o(pli/tas, they rejoined that they (the Eleans) had not justly condemned them, saying that the truce had not yet been announced at Sparta when they sent in the soldiers (they said ou) katadedi/kasqe, and ou)k e)phggelme/nai h)=sa/n pw ai( spondai\ o(/t' e)sepe/myamen). THUC. v. 49.So e)kpeplh=xqai, representing e)cepe/plhkto, XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 27. (See 123, above.)
(For examples of the perfect infinitive with a)/n, representing the pluperfect indicative and the perfect optative, see 206.)

(Future.) *)/efhs sw=s e)/ssesqai. Il. xxii. 331.So Od. iv. 664. *kai/ moi e)/eipen *murmido/nwn to\n a)/riston lei/yein fa/os h)eli/oio, he told me o( a)/ristos . . . lei/yei. Il. xviii. 9. *kai\ dh/ moi ge/ras au)to\s au)/fairh/sesqai a)peilei=s. Il. i. 161. *)epagge/lletai ta\ di/kaia poih/sein, he promises to do what is right. DEM. xix. 48. *)/efh e)nto\s h(merw=n ei)/kosin h)\ a)/cein *lakedaimoni/ous zw=ntas h)\ au)tou= a)poktenei=n, he said that within twenty days he would either bring them alive or kill them where they were. THUC. iv. 28. (Cleon said h)\ a)/cw h)\ a)poktenw=.) *tau=ta (fhsi\) pepra/cesqai duoi=n h)\ triw=n h(merw=n, he says that this will have been accomplished within two or three days (137). DEM. xix. 74. (For the rare future infinitive with a)/n, see 208.)

The infinitive is said to stand in indirect discourse and its tenses correspond to those of the indicative or optative, when it depends on a verb implying thought or the expression of thought (one of the class of verba sentiendi et declarandi), and when also the thought, as originally conceived, would have been expressed by some tense of the indicative (with or without a)/n) or optative (with a)/n), so that it can be transferred without change of tense to the infinitive. Thus in bou/letai e)lqei=n, he wishes to go, e)lqei=n represents no form of either aorist indicative or aorist optative, and is therefore said to be not in indirect discourse. But in fhsi\n e)lqei=n, he says that he went, e)lqei=n represents h)=lqon of the direct discourse. The distinction in the time of the infinitive (especially of the aorist infinitive) in these two uses is obvious.

It may be asked why the infinitive after certain other verbs should not be said to stand in indirect discourse; for example, why in keleu/ei se e)lqei=n or mh\ e)lqei=n we should not say that e)lqei=n represents e)lqe/ or mh\ e)/lqh|s of direct discourse. This might perhaps be done; and we might possibly make e)lqei=n in bou/lomai e)lqei=n represent e)/lqoimi, may I go. But with other verbs of the same class, as those of advising, teaching, striving, choosing, no form of direct discourse can even be imagined. It is much harder to draw a line between these last verbs and verbs like keleu/w and bou/lomai, or even between these two, than where it is drawn above. It is impossible to say where a Greek would have drawn the line, or to be sure that he would have drawn any line at all; for our own use, the usual definition of the infinitive in oratio obliqua (as given above) is certainly the most convenient.

(*mh/, with Infinitive.) The negative particle of the infinitive in indirect discourse is regularly ou), which is retained from the direct form (667, 5). But, after certain verbs which belong to the intermediate class between those which take the infinitive in indirect discourse and those which do not (see 136), the infinitive regularly takes mh/ for its negative. Such are verbs of hoping, promising, and swearing; with those signifying to agree or consent (o(mologw=), to trust (pisteu/w), to be persuaded (pe/peismai), to testify (marturw=).See Liddell and Scott, ed. 7, under mh/, B. 5, C; also Gildersleeve in Jour. Phil. i. p. 51. The infinitive occasionally has mh/ even after the verbs which most regularly take the infinitive with ou) in indirect discourse, as fhmi/, le/gw, nomi/zw, h(gou=mai, etc. E.g. *xrh=n o)mo/sai mh\ e(ko/nta e)lqei=n, he had to swear that he did not come intentionally. HDT. ii. 179; so i. 165. *)/omnusin mh\ pw/pot' a)mei/non' e)/ph mhde/n' a)kou=sai, he swears that nobody ever heard better verses. AR. Vesp. 1047.
*)/wmnue mhde\n ei)rhke/nai. DEM. xxi. 119. *(/otan e)lpi/swsin ou(=toi mh\ a)/llws to\n ne/on kaqe/cein. PLAT. Rep. 572E. *ou)demi/an u(me/wn e)/xw e)lpi/da mh\ ou) dw/sein u(me/as di/khn. HDT. vi. 11. (For mh\ ou) see 815, HDT. 2.) *maia/dos ui(o\s u(posxo/menos kate/neuse mh/ pot' a)pokle/yein o(/s' *(ekhbo/los e)ktea/tistai. Hymn. Merc. 521; so mh/ tina e)/sesqai. Ibid. 525.

*(wmologh/samen mh/pot' a)

 e)nanti/a a)/|dein. PLAT. Phaed. 94 C. *memarturh/kasin oi( pro/teron e)rgazo/menoi mh\ ei)=nai shko
 e)n tw=| xwri/w|. LYS. vii. 11.So DEM. xlv. 15. *swkra/th ge e)gw\ e)gguw=mai mh\ e)pilh/sesqai. PLAT. Prot. 336D. *pisteu/w mh\ yeu/sein me tau/tas ta\s a)gaqa\s e)lpidas. XEN. Cyr. i. 5, 13. *pe/peismai e)gw\ mhde/na a)dikei=n a)nqrw/pwn. PLAT. Ap. 37 A: so 37B.

*fai/hn d' a)
 e)/gwge mhdeni\ mhdemi/an ei)=nai pai/deusin para\ tou= mh\ a)re/skontos. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 39. So PLAT. Theaet. 155A. *pa/ntes e)rou=si to\ loipo
 mhde
 ei)=nai kerdalew/teron a)reth=s. XEN. Cyr. vii. 1, 18. *)eno/mise de\ mh\ a)
 gene/sqai pote\ pisto
 a)/nqrwpon. Ib. vii. 5, Ib. 59. *kai\ a)/rti e)/legon mhde/na e)qe/lein e(ko/nta a)/rxein. PLAT. Rep. 346E. *ti/s a)
 qew=n me
 pai=das h(goi=to ei)=nai, qeou\s de\ mh/; Ap. 27 D. *prou)/legon mh\ a)
 gi/gnesqai po/lemon (i.e. ou)k a)

The examples in the last paragraph are opposed to the regular usage of the language, which would demand ou) in all of them. We must suppose that the use of mh/ with the infinitive was so fixed, before the infinitive began to be used in indirect discourse, that mh/ always seemed natural, even after ou) had become the regular form after verbs of saying, thinking, etc. We sometimes find strange uses of mh/. In THUC. i. 118, o)/ntes me\n kai\ pro\ tou= mh\ taxei=s i)e/nai e)s tou\s pole/mous, having even before this been not hasty to go into wars, it may be difficult to find a better explanation of the anomalous mh/ than the perhaps heretical one, that tou= mh\ taxei=s i)e/nai had a more natural sound than tou= ou) taxei=s i)e/nai, although neither tou= nor the negative has anything to do with the infinitive. So some people say between you and I, merely because you and me sounds vulgar.

With mh/ and the infinitive in indirect discourse we may compare the rare o(/ti mh/ with the indicative, which occurs in THEOG. 659, ou)d' o)mo/sai xrh\ tou=q), o(/ti mh/pote prh=gma to/d' e)/stai, and ANT. v. 21, tau=ta skopei=te, o(/ti mh\ pronoi/a| ma=llon e)gi/gneto h)\ tu/xh|: see also SOPH. Ant. 685, o(/pws su\ mh\ le/geis o)rqw=s ta/de. *(/oti mh/ with the indicative became a regular construction in later Greek (as in Lucian). *)omo/sai o(/ti mh\ e)/stai in Theognis suggests the still more puzzling cases of mh/ alone with the indicative after oaths in Homer and Aristophanes: i)/stw *zeu\s, mh\ me
 toi=s i(/ppoisin a)nh e)poixh/setai a)/llos, Il. x. 329; i)/stw nu=n to/de gai=a . . . mh\ di) e)mh
 i)o/thta *poseida/wn e)nosi/xqwn phmai/nei *trw=as, Il. xv. 36; ma\ to
 *)apo/llw mh/ s' e)gw\ kataklinw= xamai/, AR. Lys. 917 ; so AR. Eccl. 1000; ma\ gh=n, ma\ pagi/das, . . . mh\) gw\ no/hma komyo/teron h)/kousa/ pw, AR. Av. 194.I have no explanation, even to suggest, of the strange use of mh/ in these last examples.

div2.head: Participle in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: When the participle stands in indirect discourse, it follows the rules already given for the infinitive (683), in regard to its tense and the use of a)/n. E.g. *)agge/llei tou/tous e)rxome/nous, he announces that they are coming; h)/ggeile tou/tous e)rxome/nous, he announced that they were coming. (The announcement is ou(=toi e)/rxontai.) *)agge/llei tou/tous e)lqo/ntas, he announces that they came; h)/ggeile tou/tous e)lqo/ntas, he announced that they had come. (He says h)=lqon.) *)agge/llei tou/tous e)lhluqo/tas, he announces that they have come; h)/ggeile tou/tous e)lhluqo/tas, he announced that they had come. (He says e)lhlu/qasin.) *)agge/llei (h)/ggeile) tou=to genhso/menon, he announces (or announced) that this is (or was) about to happen. (He says tou=to genh/setai.)

*ou)d' a)/ra pw/ ti h)/|dh *pa/troklon teqnho/ta di=os *)axilleu/s, nor yet did Achilles have any knowledge that Patroclus was dead. Il. xvii. 402. *gi/gnwske qeou= go/non h)u\n e)o/nta. Il. vi. 191. *thle/maxos d' a)/ra min pa/lai h)/|deen e)/ndon e)o/nta. Od. xxiii. 29: so xvii. 549, Od. 556. *toi=s te ga\r e)pixeirh/masin e(w/rwn ou) katorqou=ntes kai\ tou\s stratiw/tas a)xqome/nous th=| monh=|, for they saw that they were not succeeding in their attempts, and that the soldiers were distressed by the delay; i.e. they saw ou) katorqou=men kai\ oi( stratiw=tai a)/xqontai. THUC. vii. 47. *)emme/nomen oi(=s w(mologh/samen dikai/ois ou)=sin; do we abide by what we acknowledged to be just (i.e. di/kaia/ e)stin)? PLAT. Crit. 50A. *pa/nq' e(/neka e(autou= poiw=n e)celh/legktai, it has been proved that he is doing everything for his own interest. DEM. ii. 8. *au)tw=| *ku=ron e)pistrateu/onta prw=tos h)/ggeila, I first announced to him that Cyrus was on his march against him. XEN. An. ii. 3, 19. See SOPH. O.T. 395.

*(/opws de/ ge tou\s polemi/ous du/naisqe kakw=s poiei=n, ou)k oi)=sqa manqa/nontas u(ma=s polla\s kakourgi/as; do you not know that you learned, etc.? XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 28. (Here du/naisqe and the whole context show that manqa/nontas represents e)manqa/nete.) *me/mnhmai de\ e)/gwge kai\ pai=s w)\n *kriti/a| tw=|de cuno/nta se, I remember that you were with (cunh=sqa) this Critias. PLAT. Charm. 156A. (See 140 and the examples.)
See other examples in 904.

(Negative mh/.) The participle of indirect discourse, like the infinitive, regularly retains the negative ou) from the direct form. But, as in the case of the infinitive (685), we find many exceptions. Compare ISOC. v. 133 and THUC. i. 76, which have mh/ after oi)=da, with THUC. ii. 40 and ISOC. xv. 7, which have oi)=da ou) (all quoted in 687). See also SOPH. OC 656 , SOPH. 797 (oi)=da mh/), Ph. 79 (e)/coida mh/), O. C. 1121 (e)pi/stamai mh/); EUR. Tro. 970 (dei/cw mh/); THUC. ii. 17 (proh/|dei mh/). Here also the irregularity may be explained by the fixed earlier use of mh/ in other constructions affecting the later construction of indirect discourse (685).

div2.head: Indirect Quotation of Complex Sentences.
div2.p: When a complex sentence is indirectly quoted, its leading verb follows the principles already stated for simple sentences (669-688).
1. If the quotation depends on a primary tense, all the dependent verbs of the original sentence retain the mood and tense of the direct discourse.

2. After a secondary tense, all dependent verbs of the original sentence which there stood in the present, perfect, or future indicative, or in any tense of the subjunctive, may either be changed to the same tense of the optative or retain both the mood and tense of the direct discourse, the optative being the more common form. When the subjunctive is changed to the optative, a)/n is dropped, e)a/n, o(/tan, etc., becoming ei), o(/te, etc.
3. But dependent secondary tenses of the indicative and all dependent optatives remain unchanged after all tenses (see, however, 693). E.g.

1. (After primary tenses.) *)\an d' u(mei=s le/ghte, poih/sein (fhsi\) o(\ mh/t' ai)sxu/nhn mh/t' a)doci/an au)tw=| fe/rei. DEM. xix. 41 (i.e. poih/sw, o(\ mh/t' . . . e)moi\ fe/rei). *nomi/zw ga, a)

 mh\ kwlu/shte is in one Ms.)

3. (Past tenses of Indicative retained after secondary tenses.) *)epistei=lai de\ sfi/sin au)toi=s tou\s e)fo/rous (e)/fasan) ei)pei=n, w(s w(=n me\n pro/sqen e)poi/oun me/mfointo au)toi=s, that the Ephors charged them to say that they blamed them for what they had done before (i.e. w(=n pro/sqen e)poiei=te memfo/meqa u(mi=n). XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 6.

*)/hlpizon tou\s *sikelou\s tau/th|, ou(\s mete/pemyan, a)panth/sesqai, they hoped that the Sikels whom they had sent for would meet them here. THUC. vii. 80. *le/gousi de/ tines kai\ e(kou/sion farma/kw| a)poqanei=n au)to\n, a)du/naton nomi/santa ei)=nai e)pitele/sai basilei= a(\ u(pe/sxeto, and some say even that he (Themistocles) died a voluntary death by poison, believing that it was impossible to perform for the King what he had promised (a)du/nato/n e)stin e)pitele/sai a(\ u(pesxo/mhn). Id. i. 138. *)ante/legon, le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw ta\s sponda\s o(/t' e)se/pemyan tou\s o(pli/tas. Id. v. 49. *)/elegon w(s *cenofw=n oi)/xoito w(s *seu/qhn oi)kh/swn kai\ a(\ u(pe/sxeto au)tw=| a)polhyo/menos. XEN. An. vii. 7, 55. *(/ekaston h)ro/mhn, ei)/ tines ei)=en ma/rtures w(=n e)nanti/on th\n proi=k' a)pe/dosan (ei)si\ ma/rtures, w(=n e)nanti/on a)pe/dote; ). DEM. xxx. 19.

The aorist indicative is not changed to the aorist optative here, to avoid confusion, as the latter tense in such dependent clauses generally represents the aorist subjunctive of the direct form. Thus e)/fh a(\ eu(/roi dw/sein means he said that he would give whatever he might find (a(\ a)\n eu(/rw dw/sw); but if a(\ eu(/roi could also represent a(\ eu(=ron, it might also mean he said that he would give what he had found. In the leading clause the ambiguity is confined to indirect questions, in which the aorist indicative is generally retained for the same reason (see 125).

(Past tenses of the Indicative in unreal conditions retained.) *)edo/kei, ei) mh\ e)/fqasan cullabo/ntes tou\s a)/ndras, prodoqh=nai a)
 th
 po/lin. THUC. vi. 61. (If e)/fqasan were optative, it would represent an optative of direct discourse.) *oi)/esqe to
 pate/ra, ei) mh\ *timoqe/ou h)=n ta\ cu/la kai\ e)deh/qh ou(=tos au)tou= parasxei=n to\ nau=lon, e)a=sai a)/n pote, k.t.l., a)ll' ou)k a)
 fula/ttein kai\ th
 timh
 lamba/nein, e(/ws e)komi/sato ta\ e(autou=; DEM. xlix. 35. *tou/twn ei)/ ti h)=n a)lhqe\s, oi)esq' ou)k a)
 au)th
 labei=n; Id. xxvii. 56. *(hde/ws a)
 u(mw=n puqoi/mhn, ti/n' a)/n pote gnw/mhn peri\ e)mou= ei)/xete ei) mh\ e)petrihra/rxhsa a)lla\ ple/wn w)|xo/mhn. L. Id. 67.

(Dependent Optatives retained.) *ei)=pen o(/ti e)/lqoi a)
 ei)s lo/gous ei) o(mh/rous la/boi (he said e)/lqoimi a)
 ei) o(mh/rous la/boimi). XEN. Hell. iii. 1, 20. *(=htton a)
 dia\ tou=to tugxa/nein (dokei= moi), ei)/ ti de/oisqe par' au)tw=n. Id. An. vi. 1, Id. An. 26. *)/elegen o(/ti ou)k a)/n pote prooi=to, e)pei\ a(/pac fi/los au)toi=s e)ge/neto, ou)d' ei) e)/ti me
 mei/ous ge/nointo e)/ti de\ ka/kion pra/ceian. Ib. i. 9, Ib. 10. *deino
 a)/n ti paqei=n sauto
 h)/lpizes, ei) pu/qoinq' ou(=toi ta\ pepragme/na soi. DEM. xix. 240.

Sentences such as these are often translated like those which had a future and a dependent subjunctive in the direct discourse. Thus e)/legen o(/ti xai/roi a)
 ei) tou=to ge/noito or e)/lege xai/rein a)
 ei) tou=to ge/noito, as well as e)/legen o(/ti xairh/soi ei) tou=to ge/noito or e)/lege xairh/sein ei) tou=to ge/noito, may all be translated he said that he should rejoice if this should happen; although in the first two sentences the direct discourse was xai/roimi a)
 ei) tou=to ge/noito, I should rejoice if this should happen, and in the last two, xairh/sw e)a
 tou=to ge/nhtai, I shall rejoice if this shall happen. (See 456.)

The dependent verbs of a quotation may be changed to the optative in indirect discourse, even when the leading verb retains the indicative; and sometimes (though rarely) a dependent verb retains the subjunctive or indicative, when the leading verb is changed to the optative. This may give rise to a great variety of constructions in the same sentence. E.g. *dhlw/sas o(/ti e(/toimoi/ ei)si ma/xesqai ei)/ tis e)ce/rxoito. XEN. Cyr. iv. 1, 1. (*(/etoimoi/ ei)sin e)a/n tis e)ce/rxhtai.) *lu/sandros ei)=pe o(/ti paraspo/ndous u(ma=s e)/xoi, kai\ o(/ti ou) peri\ politei/as u(mi=n e)/stai a)lla\ peri\ swthri/as, ei) mh\ poih/saiq' a(\ *qhrame/nhs keleu/oi. LYS. xii. 74. (*)/exw, kai\ ou)k e)/stai e)a
 mh\ poih/shq' a(\ *q. keleu/ei. There is no need of the emendations poih/set) and keleu/ei.) *)edo/kei dh=lon ei)=nai o(/ti ai(rh/sontai au)to
 ei)/ tis e)piyhfi/zoi. XEN. An. vi. 1, 25. *ou)k h)gno/ei *eu)bouli/dhs o(/ti, ei) lo/gos a)podoqh/soito kai\ parage/nointo/ moi pa/ntes oi( dhmo/tai kai\ h( yh=fos dikai/ws doqei/h, ou)damou= genh/sontai oi( meta\ tou/tou sunesthko/tes. DEM. lvii. 16. (*ei) a)podoqh/setai kai\ e)a
 parage/nwntai kai\ yh=fos doqh=|, ou)damou= genh/sontai.) *)aghsi/laos gnou\s o(/ti, ei) me
 mhdete/rw| sullh/yoito, misqo
 ou)de/teros lu/sei toi=s *(/ellhsin, a)gora
 de\ ou)de/teros pare/cei, o(po/teros t' a)
 krath/sh|, ou(=tos e)xqro\s e)/stai: ei) de\ tw=| e(te/rw| sullh/yoito, ou(=to/s ge fi/los e)/soito, k.t.l. Ag. ii. 31.

*)/elegon o(/ti ei)ko/ta dokoi=en le/gein basilei=, kai\ h(/koien h(ghmo/nas e)/xontes, oi(\ au)tou\s, e)a\n spondai\ ge/nwntai, a)/cousin e)/nqen e(/cousi ta\ e)pith/deia. An. ii. 3, An. 6. *)ephrw/ta, poi=a ei)h tw=n o)re/wn o(po/qen oi( *xaldai=oi kataqe/ontes lhi/zontai. Cyr. iii. 2, Cyr. 1. *)/elecas o(/ti me/giston ei)/h maqei=n o(/pws dei= e)cerga/zesqai e(/kasta: ei) de\ mh\, ou)de\ th=s e)pimelei/as e)/fhsqa o)/felos ou)de\n gi/gnesqai, ei) mh/ tis e)pi/staito a(\ dei= kai\ w(s dei= poiei=n. Id. Oec. xv. 2.

In DEM. xviii. 148, we have both constructions of 689, DEM. 2 in the same sentence: ei) me
 tou=to tw=n e)kei/nou summa/xwn ei)shgoi=to/ tis, u(po/yesqai to\ pra=gma e)no/mize pa/ntas: a)
 d' *)aqhnai=os h)=| o( tou=to poiw=n, eu)po/rws lh/sein. Here ei) ei)shgoi=to represents a)
 (=e)a
) ei)shgh=tai, corresponding to a)
 h)=|. By keeping the subjunctive in the latter case, the expression is made more vivid by contrast.

In PLAT. Rep. 337 A we have tou/tois prou)/legon, o(/ti ei)rwneu/soio kai\ pa/nta ma=llon poih/sois h)\ a)pokrinoi=o, ei)/ ti/s ti/ se e)rwta=|, which must mean I warned them that you would dissemble and would do anything rather than answer if any one should ask you anything. The direct discourse must be ei)rwneu/setai kai\ pa/nta ma=llon poih/sei h)\ a)pokrinei=tai e)a/n ti/s ti au)to\n e)rwta=| (subj.). *)ea\n e)rwta=| must have been retained or changed to ei) with the optative; and e)rwta=| in the text is probably a copyist's mistake for e)rwtw=|, a form of the optative frequently found in the Cod. A Parisin. of Plato. See in the Republic 516 A (kaqorw=|), 518 A (gelw=|), 559 A (meletw=|), 598 C (e)capatw=|). There is, however, a various reading e)roito in a few Mss. in 337 A.

The imperfect or pluperfect sometimes stands irregularly in a dependent (as well as in the leading) clause of the indirect discourse after a secondary tense, to represent a present or perfect indicative, which would regularly be retained or changed to the present or perfect optative. Such clauses are really not included in the indirect discourse. (See 674; 701.) E.g. *)/elegon ou) kalw=s th
 *(ella/da e)leuqerou=n au)to
, ei) a)/ndras diefqeiren ou)/te xei=ras a)ntairome/nous ou)/te polemi/ous (ou) kalw=s e)leuqeroi=s, ei) diafqei/reis). THUC. iii. 32. *ou)/te ga toi=s qeoi=s e)/fh kalw=s e)/xein, ei) tai=s megalais qusi/ais ma=llon h)\ tai=s mikrai=s e)/xairon (ei) xai)/rousin). XEN. Mem. i. 3, 3. *kai\ e)/fh ei)=nai par' e(autw=| o(/son mh\ h)=n a)nhlwme/non (o(/son mh/ e)stin a)nhlwme/non). DEM. xlviii. 16. *(\a me
 ei)lh/fei th=s po/lews a)podw/sein (h(gou/mhn), I thought that he would give back what he had taken from the city; i.e. a(\ ei)/lhfen a)podw/sei. Id. xix. 151.

In a few cases, a relative or particle which had a)/n with the subjunctive in the direct form irregularly retains a)/n in indirect discourse after a past tense, although the verb has been changed to the optative. This must not be confounded with a)/n belonging to a potential optative (506; 557). E.g. *ou)k e)/sq' o(/stis ou)x h(gei=to tw=n ei)do/twn di/khn me lh/yesqai par' au)tw=n, e)peida
 ta/xista a)nh ei)=nai dokimasqei/hn (so the Mss.). DEM. xxx. 6. (The direct discourse was e)peida
 dokimasqh=|, and the regular indirect form would be e)peidh\ dokimasqei/hn or e)peida
 dokimasqw=.) (See also 702.)

When no ambiguity can arise from the change of an aorist indicative to the optative in a dependent clause of the indirect discourse, this tense may follow the general principle. This occurs chiefly in causal sentences after o(/ti, e)pei/, etc., because (713), in which the subjunctive can never be used. E.g. *ei)=xe ga le/gein w(s *lakedaimo/nioi dia\ tou=to polemh/seian au)toi=s, o(/ti ou)k e)qelh/saien met' *)aghsila/ou e)lqei=n e)p' au)to
 ou)de\ qu=sai e)a/seian au)to
 e)n *au)lidi. XEN. Hell. vii. 1, 34. (The direct discourse was e)pole/mhsan h(mi=n, o(/ti ou)k h)qelh/samen e)lqei=n ou)de\ qu=sai ei)a/samen au)to/n.) *)aphgh/sasqai/ (fasi) w(s a)nosiw/taton me
 ei)/h ei)rgasme/nos o(/te tou= a)delfeou= a)pota/moi th
 kefalh
, sofw/taton de\ o(/ti tou\s fula/kous katamequ/sas katalu/seie tou= a)delfeou= krema/menon to
 ne/kun. HDT. ii. 121.Here o(/ti katalu/seie represents o(/ti kate/lusa, because I took down; o(/te a)pota/moi (so the Mss.) might also be understood in a causal sense, since he had cut off, although in the sense of when he cut off it could not be ambiguous here. Madvig, however, reads o(/ti in both clauses. See XEN. Mem. i. 4, 19 (quoted in 714). (See also 700, and the examples.)

div2.head: Single Dependent Clauses in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: 1. The principles which govern dependent clauses of indirect discourse (689) apply also to all dependent clauses in sentences of every kind (even when what precedes is not in indirect discourse), if such clauses express indirectly the past thought of any person, even that of the speaker himself. This affects the construction only when the leading verb is past; then the dependent clause may either take the optative, in the tense in which the thought was originally conceived, or retain both the mood and the tense of the direct discourse. When a subjunctive is changed to an optative, a)/n is dropped.

2. Secondary tenses of the indicative here (as in 689, 3) regularly remain unchanged. But an aorist indicative sometimes becomes optative when no ambiguity can result from the change (see 693): this may occur in causal sentences (699 and 714) and in the relative sentences of 700.
The principle of 694 applies to the following constructions:—

I. Clauses depending on the infinitive which follows verbs of wishing, commanding, advising, and others which imply thought but do not take the infinitive in indirect discourse (684). E.g. *)ebou/lonto e)lqei=n ei) tou=to ge/noito, they wished to go if this should happen. (Here the original expression of the thought would be boulo/meqa e)lqei=n e)a
 tou=to ge/nhtai, and therefore e)a
 ge/nhtai might be retained.) *gada/tan de\ kai\ *gwbru/an e)ke/leusen o(/ ti du/nainto labo/ntas metadiw/kein: kai\ o(/stis ei)=xe ta\s e(pome/nas a)ge/las, ei)=pe tou/tw| kai\ a(/ma pro/bata polla\ e)lau/nein o(/ph| a)
 au)to
 punqa/nhtai o)/nta, w(s e)pisfagei/h. XEN. Cyr. vii. 3, 7. (Here o(/ ti du/nainto represents o(/ ti a)
 du/nhsqe, while o(/ph| a)
 punqa/nhtai represents o(/ph| a)
 punqa/nh|.) *)ebou/lonto ga sfi/sin, ei)/ tina la/boien, u(pa/rxein a)nti\ tw=n e)/ndon, h)
 a)/ra tu/xwsi/ tines e)zwgrhme/noi, for they wished that, if they should capture any one, he might be a hostage for their friends within the city, in case any should chance to have been taken prisoners (h)
 la/bwmen, and h)
 tu/xwsi). THUC. ii. 5. *oi( d' a)/lloi *qhbai=oi, ou(\s e)/dei paragene/sqai ei)/ ti mh\ proxwroi/h toi=s e)selhluqo/sin, e)peboh/qoun, who were to come up if anything should go wrong with those who had entered the city (h)/n ti mh\ proxwrh=|). Ibid.

*proei=pon au)toi=s mh\ naumaxei=n *korinqi/ois, h)
 mh\ e)pi\ *ke/rkuran ple/wsi kai\ me/llwsin a)pobai/nein. Id. i. 45. *kai\ parh/ggeilan e)peidh\ deipnh/seian suneskeuasme/nous pa/ntas a)napau/esqai, kai\ e(/pesqai h(ni/k' a)/n tis paragge/llh|. XEN. An. iii. 5, 18. (*)epeida
 deipnh/shte, and h(ni/k' a)/n tis paragge/llh|.) *peri\ au)tw=n kru/fa pe/mpei, keleu/wn mh\ a)fei=nai pri
 a)
 au)toi\ pa/lin komisqw=sin, he sent bidding the Athenians not to let them go until they should themselves have returned. THUC. i. 91. (*pri
 komisqei=en might be used.) *kai\ polla/kis toi=s *)aqhnai/ois parh/|nei, h)
 a)/ra pote\ kata\ gh=n biasqw=si, kataba/ntas e)s au)to
 tai=s nausi\ pro\s a(/pantas a)nqi/stasqai. Id. i. 93. (*ei) biasqei=en might be used.) *)hci/oun au)tou\s h(gemo/nas sfw=n gene/sqai, kai\ *pausani/a| mh\ e)pitre/pein h)/n pou bia/zhtai. Id. i. 95. (*ei)/ pou bia/zoito might be used.) *)afiknou=ntai w(s *sita/lkhn, boulo/menoi pei=sai au)to
, ei) du/nainto, strateu=sai e)pi\ th
 *poti/daian. Id. ii. 67. *(/etoimos h)=n a)poti/nein, ei) katagnoi=en au)tou=. ISOC. xvii. 16. *ei)=pon mhde/na tw=n o)/pisqen kinei=sqai pri
 a)
 o( pro/sqen h(gh=tai, I commanded that no one at the rear should move until the one before him should lead. XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 8.

*parhgge/lleto ga au)toi=s de/ka me
 ou(\s *qhrame/nhs a)pe/deice xeirotonh=sai, de/ka de\ ou(\s oi( e)/foroi keleu/oien, they were bidden to choose ten whom Theramenes had nominated, and ten whom the Ephors commanded (i.e. ou(\s a)pe/deice and ou(\s keleu/ousin). LYS. xii. 76. *)eke/leuse/ me th
 e)pistolh
 h(
 e)/graya oi)/kade dou=nai, the letter which I had written. XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 9. (*(\hn gra/yaimi would mean whatever letter I might write, representing h(
 a)
 gra/yh|s.) *dienoou=nto au)tou\s pa/lin o(/qen h)=lqon e)s *qra/|khn a)pope/mpein, they planned to send them back to Thrace, whence they had come. THUC. vii. 27. (See 689, THUC. 3.)

II. Clauses containing a protasis, the apodosis of which is implied in the past leading verb or its adjuncts. E.g. *dido/ntos d' au)tw=| pa/mpolla dw=ra *tiqrau/stou, ei) a)pe/lqoi, a)pekri/nato, when T. offered (to give) him many gifts, if he would go away. Ag. iv. 6. (*)ea
 a)pe/lqh| might be used.) *fu/lakas sumpe/mpei, o(/pws fula/ttoien au)to
, kai\ ei) tw=n a)gri/wn ti fanei/h qhri/wn, and (to be ready) in case any wild beast should appear; his thought being e)a/n ti fanh=|. Cyr. i. 4, Cyr. 7. *pro\s th
 po/lin, ei) e)pibohqoi=en, e)xw/roun, they marched towards the city, in case they (the citizens) should rush out (i.e. so as to meet them, if they should rush out), the thought being h)
 e)pibohqw=sin (490, Cyr. 1). THUC. vi. 100. *ou)d' h)=n tou= pole/mou pe/ras ou)d' a)pallagh\ *fili/ppw|, ei) mh\ *qhbai/ous kai\ *qettalou\s e)xqrou\s poih/seie th=| po/lei, i.e. Philip saw that he could neither end nor escape the war unless he should make the Thebans and Thessalians hostile to the city (the original apodosis, I cannot end or escape the war, to which e)a
 mh\ poih/sw was the protasis, is implied in ou)d' h)=n . . . *fili/ppw|). DEM. xviii. 145.

*)\hn de/ tis ei)/ph| h)\ e)piyhfi/sh| kinei=n ta\ xrh/mata tau=ta e)s a)/llo ti, qa/naton zhmi/an e)pe/qento, they set death as the penalty (i.e. voted that death should be the penalty) if any one should move, or put to vote a motion, to divert this money to any other purpose. THUC. ii. 24. (*ei) ei)/poi h)\ e)piyhfi/seien might be used.) *ta)/lla, h)
 e)/ti naumaxei=n oi( *)aqhnai=oi tolmh/swsi, pareskeua/zonto, i.e. they made their other preparations, (to be ready) in case the Athenians should still dare to risk a sea fight (their thought being we will be ready in case they shall dare, h)
 tolmh/swsi). Id. vii. 59.So h)
 i)/wsin, Id. iv. 42. *ou) to\ loipo
 e)/mellon e(/cein ei) mh\ naukrath/sousin, they were not likely to have them (provisions) for the future (as they thought) unless they should hold the sea. Id. vii. 60. *)=hn ou)de
 ma=llon me/g' au)tw=| kaq' u(mw=n ou)d' ou(/tw pra=cai, ei) mh\ tou\s *fwke/as a)polei=, he was none the more able even then to do you any great harm (he thought) unless he should destroy the Phocians (ei) mh\ a)polw=). DEM. xix. 317.See Il. v. 301. *kai\ e)gw\ to
 *eu)hno
 e)maka/risa, ei) w(s a)lhqw=s e)/xei tau/thn th
 te/xnhn kai\ ou(/tws e)mmelw=s dida/skei, I congratulated him (told him he was happy), if he really had this art. PLAT. Ap. 20B. (Here e)/xoi and dida/skoi might be used.)

III. Clauses containing a protasis depending on a past verb of emotion, like qauma/zw, ai)sxu/nomai, etc. (494). E.g. *)eqau/maze d' ei)/ tis a)reth
 e)paggello/menos a)rgu/rion pra/ttoito, he wondered that any demanded money, etc. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 7. (But in i. 1, XEN. Mem. 13, we find e)qau/maze d' ei) mh\ fanero
 au)toi=s e)stin, he wondered that it was not plain.) *)/exairon a)gapw=n ei)/ tis e)a/soi, I rejoiced, being content if any one would let it pass. PLAT. Rep. 450A. *ou)k h)|sxu/nqh ei) toiou=to kako
 e)pa/gei tw|, he was not ashamed if (or that) he was bringing such a calamity on any one. DEM. xxi. 105. *tw=| de\ mhde
 e(autw=| suneido/ti deino
 ei)sh/|ei, ei) ponhrw=n e)/rgwn do/cei koinwnei=n tw=| siwph=sai, it seemed hard, if he was to appear to be implicated, etc.; he thought, deino/n e)stin ei) do/cw (407). Id. xix. 33. (Here do/coi might be used like e)a/soi above.) *oi( d' w)/|kteiron, ei) a(lw/sointo, and others pitied them if they were to be captured, the direct thought being we pity them if they are to be captured, ei) a(lw/sontai, which might be retained (see the next example). XEN. An. i. 4, 7. *ou)k e)/fasan e)pitre/yai, ou)k e)leou=ntes ta\ tei/xh ei) pesei=tai, ou)de\ khdo/menoi tw=n new=n ei) *lakedaimoni/ois paradoqh/sontai, i.e. they felt no pity for the walls if they were to fall, nor care for the ships if they were to be surrendered. LYS. xiii. 15.

IV. Temporal sentences expressing a past intention, purpose, or expectation, especially those introduced by e(/ws or pri/n, until, after past tenses. E.g. *)=wrse d' e)pi\ kraipno
 *bore/hn, pro\ de\ ku/mat' e)/acen, e(/ws o(/ ge *faih/kessi filhre/tmoisi migei/h, i.e. to the end that (until) Ulysses should get to the Phaeacians; originally e(/ws a)
 migh=| (614, 2). Od. v. 385.So ei(/ws qermai/noito, Od. ix. 376. *sponda\s e)poih/santo e(/ws a)paggelqei/h ta\ lexqe/nta ei)s *lakedai/mona, they made a truce (to continue) until what had been said should be announced at Sparta; i.e. e(/ws a)
 a)paggelqh=|, which might have been retained. XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 20. *)aphgo/reue mhde/na ba/llein pri
 *ku=ros e)mplhsqei/h qhrw=n, until Cyrus should be satisfied. Id. Cyr. i. 4, Id. Cyr. 14. (His words were pri
 a)
 e)mplhsqh=|.) *oi( de\ me/nontes e(/stasan o(ppo/te pu/rgos *)axaiw=n a)/llos e)pelqw
 *trw/wn o(rmh/seie kai\ a)/rceian pole/moio, i.e. they stood waiting for the time when, etc. Il. iv. 334.So Il. ii. 794. *prou)ki/nhsan to\ sti=fos, w(s pausome/nous tou= diwgmou= e)pei\ sfa=s i)/doien proormh/santas, when they should see them, etc. XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 21.

*ou) ga dh/ sfeas a)pi/ei o( qeo\s th=s a)poiki/hs pri
 dh\ a)pi/kwntai e)s au)th
 *libu/hn. HDT. iv. 157. (*)api/kointo might be used.) *oi( de\ *kori/nqioi ou) proequmh/qhsan cumplei=n pri
 ta\ *)/isqmia, a(\ to/te h)=n, dieorta/swsin, until they had (should have) finished celebrating the Isthmian games, which were then going on. THUC. viii. 9.

V. Past causal sentences in which the cause is stated as one assigned by another, so far as these allow the optative (714). E.g. *)eka/kizon o(/ti strathgo\s w)\n ou)k e)peca/goi, they abused him because (as they said) he did not lead them out. THUC. ii. 21.See other examples under 714.

Though the optative is allowed here, on the principle of indirect discourse, the indicative of the direct form (e.g. e)peca/gei in the above example) seems not to have been allowed (see 715). Causal sentences are usually constructed without reference to the principle of indirect discourse (see 713).

VI. Even some ordinary relative sentences expressing the previous thought of another, which allow the optative in place of the ordinary indicative. E.g. *kai\ h)/|tee sh=ma i)de/sqai, o(/tti r(a/ oi( gambroi=o pa/ra *proi/toio fe/roito, he asked to see the token, which (he said) he was bringing from Proetus, i.e. he said fe/romai. Il. vi. 176.So Od. v. 240. *ei)/reto pai=da to
 *eu)a/dna te/koi, he asked for the child which Euadne had borne. PIND. Ol. vi. 49. *kathgo/reon tw=n *ai)ginhte/wn ta\ pepoih/koien prodo/ntes th
 *(ella/da, i.e. they accused them for what (as they said) they had done. HDT. vi. 49.So ta\ peponqw\s ei)/h, HDT. i. 44.
*kalei= to
 *la/ion, mnh/mhn palaiw=n sperma/twn e)/xous', u(f' w(=n qa/noi me/n au)to\s, th
 de\ ti/ktousan li/poi, by which (as she said) he had perished himself, and had left her the mother, etc. SOPH. O.T. 1245. If the relative clause contained merely the idea of the speaker, e)/qane and e)/lipe would be used. Here no ambiguity can arise from the use of the aorist optative (see 693). *to\ tou= krei/ttonos cumfe/ron e)/legen o(\ h(goi=to o( krei/ttwn au(tw=| cumfe/rein, he meant the superior's advantage which the superior believed to be his own advantage. PLAT. Rep. 340B. This construction is rare in Attic Greek, but is not uncommon in Herodotus.

The imperfect and pluperfect occasionally represent the present and perfect indicative in this construction. Such clauses are simply not included in the indirect discourse. (See 674; 691.) E.g. *(etoi=mos h)=n, ei) me\n tou/twn ti ei)/rgasto, di/khn dou=nai, ei) d' a)poluqei/h, a)/rxein, he was ready, if he had done any of these things, to be punished; but if he should be acquitted, to hold his command. THUC. vi. 29. (*ei) ei)/rgasto represents ei) ei)/rgasmai, while ei) a)poluqei/h represents e)a\n a)poluqw=.)

*)/an is occasionally retained with relatives and temporal particles in sentences of this kind, even when the subjunctive to which they belonged has been changed to the optative. (See 692.) E.g. *tou\s de\ lamba/nontas th=s o(mili/as misqo
 a)ndrapodista\s e(autw=n a)peka/lei, dia\ to\ a)nagkai=on au)toi=s ei)=nai diale/gesqai par' w(=n a)
 la/boien to
 misqo/n, because they were obliged (as he said) to converse with those from whom they received the pay. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 6. (Here w(=n a)
 la/boien represents w(=n a)
 la/bwsin.) *kai/ moi ta/d' h)=n pro/rrhta, to\ fa/rmakon tou=to sw/|zein e)me\ e(/ws a)
 a)rti/xriston a(rmo/saimi/ pou. SOPH. Tr. 687 (see Schneidewin's note). *)hci/oun au)tou\s mastigou=n to
 e)kdoqe/nta e(/ws a)
 ta)lhqh= do/ceien au)toi=s le/gein. ISOC. xvii. 15. *xai/rein e)w/|hs a)
 kai\ ou)k a)pokri/naio e(/ws a)
 ta\ a)p' e)kei/nhs o(rmhqe/nta ske/yaio, you would not answer (you would say) until you should have examined, etc. (e(/ws a)
 ske/ywmai). PLAT. Phaed. 101D. Here we must place o(/tan e)ksw|zoi/ato, AESCH. Pers. 450, if the text is sound. *parh/ggeilen au)toi=s mh\ pro/teron e)piti/qesqai pri
 a)
 tw=n sfete/rwn h)\ pe/soi tis h)\ trwqei/h. XEN. Hell. ii. 4, 18 ; so pri
 a)
 mete/xoien, XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 48. See e(/ws a)
 oi( no/moi teqei=en. AND. i. 81.Many scholars repudiate this use of a)/n and emend the passages: see Dindorf on SOPH. Tr. 687.
It is doubtful whether e)a/n was ever thus used with the optative.

Upon this principle (694) final and object clauses with i(/na, w(s, o(/pws, o)/fra, and mh/, after past tenses, admit the double construction of indirect discourse, and allow the subjunctive or the future indicative instead of the optative, to retain the form in which the purpose would be originally conceived. (See 318 and 339.)

The principles of indirect discourse (689, 2) apply to future conditional and conditional relative clauses which depend upon final and object clauses or other expressions of purpose after past tenses. E.g. *)elqo/ntes e)s *lakedai/mona (e)/prasson) o(/pws e(toima/sainto timwri/an, h)\n de/h|. THUC. i. 58. (Here ei) de/oi might have been used.) *)efobei=to ga\r mh\ oi( *lakedaimo/nioi sfa=s, o(po/te safw=s a)kou/seian, ou)ke/ti a)fw=sin. Id. i. 91. (Here o(po/tan a)kou/swsin is changed to o(po/te a)kou/seian, although a)fw=sin is retained.)

div2.head: oi)=d' o(/ti, without a Verb.
div2.p: *oi)=d' o(/ti sometimes means I am sure, when the context readily suggests a verb for o(/ti. E.g. *pa/reimi d' a)/kwn ou)x e(kou=sin, oi)=d' o(/ti, and here I am, against my will, and against your will, I am sure. SOPH. Ant. 276. *ma\ to\n *di/) ou)/koun tw=| ge sw=|, sa/f' i)/sq' o(/ti, i.e. be assured. AR. Pl. 889. *pa/ntwn oi)=d' o(/ti fhsa/ntwn g' a)/n, when all, I am sure, would say. DEM. ix. 1. *bou/lomai mnhmoneu/ontas u(mw=n oi)=d' o(/ti tou\s pollou\s u(pomnh=sai, i.e. I wish to remind you, though I am sure most of you remember it. Id. xix. 9.
In such cases it would be useless or impossible to add the implied verb.

div2.head: o(/pws, o(/, ou(/neka, and o(qou/neka, in Indirect Quotations.
div2.p: *(/opws is sometimes (especially in poetry) used in indirect quotations in the sense of w(s. E.g. *tou=t' au)to\ mh/ moi fra/z), o(/pws ou)k ei)= kako/s, this very thing tell me not, that you are not base. SOPH. O.T. 548. *)/anac, e)rw= me\n ou)x o(/pws ta/xous u(/po du/spnous i(ka/nw, I will not say exactly that I come breathless with haste. Id. Ant. 223. *mh\ ga\r e)lpi/sh|s o(/pws e)m' e)kbalei=s, for do not hope that you will expel me. EUR. Her. 1051.So SOPH. El. 963. *)ana/peison o(/kws moi a)mei/nw e)sti\ tau=ta ou(/tw poieo/mena. HDT. i. 37. *ou) me\n ou)de\ fh/sw o(/kws *ai)gu/ptioi par' *(ellh/nwn e)/labon tou=to. Id. ii. 49.So iii. 115, Id. 116.See also o(/pws ou) pa/nta e)pi/stamai, PLAT. Euthyd. 296E. In most of these, the original modal force of o(/pws, how, can be seen.

In SOPH. Ant. 685, we have o(/pws su\ mh\ le/geis o)rqw=s ta/de, where mh/ is a standing puzzle. It probably must be classed with the very rare o(/ti mh/ with the indicative, and with the irregular mh/ with the infinitive after verbs of saying and thinking (for all these see 685 and 686, above).

(*ou)x o(/pws, ou)x o(/ti, etc.) *ou)x o(/pws or (rarely) mh\ o(/pws, and ou)x o(/ti or mh\ o(/ti, by the ellipsis of a verb of saying, often mean I do not speak of or not to speak of. *)alla/, a)lla\ kai/, a)ll' ou)de/, or a)lla\ mhde/ usually follows in a clause which expresses a strong antithesis. After ou)x the implied verb of saying would be an indicative, after mh/ it would be an imperative or subjunctive; but, like most elliptical idioms, this is often used where the ellipsis cannot be precisely supplied. What is men tioned in the former clause as not to be spoken of may be understood to be either affirmed or negatived by the expression, according to the context; so that the force of ou)x o(/pws may sometimes be conveniently given by not only, sometimes by so far from (not only not). E.g. *ou)x o(/pws ta\ skeu/h a)pe/dosqe, a)lla\ kai\ ai( qu/rai a)fhrpa/sqhsan, not to speak of your selling the furniture (i.e. not only did you sell the furniture, but), even the doors were carried off. LYS. xix. 31. (With le/gw supplied with ou)x o(/pws we have I do not speak of your selling the furniture; but this would be awkward, and probably no precise verb was thought of.) *ei) katw/rqwsen e)kei=nos, ou)x o(/ti tw=n o)/ntwn a)
 a)pesterh/mhn, a)ll' ou)d' a)
 e)/zhn, if he had succeeded, not to speak of being deprived of my property, (not only should I have been deprived of my property, but) I should not even be alive. DEM. xxiv. 7. *ou)k e)/stin a)/cia mh\ o(/ti duoi=n tala/ntoin proso/dou, a)ll' ou)d' ei)/kosi mnw=n, it is not sufficient to represent an income even of twenty minas, not to speak of two talents. Id. xxxvi. 39. *tw=nde ou)x o(/pws kwlutai\ genh/sesqe, a)lla\ kai\ a)po\ th=s u(mete/ras a)rxh=s du/namin proslabei=n perio/yesqe, not to speak of (so far from) your becoming a hindrance to them, you will even permit them to add to their power from your own dominions. THUC. i. 35. *mh\ o(/pws o)rxei=sqai e)n r(uqmw=|, a)ll' ou)d' o)rqou=sqai e)du/nasqe, not to speak of dancing in time, you could not even stand erect. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 10. *tou\s *qhbai/ous h(gei=to e)a/sein o(/pws bou/letai pra/ttein e(auto
, kai\ ou)x o(/pws a)ntipra/cein kai\ diakwlu/sein, a)lla\ kai\ sustrateu/sein, he thought the Thebans would let him do as he pleased, and—not to speak of opposing and hindering him—would even join forces with him. DEM. vi. 9. (Here no definite verb can be supplied.) *)edi/daskon to
 dh=mon w(s ou)x o(/pws timwrh/sainto, a)lla\ kai\ e)paine/saien to
 *sfodri/an, that, so far from having punished S. , they had even praised him (ou)x o(/pws with an optative after w(s in indirect discourse). XEN. Hell. v. 4, 34.

Occasionally one of these expressions stands in the second clause; as dia\ to\n xeimw=na ou)de\ plei=n, mh\ o(/ti a)nairei=sqai tou\s a)/ndras, dunato\n h)=n, on account of the storm it was not possible even to sail, much less to pick up the men (not to speak of picking up the men). XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 35. So pepau/meq' h(mei=s, ou)x o(/pws se pau/somen, we have been stopped ourselves; there is no talk of our stopping you, SOPH. El. 796.
Compare DEM. xix. 137: e)pu/qeto au)to\n ou)de\ tou= zh=n o)/nta ku/rion au(tw=| bebaiw=sai, mh/ti g' a(\ e)kei/nw| u(pe/sxeto pra=cai, i.e. not at all (much less) to do what he had promised him.
1. In Homer o(/, the neuter of o(/s, is used like o(/ti, that. E.g.

*gignw/skwn o(/ oi( au)to\s u(pei/rexe xei=ras *)apo/llwn, knowing that Apollo himself held over him his hands. Il. v. 433. *eu)= nu kai\ h(mei=s i)/dmen o(/ toi sqe/nos ou)k e)pieikto/n. Il. viii. 32. *leu/ssete ga\r to/ ge pa/ntes, o(/ moi ge/ras e)/rxetai a)/llh|, that my prize goes elsewhere. Il. i. 120.So Od. xii. 295. (See 663, Od. 1, and 671.)

2. In the following cases o(/ t) for o(/ te (neuter of o(/s te) is used in Homer like o(/ and o(/ti:—*gignw/skwn o(/ t' a)/nalkis e)/hn qeo/s, knowing that the Goddess was weak. Il. v. 331: so xvii. 623, Od. viii. 299. *(ws ei)/donq' o(/ t' a)/r e)k *dio\s h)/luqen o)/rnis. Il. viii. 251. *nu=n d' h)/dh to/de dh=lon, o(/ t' ou)ke/ti no/stimo/s e)stin. Od. xx. 333.

Since o(/ti does not allow elision, it is now customary to write this form o(/ t) (as above). But Schmitt (after Capelle) writes o(/t) in all these cases, assuming the form to be an elided o(/te (709, 3).
3. In a few cases o(/te, when, is used in Homer in a sense which approaches very near that of o(/ti, that. E.g.

*ou)d' e)/laq' *ai)/anta *zeu\s, o(/te dh\ *trw/essi di/dw ni/khn, i.e. nor was Ajax unaware that Zeus was giving victory to the Trojans (lit. when Zeus was giving). Il. xvii. 626.Compare Il. xxiv. 563, ou)de/ me lh/qeis, o(/tti qew=n ti/s s' h)=ge. See Schmitt, pp. 40-50.
This occasional use of o(/te seems hardly to justify the assumption that o(/ t) in all the cases in 709, 2 stands for o(/te.
1. *ou(/neka in Homer, and o(qou/neka and ou(/neka in the tragedians, are sometimes used like o(/ti or w(s, that. E.g.

*peu/qeto ga\r *ku/pronde me/ga kle/os, ou(/nek' *)axaioi\ e)s *troi/hn nh/essin a)napleu/sesqai e)/mellon, for in Cyprus he heard a mighty rumour, that the Achaeans were about to sail for Troy in ships. Il. xi. 21.So Od. v. 216, Od. xiii. 309. *)/aggelle o(qou/neka te/qnhk' *)ore/sths, report that Orestes is dead. SOPH. El. 47; see SOPH. El. 1478. *)/isqi tou=to, ou(/neka *(/ellhne/s e)smen, know this, that we are Greeks. Id. Ph. 232. *)ekdidaxqei\s ou(/neka a)/kousa e)/rceien ta/de. Id. Tr. 934.

2. *dio/ti is sometimes used in the sense of o(/ti, that, by Aristotle, and occasionally by Herodotus and even by Isocrates. E.g. *dio/ti me\n toi/nun ou)x h( au)th\ (sc. e)sti/), fanero\n e)k tou/twn, i.e. that it is not the same, is plain from this. ARISTOT. Pol. iii. 4, 7.So Metaph. x. 5, 3. *dio/ti e)k tw=n barba/rwn h(/kei, punqano/menos ou(/tw eu(ri/skw e)o/n. HDT. ii. 50: see ii. 43 (with Stein's note). See ISOC. iv. 48: suneidui=a o(/ti tou=to . . . e)/fumen e)/xontes, kai\ dio/ti . . . au)tw=n dihne/gkamen.

div2.head: o(/ti, before Direct Quotations.
div2.p: Even direct quotations are sometimes introduced by o(/ti, rarely by w(s, without further change in the construction. *(/oti or w(s here cannot be expressed in English. E.g. *(o de\ a)pekri/nato o(/ti *ou)d' ei) genoi/mhn, w)= *ku=re, soi/ g' a)/n pote e)/ti do/caimi. XEN. An. i. 6, 8. *)apekri/nato o(/ti *)=w de/spota, ou) zh=|. Id. Cyr. vii. 3, Id. Cyr. 3. *ei)=pe d' o(/ti *ei)s kairo\n h(/keis, e)/fh, o(/pws th=s di/khs a)kou/sh|s. Ib. iii. 1, Ib. 8. *)\h e)rou=men pro\s au)tou\s, o(/ti *)hdi/kei ga\r h(ma=s h( po/lis, kai\ ou)k o)rqw=s th\n di/khn e)/krine,—tau=ta h)\ ti/ e)rou=men; PLAT. Crit. 50B ; so Phaed. 60A. *)\an le/gh| tis ta)lhqh=, o(/ti *lhrei=te, w)= a)/ndres *)aqhnai=oi. DEM. viii. 31: so xviii. 40, 174; xix. 22, 40, 253. See also HDT. ii. 115 (the earliest example); THUC. i. 137, THUC. iv. 38; AND. i. 49; LYS. i. 26; AESCHIN. iii. 22, AESCHIN. 120; DIN. i. 12 102 (both with w(s).See Spieker in Jour. Phil. v. pp. 221-227, who has traced the history of this construction and collected examples, especially those in the Orators.

div2.head: Section IX: Causal Sentences.
div2.p: Causal sentences express the cause of something stated in the leading sentence. They may be introduced by o(/ti, dio/ti or dio/per, w(s, ou(/neka or o(qou/neka, because; by e)pei/, e)peidh/, o(/te, o(po/te, eu)=te, and sometimes o(/pou, since, seeing that; and in Homer by o(/ or o(/ te (o(/ t)), because.

(Indicative.) Causal sentences regularly take the indicative, after both primary and secondary tenses; past causes being expressed by the past tenses of the indicative. The negative particle is ou). E.g. *kh/deto ga *danaw=n, o(/ti r(a qnh/|skontas o(ra=to, for she pitied the Danans, because she saw them dying. Il. i. 56. *xwo/menos, o(/ t' a)/riston *)axaiw=n ou)de
 e)/tisas, angry, because you did in no way honour the best of the Achaeans. Il. i. 244. *dhmobo/ros basileu\s, e)pei\ ou)tidanoi=sin a)na/sseis. Il. i. 231. *mh\ d' ou(/tws kle/pte no/w|, e)pei\ ou) pareleu/seai ou)de/ me pei/seis. Il. i. 132. *nou=son a)na\ strato
 w)=rse kakh
, o)le/konto de\ laoi\, ou(/neka to
 *xru/shn h)ti/masen a)rhth=ra *)atre+/dhs. Il. i. 11. *thle/maxon qau/mazon, o(\ qarsale/ws a)go/reuen, because he spoke boldly. Od. i. 382. *kai\ trih/rhs de/ toi h( sesagme/nh a)nqrw/pwn dia\ ti/ a)/llo fobero/n e)sti h)\ o(/ti taxu\ plei=; dia\ ti/ de\ a)/llo a)/lupoi a)llh/lois ei)si
 oi( e)mple/ontes h)\ dio/ti e)n ta/cei ka/qhntai; XEN. Oec. viii. 8. *oi( e)moi\ fi/loi ou(/tws e)/xontes peri\ e)mou= diatelou=sin, ou) dia\ to\ filei=n e)me\, a)lla\ dio/per kai\ au)toi\ a)
 oi)/ontai be/ltistoi gi/gnesqai. Id. Mem. iv. 8, Id. Mem. 7. *oi( *)aqhnai=oi e)no/mizon h(ssa=sqai o(/ti ou) polu\ e)ni/kwn, the Athenians thought they were defeated because they were not signally victorious. THUC. vii. 34. *ma=llo/n ti e)deinologei=to o(/ti min a)pe/kteine to
 au)to\s fo/nou e)ka/qhre. HDT. i. 44. *pro\s tau=ta kru/pte mhde
, w(s o( pa/nq' o(rw=n kai\ pa/nt' a)kou/wn pa/nt' a)naptu/ssei xro/nos, i.e. since time develops all things. SOPH. Fr. 280. *me/ga de\ to\ o(mou= trafh=nai, e)pei\ kai\ toi=s qhri/ois po/qos tis e)ggi/gnetai tw=n suntro/fwn. XEN. Mem. ii. 3, 4. *(/ot' ou)=n parainou=s' ou)de
 e)s ple/on poiw=, XEN. Mem. i (ke/tis a)fi=gmai. SOPH. O.T. 918. *(opo/te ou)=n po/lis me
 ta\s i)di/as cumfora\s oi(/a te fe/rein, ei(=s de\ e(/kastos ta\s e)kei/nhs a)du/natos (sc. e)sti\), pw=s ou) xrh\ pa/ntas a)mu/nein au)th=|; THUC. ii. 60. *(/ote toi/nun tou=q' ou(/tws e)/xei, prosh/kei proqu/mws e)qe/lein a)kou/ein tw=n boulome/nwn sumbou- leu/ein. DEM. i. 1. For eu)=te, since, see SOPH. Aj. 715, O. C. 84; for o(/pou (o(/kou) see HDT. i. 68.

(Optative.) When, however, the speaker implies that a cause was assigned by some other person, the principle of indirect discourse (694), after past tenses, allows the verb to stand in the optative, in the tense originally used by the person who assigned the cause (699). E.g. *to
 *perikle/a e)ka/kizon, o(/ti strathgo\s w)
 ou)k e)peca/goi, they abused Pericles, because being general he did not lead them out. THUC. ii. 21. (This states the reason of the Athenians for reproaching Pericles (o(/ti h(ma=s ou)k e)peca/gei); if Thucydides had wished to assign the cause merely on his own authority, he would have used o(/ti ou)k e)pech=gen. Cf. THUC. vii. 34 in 713.) *tou\s suno/ntas e)do/kei poiei=n a)pe/xesqai tw=n a)nosi/wn, e)pei/per h( gh/sainto mhde
 a)/n pote w(=n pra/ttoien qeou\s dialaqei=n (see 693). XEN. Mem. i. 4, 19. *oi)=sqa e)paine/santa au)to
 (*(/omhron) to
 *)agame/mnona, w(s basileu\s ei)/h a)gaqo/s, because (as he said) he was a good king. Symp. iv. 6. *)eka/lee . . . to
 me
 e)pi/stion (*di/a), dio/ti fone/a tou= paido\s e)la/nqane (694, 2) bo/skwn, to
 de\ e(tairh/ion, w(s fu/laka sumpe/myas au)to
 eu(rh/koi polemiw/taton. HDT. i. 44. (Croesus would have said dio/ti e)la/nqanon and w(s eu(/rhka.)

We should suppose that in causal sentences of the latter class (714) the mood and tense by which the cause would be originally stated might also be retained, as in ordinary indirect discourse; so that in THUC. ii. 21, above, for example, we might have o(/ti ou)k e)p eca/gei in the same sense as o(/ti ou)k e)peca/goi. This, however, seems to have been avoided, to prevent the ambiguity which might arise from the three forms, e)pech=gen, e)peca/goi, and e)peca/gei. It will be remembered that the form e)pech=gen, which is the most common in the expression of a past cause, is also the original form for expressing the corresponding time in indirect discourse, although it became exceptional here in the later usage (671; 674).
For causal relative sentences see 580. For the causal participle see 838.
The optative in causal sentences is not found in Homer.
A cause may be expressed by a potential indicative or optative with a)/n.

*de/omai ou)=n sou paramei=nai h(mi=n: w(s e)gw\ ou)d' a)
 e(no\s h(/dion a)kou/saimi h)\ sou=, I beg you then to remain with us; as there is not one whom I should hear more gladly than you. PLAT. Prot. 335D. *nu=n de\, e)peidh\ ou)k e)qe/leis kai\ e)moi/ tis a)sxoli/a e)sti\ kai\ ou)k a)
 oi(=o/s t' ei)/hn soi paramei=nai a)potei/nonti makrou\s lo/gous, e)lqei=n ga/r poi/ me dei=, ei)=mi: e)pei\ kai\ tau=t' a)
 i)/sws ou)k a)hdw=s sou h)/kouon (for e)pei/ see 719, 2). Ib. 335C. *(/oti tw=n a)dikhma/twn a)
 e)me/mnhto tw=n au(tou=, ei)/ ti peri\ e)mou= g' e)/grafen. DEM. xviii. 79; so xviii. 49.

A causal sentence may be interrogative, or its verb may express a wish or a command. E.g. *)epei\, fe/r' ei)pe\, pou= su\ ma/ntis ei)= safh/s; for—come tell me—where do you ever show yourself a prophet? SOPH. O.T. 390. *)epei\ di/dacon, h)\ ma/q' e)c e)mou=, ti/ moi ke/rdos ge/noit' a)/n. Id. El. 352: so O. C. 969. See PLAT. Gorg. 474 B: e)pei\ su\ de/cai) a)/n; *)epei\ a)/qeos a)/filos o(/ti pu/maton o)loi/man, for—may I perish! SOPH. O.T. 662.

1. A causal sentence may give the cause of something that is implied, but not expressed, in the leading sentence. Especially it may give the reason for making a statement, rather than for the fact stated. In dialogues, a causal sentence may refer to an implied yes or no. E.g.

*ou)/ nu kai\ u(mi=n oi)/koi e)/nesti go/os, o(/ti m' h)/lqete khdh/sontes; have you now no mourning at home, that you have come to distress me? (i.e. I ask this, because you have come). Il. xxiv. 239. (If the two clauses were reversed—have you come because you have no mourning at home?—the causal relation would be plainer.) *ou)/ m' e)/t' e)fa/skeq' u(po/tropon oi)/kad' i(ke/sqai, o(/ti moi katekei/rete oi)=kon, i.e. you thought I should never return (as is plain), because you wasted my house. Od. xxii. 35.See e)pei/ in Od. i. 231.
*(ws e)/stin a)ndro\s tou=de ta)/rga tau=ta/ soi, yes (answering the preceding question), for here you have the deeds of this man. SOPH. Aj. 39 : so Ph. 812.
2. By a natural ellipsis, e)pei/ sometimes has virtually the force of although or and yet. E.g.

*ai)sxunoi/mhn a)\n e)/gwge tou=to o(mologei=n, e)pei\ polloi/ ge/ fasi tw=n a)nqrw/pwn, I should be ashamed for my part to admit this, and yet many men do say so (in full, I speak for myself alone, since many say this). PLAT. Prot. 333 C. See ibid. 335 C (quoted in 717), where e)pei\ a)\n . . . h)/kouon refers to the implied idea I am sorry after all to go. In Hom. Od. i. 236, e)pei\ ou)/ ke . . . a)kaxoi/mhn, and yet I should not be thus afflicted by his death, refers to what a)/iston suggests, I am especially grieved by his death in obscurity (cf. vss. 241, Hom. Od. 242).

div2.head: Section X: Expression of a Wish.
div2.p: Wishes may be divided into two classes: (a) those referring to a future object, and (b) those referring to a present or past object which (it is implied) is not or was not attained. To the former class belong such wishes as O that he may come! or O that this may happen!—Utinam veniat, Utinam fiat; and to the latter, such as O that this had happened! or O that this were true!—Utinam hoc factum esset, Utinam hoc verum esset.
From its use in wishes the optative mood (e)/gklisis eu)ktikh/) received its name.

div2.head: Wishes Referring to the Future.
div2.p: A wish referring to the future may be expressed in Greek in two ways:—
I. by the optative alone; as in ge/noito tou=to, may this happen, mh\ ge/noito tou=to, may this not happen;

II. by the optative with ei)/qe or ei) ga/r (Homeric also ai)/qe or ai)\ ga/r), sometimes by the simple ei), negatively ei)/qe mh/, ei) ga\r mh/, etc.; as in ei)/qe ge/noito tou=to, O that this may happen, ei) ga\r mh\ ge/noito, O that it may not happen.

I. The pure optative in a wish (with no introductory particle) is an independent verb. E.g. *(umi=n me\n qeoi\ doi=en *)olu/mpia dw/mat' e)/xontes e)kpe/rsai *pria/moio po/lin eu)= d' oi)/kad' i(ke/sqai, may the Gods grant you to destroy Priam's city, etc. Il. i. 18. *mh\ ma\n a)spoudi/ ge kai\ a)kleiw=s a)poloi/mhn, may I not perish, etc. Il. xxii. 304. *mhke/t' e)/peit' *)odush=i ka/rh w)/moisin e)pei/h, mhd' e)/ti *thlema/xoio path\r keklhme/nos ei)/hn, then may the head of Ulysses no longer stand on his shoulders, and no longer may I be called the father of Telemachus. Il. ii. 259. *teqnai/hn o(/te moi mhke/ti tau=ta me/loi, may I die when these are no longer my care. MIMN. i. 2. *to\ me\n nu=n tau=ta prh/ssois ta/per e)n xersi\ e)/xeis, may you for the present continue to do what you now have in hand. HDT. vii. 5.
*)=w pai=, ge/noio patro\s eu)tuxe/steros SOPH. Aj. 550.
*ou(/tw nikh/saimi/ t' e)gw\ kai\ nomizoi/mhn sofo/s, on this condition may I gain the prize (in this contest) and be (always) considered wise. AR. Nub. 520.
*qh/sw prutanei=', h)\ mhke/ti zw/|hn e)gw/, or may I no longer live. Ib. 1255.
*cunene/gkoi me\n tau=ta w(s boulo/meqa, may this prosper as we desire. THUC. vi. 20. *)alla\ boulhqei/hs, but may you only be willing! PLAT. Euthyd. 296 D.
*plou/sion de\ nomi/zoimi to\n sofo/n. Id. Phaedr. 279 C.
*nikw/|h d' o(/ ti pa=sin u(mi=n me/llei sunoi/sein, and may that opinion prevail which is to benefit you all. DEM. iv. 51. *(/o ti d' u(mi=n do/ceie, tou=t), w)= pa/ntes qeoi\, sunene/gkoi (see 561). Id. ix. 76.So ei)=en, well, be it so.
For the relation of the optative in wishes to the optative in its most primitive meaning, see Appendix I.

II. The optative in a wish with ei)/qe (ai)/qe), ei) ga/r (ai)\ ga/r), or ei) is probably in its origin a protasis with the apodosis suppressed. E.g. *ai)/q' ou(/tws e)pi\ pa=si xo/lon tele/sei) *)agame/mnwn, O if Agamemnon would thus fulfil his wrath upon all. Il. iv. 178. *ai)/q' ou(/tws, *eu)/maie, fi/lon *dii\ patri\ ge/noio w(s e)moi/, mayest thou become in like manner a friend to father Zeus. Od. xiv. 440. *ai)\ ga dh\ ou(/tws ei)/h, fi/los w)= *mene/lae, O that this may be so. Il. iv. 189. *ai)\ ga e)moi\ tossh/nde qeoi\ du/namin periqei=en, O if the Gods would clothe me with so much strength! Od. iii. 205. *)all' ei)/ min a)eikissai/meq' e(lo/ntes, teu/xea t' w)/moiin a)feloi/meqa, kai/ tin e(tai/rwn au)tou= a)munome/nwn damasai/meqa nhle/i xalkw=|, but if we could only take him and insult him, and strip him of his armour, and subdue, etc. Il. xvi. 559. On this passage we have the note of Aristarchus in the Scholia : h( diplh=, o(/ti e)/cwqen prosupakouste/on to\ kalw=s a)
 e)/xoi: ei) au)to
 a)nelo/ntes a)eikissai/meqa, kalw=s a)
 e)/xoi. Schol. A. It does not follow necessarily from this that Aristarchus explained all optatives with forms of ei) in wishes by supplying kalw=s a)
