 e)/xoi as an apodosis (see Lange, p. 6, note 15); but if he explained this passage as an elliptical protasis, he can hardly have objected to the same explanation of other similar passages. It is surely no more necessary or logical to insist on explaining both forms of wishes alike, than it would be in English to insist that may I see him again and O if I might see him again are originally of the same construction. *ei)/qe mh/pote gnoi/hs o(\s ei)=, may you never learn who you are. SOPH. O.T. 1068.
*ei)/q' u(=min a)mfoi=n nou=s ge/noito swfronei=n Id. Aj. 1264.
*ei)/qe pai=s e)mo\s eu)/qhros ei)/h Bacch. 1252.
*ei) ga genoi/mhn, te/knon, a)nti\ sou= nekro/s. Id. Hipp. 1410. *ei)/q), w)= lw=|ste, su\ toiou=tos w)
 fi/los h(mi=n ge/noio. XEN. Hell. iv. 1, 38. *ei) ga ge/noito. Id. Cyr. vi. 1, Id. Cyr. 38. *ei) ga e)n tou/tw| ei)/h, if it may only depend on this! PLAT. Prot. 310D.
*ei)/qe gra/yeien w(s xrh/, k.t.l. Id. Phaedr. 227C.

The simple ei) (without -qe or ga/r) with the optative in wishes is poetic. *)all' ei)/ tis kai\ tou/sde metoixo/menos kale/seien. Il. x. 111.See three other Homeric examples cited in the footnote.The Homeric examples of the optative with various forms of ei) or ai) are of the highest importance for the understanding of the construction generally. The following is a list of the passages (according to Lange, Partikel EI, pp. 19-40):— Simple ei) with optative: Il. x. 111, Il. xv. 571, Il. xvi. 559, Il. xxiv. 74. (4.) *ai)\ ga/r or ei) ga/r with optative: Il. iv. 189, Il. x. 536, Il. xvi. 97, Il. xviii. 272, Il. 464, Il. xxii. 346, Il. 454; Od. iii. 205, Od. iv. 697, Od. vi. 244, Od. viii. 339, Od. ix. 523, Od. xv. 156, Od. xvii. 251, Od. 513, Od. xviii. 235, Od. 366, Od. xix. 22, Od. xx. 169, Od. xxi. 402. (20.) *ai)/qe or ei)/qe with optative: Il. iv. 178; Od. ii. 33, Od. xiv. 440, Od. xv. 341, Od. xvii. 494, Od. xviii. 202, Od. xx. 61. (7.) Eight examples (five with ei)/qe, two with ei) ga/r, one with ai)\ ga/r), in which the present optative expresses an unattained present wish, are omitted here and will be found under 739. The cases discussed in 730 are not included here. For the use of ai)/qe, ai)\ ga/r, and ai) (for ei)/qe, etc.) in Homer, see footnote to 379. *ei)/ moi cunei/h moi=ra. SOPH. O. T. 863. *ei)/ moi ge/noito fqo/ggos e)n braxi/osin. EUR. Hec. 836.
The future optative was not used in wishes. The perfect was probably not used, except in the signification of the present (see 48); as in Il. ii. 259, quoted in 722.

In Homer, as the examples show, both present and aorist optative are freely used in future wishes, as in the corresponding future conditions (455). But the present optative in Homer also expresses a present wish implying that it is not attained, as it may express a present unreal condition (438). For this use, see 739.

In the poets, especially Homer, the simple optative may express a command or exhortation, in a sense approaching that of the imperative. E.g. *tau=t' ei)/pois *)axilh=i, (you may) say this to Achilles. Il. xi. 791. *teqnai/hs, w)= *proi=t), h)\ ka/ktane *bellerofo/nthn, (you may) either die, or kill Bellerophontes. Il. vi. 164. *)alla/ tis *doli/on kale/seie, let some one call Dolios. Od. iv. 735.So in prohibitions with mh/: mhd' e)/ti soi=si po/dessin u(postre/yeias *)/olumpon, Il. iii. 407 (between two pairs of imperatives). See also AESCH. Prom. 1049 and 1051.
For Homeric optatives (without a)/n), which form a connecting link between the potential and the wishing optative (like Il. iv. 18, Il. 19), see 13 and 233.

The poets, especially Homer, sometimes use w(s before the optative in wishes. This w(s cannot be expressed in English, and it is probably exclamatory. It must not be confounded with ou(/tws used as in 727. E.g. *(ws a)po/loito kai\ a)/llos o(/tis toiau=ta/ ge r(e/zoi, O that any other may likewise perish, etc. Od. i. 47.See Od. xxi. 201. *(ws o( ta/de porw\n o)/loit), ei)/ moi qe/mis ta/d' au)da=n. SOPH. El. 126. Compare ut pereat telum, HOR. Sat. ii. 1. 43 .

*ou(/tws, thus, on this condition, may be prefixed to the optative in protestations, where a wish is expressed upon some condition; the condition being usually added in another clause. E.g. *ou(/tws o)/naisqe tou/twn, mh\ perii/dhte/ me, may you enjoy these on this condition,—do not neglect me. DEM. xxviii. 20.

When the potential optative is used to express a wish, as in pw=s a)\n o)loi/mhn, how gladly should I perish, EUR. Supp. 796, it does not belong here, as o)loi/mhn a)/n and o)loi/mhn are, in use, wholly different constructions. If ei) ga/r ken mi/mnois, Hom. Od. xv. 545, is a wish, ei)/ ken may be used as it often is in protasis in Homer (460) in the same sense as ei), or the optative may be potential in the sense O if you could remain. In Hom. Il. vi. 281, w(/s ke/ oi( au)=qi gai=a xa/noi, if ke/ is correct, must mean O that the earth could gape for him at once (potential). But the exceptional character of these expressions makes both suspicious. Hermann and Bekker read ei) ga\r kai/ in Hom. Od. xv. 545; and Bekker reads w(s de/ in Hom. Il. vi. 281.
The infinitive occurs twice in Homer in wishes with ai)\ ga/r: see 786, and 739 (end). For the infinitive used like the simple optative in wishes, especially in poetry, see 785.

There are many passages in Homer in which it is open to doubt whether the poet intended to express a wish with some form of ei), followed by a potential optative in a new sentence, or to form a complete conditional sentence. Such are—

*ei) ga\r e)p' a)rh=|sin te/los h(mete/rh|si ge/noito: ou)k a)/n tis tou/twn ge e)u/qronon *)hw= i(/koito. Od. xvii. 496. *ai)\ ga\r tou=to, cei=ne, e)/pos tetelesme/non ei)/h: tw=| ke ta/xa gnoi/hs filo/thta/ te polla/ te dw=ra e)c e)meu=. Od. xv. 536.

If we keep the colon after ge/noito in the former passage, we may translate, O that fulfilment may be granted our prayers: not one of these would (then) see the fair-throned Dawn. With a comma after ge/noito, we may translate, if fulfilment should be granted our prayers, not one of these would see the fair-throned Dawn. So in the second passage we may translate, according to the punctuation, O that this word may be accomplished: then would you quickly be made aware of kindness and many gifts from me;—or if this word should be accomplished, you would then quickly be made aware, etc. These are probably rightly punctuated above, especially the second; and the wish is on the verge of independent existence, being almost ready to dispense with the apodosis. The half-independent half-dependent nature of such clauses is best seen in a case like the following, where ei) e)qe/loi is first stated as an independent wish, and is afterwards repeated as the protasis of a regular apodosis:—

*ei) ga/r s' w(\s e)qe/loi file/ein glaukw=pis *)aqh/nh w(s to/t' *)odu/ssh=os perikh/deto kudali/moio dh/mw| e)/ni *trw/wn, o(/qi pa/sxomen a)/lge) *)axaioi/: . . . ei)/ s' ou(/tws e)qe/loi file/ein kh/doito/ te qumw=|, tw=| ke/n tis kei/nwn ge kai\ e)klela/qoito ga/moio. Od. iii. 217.

The meaning is, if only Athena would love you as she then loved Ulysses; . . . if (I say) she would thus love you, then would many a one (of the suitors) cease to think of marriage. Here, instead of leaving a simple apodosis like the kalw=s a)\n e)/xoi of Aristarchus to be mentally supplied, or to be felt without being actually supplied, the protasis is repeated (as if by afterthought) and a more precise form of conclusion is then actually expressed.

Such examples as the first two are sometimes adduced as evidence that ei) with the optative in protasis was originally a form of wish, to which an apodosis was afterwards appended. For a discussion of this view, see Appendix I.

div2.head: Wishes (Not Attained) in Present or Past Time.
div2.p: A wish referring to a present or past object, which (it is implied) is not or was not attained, may be expressed in Greek in two ways:—
I. by the past tenses of the indicative, used as in unreal conditions, with ei)/qe or ei) ga/r; or
II. by w)/felon, aorist of o)fei/lw, owe, with the infinitive.

I. The past tenses of the indicative with ei)/qe or ei) ga/r, in present and past wishes, correspond to the optative with these particles in future wishes. The construction was originally a protasis with its apodosis suppressed, ei) ga/r me ei)=des meaning, O if you had seen me! This form of wish is common in the Attic writers, but is unknown to Homer (735).

The imperfect and aorist indicative are distinguished here as in the unreal condition (410). E.g. *)iw\ ga= ga=, ei)/q' e)/m' e)de/cw, O Earth, Earth, would that thou hadst received me. AESCH. Ag. 1537.
*ei) ga/r m' u(po\ gh=n h(=ken, O if he had sent me beneath the earth. Id. Prom. 152.
*ei)/qe se ei)/qe se mh/pot' ei)do/man. SOPH. O.T. 1217. *ei)/q' eu(/rome/n s), *)/admhte, mh\ lupou/menon. EUR. Alc. 536. *ei)/qe soi, w)= *peri/kleis, to/te sunegeno/mhn, would that I had met you then. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 46. *ei)/q' ei)=xes, w)= tekou=sa, belti/ous fre/nas, O mother, would that you had a better understanding. EUR. El. 1061. *ei) ga\r tosau/thn du/namin ei)=xon, would that I had so great power. Id. Alc. 1072. *ei)/q' h)=sqa dunato\s dra=n o(/son pro/qumos ei)=. Id. Her. 731.

The indicative cannot be used in wishes without ei)/qe or ei) ga/r, as it would occasion ambiguity; this cannot arise in the case of the optative, which is not regularly used in independent sentences without a)/n, except in wishes. SOPH. OC 1713 , i)w\, mh\ ga=s e)pi\ ce/nas qanei=n e)/xrh|zes (so the MSS.) is often quoted to show that at least the indicative with mh/ alone can be used in negative wishes, with the translation, O that thou hadst not chosen to die in a foreign land. But the passage is probably corrupt, as the following words a)ll' e)/rhmos e)/qanes show. See, however, Hermann's note on this passage, and on Aul. 575.

II. The aorist w)/felon, ought, and sometimes (in Homer) the imperfect w)/fellon, of o)fei/lw (Epic o)fe/llw), owe, debeo, may be used with the infinitive to express a present or past unattained wish. The present infinitive is used when the wish refers to the present or to continued or repeated past action, and the aorist (rarely the perfect) when it refers to the past.

*)/wfelon or w)/fellon may be preceded by the particles of wishing, ei)/qe and ei) ga/r, and in negative wishes by mh/ (not ou)). E.g. *)/wfele tou=to poiei=n, would that he were (now) doing this (lit. he ought to be doing it), or would that he had (habitually) done this (lit. he ought to have done this). *)/wfele tou=to poih=sai, would that he had done this.

*(=wn o)/felon trita/thn per e)/xwn e)n dw/masi moi=ran nai/ein, oi( d' a)/ndres so/oi e)/mmenai oi(\ to/t' o)/lonto, O that I were living with even a third part, etc., and that those men were safe who then perished. Od. iv. 97.So Il. i. 415. *)andro\s e)/peit' w)/fellon a)mei/nonos ei)=nai a)/koitis, o(\s h)/|dh ne/mesi/n te kai\ ai)/sxea po/ll' a)nqrw/pwn, O that I were the wife of a better man, who knew, etc. Il. vi. 350. *th\n o)/fel' e)n nh/essi katakta/men *)/artemis i)/w|, O that Artemis had slain her, etc. Il. xix. 59. *ai)/q' w)/felles stratou= a)/llou shmai/nein. Il. xiv. 84. *ai)/q' a(/ma pa/ntes *(/ektoros w)fe/let' a)nti\ qoh=|s e)pi\ nhusi\ pefa/sqai, would that ye all had been slain instead of Hector. Il. xxiv. 253. *mhd' o)/feles li/ssesqai a)mu/mona *phlei+/wna, would that you had not besought the son of Peleus. Il. ix. 698. (See 736, below.) So xviii. 86; Od. viii. 312. *mhke/t' e)/peit' w)/feilon (?) e)gw\ pe/mptoisi metei=nai a)ndra/sin, a)ll' h)\ pro/sqe qanei=n h)\ e)/peita gene/sqai, would that I were no longer living with this fifth race of men, but had either died before it or been born after it. HES. Op. 174. *)ole/sqai w)/felon th=|d' h(me/ra|, O that I had perished on that day. SOPH. O.T. 1157. *mh/ pot' w)/felon lipei=n th\n *sku=ron, O that I never had left Scyros. Id. Ph. 969.See Id. El. 1021. *ei)/q' w)/fel' *)argou=s mh\ diapta/sqai ska/fos *ko/lxwn e)s ai)=an kuane/as *sumplhga/das. EUR. Med. 1. *ei) ga\r w)/felon oi(=oi/ te ei)=nai oi( polloi\ ta\ me/gista kaka\ e)cerga/zesqai, O that the multitude were able, etc. PLAT. Crit. 44D. *ei) ga\r w)/felon (sc. katidei=n). Rep. 432C. *paqo/ntwn a(\ mh/ pot' w)/felon (sc. paqei=n), when they suffered what would they had never suffered. DEM. xviii. 288; so 320. So w(s mh/pote w)/felen, XEN. Cyr. iv. 6, 3 (see 737).

This form with w)/felon or w)/fellon is the only expression known to Homer for past wishes, the secondary tenses of the indicative being not yet used in this construction, although they were already in good use in past (though not in present) conditions (435). In present wishes, Homer has the present optative (739) as well as the construction with w)/felon. (See 438.)

For an explanation of the origin of the use of w)/felon in wishes, see 424. It is there seen to be analogous to e)/dei and xrh=n with the infinitive, implying that what ought to be or to have been does not or did not happen. Only after its original meaning was obscured by familiar use could ei)/qe or ei) ga/r have been prefixed to it. *mh\ w)/felon may be explained in the same way; or we may suppose that mh/ originally belonged to the infinitive, and afterwards came to negative the whole expression. See the examples in 734.

*(ws, used as in 726, often precedes w)/felon etc. in Homer, and rarely in the Attic poets. E.g. *)/hluqes e)k pole/mou; w(s w)/feles au)to/q' o)le/sqai, would you had perished there. Il. iii. 428. *(ws dh\ mh\ o)/felon nika=n toiw=|d' e)p' a)e/qlw|, O that I had not been victorious in such a contest. Od. xi. 548. *(ws w)/fell' *(ele/nhs a)po\ fu=lon o)le/sqai. Od. xiv. 68.So Il. iii. 173, Il. xxii. 481. *(ws pri\n dida/cai g' w)/feles me/sos diarragh=nai, would that you had split in two before you ever taught it. AR. Ran. 955.
Neither the secondary tenses of the indicative nor the form with w)/felon in wishes can (like the optative) be preceded by the simple ei) (without -qe or ga/r).

(Present Wishes in Homer.) In Homer a present unattained wish may be expressed by the present optative, like a present unfulfilled condition (438). Here ei)/qe or ei) ga/r generally introduces the wish. E.g.

*ei) ga\r e)gw\n ou(/tw ge *dio\s pa/is ai)gio/xoio ei)/hn h)/mata pa/nta, te/koi de/ me po/tnia *(/hrh, tioi/mhn d' w(s ti/et' *)aqhnai/h kai\ *)apo/llwn, w(s nu=n h(me/rh h(/de kako\n fe/rei *)argei/oisin,

O that I were the son of Zeus, and that Hera were my mother, and that I were honoured as Athena and Apollo are honoured, etc. Il. xiii. 825. (Here te/koi is nearly equivalent to mh/thr ei)/h: cf. w)= tekou=sa, O mother, quoted under 732.) Almost the same wish occurs in Il. viii. 538.

*)=w ge/ron, ei)/q' w(s qumo\s e)ni\ sth/qessi fi/loisin w(/s toi gou/naq' e(/poito, bi/h de/ toi e)/mpedos ei)/h: a)lla/ se gh=ras tei/rei o(moi/ion: w(s o)/fele/n tis a)ndrw=n a)/llos e)/xein, su\ de\ kourote/roisi metei=nai,

would that, even as thy spirit is in thy breast, so thy knees obeyed and thy strength were firm. Il. iv. 313.At the end we have the more common form of a present wish, o)/fele/n tis a)/llos e)/xein, would that some other man had it (gh=ras).
*ei)/q' w(\s h(bw/oimi, bi/h de/ moi e)/mpedos ei)/h: tw=| ke ta/x' a)nth/seie ma/xhs koruqai/olos *(/ektwr,

O that I were again so young, and my strength were firm, etc. Il. vii. 157.The same wish, in precisely the same words, occurs also in Il. xi. 670, Il. xxiii. 629, and Od. xiv. 468; also in Il. vii. 132 in the form ai)\ ga\r, *zeu= te pa/ter, . . . h(bw=|m' w(s o(/t' . . . ma/xonto. See Od. xiv. 503, w(\s nu=n h(bw/oimi, repeating the idea of vs. 468. In Od. xviii. 79 we have nu=n me\n mh/t' ei)/hs, bouga/ie, mh/te ge/noio, better that thou wert not now, thou braggart, and hadst never been born, where ge/noio looks like a past wish; but not having been born may be included in the present wish of ei)/hs: compare te/koi in Il. xiii. 826 (above). For ai)\ ga\r e)lasai/ato, Il. x. 536, see 93 (end).
For the infinitive with a)\ ga/r in a past unattained wish in Homer, see 786.

It has been seen that the use of the moods and tenses in both classes of wishes with ei) ga/r and ei)/qe is precisely the same as in the corresponding forms of protasis (455; 410). The analogy with the Latin is also the same as in protasis:— ei) ga\r tou=to poioi/h (or poih/seien), O si hoc faciat, O that he may do this; ei) ga\r tou=to e)poi/ei, O si hoc faceret, O that he were doing this; ei) ga\r tou=to e)poi/hsen, O si hoc fecisset, O that he had done this; ei) ga\r mh\ e)ge/neto, utinam ne factum esset, O that it had not happened.

It must be remembered that it is the futurity of the object of a wish, and not its probability or possibility, that requires the optative. No amount of absurdity or extravagance in a future wish can make anything but the optative proper in expressing it. As Aristotle says ( Eth. iii. 2, Eth. 7), bou/lhsis d' e)sti\ tw=n a)duna/twn, oi(=on a)qanasi/as, wish may refer to impossibilities, as that we may live for ever; but this very wish would require the optative. So no amount of reasonableness in a present or past wish can make the imperfect or aorist indicative improper; for we may wish that the most reasonable thing were or had been ours, only such wishing implies that we do not or did not have it.

div2.head: The Infinitive.
div2.p: The infinitive is originally a verbal noun, expressing the simple idea of the verb. As a verb, it has voices and tenses; it has a subject (expressed or understood), which may define its number and person; it may have an object and other adjuncts, and, further, it is qualified by adverbs, and not by adjectives. It may have a)/n in a potential sense. It thus expresses the verbal idea with much greater definiteness than the corresponding substantives; compare, for example, pra/ttein and pra=cai with pra=cis, as expressions of the idea of doing.

The origin of the infinitive in a verbal noun is beyond question. In the oldest Sanskrit certain verbal nouns in the dative express purpose, that is, the object to or for which something is done, and are almost identical in form with the equivalent infinitives in the older Greek. Thus vidma/ne, dative of vidman, knowledge (from root vid), may mean for knowing or in order to know (old English for to know); and in Homer we have vi/dmenai (= Attic i)dei=n) from the same root vid. So Sanskrit dAva/ne, dative of dAvan, giving (from root da), is represented in Greek by the Cyprian do/venai (= Attic dou=nai) from root do.Whitney (Sanskrit Grammar, p. 314) says of these primitive Sanskrit datives: It is impossible to draw any fixed line between the uses classed as infinitive and the ordinary case-uses. See Delbrück, Forsch. Synt. iv. p. 121; and Monro, Gr. Hom. p. 163. It is safe to assume, therefore, that the Greek infinitive was originally developed in a similar way, chiefly from the dative of a primitive verbal noun; that in the growth of the language this case-form became obscured, its origin as a dative was forgotten, and it came to be used for other cases of the verbal noun, especially the accusative; that it was allowed to take an object, like the corresponding verb, and afterwards a subject (in the accusative) to make the agent more distinct; that in course of time, as its relation to the verb became closer, it developed tenses like those of the verb, so as to appear as a regular mood of the verb. The final step, taken when the use of the definite article was established, was to allow the half-noun and half-verb to have the article and so be declined like a noun in four cases, while it still retained its character as a verb. This last step was taken after Homer; but the earlier stages were already passed, more or less decidedly, before the Homeric period, so that they cannot be traced historically. Thus, although the infinitive in Homer retained some of its uses as a dative more distinctly than the later infinitive, it is hardly possible that those who used the Homeric language retained any consciousness of the original dative; for the infinitive was already established as an accusative and a nominative, it had formed its various tenses to express present, past, and future time, and it could even be used with a)/n (683). Indeed, the condition in which the infinitive appears in indirect discourse in Homer seems utterly inconsistent with any conscious survival of its force as a dative (see examples in 683).

The later addition of the article enlarged the uses of the infinitive and extended it to new constructions, especially to the use with prepositions. It thus gained a new power of taking adjuncts, not merely single words, but whole dependent clauses. (See examples in 806.) In all the constructions which were developed before the article came into use with the infinitive, as when it is the subject or the object of a verb, or follows adjectives or nouns, the infinitive continued to be used regularly without the article, although even in these constructions the article might be added to emphasise the infinitive more especially as a noun, or to enable it to carry adjuncts which would otherwise be cumbrous; in other words, all constructions in which the original force of the noun had become obscured or forgotten before the article began to be used generally remained in their original form. On the other hand, newer expressions, in which the infinitive was distinctly felt as a noun in the structure of the sentence, generally added the article to designate the case.

The subject of the infinitive, if expressed, is in the accusative. The most indefinite infinitive, so far as it is a verb, must at least have a subject implied; but as the infinitive has no person or number in itself, its subject can remain more obscure than that of a finite verb. Thus kalo/n e)stin a)poqanei=n, it is glorious to die, may imply a subject in any number or person, according to the context, while a)poqnh/|skeis or a)pe/qane is restricted to thou or he as its subject. Still, in the former case, a)poqanei=n must have an implied subject in the accusative; and if this is not pointed out by the context, we can supply tina/ or tina/s, as sometimes appears when a predicate word agrees with the omitted subject, as in fila/nqrwpon ei)=nai dei= (sc. tina/), one must be humane, ISOC. ii. 15, and drw=ntas h(/dion qanei=n (sc. tina/s), it is sweeter to die acting, EUR. Hel. 814.The infinitive of indirect discourse, which seems to have been developed originally by the Greek language, must always refer to a definite subject, as it represents a finite verb in a definite mood, tense, number, and person. Other infinitives, both with and without the article, may have a subject whenever the sense demands it, although sometimes the meaning of the leading verb makes it impossible to express an independent subject, as in peira=tai manqa/nein, he tries to learn. In general, when the subject of the infinitive is the same as the subject or object of the leading verb, or when it has been clearly expressed elsewhere in the sentence, it is not repeated with the infinitive.A few exceptional cases are quoted by Birklein (p. 93) in which the infinitive with the article appears to have a subjective genitive, like an ordinary verbal noun, instead of a subject accusative. These are gignw/skw ta\s tou/twn a)peila\s ou)x h(=tton swfroni/zousas h)\ a)/llwn to\ h)/dh kola/zein, XEN. An. vii. 7, 24 ; to\ eu)= fronei=n au)tw=n mimei=sqe, DEM. xix. 269; and ei) th=s po/lews te/qnhke to\ tou\s a)dikou=ntas misei=n, Ib. 289.In the first case the parallelism between tou/twn and a)/llwn caused the anomaly; in the second, au)tw=n has a partitive force, as if it were tou=to au)tw=n mimei=sqe; and in the third, po/lews is separated from the infinitive by the verb, and the idea is whether the hatred of evil-doers has died out (i.e. disappeared from) the state. In none of these cases would a subject accusative be the exact equivalent of the genitive. For undoubted examples in later Greek, see Trans. of Assoc. Phil. for 1877, p. 7.

div2.head: Infinitive without the Article: Infinitive as Subject, Predicate, or Appositive.
div2.p:
The infinitive may be the subject nominative of a finite verb, or the subject accusative of another infinitive. It is especially common as subject of an impersonal verb or of e)sti/. It may also be a predicate nominative or accusative, and it may stand in apposition to a noun in the nominative or accusative. E.g. *sune/bh au)tw=| e)lqei=n, it happened to him to go. *ou)k e)/nesti tou=to poih=sai, it is not possible to do this. *)adu/nato/n e)sti tou=to poih=sai. *)ech=n au)tw=| me/nein, he might have remained (i.e. to remain was possible for him). *dei= me/nein. *ou) mh
 ga/r ti kako
 basileue/men, for it is no bad thing to be a king. Od. i. 392. *)aei\ ga h(ba=| toi=s ge/rousin eu)= maqei=n. AESCH. Ag. 584. *polu\ ga r(a=|on e)/xontas fula/ttein h)\ kth/sasqai pa/nta pe/fuken. DEM. ii. 26. (Compare i. 23, quoted in 790.) *(hdu\ pollou\s e)xqrou\s e)/xein; Id. xix. 221. *dokei= oi)kono/mou a)gaqou= ei)=nai eu)= oi)kei=n to
 e(autou= oi)=kon. XEN. Oec. i. 2. *fhsi\ dei=n tou=to poih=sai, he says that it is necessary to do this. (Here poih=sai as accusative is subject of dei=n.) *to\ gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn pou labei=n e)stin, to learn is to acquire knowledge (pred. nom.). PLAT. Theaet. 209E. *cune/bh tou\s *)aqhnai/ous qorubhqh=nai, it chanced that the Athenians fell into confusion. THUC. v. 10. *ou) fa/skwn a)/nekton ei)=nai cugkei=sqai kratei=n basile/a tw=n po/lewn. Id. viii. 52. (Here kratei=n basile/a tw=n po/lewn is subject of cugkei=sqai, which is subject of ei)=nai, the whole being object of fa/skwn.) *ei(=s oi)wno\s a)/ristos, a)mu/nesqai peri\ pa/trhs, one omen is best, to fight for our country. Il. xii. 243.
For the subject infinitive in indirect discourse, see 751.

div2.head: Infinitive as Object.
div2.p: The infinitive may be the object of a verb, generally appearing as the accusative of the direct object, sometimes as the accusative of kindred meaning. Here belong (1) the infinitive after verbs of wishing, commanding, and the like (not in indirect discourse), and (2) the infinitive in indirect discourse as the object of verbs of saying and thinking.
For the infinitive in indirect discourse, see 751.

div2.head: Object Infinitive not in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: The verbs which take the ordinary object infinitive are in general the same in Greek as in English. Any verb whose action directly implies another action or state as its object, if this object is to be expressed by a verb and not by a noun, may take the infinitive.

Such are verbs signifying to wish, ask, advise, entreat, exhort, command, persuade, compel, teach, learn, accustom, cause, intend, begin, attempt, effect, permit, decide, dare, prefer, choose; those expressing willingness, unwillingness, eagerness, caution, neglect, danger, postponement, forbidding, hindrance, escape, etc.; and all implying ability, fitness, desert, qualification, sufficiency, necessity, or their opposites. E.g.

*dida/skousin au)to
 ba/llein, they teach him to shoot. *)/emaqon tou=to poih=sai, they learned to do this. *bou/letai e)lqei=n. *parainou=me/n soi pei/qesqai. *ai(rou=ntai polemei=n. *(h po/lis kinduneu/ei diafqarh=nai, the city is in danger of being destroyed. *du/natai a)pelqei=n. *toi=s cumma/xois e)/frazon i)e/nai e)s to
 *)isqmo/n, they told the allies to go to the Isthmus. THUC. iii. 15. *de/omai u(mw=n suggnw/mhn moi e)/xein. *ei)=pe strathgou\s e(le/sqai, he proposed to choose generals. *)apagoreu/ousin au)toi=s mh\ tou=to poih=sai, they forbid them to do this (815, THUC. 1). *ti/ kwlu/sei au)to
 badi/zein o(/poi bou/letai; what will prevent him from marching whither he pleases? *)aciw= lamba/nein tou=to, I claim the right to take this. *)aciou=tai qanei=n, he is thought to deserve death. *ou) pe/fuke douleu/ein, he is not born to be a slave. *)anaba/lletai tou=to poiei=n, he postpones doing this.

*laou\s d' *)atrei+/dhs a)polumai/nesqai a)/nwgen, and the son of Atreus ordered the hosts to purify themselves. Il. i. 313. *bou/lom' e)gw\ lao
 so/on e)/mmenai h)\ a)pole/sqai, I wish that the people may be safe, rather than that they perish. Il. i. 117. *)/epeiqen au)to
 poreu/esqai. XEN. An. vi. 2, 13. *)/edoce plei=n to
 *)alkibia/dhn, it was decided that Alcibiades should sail. THUC. vi. 29. *fulakh
 ei)=xe mh/t' e)kplei=n mhde/na mh/t' e)splei=n, he kept guard against any one's sailing out or in (815, THUC. 1). Id. ii. 69.
*ti/ dh=ta me/lleis mh\ ou) gegwni/skein to\ pa=n; why do you hesitate to speak out the whole? AESCH. Prom. 627 .

This use of the infinitive is too familiar to need more illustration. The tenses commonly used are the present and aorist (87), for examples of which see 96; for the perfect see 109 and 110; for the exceptional future see 113; and for the infinitive with a)/n (seldom used in this construction) see 211. For mh/ and mh\ ou) with the infinitive (as used above) see 815-817.

The poets, especially Homer, allow an infinitive after many verbs which commonly do not take this construction. The meaning of the verb, however, makes the sense clear. E.g. *)odu/rontai oi)=ko/nde ne/esqai, they mourn (i.e. long) to go home. Il. ii. 290. *)epeufh/mhsan *)axaioi\ ai)dei=sqai i(erh=a, the Achaeans shouted with applause, (commanding) that they should reverence the priest. Il. i. 22. *)/ofra tis e)rri/gh|si kaka\ r(e/cai, that one may shudder (dread) to do evil. Il. iii. 353. *(/ektora mei=nai moi=ra pe/dhsen, Fate bound (fettered) Hector to remain. Il. xxii. 5.
For the infinitive of direct object after verbs of fearing and caution, see 373. For the infinitive (not in indirect discourse) after xra/w and other verbs meaning to give an oracle, see 98.

When a noun and a verb (especially e)sti/) form an expression which is equivalent to any of the verbs above mentioned (747), they may take the infinitive. Some other expressions with a similar force may have the infinitive. E.g. *)ana/gkh e)sti\ pa/ntas a)pelqei=n. *ki/ndunos h)=n au)tw=| paqei=n ti. *)/oknos e)sti/ moi tou=to poih=sai. *fo/bos e)sti
 au)tw=| e)lqei=n. *ou) ma/ntis ei)mi\ ta)fanh= gnw=nai, I am not enough of a prophet to decide, etc. EUR. Hipp. 346. (Here ability is implied in ma/ntis ei)mi/.) *(/amaca e)n au)tai=s h)=n, kw/luma ou)=sa (ta\s pu/las) prosqei=nai, a wagon, which prevented them from shutting the gates. THUC. iv. 67.So e)pege/neto de\ a)/llois te a)/lloqi kwlu/mata mh\ au)chqh=nai, obstacles to their increase. Id. i. 16. (See 815, Id. 1.) *toi=s stratiw/tais o(rmh\ e)ne/pese e)kteixi/sai to\ xwri/on. Id. iv. 4. *to\ a)sfale\s kai\ menein kai\ a)pelqei=n ai( nh=es pare/cousin, safety both to remain and to depart. Id. vi. 18. *)/exonta tiqaseu/esqai fu/sin, capable by nature of being tamed (=pefuko/ta tiqaseu/esqai). PLAT. Polit. 264A. *ti/s mhxanh\ mh\ ou)xi\ pa/nta katanalwqh=nai ei)s to\ teqna/nai; i.e. how can it be effected that all things shall not be destroyed in death? Plat. Phaed. 72D. (See 815, 2) *de/doika mh\ polla\ kai\ xalepa\ ei)s a)na/gkhn e)/lqwmen poiei=n, lest we may come to the necessity of doing. DEM. i. 15. *(/wra a)pie/nai, it is time to go away (like xrh\ a)pie/nai, we must go away). PLAT. Ap. 42A. *)elpi/das e)/xei tou=to poih=sai (=e)lpi/zei tou=to poih=sai), he hopes to do this. But e)lpi\s tou= e(lei=n, THUC. ii. 56(798). *oi( de\ zw=ntes ai)/tioi qanei=n, and the living are those who caused them to die. SOPH. Ant. 1173.We might also have ai)/tioi tou= tou/tous qanei=n or ai)/tioi to\ tou/tous qanei=n. (See 101.) So in phrases like pollou= (or mikrou=) de/w poiei=n ti, I want much (or little) of doing anything; para\ mikro
 h)=lqon poiei=n ti, they came within a little of doing anything; where the idea of ability, inability, or sufficiency appears: so in THUC. vii. 70, braxu\ ga a)pe/lipon diako/siai gene/sqai. So e)mpodw
 tou/tw| e)sti
 e)lqei=n (=kwlu/ei tou=ton e)lqei=n), it prevents him from going; where tou= e)lqei=n may be used (807).
The infinitive depending on a noun is generally an adnominal genitive with the article tou=. See the examples above, and 798.

In laws, treaties, proclamations, and formal commands, the infinitive is often used in the leading sentences, depending on some word like e)/doce, it is enacted, or keleu/etai, it is commanded; which may be either expressed in a preceding sentence or understood. E.g. *tami/as de\ tw=n i(erw=n xrhma/twn ai(rei=sqai me
 e)k tw=n megi/stwn timhma/twn: th
 de\ ai(/resin tou/twn kai\ th
 dokimasi/an gi/gnesqai kaqa/per h( tw=n strathgw=n e)gi/gneto, and (it is enacted) that treasurers of the sacred funds be chosen, etc. Leg. 759E. So in most of the laws (genuine or spurious) standing as quotations in the text of the orators, as in DEM. xxiii. 22: dika/zein de\ th
 e)n *)arei/w| pa/gw| fo/nou kai\ trau/matos e)k pronoi/as, k.t.l. See AR. Av. 1661. *)/eth de\ ei)=nai ta\s sponda\s penth/konta, and that the treaty shall continue fifty years. THUC. v. 18. *)akou/ete lew/|: tou\s o(pli/tas nunmeni\ a)nelome/nous qw)/pl' a)pie/nai pa/lin oi)/kade. AR. Av. 448.

div2.head: Infinitive in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: The infinitive in indirect discourse is generally the object of a verb of saying or thinking or some equivalent expression. It may also be the subject of a passive verb of this class (as le/getai), or of such a verb as fai/netai, it appears, or dokei=, it seems (see 754). Here each tense of the infinitive represents the corresponding tense of the indicative (with or without a)/n) or the optative (with a)/n). (See 664, 2.)
For examples see 683 and 689. For the various tenses of the infinitive with a)/n, representing the indicative or optative with a)/n, see 204-210.

Verbs of hoping, expecting, promising, swearing, and a few others of like meaning, form an intermediate class between this construction and that of 747. For examples of the infinitive (in both constructions) after these verbs, see 136.

1. Of the three common verbs signifying to say, fhmi/ is regularly followed by the infinitive in indirect discourse, ei)=pon by o(/ti or w(s and the indicative or optative, while le/gw allows either construction. The active voice of le/gw, however, generally has o(/ti or w(s.

2. Exceptional cases of o(/ti or w(s after fhmi/ are very rare and strange: one occurs in LYS. vii. 19, o(/s fhsin w(s e)gw\ me\n pareisth/kein oi( d' oi)ke/tai e)ce/temnon ta\ pre/mna. See also XEN. Hell. vi. 3, 7 , and PLAT. Gorg. 487 D (where a clause with o(/ti precedes fh/|s).

3. Cases of ei)=pon with the infinitive of indirect discourse are less rare, but always exceptional. See Il. xxiv. 113, Il. xviii. 9, quoted in 683; HDT. ii. 30; THUC. vii. 35; PLAT. Gorg. 473 A, ei)=pon to\ a)dikei=n tou= a)dikei=sqai ka/kion ei)=nai. A remarkable case of ou) mh/ with the infinitive after ei)=pe occurs in EUR. Phoen. 1590 (quoted in 296). *ei)=pon and the active voice of le/gw take the infinitive chiefly as verbs of commanding (747).

After many verbs of this class in the passive both a personal and an impersonal construction are allowed: thus, we can say le/getai o( *ku=ros e)lqei=n, Cyrus is said to have gone, or le/getai to\n *ku=ron e)lqei=n, it is said that Cyrus went. *doke/w in the meaning I seem (videor) usually has the personal construction, as in English; as ou(=tos dokei= ei)=nai, he seems to be. When an infinitive with a)/n follows a personal verb like doke/w, this must be translated by an impersonal construction, to suit the English idiom: thus, dokei= tis a)\n e)/xein tou=to must be translated it seems that some one would have this, although tis is the subject of dokei=, since we cannot use would with our infinitive to translate e)/xein a)/n.

When an indirect quotation has been introduced by an infinitive, a dependent relative or temporal clause sometimes takes the infinitive by assimilation, where we should expect an indicative or optative. The temporal particles w(s, o(/te, e)pei/, e)peidh/, as well as the relative pronouns, are used in this construction. Herodotus uses even ei), if, and dio/ti, because, in the same way. E.g. *meta\ de\, w(s ou) pau/esqai, a)/kea di/zhsqai (le/gousi), and afterwards, when it did not cease, they say that they sought for remedies. HDT. i. 94. (Here we should expect w(s ou)k e)pau/eto.) *(ws d' a)kou=sai tou\s paro/ntas, qo/rubon gene/sqai (fasi/n), they say that, when those present heard it, there was a tumult. DEM. xix. 195. *)epeidh\ de\ gene/sqai e)pi\ th=| oi)ki/a| th=| *)aga/qwnos, (e)/fh) a)new|gme/nhn katalamba/nein th
 qu/ran. Symp. 174D. *)/efh de\, e)peidh\ ou(= e)kbh=nai th
 yuxh
, poreu/esqai. Rep. 614 B. So w(s fai/nesqai, as it appeared, 359 D. *le/getai *)alkmai/wni, o(/te dh\ a)la=sqai au)to
, to
 *)apo/llw tau/thn th
 gh=n xrh=sai oi)kei=n. THUC. ii. 102. *kai\ o(/sa au)= met' e)kei/nwn bouleu/esqai, ou)deno\s u(/steron gnw/mh| fanh=nai (e)/fasan). Id. i. 91. (Here e)bouleu/onto would be the common form.) *(hgoume/nhs dh\ a)lhqei/as ou)k a)/n pote fai=men au)th=| xoro
 kakw=n a)kolouqh=sai, a)ll' u(gie/s te kai\ di/kaion h)=qos, w(=| kai\ swfrosu/nhn e(/pesqai. PLAT. Rep. 490 C.

*ei) ga\r dh\ dei=n pa/ntws periqei=nai a)/llw| te/w| th\n basilhi/hn, (e)/fh) dikaio/teron ei)=nai *mh/dwn te/w| peribalei=n tou=to, for if he was bound (= ei) e)/dei) to give the kingdom to any other, etc. HDT. i. 129. *ei) w)=n ei)=nai tw=| qew| tou=to mh\ fi/lon, if this were (= ei) h)=n) not pleasing to God. Id. ii. 64.So iii. 108 (ei) mh\ gi/nesqai = ei) mh\ e)gi/neto, had there not occurred); vii. 229 (ei) a)ponosth=sai, if he had returned); ii. 172 (ei) ei)=nai, if he was); iii. 105 (ei) mh\ prolamba/nein = ei) mh\ prolamba/noimen). *tima=n de\ *sami/ous e)/fh, dio/ti tafh=nai/ oi( to\n pa/ppon dhmosi/h| u(po\ *sami/wn. Id. iii. 55.

In some cases, particularly when the provisions of a law are quoted, a relative is used with the infinitive, even when no infinitive precedes. E.g. *)/eqhken e)f' oi(=s e)cei=nai a)poktinnu/nai, he enacted on what conditions it is allowed to kill. DEM. xx. 158. *kai\ dia\ tau=ta, a)/n tis a)poktei/nh| tina\, th
 boulh
 dika/zein e)/graye, kai\ ou)x a(/per, a)
 a(lw=|, ei)=nai, and he did not enact what should be done if he should be convicted. Id. xxiii. 26. (Here ei)=nai, the reading of Cod. *s, is amply defended by the preceding example, in which all allow e)cei=nai.) *de/ka ga a)/ndras prosei/lonto au)tw=| cumbou/lous, a)/neu w(=n mh\ ku/rion ei)=nai a)pa/gein stratia
 e)k th=s po/lews. THUC. v. 63.

In narration, the infinitive often appears to stand for the indicative. It depends, however, on some word like le/getai, it is said, expressed (or at least implied) in something that precedes. E.g. *)apikome/nous de\ tou\s *foi/nikas e)s dh\ to\ *)/argos tou=to, diati/qesqai to
 fo/rton, and (they say) that the Phoenicians, when now they had come to this Argos, were setting out their cargo for sale. HDT. i. 1. (Here diati/qesqai is imperfect.) *)all), w)= pai=, fa/nai to
 *)astua/ghn, ou)k a)xqo/menoi tau=ta periplanw/meqa. *)alla\ kai\ se\, fa/nai to
 *ku=ron, o(rw=, k.t.l. *kai\ to
 *)astua/ghn e)pere/sqai, kai\ ti/ni dh\ su\ tekmairo/menos le/geis; *(/oti se\, fa/nai, o(rw=, k.t.l. *pro\s tau=ta de\ to
 *)astua/ghn ei)pei=n, k.t.l. *kai\ to
 *ku=ron ei)pei=n, k.t.l. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 5 and 6. (Here all these infinitives, and twelve others which follow, depend on le/getai in § 4.) *kai\ to
 keleu=sai dou=nai, and he commanded him to give it. Id. Cyr. i. 3, Id. Cyr. 9.So in HDT. i. 24 the story of Arion and the dolphin is told in this construction, the infinitives all depending on le/gousi at the beginning.

div2.head: Infinitive after Adjectives, Adverbs, and Nouns.
div2.p: The infinitive may depend on adjectives denoting ability, fitness, desert, qualification, sufficiency, readiness, and their opposites; and, in general, those expressing the same relations as the verbs which govern the infinitive (747). The omitted subject of the infinitive is the same as the substantive to which the adjective belongs. E.g. *dunato\s poiei=n, able to do. *deino\s le/gein, skilled in speaking. *)/acio/s e)sti tau=ta labei=n, he deserves to receive this. *)/acios tima=sqai, worthy to be honoured. *ou)x oi(=o/s te h)=n tou=to i)dei=n, he was not able to see this. *pro/qumos le/gein, eager to speak. *(/etoimos ki/ndunon u(pome/nein, ready to endure danger.

*qemistokle/a, i(kanw/taton ei)pei=n kai\ gnw=nai kai\ pra=cai. LYS. ii. 42. *ai( ga\r eu)praci/ai deinai\ sugkru/yai ta\ toiau=ta o)nei/dh. DEM. ii. 20. *kuri/an e)poi/hsan e)pimelei=sqai th=s eu)taci/as, they gave it (the Areopagus) power to superintend good order. ISOC. vii. 39. *bi/hn de\ a)du/natoi h)=san prosfe/rein. HDT. iii. 138. *malakoi\ karterei=n, too effeminate to endure. PLAT. Rep. 556B. *tapeinh\ u(mw=n h( dia/noia e)gkarterei=n a(\ e)/gnwte, your minds are too dejected to persevere, etc. THUC. ii. 61. (In the last two examples, malakoi/ and tapeinh/ govern the infinitive by the idea of inability implied in them.) *xrh/mata pori/zein eu)porw/taton gunh/. AR. Eccl. 236. *sofw/teroi dh\ sumfora\s ta\s tw=n pe/las pa/ntes diaqrei=n h)\ tu/xas ta\s oi)/koqen. EUR. Fr. 103.
*)episth/mwn le/gein te kai\ siga=n. PLAT. Phaedr. 276 A.
*ta)/lla eu(rh/seis u(pourgei=n o)/ntas h(ma=s ou) kakou/s. AR. Pax 430.
For examples of nouns followed by the infinitive in a similar sense, see 749. (See also 766.)

The infinitive after toiou=tos oi(=os and tosou=tos o(/sos depends on the idea of ability, fitness, or sufficiency which is expressed in these combinations. The antecedent may be omitted, leaving oi(=os with the infinitive in the sense of able, fit, likely, and o(/sos in that of sufficient. E.g.

*toiou=toi oi(=oi ponhrou= tinos e)/rgou e)fi/esqai, capable of aiming at any vicious act. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 3. *toiau/tas oi(/as xeimw=no/s te ste/gein kai\ qe/rous i(kana\s ei)=nai. PLAT. Rep. 415E. *)/efqase tosou=ton o(/son *pa/xhta a)negnwke/nai to\ yh/fisma, it came enough in advance (of the other ship) for Paches to have already read the decree (the fact that he had read it is inferred, but not expressed: see 584). THUC. iii. 49.

*ei)=pen w(s e)gw/ ei)mi oi(=os a)ei/ pote metaba/llesqai, that I am (such) a man (as) to be always changing. XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 45. *ou) ga\r h)=n w(/ra oi(/a to\ pedi/on a)/rdein, for it was not the proper season to irrigate the land. Id. An. ii. 3, Id. An. 13. *nemo/menoi ta\ au(tw=n e(/kastoi o(/son a)pozh=n, each cultivating their own land enough (to an extent sufficient) to live upon it. THUC. i. 2. *)elei/peto th=s nukto\s o(/son skotai/ous dielqei=n to\ pedi/on, there was left enough of the night for crossing the plain in the dark. XEN. An. iv. 1, 5.

This construction suggests at once the analogous use of ou(/tws w(/ste or w(/ste alone, in the sense of so as, with the infinitive (see 593). Here, as with w(/ste, the subject of the infinitive is not restricted as it is in 758.

In Homer, the pronominal adjectives toi=os, toio/sde, toiou=tos, to/sos, thli/kos, and poi=os, without a relative, sometimes take an infinitive in the same way (759); as h(mei=s d' ou)/ nu/ ti toi=oi a)mune/men, but we are not able to keep it off, Od. ii. 60; poi=oi k' ei)=t' *)odussh=i a)mune/men; Od. xxi. 195.See also Il. vi. 463; Od. iii. 205, Od. vii. 309, Od. xvii. 20.

Certain impersonal verbs (like e)/nesti, pre/pei, prosh/kei), which regularly take an infinitive as their subject (745), are used in the participle in a personal sense with the infinitive, the participle having the force of one of the adjectives of 758. Thus ta\ e)no/nta ei)pei=n is equivalent to a(\ e)/nesti ei)pei=n, what it is permitted to say; ta\ prosh/konta r(hqh=nai is equivalent to a(\ prosh/kei r(hqh=nai, what is proper to be said, as if it represented a personal construction like tau=ta prosh/kei r(hqh=nai, these things are becoming to be said. E.g.

*katidw
 to\ plh=qos tw=n e)no/ntwn ei)pei=n, seeing the number of things that may be said. ISOC. v. 110. *to
 qeo
 kalei= ou)de
 prosh/kont' e)n go/ois parastatei=n, she is calling on the God who ought not to be present at lamentations. AESCH. Ag. 1079. (*prosh/konta is used like adjectives meaning fit, proper.) *fra/z, e)pei\ pre/pwn e)/fus pro\ tw=nde fwnei=n. SOPH. O.T. 9.So ta\ h(mi=n paraggelqe/nta diecelqei=n (= a(\ parhgge/lqh h(mi=n diecelqei=n). PLAT. Tim. 90 E.

In the same way (761) certain adjectives, like di/kaios, e)pikai/rios, e)pith/deios, e)pi/docos, may be used personally with the infinitive; as di/kaio/s e)sti tou=to poiei=n, it is right for him to do this (equivalent to di/kaio/n e)stin au)to\n tou=to poiei=n). E.g. *fhmi\ pollw=| meizo/nwn e)/ti tou/twn dwrew=n di/kaios ei)=nai tugxa/nein, I say that I have a right to receive even far greater rewards than these. DEM. xviii. 53. *)edo/koun e)pith/deioi ei)=nai u(pecaireqh=nai, they seemed to be convenient persons to be disposed of. THUC. viii. 70. *qerapeu/esqai e)pikai/rioi, important persons to be taken care of. XEN. Cyr. viii. 2, 25. *ta/de toi e)c au)tw=n e)pi/doca gene/sqai, it is to be expected that this will result from it. HDT. i. 89. *polloi\ e)pi/docoi twu)to\ tou=to pei/sesqai/ ei)si, it is to be expected that many will suffer this same thing. Id. vi. 12 (for the future infinitive see 113).

Any adjective may take an infinitive to limit its meaning to a particular action; as ai)sxro
 o(ra=n, disgraceful to look upon. The infinitive is here regularly active or middle, even when the passive would seem more natural. The omitted subject of the infinitive (except when it is passive) is distinct from that of the adjective. E.g. *ai)sxro
 ga to/de g' e)sti\ kai\ e)ssome/noisi puqe/sqai, for this is disgraceful even for future men to hear. Il. ii. 119.So Il. i. 107 and 589. *tou\s ga u(pe tou/twn lo/gous e)moi\ me
 a)nagkaiota/tous proeipei=n h(gou=mai, u(mi=n de\ xrhsimwta/tous a)kou=sai, i.e. most necessary for me to speak, and most useful for you to hear. DEM. xxi. 24. *fobero
 prospolemh=sai, a terrible man to fight against. Id. ii. 22. (*oi)ki/a) h(di/sth e)ndiaita=sqai, a house most pleasant to live in. XEN. Mem. iii. 8, 8. *xalepw/tata eu(rei=n, hardest to find: r(a=|sta e)ntugxa/nein, easiest to obtain. Ib. i. 6, Ib. 9. (*politei/a) xaleph\ suzh=n, a form of government hard to live under: a)/nomos de\ (monarxi/a) xaleph\ kai\ baruta/th cunoikh=sai. PLAT. Polit. 302B and E. *lo/gos dunato\s katanoh=sai, a speech capable of being understood (which it is possible to understand). Plat. Phaed. 90D. *(o xro/nos braxu\s a)ci/ws dihgh/sasqai, the time is too short for narrating it properly. Menex. 239B. *(h o(do\s e)pithdei/a poreuome/nois kai\ le/gein kai\ a)kou/ein, convenient both for speaking and for hearing. Symp. 173B. *po/teron de\ lou/sasqai yuxro/teron; which of the two (waters) is colder for bathing? XEN. Mem. iii. 13, 3.
(Passive.) (*ku/nes) ai)sxrai\ o(ra=sqai (instead of o(ra=n). Cyn. iii. 3. *)/esti d' o( lo/gos filapexqh/mwn me\n, r(hqh=nai d' ou)k a)su/mforos. ISOC. xv. 115.
The infinitive with adjectives (here and in 758) shows distinct traces of its origin as a dative, though this origin was already forgotten. See 742 (end) and 767.

(a) The infinitive after the comparative with h)/ depends on the idea of ability or inability implied in the expression. E.g. *to\ ga\r no/shma mei=zon h)\ fe/rein, for the disease is too heavy to bear. SOPH.O.T. 1293. (See 763, above.) *(h a)nqrwpi/nh fu/sis a)sqeneste/ra h)\ labei=n te/xnhn w(=n a)\n h)=| a)/peiros, human nature is too weak to acquire the art of those things of which it has no experience. PLAT. Theaet. 149 C. (See 758.)

(b) *(/wste or w(s is sometimes expressed before this infinitive; as in XEN. Hell. iv. 8, 23 , h)/|sqonto au)to\n e)la/ttw e)/xonta du/namin h)\ w(/ste tou\s fi/lous w)felei=n, and Cyr. vi. 4, Cyr. 17, ta\s a)spi/das mei/zous e)/xousin h)\ w(s poiei=n ti kai\ o(ra=n. (See 588.)

The infinitive may be used after adverbs which correspond to the adjectives of 763. E.g. *sunebouleu/eto au)tw=| pw=s a)
 toi=s me
 eu)/nois ka/llista i)dei=n poioi=to th
 e)ce/lasin, toi=s de\ dusmene/si foberw/tata, he took counsel with him how he might proceed forth in a manner most splendid for the friendly to behold, and most terrible for the indisposed. XEN. Cyr. viii. 3, 5.

Certain nouns, which correspond in meaning to adjectives which take the infinitive as in 763, may themselves have the same construction. E.g. *qau=ma i)de/sqai, a wonderful thing to behold (like qaumasto\n i)de/sqai). Od. viii. 366.See the examples under 749.

In Homer, verbs expressing excellence or fitness sometimes take a limiting infinitive, like adjectives of similar meaning. E.g. *(/ektoros h(/de gunh\, o(\s a)risteu/eske ma/xesqai, this is the wife of Hector, who was the first (= a)/ristos h)=n) in fighting. Il. vi. 460. *(omhliki/hn e)ke/kasto o)/rniqas gnw=nai kai\ a)nai/sima muqh/sasqai, he excelled all of his age in knowledge of birds and in declaring fate. Od. ii. 158. *oi(\ peri\ me\n boulh\n *danaw=n, peri\ d' e)ste\ ma/xesqai, ye who excel the Danai in counsel and excel them in battle. Il. i. 258. (Here boulh/n shows that ma/xesqai was already felt as a limiting accusative, notwithstanding its primitive force as a dative. See 763, and 742, end.)

Even in Attic Greek a limiting infinitive, like the Homeric infinitive just mentioned (767), is sometimes found. Especially a)kou/ein, a)kou=sai, in sound, and o(ra=n, i)dei=n, in appearance, are used in this way. E.g. *dokei=s ou)=n ti diafe/rein au)tou\s i)dei=n xalke/ws falakrou= kai\ smikrou=; do you think that they differ at all in appearance from a bald little tinker? PLAT. Rep. 495E. *)akou=sai pagka/lws e)/xei, it is very fine to hear. DEM. xix. 47. *pra/gmata pare/cousin (oi( i(/ppoi) e)pime/lesqai, the horses will be troublesome to tend. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5. 46.

The Homeric use of o(moi=os, equal, like, with the infinitive belongs here. E.g. *leuko/teroi xio/nos, qei/ein d' a)ne/moisin o(moi=oi, (horses) whiter than snow, and like the winds in swiftness (lit. to run). Il. x. 437. *ou) ga/r oi(/ tis o(moi=os e)pispe/sqai posi\n h)=en, a)ndrw=n tressa/ntwn, for none was like him for following with his feet when men fled. Il. xiv. 521.

div2.head: Infinitive of Purpose.
div2.p: The infinitive may express a purpose. E.g.

*trw/wn a)/ndra e(/kaston (ei)) e(loi/meqa oi)noxoeu/ein, if we should choose every man of the Trojans to be our cup-bearers. Il. ii. 127. *xe/rniba d' a)mfi/polos proxo/w| e)pe/xeue fe/rousa, ni/yasqai, i.e. brought and poured water for washing. Od. i. 136.So Il. i. 338, do\s a)/gein, and Il. 107, Il. 108. *th
 e)c *)arei/ou pa/gou boulh
 e)pe/sthsan e)pimelei=sqai th=s eu)kosmi/as, i.e. to guard good order. ISOC. vii. 37. *oi( a)/rxontes, ou(\s u(mei=s ei(/lesqe a)/rxein mou, the rulers, whom you chose to rule me. PLAT. Ap. 28E. *de/ka de\ tw=n new=n prou)/pemyan e)s to
 me/gan lime/na pleu=sai/ te kai\ kataske/yasqai, kai\ khru=cai, k.t.l., i.e. they sent them to sail and examine, and to proclaim, etc. THUC. vi. 50. *tou\s i(ppe/as parei/xonto *peloponnhsi/ois custrateu/ein. Id. ii. 12. *cune/bhsan toi=s *plataieu=si paradou=nai sfa=s au)tou\s kai\ ta\ o(/pla, xrh/sasqai o(/ ti a)
 bou/lwntai, i.e. to do with them whatever they pleased. Id. ii. 4. *ei) bouloi/meqa/ tw| e)pitre/yai h)\ pai=das paideu=sai h)\ xrh/mata diasw=sai, if we should wish to entrust to any one either children to instruct or money to keep. XEN. Mem. i. 5, 2. *qea/sasqai parh=n ta\s gunai=kas piei=n ferou/sas, women bringing (something) to drink. Id. Hell. vii. 2. 9. *th
 po/lin kai\ th
 a)/kran fula/ttein au)toi=s pare/dwkan, they delivered the city and the citadel to them to guard. Ib. iv. 4. 15. *(\os ga a)
 u(ma=s la/qh|, tou=ton a)fi/ete toi=s qeoi=s kola/zein. DEM. xix. 71.

cit.quote: *(h qu/ra h( e)mh\ a)ne/w|kto ei)sie/nai tw=| deome/nw| ti e)mou=.
they had no money to buy provisions.
i.e., a day to defend himself in.
*)emauto/n soi e)mmeleta=n pare/xein ou) pa/nu de/doktai,
*oi(=s e)neudaimonh=sai te o( bi/os o(moi/ws kai\ e)nteleuth=sai cunemetrh/qh,
for enjoyment as well as for death.

div2.p: Here, as in 763, the infinitive is generally active or middle, even where the passive would seem more natural; as ktanei=n e)moi/ nin e)/dosan, they gave her to me to be killed. EUR. Tro. 874.

(a) The infinitive is thus used in prose chiefly after verbs signifying to choose or appoint, to give or take, to express the purpose for which anything is given or taken; and also after those signifying to send or bring. (See examples in 770.) With the last class the future participle is still more common (840). A final clause after i(/na etc. may also be used in the same sense.

(b) In poetry, the same construction occurs after verbs of motion, like ei)=mi, h(/kw, and bai/nw; and also after ei)mi/, e)/peimi, and pa/reimi (to be, to be at hand), expressed or understood. E.g. *)alla/ tis ei)/h ei)pei=n *)atrei+/dh| *)agame/mnoni, poime/ni law=n, but let some one go to tell Agamemnon. Od. xiv. 496. *bh= de\ qe/ein, and he started to run. Il. ii. 183. *ou)de/ tis e)/stin a)rh
 kai\ loigo
 a)mu=nai, nor is there any one to keep off curse and ruin. Il. xxiv. 489. *polloi\ d' au)= soi\ *)axaioi\ e)naire/men o(/n ke du/nhai, i.e. for you to slay whomsoever you can. Il. vi. 229. *ou) ga e)/p' a)nh oi(=os *)odusseu\s e)/sken, a)rh
 a)po\ oi)/kou a)mu=nai. Od. ii. 59.
*manqa/nein ga h(/komen, for we are come to learn. SOPH. O.C. 12.

(c) Even in prose, the infinitive occasionally occurs after ei)mi/ in this sense, as in PLAT. Phaedr. 229A, e)kei= skia/ t' e)sti\, kai\ po/a kaqi/zesqai h)\ a)\n boulw/meqa katakliqh=nai , there is grass to sit upon, etc. See also XEN. An. ii. 1, 6 , pollai\ de\ kai\ pe/ltai kai\ a(/macai h)=san fe/resqai e)/rhmoi, i.e. they were left to be carried away.

In Homer and Herodotus ei)=nai is often introduced to denote a purpose, where in Attic Greek a simple noun, connected directly with the leading verb, would be sufficient. E.g. *qw/rhka, to/n pote/ oi( *kinu/rhs dw=ke ceinh/ion ei)=nai, i.e. which they gave him as a present (lit. to be a present). Il. xi. 20. *li/qon ei(/leto xeiri\ paxei/h|, to/n r() a)/ndres pro/teroi qe/san e)/mmenai ou)=ron a)rou/rhs, which former men had placed (to be) as a boundary of the land. Il. xxi. 405. *darei=os katasth/sas *)artafe/rnea u(/parxon ei)=nai *sardi/wn. HDT. v. 25.So in the passive construction: *ge/lwn a)pede/xqh pa/shs th=s i(/ppou ei)=nai i(/pparxos. Id. vii. 154.

Even in Attic prose, this use of ei)=nai (773) sometimes occurs; as in DEM. xxix. 25, mnhmoneu/ousin a)feqe/nta tou=ton e)leu/qeron ei)=nai to/te, they remember his having been then manumitted (so as) to be a freeman. So a)fi/hsin au)ta\ dhmo/sia ei)=nai, he gives them up to be public property, THUC. ii. 13.

The simple infinitive in Homer may express a result as well as a purpose, as w(/ste is seldom used there in the sense of so as (589). It thus follows many expressions which would not allow it in Attic Greek. E.g. *ti/s t' a)/r sfwe qew=n e)/ridi cune/hke ma/xesqai; i.e. who brought them into conflict, so as to contend? Il. i. 8.So i. 151; and e)rize/menai, Il. ii. 214. *)all' o(/te dh\ koi/lh nhu=s h)/xqeto toi=si ne/esqai, when now their ship was loaded, so as (to be ready) to sail. Od. xv. 457.
For the infinitive in consecutive sentences with w(/ste or w(s, and e)f' w(=| or e)f' w(=|te, see 582-600; 608-610.
For the infinitive with pri/n, see 626-631.

div2.head: Absolute Infinitive.
div2.p: Absolute Infinitive.See Grünewald, Der freie formelhafte Infinitiv der Limitation im Griechischen, in Schanz's Beiträ ge, Heft 6.
The infinitive may stand absolutely in certain parenthetical phrases, expressing a limitation or qualification of some word or of the whole sentence.

1. Most frequent are the simple w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n and w(s ei)pei=n, so to speak; and w(s ei)pei=n or ei)pei=n with an adverb or other adjunct, sometimes with an object. E.g. *kai\ e)/rgou, w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n, h)\ ou)deno\s prosde/ontai h)\ braxe/os pa/nu, and of action, so to speak, they need either none or very little. PLAT. Gorg. 450D. Plato uses w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n 77 times. *(ws ei)pei=n e)/pos, so to speak. AESCH. Pers. 714: so EUR. Hipp. 1162, EUR. Her. 167 (see EUR. Or. 1). *(ws de\ sunto/mws ei)pei=n, to speak concisely. ISOC. vii. 26: so PLAT. Tim. 25E. *(ws sunelo/nti ei)pei=n. XEN. Mem. iii. 8, 10. *(ws ei)pei=n. PLAT. Phaedr. 258E : so PLAT. Rep. 619D. *(ws a(plw=s ei)pei=n, to speak simply. ISOC. iv. 154. *(ws e)n kefalai/w| ei)pei=n. Symp. 186C. *(ws to\ o(/lon ei)pei=n ge/nos. Crat. 192C. *(ws e)pi\ to\ pa=n ei)pei=n. Leg. 667D. So w(s peri\ o(/lhs ei)pei=n yuxh=s, Rep. 577E. *(/ws ge to\ dikaio/taton ei)pei=n. Leg. 624A. *(ws po/lin ei)pei=n, speaking of a state. Rep. 577C. Without w(s: to\ su/mpan ei)pei=n, HDT. ii. 91; THUC. i. 138, THUC. vii. 49. *)es to\ a)kribe\s ei)pei=n. Id. vi. 82. *su\n qew=| ei)pei=n. PLAT. Prot. 317B. *to\ d' o)rqo\n ei)pei=n, a)ne/pneusa, SOPH. O.T. 1220.

2. Other verbs of saying are used in the same way with w(s. E.g. *(ws torw=s fra/sai. AESCH. Ag. 1584. *(ws e)k tou= paraxrh=ma le/gein. PLAT. Crat. 399D. *(/ws ge e)n tw=| nu=n paro/nti le/gein. Leg. 857C. *(ws e(\n fra/zein. Id. Polit. 282B *(ws pro\s u(ma=s ei)rh=sqai, i.e. between ourselves. Rep. 595B. *(/ws ge pro\s se\ ei)rh=sqai ta)lhqh=. Prot. 339E. *(ws e)n tu/pw|, mh\ di) a)kribei/as, ei)rh=sqai. Rep. 414A.
For w(s lo/gw| ei)pei=n in Herodotus, see 782.

*)all' e)moi\ dokei=n, ta/x' ei)/sei, but, methinks, you will soon know. AESCH. Pers. 246: so SOPH. El. 410. *au)to/xqones doke/ein e)moi/ ei)si. HDT. i. 172. *)apepe/mpeto h( stratih\, w(s e)moi\ doke/ein, e)pi\ *libu/hs katastrofh=|. Id. iv. 167. *dokei=n d' e)moi/. THUC. viii. 64: so vii. 87. *)alhqh=, e)/moige dokei=n. PLAT. Men. 81 A. See Rep. 432 B, w(/s ge ou(twsi\ do/cai .

*xw=ros o(/d' i(ro\s, w(s a)peika/sai SOPH. O.C. 16.
*(ws qu/raqen ei)ka/sai EUR. H.F. 713. See HDT. i. 34. *(ws mikro
 mega/lw| ei)ka/sai. THUC. iv. 36.Once ei)ka/sai alone: SOPH. O.T. 82. *(/udwr ge e(
 pro\s e(
 sumba/llein, i.e. to compare the waters one with the other. HDT. iv. 50 (cf. e(
 pro\s e(/n, THUC. ii. 97). *)/esti de\ tou=to ou(twsi\ me
 a)kou=sai lo/gon tin' e)/xon, i.e. on first hearing it. DEM. xx. 18. *)/atopa, w(s ou(/tw g' a)kou=sai. PLAT. Euthyph. 3 B. *(/ws ge e)nteu=qen i)dei=n, as it looks from this point. Rep. 430 E. *(/osson i)/dhn. Fr. 101. *(/osa g' w(=d' i)dei=n. Pac. 856.
*ou)x, o(/son ge/ m' ei)de/nai, no, as far as I know. Aristoph. Nub. 1252. See also Aristoph. Eccl. 350, o(/ ti ka)/m' ei)de/nai, and Thesm. 34, w(/ste (w(/s te) ka)me/ g' ei)de/nai, in the same sense. *(/ws ge tw=| podi\ tekmh/rasqai. PLAT. Phaedr. 230 B.
See also w(/s g' e)moi\ xrh=sqai krith=|, EUR. Alc. 801; w(/s ge kata\ th\n e)mh\n do/can a)pofh/nasqai, PLAT. Polit. 272 D. See further, for Herodotus, 782.
(a) Here belong o)li/gou dei=n and mikrou= dei=n, wanting little, almost, and the rare pollou= dei=n, far from. E.g.

*pollw=n lo/gwn gignome/nwn o)li/gou dei=n kaq' e(ka/sthn e)kklhsi/an, when many speeches are made almost in every assembly. DEM. ix. 1. *mikrou= dei=n o(/moio/n e)sti tw=| o)neidi/zein. Id. xviii. 269; so ISOC. iv. 144, ISOC. viii. 44, ISOC. 89. *(/in' ei)dh=te pollou= dei=n a)/cion o)/nta, that you may know that he is far from deserving, etc. DEM. xxiii. 7 (the only case of pollou= dei=n).
(b) Here dei=n is often omitted, leaving o)li/gou or mikrou= in the sense of almost. E.g.
*)oli/gou frou=dos gege/nhmai, I am almost gone myself, AR. Nub. 722 , and mikrou= kathko/ntisan a(/pantas, they came near shooting them all. DEM. xviii. 151.

In many expressions ei)=nai is used absolutely, and it often seems to us superfluous. The most common case is that of e(kw
 ei)=nai, so far as being willing goes, or willingly, used almost exclusively in negative sentences. E.g. *ou)/te au)to\s e)/fh e(kw
 ei)=nai douleu/sein. HDT. viii. 116.See THUC. ii. 89, THUC. vi. 14. *(ekw
 ga ei)=nai ou)de
 yeu/somai, willingly I will tell no falsehood. Symp. 215A *ou)k w)/|mhn ge kat' a)rxa\s u(po\ sou= e(ko/ntos ei)=nai e)capathqh/sesqai. Gorg. 499C. (*)ana/gkh e)/xein) th
 a)yeu/deian kai\ to\ e(ko/ntas ei)=nai mhdamh=| prosde/xesqai to\ yeu=dos. Id. Rep. 485C: see 336 E. One positive sentence occurs, HDT. vii. 164.

Other cases of absolute ei)=nai are to\ e)pi\ sfa=s (e)pi\ e)kei/nois, e)pi\ tou/tois, kata\ tou=ton) ei)=nai, so far as they were concerned, etc. THUC. iv. 28, THUC. viii. 48; XEN. An. i. 6, 9 , XEN. Hell. iii. 5, 9 ;—kata\ (ei)s) du/namin ei)=nai, ISAE. ii. 32; PLAT. Polit. 300C ;—kata\ tou=to ei)=nai, so far as concerns this. Id. Prot. 317A;—th\n prw/thn ei)=nai, at first, HDT. i. 153.So especially to\ nu=n ei)=nai, at present (to/ belonging to nu=n): see ISOC. xv. 270; PLAT. Lach. 201 C, PLAT. Rep. 506 E; XEN Cyr. v. 3, Cyr. 42; also to\ th/meron ei)=nai, to-day, PLAT. Crat. 396 E In Aristotle's to\ ti/ h)=n ei)=nai, the ei)=nai is probably absolute, and ti/ h)=n may be a philosophic imperfect (40), the expression meaning the original essence (the what was it?).

Two expressions have w(s: w(s pa/laia ei)=nai, considering their antiquity, THUC. i. 21; and w(/s ge diako/nous ei)=nai po/lews, considering that they were servants of a state, i.e. for servants, PLAT. Gorg. 517 B.
Herodotus has a remarkable variety of expressions of this kind. Besides those already quoted, see the following:—

*to\ *de/lta e)sti\ kata/rruto/n te kai\ newsti\, w(s lo/gw| ei)pei=n, a)napefhno/s, and recently, so to speak, has appeared above water. ii. 15. (*(ws lo/gw| ei)pei=n is peculiar to Herodotus.) *kai\ w(s e)me\ eu)= memnh=sqai ta\ o( e(rmhneu/s moi e)/fh, so far as I remember rightly what the interpreter told me, etc. ii. 125. *(ws e)me\ katanoe/ein, as I understand it. ii. 28. *(ws me/n nun e)n e)laxi/stw| dhlw=sai, pa=n ei)/rhtai: w(s de\ e)n ple/oni lo/gw| dhlw=sai, w(=de e)/xei. ii. 24 and 25. *meta\ de\, ou) pollw=| lo/gw| ei)pei=n, xro/nos die/fu. i. 61. *(ws e)me\ sumballo/menon eu(ri/skein, so far as I find by conjecture. vii. 24. *(ws e)moi\ doke/ein sumballome/nw|. iv. 87. *(ws ei)=nai tau=ta smikra\ mega/loisi sumba/llein, so far as I may (ei)=nai) compare these small things with great ones. iv. 99: see ii. 10. *(ws *sku/qas ei)=nai, for Scythians, considering that they are Scythians. iv. 81. *(ws ei)=nai *ai)gu/ptou, for Egypt, i.e. for a land like Egypt. ii. 8. *mega/la e)kth/sato xrh/mata w(s a)\n ei)=nai *(rodw=pin, she gained great sums of money for a Rhodopis. ii. 135. (The force of a)/n is very doubtful here; and *(rodw=pin is often emended to *(rodw/pios or *(rodw/pi, neither of which is satisfactory.)

The absolute infinitive was probably felt as a limiting accusative; and in Pac. 232, e)cie/nai gnw/mhn e)mh\n me/llei, we might substitute e)moi\ dokei=n for gnw/mhn e)mh/n.See Grü newald, page 17. *(ws as used here can hardly be expressed in English; but it resembles some uses of w(/ste and w(s with the infinitive after adjectives in 588. It cannot be demonstrative, as might be supposed from our inadequate translation of w(s ei)pei=n, so to speak.

div2.head: Infinitive in Commands and Prohibitions for the Imperative. Infinitive in Wishes and Exclamations.
div2.p:
1. The infinitive is sometimes used in the sense of the second person of the imperative, especially in Homer. E.g. *tw=| nu=n mh/ pote kai\ su\ gunaiki/ per h)/pios ei)=nai: mh/ oi( mu=qon a(/panta pifauske/men, o(/n k' e)u\ ei)dh=|s, a)lla\ to\ me
 fa/sqai, to\ de\ kai\ kekrumme/non ei)=nai, now therefore be thou never indulgent to thy wife, etc. Od. xi. 441.So Il. i. 20, Il. 582, Il. ii. 10, Il. xvii. 501; Od. x. 297, Od. xi. 72, Od. xvii. 278, Od. xviii 106, Od. xxii. 287.
*oi(=s mh\ pela/zein, do not approach these (= mh\ pe/laze). AESCH. Prom. 712.
*pri
 d' a)
 teleuth/sh|, e)pisxei=n mhde\ kale/ein kw o)/lbion, wait, and do not yet call him happy. HDT. i. 32. *su\ de\ ta\s pu/las a)noi/cas u(pekqei=n kai\ e)pei/gesqai, and do you open the gates, and rush out and press on. THUC. v. 9. *)ea
 oi(=oi/ te genw/meqa eu(rei=n, fa/nai h(ma=s e)ceurhke/nai, say that we have found it. PLAT. Rep. 473 A. *tou=to par' u(mi=n au)toi=s bebai/ws gnw=nai, understand this in your own minds. DEM. viii. 39.

2. In the cases of the second person just given (1), the subject is in the nominative. But when the infinitive is equivalent to the third person of the imperative, its subject is in the accusative, as if some word like do/s, grant, were understood. E.g. *ei) me/n ken *mene/laon *)ale/candros kakape/fnh|, au)to\s *(ele/nhn e)xe/tw: ei) de/ k' *)ale/candron ktei/nh| *mene/laos, *trw=as e)/peiq' *(ele/nhn a)podou=nai, i.e. let him keep Helen himself,—and let the Trojans surrender Helen. Il. iii. 281-285. *teu/xea sulh/sas fere/tw, sw=ma de\ oi)/kad' e)mo\n do/menai pa/lin (sc. au)to/n). Il. vii. 78.
These examples follow the construction of the infinitive in wishes (785).

The infinitive with a subject accusative is sometimes used for the optative in the expression of a wish referring to the future. This occurs chiefly in poetry. E.g. *zeu= pa/ter, h)\ *ai)/anta laxei=n h)\ *tude/os ui(o/n, Father Zeus, may the lot fall on Ajax or on the son of Tydeus (= *ai)/as la/xoi). Il. vii. 179. *zeu= a)/na, *thle/maxo/n moi e)n a)ndra/sin o)/lbion ei)=nai, kai/ oi( pa/nta ge/noiq) o(/ssa fresi
 h(=|si menoina=| (ei)=nai = ei)/h is followed by ge/noito). Od. xvii. 354. *mh\ pri
 e)p' h)e/lion du=nai kai\ e)pi\ kne/fas e)lqei=n. Il. ii. 413. *ai)ei\ de\ toiau/tan ai)=san diakri/nein e)/tumon lo/gon a)nqrw/pwn. PIND. Py. i. 67. *qeoi\ poli=tai, mh/ me doulei/as tuxei=n (= mh\ tu/xoimi). Sept. 253. *dh/mhter, eu)daimonei=n me *qhse/a te pai=d' e)mo/n. EUR. Supp. 3. *(erma= m)polai=e, ta
 gunai=ka ta
 e)ma
 ou(/tw m' a)podo/sqai ta/n t' e)mautou= mate/ra, O that I could sell my wife and my mother at this rate! AR. Ach. 816. *)=w *zeu=, e)kgene/sqai moi *)aqhnai/ous ti/sasqai, may it be permitted me to punish the Athenians. HDT. v. 105. *(oko/teroi d' a)
 h(me/wn nikh/swsi, tou/tous tw=| a(/panti stratope/dw| nika=n, i.e. let their victory count for the whole army. Id. ix. 48.
This construction, like the preceding (784, 2), is often explained by an ellipsis of do/s, grant; see Il. iii. 351, do\s ti/sasqai. Aristarchus supplied ge/noito or ei)/h.

In two passages of the Odyssey, we find the infinitive in a wish introduced by ai)\ ga/r, once in the sense of the optative and once in that of a past tense of the indicative, with the subject (understood) in the nominative:—

*ai)\ ga\r, toi=os e)w\n oi(=o/s e)ssi, . . . pai=da/ t' e)mh\n e)xe/men kai\ e)mo\s gambro\s kale/esqai, O that, being such as you now are, you might have (= e)/xois) my daughter and be called my son-in-law. Od. vii. 311. *ai)\ ga\r, oi(=os *nh/rikon ei(=lon, . . . toi=os e)w/n toi xqizo\s e)festa/menai kai\ a)mu/nein a)/ndras mnhsth=ras: tw=| ke sfe/wn gou/nat' e)/lusa, O that I had stood by you yesterday and had punished the suitors; then would I have loosened their knees. Od. xxiv. 376.So also AESCH. Cho. 362-366, and 368.
These passages agree in construction with the second person of the infinitive in commands (784, 1).

The infinitive, with its subject accusative, may be used in exclamations of surprise or indignation. E.g. *)eme\ paqei=n ta/de, feu=, e)me\ palaio/frona, kata/ te ga=n oi)kei=n, a)ti/eton, feu=, mu/sos, that I should suffer this, alas! I, with my thoughts of old; and that I should dwell in this land, alas! an unhonoured plague! AESCH. Eum. 837. *)alla\ tou/sd' e)moi\ matai/an glw=ssan w(=d' a)panqi/sai ka)kbalei=n e)/ph toiau=ta, that these should thus cast at me the flowers of their idle tongues, etc. Id. Ag. 1662.
*)=w dusta/laina, toia/d' a)/ndra xrhsimo\n fwnei=n SOPH. Aj. 410.
*toioutoni\ tre/fein ku/na, to keep a dog like that! AR. Vesp. 835.
*tou=ton de\ u(bri/zein: a)napnei=n de/, and that he should be thus insulting, and should draw his breath! DEM. xxi. 209.
Compare Mene incepto desistere victam! VERG. Aen. i. 37. This infinitive often has the article to/ (805).

div2.head: Infinitive with the Article.
div2.p: Infinitive with the Article.See Gildersleeve, Contributions to the History of the Articular Infinitive, in Trans. of Assoc. Phil. for 1878, pp. 5-19; and The Articular Infinitive in Xenophon and Plato, in Jour. Phil. iii. pp. 193-202; Birklein, Entwickelungsgeschichte des substantivirten Infinitivs, in Schanz's Beiträge, Heft 7.

It has been seen that the infinitive without the article was already established in the Homeric language, in nearly all the constructions in which it was most frequently used in later times. In this simple form it developed its various tenses, and their uses became fixed, especially in indirect discourse; so that the infinitive gradually came to be more of a verb and less of a noun.

When the definite article had become common with nouns, it was soon prefixed to the infinitive, which thus, with all its attributes as a verb unimpaired, was restored to new life as a neuter verbal noun.By the substantial loss of its dative force the infinitive became verbalized; by the assumption of the article it was substantivized again with a decided increment of its power. Jour. Phil. iii. p. 195. As a nominative and accusative, it could be used with to/ in all the constructions in which the simple infinitive was already familiar as subject or object, although here the older form was preferred except when it was desired to emphasise the infinitive especially as a nominative or accusative. But in other constructions (especially in the genitive, dative, and accusative with prepositions), and in its wonderful capacity for carrying dependent clauses and adjuncts of every kind, the articular infinitive appears as a new power in the language, of which the older simple infinitive gave hardly an intimation.

As might be expected, the articular infinitive found its chief use in the rhetorical language, as in Demosthenes and in the speeches of Thucydides. It appears first in Pindar (for to/ in Od. xx. 52 and Frag. HES. clxxi. can hardly be the article), but always as a subject nominative, with one doubtful exception. In the dramatists and Herodotus it is not uncommon, being generally a nominative or accusative with to/, although it occurs also as a genitive or dative with tou= or tw=|; and it is found even with prepositions. In Thucydides (especially in the speeches), we find the nominative, accusative, genitive, and dative all used with the greatest freedom (in 135 cases), besides the accusative, genitive, and dative with prepositions (in 163 cases). Its fully developed power of taking dependent clauses must be seen in the Orators, especially in Demosthenes.See the statistics given by Gildersleeve in the Jour. Phil. viii. p. 332. It appears that the average number of articular infinitives in a Teubner page of Demosthenes is 1.25; of the speeches of Thucydides, 1.00; of Xenophon (whole), 1.02; of Isocrates, .60; of Antiphon, .50; of Aeschines, .30; of Andocides, .20; of Isaeus , .25; of Lysias, .12. Hypereides even exceeds Demosthenes. For the actual number of articular infinitives in each author before Aristotle, see Birklein's table, p. 91.

div2.head: Articular Infinitive as Subject or Object.
div2.p: Although the infinitive, as subject or object of a verb, generally stands without the article, the article may be prefixed to make the infinitive more prominent as a noun in the structure of the sentence.

The infinitive with to/ may stand as a subject, especially of e)sti/n. E.g. *to\ gnw=nai e)pisth/mhn pou labei=n e)stin, to learn is to acquire knowledge. PLAT. Theaet. 209 E. *to\ di/khn dido/nai po/teron pa/sxein ti/ e)stin h)\ poiei=n; Gorg. 476 D. (In the last two examples the subject infinitive has the article to emphasise it, while the predicate infinitive stands alone.) *to\ de\ paqei=n eu)= prw=ton a)e/qlwn. PIND. Py. i. 99. *ou)/toi h(du/ e)sti to\ e)/xein xrh/mata ou(/tws w(s a)niaro
 to\ a)poba/llein. XEN. Cyr. viii. 3, 42. *polla/kis dokei= to\ fula/cai ta)gaqa\ tou= kth/sasqai xalepw/teron ei)=nai, to keep advantages often seems to be harder than gaining them. DEM. i. 23 (cf. ii. 26, quoted in 745, for both construction and sense). *tou=to/ e)sti to\ a)dikei=n, to\ ple/on tw=n a)/llwn zhtei=n e)/xein. PLAT. Gorg. 483 C. *)all' oi)=mai, nu=n me
 e)piskotei= tou/tois to\ katorqou=n. DEM. ii. 20. *to\ ga qa/naton dedie/nai ou)de
 a)/llo e)sti
 h)\ dokei=n sofo
 ei)=nai mh\ o)/nta: dokei=n ga ei)de/nai e)sti
 a(\ ou)k oi)=den. PLAT. Ap. 29 A. See also 29 C.

It will be seen by comparison that most of these examples would admit the construction without the article by making the infinitive less prominent as a subject nominative. Compare ou)/te klai/ein ou)/t' o)du/resqai pre/pei, AESCH Sept. 656, with toi=s d' o)lbi/ois ge kai\ to\ nika=sqai pre/pei, Ag. 941.

The infinitive with to/ can stand as an accusative of the direct object, sometimes as an accusative of kindred meaning. The relation of such an infinitive with to/ to the verb is often less close than that of the simple infinitive in a similar case (see 811). E.g. *tlh/somai to\ katqanei=n, I shall dare to die. AESCH. Ag. 1290. *)/estin tis, e)/stin, o(/s se kwlu/sei to\ dra=n, who will prevent you from acting. SOPH. Ph. 1241.So e)pispeu/dein to\ dra=n, SOPH. El. 467. *to\ speu/dein de/ soi parainw=. Id. Ph. 620.
*to\ dra=n ou)k h)qe/lhsan, they were unwilling to act (would not act). Id. O.C. 442.
*to\ d' au)= cunoikei=n th=|d' o(mou= ti/s a)\n gunh\ du/naito, what woman would be able to live with her? (to live with her—what woman could do it?). Id. Tr. 545. *to\ u(po\ oi)/nou mh\ sfa/llesqai e)pimelei=sqai, to take care not to be upset by wine. Lac. v. 7. *ai)sxu/nontai to\ tolma=n. PLAT. Soph. 247 C. *suneqi/zesqai tai=s yuxai=s to\ th\n patri/da filei=n. LYCURG. 100. *kai\ pw=s dh\ to\ a)rxixou\s ei)=nai a)nqrw/pwn paideu/eis; XEN. Oec. xiii. 4: see also ix. 12. (So paideu/w tina/ ti.) *)epe/sxon to\ eu)qe/ws toi=s *)aqhnai/ois e)pixeirei=n. THUC. vii. 33 (cf. tou=to e)pe/sxon, THUC. ii. 76). *ou)de/ toi th=| xeiri\ pei/qomai to\ dra=n, nor am I persuaded by your violence to act (as you bid me). SOPH. Ph. 1253 (cf. ou) pei/qomai/ soi tau=ta). *kardi/as e)ci/stamai to\ dra=n, I withdraw from my resolution (i.e. I consent) to do it. Id. Ant. 1105: cf. fronei=n mete/gnw, i.e. changed his purpose (and resolved) to contemplate, AESCH. Ag. 221.
For to\ mh\ ou) with the infinitive after negatived verbs in this construction (e.g. AR. Ran. 68), see 815, 2, and 814.

The infinitive with to/ as an object accusative may follow verbs which would not allow the simple infinitive in its place. E.g. *to\ teleuth=sai pa/ntwn h( peprwme/nh kate/krine, to\ de\ kalw=s a)poqanei=n i)/dion toi=s spoudai/ois a)pe/neimen, Fate condemned all mankind to death; but a glorious death she reserved for the virtuous. ISOC. i. 43. *mo/non o(rw=n to\ pai/ein to\n a(lisko/menon, seeing only the beating of the captive. XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 21. *to\ me\n eu)noe/ein te kai\ proora=n a)/gamai/ seu. HDT. ix. 79.
The double character of the articular infinitive, as noun and verb, permits it to stand as an object wherever the object accusative of a noun would be allowed.

A few of the verbs included in 747, which govern the genitive of a noun, allow also the genitive of the infinitive with tou= (798), as well as the simple infinitive. This applies chiefly to a)mele/w, e)pimele/omai, and to the verbs of hindrance etc. included in 807. E.g. *)amelh/sas tou= o)rgi/zesqai. XEN. Mem. ii. 3, 9. (But a)melh/sas le/gein, PLAT. Phaed. 98 D. ) Most verbs of desiring and neglecting take only the simple infinitive. *)epimele/omai, which usually takes o(/pws with the future indicative (339), allows also the simple infinitive ( THUC. vi. 54), the infinitive with to/ ( Lac. v. 7), and the infinitive with tou= ( Id. Mem. iii. 3, Id. Mem. 11). (See 361, Id. Mem. 791, and 798.)

The infinitive of indirect discourse after verbs of saying and thinking sometimes takes to/. Here each tense of the infinitive preserves its time, and even the infinitive with a)/n occurs. E.g. *)=hmen d' e(toi=moi qeou\s o)rkwmotei=n to\ mh/te dra=sai mh/te tw| cuneide/nai to\ pra=gma bouleu/santi, to swear that we neither had done it (e)dra/samen) nor were in the secret (cu/nismen) of any one who had plotted the deed. SOPH. Ant. 264. *)ecomei= to\ mh\ ei)de/nai; will you swear that you have no knowledge? Ib. 535.
*kai\ to\ proeide/nai ge to\n qeo\n to\ me/llon kai\ to\ proshmai/nein w(=| bou/letai, tou=to pa/ntes kai\ le/gousi kai\ nomi/zousin. XEN. Ap. 13. See also XEN. Hell. v. 2, 36 (814).

(With a)/n.) *th=s e)lpi/dos ga\r e)/rxomai dedragme/nos, to\ mh\ paqei=n a)\n a)/llo plh\n to\ mo/rsimon, for I come clinging to the hope that I could suffer nothing except what is fated. SOPH. Ant. 235.For the articular infinitive with a)/n in other constructions, see 212.

div2.head: Infinitive with to/, after Adjectives and Nouns.
div2.p:
In some constructions in which the simple infinitive appears to preserve most distinct traces of its origin as a dative, especially after adjectives or nouns (758; 763; 766), the articular infinitive takes to/ as an accusative. E.g. *to\ de\ bi/a| politw=n dra=n e)/fun a)mh/xanos, but I am helpless to act in defiance of the citizens. SOPH. Ant. 79. *makro\s to\ kri=nai tau=ta xw) loipo\s xro/nos, a long time to settle this. Id. El. 1030 (cf. xro/nos braxu\s dihgh/sasqai, a time short for narrating, under 763). *to\ mh\ ble/pein e(toi/ma, ready to cease beholding the light. Ib. 1079 (see 758). *to\ prostalaipwrei=n ou)dei\s pro/qumos h)=n. THUC. ii. 53. *to\ me
 e)s th
 gh=n h(mw=n e)sba/llein, ka)
 mh\ e)kpleu/swmen, THUC. i (kanoi/ ei)si. Id. vi. 17. *)es de/on pa/resq' o(/de *kre/wn to\ pra/ssein kai\ to\ bouleu/ein, he is here at the right moment to act and advise. SOPH. O.T. 1416. *ai)/tios to\ se\ a)pokri/nesqai mh\ tou=to. PLAT. Lach. 190 E. (This is rare, but see DEM. viii. 56, DEM. ix. 63. *ai)/tios generally has the infinitive with tou=, DEM. 798, or the simple infinitive, DEM. 749.)

p.foreign: *(h naumaxi/a ou)xi\ dikai/an e)/xei te/kmarsin to\ e)kfobh=sai,
p.quote: the seafight offers no just ground for alarm.

cit.quote: nor have I courage to remove you.

div2.p:
The exact force given to these accusatives by those who used them is not always clear; but they come nearest to the accusative of respect or limitation (as ei)=dos ka/llistos, most beautiful in form). Sometimes the infinitive with to/ has this force, where the simple infinitive could not be used; as in LYCURG. 91, e)pei/ ge to\ e)lqei=n tou=ton, oi)=mai qeo/n tina au)to
 e)p' au)th
 a)gagei=n th
 timwri/an, for, as to his departure, I think that some God led him directly to punishment.

We occasionally find to/ with the infinitive in the Mss. in a similar loose construction, where we should expect the infinitive with tou= or tw=| in apposition with a preceding genitive or dative. See THUC. vii. 36, th=| pro/teron a)maqi/a| dokou/sh| ei)=nai, to\ a)nti/prw|ron cugkrou=sai, and viii. 87, kataboh=s e(/neka th=s e)s *lakedai/mona, to\ le/gesqai w(s ou)k a)dikei=, where most editors now read tw=| and tou= against the Mss. But Birklein defends the Mss. readings by HYPER. Epitaph. 2, a)/cion de/ e)stin e)painei=n th\n me\n po/lin h(mw=n th=s proaire/sews e(/neken, to\ proele/sqai o(/moia, . . . tou\s de\ teteleuthko/tas th=s a)ndrei/as, to\ mh\ kataisxu=nai ta\s tw=n progo/nwn a)reta/s, where the two infinitives with to/ explain proaire/sews and a)ndrei/as. (See 804.)
The infinitive with to/ appears in its greatest variety of meanings in the construction of to\ mh/ or to\ mh\ ou) after verbs implying a negative (811). See also 813 and 814.

div2.head: Infinitive with tou=, tw=|, and to/, as a Noun, in various Constructions.
