div2.p: The infinitive with tou= appears as an adnominal genitive, a genitive after verbs and adjectives and with comparatives, a partitive genitive, a genitive absolute, and a genitive expressing cause, purpose, or motive. E.g. *tou= piei=n e)piqumi/a, the desire to drink. THUC. vii. 84. *po/nous de\ tou= zh=n h(de/ws h(gemo/nas nomi/zete. XEN. Cyr. i. 5, 12. *pro\s th\n po/lin prosbalo/ntes e)s e)lpi/da h)=lqon tou= e(lei=n, i.e. hope of taking the city. THUC. ii. 56 (see 749). *to\ ga\r eu)= pra/ttein para\ th\n a)ci/an a)formh\ tou= kakw=s fronei=n toi=s a)noh/tois gi/gnetai, for doing well beyond their deserts sets fools to thinking ill. DEM. i. 23. *(h de\ diagnw/mh au(/th th=s e)kklhsi/as tou= ta\s sponda\s lelu/sqai, this vote of the assembly that the treaty had been broken. THUC. i. 87.See XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 4.

*do/cete ai)/tioi ei)=nai, a)/rcantes tou= diabai/nein, by having begun the passage of the river. XEN. An. i. 4, 15. *)orego/menoi tou= prw=tos e(/kastos gi/gnesqai, being eager each to be first. THUC. ii. 65. *pareka/lei e)pimelei=sqai tou= w(s fronimw/taton ei)=nai. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 55 ; so iii. 3, XEN. Mem. 11. (See 793.) *)epe/sxomen tou= dakru/ein, we ceased to weep. PLAT. Phaed. 117 E. (See below, E. 807.) *kai\ ga\r a)h/qeis tou= katakou/ein tino/s ei)sin, for they are unused to obeying any one. DEM. i. 23.See xxix. 17. *)/acios au)toi=s e)do/keis ei)=nai tou= toiau=t' a)kou/ein. Id. xxi. 134. *tou\s karpou\s, oi(\ tou= mh\ qhriwdw=s zh=n h(ma=s ai)/tioi gego/nasi, the fruits of the earth, which are the cause of our not living like beasts. ISOC. iv. 28. *kathra/sato tw=| ai)ti/w| tou= mh\ pa/lai a)podedo/sqai to\n misqo/n, he cursed him who was responsible for the wages not having been paid long before. XEN. An. vii. 7, 48. (*ai)/tios may take the simple infinitive and even the infinitive with to/. See 749 and 795.) *polla/kis dokei= to\ fula/cai ta)gaqa\ tou= kth/sasqai xalepw/teron ei)=nai. DEM. i. 23.So XEN. Cyr. i. 5, 13. *ne/ois to\ siga=n krei=tto/n e)sti tou= lalei=n. MEN. Mon. 387. *tou= qarsei=n to\ plei=ston ei)lhfo/tes, i.e. having become most emboldened. THUC. iv. 34. *ou)de\n ou)/te a)naidei/as ou)/te tou= yeu/desqai paralei/yei. DEM. xxxvii. 45. *ei)s tou=t' e)lh/luqe tou= nomi/zein. Id. xxii. 16. *to\ mega/lou e)/rgou o)/ntos tou= e(autw=| ta\ de/onta paraskeua/zein mh\ a)rkei=n tou=to. XEN. Mem. ii. 1, 8 (see 806).

*zhlw= se ma=llon h)\ )me\ tou= mhde\n fronei=n, for want of knowledge. I. A. 677. (*mi/nws) to\ lh|stiko\n kaqh/|rei, tou= ta\s proso/dous ma=llon i)e/nai au)tw|, in order that revenues might come in to him more abundantly. THUC. i. 4.So ii. 22, THUC. 32, THUC. 75, THUC. 93; XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 9. *tou= mh\ ta\ di/kaia poiei=n, to escape doing what was just. DEM. xviii. 107. *pro\s to\ pra=gma filoneikou=nta le/gein tou= katafane\s gene/sqai. PLAT. Gorg. 457 E. This final use appears first and chiefly in Thucydides.

The infinitive with tw=| may express cause, manner, or means; or it may follow verbs, adjectives, and adverbs which take the dative. E.g. *ou)de\ tw=| du/nasqai kai\ ei)wqe/nai le/gein e)parqei/s. LYS. xxxi. 2. *ou)deni\ tw=n pa/ntwn ple/on kekra/thke *fi/lippos h)\ tw=| pro/teros pro\s toi=s pra/gmasi gi/gnesqai. DEM. viii. 11.See xxiii. 9, tw=| me\n a)kou=sai, tw=| d' e)/rgw|. *)alla\ tw=| fanero\s ei)=nai toiou=tos w)/n, by making it plain that he was such a man. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 3. So Cyr. iv. 5, Cyr. 9. *ou) ga\r dh\ tw=| ge kosmi/ws zh=n a)/cion pisteu/ein, to trust in an orderly life. ISOC. xv. 24.
*(/ina a)pistw=si tw=| e)me\ tetimh=sqai u(po\ daimo/nwn, that they may distrust my having been honoured by divine powers. XEN. Ap. 14.
*mei=zon me/ros ne/montes tw=| mh\ bou/lesqai a)lhqh= ei)=nai. THUC. iii. 3. *)/ison de\ tw=| proste/nein. AESCH. Ag. 253. *tw=| zh=n e)/sti ti e)nanti/on, w(/sper tw=| e)grhgore/nai to\ kaqeu/dein. PLAT. Phaed. 71 C. *(/omoio/n e)sti tw| o)neidi/zein. DEM. xviii. 269. *tw=| ploutei=n u(ph/koa, obedient to wealth. AR. Pl. 146. *(/ama tw=| tima=sqai. PLAT. Rep. 468 D; so a(/ma tw=| tima=n, 468 E

The infinitive with the article, as genitive, dative, or accusative, very often follows prepositions, or adverbs used as prepositions. E.g. *tou\s ga lo/gous peri\ tou= timwrh/sasqai *fi/lippon o(rw= gignome/nous, for I see that the speeches are made about punishing Philip. DEM. iii. 1. *pro\ tou= tou\s o(/rkous a)podou=nai, before taking the oaths. Id. xviii. 26. *)ek tou= pro\s xa/rin dhmhgorei=n e)ni/ous. Id. iii. 3. *)anti\ tou= po/lis ei)=nai frou/rion kate/sth. THUC. vii. 28; so i. 69. *)apo\ tou= pei=ran didou\s cuneto\s fai/nesqai. Id. i. 138. *(/eneka tou= plei/w poih=sai th
 u(pa/rxousan ou)si/an. ISOC. i. 19. *pro\s tw=| mhde
 e)k th=s presbei/as labei=n, besides receiving nothing from the embassy. DEM. xix. 229. *)en tw=| poli/thn poiei=sqai (*xari/dhmon), in making Charidemus a citizen. Id. xxiii. 188. *)eqauma/zeto e)pi\ tw=| eu)qu/mws zh=n. XEN. Mem. iv. 8, 2. *(/omws dia\ to\ ce/nos ei)=nai ou)k a)
 oi)/ei a)dikhqh=nai, on account of being a stranger. Ib. ii. 1, Ib. 15. *pa/ntwn diafe/rwn e)fai/neto kai\ ei)s to\ taxu\ manqa/nein a(\ de/oi kai\ ei)s to\ kalw=s e(/kasta poiei=n. Id. Cyr. i. 3, Id. Cyr. 1. *pro\s to\ metri/wn dei=sqai pepaideume/nos. Id. Mem. i. 2, Id. Mem. 1; so DEM. i. 4. *para\ to\ ai)sxro/n ti u(pomei=nai. PLAT. Ap. 28 C.

The infinitive is not found with a)na/ in any case, with a)mfi/ in accusative or dative, with kata/ in genitive, with para/ in genitive or dative, with peri/ in dative, with pro/s in genitive, with u(pe/r in accusative, or with u(po/ in accusative or dative.

The genitive of the infinitive with u(pe/r is often equivalent to a final clause. E.g. *ta\s deh/seis ai(=s ke/xrhntai/ tines u(pe\r tou= ta\ me/tria kai\ ta\ sunh/qh mh\ gi/gnesqai e)n th=| po/lei (= i(/na mh\ gi/gnhtai), the solicitations which some have employed in order that moderate counsels and the ordinary principles may not prevail in the state. AESCHIN. iii. 1. *ei)s ta\s trih/reis e)mba/ntes u(pe\r tou= mh\ to\ keleuo/menon poih=sai (= i(/na mh\ poih/swsin), embarking on shipboard that they might avoid doing what was bid. DEM. xviii. 204.
The article cannot ordinarily be omitted when the infinitive follows a preposition.

(a) A singular exception occurs in a few cases of a)nti/ with the simple infinitive in Herodotus. See o(\s a)nti\ me\n dou/lwn e)poi/hsas e)leuqe/rous *pe/rsas ei)=nai, a)nti\ de\ a)/rxesqai u(p' a)/llwn a)/rxein a(pa/ntwn, i. 210, where the antithesis of a)nti\ me\n dou/lwn makes a)nti\ de\ a)/rxesqai more natural; also vi. 32 (with no antithesis). So vii. 170 (but with a various reading a)nti\ tou=).
(b) *plh/n, except, as an adverb, may have the simple infinitive; as ti/ a)/llo plh\n yeudh= le/gein, SOPH. Ph. 100.So plh\n ga/mou tuxei=n, AESCH. Eum. 737.

An infinitive, with the article in any case, may stand in apposition to a noun in the same case. E.g. *(h tw=n pai/dwn a)rxh\, to\ mh\ e)a=n e)leuqe/rous ei)=nai, e(/ws, k.t.l., the government of children,—not permitting them to be free, until, etc. PLAT. Rep. 590 E. *tou=to/ e)sti to\ a)dikei=n, to\ ple/on tw=n a)/llwn zhtei=n e)/xein. Gorg. 483 C. *tou=to proso/moion e)/xousi toi=s tura/nnois, to\ pollw=n a)/rxein. Id. Rep. 578 D. *ti/ tou/tou makariw/teron, tou= gh=| mixqh=nai; XEN. Cyr. viii. 7, 25. *dokei= tou/tw| diafe/rein a)nh\r tw=n a)/llwn zw/wn, tw=| timh=s o)re/gesqai. Id. Hier. vii. 3; so Id. Oec. xiv. 10.
For a few doubtful cases of the infinitive with to/, in apparent apposition with a genitive or dative, see 796.

The infinitive with to/ is used in exclamations of surprise or indignation. E.g. *to\ de\ mhde\ kunh=n oi)/koqen e)lqei=n e)me\ to\n kakodai/mon' e)/xonta, but to think that I, wretched fellow, should come from home without even my cap! AR. Nub. 268.
*th=s mwri/as: to\ *di/a nomi/zein, o)/nta thlikoutoni/, what folly! to believe in Zeus, now you are so big! Ib. 819.
For the simple infinitive in these exclamations, see 787.

The infinitive with its subject, object, or other adjuncts (sometimes including dependent clauses) may be preceded by the article to/, the whole sentence standing as a single noun, either as the subject or object of a verb, as the object of a preposition, or in apposition with a pronoun like tou=to. E.g. *to\ me
 ga polla\ a)polwleke/nai kata\ to
 po/lemon th=s h(mete/ras -a)melei/as a)/n tis qei/h dikai/ws: to\ de\ mh/te pa/lai tou=to peponqe/nai, pefhne/nai te/ tina h(mi=n summaxi/an tou/twn a)nti/rropon, a)
 boulw/meqa xrh=sqai, th=s par' e)kei/nwn eu)noi/as eu)erge/thm' a)
 e)/gwge qei/hn. DEM. i. 10. *to\ ga pro\s a)/ndra qnhto
 kai\ dia\ kairou/s tinas i)sxu/onta gra/fontas ei)rh/nhn a)qa/naton sunqe/sqai th
 kata\ th=s po/lews ai)sxu/nhn, kai\ a)posterh=sai mh\ mo/non tw=n a)/llwn a)lla\ kai\ tw=n para\ th=s tu/xhs eu)ergesiw=n th
 po/lin, kai\ tosau/th| periousi/a| xrh=sqai ponhri/as w(/ste mh\ mo/non tou\s o)/ntas *)aqhnai/ous a)lla\ kai\ tou\s u(/stero/n pote me/llontas e)/sesqai pa/ntas h)dikhke/nai, pw=s ou)xi\ pa/ndeinon e)sti/n; Id. xix. 55.

div2.head: Simple Infinitive and Infinitive with tou=, after Verbs of Hindrance, etc.
div2.p: Simple Infinitive and Infinitive with tou=, after Verbs of Hindrance, etc.See Madvig's Bemerkungen über einige Puncte der griechischen Wortfügungslehre, pp. 47-66.
After verbs and other expressions which denote hindrance or freedom from anything, two forms are allowed, the simple infinitive, and the genitive of the infinitive with tou=.

Thus we can say (a) ei)/rgei se tou=to poiei=n (747) and (b) ei)/rgei se tou= tou=to poiei=n (798), both with the same meaning, he prevents you from doing this. As the infinitive, after verbs implying a negation, can take mh/ to strengthen the previous negation without otherwise affecting the sense (815, 1), we have a third and a fourth form, still with the same meaning: (c) ei)/rgei se mh\ tou=to poiei=n, and (d) ei)/rgei se tou= mh\ tou=to poiei=n, he prevents you from doing this. (For a fifth form, ei)/rgei se to\ mh\ tou=to poiei=n, with the same meaning, see 811.)

If the leading verb is itself negatived (or is interrogative with a negative implied), the double negative mh\ ou) is generally used instead of mh/ in the form (c) with the simple infinitive, but probably never in the form (d) with the genitive of the infinitive; as ou)k ei)/rgei se mh\ ou) tou=to poiei=n, he does not prevent you from doing this (815, 2), but not tou= mh\ ou) tou=to poiei=n. (See also 811, for to\ mh\ ou).) E.g.

(a) *kako
 de\ poi=on ei)=rge tou=t' e)ceide/nai; SOPH. O.T. 129. *paido\s *fe/rhtos, o(
 qanei=n e)rrusa/mhn. EUR. Alc. 11. *)epi\ *)olu/nqou a)pope/mpousin, o(/pws ei)/rgwsi tou\s e)kei=qen e)pibohqei=n. THUC. i. 62. *)/allws de/ pws pori/zesqai ta\ e)pith/deia o(/rkous h)/dh kate/xontas h(ma=s (h)/|dein). XEN. An. iii. 1, 20. *eu)dokimei=n e)mpodw
 sfi/sin ei)=nai. PLAT. Euthyd. 305 D. *ei) tou=to/ tis ei)/rgei dra=n o)/knos, if any hesitation prevents you from doing this. Soph. 242 A. *th
 i)de/an th=s gh=s ou)de/n me kwlu/ei le/gein. Plat. Phaed. 108 D. *to
 *fi/lippon parelqei=n ou)k e)du/nanto kwlu=sai. DEM. v. 20.

(b) *tou= de\ drapeteu/ein desmoi=s a)pei/rgousi; XEN. Mem. ii. 1, 16. *to\ ga\r yeudo/menon fai/nesqai kai\ tou= suggnw/mhs tino\s tugxa/nein e)mpodw\n ma/lista a)nqrw/pois gi/gnetai. Id. Cyr. iii. 1, Id. Cyr. 9. *ei)=pen o(/ti kwlu/seie (a)\n) tou= kai/ein e)pio/ntas. Id. An. i. 6, Id. An. 2. *)epe/sxomen tou= dakru/ein. PLAT. Phaed. 117 E (cf. 117 C, quoted in 811). *)apesxo/mhn tou= labei=n tou= dikai/ou e(/neka. DEM. xix. 223.

(c) *qnhtou/s g' e)/pausa mh\ prosde/rkesqai mo/ron AESCH. Prom. 248.
*tou)mo\n fula/cei s' o)/noma mh\ pa/sxein kakw=s SOPH. O.C. 667.
*(/oper e)/sxe mh\ th\n *pelopo/nnhson porqei=n, which prevented him from ravaging the Peloponnesus. THUC. i. 73. *diekw/luse mh\ diafqei=rai. Id. iii. 49. *)epege/neto kwlu/mata mh\ au)chqh=nai. Id. i. 16. *pe/mpousi kh/ruka, u(podeca/menoi sxh/sein to\n *spartih/thn mh\ e)cie/nai. HDT. ix. 12.
*ei)=rge mh\ blasta/nein. PLAT. Phaedr. 251 B.

*ou) ga e)/sti *(/ellhsi ou)demi/a e)/kdusis mh\ ou) do/ntas lo/gon ei)=nai sou\s dou/lous. HDT. viii. 100. (See 815, HDT. 2; 816.) *ou) dunatoi\ au)th
 i)/sxein ei)si\ *)argei=oi mh\ ou)k e)cie/nai. Id. ix. 12.
*(/wste ce/non g' a)
 ou)de/n' o)/nq', w(/sper su\ nu=n, u(pektrapoi/mhn mh\ ou) suneksw/|zein. SOPH. O.C. 565.
*ti/ e)mpodw
 mh\ ou)xi\ u(brizome/nous a)poqanei=n; XEN. An. iii. 1, 13. (*ti/ e)mpodw/n implies ou)de
 e)mpodw/n.) *ti/nos a)
 de/oio mh\ ou)xi\ pa/mpan eu)dai/mwn ei)=nai; what would hinder you from being perfectly happy? Id. Hell. iv. 1, Id. Hell. 36.

(d) *pa=s ga a)sko\s du/o a)/ndras e(/cei tou= mh\ katadu=nai, i.e. will keep two men from sinking. XEN. An. iii. 5, 11. *(\on ou)dei/s pw proqei\s tou= mh\ ple/on e)/xein a)petra/peto. THUC. i. 76. *ei) d' a)/r' e)mpodw/n ti au)tw=| e)ge/neto tou= mh\ eu)qu\s to/te dika/sasqai. DEM. xxxiii. 25. *)hpi/stato th
 po/lin mikro
 a)polipou=san tou= mh\ tai=s e)sxa/tais sumforai=s peripesei=n. ISOC. xv. 122. *)aposobou=ntes a)
 e)mpodw
 gi/gnointo tou= mh\ o(ra=n au)tou\s to\ o(/lon stra/teuma. XEN. Cyr. ii. 4, 23. *ei)do/tes o(/ti e)n a)sfalei= ei)si tou= mhde
 paqei=n. Ib. iii. 3, Ib. 31 (cf. THUC. vi. 18, quoted in 749). *tou= de\ mh\ (kakw=s) pa/sxein au)toi\ pa=san a)/deian h)/gete, you were entirely free from fear of suffering harm. DEM. xix. 149. *)enou/shs ou)demia=s e)/t' a)postrofh=s tou= mh\ ta\ xrh/mat' e)/xein u(ma=s, there being no longer any escape from the conclusion that you have taken bribes (from your having bribes). Id. xxiv. 9.
The last two examples show that the genitive of the infinitive can take mh/, even after nouns implying hindrance or freedom. In the two following, the addition of mh/ is more peculiar:—

*(h a)pori/a tou= mh\ h(suxa/zein, the inability to rest. THUC. ii. 49. *th=| tou= mh\ cumplei=n a)pisti/a|, through distrust of sailing with them; i.e. through unwillingness to sail, caused by distrust. Id. iii. 75.

The infinitive with tou= mh/ can be used as a genitive in its ordinary negative sense; as ou)/te e)/stin ou)demi/a pro/fasis h(mi=n tou= mh\ dra=n tau=ta, no ground for not doing this. PLAT. Tim. 20 C. See also examples in 798.

Although mh\ ou) is more common than mh/ after negatives in the form (c), the simple mh/ sometimes occurs. E.g. *ou) polu\n xro/non m' e)pe/sxon mh/ me naustolei=n taxu/. SOPH. Ph. 349. *ou)de/ m' o)/mmatos froura\n parh=lqe, to/nde mh\ leu/ssein sto/lon. Id. Tr. 226.
The infinitive in the forms (a), (c), and (d), (but, according to Madvig, not in the form (b), with tou= without mh/) may follow negatives in the construction of 807. See the examples.

div2.head: Infinitive with to\ mh/, or to\ mh\ ou).
div2.p: The infinitive with to\ mh/ is used after many verbs and expressions which denote or even imply hindrance, prevention, omission, or denial, the mh/ merely strengthening the negative idea of the leading verb. If the leading verb is itself negatived, or is interrogative with a negative implied, to\ mh\ ou) is generally used with the infinitive instead of to\ mh/ (compare 807).

This infinitive with to\ mh/ or to\ mh\ ou) is often less closely connected with the leading verb than the simple infinitive (see 791), and it sometimes denotes merely the result of a prevention or omission. It is sometimes an object accusative, as after expressions of denial; but it oftener resembles the accusative of respect or limitation. It adds a fifth expression, ei)/rgei se to\ mh\ tou=to poiei=n, to the four already given in 807 as equivalents of he prevents you from doing this; and a corresponding form, ou)k ei)/rgei se to\ mh\ ou) tou=to poiei=n, for he does not prevent you from doing this. E.g.

*to
 plei=ston o(/milon ei)=rgon to\ mh\ proecio/ntas tw=n o(/plwn ta\ e)ggu\s th=s po/lews kakourgei=n, they prevented them from injuring, etc. THUC.iii. 1. *to\ de\ mh\ lehlath=sai e(lo/ntas sfe/as th
 po/lin e)/sxe to/de, this prevented them from plundering the city. HDT. v. 101. *oi(=oi/ te h)=san kate/xein to\ mh\ dakru/ein, to restrain their tears. PLAT. Phaed. 117 C (cf. 117 E, quoted in 807). *fo/bos te cuggenh\s to\ mh\ a)dikei=n sxh/sei, will check injustice. AESCH. Eum. 691. *ou(=toi/ ei)sin mo/noi e)/ti h(mi=n e)mpodw
 to\ mh\ h)/dh ei)=nai e)/nqa pa/lai e)speu/domen. XEN. An. iv. 8, 14. *ki/mwna para\ trei=s a)fei=san yh/fous to\ mh\ qana/tw| zhmiw=sai, i.e. by three votes they allowed Cimon to escape the punishment of death. DEM. xxiii. 205. *trei=s de\ mo/nai yh=foi dih/negkan to\ mh\ qana/tou timh=sai, and only three votes prevented you from condemning him to death (lit. made the difference about condemning, etc.). Ib. 167.See XEN. Cyr. v. 1, 25 , and Ag. v. 4. *fo/bos ga a)nq' u(/pnou parastatei= to\ mh\ bebai/ws ble/fara sumbalei=n u(/pnw|, i.e. stands by to prevent my closing my eyes in sleep. AESCH. Ag. 15.

*ou)k e)nantiw/somai to\ mh\ ou) gegwnei=n pa=n o(/son prosxrh/|zete Prom. 786.
*ou)de
 ga au)tw=| tau=t' e)parke/sei to\ mh\ ou) pesei=n a)ti/mws ptw/mat' ou)k a)nasxeta/, this will not suffice to prevent him from falling, etc. Ib. 918.
*lei/pei me
 ou)d' a(\ pro/sqen h)/|demen to\ mh\ ou) baru/ston' ei)=nai, they have no lack of being heavily grievous. SOPH. O.T. 1232. *mh/toi, kasignh/th, m' a)tima/sh|s to\ mh\ ou) qanei=n te su
 soi\ to
 qano/nta q' a(gni/sai, do not think me too unworthy to die with thee, etc. Id. Ant. 544. (Compare Ant. 22, and O. C. 49.) *ou)k a)pesxo/mhn to\ mh\ ou)k e)pi\ tou=to e)lqei=n, I did not refrain from proceeding to this subject. PLAT. Rep. 354 B; see Crit. 43 C. *ou)k a)pe/sxonto ou)d' a)po\ tw=n fi/lwn to\ mh\ ou)xi\ pleonektei=n au)tw=n peira=sqai. XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 32. *au)th
 me
 ou) misou=nt' e)kei/nhn th
 po/lin to\ mh\ ou) mega/lhn ei)=nai keu)dai/mona, not grudging that city its right to be great, etc. AR. Av. 36. (Compare mi/shse/n min kusi\ ku/rma gene/sqai, Il. xvii. 272.) *ou)dei\s a)ntile/gei to\ mh\ ou) le/cein o(/ ti e(/kastos h(gei=tai plei/stou a)/cion e)pi/stasqai, no one objects to saying, etc. Symp. iii. 3. *mh\ parh=|s to\ mh\ ou) fra/sai, do not omit to speak of it. SOPH. O.T. 283. *ou)de/na du/nasqai kru/ptein to\ mh\ ou)x h(de/ws a)
 kai\ w)mw=n e)sqi/ein au)tw=n, that no one is able to prevent people from knowing that he would gladly even eat some of them raw. XEN. Hell. iii. 3, 6.

The form to\ mh\ is more common here when the leading verb is negative, where regularly to\ mh\ ou) would be used, than mh/ for mh\ ou) in the corresponding case (809). E.g. *ou)k a)
 e)sxo/mhn to\ mh\ a)poklh=|sai tou)mo
 a)/qlion de/mas. SOPH. O.T. 1387. *ti/s sou= a)pelei/fqh to\ mh/ soi a)kolouqei=n; i.e. who failed to follow you? XEN. Cyr. v. 1, 25. *)/akos d' ou)de
 e)ph/rkesan to\ mh\ po/lin me
 w(/sper ou)=n e)/xei paqei=n. AESCH. Ag. 1170. *kai\ fhmi\ dra=sai kou)k a)parnou=mai to\ mh/. SOPH. Ant. 443. *ou)d' a)/rnhsis e)/stin au)toi=s to\ mh\ tau=q' u(pe *fili/ppou pra/ttein, it is not even possible for them to deny that they did these things in the interesi of Philip. DEM. xix. 163; so xx. 135. So perhaps we may explain to\ mh\ e)pibouleu/ein in HDT. i. 209 (see § 814).

Although the infinitive with to\ mh/ is most frequently used (as in 811) after verbs containing a negative idea, it can also have a negative sense as the object of other verbs or with adjectives. See to\ mh\ sfa/llesqai e)pimelei=sqai (quoted in 791), and to\ mh\ ble/pein e(toi/ma (quoted in 795), in both of which the infinitive is really negatived by mh/. We must distinguish also the use of tou= mh/ with the infinitive as an ordinary negative expression (see examples in 798) from that which is explained in 807. Compare, likewise, to\ mh\ ou) with the infinitive in 814 and in 811. The nature of the leading verb will always make the force of the negative plain. We have the same distinction, with the simple infinitive, between a)nagka/zei se mh\ e)lqei=n, he compels you not to go (747), and ei)/rgei se mh\ e)lqei=n, he prevents you from going (807).

The infinitive with to\ mh\ ou) may be used in a negative sense in various constructions with verbs and expressions which do not have a negative meaning, provided these are themselves negatived or are interrogative implying a negative. Though to\ mh\ ou) is more common here, to\ mh/ is also allowed. E.g. *koudei/s ge/ m' a)
 pei/seien a)nqrw/pwn to\ mh\ ou)k e)lqei=n e)p' au)to/n, and no man can persuade me not to go after him. AR. Ran. 68.
*ou) me/ntoi e)/peiqe/ ge to\ mh\ ou) megalopra/gmwn te kai\ kakopra/gmwn ei)=nai, but he did not persuade them that he was not full of great and evil undertakings. XEN. Hell. v. 2, 36. (For similar expressions with mh\ ou) without to/, see 749 and 815, 2) *toi=s qeoi=s ou)de
 a)
 e)/xoimen me/myasqai to\ mh\ ou)xi\ pa/nta pepraxe/nai, we cannot blame the Gods for not having done everything. Id. Cyr. vii. 5. 42 (cf. tau=t' ou)=n u(mi=n me/mfomai, AR. Nub. 525 ). *ou)de\ o(/sion e)/moige ei)=nai fai/netai to\ mh\ ou) bohqei=n tou/tois toi=s lo/gois pa/nta a)/ndra. Leg. 891 A. *)/alogon to\ mh\ ou) te/mnein. Soph. 219 E (see 817). *toi=s de\ ou)de\ lo/gos lei/petai to\ mh\ ou) ponhroi=s ei)=nai. DEM. xxiv. 69.This is cited by Birklein (p. 67) as the only case of the article with mh\ ou) in the Orators; and no case occurs in either Herodotus or Thucydides.

*ou)/kwn e)sti\ mhxanh\ ou)demi/a to\ mh\ e)kei=non e)pibouleu/ein e)moi/, there is then no way by which I can believe that he is not plotting against me. HDT. i. 209 (cf. PLAT. Phaed. 72 D). *(/ecei ti/na gnw/mhn le/gein to\ mh\ eu)ru/prwktos ei)=nai; AR. Nub. 1084.
*)/efh ou)x oi(=o/n te ei)=nai to\ mh\ a)poktei=nai/ me, he said it was not possible not to condemn me to death. PLAT. Ap. 29 C.

div2.head: mh\ ou) with Infinitive and Participle, and (Rarely) with Nouns.
div2.p: 1. The use of mh/ with the infinitive in the forms (c) and (d) in 807 is to be referred to the general principle, by which the infinitive after all verbs expressing a negative idea (as those of denying, distrusting, ,concealing, forbidding, preventing, etc.) can always take mh/, to strengthen the negation implied in the leading verb. Thus we say a)rnei=tai mh\ a)lhqe\s ei)=nai tou=to, he denies that this is true; a)phgo/reue mhde/na tou=to poiei=n, he forbade any one to do this. This mh/ can, however, be omitted without affecting the sense.

2. An infinitive which for any reason would take mh/ (either affecting the infinitive itself, as an ordinary negative, or strengthening a preceding negation, as in the case just mentioned) generally takes the double negative mh\ ou), if the verb on which it depends is itself negatived or is interrogative with a negation implied. Thus the example given above, a)rnei=tai mh\ a)lhqe\s ei)=nai tou=to, if we negative the leading verb, generally becomes ou)k a)rnei=tai mh\ ou)k a)lhqe\s ei)=nai tou=to, he does not deny that this is true. So, when the original mh/ really negatives the infinitive, as in di/kaio/n e)sti mh\ tou=ton a)fie/nai, it is just not to acquit him, if we negative the leading verb, we commonly have ou) di/kaio/n e)sti mh\ ou) tou=ton a)fie/nai, it is not just not to acquit him. E.g.

*(ws ou)x o(/sio/n soi o)
 mh\ ou) bohqei=n dikaiosu/nh|, because (you said) it would be impious for you not to bring aid to Justice. PLAT. Rep. 427 E. *ou)k a)
 piqoi/mhn mh\ ou) ta/d' e)kmaqein safw=s, I cannot consent not to learn the whole. SOPH. O.T. 1065. *)/andra d' ou)k e)/sti mh\ ou) kako
 e)/mmenai, it is not possible for a man not to be base. SIMON. v. 10.See also PLAT. Phaed. 72 D (in 749). For examples in which mh\ ou) strengthens the negation of the leading verb, see 807.
This applies also to the infinitive with to\ mh/. See 811 and 814.

When mh/ or mh\ ou) with the infinitive follows a verb of hindrance, etc. (807), neither mh/ nor mh\ ou) can be translated. When mh/ really negatives the infinitive (as in the examples last given), mh\ ou) must be translated by one negative. In PLAT. Rep. 368 B, the passage quoted in 427 E (815, 2, above), Socrates had said de/doika mh\ ou)d' o(/sion h)=| . . . a)pagoreu/ein kai\ mh\ bohqei=n, being prevented from saying mh\ ou) bohqei=n by the previous mh\ ou)d). In XEN. Ap. 34 we have ou)/te mh\ memnh=sqai du/namai au)tou= ou)/te memnhme/nos mh\ ou)k e)painei=n.

Verbs and expressions which contain such negative ideas as impossibility, difficulty, unwillingness, or impropriety sometimes take mh\ ou) (instead of the simple mh/) with the infinitive, to express a real negation, even when the leading verb is not negatived. E.g. *dh/mou a)/rxontos a)du/nata mh\ ou) kako/thta e)ggi/nesqai, it is impossible that vice should not come in (as if it were ou) dunata/). HDT. iii. 82. *deino\n e)do/kee ei)=nai mh\ ou) labei=n au)ta/. Id. i. 187. *(/wste pa=sin ai)sxu/nhn ei)=nai mh\ ou) suspouda/zein, so that all were ashamed not to join heartily in the work. XEN. An. ii. 3, 11. So h)|sxu/neto mh\ ou) fai/nesqai, Cyr. viii. 4, Cyr. 5. *ai)sxro/n e)sti mh\ ou)xi\ fa/nai. PLAT. Prot. 352 D. *pollh\ a)/noia mh\ ou)x h(gei=sqai. Symp. 210B. So after a)no/hton, ib. 218 C; after a)/logon, id. Soph. 219E (see 814). For xalepo/s followed by mh\ ou), see example under 819.
*mh\ ou) is occasionally used with participles in negative sentences, in place of the simple mh/, to express a negative condition. The following cases are quoted:—

*ou)/kwn di/kaion ei)=nai (*darei=on a)ndria/nta) i(sta/nai mh\ ou)k u(perballo/menon toi=si e)/rgoisi, i.e. he said that Darius had no right to set up his statue (in front of that of Sesostris), unless he surpassed him in his exploits (= ei) mh\ u(perba/lletai). HDT. ii. 110. *katarrw/dhsan mh\ ou) . . . th
 *mi/lhton oi(=oi/ te e)/wsi e)celei=n mh\ ou) e)o/ntes naukra/tores, they feared that they might not be able to capture Miletus without being masters of the sea (their thought was ei) mh\ naukra/tore/s e)smen). Id. vi. 9. *ei)na/th| de\ ou)k e)celeu/sesqai e)/fasan mh\ ou) plh/reos e)o/ntos tou= ku/klou, they refused to march out on the ninth of the month (and thereafter) until the moon should be full (e)a
 mh\ plh/rhs h)=|). Id. vi. 106. *dusa/lghtos ga a)
 ei)/hn toia/nde mh\ ou) katoiktei/rwn e(/dran, for I should be hard of heart (817) should I feel no pity for such a band of suppliants (ei) mh\ katoiktei/roimi). SOPH. O.T. 12. *ou) ga a)
 makra
 i)/xneuon au)to\s, mh\ ou)k e)/xwn ti su/mbolon, for I should not have traced it far, if I had attempted it by myself without any clue. Ib. 220. (For the force of the subordinate condition of mh\ ou)k e)/xwn in its relation to the real protasis in au)to/s, see 511.) *(/hkeis ga ou) kenh/ ge, tou=t' e)gw\ safw=s e)/coida, mh\ ou)xi\ dei=m' e)moi\ fe/rousa/ ti, i.e. you have not come empty-handed, — (not at least) without bringing me some cause for alarm (i.e. ou)k ei) mh\ fe/reis). Id. O.C. 359. (*mh\ ou)xi\ fe/rousa adds a condition as a qualification to kenh/.) *ou)k a)/ra e)sti\ filo
 tw=| filou=nti ou)de
 mh\ ou)k a)ntifilou=n, unless it loves in return. Lys. 212 D. (Cf. fi/loi de/ ge ou)k a)
 ei)=en mh\ peri\ pollou= poiou/menoi e(autou/s, D. 215B. ) *ti/s ga a)
 h)boulh/qh mikra\ kerda=nai, k.t.l.; ou)d' a)
 ei(=s mh\ ou) suneidw\s e(autw=| sukofantou=nti, not a man (would have wished for this) if he had not been conscious that he was a sycophant (=ei) mh\ sunh/|dei). DEM. lviii. 13. *ou)/te ga nauago\s, a)
 mh\ gh=s la/bhtai fero/menos, ou)/pot' a)
 sw/seien au(to/n: ou)/t' a)nh pe/nhs gegw\s mh\ ou) te/xnhn maqw
 du/nait' a)
 a)sfalw=s zh=n to
 bi/on (i.e. ei) mh\ ma/qoi, corresponding to a)
 mh\ la/bhtai). Fr. 213.

*mh\ ou) occasionally occurs with nouns, in the same general sense as with participles, to express a negative condition to a negative statement. E.g. *ai(/ te po/leis pollai\ kai\ xalepai\ labei=n, mh\ ou) xro/nw| kai\ poliorki/a|, the cities were many, and difficult (=not easy, 817) to capture except by time and siege. DEM. xix. 123. *toiau/ths de\ timh=s tuxei=n ou)x oi(=o/n te mh\ ou) to\n polu\ th=| gnw/mh| diafe/ronta, to attain such honour is not possible except for one who is of far transcendent wisdom. ISOC. x. 47. (If to/n is omitted, diafe/ronta as a participle belongs under 818.)
It may be noted that mh\ ou) in poetry always forms one syllable.

div2.head: The Participle.
div2.p: As the infinitive is a verbal noun, so the participle is a verbal adjective; both retaining all the attributes of a verb which are consistent with their nature.

The participle has three uses:—first, it may express an attribute, qualifying a noun like an ordinary adjective (824-831); secondly, it may define the circumstances under which the action of the sentence takes place (832-876); thirdly, it may be joined to a verb to supplement its meaning, often having a force resembling that of the infinitive (877-919).

The distinction between the second and third of these classes is less clearly marked than that between the first and the two others: thus in h(/detai timw/menos, he delights in being honoured, the participle is generally classed as supplementary (881), although it expresses cause (838). Even an attributive participle may also be circumstantial; as o( mh\ darei\s a)/nqrwpos, the unflogged man (824), involves a condition. The three classes are, nevertheless, sufficiently distinct for convenience, though the lines (like many others in syntax) must not be drawn so strictly as to defeat their object.

div2.head: Attributive Participle.
div2.p:
The participle may qualify a noun, like an attributive adjective. Here it may often be translated by a finite verb and a relative, especially when it is preceded by the article. E.g.
*po/lis ka/llei diafe/rousa, a city excelling in beauty.
*)anh\r kalw=s pepaideume/nos, a man (who has been) well educated.
*oi( pre/sbeis oi( para\ *fili/ppou pemfqe/ntes, the ambassadors (who had been) sent from Philip.
*)/andres oi( tou=to poih/sontes, men who will do this.
*)en th=| *messhni/a| pote\ ou)/sh| gh=|, in the land which was once Messenia. THUC. iv. 3.
*strateu/ousin e)pi\ ta\s *ai)o/lou nh/sous kaloume/nas, they sail against the so-called Aeolian islands, lit. the islands called those of Aeolus. Id. iii. 88.
*ai( a)/ristai dokou=sai ei)=nai fu/seis, the natures which seem to be best. XEN. Mem. iv. 1, 3.
*ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai THUC. vii. 23.
*)epepei/smhn me/gan ei)=nai to\n kateilhfo/ta ki/ndunon th\n po/lin, the danger which had overtaken the city. DEM. xviii. 220.
*(o mh\ darei\s a)/nqrwpos ou) paideu/etai MEN. Mon. 422.

The participle with the article may be used substantively, like any adjective. Here it may generally be translated by a finite verb and a relative, the verb expressing the tense of the participle. E.g. *oi( kratou=ntes, the conquerors. *oi( pepeisme/noi, those who have been convinced. *ou(=to/s e)sti o( tou=to poih/sas, this is the one who did it. *ou(=toi/ ei)sin oi( u(ma=s pa/ntas a)dikh/sontes, these are the men who will wrong you all. *pa/ntes oi( paro/ntes tou=to e(w/rwn, all who were present saw this. *to\ kratou=n th=s po/lews, the ruling part of the state.

*(o mh\ labw
 kai\ diafqarei\s neni/khke to
 w)nou/menon, he who did not take (the bribe) and become corrupt has defeated the one who would buy him. DEM. xviii. 247 (see 841). *tw=n e)rgasome/nwn e)no/ntwn, there being in the country those who would cultivate it (i.e. men to cultivate it). XEN. An. ii. 4, 22. (See 826 and 840.) *para\ toi=s a)ri/stois dokou=sin ei)=nai, among those who seem to be best. Id. Mem. iv. 2, Id. Mem. 6. *)=hn de\ o( me
 th
 gnw/mhn tau/thn ei)pw
 *pei/sandros, and Peisander was the one who gave this opinion. THUC. viii. 68. *toi=s *)arka/dwn sfete/rois ou)=si cumma/xois proei=pon, they proclaimed to those of the Arcadians who were their allies. Id. v. 64. *)afekte/on e)gw/ fhmi ei)=nai tw=| swfronei=n dunhsome/nw|, i.e. one who is to be able to be discreet. XEN. Symp. iv. 26.

When the participle, in either of these constructions, refers to a purpose, intention, or expectation, it is generally future, though sometimes present. E.g. *no/mon dhmosi/a| to\n tau=ta kwlu/sonta te/qeintai toutoni/, they have publicly enacted this law, which is to prevent these things. DEM. xxi. 49.See XEN. An. ii. 4, 22 in 825. *(o h(ghso/menos ou)dei\s e)/stai, there will be nobody who will lead us. Ib. ii. 4, Ib. 5. *pollou\s e(/comen tou\s e(toi/mws sunagwnizome/nous h(mi=n. ISOC. viii. 139.
See the more common use of the circumstantial future participle to express a purpose, in 840.

(a) Participles, like adjectives, are occasionally used substantively even without the article, in an indefinite sense; generally in the plural. E.g. *)/eplei dw/deka trih/reis e)/xwn e)pi\ polla\s nau=s kekthme/nous, he sailed with twelve triremes against men who had many ships. XEN. Hell. v. 1, 19. *(/otan polemou/ntwn po/lis a(lw=|, whenever a city of belligerents is taken. Id. Cyr. vii. 5, Id. Cyr. 73. *meta\ tau=ta a)fiknou=ntai/ moi a)pagge/llontes o(/ti o( path\r a)fei=tai, there come messengers announcing, etc. ISOC. xvii. 11. *du/nait' a)\n ou)d' a)\n i)sxu/wn fugei=n, not even a strong man could escape. SOPH. El. 697.
*ou)k e)/sti filou=nta (a lover) mh\ a)ntifilei=sqai; Lys. 212

(b) This use in the singular appears especially in qnhto
 o)/nta, one who is a mortal. This indefinite expression, though masculine, may refer to both sexes. E.g. *)en poiki/lois de\ qnhto
 o)/nta ka/llesin bai/nein e)moi\ me
 ou)damw=s a)/neu fo/bou, i.e. for a mortal (like myself) to walk on these rich embroideries, etc. AESCH. Ag. 923. *kou/fws fe/rein xrh\ qnhto
 o)/nta sumfora/s, (one who is) a mortal (like yourself) must bear calamities lightly (addressed to Medea). EUR. Med. 1018.So in SOPH. Ant. 455 qnhto
 o)/nq) means a mortal (like myself), and refers to Antigone, not to Creon ; she means that Creon 's proclamations could not justify her in violating the edicts of the Gods.

In the poets, the participle with the article sometimes becomes so completely a substantive, that it takes an adnominal genitive rather than the case which its verbal force would require. A few expressions like oi( prosh/kontes, relatives, to\ sumfe/ron or ta\ sumfe/ronta, gain, advantage, ta\ u(pa/rxonta, resources, are thus used even in prose. E.g. *(o e)kei/nou tekw/n, his father (for o( e)kei=non tekw/n). EUR. El. 335. *ta\ mikra\ sumfe/ronta th=s po/lews, the small advantages of the state. DEM. xviii. 28. *basile/ws prosh/konte/s tines, certain relatives of the king. THUC. i. 128.

(a) The neuter singular of the present participle with the article is sometimes used as an abstract noun, where we should expect the infinitive with the article. This occurs chiefly in Thucydides and in the poets. E.g. *)en tw=| mh\ meletw=nti a)cunetw/teroi e)/sontai, in the want of practice they will be less skilful. THUC. i. 142. (Here we should expect e)n tw=| mh\ meleta=n.) *gnw/tw to\ me
 dedio\s au)tou= tou\s e)nanti/ous ma=llon fobh=son, to\ de\ qarsou=n a)dee/steron e)so/menon. Id. i. 36. (Here to\ dedio/s, fear, is used like to\ dedie/nai, and to\ qarsou=n, courage, like to\ qarsei=n or to\ qa/rsos.) *meta\ tou= drwme/nou, with action (like meta\ tou= dra=sqai). Id. v. 102. *tou= u(papie/nai ple/on h)\ tou= me/nontos th
 dia/noian e)/xousin (infin. and partic. combined). Id. v. 9. *kai\ se/ g' ei)sa/cw: to\ ga nosou=n poqei= se cumparasta/thn labei=n. SOPH. Ph. 674 (to\ nosou=n = h( no/sos). *to\ ga poqou=n e(/kastos e)kmaqei=n qe/lwn ou)k a)
 meqei=to, pri
 kaq' h(donh
 klu/ein. Id. Tr. 196.

This is really the same use of the neuter singular of an adjective for the corresponding abstract noun, which is common in ordinary adjectives; as to\ kalo/n, beauty, for to\ ka/llos; to\ di/kaion and to\ a)/dikon for h( dikaiosu/nh and h( a)diki/a.

(b) A similar construction sometimes occurs when a participle and a noun are used like an articular infinitive with its subject, where in English we generally use a finite verb. E.g. *meta\ de\ *so/lwna oi)xo/menon e)/labe ne/mesis mega/lh *kroi=son, i.e. after Solon was gone (like meta\ to\ *so/lwna oi)/xesqai). HDT. i. 34. *)epi\ tou/tou turanneu/ontos, in his reign. Id. i. 15: so viii. 44. *)/etei pe/mptw| meta\ *surakou/sas oi)kisqei/sas, in the fifth year after the foundation of Syracuse. THUC. vi. 3. Compare post urbem conditam in Latin. *meta\ kalo\n ou(/tw kai\ pantodapo\n lo/gon r(hqe/nta (like meta\ to\ . . . r(hqh=nai). Symp. 198B. *th=| po/lei ou)/te pole/mou kakw=s sumba/ntos ou)/te sta/sews pw/pote ai)/tios e)ge/neto, i.e. the cause of a disastrous result of any war (like tou= po/lemo/n tina kakw=s sumbh=nai). XEN. Mem. i. 2, 63.
(c) The same construction occurs in Homer; as e)s h)e/lion katadu/nta, to the going down of the sum, Il. i. 601; a(/m' h)oi= fainome/nhfin, Il. ix. 682.
For the peculiar use of the aorist participle here, see 149.

The participle is sometimes used like a predicate adjective, with ei)mi/ or gi/gnomai. E.g. *ti/ pot' e)sti\n ou(=tos e)kei/nou diafe/rwn; in what is this man different from that one (another form for diafe/rei)? PLAT. Gorg. 500 C. *sumfe/ron h)=n th=| po/lei, it was advantageous to the state (= sune/feren). DEM. xix. 75. *ou)/te ga\r qrasu\s ou)/t' ou)=n prodei/sas ei)mi\ tw=| ge nu=n lo/gw|. SOPH. O.T. 90. *)aparneo/meno/s e)sti (=a)parne/etai). HDT. iii. 99. *(h de\ e)sti\ de/ka stadi/ous a)pe/xousa, and it (the island) is ten stades distant. Id. ix. 51.

*(\an h)=| qe/lousa, pa/nt' e)mou= komi/zetai, whatever she wants, she always obtains from me (for a(\n qe/lh|). SOPH. O.T. 580. *)=hn ga\r o( *qemistoklh=s bebaio/tata dh\ fu/sews i)sxu\n dhlw/sas, kai\ a)/cios qauma/sai, Themistocles was one who manifested, etc. THUC. i. 138. *tou=to ou)k e)/sti gigno/menon par' h(mi=n; is not this something that goes on in our minds? Phil. 39C. *tou=to kinduneu/ei pro/pon tina\ gigno/menon h( dikaiosu/nh ei)=nai, justice seems somehow to be proving to be (lit. becoming) this. Rep. 433 B.
So with u(pa/rxw and the poetic pe/lomai; as tou=to u(pa/rxein u(ma=s ei)do/tas h(gou=mai, I think you may be presumed to know this, DEM. xviii. 95; e)mei=o lelasme/nos e)/pleu, Il. xxiii. 69.

On the same principle, the participle is used in all periphrastic forms with ei)mi/ and e)/xw for the perfect, pluperfect, and future perfect. In the future perfect active, the periphrastic form is generally the only one in use; in the third person plural of the perfect and pluperfect middle and passive of most verbs, it is the only form possible. Examples of the perfect participle with ei)mi/ or h)=n as peculiar forms of the perfect and pluperfect, in other persons, are given in 45; of e)/xw and ei)=xon with the aorist and perfect participle for the perfect and pluperfect, in 47 and 48; of e)/somai with the perfect and aorist participle for the future perfect, in 80 and 81.

div2.head: Circumstantial Participle.
div2.p: The participle may define the circumstances under which an action takes place, agreeing with the noun or pronoun to which it relates. The negative of such a participle is ou), unless it has a conditional force.
The relations expressed by the participle in this use are the following:—

I. Time, the tenses of the participle denoting various points of time, which is relative to that of the leading verb. E.g. *tau=ta ei)pw\n a)ph/|ei, when he had said this, he departed. *)aph/nthsa *fili/ppw| a)pio/nti, I met Philip as he was departing. *tou=to pepoihko/tes xairh/sousin. *tau=ta e)/pratte strathgw=n, he did these things while he was general. *tau=ta pra/cei strathgw=n, he will do these things when he is general. *turanneu/sas de\ e)/th tri/a *(ippi/as e)xw/rei u(po/spondos e)s *si/geion, after a rule of three years. THUC. vi. 59. *nu=n me\n deipnei=te: deipnh/santes de\ a)pelau/nete, i.e. after supping. XEN. Cyr. iii. 1, 37. So vii. 5, XEN. Cyr. 78; XEN. An. vii. 1, 13.

*(/aper kai\ a)rxo/menos ei)=pon, as I said also at first. THUC. iv. 64. *teleutw=n ou)=n e)pi\ tou\s xeirote/xnas h)=|a, finally then I went to the artisans. PLAT. Ap. 22 C. *)oli/gon xro/non dialipw
 e)kinh/qh, after a little while he moved. Id. Phaed. 118. *ou) polu
 xro/non e)pisxw
 h(=ke, after (waiting) no long time he came. Ib. 59 E *dialei/pousan xro/non, at intervals (of Clotho's regular movements). Rep. 617 C. *opws xroni/zon eu)= menei= bouleute/on. AESCH. Ag. 847: cf. xronisqei/s, Ib. 727.
II. Means. E.g.

*lh|zo/menoi zw=sin, they live by plunder. XEN. Cyr. iii. 2, 25. *tou\s *(/ellhnas e)di/dacan, o(
 tro/pon dioikou=ntes ta\s au(tw=n patri/das kai\ pro\s ou(\s polemou=ntes mega/lhn a)
 th
 *(ella/da poih/seian. ISOC. xii. 44. *ou) ga a)llotri/ois u(mi=n xrwme/nois paradei/gmasin a)ll' oi)kei/ois, eu)dai/mosin e)/cesti gene/sqai, for it is by using not foreign but domestic examples that you can become prosperous. DEM. iii. 23. *tw=n no/mwn a)/peiroi gi/gnontai kai\ tw=n lo/gwn, oi(=s dei= xrw/menon o(milei=n toi=s a)nqrw/pois, which we (tina/) must use in our intercourse with men. PLAT. Gorg. 484 D. So often xrw/menos in the sense of with (cf. 843).

III. Manner and similar relations, including manner of employment, etc. E.g. *proei/leto ma=llon toi=s no/mois e)mme/nwn a)poqanei=n h)\ paranomw=n zh=n, he preferred to die abiding by the laws, rather than to live disobeying them. XEN. Mem. iv. 4, 4. *proairou=ntai ma=llon ou(/tw kerdai/nein a)p' a)llh/lwn h)\ sunwfelou=ntes au(tou/s, they prefer to get gain by this means from each other, rather than by uniting to aid themselves. Ib. iii. 5, Ib. 16. *kai\ h(\ gela/sasa e)/fh, and she said with a laugh. Symp. 202B. *(arpa/santas ta\ o(/pla poreu/esqai, to march having snatched up their arms (i.e. eagerly). DEM. iii. 20: cf. oi(=on r(i/yantas ta\ i(ma/tia, PLAT. Rep. 474 A.

The following participles of manner are used in peculiar senses: fe/rwn, hastily; fero/menos, with a rush; a)nu/sas, quickly; katatei/nas, earnestly; diateina/menos and diatetame/nos, with all one's might; fqa/sas, before (anticipating); laqw/n, secretly; e)/xwn, continually; klai/wn, to one's sorrow; xai/rwn, with impunity (to one's joy). E.g. *ei)s tou=to fe/rwn perie/sthse ta\ pra/gmata, he rapidly brought things to such a pass. AESCHIN. iii. 82. *(ws e)se/peson fero/menoi e)s tou\s *(/ellhnas oi( *mh=doi, when the Persians fell upon the Greeks with a rush. HDT. vii. 210.So oi)xh/sesqai ferome/nhn kata\ r(ou=n, PLAT. Rep. 492 C. *)/anoig' a)nu/sas to\ frontisth/rion, make haste and open the thinking-shop. AR. Nub. 181.
*katatei/nas e)rw= to\n a)/dikon bi/on e)painw=n, I will speak earnestly in praise of the unjust life. PLAT. Rep. 358 D: so 367 B. See Rep. 474 A, and XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 23. *ei)=t' a)ne/w|cas me fqa/sas, then you opened it (the door) before I could knock. Plut. 1102: so o(/s m' e)/bale fqa/menos, Il. v. 119; but in such expressions e)/fqh balw/n etc. (887) is more common. *)apo\ tei/xeos a)/lto laqw/n, he leaped from the wall secretly. Il. xii. 390: cf. lh/qousa/ m' e)ce/pines, SOPH. Ant. 532; here again e)/laqon with the participle is more common (see 893). *ti/ kupta/zeis e)/xwn; why do you keep poking about? AR. Nub. 509.
*klai/wn a(/yei tw=nde, you will lay hands on them to your sorrow. EUR. Her. 270: so SOPH. Ant. 754. *ou)/ ti xai/rwn e)rei=s, you shall not speak with impunity. Id. O.T. 363; so Ant. 759. *tou=ton ou)dei\s xai/rwn a)dikh/sei. PLAT. Gorg. 510 D. Compare tacame/nous, according to agreement, Id. Rep. 416 E.
IV. Cause or ground of action. E.g.

*le/gw de\ tou=d' e(/neka, boulo/menos do/cai soi\ o(/per e)moi/, and I speak for this reason, because I wish, etc. PLAT. Phaed. 102 D. *)apei/xonto kerdw=n, ai)sxra\ nomi/zontes ei)=nai, because they believed them to be base. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 22. *ti/ ga\r a)\n boulo/menoi a)/ndres sofoi\ w(s a)lhqw=s despo/tas a)mei/nous au)tw=n feu/goien, with what object in view, etc. (i.e. wishing what)? PLAT. Phaed. 63 A. *ti/ ga\r dedio/tes sfo/dra ou(/tws e)pei/gesqe; what do you fear, that you are in such great haste? XEN. Hell. i. 7, 26.
For the participle with w(s, used to express a cause assigned by the subject of the sentence, see 864.

(a) Here belong ti/ maqw/n; and ti/ paqw/n; both of which have the general force of wherefore? *ti/ maqw\n tou=to poiei=; however, properly means what put it into his head to do this? or with what idea does he do this? and ti/ paqw\n tou=to poiei=; means what has happened to him that he does this? E.g.

p.quote: with what idea did he add this to the law?

cit.quote: *ti/ paqou=sai, ei)/per *nefe/lai g' ei)si\n a)lhqw=s, qnhtai=s ei)/casi gunaici/n;
what has happened to them that they resemble mortal women?

div2.p: (b) These phrases may be used even in dependent sentences, ti/ becoming o(/ ti, and the whole phrase meaning because. E.g.

*ti/ a)cio/s ei)mi paqei=n h)\ a)poti=sai, o(/ ti maqw\n e)n tw=| bi/w| ou)x h(suxi/an h)=gon; what do I deserve to suffer or pay because I did not keep quiet? i.e. for taking it into my head not to keep quiet? PLAT. Ap. 36 B. *(/omws a)\n kaka\ h)=n, o(/ ti ma/qonta xai/rein poiei= kai\ o(ph|ou=n; would they still be evil because they give us joy in any conceivable manner? Prot. 353 D. (In cases like this, the original meaning of the participle is forgotten.) So Euthyd. 283 E and 299 A.

V. Purpose, object, or intention, expressed by the future participle, rarely by the present. E.g. *)=hlqe luso/menos qu/gatra, he came to ransom his daughter. Il. i. 13. *parelh/luqa sumbouleu/swn, I have risen to give my advice. ISOC. vi. 1. *)ebouleu/santo pe/mpein e)s *lakedai/mona pre/sbeis tau=ta/ te e)rou=ntas kai\ *lu/sandron ai)th/sontas e)pi\ ta\s nau=s, in order to say this, and to ask for Lysander as admiral. XEN. Hell. ii. 1, 6. *)ea\n ei)s po/lemon (h( patri\s) a)/gh| trwqhso/menon h)\ a)poqanou/menon, poihte/on tau=ta, even if it lead any one into war to be wounded or to perish. PLAT. Crit. 51 B. *au)=qis de\ o( h(ghso/menos ou)dei\s e)/stai, there will be nobody to lead us (=o(\s h(gh/setai). XEN. An. ii. 4, 5. (This participle is also attributive: see 826.) *prosbola\s pareskeua/zonto tw=| tei/xei poihso/menoi, they prepared (themselves) to make attacks on the wall. THUC. ii. 18.

*)/etuxon ga\r (nh=es) oi)xo/menai, periagge/llousai bohqei=n, for some ships happened to be gone, to give notice to send aid. Id. i. 116.So a)rnu/menoi, Il. i. 159.The present here expresses an attendant circumstance (843) as well as a purpose. See also fqei/ronte, AESCH. Ag. 652.

VI. Condition, the participle standing for a protasis, and its tenses representing the various forms of condition expressed by the indicative, subjunctive, or optative (472). E.g. *oi)/ei su\ *)/alkhstin u(pe *)admh/tou a)poqanei=n a)
, h)\ *)axille/a *patro/klw| e)papoqanei=n, mh\ oi)ome/nous a)qa/naton mnh/mhn a)reth=s pe/ri e(autw=n e)/sesqai, do you think that Alcestis would have died for Admetus, etc., if they had not believed, etc. Symp. 208D. (Here mh\ oi)ome/nous is equivalent to ei) mh\ w)/|onto.) *ou) ga a)
 au)toi=s e)/melen mh\ tou=q' u(polamba/nousin, for it would not have concerned them, unless they had had this idea. DEM. ix. 45. (*mh\ u(polamba/nousin = ei) mh\ tou=to u(pela/mbanon.) *)/astrwn a)
 e)/lqoim' h(li/ou pro\s a)ntola\s kai\ gh=s e)/nerqe, dunato\s w)
 dra=sai ta/de, if I should be able to do this (ei) dunato\s ei)/hn). EUR. Ph. 504.So the attributive participles o( mh\ darei/s (824) and o( mh\ labw/n (825).
In SOPH. OT 289 , pa/lai de\ mh\ parw\n qauma/zetai, the construction represents qauma/zomen ei) mh\ pa/restin, we wonder that he is not here (494).
For mh\ ou) with the participle in negative conditions, where mh/ is more common, see 818.
See other examples under 472.
VII. Opposition, limitation, or concession, where the participle may often be translated by although. E.g.

*ou(=tos de\ kai\ metapemfqh=nai fa/skwn u(po\ tou= patro\s, kai\ e)lqw
 ei)s th
 oi)ki/an, ei)selqei=n me
 ou)/ fhsin, *dhmofw=ntos d' a)kou=sai grammatei=on a)nagignw/skontos, kai\ proeiselhluqw\s kai\ a(/panta diwmologhme/nos pro\s to
 pate/ra, and this man, although he admits that he was summoned, and although he did go to the house, yet denies that he went in, etc., although he had previously gone in and arranged everything with my father. DEM. xxviii. 14. *)oli/ga duna/menoi proora=n peri\ tou= me/llontos polla\ e)pixeirou=men pra/ttein, although we are able to foresee few things, etc. XEN. Cyr. iii. 2, 15. *(elw
 kai\ dunhqei\s a)
 au)to\s e)/xein, pare/dwke, i.e. when he had captured it (Olynthus) and might have kept it himself, he surrendered it. DEM. xxiii. 107.
The participle in this sense is very often accompanied by kai/per and other particles. (See 859.) This construction is the most common equivalent of a clause with although.
VIII. Any attendant circumstance, the participle being merely descriptive. E.g.

*paralabo/ntes *boiwtou\s kai\ *fwke/as e)stra/teusan e)pi\ *fa/rsalon, they took Boeotians and Phocians with them and marched against Pharsalus. THUC. i. 111. *paragge/llei tw=| *klea/rxw| labo/nti h(/|kein o(/son h)=n au)tw=| stra/teuma, he sends orders to Cl.to come with all the army that he has. XEN. An. i. 2, 1. *)/erxetai *manda/nh to
 *ku=ron to
 ui(o
 e)/xousa, Mandane comes with her son Cyrus. Id. Cyr. i. 3, Id. Cyr. 1. *katadiw/cantes kai\ nau=s dw/deka labo/ntes tou/s te a)/ndras a)nelo/menoi a)pe/pleon, kai\ tro/paion sth/santes a)nexw/rhsan. THUC. ii. 84. *mi/a e)s *pelopo/nnhson w)/|xeto pre/sbeis a)/gousa, one (ship) was gone to Peloponnesus with ambassadors. Id. vii. 25. *do\s tw=| cei/nw| tau=ta fe/rwn, take these and give them to the stranger. Hom. Od. xvii. 345. *boh=| xrw/menoi, with a shout. THUC. ii. 84.
The participles e)/xwn, a)/gwn, labw/n, fe/rwn, and xrw/menos may often be translated by with: see examples in 843. (For another use of fe/rwn see 837.)
IX. That in which the action of the verb consists. E.g.

*to/d' ei)=pe fwnw=n, thus he spake saying. AESCH. Ag. 205. *(/os' h(ma=s a)gaqa\ de/drakas ei)rh/nhn poih/sas, what blessings you have done us in making peace! Pac. 1199. *eu)= g' e)poi/hsas a)namnh/sas me, you did well in reminding me. PLAT. Phaed. 60 C.
See other examples under 150, where the peculiar force of the aorist participle in such cases, denoting the same time with the verb, is illustrated.
The examples show that no exact distinctions of all circumstantial participles are possible, as many express various relations at the same time. See 823.

div2.head: Genitive Absolute.
div2.p:
When a circumstantial participle (832-846) belongs to a substantive which is not grammatically connected with the main construction of the sentence, both the substantive and the participle generally stand in the genitive, in the construction called the genitive absolute. E.g.
*ou)/ tis e)meu= zw=ntos soi\ barei/as xei=ras e)poi/sei, no one while I live shall lay heavy hands upon you. Il. i. 88.
*tau=t' e)pra/xqh *ko/nwnos me\n strathgou=ntos, *eu)ago/rou de\ tou=to parasxo/ntos kai\ th=s duna/mews th\n plei/sthn paraskeua/santos these were accomplished while Conon was general, and after Evagoras had thus supplied him, etc. ISOC. ix. 56.
*fobou=mai mh\, prosdecame/nwn tw=n nu=n a)nqesthko/twn au)tw=| kai\ mia=| gnw/mh| pa/ntwn filippisa/ntwn, ei)s th\n *)attikh\n e)/lqwsin a)mfo/teroi DEM. xviii. 176 : see xix. 50 (present and perfect).
*)afi/keto deu=ro to\ ploi=on, gno/ntwn tw=n *kefallh/nwn a)ntipra/ttontos tou/tou . . . kataplei=n the Cephallenians having determined to sail in, although this man opposed it. Id. xxxii. 14.
*)aqhnai/wn de\ to\ au)to\ tou=to paqo/ntwn, diplasi/an a)\n th\n du/namin ei)ka/zesqai ( oi)=mai ), i.e.if the Athenians should ever suffer this same thing, etc. THUC. i. 10.
*(/olhs ga\r th=s po/lews e)pitrepome/nhs tw=| strathgw=|, mega/la ta/ te a)gaqa\ katorqou=ntos au)tou= kai\ ta\ kaka\ diamarta/nontos ei)ko\s gi/gnesqai XEN. Mem. iii. 1, 3.

The genitive absolute was probably used at first to express time (present or past according to the tense), and afterwards the other circumstantial relations, cause, condition, concession, etc. The construction is most fully developed in Attic prose, especially in the Orators.See Spiker in Jour. Phil. vi. pp. 310-343, on The Genitive Absolute in the Attic Orators.

A participle sometimes stands alone in the genitive absolute, when a noun or pronoun can easily be supplied from the context, or when some general word like a)nqrw/pwn or pragma/twn is understood. E.g. *oi( de\ pole/mioi, prosio/ntwn, te/ws me\n h(su/xazon, but the enemy, as they (men before mentioned) came on, for a time kept quiet. XEN. An. v. 4, 16. So e)pagome/nwn au)tou/s, when they were called in (when people called them in), THUC. i. 3. *ou(/tw d' e)xo/ntwn, ei)ko\s, k.t.l., and things being so (sc. pragma/twn), etc. XEN. An. iii. 2. 10. *ou)k e)caitou/menos, ou)k *)amfiktuonika\s di/kas e)pago/ntwn, ou)k e)paggellome/nwn, ou)damw=s e)gw\ prode/dwka th\n ei)s u(ma=s eu)/noian. DEM. xviii. 322. (Here the vague idea they is understood with e)pago/ntwn and e)paggellome/nwn.) So polemou/ntwn, PLAT. Rep. 557 E.

So when the participle denotes a state of the weather; as u(/ontos pollw=|, when it was raining heavily, XEN. Hell. i. 1, 16. In such cases the participle is masculine, *dio/s being understood. See
AR. Nub. 370, u(/onta ; and Il. xii. 25, u(=e d' a)/ra *zeu/s.

A passive participle may stand in the genitive absolute with a clause introduced by o(/ti. If the subject of such a clause is plural, or if there are several subjects, the participle itself may be plural, by a kind of attraction. E.g. *safw=s dhlwqe/ntos o(/ti e)n tai=s nausi\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn ta\ pra/gmata e)ge/neto, it having been clearly shown, that, etc. THUC. i. 74. *)esaggelqe/ntwn o(/ti *foi/nissai nh=es e)p' au)tou\s ple/ousin, it having been announced, that, etc. Id. i. 116.So XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 18 ; vi. 2, XEN. Cyr. 19.

The genitive absolute is regularly used only when a new subject is introduced into the sentence (847) and not when the participle can be joined with any substantive already belonging to the construction. Yet this principle is sometimes violated, in order to make the participial clause more prominent and to express its relation (time, cause, etc.) with greater emphasis. E.g. *diabebhko/tos h)/dh *perikle/ous, h)gge/lqh au)tw=| o(/ti *me/gara a)fe/sthke, when Pericles had already crossed over, it was announced to him that Megara had revolted. THUC. i. 114.
So sometimes in Latin, but generally with difference in meaning: as Galliam Italiamque tentari se absente nolebat, CAES. Bell. Civ. i. 29.

div2.head: Accusative Absolute.
div2.p: The participle of an impersonal verb stands in the accusative absolute, in the neuter singular, with or without an infinitive, when other participles with their subjects would stand in the genitive absolute.

Such are e)co/n, de/on, paro/n, prosh=kon, pre/pon, pare/xon, me/lon, metame/lon, dokou=n, do/can, and the like; also passive participles used impersonally (as prostaxqe/n, ei)rhme/non, dedogme/non); and such expressions as a)du/naton o)/n, it being impossible, composed of an adjective and o)/n; also tuxo/n, perchance. E.g.

*oi( d' ou) bohqh/santes de/on u(giei=s a)ph=lqon; and did those who brought no aid when it was necessary escape safe and sound? PLAT. Alcib. i. 115B. *(apla=s de\ lu/pas e)co
 (sc. fe/rein), ou)k oi)/sw dipla=s. I. T. EUR. 688. *pare/xon de\ th=s *)asi/hs pa/shs a)/rxein eu)pete/ws, a)/llo ti ai(rh/sesqe; HDT. v. 49. *eu)= de\ parasxo/n, and when an opportunity offers. THUC. i. 120. *ou) prosh=kon, improperly. Id. iv. 95. *sundo/can tw=| patri\ kai\ th=| mhtri\, gamei= th
 *kuaca/rou qugate/ra. XEN. Cyr. viii. 5, 28. *ei)rhme/non ku/rion ei)=nai o(/ ti a)
 to\ plh=qos tw=n cumma/xwn yhfi/shtai. THUC. v. 30.So dedogme/non, id. i. 125; gegramme/non, THUC. v. 56; and prostetagme/non, Leg. 902 D. *kai\ e)nqe/nde pa/lin, prostaxqe/n moi u(po\ tou= dh/mou *me/nwna a)/gein ei)s *(ellh/sponton, w)|xo/mhn. L. DEM. 12. *parekeleu/onto/ te, a)du/naton o)
 e)n nukti\ a)/llw| tw| shmh=nai. THUC. vii. 44. *)/egwg), e)/fh o( *ku=ros, oi)=mai, a(/ma me
 sunagoreuo/ntwn h(mw=n, a(/ma de\ kai\ ai)sxro
 o)
 to\ a)ntile/gein, k.t.l. XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 20. (See 876.) *)antipareskeua/zeto e)rrwme/nws, w(s ma/xhs e)/ti deh=son, on the ground that there would still be need of a battle. Ib. vi. 1, Ib. 26. *oi( de\ tria/konta, w(s e)co
 h)/dh au)toi=s turannei=n a)dew=s, proei=pon, k.t.l., i.e. thinking that it was now in their power, etc. Id. Hell. ii. 4, Id. Hell. 1.
Rarely the infinitive in the accusative absolute has to/; as ai)sxro\n o)\n to\ a)ntile/gein, XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 20 (above): so v. 1, XEN. Cyr. 13; PLAT. Rep. 521 A, PLAT. Rep. 604 C.

Even the participles of personal verbs sometimes stand with their nouns in the accusative absolute, in all genders and numbers, if they are preceded by w(s or w(/sper (864; 867). E.g. *dio\ kai\ tou\s ui(ei=s oi( pate/res a)po\ tw=n ponhrw=n a)nqrw/pwn ei)/rgousin, w(s th
 me
 tw=n xrhstw=n o(mili/an a)/skhsin ou)=san th=s a)reth=s, th
 de\ tw=n ponhrw=n kata/lusin (sc. ou)=san). XEN. Mem. i. 2, 20. *fi/lous ktw=ntai w(s bohqw=n deo/menoi, tw=n d' a)delfw=n a)melou=sin, w(/sper e)k politw=n me
 gignome/nous fi/lous, e)c a)delfw=n de\ ou) gignome/nous, as if friends were made from fellow-citizens, and were not made from brothers. Ib. ii. 3, Ib. 3. *(ws tou\s *boiwtou\s th
 tw=n o)noma/twn su/nqesin tw=n *dhmosqe/nous a)gaph/sontas. AESCHIN. iii. 142. *(/wsper u(ma=s a)gnoou=ntas. Ib. 189. *me/giston ou(/tw diakei=sqai ta\s gnw/mas u(mw=n, w(s e(/kaston e(ko/nta proqu/mws o(/ ti a)
 de/h| poih/sonta. DEM. xiv. 14.

The accusative absolute used personally without w(s or w(/sper is very rare. It occurs chiefly with neuter participles which are regularly impersonal. E.g. *prosh=kon au)tw=| tou= klh/rou me/ros o(/son per e)moi/. ISAE. v. 12. *tau=ta de\ gino/mena, pe/nqea mega/la tou\s *ai)gupti/ous katalamba/nei. HDT. ii. 66. *)/hdh a)mfote/rois me
 dokou=n a)naxwrei=n, kurwqe
 de\ ou)de
, nukto/s te e)pigenome/nhs, oi( me
 *makedo/nes e)xw/roun e)p' oi)/kou. THUC. iv. 125. *do/canta de\ tau=ta kai\ peranqe/nta ta\ stra- teu/mata a)ph=lqe. XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 19. *do/can h(mi=n tau=ta occurs in PLAT. Prot. 314 C, where we may supply poiei=n, or do/can tau=ta may represent e)/doce tau=ta. So XEN. An. iv. 1, 13.

div2.head: Adverbs connected with the Circumstantial Participle.
div2.p:
The adverbs to/te, h)/dh (to/te h)/dh), e)ntau=qa, ei)=ta, e)/peita, and ou(/tws are often joined to the verb of the sentence in which the temporal participle stands, to give greater emphasis to the temporal relation. E.g. *)eke/leuen au)to
 sundiaba/nta, e)/peita ou(/tws a)palla/ttesqai, he commanded that, after he had joined them in crossing, he should then retire as he proposed XEN. An. vii. 1, 4. *peiqome/nwn de\ tw=n *sami/wn kai\ sxo/ntwn th
 *za/gklhn, e)nqau=ta oi( *zagklai=oi e)boh/qeon au)th=|. HDT. vi. 23. *)apofugw
 de kai\ tou/tous, strathgo\s ou(/tw *)aqhnai/wn a)pede/xqh, and having escaped these also, he was then (under these circumstances) chosen general of the Athenians. Id. vi. 104.
*ei)=ta, e)/peita, and ou(/tws sometimes refer in the same way to a participle expressing opposition or limitation; in which case they may be translated by nevertheless, after all. E.g.

*pa/ntwn d' a)topw/tato/n e)sti, thlikau/thn a)nelo/ntas marturi/an ou(/tws oi)/esqai dei=n ei)kh=| pisteu/esqai par' u(mi=n, it is most absurd of all that, although they have destroyed so important a piece of evidence, they should after all think, etc. DEM. xxviii. 5. *deina\ me/nt' a)\n pa/qois, ei) *)aqh/naze a)fiko/menos, ou(= th=s *(ella/dos plei/sth e)sti\n e)cousi/a tou= le/gein, e)/peita su\ e)ntau=qa tou/tou mo/nos a)tuxh/sais, if, although you are come to Athens, you should after all be the only one to fail in obtaining this. PLAT. Gorg. 461 E.

*ou(/tws, dia\ tou=to, and dia\ tau=ta sometimes refer in the same way to a participle denoting a cause. E.g. *nomi/zwn a)mei/nonas kai\ krei/ttous pollw=n barba/rwn u(ma=s ei)=nai, dia\ tou=to prose/labon, because I believed, etc. XEN. An. i. 7, 3. *(uma=s de\ h(mei=s h(ghsa/menoi i(kanou\s gnw=nai, ou(/tw parela/bomen. PLAT. Lach. 178 B.

The adverbs a(/ma, metacu/, eu)qu/s (Ionic i)qe/ws), au)ti/ka, a)/rti, and e)cai/fnhs are often connected (in position and in sense) with the temporal participle, although grammatically they qualify the verb of the sentence. E.g. *(/ama proiw
 e)peskopei=to ei)/ ti dunato
 ei)/h tou\s polemi/ous a)sqeneste/rous poiei=n, as he advanced, he looked at the same time to see whether it was possible, etc. XEN. Cyr. v. 2, 22. *(/ama katalabo/ntes proseke/ato/ sfi, as soon as they had overtaken them, they pressed hard upon them. HDT. ix. 57. *nekw\s metacu\ o)ru/sswn e)pau/sato, manthi/ou e)mpodi/ou genome/nou, Necho stopped while digging (the canal), etc. Id. ii. 158. *pollaxou= dh/ me e)pe/sxe le/gonta metacu/, it often checked me while speaking. PLAT. Ap. 40 B. *)epipo/nw| a)skh/sei eu)qu\s ne/oi o)/ntes to\ a)ndrei=on mete/rxontai, by toilsome discipline, even while they are still young, etc. THUC. ii. 39. *tw=| deciw=| ke/ra| eu)qu\s a)pobebhko/ti oi( *kori/nqioi e)pe/keinto, the Corinthians pressed upon the right wing, as soon as it was disembarked. Id. iv. 43. *)arca/menos eu)qu\s kaqistame/nou, beginning as soon as it (the war) broke out. Id. i. 1. *dio/nuson le/gousi w(s au)ti/ka geno/menon e)s to
 mhro
 e)nerra/yato *zeu/s, they say of Dionysus that, as soon as he was born, Zeus sewed him into his thigh. HDT. ii. 146. *th
 yuxh
 qewrou=nta e)cai/fnhs a)poqano/ntos e(ka/stou, viewing the soul of each one the moment that he is dead. PLAT. Gorg. 523 E. *kai\ au)tou= metacu\ tau=ta le/gontos o( *kleini/as e)/tuxen a)pokrina/menos. Id. Euthyd. 275 E.

The participle expressing opposition, limitation, or concession is often strengthened by kai/per or kai/ (after a negative, by ou)de/ or mhde/, with or without pe/r), or by kai\ tau=ta, and that too. *(/omws, nevertheless, may be connected with the participle (like a(/ma, etc. in 858), belonging, however, grammatically to the leading verb. E.g. *(/ektora kai\ memaw=ta ma/xhs sxh/sesqai o)i/w. Il. ix. 655.
*)epoiktei/rw de/ nin du/sthnon e)/mpas, kai/per o)/nta dusmenh=, although he is my enemy. SOPH. Aj. 122.
*ou)k a)
 prodoi/hn, ou)de/ per pra/sswn kakw=s. EUR. Ph. 1624. *gunaiki\ pei/qou mhde\ ta)lhqh\ klu/wn (= mhde\ h)
 ta)lhqh= klu/h|s). Id. Fr. 443. *pei/qou gunaici\, kai/per ou) ste/rgwn o(/mws, although you are not fond of them. Sept. 712. (Here o(/mws, qualifies pei/qou; although, as usual, it is joined with the participle for emphasis.) *)adikei=s o(/ti a)/ndra h(mi=n to
 spoudaio/taton diafqei/reis gela=n a)napei/qwn, kai\ tau=ta ou(/tw pole/mion o)/nta tw=| ge/lwti. XEN. Cyr. ii. 2, 16.

In Homer, the two parts of kai/ . . . per are generally separated by the participle, or by some emphatic word connected with it. *kai/ is here very often omitted, so that pe/r stands alone in the sense of although. Both of these uses are found also in tragedy. E.g. *to
 me
 e)/peit' ei)/ase, kai\ a)xnu/meno/s per e(tai/rou, kei=sqai. Il. viii. 125. *kai\ kratero/s per e)w
, mene/tw trita/th| e)ni\ moi/rh|. Il. xv. 195. *te/tlaqi, mh=ter e)mh\, kai\ a)na/sxeo khdome/nh per, mh/ se fi/lhn per e)ou=san e)n o)fqalmoi=sin i)/dwmai qeinome/nhn: to/te d' ou)/ ti dunh/somai a)xnu/meno/s per xraismei=n. Il. i. 586.

*ka)gw/ s' i(knou=mai, kai\ gunh/ per ou)=s' o(/mws EUR. Or. 680.
*ta/fon ga\r au)th\ kai\ kataskafa\s e)gw\, gunh/ per ou)=sa, tw=|de mhxanh/somai Sept. 1037. So pe/r alone in Herodotus, as a)skeuh/s per e)w/n, iii. 131 .

*kai/toi was very seldom used like kai/per with the participle, its only regular use being with finite verbs. E.g. *ou)de/ moi e)mmele/ws to\ *pitta/keion ne/metai, kai/toi sofou= para\ fwto\s ei)rhme/non. Fr. 5, Fr. 8 (ap. PLAT. Prot. 339 C). *(ikana/ moi nomi/zw ei)rh=sqai, kai/toi polla/ ge paralipw/n. LYS. xxxi. 34.

*(/ate, and oi(=a or oi(=on, as, inasmuch as, are used to emphasise a participle denoting the cause or ground of an action. Here the cause assigned is stated merely on the authority of the speaker or writer. (See 864.) E.g. *(o de\ *ku=ros, a(/te pai=s w)\n kai\ filo/kalos kai\ filo/timos, h(/deto th=| stolh=|, but Cyrus, inasmuch as he was a child (as being a child), etc. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 3. *(/ate xro/nou e)gginome/nou suxnou=, as a long time intervened. HDT. i. 190: in the same chapter, oi(=a de\ e)cepista/menoi. So a(/te lhfqe/ntwn, THUC. vii. 85. *ma/la de\ xalepw=s poreuo/menoi, oi(=a dh\ e)n nukti/ te kai\ fo/bw| a)pio/ntes, ei)s *ai)go/sqena a)fiknou=ntai, inasmuch as they were departing by night, etc. XEN. Hell. vi. 4, 26. *oi(=on de\ dia\ xro/nou a)figme/nos, a)sme/nws h)=|a e)pi\ ta\s sunh/qeis diatriba/s. PLAT. Charm. 153 A.

In Herodotus, w(/ste is used in the sense of a(/te; as in i. 8, w(/ste tau=ta nomi/zwn, inasmuch as he believed this. So vi. 136, h)=n ga\r a)du/natos, w(/ste shpome/nou tou= mhrou=. In THUC. vii. 24, w(/ste (so the MSS.) ga\r tamiei/w| xrwme/nwn tw=n *)aqhnai/wn toi=s tei/xesin, Bekker wrote a(/te for w(/ste, and Stahl reads w(/sper.

*(ws may be prefixed to participles denoting a cause or ground or a purpose, sometimes to other circumstantial participles. It shows that what is stated in the participle is stated as the thought or assertion of the subject of the leading verb, or as that of some other person prominent in the sentence, without implying that it is also the thought of the speaker or writer. E.g. *oi( me
 diw/kontes tou\s kaq' au(tou\s w(s pa/ntas nikw=ntes, oi( d' a(rpa/zontes w(s h)/dh pa/ntes nikw=ntes, one side pursuing those opposed to them, thinking that they were victorious over all; and the other side proceeding to plunder, thinking that they were all victorious. XEN. An. i. 10, 4. *th
 pro/fasin e)poiei=to w(s *pisi/das boulo/menos e)kbalei=n, he made his pretence as if he wished to drive out the Pisidians. Ib. i. 2, Ib. 1. *sullamba/nei *ku=ron w(s a)poktenw=n, he seizes Cyrus with the (avowed) object of putting him to death. Ib. i. 1, Ib. 3. *diabai/nei w(s a)mh/swn to
 si=ton. HDT. vi. 28. *oi( *)aqhnai=oi pareskeua/zonto w(s polemh/sontes, the Athenians prepared with the (avowed) intention of going to war. THUC. ii. 7. *to
 *perikle/a e)n ai)ti/a| ei)=xon w(s pei/santa sfa=s polemei=n kai\ di) e)kei=non tai=s cumforai=s peripeptwko/tes, they found fault with Pericles, on the ground that he had persuaded them to engage in the war, and that through him they had become involved in the calamities. Id. ii. 59. (Here Thucydides himself is not responsible for the statements in the participles, as he would be if w(s were omitted.) *)aganaktou=sin w(s mega/lwn tinw=n a)pesterhme/noi, they are indignant, because (as they allege) they have been deprived, etc. PLAT. Rep. 329 A. *basilei= xa/rin i)/sasin, w(s di) e)kei=non tuxou=sai th=s au)tonomi/as tau/ths, i.e. they thank him because (they believe) they have obtained this independence through him. ISOC. iv. 175. *(ws ga ei)do/twn peri\ w(=n e)pe/mfqhsan a)kou/ete, for you hear them as men who (you believe) know about what they were sent for. DEM. xix. 5.

*)/elege qarrei=n w(s katasthsome/nwn tou/twn ei)s to\ de/on, he bade them take courage, on the ground that these matters were about to be settled as they should be. XEN. An. i. 3, 8. *)ek de\ tou/twn eu)qu\s e)kh/rutton e)cie/nai pa/ntas *qhbai/ous, w(s tw=n tura/nnwn teqnew/twn, because (as they said) the tyrants were dead. Id. Hell. v. 4, Id. Hell. 9. *)apelogh/sato o(/ti ou)x w(s toi=s *(/ellhsi polemhso/ntwn sfw=n ei)/poi, that he said what he did, not because they intended to be at war with the Greeks. Id. An. v. 6, Id. An. 3.So w(s e)pibouleu/ontos *tissafe/rnous tai=s po/lesi, on the ground that T. was plotting, ib. i. 1, Id. An. 6. *(ws ou) prosoi/sontos (sc. e)mou=) ta\s xei=ras, . . . di/daske, since (as you may feel sure) I will not lay hands on you, teach me. Id. Mem. ii. 6, Id. Mem. 32. *(ws a)namenou=ntos kai\ ou)k a)poqanoume/nou (sc. e)mou=), ou(/tw paraskeua/zou, make your preparations in the idea that I shall remain and shall not die. Id. Cyr. viii. 4, Id. Cyr. 27. *nu=n de\, w(s ou(/tw e)xo/ntwn, stratih\n w(s ta/xista e)kpe/mpete. HDT. viii. 144.So w(s be/baion o)/n, THUC. i. 2; DEM. xviii. 207.

It is a mistake to suppose that w(s implies that the participle does not express the idea of the speaker or writer. It implies nothing whatever on this point, which is determined (if at all) by the context. The question whether the clause with w(s gives the real or the pretended opinion of the leading subject is also determined (if at all) by the context.
*(ws may also be used before participles standing in indirect discourse with verbs of knowing, etc. (see 916).

*(/wsper, as, as it were, with the participle denotes a comparison of the action of the verb with an assumed case. The expression may generally be translated by as if with a verb; but the participle is not felt to be conditional in Greek, as is shown by the negative ou) (not mh/). E.g. *)wrxou=nto w(/sper a)/llois e)pideiknu/menoi, they danced as if they were showing off to others (i.e. they danced, not really but in appearance showing off). XEN. An. v. 4, 34. *ti/ e)moi\ tou=to le/geis, w(/sper ou)k e)pi\ soi\ o)
 o(/ ti a)
 bou/lh| peri\ e)mou= le/gein; why do you say this to me, as if it were not in your power to say what you please about me? Id. Mem. ii. 6, Id. Mem. 36.In both these cases, there is a comparison between the action stated in the verb and dancing or speaking under circumstances stated in the participial clause. The if in our translation is a makeshift, which we find convenient in expressing the supposed case in a conditional form, which, however, is not the Greek form. The construction is the same as when w(/sper takes a noun, as to
 ki/ndunon parelqei=n e)poi/hsen w(/sper ne/fos, it caused the danger to pass by like a cloud, DEM. xviii. 188; only we can translate w(/sper ne/fos, but we could not translate w(/sper ne/fos o)/nta.

*(/wsper h)/dh safw=s ei)do/tes o(\ prakte/on e)sti
, ou)k e)qe/let' a)kou/ein, you are unwilling to hear, as if you already knew well what should be done. ISOC. viii. 9. *)aph/ntwn o)li/goi pro\s polla\s muria/das, w(/sper e)n a)llotri/ais yuxai=s me/llontes kinduneu/sein, as if they had been about to incur the risk with others' lives. Id. iv. 86. *th
 h(mi/seian ei)/lhfen, w(/sper pro\s to
 *di/a th
 xw/ran nemo/menos, a)ll' ou) pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous ta\s sunqh/kas poiou/menos, he has taken half (of the land) as if he were dividing the country with Zeus, and not making a treaty with men. Ib. 179. *pro\s toi=s a)/llois, w(/sper au)to\s a(plw=s kai\ met' eu)noi/as pa/ntas ei)rhkw\s tou\s lo/gous, fula/ttein e)me\ e)ke/leuen, as if he had himself spoken, etc. DEM. xviii. 276. *oi( *(/ellhnes ou(/tws h)gana/kthsan, w(/sper o(/lhs th=s *(ella/dos peporqhme/nhs, as if the whole of Greece had been laid waste. ISOC. x. 49.See Id. iv. 53, w(/sper ou) tou\s lo/gous o)/ntas, and XEN. An. iii. 1, 14 , XEN. An. v. 7, 24 ; Mem. ii. 3, Mem. 3; Oec. ii. 7.In PLAT. Ap. 35 A, we have w(/sper a)qana/twn e)some/nwn e)a
 u(mei=s au)tou\s mh\ a)poktei/nhte, i.e. as if they will be (like men who will be) immortal if you do not put them to death, where the future participle indicates that there is no condition (473).
The participle with w(/sper generally denotes attendant circumstances (843), sometimes manner (836).

*(/wsper, like any particle meaning as, can be followed by ei) and an actual condition, the apodosis of which it represents; as in w(/sper ei) paresta/teis, as (you would do) if you had lived near by, AESCH. Ag. 1201.A participle with w(/sper ei) seems to have hardly more conditional force than one with the simple w(/sper; as e)me\ w)/|xou katalipou=s' w(sperei\ prokei/menon, you went off and left me as if I had been laid out, AR. Eccl. 537.See w(/sper ei) nomi/zwn, DEM. xxx. 7.

When a real condition is expressed, we generally have w(/sper a)
 ei), as in w(/sper a)
 ei)/ tis ai)tiw=|to, DEM. xviii. 194.But when w(/sper a)
 ei) (or w(speranei/) is followed by a participle or a noun without a verb, it is hardly possible that either of the verbs which were originally understood with a)/n and ei) (227) was felt as implied in the language as we find it: indeed, it would seldom be possible to supply an actual verb. Thus in o(moi/ws dieporeu/qhsan w(speranei\ propempo/menoi, they proceeded as if they were under escort, ISOC. iv. 148, and in w(speranei\ h(gou/menoi, as if they believed, DEM. xviii. 214, w(/sper alone would have given essentially the same sense. So in e)fobh/qh w(speranei\ pai=s, PLAT. Gorg. 479 A, w(/sper pai=s, like a child, would probably have expressed the whole idea with less emphasis.

div2.head: Remarks on w(/sper and w(s with the Participle.
div2.p:
1. In Homer w(/s te, w(s ei), and w(s ei)/ te are used in a sense approaching that of w(/sper in Attic Greek. *(ws here always expresses a comparison, and when ei) is added the form must originally have included a condition; but, even in Homer, the force of ei) had become so weakened that it is hardly possible that any actual verb was felt to be implied in the expression. E.g. *)axaiw=n oi)=ton a)ei/deis, w(/s te/ pou h)\ au)to\s parew
 h)\ a)/llou a)kou/sas, you sing as if you had been present yourself or had heard from another. Od. viii. 490. *ki/rkh| e)ph/ica w(/s te kta/menai meneai/nwn, I rushed upon Circe as if I were eager to kill her. Od. x. 322: so x. 295. *to
 d' o( ge/rwn e)u\ e)/trefen, a)mfagapa/zomenos w(s ei)/ q' e(o
 ui(o
 e)o/nta, welcoming him as (if he had been) his own son. Il. xvi. 191. *po/ll' o)lofuro/menoi w(s ei) qanato/nde kio/nta, as (if he were) going to death. Il. xxiv. 327. *ti/s nu/ se toia/d' e)/recen, w(s ei)/ ti kako
 r(e/zousan e)nwph=|, as if you were doing any evil openly. Il. v. 373. *kapno\s gi/gnetai e)c au)th=s, w(s ei) puro\s ai)qome/noio, as (if) when a fire is burning. Il. xxii. 149; so Od. xix. 39.

2. In Homer w(s ei) may have a noun without a participle. Here the comparative force is specially clear, as the difficulty of supplying a verb with ei) is specially great: see m' a)su/fhlon e)/recen w(s ei)/ tin' a)ti/mhton metana/sthn, he made me of no account, like some dishonoured stranger, Il. ix. 648, Il. xvi. 59.So w(s ei)/ te kata\ r(o/on, as if down stream, Od. xiv. 254; w(/s te peri\ yuxh=s, as it were for my life, Od. ix. 423.See Lange, Partikel EI, pp. 235-243. I cannot follow Lange (p. 241), in making the Attic w(s with the participle the natural successor of the Homeric w(s ei) with the participle.

The weak conditional force that appears in the Homeric w(s ei) with a participle or a noun (869) helps to explain the perhaps still weaker condition of w(/sper ei) or w(/sper a)\n ei) in Attic Greek (868).

The very few cases of w(s with the participle in Homer do not indicate that w(s had yet begun to develop its later force (864). See Od. xvi. 21, pa/nta ku/sen perifu\s, w(s e)k qana/toio fugo/nta, he kissed him all over, like one escaped from death, though we might translate since he felt that T. had escaped from death. No such force is possible, however, in Il. xxiii. 430, w(s ou)k a)i/onti e)oikw/s, appearing like one who heard not.
Herodotus uses w(/ste with the participle in the sense of a(/te, although he has w(s with the participle in the Attic sense (864). See examples under 863.

*(ws ei) (or w(sei/) and w(s ei)/ te appear occasionally in Attic poetry with nouns or adjectives in their Homeric sense. So math\r w(sei/ tis pista/, like some faithful mother, SOPH. El. 234; ptu/sas w(sei/ te dusmenh=, spurning her as an enemy, Ant. 653.

*(/wsper with the participle occasionally seems to have the same force as a(/te or oi(=on; as in EUR. Hipp. 1307, o( d' w(/sper w)\n di/kaios ou)k e)fe/speto lo/gois, inasmuch as he was just, etc. Or is the meaning here he, like a just man?

In PLAT. Rep. 330 E, h)/toi u(po\ th=s tou= gh/rws a)sqenei/as h)\ kai\ w(/sper h)/dh e)ggute/rw w)\n tw=n e)kei= ma=llo/n ti kaqora=| au)ta/, the same force is generally given to w(/sper. But it may have the comparative force: either because of the feebleness of old age, or perhaps (feeling) like one who is nearer the other world, he takes a more careful view of it,—a genitive of cause with u(po/ and a participle of circumstance being united under h)/toi and h)/.

div2.head: Omission of w)/n.
div2.p: The participle w)/n is sometimes omitted, leaving a predicate adjective or noun standing by itself.

(With nouns.) *eu)qu\s, oi(=a dh\ pai=s (sc. w)\n) fu/sei filo/storgos, h)spa/zeto au)to/n, as he was by nature an affectionate child. XEN. Cyr. i. 3, 2. *au)tou\s ei)s th\n politei/an ou) paradeco/meqa, a(/te turanni/dos u(mnhta/s (sc. o)/ntas), since they sing the praises of tyranny. PLAT. Rep. 568 B.

2. Without the above mentioned particles (875, 1), w)/n is rarely omitted, and probably only in poetry. E.g. *tou\s o)/rnis, w(=n u(fhghtw=n (sc. o)/ntwn) e)gw\ ktanei=n e)/mellon pate/ra to\n e)mo/n, the birds, by whose guidance, etc. SOPH. O.T. 966. So 1260, and O. C. 1588. *noei=s qa/ptein sf), a)po/rrhton po/lei (sc. o)/n); do you think of burying him, when it is forbidden to the city? Id. Ant. 44.

3. The adjectives e(kw/n, willing, and a)/kwn, unwilling, omit w)/n like participles. E.g. *)emou= me\n ou)x e(ko/ntos, against my will. SOPH. Aj. 455.
*)ae/kontos e)mei=o. Il. i. 301. *niki/an kai\ *dhmosqe/nhn a)/kontos tou= *guli/ppou a)pe/sfacan. THUC. vii. 86. So AESCH. Prom. 771. *para\ tou/twn ou)k a)/n pote la/bois lo/gon ou)/te e(ko/ntwn ou)/te a)ko/ntwn. PLAT. Theaet. 180 C.

4. A predicate adjective or noun sometimes stands without w)/n, when it is connected by a conjunction to a participle in the same construction. E.g. *ti/ me ou)k o)lome/nan u(bri/zeis, a)ll' e)pi/fanton; why do you insult me when I am not yet dead, but am before your eyes? SOPH. Ant. 839. *lo/gois de\ sumba\s kai\ qew=n a)nw/motos. EUR. Med. 737: so EUR. Or. 457. *lu/tra fe/rwn kai\ i(ke/ths (sc. w)
) tw=n *)axaiw=n. PLAT. Rep. 393 D. So HDT. i. 60 (a)polei/pousa . . . kai\ eu)eidh/s), and 65 (a)delfide/ou me
 . . . basileu/ontos de/); THUC. iii. 82 (ou)k a)
 e)xo/ntwn pro/fasin ou)d' e(toi/mwn). See other examples in Kühner, vol. ii. § 491.

div2.head: Combinations of Circumstantial Participles.
div2.p:
As the participle in the genitive or accusative absolute denotes the same relations (time, cause, etc.) as the circumstantial participle in its ordinary construction (833-845), both may be used in the same sentence and be connected by conjunctions. When several participles denoting these relations occur in any sentence, those which belong to substantives already connected with the main construction agree with these in case, while those which refer to some new subjects stand with these in the genitive absolute; any which are impersonal standing in the accusative absolute. E.g. *oi( me
 *(/ellhnes strafe/ntes pareskeua/zonto w(s tau/th| prosio/ntos (sc. tou= basile/ws) kai\ deco/menoi, they prepared themselves with a view to his (the King's) coming up and to receiving him. XEN. An. i. 10, 6. *kai\ pa/nta diapraca/menos e)n th=| e)kklhsi/a| (*kle/wn), kai\ yhfisame/nwn *)aqhnai/wn au)tw=| to
 plou=n, tw=n te e)n *pu/lw| strathgw=n e(/na proselo/menos, th
 a)nagwgh
 dia\ ta/xous e)poiei=to. THUC. iv. 29. *)alkibia/dhs toi=s *peloponnhsi/ois u(/poptos w)
, kai\ a)p' au)tw=n a)fikome/nhs e)pistolh=s w(/st' a)poktei=nai, u(poxwrei= para\ *tissafe/rnhn. Id. viii. 45. *th=s ga e)mpori/as ou)k ou)/shs ou)d' e)pimignu/ntes a)dew=s a)llh/lois ou)/te kata\ gh=n ou)/te dia\ qalasshs, nemo/menoi/ te ta\ e(autw=n e(/kastoi o(/son a)pozh=n kai\ periousi/an xrhma/twn ou)k e)/xontes ou)de\ gh=n futeu/ontes, a)dhlo
 o)
 o(po/te tis e)pelqw
 kai\ a)teixi/stwn a(/ma o)/ntwn a)/llos a)fairh/setai, th=s te kaq' h(me/ran a)nagkai/ou trofh=s pantaxou= a)
 h(gou/menoi e)pikratei=n, ou) xalepw=s a)pani/stanto.
