Id. i. 2.Here ou)/shs and e)pimignu/ntes belong to the leading clause; nemo/menoi, e)/xontes, and futeu/ontes— corresponding to h(gou/menoi—are in the second line; a)/dhlon o)/n depends on nemo/menoi, etc., and introduces the indirect question o(po/te . . . a)fairh/setai, which contains e)pelqw/n and a)teixi/stwn o)/ntwn as circumstantial participles.

div2.head: Supplementary Participle.
div2.p: The supplementary participle completes the idea expressed by a verb, by stating that to which its action relates. It often approaches very near the use of the object infinitive. It may belong to either the subject or the object of the verb and agree with it in case. E.g. *pau/ome/n se le/gonta, we stop you from speaking; pauo/meqa le/gontes, we cease speaking.

The supplementary participle has two uses. In one of these it corresponds to the infinitive in indirect discourse, with its tenses representing the same tenses of the direct form; and in the other it corresponds to the object infinitive in other constructions, so far as it approaches the infinitive at all in meaning. (See 746.)

Compare pau/ome/n se le/gonta, we stop you from speaking, with dei/knusi/ se le/gonta ta)lhqh=, he shows that you speak the truth; and compare both with kwlu/ome/n se le/gein, we prevent you from speaking, and fhsi/ se le/gein ta)lhqh=, he says that you speak the truth.

div2.head: I. Not in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: I. The participle may be used with verbs signifying to begin, to continue, to endure, to persevere, to cease, to stop (i.e. cause to cease), and to permit or put up with. E.g.

*)egw\ d' h)=rxon xalepai/nwn, and I was the first to be angry. Il. ii. 378. *)/arcomai a)po\ th=s i)atrikh=s le/gwn, I will begin my speech with the art of medicine. Symp. 186B. *au(/th h( oi)ki/h diatele/ei mou/nh e)leuqe/rh e)ou=sa *perse/wn, this house continues to be the only free one among the Persians. HDT. iii. 83.So XEN. An. iv. 3, 2 ; DEM. xviii. 1. *ou)k a)ne/comai zw=sa, I shall not endure life. EUR. Hipp. 354. *)ane/xesqai/ tinwn e)n tai=s e)kklhsi/as lego/ntwn, to endure certain men saying. DEM. ix. 6.So a)ne/cei le/gontos e)mou= peri\ tou/twn; will you allow me to say? PLAT. Rep. 613 C. With the accusative: kai\ tau=t' *)ia/swn pai=das e)cane/cetai pa/sxontas; and will Jason endure to have his children suffer this? EUR. Med. 74. *lipare/ete me/nontes, persevere and hold your ground. HDT. ix. 45. *oi( d' e)karte/roun pro\s ku=ma lakti/zontes. I. T. EUR. 1395. *trw=as d' ou) lh/cw e)nari/zwn, I will not stop slaying Trojans. Il. xxi. 224. *pau=sai le/gousa, stop talking. EUR. Hipp. 706; so 474. *th\n filosofi/an pau=son tau=ta le/gousan, stop Philosophy from talking in this style. PLAT. Gorg. 482 A. A. *)ekei/noisi tau=ta poieu=si ou)k e)pitrepte/a e)sti/, we must not allow them to act in this way. HDT. ix. 58. *(h po/lis au)toi=s ou)k e)pitre/yei parabai/nousi to\n no/mon, the city will not put up with their transgression of the law. ISOC. xii. 170.

The poets sometimes have the participle with tolma/w and tla/w, to endure, to have courage, and with me/nw, to await, which usually take the infinitive. E.g. *)eto/lma ballo/menos. Od. xxiv. 162. *to/lma d' e)rw=sa, have the courage to love. EUR. Hipp. 476. *tlh=nai/ se drw=san a(\n e)gw\ paraine/sw, that you take courage to do what I shall advise. SOPH. El. 943.So praqe/nta tlh=nai, endured to be sold, AESCH. Ag. 1041; spei/ras e)/tla, was bold enough to plant, Sept. 754. *)/ofra me/noien nosth/santa a)/nakta, that they might await the king's return. Il. xiii. 38 (compare iv. 247, me/nete *trw=as e)lqe/men; ).
For the aorist participle in the last three examples, see 148.

II. The participle may be used with many verbs which denote a state of the feelings, as those signifying to repent, to be weary, to be pleased, displeased, satisfied, angry, troubled, or ashamed. E.g.

*meteme/lonto ta\s sponda\s ou) deca/menoi, they repented that they had not accepted the peace. THUC. iv. 27. *tou\s desmw/tas meteme/lonto a)podedwko/tes, they repented of having returned the prisoners. Id. v. 35. *ei) meteme/lhse/ oi( to\n *(ellh/sponton mastigw/santi, whether he repented that he had scourged the Hellespont. HDT. vii. 54. *)ea/n tis mh\ a)poka/mnh| zhtw=n, provided one is not weary of seeking. PLAT. Men. 81 D. *tw=| me/n r(a xai=ron nosth/santi, they rejoiced in his return. Hom. Od. xix. 463: so Hom. Il. xviii. 259. *timw/menoi xai/rousin, they delight to be honoured. EUR. Hipp. 8. *xai/rousin e)cetazome/nois toi=s oi)ome/nois me\n ei)=nai sofoi=s ou)=si d' ou)/, i.e. they delight in having them examined. PLAT. Ap. 33 C. In poetry xai/rw may have the accusative: tou\s ga\r eu)sebei=s qeoi\ qnh/|skontas ou) xai/rousi, for the Gods do not rejoice in the death of the pious. EUR. Hipp. 1340.
*se\ me\n eu)= pra/ssont' e)pixai/rw SOPH. Aj. 136.
*file/w with nominative: filei=s de\ drw=s' au)to\ sfo/dra, and you are very fond of doing it. AR. Pl. 645. *ou) ga/r ti/s toi a)nia=tai pareo/nti. Hom. Od. xv. 335. *th=s *ai)oli/dos xalepw=s e)/feren a)pesterhme/nos, he took it hard that he was deprived of Aeolis. XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 13. *(upo\ smikrote/rwn timw/menoi a)gapw=sin, they are content to be honoured by smaller men. PLAT. Rep. 475 B. *)elegxo/menoi h)/xqonto, they were vexed at being exposed. XEN. Mem. i. 2, 47. *tou\s froni/mous a)ganaktei=n a)poqnh/|skontas pre/pei, it is right to be indignant when the wise die. PLAT. Phaed. 62 E. *(ws misw= s' e)/xwn. EUR. Supp. 1108. *ou) nemesw= *)agame/mnoni o)tru/nonti ma/xesqai *)axaiou/s. Il. iv. 413. *)adikou/menoi ma=llon o)rgi/zontai h)\ biazo/menoi. THUC. i. 77. *tou=to ou)k ai)sxu/nomai le/gwn, I say this without shame (see 903, THUC. 1). XEN. Cyr. v. 1, 21.
*ai)/desai pate/ra prolei/pwn SOPH. Aj. 506.
*nikw/menos lo/goisin ou)k a)nai/nomai, I am not sorry (non piget) to be overcome by your words. AESCH. Ag. 583.
*eu)= dra/sas de/ s' ou)k a)nai/nomai, I do not regret that I helped you. EUR. H.F. 1235.
*qanou=sa ou)k a)nai/nomai, I do not regret my death (about to come). I. A. 1503.
*)anai/nomai to\ gh=ras u(mw=n ei)sorw=n, I am troubled at the sight, etc. Bacch. 251. (*)anai/nomai, refuse, takes the infinitive: see AESCH. Ag. 1652.)
Most of the participles of 881 denote a cause or ground of action, and might be placed under 838. (See 823.)

III. The participle with verbs signifying to find, to detect, or to represent, denotes an act or state in which a person or thing is found, detected, or represented. E.g. *eu(=ren d' eu)ru/opa *kroni/dhn a)/ter h(/menon a)/llwn, she found the son of Kronos sitting apart. Il. i. 498.So i. 27. *(o de\ kh=ruc a)fiko/menos eu(=re tou\s a)/ndras diefqarme/nous, the herald, when he came, found the men already put to death. THUC. ii. 6. *)\hn ga eu(reqh=| le/gwn soi\ tau)/t), e)/gwg' a)
 e)kpefeugoi/hn pa/qos, if he shall be found to tell the same story as you, etc. SOPH. O.T. 839. *katalamba/nousi th
 *poti/daian kai\ ta)/lla a)festhko/ta, they find Potidaea and the other towns in revolt. THUC. i. 59. *kako/s g' w)
 e)s fi/lous a(li/sketai, he is detected in baseness. EUR. Med. 84. *)ea
 a(lw=|s e)/ti tou=to pra/ttwn, a)poqanei=, if you are ever caught doing this again, you shall die. PLAT. Ap. 29 C. So PLAT. Rep. 389 D. *basile/as pepoi/hke tou\s e)n *(/aidou to
 a)ei\ xro/non timwroume/nous, he has represented kings in Hades as suffering punishment without ceasing. Gorg. 525 D. *)/aklhton e)poi/hsen (*(/omhros) e)lqo/nta to
 *mene/lewn e)pi\ th
 qoi/nhn. Symp. 174C.
It is sometimes difficult to distinguish this use of the participle from that of indirect discourse, especially with eu(ri/skw. (See 904.)

IV. The participle (not in indirect discourse) with verbs signifying to hear, learn (hear of), see, or perceive denotes the act which is perceived or heard of (not, as in indirect discourse, the fact that the act occurs). Here the participle approaches very nearly the ordinary object infinitive in its use, and the tenses of the participle differ only as the same tenses of the infinitive differ in such constructions, the aorist not denoting past time (148). E.g. *baru\ de\ stena/xontos a)/kousen, and he heard him groaning heavily. Od. viii. 95. *ei) de\ fqegcame/nou teu h)\ au)dh/santos a)/kousen, but if he had heard any one call or speak. Od. ix. 497. (The aorist participles denote the occurrence of the act, as the present denotes its progress.) *)/hkousa de/ pote au)tou= kai\ peri\ fi/lwn dialegome/nou, I once heard him discourse, etc. (see 886). XEN. Mem. ii. 4, 1.
*tosau=ta fwnh/santos (sc. au)tou=) ei)shkou/samen, so much we heard him say. SOPH. O.C. 1645.
*)/hdh pw/pote/ tou h)/kousas au)tw=n lo/gon dido/ntos ou) katage/laston; PLAT. Rep. 493 D. *mega/l' e)/kluen au)dh/santos. Hom. Od. iv. 505. *ou)/ pw pepu/sqhn *patro/kloio qano/ntos, they had not yet heard of the death of Patroclus. Hom. Il. xvii. 377; so 427. *(ws e)pu/qonto th=s *pu/lou kateilhmme/nhs, when they heard of the capture of Pylus. THUC. iv. 6. (But with the accusative, in o(/ti pu/qoito to\ *plhmmu/rion e(alwko/s, that he had heard that P. was captured, THUC. vii. 31, as indirect discourse. See Classen's note on iv. 6.) *oi( tou/tous o(rw=ntes pa/sxontas, those who see these suffer. PLAT. Gorg. 525 C. *mh/ se i)/dwmai qeinome/nhn. Il. i. 587.So Od. x. 99. *tw=| ke/ m' i)/dois prw/toisin e)ni\ proma/xoisin mige/nta, then would you see me mingle with the foremost champions. Od. xviii. 379; so 176, o(
 h)rw= geneih/santa i)de/sqai, to see with a beard.
*tw=| pw/pot' ei)=des h)/dh a)gaqo/n ti geno/menon; to whom did you ever yet see any good come? AR. Nub. 1061.
*(/otan au)to
 i)/dh| e)cai/fnhs ptai/santa pro\s th=| po/lei kai\ e)kxe/anta ta/ te au(tou= kai\ e(auto/n, when he sees him suddenly come into collision with the state and fall overboard with all his belongings. PLAT. Rep. 553 A. *ei) mh\ w)/fqhsan e)lqo/ntes. THUC. iv. 73. (The aorist participle with a verb of seeing is not common in prose.) *ai)sqo/menos *lamprokle/a pro\s th
 mhte/ra xalepai/nonta, perceiving Lamprocles angry with his mother. XEN. Mem. ii. 2, 1. *ou)demi/an pw/pote a)ge/lhn h)|sqh/meqa susta=san e)pi\ to
 nome/a. Id. Cyr. i. 1, Id. Cyr. 2.So also ai)sqa/nomai with the genitive: h)/|sqhsai/ mou h)\ yeudomarturou=ntos h)\ sukofantou=ntos; Id. Mem. iv. 4, Id. Mem. 11. *oi)=mai/ se ou)k a)
 fa/nai genome/nou pote\ e)n sautw=| tou= toiou/tou ai)sqe/sqai, I think you would not say that you ever knew such a thing to happen within yourself. PLAT. Rep. 440 B. *to
 de\ no/hsen e(stew=t), and he perceived him standing. Il. iv. 200.

The participle may be used in a similar way, having the same distinction of present and aorist (884), with periorw= (periei=don), and sometimes with e)forw=, ei)sorw= (e)pei=don, ei)sei=don), and even the simple o(rw= (ei)=don), in the sense of overlook, allow, or not to prevent. E.g.

*tou\s cumma/xous ou) perioyo/meqa a)dikoume/nous, we shall not let our allies be wronged. THUC. i. 86. *mei/zw gigno/menon to
 a)/nqrwpon periorw=men, we allow the man to grow greater. DEM. ix. 29. *(umi=n e)piskh/ptw . . . mh\ periidei=n th
 h(gemoni/hn au)=tis e)s *mh/dous perielqou=san, I adjure you not to see the leadership come round again into the hands of the Medes. HDT. iii. 65. *mh\ perii/dwmen u(brisqei=san th
 *lakedai/mona kai\ katafronhqei=san, let us not allow Lacedaemon to be insulted and despised. ISOC. vi. 108. *periei=de to
 au(tou= pate/ra kai\ zw=nta tw=n a)nagkai/wn spani/zonta kai\ teleuth/santa ou) tuxo/nta tw=n nomi/mwn, he allowed his own father to remain in want (pres.) of the necessaries of life while he lived, and not to receive (aor.) a decent burial when he died. DIN. ii. 8. *kai\ mh/ m' e)/rhmon e)kpesou=san ei)si/dh|s, do not see me driven out without a friend. EUR. Med. 712.
*mh/ m' i)dei=n qano/nq' u(p' a)stw=n, not to see me killed by citizens. Id. Or. 746. See other examples of the aorist participle with these verbs in 148. For the infinitive, often in nearly the same sense, see 903, 6.

The verbs of perception included in 884 may take the participle also in indirect discourse, with the natural force of each tense preserved (see 904). With some of these verbs, the construction of the participle is generally shown by its case: thus a)kou/w and punqa/nomai in Attic Greek regularly take the genitive in the construction of 884, and the accusative in indirect discourse. See Ellendt, Sophocl. Lex.s.v. a)kou/w, who does not allow an exception in SOPH. Ph. 615.For the less fixed usage of Homer with a)kou/w and peu/qomai, see Schmitt in Schanz's Beiträge, p. 9. Other verbs, as o(rw=, have the accusative regularly in both constructions, but the context generally makes the meaning plain: see, however, EUR. Hec. 342. *ai)sqa/nomai sometimes has the genitive, as in some examples in 884, but not in indirect discourse.

V. With lanqa/nw, to escape the notice of, tugxa/nw, to happen, and fqa/nw, to anticipate or get the start of, the participle contains the leading idea of the expression and is usually translated by a verb in English. Here the aorist participle does not denote time past relatively to the leading verb (unless the latter is a present or imperfect), but coincides with it in time (144). Other tenses of the participle express their usual relations of time to the verb (147). E.g. *fone/a tou= paido\s e)la/nqane bo/skwn, he was unconsciously supporting the slayer of his son. HDT. i. 44. *)/h se lanqa/nei pro\s tou\s fi/lous stei/xonta tw=n e)xqrw=n kaka/; are you unaware that our enemies' evils are advancing upon our friends? SOPH. Ant. 9. *tou\s d' e)/laq' ei)selqw
 *pri/amos, and Priam entered unnoticed by them. Il. xxiv. 477; so xvii. 1. *mh/ se la/qh|sin kei=s' e)cormh/sasa, lest the ship be driven thither before you know it. Od. xii. 220. *fu/lasse d' o(/ g' ei)s e)niauto
, mh/ e( la/qoi pariw/n. Od. iv. 526. *(ra=|on e)/laqon e)selqo/ntes, they entered more easily without being noticed. THUC. ii. 2. *)ela/qomen h(ma=s au)tou\s pai/dwn ou)de
 diafe/rontes; did we never find out that all the time we were no better than children? PLAT. Crit. 49 B. (See 147, 2.)

*)arxi/damos au)tw=| ce/nos w)
 e)tu/gxane. THUC. ii. 13. *(o h(gemw
 e)tu/gxane teqnhkw/s, it happened that the guide had died (was dead). Id. iii. 98. *)/etuxon e)/foroi e(/teroi a)/rxontes h)/dh, there happened to be other Ephors already in office. Id. v. 36. *)/etuxen h(mw=n h( fulh\ prutaneu/ousa, our tribe happened to hold the prytany. PLAT. Ap. 32 B. *)/etuxon kaqh/menos e)ntau=qa. Euthyd. 272 E. *)en tw=| sko/tw| ga tou=t' e)/tuxon e)/ndon labw/n. AR. Eccl. 375. *)/etuxon parageno/menos i(/ppon e)/xwn, I came, as it happened, with a horse. Symp. 221A. *)es *nau/pakton, h(
 e)/tuxon h(rhko/tes newsti/, in Naupactus, which it happened they had lately captured. THUC. i. 103. (See 147, THUC. 1.) *)ea
 mh/ tis au)th=| bohqh/sas qew=n tu/xh|, unless some God by chance comes to its aid. PLAT. Rep. 492 A; so 495 B. *ka)
 ei) tu/xoien e)n tw=| paraxrh=ma kukew=na pio/ntes, even if they should happen to drink a kukew/n, on the spot. Ib. 408 B.

*fqa/nousin e)p' au)ta\ katafeu/gontes, they are the first to run to them. AESCHIN. iii. 248. *au)toi\ fqh/sontai tou=to dra/santes, they will do this for themselves first. PLAT. Rep. 375 C. *)/efqhsan pollw=| tou\s *pe/rsas a)piko/menoi, they arrived long before the Persians. HDT. iv. 136. *boulo/menoi fqh=nai tou\s *)aqhnai/ous a)piko/menoi e)s to\ a)/stu. Id. vi. 115. *fqa/nei pa=san e)p' ai)=an bla/ptous' a)nqrw/pous, i.e. she (Ate) harms men over the whole earth before Prayers can avail. Il. ix. 506. *)/efqh o)reca/menos, he hit him first. Il. xvi. 322. *(oppo/tero/s ke fqh=|sin o)reca/menos xro/a kalo/n, whichever shall first hit. Il. xxiii. 805. *)ou)k e)/fqasan puqo/menoi to\n po/lemon kai\ h(=kon, no sooner did they hear of the war than they came. ISOC. iv. 86. *fqa/nousin (hist. pres.) e)pi\ tw=| a)/krw| geno/menoi tou\s polemi/ous. XEN. An. iii. 4, 49.

So sometimes with dialanqa/nw and the poetic lh/qw. E.g. *toiau/ths politei/as mete/xein, e)n h(=| mh\ dialh/sei xrhsto\s w)/n. ISOC. iii. 16. *ou)de/ se lh/qw kinu/menos, nor do I ever move without your knowledge. Il. x. 279.

*kure/w in poetry takes the participle like tugxa/nw. E.g. *tou=ton oi)=sq' ei) zw=n kurei=; do you know whether perchance he is alive? SOPH. Ph. 444. *seswsme/nos kurei=. AESCH. Pers. 503.
*tau=t' ei)rhkw\s kurei=; Soph. O.C.414.
*)exqro\s w)\n kurei= EUR. Alc. 954.
So sugkure/w in HDT. viii. 87, with the aorist participle (144): ei) suneku/rhse h( tw=n *kalunde/wn parapesou=sa nhu=s.

*sumpi/ptw (chiefly in Herodotus) and sumbai/nw may take the participle like tugxa/nw. E.g. *kai\ to/de e(/teron sune/pese geno/menon, and this other event occurred, as it chanced. HDT. ix. 101. *sunepeptw/kee e)/ris e)ou=sa, it had happened that there was a quarrel. Id. i. 82. *ou(/tw ga\r sumbai/nei a(/ma kai\ h( tw=nde eu)ge/neia kosmoume/nh. PLAT. Menex. 237 C. *pa/nta cumbai/nei gigno/mena. Phil. 42C. *(/opou a)\n cumpi/pth| e)n th=| yuxh=| kala\ h)/qh e)no/nta. Id. Rep. 402 D.

*qami/zw, to be wont or frequent, may take the participle. E.g. *ou)/ ti komizo/meno/s ge qa/mizen, he was not used to being thus cared for. Od. viii. 451. *ou) qami/zeis katabai/nwn ei)s to\n *peiraia=, you do not come down to the Piraeus very often. PLAT. Rep. 328 C.
For examples of the aorist participle with the present or imperfect of some of the above verbs (887-890), retaining its own reference to past time, see 146.

As lanqa/nw is active and means to escape the notice of, it must have an object expressed or understood. When none is expressed, sometimes pa/ntas is understood, and sometimes a reflexive referring to the subject. Thus e)/laqe pou=to poih/sas may mean either he did this without any one's knowing it (sc. pa/ntas), or he did this unconsciously (sc. e(auto/n).

The usual construction of lanqa/nw and fqa/nw (and rarely that of tugxa/nw and kure/w) with the participle may be reversed, these verbs appearing in the participle, and what is generally the participle becoming the verb. E.g. *)\ay a)po\ tei/xeos a)=lto laqw/n, back from the wall he leaped secretly (for e)/laqen a)/lmenos). Il. xii. 390. *(/opws mh\ poiw=ntai e)/kplous au)to/qen lanqa/nontes. THUC. iii. 51. *(/os m' e)/bale fqa/menos, who took advantage of me and hit me. Il. v. 119. *fqa/nontes h)/dh dh|ou=men th
 e)kei/nwn gh=n. XEN. Cyr. iii. 3, 18. *th
 e)sbolh
 fqa/santes prokate/labon. THUC. iv. 127; so ii. 52. *)oli/g' a)lhqh= polla\ de\ yeudh= le/gei tuxw/n, i.e. speaks at random. I. A. 957. *plhsi/on ga h)=n kurw=n, for he happened to be near. SOPH. Ph. 371.See AESCH. Supp. 805.

The phrase ou)k a)
 fqa/nois (or ou)k a)
 fqa/noite), you could not be too soon, is used with the participle as an exhortation, meaning the sooner the better. The first and third persons are less common in this sense. E.g. *)apotre/xwn ou)k a)
 fqa/nois, the sooner you run off the better. AR. Pl. 1133.So HDT. vii. 162; XEN. Mem. iii. 11, 1. *ou)k a)
 fqa/nois le/gwn, the sooner you speak the better. Symp. 185E. *ou)k a)
 fqa/noimi (le/gwn), I might as well speak at once. Ib. 214E. *ei) mh\ timwrh/sesqe tou/tous, ou)k a)
 fqa/noi to\ plh=qos tou/tois toi=s qhri/ois douleu=on, the people might as well be slaves to these beasts at once. DEM. xxiv. 143.

VI. The participle, with many verbs signifying to come or to go, contains the leading idea of the expression. Such verbs are oi)/xomai, to be gone, h(/kw, to have come, e)/rxomai, ei)=mi, with the Homeric bh=, and e)/ban or ba/n, from bai/nw. Some of these uses are very peculiar. E.g. *)/wixet' a)popta/menos, it flew away and was gone. Il. ii. 71. *oi)/xetai feu/gwn o(\n ei)=xes ma/rtura, the witness whom you had has run away. AR. Pl. 933.
*(/in' ei)dh=|s ou(\s fe/rwn h(/kw lo/gous, that you may know the words I bring with me. EUR. Or. 1628.
*)/erxomai e)pixeirw=n soi e)pidei/casqai th=s ai)ti/as to\ ei)=dos, I am going to undertake to show you the nature of the cause. PLAT. Phaed. 100 B. *ou)k e)/rxomai e)re/wn w(s ou(/tw h)\ a)/llws pws tau=ta e)ge/neto, I am not going to say that these things occurred so, or in some other way (cf. French je vais dire). HDT. i. 5. *)/hie tau/thn ai)ne/wn dia\ panto/s, he always praised her (he went on praising her, French il allait la louant toujours: see Baehr's note). Id. i. 122. *kai\ e)gw\ me\n h)=|a ta\s e)fech=s e)rw=n, and I was going to speak of them in order. PLAT. Rep. 449 A; so 562 C. *bh= feu/gwn, he took flight. Il. ii. 665; so bh= a)i/casa, Il. ii. 167. *ou(\s mh\ kh=res e)/ban qana/toio fe/rousai, Il. ii. 302; so xix. 279.
VII. Herodotus uses the participle with peirw=mai, to try, and with pollo/s ei)mi or gi/nomai, pollo\s e)/gkeimai, and pantoi=os gi/nomai, to be urgent; rarely with e)pei/gomai, to press on. E.g.

*ou)k e)peira=to e)piw
 o( *ku=ros, Cyrus did not attempt to approach. i. 77; so i. 84, vi. 50, vii. 9. *pollo\s h)=n lisso/menos o( cei=nos, the stranger entreated urgently. ix. 91. *ge/lwn de\ pollo\s e)ne/keito le/gwn toia/de, and Gelon spoke urgently as follows. vii. 158. *to/te pantoi=oi e)ge/nonto *sku/qai deo/menoi *)iw/nwn lu=sai to
 po/ron, they begged them in every way (lit. they took every form in begging them), etc. vii. 10. *)\hn mh\ e)peixqh=|s naumaxi/hn poieu/menos, if you do not press on and fight a naval battle. viii. 68 (but just below, h)
 e)peixqh=|s naumaxh=sai).

The participle with peirw=mai, polu\s e)/gkeimai, and e)/gkeimai alone, occurs occasionally in Attic Greek. So also with pa/nta poiw= and rarely with spouda/zw. E.g.
*ou)k e)rw= soi pri\n a)\n pantaxh=| peiraqw= skopw=n PLAT. Theaet. 190 A. So ANT. Tetr. A. g. 1.
*polu\s e)ne/keito le/gwn THUC. iv. 22.
*)ene/keinto feu/gontes Id. ii. 81.
*pa/nta poiou=si kai\ le/gousi feu/gontes th\n di/khn PLAT. Euthyph. 8 C .
*ta\ plou/tou kai\ duna/mewn diw/gmata ti/ kai/ tis a)\n w(s a)/cia lo/gou spouda/zoi memfo/menos; why should any one seriously censure them as if they were worth noticing? Id. Polit. 310 B ; so XEN. Oec. ix. 1.

VIII. *)apodei/knumi, kaqi/zw, and paraskeua/zw, in the meaning to put into a certain condition, to render, may take the participle. E.g. *(/ama kai\ ta)pith/deia ma/lista e)/xontas a)podei/cein kai\ ta\ sw/mata a)/rista e)/xontas paraskeua/sein, (I undertake to say) that he will at the same time make them (show them forth) best supplied with provisions, and cause them to have their bodies in the best condition. XEN. Cyr. i. 6, 18. *ble/pont' a)podei/cw s' o)cu/teron tou= *lugke/ws, I will make you see sharper than Lynceus. AR. Pl. 210. *)ea\n klai/ontas au)tou\s kaqi/sw. Eur. Ion. 535 So Cyr. ii. 2, Cyr. 14.See these verbs in Liddell and Scott.

IX. *)arke/w (and a(/lis ei)mi/ in poetry), to be sufficient, and i(kano/s, h(di/wn, krei/sswn, a)mei/nwn, or belti/wn with ei)mi/, are sometimes used in a personal construction with the participle (like dh=lo/s ei)mi, etc. 907), where we should expect an impersonal construction with the infinitive. E.g. *)arke/sw qnh/|skous' e)gw/, it will be enough for me to die. SOPH. Ant. 547. (We might expect a)rke/sei e)me\ qnh/|skein.) So a)rkei/tw dedhlwme/non, THUC. v. 9. *(ikano\s e)/fh au)to\s a)tuxw=n ei)=nai, he said that it was enough for himself to be in misfortune. ISAE. ii. 7. *krei/sswn ga\r h)=sqa mhke/t' w)\n h)\ zw=n tuflo/s. SOPH. O.T. 1368. *(hdi/ous e)/sesqe a)kou/santes, you will be more pleased to hear. DEM. xxiii. 64.So a(/lis nosou=s' e)gw/ (sc. ei)mi/), it is enough for me to be afflicted. SOPH. O.T. 1061.

The X. participles boulo/menos, e)qe/lwn (poetic), h(do/menos, a)/smenos, a)xqo/menos, prosdexo/menos, e)lpo/menos, e)ldo/menos (Ionic), and occasionally others, may agree in case with a dative which depends on ei)mi/, gi/gnomai, or some verb signifying to come, to appear, or to happen. E.g.

*(\ws a)/ra tw\ *trw/essin e)eldo/menoisi fanh/thn, thus then did they appear to the delight of the Trojans. Il. vii. 7. *)emoi\ de/ ken a)sme/nw| ei)/h, and I should be pleased with it. Il. xiv. 108. *(hdome/noisin h(mi=n oi( lo/goi gego/nasi, we are pleased with the proposals made to us. HDT. ix. 46. *qe/lonti ka)moi\ tou=t' a)\n h)=n. SOPH. O.T. 1356. *tw=| plh/qei ou) boulome/nw| h)=n, it was not the wish of the majority. THUC. ii. 3; so vii. 35. *prosdexome/nw| moi ta\ th=s o)rgh=s u(mw=n e)s e)me\ gege/nhtai, I have been expecting the manifestations of your wrath against me. Id. ii. 60; so vi. 46. *(/otw| u(mw=n mh\ a)xqome/nw| ei)/h. XEN. Cyr. iv. 5, 21. *)\an boulome/nois a)kou/ein h)=| toutoisi\, mnhsqh/somai, if these shall want to hear it. DEM. xviii. 11. *(/ora, ei)/ soi boulome/nw| (sc. e)sti\n) a(\ le/gw. PLAT. Rep. 358 D

See also tou/twn pepeirame/nois a)/n ti ge/noito kai\ u(mi=n, THUC. v. 111; and a)sme/nw| de/ soi h( poikilei/mwn nu\c a)pokru/yei fa/os you will be glad when spangled-robed night shall hide the light, AESCH. Prom. 23.
Compare TAC. Agric. 18: Quibus bellum volentibus erat.

XI. In a similar way, the dative of any participle may be used with certain impersonal expressions which take the dative, especially those signifying it is fitting, good, pleasant, profitable, or their opposites, and those implying fear or confidence. E.g.

*ei) to/d' au)tw=| fi/lon keklhme/nw| (sc. e)sti/n), if it pleases him to be thus called. AESCH. Ag. 161. *ou)k a)/cion tou/tois polla/kis xrh=sqai sumbou/lois, oi(=s ou)de\ a(/pac e)lusite/lhse peiqome/nois (sc. u(mi=n), whom it did not profit you to obey even once. LYS. xxv. 27. *fronei=n w(s deino
 e)/nqa mh\ te/lh lu/h| fronou=nti, where it does not profit one to be wise. SOPH. O.T. 316. *)eph/reto to
 qeo
 ei) lw=|on kai\ a)/meinon ei)/h th=| *spa/rth| peiqome/nh| oi(=s ou(=tos e)/qhke no/mois, whether it was better for Sparta to obey. Lac. viii. 5. *)antiparaba/llonti (sc. e)moi\) ta\ e)mautou= pa/qh pro\s ta\ e)kei/nwn ou)k a)
 a)hde\s ei)/h, it would not be unpleasant for me to compare, etc. PLAT. Ap. 41 B. *ai(\ dokou=si ka/llistai tw=n e)pisthmw=n kai\ e)moi\ pre/poi a)
 ma/lista e)pimelome/nw|, those which seem to be the noblest of the sciences, and which it would be most fitting for me to study. XEN. Oec. iv. 1. *tou=to kai\ pre/pein e)moi\ dokei= kai\ a)/cion kinduneu=sai oi)ome/nw| ou(/tws e)/xein (i.e. pre/pei moi oi)ome/nw| tou=to ou(/tws e)/xein), it seems fitting and worth the risk for me to believe that this is so. PLAT. Phaed. 114 D. *(=wi mh/ )sti drw=nti ta/rbos, ou)k e)/pos fobei=, one who has no dread of a deed, a word does not frighten. SOPH. O.T. 296.
So ei)/ moi cunei/h fe/ronti moi=ra ta\n eu)/septon a(gnei/an, may it continue to be my fate to bear, etc. Id. 863.
With the expressions of 901 the infinitive is more common (903, 7).

div2.head: Omission of w)/n.
div2.p:
Occasionally the participle w)/n is omitted in the constructions of the supplementary participle that have been enumerated (879-901). E.g.
*katalamba/nomen *fili/ppou paro/ntas pre/sbeis, kai\ tou\s me\n h(mete/rous fi/lous e)n fo/bw| (sc. o)/ntas) tou\s d' e)kei/nou qrasei=s DEM. xviii. 211.
*)all' ou) perio/yetai/ m' o( qei=os a)/nippon (sc. o)/nta), but my uncle will not let me go without a horse. AR. Nub. 124.
*ei) de/ ti tugxa/nei a)hde/s (sc. o)/n). PLAT. Gorg. 502 B.
*tugxa/nei h(mw=n e(/kastos ou)k au)ta/rkhs (sc. w)/n). Id. Rep. 369 B.

div2.head: Infinitive with Verbs which may also have the Supplementary Participle.
div2.p: Some verbs which take the supplementary participle allow also the infinitive in a similar construction, but with some difference in the meaning or at least in the point of view.

1. *ai)sxu/nomai and ai)dou=mai with the participle (881) mean I am ashamed of doing (something which I am doing or have done); with the infinitive, I am ashamed to do (something which I have not yet done). E.g. *tou=to me
 ou)k ai)sxu/nomai le/gwn: to\ d' *)ea
 me/nhte par' e)moi\ a)podw/sw ai)sxunoi/mhn a)
 le/gein, this (something just said) I am not ashamed of saying; but I should be ashamed to say the following, etc. XEN. Cyr. v. 1, 21. *ai)sxu/nomai u(mi=n ei)pei=n ta)lhqh=, I am ashamed to tell you the truth (but still I must tell it). PLAT. Ap. 22 B. *ai)dou=ntai tou\s paro/ntas a)polei/pein, i.e. they are ashamed to leave them (and do not). XEN. Symp. viii. 35. But ai)/desai pate/ra prolei/pwn, be ashamed of leaving your father (as you threaten to do), SOPH. Aj. 506. A comparison of the last example with PLAT. Ap. 22 B (above) shows that the choice of the infinitive or participle may depend on the point of view of the speaker in a special case. In Aj. 506, the threat is viewed as the inception of the act.

2. *)ane/xomai, u(pome/nw, tla/w, and tolmw= with the participle (879; 880) mean to endure something now going on or already done; with the infinitive, to have the courage or to venture to do something not yet done. E.g. *katamei/nantes a)ne/sxonto to\n e)pio/nta e)pi\ th\n xw/rhn de/casqai, they remained and had the courage to receive the invader of their country. HDT. vii. 139. (Cf. ou)k a)ne/comai zw=sa under 879.) So u(pomei/nanta ta\ pa/nta pa/sxein, taking courage to suffer everything. Leg. 869 C. (Cf. mh\ u(pome/nein *ce/rchn e)pio/nta, not to await the coming of Xerxes, i.e. not to wait to see his coming, HDT. vii. 120.) *)/etla ou)ra/nion fw=s a)lla/cai SOPH. Ant. 944.
*to/lmhso/n pote o)rqw=s fronei=n AESCH. Prom. 999.
*)ane/xomai with the infinitive, and tla/w and tolmw= with the participle, are rare.
3. *)apoka/mnw tou=to poiw=n (881) is I am weary of doing this; a)poka/mnw tou=to poiei=n is I cease to do this through weariness. E.g.

*mh/te tau=ta fobou/menos a)poka/mh|s sauto\n sw=sai, do not, through fear of this, despair of saving yourself. PLAT. Crit. 45 B. (Cf. ou)k a)poka/mneis mhxanw/menos, you are not tired of contriving, XEN. Mem. ii. 6, 35. )

4. *)/arxomai (Homeric a)/rxw) with the participle (879) means to be first in something, to begin with something, or to be at the beginning (not at the end); with the infinitive, to begin to do something. E.g.

*)/hrcanto ta\ makra\ tei/xh *)aqhnai=oi oi)kodomei=n, the Athenians began to build the long walls. THUC. i. 107. *dei= e)me\ e)pideiknu/nai, w(s ou)/t' h)/rcato le/gein ta\ be/ltista ou)/te nu=n diatelei= pra/ttwn ta\ sumfe/ronta tw=| dh/mw|. AESCHIN. iii. 50.

5. *pau/w with the participle (879) means to stop what is going on; with the infinitive, to prevent a future act. E.g. *)/em' e)/pausas ma/xesqai, you prevented me from fighting. Il. xi. 442. (But e)/m' e)/pausas maxo/menon would be you stopped me while fighting.) *(payw|dou\s e)/pause a)gwni/zesqai. HDT. v. 67.

6. *periorw= and the other verbs signifying to overlook or see (in the sense of permit) with the participle (885) mean to see an act done without interfering to stop it; with the less frequent infinitive, to permit an act to be done without interfering to prevent it. Strictly speaking, the infinitive here expresses time future to that of the verb, while the time of the participle coincides with that of the verb. Still, both forms may sometimes be used to express practically the same sense, and may even refer to the same event, though the point of view is different. E.g. *periidei=n au)to
 e)n th=| skeuh=| pa/sh| a)ei=sai, to let him sing in full dress. HDT. i. 24. *qa/lassan pneu/mata/ fasi ou) perio/yesqai fu/si th=| e(wuth=s xra=sqai, they say that the winds will not permit the sea to follow its own nature. Id. vii. 16. *tou\s ga *)aqhnai/ous h)/lpizen i)/sws a)
 e)pecelqei=n kai\ th
 gh=n ou)k a)
 periidei=n tmhqh=nai, for he hoped that the Athenians would perhaps come forth and not let their land be ravaged. THUC. ii. 20.But in ii. 18 he has said, prosde/xomenos tou\s *)aqhnai/ous th=s gh=s e)/ti a)kerai/ou ou)/shs e)ndw/sein ti kai\ katoknh/sein periidei=n au)th
 tmhqei=san, a)nei=xen, that they would be unwilling to see it (the land) ravaged (referring to the same thing with periidei=n tmhqh=nai, to let it be ravaged, in 20); and again in 20, oi( *)axarnh=s ou) perio/yesqai e)do/koun ta\ sfe/tera diafqare/nta, it did not seem likely that the Acharnians would see their property destroyed.

7. The impersonal expressions of 901 take the infinitive more frequently than the participle, the distinction being similar to that in the last case (6). E.g. *ou) tou=to prw=ton h)rw/ta po/teron lw=|on ei)/h au)tw=| poreu/esqai h)\ me/nein, whether it was better for him to go or stay. XEN. An. iii. 1, 7. But in XEN. Vect. vi. 2 we have e)pere/sqai tou\s qeou\s ei) lw=|on kai\ a)/meinon ei)/h a)\n th=| po/lei ou(/tw kataskeuazome/nh|, whether it would be better for the state, supposing it to be thus constituted; the difference between this and better for the state to be thus constituted (ou(/tw kataskeua/zesqai) being practically very slight.

8. It is more than doubtful whether lanqa/nw, tugxa/nw, and fqa/nw (887) ever have the infinitive in classic Greek. The passages formerly cited for this are now generally emended, or the readings are doubted: thus, in PLAT. Rep. 333 E, laqei=n e)mpoih=sai must be for laqei=n e)mpoih/sas (Schneider), and in AR. Eq. 935, fqai/hs e)lqei=n, and AR. Nub. 1384, ou)k e)/fqhs fra/sai , Meineke reads e)lqw/n and fra/sas. See Classen on THUC. iii. 82, o( fqa/sas qarsh=sai (?).

div2.head: II. Participle in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: The participle is used with verbs signifying to see, to hear or learn, to perceive, to know, to be ignorant of, to remember, to forget, to show, to appear, to prove, to acknowledge, and with a)gge/llw, to announce, in a sense approaching that of the infinitive in indirect discourse. Here each tense of the participle represents the corresponding tense of the indicative or optative. (See 687.)

The participle may belong to either the subject or the object of these verbs, and agree with it in case. E.g.
*me/mnhmai au)to
 tou=to poih/santa, I remember that he did this (e)poi/hsen);
me/mnhmai tou=to poih/sas, I remember that I did this (e)poi/hsa).
*oi)=de tou/tous eu)= pra/contas, he knows that they will prosper;
oi)=de au)to\s eu)= pra/cwn, he knows that he himself will prosper.
*ei)/ k' au)to
 gnw/w nhmerte/a pa/nt' e)ne/ponta, if I shall find that he tells all without fault. Od. xvii. 549.
*(orw= de/ m' e)/rgon deino
 e)ceirgasme/nhn, and I see that I have done a terrible deed. SOPH. Tr. 706.
*(hmei=s a)du/natoi o(rw=men o)/ntes th=| oi)kei/a| mo/non duna/mei perigene/sqai, we see that we are unable, etc. (a)du/natoi/ e)smen). THUC. i. 32.
*)/hkouse *ku=ron e)n *kiliki/a| o)/nta, he heard that Cyrus was in Cilicia. XEN. An. i. 4, 5.
*peri\ th=s xw/ras, o(/ti h)/kouon dh|oume/nhn, because they heard that it was suffering from ravages. Ib. v. 5, Ib. 7. *(/otan klu/h| tino\s h(/cont' *)ore/sthn, when she hears from any one that Orestes is coming. SOPH. El. 293. *puqo/menoi *)artace/rchn newsti\ teqnhko/ta, learning that Artaxerxes had recently died. THUC. iv. 50; so HDT. vi. 23. *)epei\ pro\s a)ndro\s h)/|sqet' h)dikhme/nh. EUR. Med. 26. *)/hisqonto tou\s met' *)ariste/ws e)pipario/ntas. THUC. i. 61. *dia\ th
 *)ili/ou a(/lwsin eu(ri/skousi e)ou=san th
 a)rxh
 th=s e)/xqrhs (see 883). HDT. i. 5. *)epeida
 gnw=sin a)pistou/menoi, when they find out that they are distrusted. XEN. Cyr. vii. 2, 17. *)/hidesan *swkra/thn au)tarke/stata zw=nta. Id. Mem. i. 2, Id. Mem. 14. *)en polutro/pois ga cumforai=s e)pi/stantai trafe/ntes. THUC. ii. 44. *diabeblhme/nos ou) manqa/neis. HDT. iii. 1. *)ennoou=mai fau=los ou)=sa. EUR. Hipp. 435. *)ennoh/sas ge/nos e)pieike\s a)qli/ws diatiqe/menon. PLAT. Criti. 121 B. *ti/s ou(/tws eu)h/qhs e)sti
 u(mw=n o(/stis a)gnoei= to
 e)kei=qen po/lemon deu=ro h(/conta; DEM. i. 15. *me/mnhmai *kriti/a| tw=|de cuno/nta se (i.e. cunh=sqa). PLAT. Charm. 156 A. *memnh/meq' e)s ki/ndunon e)lqo/ntes me/gan (i.e. h)/lqomen). EUR. Hec. 244.
*)epilelh/smeq' h(de/ws ge/rontes o)/ntes Bacch. 188.
*)epidei/cw de\ tou=ton ou) mo/non w(mologhko/ta ei)=nai to
 *milu/an e)leu/qeron (with six other participles, perfect, aorist, and present). DEM. xxix. 5. *(o po/lemos ou(=tos dhlw/sei mei/zwn gegenhme/nos au)tw=n (i.e. mei/zwn gege/nhtai). THUC. i. 21. *ei) fanh/setai tau=q' w(mologhkw\s, para/ te tou= *dhmofw=ntos ta\s tima\s ei)lhfw\s, au)to/s te . . . a)pogra/yas, oi)kw=n te th
 oi)ki/an, k.t.l. DEM. xxvii. 16. *eu)qu\s e)legxqh/setai geloi=os w)/n. XEN. Mem. i. 7, 2. *ou(/tws o(mologoume/nh ou)=sa dou/lh kai\ a(/panta to
 xro/non ai)sxrw=s biou=sa, when it was thus admitted that she was a slave and was all the time living a life of disgrace. ISAE. vi. 49. *ei) mh\ e)ch/ggeile prosio
 to\ stra/teuma, had he not reported that the enemy was advancing. XEN. Hell. vii. 5, 10. *)aphgge/lqh *fi/lippos u(mi=n *(hrai=on tei=xos poliorkw=n, it was reported to you that he was besieging, etc. DEM. iii. 4.
Compare the examples of o(rw=, a)kou/w, and similar verbs here given with those of the same verbs under 884, in which the participle is not in indirect discourse.
See other examples of the participle in indirect discourse under 687, where examples of the participle with a)/n may be found (see also 213-216).

When one of these verbs has for its object an accusative of the reflexive pronoun referring to its subject, the participle generally agrees with the reflexive. Thus we may have either dei/cw e)mauto\n tou=to pepoihko/ta, I shall show that I have done this, or dei/cw tou=to pepoihkw/s.
The participle of an impersonal verb in this construction stands alone in the neuter singular. The following includes both the personal and the impersonal construction:—

*peira/somai dei=cai kai\ meto\n th=s po/lews h(mi=n kai\ peponqo/ta e)mauto\n ou)xi\ prosh/konta, I shall try to show not only that we have rights in the city, but also that I have suffered, etc. DEM. lvii. 1 . (The direct discourse is me/testi th=s po/lews h(mi=n, kai\ pe/ponqa au)to/s. Compare 876.)

The participle is used in the same way in a personal construction with dh=lo/s ei)mi and fanero/s ei)mi, in preference to an impersonal expression. So with e)pa/istos gi/nomai in Herodotus. E.g.
*dh=lo/s t' h)=n oi)o/menos, k.t.l., it was evident that he thought, etc. XEN. An. ii. 5, 27. (This is equivalent to dh=lon h)=n o(/ti oi)/oito. See 899; 912.)
*)apiko/menoi me\n faneroi/ ei)si e)s *)/oasin po/lin, it is evident that they came to the city Oasis. HDT. iii. 26.
*(ws e)pa/istos e)ge/neto tou=to e)rgasme/nos, when it became known (heard of) that he had done this. Id. ii. 119.
Similar is the participle with fanero\n poiw=, as fanero\n pa=sin e)poi/hsan ou)k i)di/a| polemou=ntes, they made it evident to all that they were not fighting for themselves. LYCURG. 50.

When su/noida and suggignw/skw have a dative of the reflexive referring to the subject, a participle may stand either in the dative agreeing with the reflexive, or in the nominative agreeing with the subject; as su/noida e)mautw| h)dikhme/nw| (or h)dikhme/nos), I am conscious to myself that I have been wronged. E.g.
*)egw\ ou)/te mega ou)/te smikro\n cu/noida e)mautw=| sofo\s w)/n PLAT. Ap. 21 B.
*)emautw=| cunh/|dein ou)de\n e)pistame/nw| Ib. 22B.

When the participle of indirect discourse belongs to an infinitive depending on a verb with an object dative to which the participle refers, the participle stands in the dative. E.g. *sumbe/bhke toi=s proesthko/si kai\ ta)/lla plh\n e(autou\s oi)ome/nois pwlei=n prw/tous e(autou\s peprako/sin ai)sqe/sqai it has been the lot of those who were in authority and who thought they were selling everything except themselves, to find that they have sold themselves first. DEM. xviii. 46.

Some verbs which regularly have the infinitive or o(/ti and w(s in indirect discourse occasionally take the participle. E.g.
*no/mize a)/ndra a)gaqo\n a)poktei/nwn, think that you are putting to death a good man. XEN. An. vi. 6, 24.
*)anebh/seto e)reou=sa fi/lon po/sin e)/ndon e)o/nta Hom. Od. xxiii. 1.
*qano/nt' *)ore/sthn nu=n te kai\ pa/lai le/gw SOPH. El. 676. See O. C. 1579; EUR. Hel. 1076.
*ou) *trw|a\s gunh\ tekou=sa kompa/seien a)/n pote, i.e. none could boast that she was the mother (of such children), e)/tekon being the direct form. EUR. Tro. 477.
*meto\n a)/n pote le/goito Phil. 22
*sme/rdin mhke/ti u(mi=n e)o/nta logi/zesqe HDT. iii. 65.
*ou) ga\r eu)tuxw=n a)rnh/somai, for I will not deny that I am happy. EUR. Alc. 1158. So a)rnei= katakta/s; Id. Or. 1581.

The participle w)/n is sometimes omitted in indirect discourse. E.g.
*su\ de\ sw=s i)/sqi (sc. w)/n), but know that you are safe. SOPH. O.C. 1210.
*ei)dw\s eu)trepei=s u(ma=s (sc. o)/ntas). DEM. iv. 18 ; so iv. 41.
*)/aggelle pasw=n a)qliwta/thn e)me/ (sc. ou)=san). EUR. Hec. 423.

The verbs included in 904 may also be followed by a clause with o(/ti or w(s in indirect discourse. When dh=lo/n e)stin and fanero/n e)stin are used impersonally, they regularly take o(/ti or w(s. E.g.
*)/hisqeto o(/ti to\ *me/nwnos stra/teuma h)/dh e)n *kiliki/a| h)=n XEN. An. i. 2, 21.
*ai)sqa/nesqe w(s a)qu/mws h)=lqon
Ib. iii. 1. 40
*)akou/ontes o(/ti ou(=tos poli/zei to\ xwri/on
Ib. vi. 6. 4
*tosou=to/n g' oi)=da ka)mauth\n, o(/ti a)lgw= SOPH. El. 332.
*tau=ta i)/sasin o(/ti fu/sei te kai\ tu/xh| gi/gnetai PLAT. Prot. 323 D.
*dh=lon (sc. e)sti/n) o(/ti ou(/tws e)/xei XEN. An. i. 3, 9.
*fanero\n de\ o(/ti ou)/t' a)\n *qra|ci\n ou)/te *sku/qais e)qe/loien a)\n diagwni/zesqai Id. Mem. iii. 9. 2
*tou=to fanero\n, w(s . . . le/gomen PLAT. Soph. 237 D.

Verbs signifying to remember or to know may have o(/te, when, and the indicative, to emphasise the temporal relation. E.g.
*ei) ga\r me/mnhsai o(/t' e)gw/ soi a)pekrina/mhn, for if you remember (the time) when I answered you, etc. PLAT. Men. 79 D.
*oi)=sq' o(/te xruse/ois e)fa/nh su\n o(/plois EUR. Hec. 112.
So Il. xv. 18. (See 519, end.)

div2.head: Infinitive with the Verbs of § 904.
div2.p: Many of the verbs which regularly have the participle in indirect discourse (904) may also take the infinitive in nearly or quite the same sense.

1. *)akou/w, punqa/nomai, and ai)sqa/nomai, which have the participle both in indirect discourse (904) and in the other construction (884-886), sometimes take the infinitive in indirect discourse, in a sense differing little, if at all, from that of the participle. E.g.
*)akou/w de\ kai\ a)/lla e)/qnh polla\ toiau=ta ei)=nai, I hear that there are also many other such nations. XEN. An. ii. 5, 13. (*polla\ toiau=ta o)/nta would apparently mean the same.) So Mem. iv. 2. 4.
*)akou/w au)to\n e)rei=n, I hear that he will say. DEM. xix. 202. (Compare SOPH. El. 293, under 904.)
*punqano/menos to\n *qoukudi/dhn kth=si/n te e)/xein kai\ a)p' au)tou= du/nasqai e)n toi=s prw/tois THUC. iv. 105. So DEM. xix. 201.
*ai)sqano/menos au)tou\s me/ga para\ basilei= *darei/w| du/nasqai THUC. vi. 59.

2. *(orw= has the participle in both constructions (904; 886), but the infinitive (of indirect discourse) only in THUC. viii. 60 (according to Kühner, § 484. 2): e(w/rwn ou)ke/ti a)/neu naumaxi/as oi(=o/n te ei)=nai e)s th\n *xi/on bohqh=sai, where Krü ger brackets ei)=nai.

3. *)agge/llw may have the infinitive in indirect discourse, in place of the regular participle (904). E.g. *(o *)assu/rios ei)s th\n xw/ran au)tou= e)mbalei=n a)gge/lletai, is reported to have invaded his country. XEN. Cyr. v. 3, 30.

4. *(omologw=, to admit or grant, is but rarely followed by the participle (904), and generally takes the infinitive of indirect discourse. E.g. *(omologei=tai pro\s pa/ntwn kra/tistos dh\ gene/sqai qerapeu/ein ( tou\s fi/lous ). XEN. An. i. 9, 20. (See 136.)

5. *fai/nomai, to appear, which generally takes the participle in indirect discourse (904), sometimes has the infinitive. The distinction generally holds that fai/netai sofo\s w)/n means he is manifestly wise, while fai/netai sofo\s ei)=nai means he seems to be wise; but in some cases the two constructions cannot be distinguished in sense. E.g.
*th=| fwnh=| safw=s klai/ein e)fai/neto, by his voice he seemed plainly to be weeping (but he really was not). XEN. Symp. i. 15.
Compare kai/ sfi eu)/noos e)fai/neto e)w/n, and he was plainly well disposed towards them HDT. vii. 173.
But see also AESCH. Ag. 593, plagkto\s ou)=s' e)faino/mhn , I appeared to be crazed, said by Clytemnestra of herself, after she was shown to have been right.
*tou=to/ moi qeio/taton fai/netai gene/sqai, this seems to me to have been a most wonderful event. HDT. vii. 137.

Other verbs of this class (904) may be used in a peculiar sense, in which they have the infinitive not in indirect discourse. Others, again, allow both constructions of the infinitive; while gignw/skw and eu(ri/skw have the infinitive in three different senses.

1. *manqa/nw, me/mnhmai, and e)pila/nqanomai, in the sense of learn, remember, and forget to do anything, take the ordinary object infinitive. E.g.
*)epei\ ma/qon e)/mmenai e)sqlo\s ai)ei\ kai\ prw/toisi meta\ *trw/essi ma/xesqai, since I learned to be brave, etc. Il. vi. 444.
*tou\s prodo/tas ga\r misei=n e)/maqon AESCH. Prom. 1068. So XEN. An. iii. 2, 25.
*memnh/sqw a)nh\r a)gaqo\s ei)=nai, let him remember to be a brave man. Ib. iii. 2. 29 (with w)/n it would mean let him remember that he is a brave man).
*memnh/sontai deu=ro a)pope/mpein Id. Cyr. viii. 6. 6
*)epelaqo/mhn tou\s kadi/skous e)kfe/rein, I forgot to bring out the urns. AR. Vesp. 853.
*)oli/gou e)pelaqo/meq' ei)pei=n PLAT. Rep. 563 B.

2. (a) *oi)=da and e)pi/stamai, which regularly have the participle in indirect discourse, take the ordinary infinitive in the sense of know how to do anything. E.g.
*mh\ yeu/de', e)pista/menos sa/fa ei)pei=n, do not be false, when you know how to speak truly. Il. iv. 404.
*oi)=d' e)pi\ decia\, oi)=d' e)p' a)ristera\ nwmh=sai bw=n Il. vii. 238.
*proba/llesqai d' h)\ ble/pein e)nanti/on ou)/t' oi)=den ou)/t' e)qe/lei DEM. iv. 40. So EUR. Hipp. 729, EUR. Med. 664.
*ei)/kein d' ou)k e)pi/statai kakoi=s, she knows not how to yield to troubles. SOPH. Ant. 472 ; so SOPH. Aj. 666; EUR. Hipp. 996.

(b) But these verbs in the sense to know or to believe sometimes take the infinitive (like the participle) in indirect discourse. This is rare in prose, except with e)pi/stamai, to believe, in Herodotus. E.g.
*)/isqi ta\ sklh/r' a)/gan fronh/mata pi/ptein ma/lista, know that too stubborn spirits are most apt to fall (like pi/ptonta). SOPH. Ant. 473. (*oi)=da with the participle follows in 477.)
*eu)= nu=n e)pi/stw tw=nde/ m' ai)sxu/nhn e)/xein Id. El. 616 ; so O. T. 690, Ant. 1092; AESCH. Pers. 337.
*eu)= i)/sqi tou=ton i)sxurw=s a)nia=sqai XEN. Cyr. viii. 3, 44 ; so viii. 7.12
*)epista/menoi to/te teleuth=sai, believing that he (Cyrus)had then perished. HDT. i. 122 ; so iii. 66, 134, and 140, HDT. vii. 172. See i)/sqi mh/pot' a)\n tuxei=n, SOPH. Ph. 1329 ; and to/d' i)/sqi, mh\ gh=mai, EUR. Med. 593 ; cf. I. A.1005.
3. *gignw/skw, besides its construction with the participle in indirect discourse (904), has three uses with the infinitive:—

(a) In the meaning to decide or judge, with the infinitive in indirect discourse; as to\ d' i)/son a)ntapo/dote, gno/ntes tou=ton ei)=nai to\n kairo/n making up your minds that this is that time, etc., THUC. i. 43 ; so HDT. ix. 71; XEN. An. i. 9, 17.

(b) In the meaning to determine or resolve, with the ordinary object infinitive; as *)alua/ttea e)/gnwsan dou=nai th\n qugate/ra *)astua/gei+ they decided that Alyattes should give his daughter to Astyages, HDT. i. 74 ; so XEN. Hell. iv. 6, 9 , e)/gnw diw/kein, and XEN. Hell. iii. 1. 12; ISOC. xvii. 16.

(c) Occasionally in the meaning to learn (e)/gnwn), with the object infinitive, like manqa/nw and me/mnhmai (1); as i(/na gnw=| tre/fein th\n glw=ssan h(suxwte/ran that he may learn to keep his tongue more quiet SOPH. Ant. 1089.

4. *dei/knumi and other verbs signifying to show, besides the participle in indirect discourse (904), may take an object infinitive in the sense to show how to do anything. E.g.
*)ape/deican oi( h(gemo/nes lamba/nein ta\ e)pith/deia, the guides instructed them to take provisions. XEN. An. ii. 3, 14.
*diaithth/ria toi=s a)nqrw/pois e)pedei/knuon tou= me\n qe/rous e)/xein yuxeina\, tou= de\ xeimw=nos a)leeina/, I taught the men to keep their dwellings cool in summer and warm in winter. Id. Oec. ix. 4.

5. *dhlw= sometimes has the infinitive (like the regular participle, 904) in indirect discourse; and sometimes in the sense of command (make known) it has the ordinary object infinitive. E.g.
*dhloi=s ga\r au)to\n swro\n h(/kein xrhma/twn e)/xonta, for you indicate that he has come with a heap of money. AR. Pl. 269.
*dhlou=ntes prosi/esqai ta\ kekhrugme/na, showing that they accepted the terms which were announced. THUC. iv. 38.
*khru/gmati e)dh/lou tou\s e)leuqeri/as deome/nous w(s pro\s su/mmaxon au)to\n parei=nai, he proclaimed that those who wanted freedom should come to him as to an ally. Xen. Ag. i. 33.

6. (a) *eu(ri/skw, which has two constructions with the participle (883; 904), occasionally has the infinitive in indirect discourse. E.g. *eu(/riske prh=gma/ oi( ei)=nai e)lau/nein e)pi\ ta\s *sa/rdis he found that he must (prh=gma/ moi e)sti, mihi opus est) march to Sardes. HDT. i. 79 : so i. 125, HDT. vii. 12. See PLAT. Leg. 699 B.
(b) The middle may take the ordinary object infinitive in the sense of discover how to do anything. E.g. *ou)dei\s lu/pas eu(/reto pau/ein, no one ever found out how to stop pains. EUR. Med. 195.
(c) The middle may also have the infinitive in the sense of procure by asking. E.g.

cit.quote: *para\ de\ sfi/si eu(/ronto para\ *pausani/ew e(sta/nai *potidaihte/wn tou\s pare/ontas
they gained (the favour) from Pausanias that those who were present from Potidaea should stand next to themselves.

div2.head: w(s with the Participle in Indirect Discourse.
div2.p:
The participle in indirect discourse may be preceded by w(s, which implies that the thought of the participle is expressed as that of the leading subject, or as that of some person prominent in the sentence. (See 864.) When this is already implied in the context, as it often is, w(s adds only emphasis to the expression. Thus i)/sqi tau=ta ou(/tws e)/xonta means know that this is so; but i)/sqi w(s tau=ta e)/xonta means know that (as you may assume) this is so, i.e. be assured that this is so. E.g.
*(ws mhde\n ei)do/t' i)/sqi m' w(=n a)nistorei=s understand (that you must look upon) me as knowing nothing of what you seek. SOPH. Ph. 253.
*(ws mhke/t' o)/nta kei=non e)n fa/ei no/ei, think of him as no longer living. Ib. 415.
*(ws tau=t' e)pi/stw drw/men', ou) me/llont' e)/ti understand that (as you may assume) these things are going on, etc. Ib. 567.
*tau=ta gh=| th=|d' w(s telw=n e)fai/neto Id. O.C. 630.
*kai\ tou=to e)pista/sqw *kroi=sos, w(s u(/steron a(lou\s th=s peprwme/nhs and let Croesus understand this, that he was captured later than it was fated for him to be. HDT. i. 91.
*(ws mh\ )mpolh/swn i)/sqi th\n e)mh\n fre/na, be assured that you will not buy me off from my determination. SOPH. Ant. 1063.
*dhloi=s d' w(/s ti shmanw=n ne/on, you show that you have something new in your mind to disclose. Ib. 242.
*dh=lo/s e)stin w(/s ti drasei/wn kako/n, it is very plain that he wishes to do some harm. Id. Aj. 326.
*dh=los h)=n *ku=ros w(s speu/dwn, Cyrus showed that he was in haste. XEN. An. i. 5, 9.
*dh=loi e)/sesqe w(s o)rgizo/menoi toi=s pepragme/nois, you will show that you are angry. LYS. xii. 90.
*pate/ra to\n so\n a)ggelw=n w(s ou)k e)/t' o)/nta (he comes) to announce that your father is no more. SOPH. O.T. 956. (In vs. 959, the messenger himself says eu)= i)/sq' e)kei=non qana/simon bebh/kota.)
The force of w(s here can seldom be well expressed in English.

In place of the participle with w(s in indirect discourse, we may have a circumstantial participle with w(s in the genitive or accusative absolute, followed by a verb to which the participle would naturally be the object. E.g.
*(ws w(=d' e)xo/ntwn tw=nd' e)pi/stasqai/ se xrh/ you must understand that this is so; lit. believing this to be so, you must understand (it is so). SOPH. Aj. 281 ; see Schneidewin's note. By an entirely different construction this comes practically to the same meaning as w(s w(=d' e)/xonta ta/d' e)pi/stasqai/ se xrh/.
*(ws toi/nun o)/ntwn tw=nde/ soi maqei=n pa/ra in the belief that this is so, you may learn it, i.e. you may learn that this is so. AESCH. Prom. 760.
*(ws pole/mou o)/ntos par' u(mw=n a)paggelw=; shall I announce from you that there is war? lit. shall I make a report from you on the assumption that there is war? XEN. An. ii. 1, 21.
*(ws pa/nu moi dokou=n, ou(/tws i)/sqi know that I think so very decidedly; lit. in the belief that this seems so to me, understand accordingly. Id. Mem. iv. 2. 30
*(ws e)mou= a)gwnioume/nou, ou(/tws gi/gnwske, know that I shall contend. Id. Cyr. ii. 3. 15

*(ws with the participle in the genitive or accusative absolute, used as in 917, may depend on verbs or expressions which do not take the participle without w(s in indirect discourse. E.g.
*(ws ou)ke/t' o)/ntwn tw=n te/knwn fro/ntize dh/ think of it, that your children are no longer living, lit. knowing that your children are no longer living, think of it. EUR. Med. 1311.
*(ws kai\ tw=n stratiwtw=n kai\ tw=n h(gemo/nwn u(mi=n mh\ memptw=n gegenhme/nwn, ou(/tw th\n gnw/mhn e)/xete be of this mind, that both your soldiers and their leaders have been free from blame. THUC. vii. 15.
*(ws e)mou= ou)=n i)o/ntos o(/ph| a)\n kai\ u(mei=s, ou(/tw th\n gnw/mhn e)/xete be of this opinion, that I shall go wherever you do. XEN. An. i. 3, 6.
*(ws toi/nun mh\ a)kousome/nwn, ou(/tws dianoei=sqe make up your minds then that we shall not hear; lit. knowing then that we shall not hear, so make up your minds. PLAT. Rep. 327 C .
*)en tou/tois me\n w(s didaktou= ou)/shs th=s a)reth=s le/gei, here he speaks of virtue as a thing that can be taught. Id. Men. 95 E.
*(upoqe/menoi w(s tou/tou ou(/tws e)/xontos, proi+/wmen having premised that this is so, let us proceed. Rep. 437 A.
*dianohqe/ntes w(s i)o/ntwn a(pa/ntwn a)ei\ kai\ r(eo/ntwn, thinking of all things as moving and in flux.
Crat. 439 C.
*ou(/tw skopw=men, w(s ta/x' a)\n, ei) tu/xoi, kai\ tou/twn ka)kei/nwn sumba/ntwn let us look at the case, feeling that both this and that might perhaps happen if it should so chance; lit. with the idea that both this and that might perhaps happen if it should so chance, let us look at it in this light. DEM. xxiii. 58.
*(ws de/on au)to\n teqna/nai Id. xxi. 70.

Verbs of saying and thinking which do not take the participle in indirect discourse sometimes have the participle (in the accusative or nominative) with w(s, which in some cases approaches very near indirect discourse, and in others is more like a circumstantial participle. E.g.
*fronti/zeq' w(s tou/tois te kai\ sofwte/rois a)/lloisi tou/twn plei/osin maxou/menoi consider that you will have to fight with these, etc. SOPH. El. 1370 (cf. EUR. Med. 1311, quoted in 918).
*le/gousin h(ma=s w(s o)lwlo/tas, they speak of us as lost. AESCH. Ag. 672.
*(ws ou)k u(pei/cwn ou)de\ pisteu/swn le/geis; do you speak with a resolution not to yield or to believe? SOPH. O.T. 625.
*kambu/shs *)/iwnas me\n kai\ *ai)ole/as w(s dou/lous patrwi/ous e)o/ntas e)no/mize, he thought of Ionians and Aeolians as his father's slaves. HDT. ii. 1.
*(ws strathgh/sonta e)me\ mhdei\s lege/tw, let no one speak of me as the one who is to be general. XEN. An. i. 3, 15.
*)edo/kei polla\ h)/dh a)lhqeu=sai toiau=ta, ta\ o)/nta te w(s o)/nta kai\ ta\ mh\ o)/nta w(s ou)k o)/nta he was thought to have already reported truly many such occurrences, (reporting) what was real as real, and what was unreal as unreal. Ib. iv. 4. 15
*(/otan w(s peto/menoi e)n tw=| u(/pnw| dianow=ntai, when in their sleep they fancy themselves flying. PLAT. Theaet. 158 B

div2.head: Verbal Adjectives in -te/os and -te/on
div2.p: The verbal in -te/os is used in both a personal and an impersonal construction.

In the personal construction, the verbal is always passive in sense. It expresses necessity (like the Latin participle in -dus and agrees with its subject in case. This construction is, of course, restricted to transitive verbs. E.g.
*)Wfelhte/a soi h( po/lis e)sti/, the city must be benefited by you. XEN. Mem. iii. 6, 3
*)/Allas (nau=s) e)k tw=n cumma/xwn metapempte/as ei)=nai (e)/fh), he said that others must be sent for. THUC. vi. 25
*Ou) ga\r pro\ th=s a)lhqei/as timhte/os a)nh/r a man must not be honoured before the truth PLAT. Rep. 595C.
*(Omoi/as fhsi\n a(pa/sas ei)=nai kai\ timhte/as e)x i)/sou Ib. 561C.
*Fra/zontes w(s ou)/ sfi periopte/h e)sti\ h( *(Ella\s a)pollume/nh. HDT. vii.168.
The substantive denoting the agent is here in the dative. ei)mi/ is often omitted.

In the impersonal construction (which is the more common), the verbal is in the neuter of the nominative singular (sometimes plural), with e)sti/ expressed or understood. The expression is equivalent to dei=, (one) must, with the infinitive active or middle of the verb to which the verbal belongs.

This contruction is practically active in sense, and allows transitive verbals to have an object in the same case which would follow their verbs. The agent is generally expressed by the dative, sometimes by the accusative. E.g.
*Tau=ta h(mi=n (or h(ma=s) poihte/on e)sti/, we must do this, equivalent to tau=ta h(ma\s dei= poih=sai.
*Oi)ste/on ta/de we must bear these things EUR. Or. 769
*Peiste/on ta/de (sc. soi/), you must obey in this (=dei= pei/qesqai). SOPH. Ph. 994
*)Apallakte/on au)tou= (tou= sw/matos), kai\ au)th=| th=| yuxh=| qeate/on au)ta\ ta\ pra/gmata (= dei= a)palla/ttesqai au)tou=, kai\ th=| yuxh=| qea=sqai ta\ pra/gmata), we must free ourselves from it (the body), and with the soul itself we must contemplate things themselves. PLAT. Phaed. 66 E.
*Fhmi\ dh\ dixh=| bohqhte/on ei)=nai toi=s pra/gmasisn u(mi=n, I say that you must give assistance in two ways. DEM. i.17.
*Ti/ a)\n au)tw=| poihte/on ei)/h; what would he be obliged to do? XEN. Mem. 1.7,2
*)Eyhfi/santo polemhte/a ei)=nai (= dei=n polemei=n), they voted that they must go to war THUC. i. 88.
*Th=n xw/ran, e)c h(=s au)toi=s o(rmwme/nois polemhte/a h)=n. Id. vi. 50.
*Ou)/te misqoforhte/on a)/llous h\) tou\s strateuome/nous, ou)/te meqekte/on tw=n pragma/twn plei/osin h)\ pentakisxili/ois. Id. viii. 65 (Here both the accusative and the dative of the agent are found: see 926.)
*(Hmi=n de\ cu/mmaxoi a)gaqoi\, ou(\s ou) paradote/a toi=s )Aqhnai/ois e)sti\n, ou)de\ di/kais kai\ lo/gois diakrite/a mh\ lo/gw| kai\ (h(ma=s) au)toi\s blaptome/nous, a)lla\ timwrhte/a e)n ta/xei kai\ panti\ sqe/nei ( = ou(\s ou) dei= h(ma=s paradou=nal, k. t. l.). Id. i. 86
*Ite/on a)\n ei0/h qeasome/nous (sc. h(ma=s), it would be best for us to go and see her. XEN. Mem. iii. 11,1
*)Ou)deni\ tro/pw| fame\n e(ko/ntas a)dikhte/on ei)=nai. PLAT. Crit. 49 A.
*)Ata\r ou) junaikw=n ou)de/pot' e)/sq' h(ttht/ea h(mi=n (= ou) junaikw=n dei= h(tta=sqai), but we must never be beaten by women. AR. Lys. 450
So SOPH. Ant. 678
It will be seen that this construction admits verbals of both transitive and intransitive verbs.
The Latin participle in -dus is used in the same personal construction as the Greek verbal in -te/os; as epistula scribenda est, e)pisto/lh grapte/a e)sti/n, a letter must be written.

The impersonal construction is found in Latin, but generally only with verbs which do not take an object accusative, as Eundum est tibi (i)te/on e)sti/ soi), — Moriendum est omnibus. — Bello utendum est nobis (tw=| pole/mw| xrhste/on e)sti\n h(mi=n), we must employ war See Madvig's Latin Grammar, § 421.
Occasionally the earlier Latin uses even the object accusative, like the Greek, as Aeternas quoniam poenas in morte timendum est, LUCR. i.112
A sentence sometimes begins with an impersonal verbal in -te/on and is continued with an infinitive, the latter depending on dei= implied in the verbal. E.g.

cit.quote: *Pantaxou= poihte/on a(\ a)/n keleu/h| h( po/lis kai\ h( patri\s, h)\ pei/qein au)th/n.

div2.p: The dative and the accusative of the agent are both allowed with the verbal in -te/on (or -te/a), although the equivalent dei= with the infinitive has only the accusative. Thus we can say tou=to h(mi=n poihte/on or tou=to h(ma=s poihte/on, but only tou=to h(ma=s dei= poiei=n.

div2.head: The Relation of the Optative to the Subjunctive and Other Moods.
div2.p: In the chapter on the general view of the moods, no attempt was made to assign to either the subjunctive or the optative a single fundamental idea from which all the uses of the mood could be derived, except so far as the idea of futurity was shown to belong essentially to the subjunctive in all its most primitive uses. It would be impossible to include under one fundamental idea all the actual uses of any mood in Greek, except the imperative; for even the indicative is used to express unfulfilled conditions, unaccomplished wishes, and unattained purposes, none of which can be brought under the ideas of declaration or absolute assertion commonly attributed to this mood. Again, it is not to be expected that the true fundamental idea of any mood should include all its uses in a developed language; for the fortunes of language often depend on causes which are quite independent of the original essence of the forms employed, and which seldom can be referred to invariable laws of thought. The same idea can be expressed in two cognate languages by different moods: as he would have seen is ei)=den a)/n in Greek and vidisset in Latin, while in Sanskrit it would be expressed by a past augmented future equivalent to the Greek e)/mellen o)/yesqai (see § 428). Even within the Greek itself, we have if he were wise expressed by ei) sofo\s ei)/h in Homer and by ei) sofo\s h)=n in Attic; and in Homer, both ou)k a)\n e)/gnws and ou)k a)\n gnoi/hs can mean you would not have discerned, while the latter can mean also you would not discern (in the same future sense as in Attic).

One doctrine of the original meaning of the Greek subjunctive and optative has gained such general approval of late, that it is entitled to special consideration. This teaches that the fundamental idea of the subjunctive is will, and that of the optative is wish. In the subjunctive, the idea of will appears especially in exhortations and prohibitions and in expressions of purpose. It can also be used to explain the subjunctive in protasis, by understanding e)/lqh| in h)\n e)/lqh| to mean originally let him go, suppose him to go (in some case). But before we can decide that will is the fundamental idea of the subjunctive, or even that it is a necessary and essential part of the idea of this mood, we must ask, first, whether it is essential to those uses of the subjunctive which we have a right on other grounds to call the most primitive; and, secondly, whether there is any other idea equally essential and equally primitive, from which the idea of will could have been evolved more simply and naturally than this could have been evolved from the idea of will.

The subjunctive nowhere bears more distinct marks of primitive simplicity than when it appears in Homer as a simple future; as in ou) ga/r pw toi/ous i)/don a)ne/ras ou)de\ i)/dwmai, for never yet have I seen such men, nor shall I ever see them, Il. i. 262, and in kai/ pote/ tis ei)/ph|sin, and some one will say, Il. vi. 459, followed by w(/s pote/ tis e)re/ei in vs. 462, referring to the same thing. See other examples in § 284. In this sense it is negatived by ou), like an indicative; and it may be modified by ke/ or a)/n, like the future indicative in Homer, and thus acquire a potential sense (see § § 285 and 286). It is seldom that any modal form (except a plain indicative) is found so free from associations which might affect its meaning and conceal its original character. It has, moreover, its exact counterpart in Sanskrit in the Vedic subjunctive, which is negatived by na/, the equivalent of ou).See Delbrück, Syntaktische Forschungen, Il. i. (Conjunctiv und Optativ), pp. 23-25. This simple subjunctive has no element of will. It expresses what the speaker regrets as readily as what he is resolved to do. Thus in both the examples above quoted, the subjunctive expresses an act which is decidedly contrary to the speaker's will and wish. This subjunctive and the future indicative run parallel in all their constructions, and the former expresses will only so far as the latter does. The only character that is beyond question in this subjunctive is its reference to future time, and if we were left to this use alone, we should have no hesitation in designating the subjunctive as a form expressing futurity like a future tense. As this use cannot be deduced from the subjunctive as an expression of will, let us see whether the opposite process, the evolution from the simple future meaning of the uses in which will appears, is any easier and does any less violence to the principles of the language.

The use of the subjunctive which strikes every one as coming next in simplicity to the Homeric construction just described is seen in exhortations, like i)/wmen, let us go, and (in its negative form) in prohibitions, like mh\ i)/wmen, let us not go, mh\ ei)/phte tou=to, do not say this. This use of the subjunctive is found also in Sanskrit, and its negative is there generally (though not always) mA, the equivalent of mh/. It thus appears that the marked distinction which is seen in the early Greek between i)/wmen, we shall go, and i)/wmen, let us go, in both positive and negative forms, was probably inherited from an ancestral language, so that we need not seek for the development of this distinction within the Greek itself. It is obvious that the future element is equally strong in both expressions, while the hortatory subjunctive also expresses will. Now it is much more natural to suppose that a future form expressing exhortation or prohibition originated in a form expressing mere futurity, than that the merely future form originated in the exhortation or prohibition. We cannot derive ou)k i)/dwmai, I shall not see, from mh\ i)/dwmai, let me not see. But it is by no means impossible that, in some language which was a common ancestor of Greek, Latin, and Sanskrit, subjunctive (i.e. originally future) forms came to be used to express both commands and prohibitions; that, when these imperative expressions became distinguished from the subjunctive in its ordinary future sense, they adopted the negative (the ancestor of mâ ' and mh/) which was used with similar imperative forms, though this use of the negative might not at first be very rigid; and that thus mh/ i)/wmen, in the sense let us not go, became established in early Greek as opposed to ou)k i)/wmen, we shall not go. In Sanskrit, however, the use of mA/ in such cases was less fixed, and here na/ (the equivalent of ou)) is sometimes found with the subjunctive in prohibitions.See Delbrück, Conjunctiv und Optativ, p. 112. This last is what we should have if in xeiri\ d' ou) fau/seis pote/, you shall never touch me, EUR. Med. 1320, we could substitute an Homeric subjunctive (e.g. yau/sh|s) for the future indicative. The cases of mh/ with the future in prohibitions given in § 70, like mh\ boulh/sesqe ei)de/nai, do not wish to know, DEM. xxiii. 117, are too few to be of much weight in the discussion; but they seem to show an abortive tendency to establish the future indicative with mh/ by the side of the subjunctive in prohibitions. What the future could do in an imperative sense is shown by examples like pa/ntws de\ tou=to dra/seis, but by all means do this, AR. Nub. 1352 , and others quoted in § 69; but the natural negative here was ou), not mh/, as in ou) yau/seis above.

If the origin of the interrogative subjunctive in appeals (§ 287) and of its negative mh/ has been correctly explained in §§ 288 and 291, this is merely an interrogative form of the subjunctive in exhortations and prohibitions, and calls for no special discussion here. The origin of the use of the subjunctive with ou) mh/ is still to uncertain to give this construction much weight in determining the essential character of the subjunctive. If the view of this construction which is advocated in this work (see Appendix II.) is accepted, the form is an offshoot of the prohibitory subjunctive. If it is thought to be an original construction, expressing a strong denial or prohibition by its own force, the subjunctive appears in its original future force. Whatever theory we may have of the origin of this subjunctive, the form is interchangeable in use with the future indicative.

In dependent sentences, the subjunctive is used in two constructions, —in so-called final clauses, and in conditional sentences. In negative final constructions with mh/, the subjunctive was originally prohibitive (§§ 262, 307); in positive clauses with the final particles, it expresses something aimed at, that is, an object of will. But here, as in independent sentences, to derive the more complex from the more simple is far more natural than the reverse. Further, in all final constructions the future indicative may be used in the same sense as the subjunctive; this could hardly be done if the subjunctive contained an essential element of will which is wanting in the future. Again, the subjunctive is very common in final constructions after past tenses, where the optative is the regular form (318); it cannot be supposed that the idea of will is present in such final clauses when they have the subjunctive (as they generally do in Thucydides) and is absent when they have the optative (as is more common in Xenophon). In conditional sentences, although we may explain the subjunctive as originally hortatory, h)\n e)/lqh| meaning let him come (we will suppose), it is more natural to refer this use to the primitive use of the subjunctive as a simple future, ei)/ ken e)/lqh| (or ei) e)/lqh|), in case he shall come, making a supposition of a future event of which the Homeric e)/lqh|, he will come, might make a statement (see §§ 11 and 398). We thus avoid the necessity of explaining the indicative and the subjunctive in protasis on different principles. As each of the various tenses of the indicative with ei) expresses a supposition in the time which it naturally denotes (§ 3, c), so the subjunctive is a natural form to express a future supposition. Thus, as ei) genh/setai tou=to supposes what genh/setai tou=to states, ei) ge/nhtai tou=to naturally supposes what (in the older language) ge/nhtai tou=to, this will happen, states. As the former cannot be explained by the idea of will, it seems unnecessary and illogical to introduce this idea to account for the latter. What has been said of ordinary conditional sentences applies also to relative conditions.

The only use of the subjunctive in conditions which cannot be derived from the simple future meaning is that in general suppositions; but the undeveloped state of this construction in Homer and other considerations make it highly probable, if not certain, that this is a use of the subjunctive which grew up within the Greek language itself at a comparatively late period, and that it is not one of the primitive uses of the mood. (See §§ 11, b, 400, 401.)

It is certain that no trace of the subjunctive as a mood of will can be seen in its actual use in conditional sentences. Thus h)
 th
 po/lin e(/lwsi could always be said as properly by the friends as by the enemies of a city, by the besieged as well as by the besiegers. In Il. iii. 71, o(ppo/tero/s ke nikh/sh|, spoken by Priam, is, as an expression, perfectly neutral as regards the hope or desire of victory. It may be said with truth, that the primitive meaning of a verbal form is apt to be weakened, or even to disappear, in actual use. But is it logical to assume a lost meaning to account for an expression, when the meaning which remains accounts for it satisfactorily without external help? When we find h)
 e(/lwsi th
 po/lin actually expressing a mere future supposition, with no idea of will, in all periods of the language, and when we find e(/lwsi meaning they will capture in the earliest period that we know, why should we assume an original idea of will (which was afterwards lost) in h)
 e(/lwsi to account for its actual meaning? The view of the conditional sentence here adopted is confirmed by paratactic conditions like the following: qu/seis de\ th
 pai=d' : e)/nqa ti/nas eu)xa\s e)rei=s; I. A. 1185, where qu/seis makes a supposition, supposing you shall sacrifice the girl, which would generally be expressed by ei) qu/seis or h)
 qu/sh|s: so a)dikei= tis e(kw/n and e)ch/marte/ tis a)/kwn, both expressing suppositions, DEM. xviii. 274.See C. F. Hermann, de Protasi Paratactica, p. 7.

On these grounds we may feel justified in regarding the subjunctive as originally and essentially a form for expressing future time, which the Greek inherited, with its subdivision into an absolute future negatived by ou) and a hortatory future negatived by mh/, and used in independent sentences.

The name optative mood (e)/gklisis eu)ktikh/), which was invented by grammarians long after the usages of the language were settled, designated the mood by the only use which it then had in independent sentences without a)/n, that of wishing. It is evident that this name in itself is no ground for assuming that wishing was the primitive function, or even an essential function, of the optative, any more than the name of the subjunctive (e)/gklisis u(potaktikh/) would lead us to assume dependence as an original or necessary characteristic of that mood. We have already mentioned the theory that the optative is the mood of wish, as the complement of that which makes the subjunctive the mood of will. This theory finds no support in the potential use of the optative with or without ke/ or a)/n, which is the only independent use of the optative except in wishes and exhortations. Surely a)po/loito a)/n, he would perish, can never have been developed from a)po/loito, may be perish, for the former is no more likely to be said by one who wishes the death of a person than by one who fears it, and there is nothing in the addition of a)/n or ke/ which can reasonably be supposed to change a form, which in itself expresses wish, to a neutral form or even to one expressing what is feared. The fundamental distinction in negative sentences between mh\ a)po/loito and ou)k a)\n a)po/loito (or ou)k a)po/loito) is still more significant. Nor can any support for the theory be found in dependent final constructions or in indirect discourse. No one would see a distinction of will and wish in i)/dh| and i)/doi in e)/rxetai i(/na i)/dh| tou=to and h)=lqen i(/na i)/doi tou=to, or in fobou=mai mh\ e)/lqh| and e)fobh/qhn mh\ e)/lqoi,—not to speak of h)=lqen i(/na i)/doi tou=to and h)=lqen i(/na i)/dh| tou=to. Still less would any one dream of looking for wish in the optative in ei)=pen o(/ti e)/lqoi, he said that he had come, or in h)/reto ei)/ tis ei)/h sofw/teros. In all these dependent constructions, the optative is only the representative of the subjunctive or indicative when these are, as it were, transferred to the past by depending on a verb of past time; but, if wish were the fundamental idea of the optative, we should hardly expect this to vanish so utterly, since the essential character of the optative would naturally be especially marked where it is used by a fixed principle of the language as a substitute for an indicative or a subjunctive.

The only strong argument for the theory that the optative is primarily the mood of wish is found in the optative with ei) in protasis. It is maintained that a gradual development of this conditional form from the simple optative in a wish can be actually seen in Homer. The strongest and most attractive statement of this argument is given by Lange in his elaborate, but unfortunately unfinished, treatise on the particle ei) in Homer.Der Homerische Gebrauch der Partikel EI, von Ludwig Lange, des vi. Bandes der Abhandlungen der philologisch-historischen Classe der Königl. Sächsischen Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften No. 4. Lange himself, nevertheless, believes the optative to be originally the mood of Einbildungskraft, not of wish. Delbrück's treatment of the optative in his Syntaktische Forschungen, vol. i., is based on this doctrine. When Lange states (p. 485) that, of 200 examples of ei) with the optative in Homer, 136 are expressions of wish, the majority seems decisive; although we may even here withhold our judgment until we examine the majority and also see what the minority of 64 have to say. The majority of 136 is made up as follows:—

1. Ordinary wishes with ei) ga/r, ei)/qe (ai)\ ga/r, ai)/qe), or ei), like ai)/q' ou(/tws, *eu)/maie, fi/los *dii\ patri\ ge/noito, Od. xiv. 440; ai)\ ga\r ou(/tws ei)/h, Il. iv. 189; ei)/q' w(\s h(bw/oimi, bi/h de/ moi e)/mpedos ei)/h, Il. xi. 670. (Of these there are 38 cases.)

2. Cases in which a wish with ei) and the optative (like the expressions just quoted) is followed by an apodosis expressing a consequence which would follow the fulfilment of the wish. Thus the last example in 1 appears in Il. vii. 157 with such an apodosis:—
ei)/q' w(\s h(bw/oimi, bi/h de/ moi e)/mpedos ei)/h: tw=| ke ta/x' a)nth/seie ma/xhs koruqai/olos *(/ektwr.

If we put a comma at the end of the first verse, we have a full conditional sentence. In many cases it is doubtful which punctuation is correct. Lange includes under this head even such sentences as Il. vii. 28, a)ll' ei)/ moi/ ti pi/qoio, to/ ken polu\ ke/rdion ei)/h, and Od. xx. 381. (Of these there are 28 cases.)

3. Ordinary conditional sentences, in which the fusion between the optative with ei) expressing a wish (i.e. supposing something that is desired) and a following apodosis with ke/ or a)/n is said to be complete, as in Il. xiii. 485:—
ei) ga\r o(mhliki/h ge genoi/meqa tw=|d' e)pi\ qumw=|, ai)=ya/ ken h)e\ fe/roito me/ga kra/tos h)/ ke feroi/mhn.
(Of these there are 19 cases, against 18 otherwise similar cases in which the optative with ei) supposes something not desired.)
4. Cases of which the following are examples:—
h)/luqon, ei)/ tina/ moi klhhdo/na patro\s e)ni/spois, Od. iv. 317. pa/pthnen d' a)na\ pu/rgon *)axaiw=n, ei)/ tin' i)/doito h(gemo/nwn, o(/s ti/s oi( a)rh\n e(ta/roisin a)mu/nai, Il. xii. 333.
Such examples are variously explained, but the protasis generally refers to something that is desired. (Of these there are 43 cases.)

5. Ordinary conditional sentences in which ei) with the optative expressing a wish follows an apodosis; as in Il. xxii. 20, h)= s' a)\n tisai/mhn, ei)/ moi du/nami/s ge parei/h. These differ from those in 3 only in the position of the protasis. (Of these there are 8 cases of wishes, against 33 in which no wish is implied, of which last 17 are concessive.)

The minority of 64 examples, in which ei) with the optative does not express a wish, is made up of the 18 dissenting cases under 3, the 33 under 5 which contain no wishes, 5 exceptional cases (as Lange views them) under 4 (2 with doubtful readings), and 8 cases of w(s ei) with the optative in similes, like i)/san w(s ei)/ te puri\ xqw\n pa=sa ne/moito, Il. ii. 780.

It will be seen that the strength of the argument lies in the gradual development of the optative conditional sentence which is supposed to appear in 1, 2, and 3. This is further enforced by reference to cases in which the simple optative in a wish (without any form of ei)) is followed by an apodosis, like the equivalent optatives with ei) in 2, thus showing the absence of a conditional force in the latter. See Od. xv. 180:—
ou(/tw nu=n *zeu\s qei/h, e)ri/gdoupos po/sis *(/hrhs: tw=| ke/n toi kai\ kei=qi qew=| w(\s eu)xetow/|mhn.
Since the two clauses are grammatically independent here, it is argued that they must be equally so in the examples in 2.
